title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/Jack Manning

title: Washout in Alcan Hihgway
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that part of the Alcan Highwaythe main road link between Alaska and the continental United Stateshad been washed out. The Alcan Highway is washed out due to torrential rains between Fort Nelson and Watson Lake in Canada, the department said. Travelers should anticipate delays up to two weeks.

title: WIDER GAP SEEN IN PROFIT ON OIL
description: The First National City Bank said yesterday that the oil companies socalled capital gap has not only persisted but widened despite sharply increased earnings In 1973 and 1974.

title: Young Berry Pickers Upset by U.S. Law
description: OREGON CITY, Ore.One moment the road is quiet and sedate like most suburban streets before 7 A.M. But suddenly the pavement is clogged with scores of bicycles in a bizarre, adolescent rush hour.

title: JUSTIN BIJUR 64, DIES, EXMACY EXECUTIVE
description: ELBERON, N.J., June 30 Sustin Bijur, a former executive of Macy's died today at the Monmouth Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived at 876 Elberon Avenue.

title: Chase Venture in Iran
description: LONDON, June 30 (UPI) The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Industrial Credit Bank of Iran have agreed to form a new joint banking venture called the International Bank of Iran, it was announced today. Chase and the Industrial Credit Bank will control 35 per cent each of the shares with the remaining 30 per cent to be sold to Iranian shareholders.

title: Miyama's Herd and Jazz in Japan
description: TOKYO, June 30Miyama and His New Herd, which brings a combination of the essence of jazz and traditional Japanese music and culture to the Newport Jazz Festival in New York tonight, is one of several major jazz bands in Japan.

title: Serling Memorial Monday
description: ITHACA, N. Y. June 30 (UPI) A memorial service for Rod Serling will be held next Monday at Cornell University's Sage Chapel. Dean John Keshishoglou of Ithaca College's School of Communications said the service would begin at 2 P.M. Mr. Serling had been, a visiting professor at Ithaca College, across town from Cornell. The 50yearold writer and producer, best known for the Twilight Zone series he created for television, died Saturday at Strong Memorial Hospital fin Rochester. He had Suffered a heart attack while undergoing 10 hours of openheart surgery Thursday.

title: National League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES New York 5, Chicago 1. Cincinnati 9, Houston 6 (12 inn).

title: People in Sports
description: Making their eighth coaching change in the last eight years, the Detroit Red Wings yesterday named Doug Barkley, to succeed Alex Delvecchlo, who will devote fulltime to his job as general manager of the National Hockey Leaeue team.

title: Election in Cape Verde Islands is Smooth and Turnout is Big
description: The party says that a big turnout today will constitute an endorsement of union with GuineaBissau. The party says that opposition to that union among wealthier Cape Verdian melted after two general strikes and riots in support of the party.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Los AngelesRandy Shields, 136, North Hollywood, Calif., outpointed Centavito Hernandez, 138, Mexico, 10.

title: Vietnamese Admits Security Problem Of Armed Holdouts
description: BONN, June 30The President of the National Liberation Front in South Vietnam, in an interview with the German news magazine Der Spiegel, has admitted that the new government in Saigon has security problems in the form of continuing armed resistance by soldiers of the defeated regime.

title: N.F.L. Says 8 Clubs Lost Money in '74
description: Eight of its teams lost money last season, the National Football League announced yesterday through its Management Council. The financial report was disputed by the players union, which called it a subterfuge to allow the league to drop four nlavers from each team.

title: DETENTE SCORED BY SOLZHENITSYN
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Aleltsandr I. Solzhenitsyn bitterly assailed the Soviet Union tonight and said that the United States was being duped by Moscow's efforts at furthering detente.

title: Food Stamp Rolls Drop; Officials Unsure of Cause
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Enrollment in the food stamp program declined slightly in May for the first time since the recession began driving unemployment up to its current level of 9.2 per cent.

title: Energy Development Plan Offers Priorities for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Government published today a new energy development plan that assigns more money to solar energy and to conservation but also asserts with new force the Administration's continuing view that top priorities must go to coal and harnessing the energy of the atom.

title: Market Place
description: This promises to be an active year for redemption of convertible securities. The runup in stock prices has caused companies to choose redemption as a means of reducing fixed interest and dividend costs.

title: James V. Lione Dies at 78; Former Attorney for R.E.A.
description: James V. Lione, a retired lawyer who was general attorney for the Railway Express Agency for many years and served briefly as a Queens City Court and Civil Court judge in 1962, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 215.29 28th Avenue. Bayside.

title: Garbagemen's Security Turns to Ashes
description: Do you think we like to pick up garbage? We took this job for security, said Jim Governale, one of 55 sanitationmen in District 38 in Brooklyn who refused to work yesterday to protest the city's dismissal of employes.

title: Edison's Films on the Revolution Will Play Again for Bicentennial
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J.Thomas Alva Edison's pioneering Kinetbscope films on the Revoluionary War are being dusted off at the inventor's old laboratory here for reproduction and distribution to schools around the state next year as part of the Bicentennial celebration.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Sharp opposition to a pending proposal to designate 57th Street as a local access interchange road to be used by trucks between a future West Side interstate highway and the Queensboro Bridge was expressed yesterday by two merchants groups and Representative Edward 1. Koch. The executive vice president of the Fifth Avenue Association, Michael B. Grosso, writing also on behalf of the 57th Street Association, asked State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler in a letter to help the groups' efforts to rid 57th Street of truck traffic which, he said, depressed property values and was a nuisance for residents and merchants alike.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Suite No: 1, Muffat; Concerto for Oboe and Violin, Bach; Le Ballet des Ages, Campra.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: 2 Held in Quebec Kidnaping
description: SHERBROOKE, Que., June 30 (UPI)Two brothers were arraigned today on kidnaping charges in the abduction of Lena Blanchet, wife of a Quebec millionaire, held in drugged captivity five days for a $1million ransom. Fernand Beland, 37, and his brother, JeanMarc, 25, pleaded not guilty.

title: Thai Moslems, Oppressed Minority, Strive to Find Way in Secular World
description: PATTANI, ThailandThe Malay Moslem minority, long the target of discrimination and persecution, is struggling to adapt to a modern world that still does not accept it while trying to retain the values it has jealously guarded in an alien land for 700 years.

title: Indian Complaint Denied As the F.B.I. Seeks Killers
description: OGLALA, S.D., June 30 (UPI) The F.B.I. denied today Indian charges that officers were using heavyhanded tactics in their search for the killers of two agents slain on the Pine ???rute Reservation.

title: Endurance Tested In 2 New Dances By Ailey Workshop
description: Alvin Ailey's long association with Clark Center almost predicted that the young Alvin Ailey Repertory Workshop would make its first appearance in Manhattan under the center's sponsorship. The group is eager, energetic and willing to try to wring the most from any piece it attempts. On Sunday evening at the City University Graduate Center Mall on 42d street it showed two new dances and two from the senior Ailey company's repertory.

title: U.N.INQUIRYURGED ON CHILE'S WOMEN
description: MEXICO CITY, June 30Hortensia Bussi de Allende, the widow of Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile, called on the United Nations today to sponsor a committee of women to investigate what she termed crimes of the fascist junta in Chile especially crimes against women.

title: 7 BRIDGES REMAIN IN CLOSED POSITION
description: In a surprise turnabout that reversed a decision announced earlier in the day, the city said last night that seven drawbridges to be left untended as a result of layoffs would be left in closed positions. Thus, vehicular trairic wouia continue to flow but navigation would he blocked on the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, Newtown Creek between Brooklyn and Queens and Dutch Kills Creek in Queens.

title: Advertising
description: Although it was their day off yesterday, the cast of the musical A Chorus Line arrived early at the Newman Theater down on Lafayette Street. They'd be spending the day tlitre shooting a commercial.

title: John Akar, Actor, Writer And Sierra Leone Envoy
description: John Akar, an actor who was Ambassador to the United States in 1969 and High Commissioner to Canada and Jamaica in 1970 from his native Sierra Leone, died June 23 of a heart ailment in Jamaica, where he lived. His age was 48.

title: Malpractice Coverage Goes On As Argonaut Pulls Out of State
description: Malpractice insurance coverage in New York State by the Argonaut Insurance Company ceased at 12:01 A.M. today without a crisis, as doctors and hospitals acquired coverage from the mutual company set up under the auspices of the Medical Society of the State of New York or from the joint underwriting association of private companies set up by state law.

title: PEKING SAYS SOVIET COVETS SOUTH ASIA
description: PEKING, June 30 China charged tonight that the Soviet Union's ambitions threatened peace in Southeast Asi?.

title: Police Shove 10 Youths in Chinatown Demonstratiop
description: At least 10 young demonstrators were clubbed to the ground by poke officers outside the Fifth Precinct station house on Elizabeth Street in Chinatown last night after they refused to allow a patrol car to move down the street.

title: U.S. AID TO STATE EXPECTED TO DROP
description: Governor Carey disclosed yesterday that Federal aid for social services in the state was scheduled to drop from $220.5million in the fiscal year just ended to $217.5million in the coming year because the state's share of national population is declinine.

title: Father and Son
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanThe symbolism of the largerthanlife painting on the wall of the Premier's uncluttered office is too tempting to resist. Father and son, alone on the windy beach: Chiang Kaishek, austere in a long mandarin tunic, gazes through visionfilled eyes to the distant mainland of China; Chiang Chingkuo, hands stuffed casually in the pockets of a battered brown leather jacket, has dropped his glance to the rocky land on which they stand.

title: Ali Beats Bugner
description: Muhammad Ad scored a 15round decision over Joe Bugner in their heavyweight title fight in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Details, Page 23.

title: Tower Was Urged to Shift Runways Before Jet Crash
description: Eight minutes before the Eastern Airlines crash at Kennedy International Airport last Tuesday, the pilot of another jet twice urged that the runway being used be changed because he had encountered a treacherous shift of air currents just before landing, according to tapes made public yesterday. The crash left 112 people dead, making it the nation's worst singleaircraft disaster.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It happens to all of us at one time or anotheran heirloom or expensive glass chipped, a figurine or bowl broken, a decanter stopper lost. The answer is not wails, despair, or the garbage can; it's a place called Gem Monogram & Cut Glass Corporation, a firm that's been mending cracks and shatters for almost four decades.

title: School Officials Weigh Changes if State Slashes Aid
description: ALPINE, June 30Perplexed by daily mercurial budget developments in Trenton and not knowing what precisely to react to, some Bergen County officials talked today of dropping an entire month of school, eliminating teaching positions and extracurricular programs and possibly charging tuition for summer school.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Jules Lederer, who under the pen name of Ann Landers offers advice on personal problems to millions of newspaper readers, announced in her column today that she and her husband of 36 years would be divorced.

title: 21 County School Superintendents Get Dismissal Notices Effective on Monday
description: TRENTON. June 30  School superitendents from all of New Jersey's 21 counties were auintoiled here today by Education Commissioner Fred G. Butte to discuss termination of theiremployment and closing of their offices effective next Monday. They were among first victims of Governor Byrne's announced $384million in budgetary cutbacks.

title: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at MilwaukeeDobson (86) vs. Colborn (26).

title: The Summer Of 39
description: That summer we played step ball until dark and ate fried fish for supper and, afterwards, hung out at Sommers confectionary store. Schmidt, whose old man had money, bought himself a milkshake two or three times a week to put on weight for football, and we would go inside and watch him drink it and listen to Frank Sinatra on the juke box and argue about Hitler.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, June 30, 1975 Pelltion flied by;

title: Byrne Cuts Off the Salary Of DeRose's Harbor Post
description: TRENTON, June 30 (UPI)Governor Byrne today cut off the $30,500 salary of Ralph C. DeRose, the New Jersey member of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, who works parttime in the job.

title: 4Run Met 8th Beats Cubs, 51
description: Strong pitching by George Stone and a fourrun uprising in the eighth inning gave the Mets a 51 victory over the Cubs at Shea Stadium last light and saved the beleagured Met bull pen au evening's work.

title: SUSLOV CRITICIZES U.S. OVER DETERE
description: MOSCOW. June 30A Soviet leader told a delegation of American Senators today that detente between the two nations was threatened and that American action in a number of areas was needed to correct the situation.

title: Indian Boiler
description: It is now almost a week since Prime Minister Indira Gandhi blotted out democracy and democratic freedoms at least temporarily in her country. It must be conceded that Mrs. Gandhi's boldness has seemed to pay off handsomely from her point of viewthus far. By declaring a state of emergency, arresting hundreds or thousands of key figures in the opposition, and effectively muzzling India's hitherto lively press, she has won peace a sort familiar in authoritarian societies.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Indian policemen shot and killed several antiGovernment demonstrators during disorders in the eastern state of Bihar, travelers from Bihar said in New Delhi yesterday. Bihar is the political stronghold of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's most powerful political opponent, Jaya Prakash Narayan. No confirmation of the reports of the killings was forthcoming from the central Government in New Delhi, which canceled without explanation a news conference that had been scheduled. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Interest Rates Up
description: As the Municipal Assistance Corporation and Massachusetts sold $1.45billion of bonds yesterday in one of the most active sales days in the taxexempt market's history, the credit markets continued to sink.

title: Jazz Events
description: Noon to 2 P.M., Equitable Life Plaza, Avenue of the Americas and 51st Street: Lionel Hampton and His Orchestra (free).

title: Maverick State is Wary Of New Delhi's Next Step
description: AHMADABAD, India, June 30Here in the state of Gujarat, unlike in other parts of India, political opponents of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi have not been arrested.

title: Portugal Dismisses Her U.N. Delegate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30Portugal has ordered her chief delegate here, Jose Veiga Simko, to relinquish all official duties following a speech in which he made a thinly veiled attack on Lisbon's military leaders as suppressing civil liberties.

title: Red Sox in Split; Pitcher is Injured
description: The Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles, 52, in the first game of a doubleheader last night in Fenway Park, but it was a costly victory. Dick Pole, who held the Orioles to four hits through eight innings, was struck in the face by a line drive and was taken to a hospital.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jung 30 (AP)The agency charged with keeping an eye on inflation for the Government said today it is beginning an investigation into the rising costs of farm machinery and equipment.

title: N.C.A.A. Hearing Off
description: EAST LANSING, MicrJune 30 (AP)The National Collegiate Athletic Association has postponed for a second time its hearing into alleged violations of Michigan State's football recruiting program, university officials said today. No new dare was set. The. N.C.A.A. gave no reason for the delay, according to the university.

title: BraffBarnes Quartet Upstages Two Big Bands
description: The Newport Jazz Festival, which has eight big bands on tap this year, presented the first two, Buddy Rich's and Harty James's, on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall. But although Mr. Rich's band is representative or the aggressively virtuosic presentday big jazz ensembles, and Mr. James's group typifies the steamroller power of the swingera bands, they were both upstaged by a foursome, the Ruby BraffGeorge Barnes Quartet, which slipped into the program between the two bands.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Richard J. Vizzini, right, of the firemen's union; Victor Gotbaum, center, of the municipal employes, and Ken McFeeley, facing camera at left, of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, with others yesterday in Albany as Mayor. Beame talked with State Senators on the city's problems.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS RIGHT OF SUSPECT TO REFUSE LAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that a competent person accused of a crime has a constitutional right to refuse professional legal assistance and conduct his own defense.

title: Ford Pledges to Resist the Third World in the U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, June 30President Ford declared today that the United States would resist efforts of thirdworld countries to exploit the machinery of the United Nations for narrow political interests. han was sworn in as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: Deaths
description: ALBERTSarah. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Ruth Appelbaum. Grace Gelfand and Irving Albert. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Dear sister of Anna Simon, Abraham Tamor and Eva Fink and the late David Tamor. ServIces Tuesday, 10:15 A.M. The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Failure of Compromise Near, State Senate Moves on School Bill
description: ALBANY, Tuesday, July 1With only minutes to go in New York City's fiscal year, Warren M. Anderson, the Republican Senate majority leader, suddenly set aside his own bill in the final rollcall and resumed negotiations with Governor Carey and Mayor Beame in search of a compromise on the twin problems of new city taxes and statewide school aid.

title: Heavy Bidding Marks Latest U.S. Gold Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 30, (Reuters)The United States Government was swamped with about 750 bids from dealers, bankers and American citizens today for 500,000 ounces offered at the Treasury's second gold auction in six months.

title: Language Ability Found In Right Side of the Brain
description: F. A new optical device that allows scientists to communicate visually with either hemisphere of the brain has shown that the right hemisphere of an adult. once thought to lack much lauguage ability, has the vocabulary of a 14yearold and the syntactical ability of a 5yearold.

title: News Sumniary and Index
description: Indian policemen shot and killed several antiGovernment demonstrators during disorders in the eastern state of Bihar, travelers from Bihar said in New Delhi yesterday. Bihar is the political stronghold of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's most powerful political opponent, Jaya Prakash Narayan. No confirmation of the reports of the killings was forthcoming from the central Government in New Delhi, which canceled without explanation a news conference that had been scheduled. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: ExJustice on Trial in Scheme To Abet Union Embezzling
description: A retired justice of the State Supreme Court and the chief clerk of the criminal term of Brooklyn Supreme Court went on trial in a Federal Ciurt in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of abetting an alleged union embezzlement scheme by accepting money from pension funds for conventionjunketing expenses.

title: PERUVIANS DECREE MAJOR PRICE RISE
description: LIMA, Peru, June 30 (UPI)The Peruvian Government announced a series of sweeping economic measures today, including acrosstheboard price increases of up to 50 per cent on basic consumer items.

title: Security Heavy For Title Bout
description: KUALA I.UMPUR, Malaysia, Tuesday July 1 (AP)Some 1,800 police officers guarded Ivlerdeka Stadium today for Muhammad Ali's heavyweight title defense against Joe Bugner of Britain.

title: Scalpers at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (Reuters)Some tennis fans paid 10 times the official price to see today's women's quarterfinals at the Wimbledon tennis championship. Seats worth $10 were sold for $100 by scalpers.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Attendance, 19,468. Track parimutuel handle, $2,650,758. OTB handle, $1,520,456.

title: Harry Morris, Set Record For Navy Enlisted Service
description: SAN DIEGO, June 30 (AP)7 Harry Morris, who was on active duty in the Navy longer than any other enlisted man in history, died last night at 87.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: I am the clerk. Nobody else is here. They are all in jail.

title: ZAMBIAN LEADERS NATIONALIZE LAND
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 30President Kenneth Kaunda announced today a series of sweeping nationalization steps and other measures aimed at aiding Zambia's ailing economy and curbing a rapidly growing capitalist class.

title: Walker Runs a 3:52.2 Mile And 5 Others Better 3:55
description: STOCKHOLM, June 30 (AP) John Walker, New Zealand's middledistance star, ran a mile in 3 minutes 52.2 seconds today, highlighting the first day of a two day international track and field meet.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Assembly last night passed a bill extending New Jersey's wiretap law for three years. The measure, which passed by a vote of 614, was sent to Governor Byrne, who immediately signed it into law. New Jersey's present wiretap law expired at midnight. The new law will expire July 1, 1978.

title: Summer Schools In City to Undergo Drastic Cutback
description: The Board of Education's summer high schools will be able to enroll only 11,000 students, 45,000 fewer than last year, in six schools, 17 fewer than last summer.

title: Goldin Puts Hidden Deficit At Possibly $600Million
description: A hidden city deficit of $292million found in a state auditdisclosed Sunday couldmount to as much as $600million, according to a confidential report by City Controller Harrison J. Goldin on how to reform New York's budgetary practices. The deficit was attributed to the city's having overestimated anticipated Federal and state aid.

title: OCCUPANCY BEGINS IN QUEENS HOUSING
description: After nearly four years of construction punctuated by a bitter dispute that drew national attention, the Forest Hills lowincome housing development quietly received its first families yesterday.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.) FIRST$7,000, pace, mile.

title: Tower Was Urged to Shift Runways Before Jet Crash
description: Eight minutes before the Eastern Airlines crash at Kennedy International Airport last Tuesday, the pilot of another jet twice urged that the runway being used be changed because he had encountered a treacherous shift of air currents just before landing, according to tapes made public yesterday. The crash left 112 people dead, making it the nation's worst singleaircraft disaster.

title: M'GOVERN IS SEEKING ALLIES IDEAS ON 76
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) Senator George McGovern of South Dakota is conducting a poll of influential political allies to learn how they feel about, suggestions that he seek the Democratic Presidential nomination again in 1976.

title: 480 Road Deaths Foreseen
description: CHICAGO, June 30 (UPI) The National Safety Council predicted today that 480 to 500 persons would be killed in traffic accidents during the threeday Fourth of July weekend.

title: Pioneer in Use of LDopa To Join Sloan Cancer Unit
description: Dr. George C. Cotzias, who pioneered in the use of the drug LDopa to alleviate the symptoms of Parkinson's disease, will join the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center today to do research on the possible effects of LDopa on cancer.

title: People and Business
description: When the EuropeanAmericap Bank and rust Company took over the aroubled Franklin National Bank, it found a management vacuum. Yesterda it moved to fill the space by naming Klaus Jacobs, a 41yearold German trained banker, to be president, switching him from his post of vice chairman, The announcement was made by H. E. Ekblom, chairman, who continues as chairman and chirf executive officer.

title: BUTZ TO PROPOSE GRAIN TRADE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz will propose to Congress a cooperative Federalstate system to tighten inspection procedures in an attempt to elminate alleged corruption in the grainexport trade of the United States, Government sources said today.

title: Ali Still Calls Bugner The Future Champion
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Tuesday, July 1 (UPI) Muhammed Ali still had three more minutes to go before he would finish his chore with Joe Bugner this morning. He leaned over the ropes and shouted to Joe Frazier: You're next. Be ready!

title: Living in New york: The Homing Instinct
description: From the beginning it was ordained: Angelo T. Cometa would become a New Yorker. He would do it the hard way, by scrambling, and then, when the city was dropping into his hands like a rich pasta, he would leave it. He would have to; he would be broke.

title: Immigration Official is Seized In Plot Aiding Chinese Aliens
description: NEWARK, June 30 The thirdranking official in the New Jersey office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service was indicted here today on charges of taking bribes to give permanent residence status to waiters at Chinese restaurantsthree of which he ownedwho were in the United States illegally.

title: Music: 3d Rug Concert Season Ends
description: Nobody has adequately explained the overwhelming success of the New York Philharmonic's Rug Concerts, but the third season of the series, which closed, on Sunday night underscored the informal format's basic appeal Pierre Boulez conducted a 70member orchestra in a program whose climax and conclusion was a glistening performance of Stravinsky's Petrushka, complete and in the original version of 1911, with its doubled winds and oriental richness of instrumental color.

title: SHELL OIL RAISES GASOLINE 3 CENTS
description: The Shell Oil Company has increased prices effective today for automobile gasoline, distillates and jet fuel, it was announced yesterday by James B. Henderson, the company's vice president  oil products. The rises. include 3 cents a gallon for auto fuel, 1 cent per gallon for distillates and 1.25 cents for jet fuel. Mr. Henderson said they were made in accordance with Federal Energy Administration regulations.

title: Met Museum Asks $1.75 Voluntary Fee
description: In response to higher operating costs and a drop in endowment income, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is asking its patrons to increase their voluntary admission fees to $1.75 from $1.50, as of today. People 65 and older and children under 12 will still be admitted free, wih the suggested fee for students remaining at 50 cents.

title: KOREAN REDS BEAT TWO U.S. SOLDIERS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 30 (UPI)  More than a dozen North Korean guards punched and kicked an American officer and a woman sergeant today outside a building in the truce compound of Panmunjom where the Korean Military Armistice Commission was meeting.

title: Seat Price on Big Board Up $2,000
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported two new records yesterday. An exchange seat sold at a new 1975 high of $130,000, up $2,000 from the last sale on June 26. Secondquarter trading volume set a new quarterly high of 1.35 billion shares, up from the former record set in the first quarter when volume reached 1.31 billion shares.

title: Today's Entries at Bowie
New Idea in Vacations: Learning to Play Tennis Well
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C.Americans are rushing to tennis camps in record numbers this year, often as a substitute for a more traditional vacation.

title: Sikes and 11 in Navy Said to Hold Stock In Bank on Base
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., June 30 (AP)  Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, and 11 Navy officers, are listed as stockholders in the first and only private bank ever established on the grounds of a United States Navy base. The St. Petersburg Times reports.

title: Chess:
description: OBERLIN, Ohio  Samuel Reshevsky, going into the 11th round of the 1975 United States championship, needed a victory badly if he was to overtake the leaders. Walter Browne was a point ahead of him and Kenneth Rogoff had a halfpoint edge on the second of the two places that qualify for the Interzonal tournament, the next stage for world championship aspirants.

title: New Device Finds Farthest Galaxy
description: Using a revolutioncry observing system that cancels the glow of the night sky, a California astronomer has shown that a blurry spot north of the Pleiades is the most distant galaxy yet discovered.

title: Miss Evert, Mrs. King Gain Semifinals
description: WIMBLEDON, England, Stine 30It was the day for the old champions at Wimbledon, the greats of yesteryear.

title: Jobs, Skilled and Unskilled, Go Begging in Many Cities
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30Help Wanted.

title: Dr. Merritt Stiles, 75, Dies; Headed U.S. Ski Association
description: PRIEST LAKE, Idaho, June 30 (AP)Dr. Merritt N. Stiles, an advocate of skiing for the elderly, died yesterday all his summer home here. He was 75 years old.

title: JULIE RIPLEY FORMAN
description: Julie Ripley Forman, cofounder, director emeritus and a trustee of the Forman School, a coeducational preparatory school in Litchfield, Conn., died Sunday at her home in Litchfield. She was 73 years old.

title: The New York Times
description: The New York Times

title: Archer Daniels Midland Agrees to Acquire Tabor
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the principal stockholders of Tabor & Co. of Decatur, ill., to acquire that company for approximately 1 million shares of Archer Daniels Midland stock valued at more than $32million.

title: Energy Development Plan Offers Priorities for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Government published today a new energy development plan that assigns more money to solar energy and to conservation but also asserts with new force the Administration's continuing view that top priorities must go to coal and harnessing the energy of the atom. A national plan for energy research, development and demonstration, ordered by Congress, was made public by. the Energy Research and. Development Administration. Following a 10minute briefing by Robert C. Seamans, Jr., the agency administrator, President Ford said:

title: New Year's Resolutions
description: Querulous and confused, New York today enters a new fiscal year and era that pose an unprecedented challenge to the capacity of New Yorkers to cooperate and even to make some sacrificefor the city's salvation.

title: Oil Consumption is Down
description: THE HAGUE (UPI)Offlcial statistics showed consumption of oil products in the Netherlands last, year dropped more than 12 per cent compared with 1973, Deliveries on the home market totaled 22,2 million tons in 1974, as against 25.4 million tons in 1973.

title: Grace Note
description: Some New York stories have an upbeat endingeven some stories involving money. What seemed like a particularly long shot, the saving of the Gothic Revival houses on Fourth Avenue owned by Grace Church, is now a reality. The necessary sum has now been raised for the church to provide the kind of school facilities that will use rather than destroy the buildings historic facades. Great credit is due to those who, when the prospects seemed blackest, pitched in to raise and contribute to the building fund.

title: N.A.A.C.P.TOWEIGH JOB RIGHTS ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the organized labor movement, two traditional friends in support of civil rights, appear headed for a confrontation in the N.A.A.C.P. convention here this week over the issue of job seniority.

title: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr.
description: The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr.

title: Contract Awards
description: Governmental agencies have awarded a number of contracts for more than $100million each and several smaller ones, it was revealed yesterday. Those receiving the large awards were Air Products & Chemicals, Inc., Avondale Shipyards, Inc., and the Aerospace Corporation.

title: Plan to Sell Washington Star is Denied
description: Newbold Noyes, a board member of the company that controls The Washington Star, has denied in a letter to the editor of The Star that the board apparently favors closing down the newspaper.

title: Edison's Fihns on the Revolution Will Play Again for Bicentennial
description: WEST ORANGE. N. J.Thoinas Alva Edison's pioneering Kirietcrscope films on the Revolutionary War are being dusted off at the inventor's Old faboratory here for reproduction and distribution to schools around the state next year as part of the Bicentennial celebration.

title: WILLIAMS LISTENS TO PLEAS BY AGED
description: NEWARK, June 30United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., ranking member of a special Senate committee on the aging, heard officeholders and the elderly plead today for greater Federal assistance to those squeezed between fixed incomes of pensions and Social Security and the rising cost of living.

title: COMPANY REPORTS
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: Amex and OTC Stocks Climb; Market Index Rises 0.46 Point
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market rose yesterday for the ninth consecutive session. Volume, however, was off on both markets.

title: Holyoke College Fills Post
description: BOSTON, June 30 (AP)The Speaker of the Massachusetts House, David M. Bartley, was named president of Holyoke Community College today, the Board of Regional Community Colleges announced. The board president, William Dwyer, said that Mr. Bartley would take office July 21.

title: ARTHUR J. NEPPEL JR.
description: Arthur J. Neppel Jr., a senior captain for Pan American World Airways, died Sunday in New York Hospital, apparently of a stroke. He was 57 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: DeLury,AfterCourtLoss, Says Strike Is Inevitable
description: John J. DeLury, the sanitation union president, warned yesterday that a garbage strike was inevitable today after his union had failed in a lastditch court effort to keep the financially pressed city from laying off 2,934 men.

title: Jobs, Skilled and Unskilled, Go Begging in Many Cities
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30Help Wanted.

title: Index Slides to 81.9 From 83.9 Figure
description: Weekly steel production fell in the week ended June 28 below the 2 millionton level for the first time since the week ended Dec. 25, 1971, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: 5 Are Killed and 10 Injured By Gas Leak in Ohio Plant
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30 (UPI)  At least five persons were killed and 10 injured today at the Inland Products, Inc., plant here when they became trapped in a well and apparently inhaled a lethal dose of leaking sewer gas.

title: With Rival Parties Leaderless, Political Opposition Grows Dim
description: NEW DELHI, June 30When a reporter telephoned the headquarters of the bestorganized Indian opposition party today, a voice answered:

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Columbia Gets 5,000 World War I Posters
description: World War I posters from a collection of almost 5.000 that survived two world wars, Nazi looting and 26 years in the basement of a West Side apartment house, have been put on display at Columbia University.

title: Beirut Radio Says Cabinet is Formed; Fighting Continues
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, July 1The Government radio and television said yesterday that a Cabinet of prominent Moslems and Christians had been formed to halt factional fighting in which hundreds of people have been killed since April.

title: Books of The Times
description: Over the nation's radios, President Franklin D. Roosevelt read a parable. It was the story of an old clergyman, troubled in a Christmastime of war and hate, and how he then recalled that even poor Judas Iscariot had shared in the last supper. Not even to Judas, the betrayer, was the wine of life denied, the dominie exulted. He had found Christmas once more he heard the voice of the herald angels.

title: 5 NURSING HOES CLOSED BY STATE
description: The number of nursing homes in New York listed as providing substandard care rose from 34 in May to 40 in June, the State Health Department reported yesterday.

title: Boy Meets Gin for $350,000
description: John Nerud, the Nebraska farmboy who made a fortune training race horses for millionaires credited his father with pointing, him in the right direction.

title: MRS. PERON FACES GROWING UNREST
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 30Strikes erupted throughout Argentina again today to protest the Government's economic austerity measures and to press trade union leaders into taking a firm stand against President Isabel Martinez de Pern and Jose Lopez Rega, the rightist strongman of her Cabinet.

title: Yugoslavia Granted Loan
description: WASHINGTON (AP)Yugosiavia was granted 5120million in loans by the World Bank for development of electric power and agricultural projects.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games and the Standings
description: OAKLAND (A.) CHICAGO IA.)

title: Judge Rejects I.B.M. Bid For Access to Census Data
description: Judge David N. Edelstein has rejected in Federal Court in New York International Business Machines Corporation's appeal for access to certain raw census data submitted to the Commerce Department by computer equipment makers.

title: Economics Without A Helmet
description: By careful count, President Ford seized six separate opportunities at his latest news conference to express nis concern about reigniting inflation. He made one vague reterence to his optimism about generating more employment and another to his hope that unemployment might not be as high next year as his own advisers have forecast. He left no doubt whatever that his only policy is to hold down inflation and that those without jobs or hope of jobs are out of luck, as far as he's concerned.

title: DONALD DODGE
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 30Donald Dodge, a former New York architect, died Saturday in the local hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: DeLury, After Court Loss, Says Strike Is Inevitable
description: John J. DeLury, the sanitation union president, warned yesterday that a garbage strike was inevitable today after his union had failed in a lastditch court effort to keep the financially pressed city from laying off 2.934 men.

title: Dividends
description: Pe Stk of Pay. riod Rate Record able

title: OUTPUT FORECAST HURTS CORN PRICE
description: Corn futures prices for December and later delivery dropped about 2 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday following a higherthanexpected estimate of corn acreage planted issued by Conrad Leslie, a crop expert. December corn closed at $2.35, off 2 cents.

title: BONDS TO AID CITY TO COST STATE 9%
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation's $1billion bond issue offered formally to investors yesterday will cost the new agency somewhat more than 9 per cent in interest charges annually, a figure well above the record 7.69 per cent rate that New York City itself paid in its most expensive bond sale, a year ago.

title: $384MILLION CUTS TO BEGIN IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, June 30Final efforts to break a legislative deadlock on taxes failed this evening in New Jersey and the $384million in state budget cuts ordered by Governor Byrne were to be implemented at midnight.

title: Earnings Decline at General Mills and Lukens Steel Despite Higher Sales
description: General Mills, Inc., which makes packaged foods and is also involved in apparel, toys, restaurants and specialty chemicals, reported yesterday slightly lower earnings for the final quarter as a result of a change to the lastin, firstout (LIFO) inventory valuation method, although sales set a record for the period.

title: RICHARD P. LOVING; IN LANDMARK SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Richerd Perry Loving, whose marriage to a childhood sweetheart led to the Supreme Court's decision overturning laws banning interracial marriage, was killed in an automobile accident yesterday in Caroline County, Va., about 70 miles south of Washington. His wife, Mildred, was injured but is reported in satisfactory condition.

title: Pinter's No Man's Land Hailed in London
description: LONDONOne of the most gratifying aspects of the current London theatrical season has been the exuberant success of the National Theater at the Old Vica success admittedly made somewhat ironic by the company's dire financial condition.

title: KOREAN REDS BEAT TWO U.S. SOLDIERS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 30 (UPI)  More than a dozen North Korean guards punched and kicked an American officer and a woman sergeant today. outside a building in the truce compound of Panmunjom where the Korean Military Armistice Commission was meeting.

title: Pollak Holds Lead In Hipkins Sailing
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 30One boat capsized, another was disqualified after winning the first race, and Christopher Pollak of Cedar Point Yach Club, Westport, Conn., held a onequarterPoint Yacht Club, Westport, ing championship of Long island Sound after the first three races in the 24th annual series held today off Riverside Yacht Club.

title: Monzon, Galindez Retain Crowns Here
description: Halfway round the world from Kuala Lumpur and the traveling heavyweights, Madison Square Garden staged its piece of the international fight action last night with a championship tripleheader in which two world titles were successfully defended live and a third was defended on television from Southeast Asia.

title: HOUSING UNIT LOSES RENT STRIKE RULING
description: TRENTON, June 30 (AP)A state appeals court ruled today that the state could not pay rents directly to local housing authorities when welfare recipients refused to pay their rent.

title: Marines' New Leader
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Every morning before breakfast, at the age of 55, Louis Hugh Wilson dons a sweatsuit and jogs two miles. For the marines, that is probably one of the most important things they should know about their new commandant.

title: HOMER J. BARR
description: BOSTON, June 30 (AP) Homer J. Barr, head wrestling coach at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, died here yesterday at New England Baptist Hospital at the age of 48.

title: American League
description: Milwaukee 5. New York 4, Boston 5, Baltimore 2 (1st). Baltimore 8, Boston 2 (2d).

title: University of California Gets a New President
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 30Twentysix years after he was forced to leave the University of California for refusing to sign a loyalty oath, David S. Saxon will assume the presidency of the ninecampus, 119,000student system this week.

title: Open Interest
Shipping/Mails
description: TOMORROW, JULY 2 MAKHAIL LERMONTOV. Ballic left Bermuda June 30, due 8 A.M. at W. 50th St.

title: Beirut Radio Says Cabinet is Formed; Fighting Continues
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, July 1The Government radio and television said yesterday that a Cabinet of prominent Moslems and Christians had been formed to halt factional fighting in which hundreds of people have been killed since April.

title: STAFF IS RESISTING SALE OF LE FIGARO
description: PARIS, June 30A dispute that has been growing in the French newspaper business neared a crisis late today with the announcement that the controlling stock of the widely read morning daily Le Figaro would be sold to a publisher against the will of a part of the news staff.

title: LAYOFFS OF 40,000 ORDERED AS CITY ENDS FISCAL YEAR
description: The Beame administration, despairing of 11thhour financial aid from Albany, finally gave the goahead yesterday afternoon for massive municipal layoffs under a crisis budget that ushers in a period of civic austerity.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS RIGHT OF SUSPECT TOREFUSELAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that a competent person accused of a crime has a constitutional right to refuse professional legal assistance and conduct his own defense.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The decision taken by the Alaska Supreme Court, which legalizes marijuana possession for personal use, cannot be based on the contention that marijuana as presently used in the U.S. does not constitute a public health problem of any significant dimension  and that the effects of marijuana on the individual are not serious enough to justify widespread concern (news article May 28).

title: To 7th Avenue, Two Designers Bring Sweet Smell of Success
description: When Barry Schwartz, Calvin Klein's partner, was asked how business was going, instead of saying, Don't ask, he reported that he had booked $5million worth of orders in three weeks.

title: Life and Death
description: The National Center for Health Statistics has recently published its annual summary of the nation's vital statistics, a document which deserves much more attention than it has received. In 1974, the population of the United Stairs was healthierat least as indicated by the statistics on life and deaththan ever before in history. An American baby born last year had a life expectancy of 72 years, the highest figure on record and a gain of more than a full year since 1970.

title: Congressional Unit Sees No Inflation in a Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The new nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, in its first detailed forecast of the economy, said today that substantial additional tax reduction next year would not create any additional Inflation and would also create no adverse effects on the ability of businesses to borrow to finance new plants and equipment.

title: Boston Museum Names Fontein Acting Director
description: The Boston Museum of Fine. Arts, which on June 9 terminated without explanation the contract of its director, Merrill C. Rueppel, has appointed as acting director Jan Fontein, its curator of Asian art. A committee appointed by the board of trustees will continue the search for a permanent director.

title: $384 MILLION CUTS TO BEGIN IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, June 30Final efforts to break a legislative deadlock on taxes failed this evening in New Jersey and the $384million in state budget cuts ordered by Governor Byrne were to be implemented at midnight.

title: COPPER GROUPTOEND ALLEGED CONSPIRACY
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The Copper Development Association and II copper concerns agreed today to end an alleged conspiracy to promote the use of copper in plumbing.

title: Northrop Retained Friends of Brazilian General to Help Win $72Million Contract
description: The Northrop Corporation, which has admitted to paying bribes overseas to help sell its fighter planes and employing retired United States generals for a variety of sensitive tasks, also used wellconnected agents in Brazil to win a lucrative fighter plane contract there.

title: Several Protesting Mrs. Gandhi's Rule Are Reported Slain
description: NEW DELHI, June 30Indian policemen shot and killed several antiGovernment demonstrators during disorders yesterday in the eastern state of Bihar, travelers from there said in New Delhi today.

title: Washington Dentists' Directory Shows Wide Variances in Fees
description: WASHINGTON, June 30A consumer group made public today a directory of dentists in the District of Columbia showing that the customary fee for an initial examination, with Xrays, ranges from $15 to $75 with no commensurate differences that the group could find in quality or thoroughness of treatment.

title: Pound Falls to Low of $2.19; Wilson Bars Panic Solutions
description: LONDON, June 30  The pound reached a new low on world currency markets today, but officials here seemed preparedfor both financial and political reasonsto let the slide continue until the country comes to grips with fundamental economic problems.

title: PENNSYLVANIA HIT BY EMPLOYES STRIKE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. Tuesday, July 1 (AP)Unions representing thousands of state employes, including some prison guards, struck last night after rejecting the state's offer of 3.5 ver cent wage increase.

title: BROWNE TAKES TITLE IN U.S. CHESS PLAY
description: OBERLIN, Ohio, June 30 (AP)Walter Browne won his second straight United States chess championship yesterday, although he was not on hand for the final round.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHEERFUL EARFUL It was pleasant last Friday after seeing the uptown revival of Berkeley Square to cross the street for a drink and enter at the exact moment when the young pianist started singing another London souvenir, Gershwin's A Foggy Day. It was also rewarding.

title: CLAPTON OPENS TOUR AT NASSAU COLISEUM
description: It is now the fashion to bring in a surprise guest at the opening of the tour of a rock superstar. So it was no surprise at Nassau Coliseum on Saturday, when the British guitarist Eric Clapton brought out two more frontranking rock guitarists, Devadip Carlos Santana and John McLaughlin, to share a couple of encores with him. The three guitarists chose the basic Stormy Monday Blues to work out on, and Mr. McLaughlin, leader of the avantrock Mahavishnu Orchestra, submerged the farout in favor of the earthy on his solo.

title: Diplomats Protest in Vain as Communists Occupy Key Facilities for 3d Day
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 30?he United States Embassy, with three of its key facilities, ?? staff living quarters, ?? today by proCommunist policemen and civilian demonstrators for the third day, has informed the Foreign Ministry that it may have to ?? because of lack of admainistrative support.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: BirdCarving
description: Before World War II, only a handful of collectors prized the work of American carvers of waterfowl and shorebird decoys, but today single pieces by the best of those artists sell for hundreds and sometimes thousands of dollars.

title: President is Picked By Todd Shipyards At Board Meeting
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation, the world's largest independent shipbuilding and shiprepair business, yesterday installed a new president, Arthur W. Stout Jr., 54 who becomes chief operating officer.

title: Ohio Standard Seeks Rise In Gas Used in Fertilizer,
description: CLEVELAND, June 30, (UPI) The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) today appealed to the Federal Power Commission for more natural gas to produce fertilizer for Midwestern farmers for the 197576 crop season.

title: New Welfare Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, Rine 30 (UPI) More than 11 million adults and children receiving welfare benefits will have to give their Social Security numbers to state agencies, the Government said today in a move to curb welfare cheating. Starting tomorrow, applicants for Aid to Families With Dependent Children must submit the numbers. Persons already receiving benefits must provide their numbers within the next six months.

title: Area Fives Organize Big 7
description: The long and muchdiscussed formation of a metropolitan area college basketball corrference to help spur declining spectator interest became a reality yesterday. Columbia Princeton St. John's, Fordham, Manhattan, Seton Hall and Rutgers have formed the New JerseyNew York Basketball 7 Conference. Columbia and Princeton will also continue to play in the Ivy League.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Homer in 9th Tops Yanks
description: MILWAUKEE, June 30Just when it seemed the Yankees would beat Milwaukee tonight in spite of the Rolling Stones and Pink Floyd, Bobby Darwin hit a pinchhit, tworun homer in the ninth inning that vaulted the Brewers to a 54 victory.

title: Several Protesting Mrs. Gandhi's Rule Are Reported Slain
description: NEW DELHI, June 30Indian policemen shot and killed several antiGovernment demonstrators during disorders yesterday in the eastern state of Bihar, travelers from there said in New Delhi today.

title: No Amer Soccer League
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: LAYOFFS OF 40,000 ORDERED AS CITY ENDS FISCAL YEAR
description: The Beame administration, despairing of 11thhour financial aid from Albany, finally gave the goahead yesterday afternoon for massive municipal layoffs under a crisis budget that ushers in a period of civic austerity.

title: U.S. Accuses Michigan Bishop on Naturalization
description: The Government has formally charged the Rumanian Orthodox Bishop of America, Valerian D. Trifa of Grass Lake, Mich., with having won ins naturalization through false and untrue denials of membership in the Iron Guard and participation in the murder of Jews And Masons in Faicist Rumania in 1941.

title: LeaseRenewal Increases Are Set on Stabilized Units
description: Tenants renewing leases in many of the city's 650,000 rentstabilized apartments in the year starting today will face maximum rent increases of 7.5 per cent for a oneyear renewal lease, 9.5 per cent for a twoyear renewal, and 12.5 per cent for a threeyear renewal, the Rent Guidelines Board announced yesterday.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 30The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Living in Newyork: The Homing Instinct
description: From the beginning it was ordained: Angelo T. Cometa would become a New Yorker. He would do it the hard way, by scrambling, and then, when the city was dropping into his hands like a rich pasta, he would leave it. He would have to; he would be broke.

title: Stock Index Sets a 3 Month High
description: Stocks finished the first halt of 1975 yesterday on an optimistic note as the Dow Jones industrial average reached its highest level since March 26, 1974.

title: European Parley: End is in Sight
description: GENEVA, June 29Although diplomats from 35 countries are still arguing over the last clauses in the European security document on which they have been negotiating for two and a half years, the end is in sight. When they look back and try to answer whether the exercise has been worth While, they offer a narrow but delicately shaded scale of opinions on what was actually achieved.

title: Ford Signs Jobless Pay Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) President Ford signed legislation today extending until the end of the year the program that guarantees jobless workers 65 weeks of unemployment compensation. Without the extension, the program would have expired tomorrow and workers would have been eligible to collect benefits ranging from $65 to $100 a week for only 52 weeks. About 250,000 persons would have had their unemployment checks cut off.

title: Summit Delay In Europe Seen
description: GENEVA, June 30  The Soviet Union abandoned hope today of having heads of government meet as early as July 22 to write the closing chapter to the twoandahalfyear history of the 35nation European security conference.

title: Indian Government Expels American Reporter
description: NEW DELHI, June 30 (AP)The Indian Government today ordered the expulsion of Lewis M. Simons, staff correspondent here of The Washington Post, and gave him 24 hours to leave the country.

title: Assembly Goes Through Motions on Savings Banks
description: ALBANY, June 30  With the savings bank measure not expected to come up for debate in the Senate, the Assembly today went through the motions of passing a bill that would give the banks the right to offer checking accounts and credit cards in excnange for setting up a $3billion pool to finance mortgages in deteriorating neighborhoods.

title: Kent State Guardsman Testifies He Lied
description: CLEVELAND. June 30 A Ormer Ohio National Guard officer testified today that he lied to fellow guardsmen and other persons five years ago about finding a gun on the body of one of four students killed at Kent State University.

title: clinic is Losing CableTV Link to Doctors
description: The chubby 2yearold played with a stethoscope, unimpressed that his image and that of his mother, holding him on her lap, were on the television ??? before them. Nor did he show the slightest interest in questions about him coming from another television receiver by Dr. Nicholas Cunningham.

title: ERNEST F. TIPPETTS, ENGINEER, DIES AT 75
description: Ernest F. Tippetts, a consulting engineer and former partner of TippettsAbbettMcCarthyStratton, engineers and architects here, died Saturday in St. Petersburg, Fla: He was 75 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: The New YorkNew Jersey Regional Championships that ended Sunday night at Grossinger, N.Y., proved to be a Silverman family triumph.

title: Israeli Ponders a Suspension in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30Yosef Tekoah, Israel's delegate here, says that if Arab countries succeed in suspending Israel from the General Assembly this fall he would favor Israel's reconsidering her attitude toward all United Nations activities, including the Geneva conference on the Middle East.

title: SkiFund Official Named
description: PARK CITY, Utah, June 30 (UPI)Graham Anderson of Seattle was appointed today as vice president of the United States Ski Education Foundation, the fundraising arm of the United States national ski team. Anderson, 41 years old, is a former competitor at the University of Washington and ski coach in the Pacific Northwest. He will work with Bradford Briggs, the Foundation president, as coordinator of special programs and committees.

title: Minischools Have Given New Lift to Potential Dropouts
description: Margaret Banks is hoping that the diploma she received last week at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens will be the break she needs to escape her deadend, afterschool job as a supermarket cashier. Had it not been for the minischool at Jackson she might not have remained enrolled long enough to get that diploma.

title: State Unit Presses Inquiry Into Fencing Stolen Goods
description: An inquiry into organized crime, the theft of goods in transit and the fencing of stolen merchandise has been undertaken by the State Commission of Investigation, a court affidavit disclosed yesterday.

title: Irwin Wins Golf by Stroke
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., June 30 (AP)Hale Irwin scored 13 consecutive pars, slipped past the struggling George Johnson and scored his second victory of the season today in the Western open golf tournament.

title: F.B.I.'s Persistence
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is nothing if not persistent. As far back as last October its plan to give its computerized information system a new capacity to permit it to monitor state and local law enforcement communications ran into a storm of protest from both Capitol Hill and the White House. Undaunted, the F.B.I. kept at it and, according to proposals recently published in the Federal Register, still intends to press to acquire the capacity for information control.

title: All the Presidents Friends
description: WASHINGTONOne of the apparent changes in Washington since President Nixon's resignation has been a more open and less hostile relationship between President Ford and the press, In contrast to his predecessor, Mr. Ford is personable and relaxed with the press. He does not seem to bear animosities toward journalists, and he generally seems willing to meet with them to explain his policies. In the ten months since assuming office Mr. Ford has held sixteen press conferences (Mr. Nixon held only four in his last ten months in office).

title: All Outpoinis Bugner and Keeps Title; Champion Decides to Continue Career
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Tuesday, July 1With the ease of assaulting a statue, Muhammad Ali retained the world heavyweight boxing championship on a unanimous 15rourid decision over Joe Bugner after announcing his intention to continue his career with bouts against Joe Frazier, George Foreman and Ken Norton.

title: Newport Jazz
description: Though the national focus on jazz was centered on midtown Manhattan last week with the opening of the Newport Jazz Festival, connoisseurs also found their way to the lofts, studios, bars and small nightclubs around town where the art is kept alive and growing 365 days a year.

title: Democrats Pass Rule Changes On Delegates for the Convention
description: The threat of opposition to new rules for the selection of delegates to the Democratic National Convention faded yesterday at a meeting of the State Democratic Committee.

title: Tennis Upsets On New Circuit
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 30The new Ms. America women's tennis circuit started ed today with two upsets at Grossinger's courts. Kris Kemmer Shaw of New York was toppled by Jane Stratton of Salt Lake City, 57, 76, 63, and Susan Mehmedbasich of El Cerrito, Calif., lost to Roberta Stark of Jacksonville. Fla., 60, 36, 75.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A NoWin Tax Battle
description: TRENTON, July 1The leg islative tax battle in New Jersey between Governor Byrne and the huge Democratic majorities in both houses culminated early this morning in bitter recriminations, partisan divisiveness and impotence, and a threat of criminal libel action.

title: Boris Exemplifies Singers Switching Of Roles in Bolshoi
description: Watching the Bolshoi Opera perform as a repertory company is one of the pleasureable byproducts of its current visit to the Metropolitan Opera Rouse. It is true that some principal artists sing nothing but leading roles, but there are a host of singers who alternate between bit and major parts.

title: About New York
description: Instead of a line of city sanitation trucks waiting to unload, there was echoing silence yesterday morning at the 91st Street marine transfer station, only a couple of blocks from Gracie Mansion.

title: Ford Asks Blacks Support on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 President Ford urged black leaders today to support his policy of fiscal restraint as a key to fulfillment of equality for American minorities. The President's remarks, to the 66th convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, were met with restraint.

title: $2,180 TAXES PAID TO U.S. BY JAVITS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York RepublicarrLiberal, and his wife paid $2,180 in Federal income taxes last year on gross earnings of $91,526, adjusted to $86,526, according to a voluntary disclosure made by the Senator in the issue of The Congressional Record distributed today.

title: BilingualBicultural Education is Planned by Colorado
description: DENVER, June 30 Rubdn Valddz, a onetime high school dropout from the southern Colorado town of Trinidad, remembered that he never heard or read abdut a Spanish name linked to something good while in school.

title: On Democracy
description: The Government of Portugal has just dismissed its chief delegate to the United Nations, Prof. Jose Veiga Simao. The ambassador's crime seems to have been a speech he delivered last week denouncing arbitrary arrests, imprisonment without trial and other violations of elementary human rights.

title: THADDEUS BARSH, 54, PASSAIC POLITICIAN
description: PASSAIC, N. J., July 1Thaddeus A. Barsh, former president of the Passaic Valley Water Commission, died today at Beth Israel Hospital here. He had collapsed at hts home here this morning. He was 54 years old.

title: Laotians Sift Facts and Rumors Before Deciding to Stay or Flee
description: VIETIANE, Laos, July 1The 22 Americans remaining at the oncelarge United States Embassy here are not the only ones who are not sure whether they will be able to stay in Laos.

title: Amin Offers Pardon
description: President Idi Amin of Uganda announced yesterday that he had decided to pardon Denis Cecil Hills, the British teacher he had sentenced to death. Page 3.

title: Another Truman?
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The selling of Gerald R. Ford as a plausible President is well advanced. Under the management of the shrewd politicians and businessmen who comprise his kitchen Cabinet, Mr. Ford is being marketed as another Harry Truman, another honest, decent, friendly Middle Westerner who talks simply and acts on readily understandable human instincts.

title: WINE TALK
description: That cork that you yanked from your bottle of dinner wine may have been more interesting than the wine.

title: Telephoning Explained
description: PARISVoices on the telephone anywhere in the world and especially in Paris are traditionally believed to come out of the sound box and through the vocal chords of human beings.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Bridge:
description: The New York bridge scene is wellendowed with colorful, flamboyant personalities, many of whom firmly believe themselves to be the world's best player.

title: Connors. Ashe, Tanner Score
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1For the second year running, three Americans are in the semifinals of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: Pickets May Cause Jam On the Henry Hudson
description: Motorists who use the Henry Hudson Parkway were advised early today to avoid the southbound roadway below 125th Street this morning.

title: List of Remaining Performances
description: Remaining tree concerts by the Metropolitan Opera in New York City.

title: A Fire Hero Learns He's Dismissed
description: Last week Fireman Thomas K. Newbert was elbowdeep in foam used to smother fires as he and Fireman Richard Wieser rescued a Norwegian sailor from the burning wreckage of Eastern Airlines Flight 66.

title: VIOLENCE FLARES
description: Tons of garbage piled up on the city's streets yesterday as 10,000 sanitationmen, protesting the layoffs of 2,934 of their number, began a walkout that Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh called the best organized wildcat strike I'ye ever seen.

title: Britain Asks Pact to Limit Wage Increases to 10%
description: LONDON, July 1In a surprise statement before the House of Commons this afternoon, Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey warned labor and management that unless they devised a voluntary plan limiting wage increases to 10 per cent, the Government, would move toward statutory controls on incomes, prices and dividends.

title: Soviet to Tax Funds From Abroad 30%
description: MOSCOW, July 1A new law was made public today under which the Soviet Government will extract a tax of 30 per cent from all money sent from abroad to Soviel citizens.

title: One Man's Call to India's Opposition. Why it Led to Crackdown!
description: NEW DELHI, July 1On that night J. P. spoke much truth, a Punjabi laborer said. But he said so many bad things about Indira Gandhi that I knew the police would come.

title: NEWARK BANK GUARD IS KILLED IN HOLDUP
description: NEWARK, July 1 (UPI)A retired police officer working as a security guard was shot to death today by a gunman who held up a bank here and escaped with about $500, the police reported.

title: $139 Tennis Racquet Finds Few Takers
description: Would you buy a tennis racquet for $139? And that's for the frame alone. Stringing it would cost an extra $10 to $23, depending whether nylon or gut was used. Compare that with the $40 to $60 an average quality racquet costs.

title: FORD READY TO TRY NEW SWIMMING POOL
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)  President Ford said today that he was eager to take his first dip in the new $66,840 White House swimming pool built for him with contributions from school children, prominent Republicans, golfing partners and the wife of a former President.

title: Illinois Prosecutor in Governor's Race
description: CHICAGO, July 1James R. Thompson, the young United States Attorney who prosecuted some of Chicago's top Democarts, announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor of Illinois next soring.

title: The Case That Stirred Chinatown is Dropped,
description: Charges were dismissed yesterday against Peter Yew, whose arrest during a small demonstration in April became a rallying point for thousands of residents of Chinatown and the focus of two major demonstrations at City Hall.

title: Britain Asks Pact to Limit Wage Increases to 10%
description: LONDON, July 1In a surprise statement before the House of Commons this afternoon, Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey warned labor and management that unless they devised a voluntary plan limiting wage increases to 10 per cent, the Government would move toward statutory controls on incomes, prices and dividends.

title: FARM BOSS FREED IN MIGRANT TRIAL
description: NEWARK, July 1A Federal jury found a South Jersey farm foreman not guilty here today of holding migrant workers from Puerto Rico in involuntary servitude last summer.

title: Nixon Declares Johnson Urged Taping System in White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Former President Richard M.. Nixon says he installed the extensive White House taping system at the urging of his predecessor. Lyndon B. Johnson, who he said, had a similar system.

title: CHESSIE SYSTEM LISTS PROFIT DROP
description: Chessie System, Inc., the first railroad to issue its secondquarter operating results, announced yesterday that earnings in the period were $24million, or $1.30 a share, down from $25.1million, or $1.41 a share, in the year ago period. First half net was $40.1million, compared with $38.6million in 1974.

title: Defeats Split Bitter House Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Democrats in the House of Representatives who began this year with a huge majority and ambitions of guiding the nation's policies  are fractured today by rancor of an intensity seldom seen in Ahe normally chummy atmosphere of Congress.

title: People and Business
description: The world's weather is changing, as many people have observed. We're getting longer springs, shorter growing seasons and quicker return of cold weather in the fall, Earl S. Finkle, a meteorologist said yesterday.

title: ROBINSON NAMED BY SCHOOL BOARD
description: Isaiah E. Robinson was elected president of the Board of Education yesterday and immediately called upon teachersl, and others to shun the example of the sanitationmen and, instead, use creativity and imagination to minimize the impact of budget cuts on the schools.

title: Differences
description: LOS ANGELES  Feminists crisply cite statistics on the availability of qualified women and personnel officers solemnly search for them. Nevertheless few American women win fame, power, or distinction. Why? Perhaps because public policies of equality are undercut by personal experiences with inequality.

title: About Education
description: Since 1971, when John F. Kennedy High School opened, its English program has been one of the most experimental in the city. The school has used elective ungraded classes, where students enrolled in a given coursewithin certain limits and experience regardless of their abilities.

title: Record Bond Issue is Sold In the TaxExempt Market
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation's $1billion bond issue that was offered to investors initially on Monday at yields as high as 9 per cent was reported sold out late yesterday afternoon. The big bond issue, representing the largest sale of taxexempt bonds ever made, produced no stampede of orders, however, despite its yields, among the highest taxexempt interest rates ever offered to investors. Early yesterday, some dealers talked of increasing the size of the issue to Sl.25billion, but that possibility was knocked down as the underwriters processed orders.

title: Pollak Wins L.I. Sound Sailing Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 1Christopher Pollak of the Cedar Point Yacht Club in Westport, until recently a Navy lieutenant, won the annual men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today. He captured the Commodore Hipkins Trophy in taking the regatta by 2 points.

title: Four. Special High Schools for the Gifted Keep Stability Amidst All the Changes
description: In a period when the rest of the city's high schools have been undergoing fundamental changes in curriculum and organization, four special schools here are today among the most stable in the city.

title: TRRE IS DECLARED IN BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, July 2A new Cabinet was installed in Lebanon yesterday, and a few hours later a ceasefire was announced in, the persistent street fighting between armed groups of Christians and Moslems.

title: Carmody Wins Mile
description: Dennis Carmody and Art Kijek were among the winners in the Roadrunners Club of New York speed program at Queensborough College in Bayside yesterday. Carmody, 16 years old, ran the mile in 4 minutes 34.5 seconds. Kijek captured the veterans event (for competitors over 40) in 5:18. Anita Scandurra, 19, took the women's race in 5:33.5.

title: Lolich Carries His Weight on 3Hitter
description: Mickey Lolich, who believes his pot belly gets more publicity than his pitching, hurled threehit ball last night and was supported by a tworun homer from Ron LeFlore as the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians. 62.

title: HalfFares Due on the 4th
description: The halffare plan of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will be in effect on Friday, the Fourth of July.

title: Television
A MatchRace Feud: Baeza vs. Whiteley
description: Sounding more like a fight promoter than a jockey, Braulio Baeza said yesterday he couldn't stand the sight of Frank Whiteley.

title: LE FIGARO IS STRUCK AFTER RIFT ON SALE
description: PARIS, July 1  Publication of the morning newspaper Le Figaro was suspended today in the wake of a 24hour strike by journalists resisting the sale of controlling stock to a new owner.

title: U.S., Silent on India, Deplores Newsman's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The United States, withholding any direct criticism of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's emergency Hiler has tried to avoid giving Indian politicians a pretext to blame Washington for the crisis Administration officials said today. A slight shift from that policy occurred today when Washington criticized India's expulsion of an American news correspondent.

title: In Memoriam
description: In Memoriam

title: 4 TOP CONCERNS RAISE GAS PRICES UP TO 3C A GALLON
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Four major oil companies raised refinery gasoline prices by as much as 3 cents a gallon today, the start of the high season for summer vacations and motoring.

title: Legislature Votes Carey Plan For New Correction Commission
description: ALBANY, July 1The Legislature today approved a bill eliminating the present sevenmember, parttime State Commission of Correction and replacing it with a threemember, fulltime salaried board appointed by the Governor, with expanded powers.

title: Catskills on the Line
description: Whoever has made a voyage up the Hudson must remember the Kaatskill mountains, Rip Van Winkle recalled in Washington Irving's famous tale. They are  seen away to the west of the river, swelling up to a noble height, and lording it over the surrounding country.

title: Yankees Lose to Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE, July 1Milwaukee might be a nice place to live, but the Yankees don't like to visit here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Denis Healey, warned labor and management that the Government would move toward statutory controls on incomes and prices unless they devised a voluntary plan limiting wage increases to 10 per cent. The surprise statement in the House of Commons was the strongest move yet to curb Britain's soaring inflation. The pound sterling, which had been sliding, rose slightly on international markets, while the Labor party's left wing said legal restraints on free bargaining would violate Government pledges. [Page 1, Columns 23.1

title: Tomahawks Win, 2520
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., July 1Doug Hayes scored 9 points on four goals and five assists tonight to lead the firstplace Long Island Tomahawks to a 2520 triumph over the Boston Bolts in a National Lacrosse League game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: PATERSON HOUSING GETS $355,000 AID
description: A $355,000 grant has been received by the City of Paterson from the Federal Government to rehabiliate city housing and to encourage families to take over ownership of property in which they live.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Notes on Pebole
description: The armed forces will have their first black officer of fourstar rank upon Senate confirmation of Lieut Gen Daniel James Jr. of the Air Force as a full general. The 55yearold General James. nominated yesterday by President Ford, will be commander in chief of the North American Air Defense Command, a joint United StatesCanadian command and of the Aerospace Defense Command, with his headquarters Colorado Springs.

title: TAKEI DANCE LOOKS AT NATURE OF TIME
description: Despite its pretty images, a flower garden of white winged darts and a dozing, playful woman as comfortable as a house cat, Kei Takei's After Lunch ran to tedious length on Monday evening. Miss Takei's preoccupation with time has never been more directly explored than it Was in this dance piece given at New York University's School of the Arts Theater.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor My company shares your concern over the nuclear developments discussed in your editorials of June 9 and 13. The U.S. can no longerif it ever coulddictate the terms upon which nations share nuclear technology.
