description: MILWAUKEE, July 2 (AP) Miller Barber sank four putts from 20 feet or beyond and posted a sevenunderpar 65 that survived a late challenge by Andy Northtoday for a twostroke lead in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee nnen solf tournament.

title: An Apolitical O.T.P.
description: The White House Office of Telecommunications Policy was a good idea when it was created in 1970 and it still makes senseif the right man or woman serves as its director. It was designed to coordinate telecommunications policy within the executive branch and advisc the President on how the public can best be served in matters ranging from local educational broadcasting to Federal Communications Commission regulatory activities.

title: Chess:
description: In winning the 1975 United States championship, his second in succession, Walter Browne displayed a steadiness his rivals failed to match. The only other player to go through the event undefeated was Arthur Bisguier, hut, while Bisguier could not gain a single point outright, Browne won four games to take the $2,300 first prize.

title: Body of Missing Girl, 9 Found Near Her Home
description: The police said an unidentified boy had found the body of Bunny Bateman beneath a brown blanket. They said the girl apparently had been strangled but did not know if she had been sexually abused.

title: Review is Asked on Ruling On Kennecott Divestiture
description: Six of the 14 members of the Senate Committee on Public Works have formally asked the Federal Trade Commission to reconsider its 1971 decision ordering the Kennecott Copper Corporation to divest itself of the Peabody Coal Company, the nation's largest coal producer.

title: Yankee Box Score
description: Two out when winning run scored.

title: Ubiquitous Straw Bag: Many Shapes
description: Put away the Gucci and the Vuitton and go native. The bag of summer is a woven straw affair that might carry vegetables in its native habitat: North Africa, the Philippines or China. It is best in the natural color of the straw, with pattern left to the weave, rather than added adornment. Embroidered flowers, souvenir of Acapulco or coy linings are outthey mark you as the wrong kind of tourist.

title: Miles Davis and Septet Play a Song at Midnight
description: The combination of Miles Davis's dour onstage image and the uncompromising, blastingly amplified nature of his current music is clearly not to everybody's taste and especially not to tastes oriented toward the traditional jazz that is the Newport Jazz Festival's specialty.

title: Mets Top Cubs, 72, for Matlacks 10th
description: The scoreboard read New York Mets 7, Chicago Cubs 2, but it really wasn't that much of a drubbing last night at Shea. Stadium, with the Cubs giving away a few runs before a crowd of 16,055. In the, sixth inning, for example, Chicago let the Mets wring three runs from one hit. It was far from one, or the Mets classier games, but it was a memorable occasion for Jon Matlack, their lefthander.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said ??? democracy in India had given too much license to newspapers and opposition leaders trying to abuse it and weaken the nation's confidence. Arrests of large numbers of antiGovernment demonstrators were reported in parts of Northern India. Strict censorship rules were extended to cartoons, photographs and advertisements likely to come within the purview of the regulations. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: FLOODS RUIN CROPS IN RED RIVER VALLEY
description: FARGO, N. D., July 2 (UPI) Flpod waters, swollen by a foot or more of rain, turned into an ocean in the Red River Valley today, wiping out crops, keeping several hundred persons from their homes and causing hundreds of million dollars in damage.

title: Milwaukee Leaders
Governor Vetoes Bill That Would Give JobSecurity Priority to War Veterans
description: ALBANY, July 2Governor Carey has vetoed a bill that would have given veterans of the two world wars and of the Korean and Vietnam conflicts an absolute preference in retention of Civil Service positions over their nonveteran colleagues in the event of layoffs or job eliminations, his office announced today.

title: Black General on Racism
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., July 1 (AP)Lieut. Gen Daniel James Jr., the first black to be nominated for the rank of fourstar general, said today that institutionalized racism has been eliminated from the armed services.

title: Dakota Tribal Violence Linked to Political Rivalry
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., July 2Crouched in a ditch near the side of the road, a lanky young supporter of the militant American Indian Movement gripped his rifle and watched through the darkness for oncoming pickup trucks. It was 1 A.M., and down the hill under the light of a half moon, stood a teepee sheltering the body of a compatriot slain in a gun battle with agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Shift in Bolshoi Conductors
description: Yuri Simonov, music director of the Bolshoi Opera, will conduct tonight's performance of Pique Dame and the three remaining performance of the Tchaikovsky work, Gennady Rozhdestvensky, who was scheduled to conduct, will be unable to because of illness in his family, according to a spokesman for Hurok Concerts, Inc., sponsor of the company's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Summer Theaters Get Out S.R.O. Sign
description: The curtains have started to go up along with the temperature, at the summer theaters, and the season is shaping up as a good one in the reports of the hopeful producers.

title: A Tanker Chartered for Wheat In May Still Tied Up in Dispute
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 2An oil tanker chartered to carry American wheat to Egypt in late May is still sitting partly loaded in the port here, while a costly dispute continues over inspectors rulings that it is not clean enough to take the cargo.

title: Fanciers Participate In Building Hospital
description: If it wasn't for the dogshow sport, the first public diabetes hospital in America probably still wouldn't be built, said Don Starkweather, who teaches at the hospital in Birmingham. Ala., which was two years old last month. It was largely contributions from fanciers which helped fi nance the hospital, continued S t a rkweather. The director is Dr. Burls Boshell, a miniature pinscher breeder and a judge, and two members of the board are Jud Streicher and Dan Hamilhurg, boxer breeders.

title: Censorship in India: Grim Editors, Lifeless Papers
description: NEW DELHI, July 2An Indian newspaper executive with tired eyes gestured furtively toward the turbaned policeman guarding the entrance of The Motherland, an opposition newspaper that has been closed down.

title: Celebrators Turning Defeats Into Victories
description: With revisionist ardor and amnesiac delight, Bicentennial officials are wiping the slate clean of Revolutionary War defeats.

title: A Volcano in West Showing Signs of Life
description: CONCRETE, Wash., July 2Mount Baker, a 10,778foot longdormant volcano towering near this tiny town, is coming baci; to life and may soon provide the first major volcanic activity in the 48 contiguous states in 60 years.

title: P.B.A. Hints at Slowdown; Bars Formal Job Action
description: The leadership of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association voted yesterday against taking any formal job action in the wake of the dismissal of 5,000 city police officers.

title: State Court Broadens the Right Of Citizens to Challenge Laws
description: ALBANY, July 2The State Court of Appeals ruled today tliat an individual taxpayer had the right to go to court to challenge the constitutionality of a state law in cases where a denial of that right would mean, in effect, that the law in questionwould not be challenged.

title: Spy Hearing Postponed
description: BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP)H Sahag K. Dedeyan, 41 years old, arrested last Friday on charges of spying for the Soviet Union, has been granted a delay until July 17 for a preliminary hearing. Mr. Dedeyan, a resident of Rockville, Md., is charged with supplying copies of a secret report on the NATO defense system to a cousin who allegedly photographed the papers and turned them over to Soviet agents.

title: Court Voids State Law Curbing Contraceptive Selling and Ads
description: A state law that, restricts the distribution and advertising of nonprescription contraceptives was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a panel of three federal judges here.

title: Newport Jazz
description: The Newport Jazz Festival's Salute to Jazz and the American Song started out at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening as though it were going to be a triumph. But then it began melting as inexplicably as that cake in MacArthur Park.

title: Fiscal Cuts Hit Home In Streets of Bayside
description: We are the orphans of the city, because Bayside is a middleclass area, Lucille Sammartine exclaimed yesterday. She said she was fuming over city policies as she pushed her cart with groceries along 43d Avenue from Bell Boulevard in the northeast Queens area.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said that democracy in India had given too much license to newspapers and opposition leaders trying to abuse it and weaken the nation's confidence: Arrests of large numbers of antiGovernment demonstrators were reported in parts of Northern India. Strict censorship rules were extended to cartoons, photographs and advertisements likely to come within the purview of the regulations. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: EGYPTIAN DEMAND DIVIDES ISRAELIS
description: JERUSALEM, July 2A political debate over whether to accede to Egypt's demand for complete Israeli withdrawal from the strategically important Sinai mountain passes has Opened deep divisions in the Israeli Government, the ruling Labor party and the smaller parties of right and left.

title: And the Favorite Bag is Made of Sea Grass
description: Straw has always been a wonderfully cool material for summer bags and there certainly is enough basketry around to suit every taste and pocketbook. But the runaway favorite with big spender and penny pincher alike is a simple sea grass one from China that is relatively inexpensive, anywhere from $3.89 to $7.

title: JOHN M'MASTER, 77, INSURANCE OFFICER
description: John McMaster, who retired several years ago as first financial vice president of Great American Insurance Companies here, died yesterday at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Sharon.

title: Advertising
description: Tomorrow on the Elipse In Washington the Yippies will celebrate the Fourth of July their way, with a smokein, their sixth annual. It will be on and with grass.

title: Excerpts From Action Plan of Women's Meeting
description: MEXICO CITY, July 2Following are excerpts from the official English text of the World Plan of Action adopted late last night by the I,300 delegates at the International Moments Year World Conference:

title: Benefit by Panovs Will Provide Free Theater
description: HOLMDEL, NJ., July 2Valery and Galina Panov, the Russian migr dancers, made their metropolitan area debut tonight in a gala benefit for the Garden State Arts Center's Cultural Fund.

title: Upsets Mark Semifinals At Ms. Net
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y:, July 2 Joanne Russell of Naples, Fla., and Anne (Bunny) Bruning of La Jolla, Calif., both servevolley players, registered upsets today and reached the final of the $10,000 Ms. America circuit women's tennis tournament at Grossinger's Hotel.

title: 1,600 Furloughed in Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, July 2 (UPI)About 1,600 workers were furloughed today as the strike that has halted publication of The Pittsburgh Press and PostGazette moved into its sixth day. The company said that 1,000 workers were furloughed last Friday when delivery drivers walked off the job ??? a dispute over the reassignment of a newsprint dock employe.

title: Town Says Zoning Bars Black Church's Services
description: WOODLYNNE, July 2Officials of the Borough of Woodlynne said today they would seek temporary restraining order tomorrow barring the First Church of God and. Saints, and its pastor, the Rev. John H. Brent, from continuing to hold prayer services here in violation of local zoning laws.

title: Civil Rights Lawyer Will Defend C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Central Intelligence Agency, in a move that has surprised, mystified and angered various segments of Washington's legal community, has hired Arnold & Porter, one of the city's leading law firms, to serve as consulting counsel during Senate and House hearings on the agency.

title: Opera: Bolshoi's Pique Dame Is the Real Thing
description: When the Metropolitan Opera staged Tchaikovsky's Queen of Spades a few years ago, there were many cuts, especially in the choral sections, and the idea seemed to be to get the opera ended as soon as possible. Last night, the Bolshoi Opera presented its first Pique Dame (to use the officially listed, and more familiar title), and this was more like the real thing. It was complete, it was sung in Russian, and it had all the trimmings, including a charming little thirdact ballet, danced by lovely young women.

title: 4 Muslims Shot From Car
description: CHATTANOOGA, July 2 (AP) Four members of a Black Muslim religious sect, including two 6yearold children, were wounded yesterday by a shotgun blast from a passing automobile the police said today. It was the second incident within a week in which Black Muslims have been shot at from a passing car. Ahmad Majied, 19 years old, Deborah McClure, 20. and the children, Tanya and Tammy Lee, were treated for superficial shotgun pellet wounds and released.

title: Mrs. King Beats Miss Evert At Wimbledon by 26, 62, 63
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2In one of the most incredible comebacks of her long career, Billie Jean King struggled from 03 and 1540 in the third set, took six games running and defeated Chris Evert today, 26, 62, 63, reaching her ninth final at the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: Bicentennial Comes Into Its Own Over the 4th, With Parades, Fireworks Displays, and Sousa
description: Although tomorrow is only the 199th annual celebration of the Fourth of July, Bicentennial Fever, having apparently infected millions of Americans a full year in advance, will be in abundant evidence in the New York Metropolitan area, with parades, fireworks displays, flagwaving, Sousaflavored concerts and cannon salutes.

title: Black General on Racism
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., July 1 (AP)Lieut Gen Daniel James Jr. the first black to be nominated for the rank of fourstar general, said today that institutionalized racism has been eliminated from the armed services.

title: 33 American Crews Await Henley Start
description: HENLEY  ON  THAMES. England, July 2ite Henley Royal Regatta, which has been rowed on the same stretch of the Thames since 1839, bgins tomorrowThirtythreeAmerican ??? are here.

title: Rumors of Increase in Prime Cited Dow is off 7.04
description: Stock prices retreated widely yesterday on reports that the First National City Bank might raise its prime interest rate to 7 per cent.

title: Butkus Wins Ruling On Bear Contract
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (UPI)A circuit court judge ruled today that the Chicago Bears football team was liable for the four remaining years of fiveyear contract with Dick Butkus, former star linebacker.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Tenants of the 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments here were advised by the city not to pay newly authorized fuelcosts rent increases until they received detailed information from their landlords about their building's fuel expenses and income.

title: Connor and 2 Councilmen Call Ferry Cuts Gravest Injustice
description: Three Staten Island politicians jumped aboard the ferry issue yesterday in an attempt to keep nighttime service afloat.

title: Mets Records
description: TeemAB, 2463. H

title: Fiscal Cuts Hit Home In Streets of Bayside
description: We are the orphans of the city, because Bayside is a middleclass area, Lucille Sammartine exclaimed yesterday. She said she was fuming over city policies as she pushed her cart with groceries along 43d Avenue from Bell Boulevard in the northeast Queens area.

title: From Arizona, N.Y.
description: The following open letter appeared in The Arizona Republic, where Mr. Lavine, a former New York newspaperman, is an editorial writer.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 3, 1975

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that the New Jersey Board of Higher Education had ordered a 50 per cent increase in tuition at the state's public colleges. The board put a recommendation by Ralph A. Dungan, Chancellor of Higher Education, for such an increase over for discussion at a meeting scheduled for July 25.

title: New Yorkers Feeling Baltimore Woes of 74
description: New Yorkers are now beginning to share what residents of Baltimore experienced one year ago, when thousands of city workers went on strike to win better contracts.

title: Opponent of Marcos Loses Plea for CivilCourt Trial
description: MANILA, the Philippines, July 2 (AP) Benigno S. Aquino Jr., once the main political opponent of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, will he tried in a military court on charges or subversion, murder and illegal possession of firearms, the government said to, day.

title: RACIAL TENSIONS STILL SEEN IN ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Army Secretary Howard M. Callaway said today that despite enormous progress in improving race relations in the military, there is still a lot of racial tension within the Army.

title: Original 76 Document Auctioned for $88,000
description: LONDON, July 2  Two New York book dealers paid $88,000 today for one of the original printed copies of the Declaration of Independence.

title: TWO GRAND MIES INDICT HOLLANDER
description: Eugene Hollander, a major nursinghome operator and long the chief spokesman for the industry here, was indicted by state and Federal grand juries yesterday on charges of stealing more than $1.2million in Modiraid and medicare funds.

title: Windmills to Be Studied As a State Energy Source
description: HOBOKEN, July 2 (UPI)Serious research into windmills did not begin at Stevens Institute of Technology until Prof. Franklin Pollock was nearly blown over by a gust of wind from across the Hudson River.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Trout on the Willowemoc
description: ROSCOE, N.Y.  When Paul Updike of Roscoe and I visited the nokill section of the Willowemoc River last week and assembled, our trout rods in the last hour before dusk., it was only the prelude to a long planned fishing trip on the Delaware River.

title: National League
description: New York 7, Chicago 2 (n.).

title: Babes in Toyland: Fun for Children
description: THE ADVENTURES OF TOM SAWYER, (1938; 77 minutes), 12:30 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at Films for Children Program, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. 9657078.

title: Events Today
description: BOLSHOI OPERA, Metropolitan Opera House, Tchaikovsky's Eugene Onegin, 7:30.

title: Quarrie Outruns Williams Twice
description: MILAN, Italy, July 2 (AP) Don Quarrie, the Jamaican sprinter, beat the American star, Steve Williams, twice tonight to highlight an international track and field meet.

title: Influence of Tatum Marks Playing of 8 Solo Pianists
description: If Art Tatum had not existed, he might have been created, in the Frankenstein manner, from the stream of Tatumesque runs that kept flowing through the piano that held the center of the stage of Carnegie Hall late Tuesday evening.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: India Declared Free of Smallpox
description: An official of the World Health Organization disclosed yesterday that there has been no spread of the dreaded disease since the last two cases were detected in May. Both patients are recuperating in guarded isolation where they will remain until there is no danger that they can spread the contagious infection to others.

title: Garrett is Cleared In Report of S.E.C. On Role in Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Securities and Exchange Commission staff has cleared Ray D. Garrett Jr., the agency's chairman, of any improprieties in connection with a commission investigation of a company with which he was associated before joining the agency.

title: Chronic Crisis: III
description: LONDON  In July, 1966, Britain was going through an acute stage of her longrunning economic melodrama. The Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, niaae a speech giving assurance that the value of the pound would be maintained. He blamed the crisis atmosphere on the sell Britain short brigade, on moaning Minnies and wet editorials.

title: Bonn's Independence From U.S. Is Gaining
description: BONN, July 2The American withdrawal from Indochina this spring shook and worried West Germany, the most powerful ally of the United States in Europe. But the Germans preoccupation was that America might turn away from them, not that West Germany should reappraise its transAtlantic ties.

title: Venezuela Aid to Bank Up
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 2 (AP)Venezuela will increase its contributions to the InterAmerican Development Bank by about $379million, a government spokesman said today.

title: ABSENT COLEMAN FOCUS OF PARLEY
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 2Though Dr. James S. Coleman, the sociologist, is vacationing in West Virginia, the University of Chicago professor dominated much of a threeday meeting here on equal education, where speakers and panelists accused him of abandoning the fight for school integration.

title: Personal Finance: Income of Scholars
description: Federal tax law has long held that scholarships and fellowships are not part of gross income and therefore are not subject to Federal income tax.

title: 4 Nixon Justices Dominate Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The voting solidarity of the four Justices named by President Nixon to the Supreme Court fell off perceptibly during the term that closed this week, but their power to control decisionmaking remained strong.

title: CONTROL OF AIRPORT CLARIFIED BY F.A.A.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration acknowledged yesterday that any decision of an airport operator to halt flying at a field would be dictated not by flight conditions in the air but only if something developed on the ground that affected the usability of runways.

title: P.B.A. Hints at Slowdown; Bars Formal Job Action
description: The leadership of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association voted yesterday against taking any formal job action in the wake of the dismissal of 5,000 city police officers.

title: MICHAEL HA ZANI, ISRAELI MINISTER
description: TEL AVIV, July 2Michael Hazani, Israeli Minister for Social Welfare, collapsed and died in Jenin on the West Bank of the Jordan today, pleading for ArabJewish amity. He was 62 years old.

title: A Mixed Bill IsOpener at Jacob's Pillow
description: LEES Mass., July 2The perilous nature of oneman institutions, no matter how worthwhile and seemingly vibrant, is that they may not survive the passing of their founder. Ted Shawn, who died three years ago, was synonymous with the birth, developmental and glory years of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. Some suspected in fact, that he was the Pillow and without him it wouldn't be the same. Well, it hasn't been exactly the same, but in the third season since his death, it has survived and is true to him in its fashion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again our city fathers are demonstrating their shortsightedness. As the inclusion of current expenses in the capital budget led in part to today's fiscal crisis, so will the cuts in the education budget lead to the future deterioration of New York's standing as America's business center.

title: It's Jazztime in Moscow Too
description: MOSCOW, July 2 (UPI)Some 10,000 Soviet jazz fans gave an ecstatic welcome to a group of American musicians last night for an evening devoted to Louis Armstrong, The Lenin Sports Palace was filled to overflowing for the first of five concerts by the New York Jazz Repertory Company.

title: Dan Dailey's Son Dead
description: SANTA MONICA. Calif., July 2 (UPI)Dan Dailey 3d, 29yearold son of the singer and dancer was found dead of a bullet wound early yesterday on the lawn in front of St. John's Hospital. The police said Mr. Dailey had apparently shot himself in the right side of the head. They said a note was discovered next to the body, but the contents were not disclosed. An autopsy was scheduled for today.

title: Not Much Guidance
description: The most charitable comment to be made about the recent report by Governor Carey's task force on the financing of education is that the panel's heart is approximately in the right place. It is easy to agree with its view that the state should carry a greater part of the burden in the financing of public schools, particularly in the hardpressed cities.

title: 2 Seized After a Man, 90, Is Robbed for Fifth Time
description: A 90yearold Bronx man who was beaten and robbed five times in the last year hopes the attempt on him again yesterday was the last. The police arrested two youths when the man went to a subway station to pay them $200 on their demand.

title: Chryslers Violating Air Law Found by E.P.A. Inspectors
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was turning over to the Justice Department for possible prosecution the question whether the Chrysler Corporation turned out cars that violated cleanair laws.

title: Bicentennial Comes Into Its Own Over the 4th, With Parades, Fireworks Displays, and Sousa
description: Most of the celebrations ape scheduled for July 4 itself, but some will be held on Saturday and Sunday. Most of the events will be on a local level, but apparently there is hardly a town or neighborhood that will not be saluting Old Glory in some way over the holiday weekend.

title: U.S. Says Stirling Homex Reported Phantom $ales
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the bankrupt Stirling Homex Corporation, once one of the nation's leading modular homebuilders, of creating phantom sales, making illegal political contributions, using illegal bugging equipment and making payoffs to union officials.

title: Britain Ends a Blockade On Oil Bound for Rhodesia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2Britain has ended her nineyear naval blockade of Mozambique. It was aimed at preventing the shipment of oil to Rhodesia in violation of United Nations sanctions imposed against the breakaway former British coiony in 1966 because of its racial policies.

title: Diane Mandle is Bride Of Eric Davis, Painter
description: Diane Mendle, an actress, was married yesterday noon to Eric Davis of London, painter and fashion designer. State Supreme Court Justice Alvin Ruskin performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton Inn in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: 26 Fire Department Companies Closed
description: The Fire Department shut down 26 of its 360 companies yesterday morning because of the city's financial crisis, but most firemen continued to hold out hope that Mayor Beame would somehow raise new money and that at least some of them would be restored.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER OFF
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over thecounter market continuer to fall for the second straight day in decreased trading. Prefpfittaking, a belief by some investors that bank prime interest rates may be raised shortly and an increase in gasoline prices appeared to be the depressing factors.

title: Gas Supplies Rise as Output is Increased
description: Supplies of gasoline in the United States rose last week for the first time since Feb. 21 as the nation's refineries increased their output to 85.7 per cent of capacity.

title: SIMON SEES SLOWING IN GAINS BY BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told a small, mostly silent assembly of black leaders today that job and social advancements for blacks would be stunted until the economy recovered.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Don Hogan Charles

title: Blast at Pat Nixon Home
description: CERRITOS, Calif., July 2 (UPI)A small explosive device damaged the Pat Nixon memorial home here early today. Sheriff's deputies said the explosion; which occurred about 2 A.M., had been caused by a device that was apparently tossed into the unoccupied farmstyle house where the former First Lady used to live. Damage was estimated to he, about $500.

title: Man Dies in Tank Blast
description: CENTRALIA, Ill., July 2 (UPI) One man was killed and six others were injured, two critically, when a steel, tank exploded yesterday at the Valley Steel Co. plant, sending shrapnel and flames shooting into a small group of workmen.

title: aidOff Women Police Officers Embittered
description: There is a house in Belmar on the New Jersey shore that is about to be painted a bitter pink, or so its summer occupants say.

title: Notes on People
description: A full cast was put on Gov. George C. Wallace's left leg yesterday and will remain for about three weeks. The simple fracture of the tibia the larger bone between ankle and knee  probably occurred during the Alabama Governor's physiotherapy exercises, according to his physician, Dr. Hamilton Hutchinson of Montgomery.

title: Radio
U.S and State Indict Hollander on Nursing Home Fraud Chargs
description: Eugene Hollander, who was long the chief spokesman for the city's nursinghome industry, was indicted by state and Federal grand juries yesterday on charges involving more than $1.2million in Medicaid and Medicare frauds.

title: and Fair
description: At the same time, the city must he fair and rational. Mayor Beame has egregiously abused and misused the dismissed workers and their families in his myopic effort to extract higher taxes from the State Legislature and a cowed citizenry.

title: No Amer Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Baltimore 3. Miami 2. Washington 4. Philadelphia 1. Denver 6, San Antonio 2.

title: Jazz Events
description: Noon to 2 P.M., Equitable Life Plaza, Avenue of the Americas and 51st Street: Zoot Sims and group (free).

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that the New Jersey Board of Higher Education had ordered a 50 per cent increase in tuition at the state's public colleges. The hoard put a recommendation by Ralph A. Dungan, Chancellor of Higher Education, for such an increase over for discussion at a meeting scheduled for July 25.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Magna Carta is Coming to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Almost 199 years after the rebellious American colonies declared their independence from the British crown, the British announced today that they planed to send one of their most cherished documents, one of the original copies of Magna Carta, to commemorate the success of that rebellion.

title: Sake Sets Its Cup For Male Drinker
description: KOBE, JapanIn an attempt to bolster sales of sake, the traditional Japanese rice wine, brewers have decided to emphasize the masculinity of the drink.

title: New Wheat Seed Offers 20% Output Gain
description: YODER, Kan.,  A longawaited breakthrough in the development of hybrid wheat seed has occurred this summer, offering America's winter wheat farmers the chance of eventually increasing their yields by at least 20 per cent.

title: James Robertson Justice Dead; Scottish Actor in Doctor Films
description: LONDON, July 2 James Robertson Justice, the Scottish actor who was perhaps best known for his role as a peppery surgeon in British comedy films, was found dead in bed today at his home in the village of King's Somborne in southern England. He was 70 years old.

title: 'Field Marshal and His Problems
description: For Sanitation Commissioner Robert Groh, the second full day of a citywide garbage strike brought with it a dizzying range of logistical problemsand all too few solutions.

title: Fire in Boston Subway Forces Hundreds to Flee
description: BOSTON, July 2 (AP)A three car subway train collided with a dangling overhead power cable in a tunnel today, setting the first car afire and forcing the evacuation of 400 passengers on foot.

title: MRS. WINANT OF CBS TO JOIN PUBLIC TV
description: Ethel Winant, a production and casting executive for CBSTV for two decades, is leaving the network July 14 to join the Children's Television Workshop as executive producer of its new history series contemplated for next season on public television.

title: ExLibrary Aide Arrested
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July (AP)The former director of the Wilmington Institute Library has been arrested on 31 counts charging him with stealing $80,750 in library money and then altering the ledger hooks to cover up. Jack W. Bryant, 49 years old, was released after posting bond to face an arraignment today.

title: Business Briefs
description: GENEVA, July 1 (UPI)New York has become a relatively cheap place to live compared with other major world cities, a leading business research company reported today.

title: THAI SAYS CHINESE DENY AIDING REBELS
description: PEKING, July 2Premier Kukrit Pramoj of Thailand said here tonight that Chinese leaders had denied they supported proCommunist insurgents in his country.

title: STARR REPORTS LOSS, CITES COURT BATTLE
description: The Starr Broadcasting Group, Inc., owner of a number of radio stations in the United States including WQIVFM here, lost $395,458 in the third quarter of the current fiscal year, according to Peter Starr, president of the concern. About 35 per cent of the current loss comes from legal expenses incurred in its battle with citizens groups that have challenged the license of WQIV, he said.

title: E.E.C. GAINS TIED TO INFLATION REIN
description: BRUSSELS, July 2 (Reuters) Lasting steady economic growth and a gradual reduction of unemployment inside the European Economic Community can only be obtained if the rise in prices slows down appreciably where it remains excessive, particularly in Britain, the Common Market's executive commission said in a draft report today.

title: U.S. Assails French Pilot for 74 Injuries
description: The National Transportation Safety Board criticized the pilot of an Air France jet yesterday for his actions in an encounter with turbulence that led to 15 injuries a year ago.

title: A Volcano in West Showing Signs of Life
description: CONCRETE, Wash., July 2Mount Baker, a 10,778foot longdormant volcano towering near this tiny town, is coming back to life and may soon provide the first major volcanic activity in the 48 contiguous states in 60 years.

title: CAREY HIRES AIDE TO STUDY OIL CASE
description: ALBANY, July 2  Governor Carey hired the former general counsel of the Democratic National Committee today to undertake a full investigation of the allegations that the Governor had used his influence to help arrange a big oil deal for his oilman brother.

title: June Retail Chain Sales Generally Held to May Gains
description: Sales of the latices largest retail chains in June generally held to the gains of May, continuing the better trend since Easter, according to results reported yesterday.

title: Miss Lauer Paces 11 Tour Qualifiers
description: ATLANTA, July 2 (UPIBonnie Lauer of Orchard Lake, Fich., has placed 11 qualifiers for the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: FORT LEE UPHELD ON RENT LEVELING
description: TRENTON, July 2A Fort Lee rentleveling ordiance Bra. iting landlords to 2.5 per cent rent increases was upheld today in Superior Court in Bergen County. According to Fort Lee's attorney, Armand Pohan, the 2.5 per cent rate is the lowest in the state.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Gillespie's Tone Offers Contrast With Hubbard's
description: The appearances of Freddie Hubbard and Dizzy Gillespie at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday provided effective contrasts on the state of the art of contemporary jazz trumpet playing.

title: Numerous Garbage Blazes Give Firemen One of Busiest Nights
description: Hundreds of small garbage firs throughout the five boroughs and two twoalarm blazes in vacant buildings in the South Bronx kept fire complains dashing from one area to another last night in what a department spokesman described as one of the busiest nights in anybody's memory.

title: NEW STATE OFFER TO CITY REPORTED IN FISCAL CRISIS
description: Mayor Beame was called to a meeting with Governor Carey, the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, and legislative leaders at the Executive Mansion in Albany last night amid indications that there was some movement in the stalled negotiations between Mr. Beame and Mr. Anderson.

title: LAYOFFS INVOLVE PAINFUL CHORES
description: The job of laying off nearly 19,000 mayoral agency employes preoccupied the managers of many city governmental units yesterday as they coped with complexities of paperwork and the conflicts of their own emotions.

title: EASTERN AGREES TO SELL ROUTES
description: Eastern Air Lines has agreed to sell to United Airlines its nonstop route authority between Chicago and New Orleans for $5million, subject to approval of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Yanks Beaten By Indians, 32
description: CLEVELAND, July 2Like a stick of dynamite with a delayed fuse, a strategic move made by Frank Robinson in the seventh inning tonight exploded in the Yankee collective faces in the ninth and led to a 32 victory by the Cleveland Indians.

title: EGYPTIAN DEMAND DIVIDES ISRAELIS
description: JERUSALEM, July 2A political debate over whether to accede to Egypt's demand for complete Israeli withdrawal from the strategically important Sinai mountain passes has opened deep divisions in the Israeli Government, the ruling Labor party and the smaller narties of right and left.

title: Celebrators Turning Defeats Into Victories
description: With revisionist ardor and. amnesiac delight, Bicentennial officials are wiping the slate clean of Revolutionary War defeats.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey vetoed a bill that would have given veterans of the two world wars end the Korean and Vietnam conflicts an absolute preference in retention of Civil Service positions over their nonveteran colleagues in the event of layoffs or job elimination. Approval of the measure could have created havoc in New York City, which is faced with mass layoffs.

title: At Namagansett
description: The Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association, which has refused to run horses without a new contract, set up picket lines at the track.

title: NUISANCE TAXES I GAIN IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, July 2 Democratic leaders in the Assembly have abandoned their commitment to a state income tax, and were reported this evening to have enough votes to approve an alternative package of nuisance taxes that would cancel most of the $384million in state budget cuts ordered by Governor Byrne.

title: Ford and Critics Jockey on Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The White House and Congressional Democrats began jockeying today or advantage in a political battle over prices for oil and natural gas that is expected to dominate the capital's business in July.

title: Rise in the Dollar Best for the Year
description: The dollar gained strongly on world currency markets yesterday. The rise was the largest for a single day this year.

title: Flies Pose Health Threat As Garbage Piles Grow
description: Simpson Street in the South Bronx is always a place of decay, but yesterday it was worse. Flies hang over the uncollected garbage in little clouds, and the people on Simpson Street said this was the worst thing of all.

title: Market Place
description: At today's prices, I.B.M. must seem attractive to some who have always said they would buy the stock if it did not carry such a high priceearnings ratio.

title: KENT TRIAL IS TOLD OF FIRE IN AIR PLEA
description: CLEVELAND, July 2 (UPI)A former Ohio National Guard staff sergeant testified today that he screamed, If you're going to fire, fire in the air, when guardsmen began shooting at antiwar demonstrations at Kent State University on May 4, 1970.

title: First Claims for Jobless Aid Increase 10,000 in a Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) First claims for regular state unemployment insurance benefits in the week ending June 21 increased by about 10,000 from the previous week's level, the Government said today.

title: Text of the Statement Broadcast by Mayor Beanie
description: Following is a transcript of Mayor Beanie's broadcast statement from Gracie Mansion yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Dr. May and Wife, Nutritionists, Die
description: Dr. Jacques M. May, widely known medical geographer, and his wife, the former Donna McLelland, died Monday in an automobile accident in Tunisia. He was 79 years old and she was 35. They lived in Chatham, Mass.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN PROCEEDINGS

title: 17 Seized in Penns Ylvania State Employe Strire
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 2 (AP)Pennsylvania won court injunctions and arrests mounted today as a strike by an estimated total of 50,000 state employes entered its second day.

title: Don't Call UsWe'll Call You. Or, Blowing a C.I.A. Career.
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is so much in the news these days that I thought it might be interesting to tell how it recruited me more than twenty years ago when it, and I, were still in the formative years. I imagine my experience was not unique, and many of those who are now in the C.I.A.'s upper echelons must have been recruited the same way.

title: Senatorial Group Received by Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, July 2A United States Senatorial delegation conferred with Leonid I. Brezhnev for two and one half hours today and came away saying they were convinced that the Soviet leader was genuinely worried about the arms race.

title: U.S. Yachtsman First in Norway
description: HANKOE, Norway, July 2 (AP)An American yachtsman, Albert Fay of the Texas Corinthian Club, was declared the unofficial winner of the King Olav Gold Cup for 5.5Meter yachts today.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: By the time he came to live with the Adlers, Jonathan had been in 13 foster homes and institutions. He was 9 years old. This, the agency hoped, would be the last placement, Jonathan was legally free for adoption and the Adlers, a childless couple, said they were interested in adopting him.

title: 2 Indian Homers Sink Yanks, Medich, 32
description: CLEVELAND, July 3The fireworks that exploded at Cleveland Stadium tonight did not celebrate, one day early, the 199th birthday of the United States. Nor did they signify the end of the Yankees fivecity, 15day sojourn away from New York.

title: A Damaged Mast Forces Sloop Out of Ocean Race
description: War Baby, the 68foot sloop from Bermuda, found the pounding seas of the Atlantic Ocean too tough in the transatlantic race to England and on Monday night her 90foot mast broke. The 11yearold vessel returned yesterday to Newport, R.I., the starting point of the 3,100mile race last Saturday.

title: KISSINGER VISITED BY ISRAELI ENVOY FOR SECRET TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel flew secretly to the Virgin Islands to confer on Tuesday night and yesterday morning with Secretary of State Kissinger on what Israel could expect to receive for making a new EgyptianIsraeli accord possible.

title: Faults in Antiskid Device
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 3 (UPI). A potential malfunction in the B. F. Goodrich Company's antiskid device for truck trailers has been uncovered by extensive ontheroad use, the company reported today. The malfunction can cause significant loss of brake pressure at speeds above 30 miles an hour, Goodrich said, in a report to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES STATE LOAN UNIT
description: The vice president of a teamsters local here filed suit in State Supreme Court yesterday, challenging the constitutionality of the Municipal Assistance corporation and its right to issue bonds.

title: 3 Aluminum Makers Bow To U.S. PriceDelay Plea
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Ford Administration, warning of possible adverse effects on the economy, asked four major aluminum companies today to delay proposed price increases for 30 days. Two of them, the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company, immediately agreed.

title: Basques Use France As AntiSpanish Base
description: BAYONNE, France  It is the season for tourists here in the Basque country, and there is no visible sign of tension in the sparkling resorts aiong the Bay of Biscay.

title: Rev. Raymond W. Schouten, ExHead of Canisius College
description: BUFFALO, July 3 (AP)The Rev. Raymond W. Schouten, president of Canisius College here from 1947 to 1952, died today in Sisters Hospital at the age of 69.

title: Amex and OTC Stocks Rise in a Lackluster Day
description: After a slow start, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market closed higher yesterday in lackluster trading.

title: INMATE HIDING OUT IN RAHWAY PRISON
description: RAHWAY, July 3 (UPI) Guards searched throughout the Rahway State Prison today for a convicted murderer believed hiding out to avoid a disciplinary transfer to the Trenton State Prison.

title: Rape Defendant Loses Appeal on Resistance
description: A New Jersey appeals court ruled yesterday that the victim of a rape is not duty bound to resist to the uttermost, but should resist as much as possible under the circumstances.

title: Mitchell Disbarred As Lawyer in State
description: John N. Mitchell, the former United States Attorney General who was convicted of perjury and conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Watergate scandal, was disbarred yesterday from practicing law in New York State.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOW. TO BE AWAKE AND ALIVE. By Mildred Newman and Bernard Berkowitz. 112 pages. Random House. $4.95.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE FIELD STABILIZING; INFLATION SLOWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The nation's job picture apparently has stabilized and inflation continues to be moderate, Labor Department reports for June indicated today.

title: Wilson Cabinet Gaining Support For Limiting Wage Rise to 10%
description: LONDON, July 3Prime Minister. Harold Wilson, facing unrest in the Labor party and anger among trade unions, insisted today that his Government would press forward with plans to limit wage increases to 10 per cent.

title: Salmon Making Comeback
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Once almost extinct in New England, salmon are now being produced there by the thousand. Last year, 2,600 of them were raised by Maine Salmon Farms, Inc., under a program sponsored by the University of New Hampshire and funded by a federal Sea Grant. This year it is expected that 20,000 pansized fish will be marketed to hotels and England.

title: Phillips Collection Curator in Capital Stole 21 Prints Valued at Over $70,000
description: A group of 21 prints worth more than $70,000 were stolen earlier this year from the Phillips Collection, a leading gallery of modern art in Washington, by its curator, Richard Friedman, according to the gallery's director, Laughlin Philips.

title: WARNING IS URGED ON DIABETES PILES
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Food and Drug Administration is proposing e strongly worded label for pills used by more than a million diabetics, warnning that patients may be more likely to die of heart disease if they become regular users of the drugs.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Now and then, even the most ardent of Francophiles must tire of French restaurants and sneak off to an Italian, Chinese, Mexican or Indian place for relief from an exquisitely adjusted but, after all, not very flexible formula for dining. The very perfection of the formula has made the French palate the most sensitive, but at the same time the most chauvinistic, in the world, unless the Italian rivals it in the latter form of provincialism.

title: LEADER OF RADICALS IS SEIZED IN HOUSTON
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced tonight the arrest of Thera Wheller, believed to be one of the founders of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: THOMAS P. SKIDD
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 3Thomas P. Skidd, a former athlete and a tax consultant, died today at Norwalk Hospital. He was 69 years old and had lived here until moving to Westport a few years ago.

title: As Picnics Go, It Was an Event, And Not Just Because of the Food
description: CARVERSV]LLE, Pa.It's show business, said Robert L. Green, dashing between twin ovens holding ham en =Ate, a refrigerator laden with 20 varieties of aspic, and tables, counters, chairs and stools covered with baskets of homemade bread, casseroles of meatballs and mushrooms, platters of duck, meat loaf and vegetables, bowls of cold rice salad with anchovies, seafood and pimientos and silver servers heaped with dessert breads and fruit.

title: CORRECTION
description: Through misinformation supplied to The New York Times, two events were incorrectly listed in yesterday's Bicentennial weekend Going Out Guide. The Thunderbirds Air Force jet demonstration of precision flying will be seen at 2 P.M. today at Jones Beach and at 2 P.M. tomorrow at Coney Island. The fireworks display off Battery Park is scheduled for 9 P.M. today.

title: Slower is Saner
description: Out of the unlamented long lines and No Gas Today signs at service stations last year came a genuine effort to economize fuel consumption by reducing speed limits on the highways. The 55mileanhour regulation brought the realization to many drivers that going like sixty (or seventy) didn't make all that much of a time difference. It even became almost pleasant to return to what used to be called motoring, instead of instinctively stepping on the gas.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Carrying Out Major Aims During Crisis
description: NEW DELHI, July 3An aging state railway executive was dismissed. Plans to rejuvenate old tea plantations were proclaimed. Delhi utility workers were threatened with strict diciplinary action if they showed a lack of visor.

title: Jersey Treasurer Says Tax Package Will Leave a Deficit of $133.2Million
description: TRENTON, July 3 State Treasurer Richard C. Leone said today that the package of increased sales taxes and other nonincome levies under consideration by the Legislature would still leave the state with a budget deficit of as much as $133.2million.

title: About Real Estate
description: WHITE PLAINSIt is customary to fit pioneering forms of realestata development into an appropriate phase of longterm change.

title: POLLEN LOOKS BAD INSTATE THIS YEAR
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 3 (UPI)The outlook for the 1975 pollen season in New Jersey looks bad for hayfever sufferers, a medical technologist said today.

title: WARNING IS URGED ON DIABETES PILLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Food and Drug Administration is proposing a strongly worded label for pills used by more than a million diabetics, warnning that patients may be more likely to die of heart disease if they become regular users of the drugs.

title: CURB IS PROPOSED ON VAGINAL DRUG
description: A leading medical publication has recommended that Flagyl, a drug widely used to treat vaginal infections, be restricted to those cases that cannot be treated by other means because Flagyl causes cancer in animals and can damage genes.

title: Public Library Gets MatchingFund Offer
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has offered to match dollar for dollar up to $625,000 in gifts made by Nov. 30, 1975 to the Endowment on behalf of the New York Public Library.

title: The Dance: Raymonda
description: One's first view of any production of Raymonda is apt to be at least mildly confusing. With a young girl, a Christian crusader and a Saracen knight, to say nothing of a mysterious woman intended to be guardian of the castle, the story is not easy to follow, and although the ballet's music by Glazunov falls easily on the ear it falls there just a little unmemorably.

title: Bolshoi Pique Dame ls the Real Thing
description: When the Metropolitan Opera staged Tchaikovsky's Queen of Spades a few years ago, there were many cuts, especially in the choral sections, and the idea seemed to be'to get the opera ended as soon as possible. Wednesday night, the Bolshoi Opera presented its first Pique Dame (to use the officially listed, and more familiar title), and this was more like the real thing. It was complete, it was sung in Russian, and it had all the trimmings, including a charming little thirdact ballet, danced by lovely young women.

title: Wohlhuter Wins 800 In Norway
description: OSLO, Norway, July 3 (AP)  Rick Wohihuter of Chicago gained revenge over Lutsiano Susanj of Yugoslavia tonight, winning an 800meter race in 1 minute 46.4 seconds at Bislett Stadium.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB Payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: SPACESUIT LEAKS INFINUPRACTIU
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 3 (UPI)The three American astronauts who will rendezvous with a Russian crew in space later this month put their spacecraft through a final practice run today, but discovered a leak in their spacesuit system.

title: Western Union Corp. Files For Higher Rates with F.C.C.
description: The Western Union Corporration filed yesterday with the Fifferal. Communication Commission for higher rates for seldcted Telex and TWX services and terminals.

title: Chief Executive Retiring at 56 At Embattled Chrysler Corp.
description: DETROIT, July 3Lynn A. Townsend, chairman and chief executive officer of the embattled Chrysler Corporation, announced today his intention to retire Oct. 1.

title: Pieces of Dreams Show Offered at Carnegie Hall
description: The Newport Jazz Festival concert entitled Pieces of Dreams at Carnegie Hall late Wednesday night brought together three artists with no obvious affinities except that none was particularly abrasive or traditional.

title: HIGHLEVEL TALKS ENDED WALKOUT
description: Yesterday's agreement ending the walkout of city sanitationmen grew out of highlevel negotiations that were under way even as the sanitationmen's union and the city were jousting in court and before thousands of workers went out on strike.

title: Conviction in Rape Questioned On Basis of Resistance Upheld
description: A New Jersey appeals court ruled yesterday that the victim of a rape attack is not duty bound to resist to the uttermost, but should resist as much as possible under the circumstances.

title: New Look for the Old Game
description: It's too early to call it a revolution, but the most significant change in baseball this yearmaybe this generation is that the boys are running again. They are stealing bases in nearly record numbers and in the American League they may steal more bases than at any other time since 1917, just before Babe Ruth started his own revolution by hitting home runs. Mickey Rivers of the California Angels already has stolen 44 bases, almost three times as many as all the New York Mets combined. The Angels and the Oakland A's already have stolen more than 100 apiece, with half the season remaining. smart computer in Boston has calculated that the American League will steal 555 its present rate and the National League, 1,098. And even 36yearold Lou Brock the St. Louis Cardinals, who made it 118 times last summer, has run the gantlet 30 times in three months despite disclaimers that his best thievery is past.

title: A Declaration
description: This is the age of the impersonal, in which people sleep in beehive apartment buildings, transport themselves upon eightlane highways and aircraft the size of movie theaters, and conduct their business in the swarming and boundless cities of the twentieth century. It is an age, too, of public affairs, in which the relations of governments, the budgets of cities, the pronouncements of great officials seem somehow to outweigh the ordinary and persisting entanglemerits of men and women, the old verities of the human heart.

title: Madras People Jubilant As the Monsoon Comes
description: NEW DELHI, July 3  It rained in Madras today.

title: M.W. BADWIN, 72, MEDIEVALIST, DIES
description: Marshall W. Baldwin, an authority on medieval European history and professor emeritus of history at New York University, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital He was 22 years old and lived at 82 Ditmars Street City Island, the Bronx.

title: Frank Carrington, CoFounder Of Paper Mill Playhouse, Dies
description: Frank Carrington cofounder and producer of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N. J., died yesterday at his home in Millburn. He lived in a conyerted barn on Brookside Drive near the theater he operated. He was about 73 years old.

title: 3 Aluminum Makers Bow To U.S. PriceDelay Plea
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Ford Administration, warning of possible adverse effects on the economy, asked four major aluminum companies today to delay proposed price increases for 30 days. Two of them, the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company, immediately agreed.

title: CORRECTION
description: Through misinformation supplied to The New York Times, two events were incorrectly listed in yesterday's Bicentennial weekend Going Out Guide, The Thunderbirds Air Force jet demonstration of precision flying will be seen at 2 P.M. today at Jones Beach and at 2 P.M, tomorrow at Coney Island. The fireworks display off Battery Park is scheduled for 9 P.M. today.

title: Phillies Beat Cards and a Struggling Gibson, 74
description: He used to throw bullets, rising fastballs that overpowered the best hitters in the National League. They made him a Cy Young Award winner in 1968 and 1970; the most valuable player in the league in 1968, the career strikeout leader among righthanded pitchers, the active pitcher with the most victories in either league.

title: The Pop Life
description: Some presentday hits are said to ship gold or ship platinum, which in the argot of the record business means that the Very announcement of their release provokes a massive demand.

title: German Reserves Cut
description: The Bundesbank has cut minimum reserve requirements of West German banks on domestic and foreign liabilities by 10 per cent. P. 33.

title: U.S. Beginning to Fly Refugees Back to Asia
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The United States has started flying South Vietnamese refugees who wish to return to their native land toward home, Administration sources said today.

title: Events Today
description: BOLSHOI OPERA, Metropolitan Opera House, Mussorgskv's Boris Godunov, 7:30.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The State Department announced yesterday that Secretary of State Kissinger and the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, Simcha Dinitz, met secretly in the Virgin Islands Tuesday night and Wednesday morning to discuss what concessions would be made to Israel if she yielded to Egypt's insistence on Israel's withdrawal from the Mitla and Gidi mountain passes in Sinai. The meeting was reportedly held at Israel's request. Israel, it was said, sought firm assurances of more future American economic, military and political support if she gave up the two mountain passes. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: A Catch22 Develops When Defendant Turns Victim
description: What happens when a de fendant in a serious felony case turns out to have been the victim and then tries to seek damages?

title: BUNDESBANK CUTS RESERVES FLOOR
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 3 (Reuters)The Bundesbank said it had cut the bank's minimum reserve requirements on domestic and foreign liabilities 10 per cent effective July 1.

title: GEORGE P. LIMB
description: WASHINGTON, July 3George P. Lamb, a lawyer who specialized in defending antitrust proceedings before the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal courts, died here at Georgetown University Hospital Tuesday. He was 65 years old.

title: Wimbledon Results
description: Arthur Ashe, Miami, defeated Tony Roche, Australia, 57, 64, 75, 89, 64; Jimmy Connors, Belleville, III., defeated Roscoe Tanner, Lookout Mountain, Tenn., 64, 61.

title: Florida TakeOyer Of Racing Weiglied
description: TALLAHASSEE, Flaz, July 3 (AP)Gov. Reubin Askew named three members today to a newly created committee to study the feasibility of a state takeover of horse racing in Florida.

title: As Holiday Beckons,Teen Hitchhikers Defy the Dangers
description: TOMS RIVER, July 3Be witched by a freewheeling  mode of transportation as indigenous to this country as the dandelion, hitchhikers armed with bathing suit, back pack and duffle bag are expected to take to New Jersey roads in increasing slumbers this holiday weekend.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: CLASSY COMFORT The Americana Hotel's French Quarter is a pleasant surprise one of the few cocktail lounges in the midtown Broadway  Seventh Avenue area where you can dance on a parquet larger than a dime to live music, that of the Tony Terini Trig. You can also relax at the center bar (Scotch is $2.45) or among surrounding clusters of divans and wingback chairs. With its red and black decor and subdued lighting, this room is more suggestive to one Louisianian of chic Madrid than of the venerable Vieux Carre of New Orleans.

title: A.H. Benjamin Weds Nancy Kaufman
description: Nancy Sue Kaufman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Kaufman of Bridgewater, N. J., was married yesterday evening to Andrew H. Benjamin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin I. Benjamin of Salisbury, Md. The ceremony was performed at the Somerville (N. J.) Inn by Rabbi Michael Abraham of Temple Beth El in Somerville.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERJoseph. Montef lore Hospital and Medical Center notes with sorrow the passing of Joseph Adler, rather of Robert Adler, administrator, Ambulatory Care Divi. story of our Hospital. Our deepest sympathy to Mr. Adler and other members of his family.

title: Woodlynne is Denied Injunction To Bar Black Church's Services
description: CAMDEN, July 3Judge Louis L. Goldman of State Superior, Court today denied a request by the Borough of Woodlynne to bar a black church from conducting services in alleged violation of local zoning laws.

title: About New York
description: Book  in 1927. when he Was a schoolboy sneaking up the hack stairway to listen to Fletcher Hendenson's orchestra at the old Roseland Ballroom, John Hammond was saying New York was already the jazz capital of the world.

title: Allen Street Baths Still Going Strong at 70
description: The Allen Street Baths celebrated its 70th anniversary yesterday with a splash.

title: RUMANIA SPEEDS JEWS DEPARTURE
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Rumania has speeded emigration of Jews to Israel in the last three weeks in an evident effort to comply with United States stipulations linking that movement to the granting of trade preferences, diplomatic officials reported today.

title: A.M.A. Confirms and Justifies Lobbying, for Haynsworth in 69
description: A spokesman for the American Medical Association confirmed yesterday that the association had helped the Nixon White House lobby for the confirmation of Judge Clement L. Haynsworth Jr. to the Supreme Court in 1969 and called the effort entirely proper.

title: Connors, Ashe Win and Reach Wimbledon Tennis Final Round
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 3  Jimmy Connors crushed Roscoe Tanner, 64, 61, 64, today on center court in 80 minutes. Saturday he will meet Arthur Ashe, a 57, 64, 75, 89, 64 victor over Tony Roche, in the first allAmerican tennis final at Wimbledon since Jack Kramer granted a meager six games to Tom Brown in 1947.

title: Grain Loan to ExLegislator Described
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., July 3 Senator Dick Clark, Democrat of Iowa, said today he had learned that one of the world's largest grain corporations had lent money to a former state Representative so that he could start a business that would be responsible for inspecting the corporation's grain to determine its value and quality.

title: Rain, Dark Curb Round For Golfers
description: MILWAUKEE, July 3 (AP)  Gibby Gilbert and Ken Still tied for the lead among those who finished the second round today as lightning, rain and darkness forced suspension of play in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: Judge Bought Land in Alabama From GreatAunt of Defendant
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 27 In a series of complicated transactions and negotiations, a Federal judge here recently arranged to purchase valuable property at less than its estimated market price from the elderly relative of a young man on whom he was about to pass sentence.

title: H.E.W. CHIEF SUED ON SEGREGATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Three civil rights organizations asked the Federal District Court here today to compel the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to require Northern and Western States to end school segregation or face termination of their Federal school aid.

title: Collision of U. S. and Soviet Subs Off Siberia in 1974 Is Recounted
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif.. July 3 (UPI)  A Soviet nuclear submarine and the United States nuclearpowered submarine Pintado, both carrying nuclear weapons, collided in 1974 while the Pintado was engaged in an intelligence gathering mission for the Navy and the Central Intelligence Agency in Soviet territorial waters in the Pacific, it was reported today.

title: The Women Head Home
description: MEXICO CITY. July 3The 10year plan of action unanimously adopted at the International Women's Year World Conference here will probably benefit women from the developing nations more than women from the industrialized worldif it benefits anybody at all.

title: American League
description: Cleveland 3. New York 2 (n.). Detroit 9, Baltimore 5 (n.). Milwaukee 3, Boston 2 10 inn., n.). California 7, Minnesota 6. Chicago 3, Oakland 2. Kansas City 10, Texas 3 (n.).

title: GARDINER BOWDEN
description: Gardiner Sutphin Bowden, president of J. B. Bowden, Inc., jewel manufacturers here, and a descendant of Lion Gardiner of Gardiners Island and Rufus King, American statesman, died Wednesday in Brooklyn Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 441 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Mrs Price Tennis Victor
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I.. July 3  Mrs. Adria Price of Roslyn Heights, L. I., defeated Mrs. Eleanor Wright of Suffern, N. Y., 62, 61, today in the final of the first New York State women's 35years  old  and  over tennis championship at the Racquet Club.

title: Killings in Latin Quarter Expose Web of Terrorism
description: PARIS, July 3The special police captain thought he was pushing a light switch at 9 Rue Toullier, a warren of old apartments in the Latin Quarter near the Sorbonne. But it was a doorbell, and it was the wrong door.

title: Station WRVRFM Sold to Sonderling By Riverside Church
description: Radio station WRVRFM, which features jazz on most of its programs, has been sold by the Riverside Church to the Sonderling Broadcasting Corporation for $2.3million.

title: OUTBOUND TRAFFIC FROM CITY HEAVY
description: Braving traffic jams and the threat of severe thunderstorms, New Yorkers streamed out of town yesterday for the long Fourth of July holiday weekend, leaving the Big Apple and its uncollected garbage to steam in the muggy weather.

title: Big Store Sales Up 7%.
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.06billion, up 7 pet cent from the yearearlier $994 million. Total retail store sales were about $10.93billion, up 4 per cent from last year's $10.51billion.

title: State Fire Fighters Group Backs Peyser for Senate,
description: The New York State Professional Fire Fighters Association announced yesterday that it was endorsing Representative Peter A. Peyser, Westchester County Republican, in his planned 1976 United States Senate primary race for the seat now held by Senator James L. Buckley.

title: Ford vs. Solzhenitsyn
description: Does President Ford know the difference betweendtente and appeasement? This unlikely question arises in light of the news that President Ford decided not to receive Nobel laureate Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn because to do so would be inconsistent with dtente. Thus one of the world's leading writers, the most eloquent contemporary Russian enomy of dictatorship, was snubbed by an occupant of the White House who otherwise finds time to receive eminent soccer players and lovely cotton queens.

title: McFeeley Scores Accoid On Sanitation Rehiring
description: The head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association reacted angrily last night to the city's decision to reinstate only 2,000 of 5,000 laidoff police officers and accused Mayor Beame and the leader of the sanitation workers union of playing game of patsy at the expense of the Police Department.

title: Community Land Use
description: The legal merrygoround on which the nation's communities have been whirling in regard to growth controls has just received another spin.

title: Bluefish Are Moving Into L. I. Waters
description: AREA ABluefish appear to be moving up the New Jersey and Long Island coasts in increasing numbers. Capt. Howard Rogan of Bogates Basin said yesterday that loads of the choppers were being taken about 20 miles southeast of Bridle by anglers using mossbunkers as chum and smelts and butterfish as bait. The sizes ranged from 8 to 12 pounds.

title: Portugal Planning The Nationalization Of Radio Stations
description: LISBON, July 3 (UPI) Portugal's military rulers said today that they would nationalize the country's radio stations in a move aimed at ending a power struggle over control of a Roman Catholic station.

title: KISSINGER VISITED BY ISRAELI ENVOY FOR SECRETTALKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel flew secretly to the Virgin Islands to confer on Tuesday night and yesterday morning with Secretary of State Kissinger on what Israel could expect to receive for making a new EgyptianIsraeli accord possible.

title: Met La Traviata in the Bronx Proves to Be a Delightful Event
description: The first of the Metropolitan Opera's parks performances of La Traviata took place Wednesday night at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, and it was by and large a delightful occasion. Even if there were a lot fewer people than, the more than 75,000 who turned up the previous night in Central Parkpolice estimates were around 15,000, which seemed generousthe weather arid, one suspects, the performer were lust rewarding.

title: Market Place
description: The Amerace Corporation had planned a gentlemanly takeover of the Anchor Coupling Company, Inc. There was to be no surreptitious accumulation of shares, no proxv fieht.

title: Aluminum Price Rises Are Put Off Reluctantly
description: Three major aluminum producers reluctantly agreed yesterday to postpone for 30 days planned price increases in line with a request from the Council on Wage and Price Stability. The Aluminum Company of America, the Reynolds Metals Company and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation issued statements indicating they would comply with the request sent to them by Albert Rees, director of the council.

title: Ronson is Planning To Buy Its Stock
description: The Ronson Corporation, manufacturer of cigarette lighters and other metal products, announced yesterday an agreement in principle with Liquigas S.P.A. of Italy and its subsidiary, Linuifin. A.G.

title: Rail Ton Mileage Off 9.7%
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.4 billion tonmiles, 9.7 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 465,961 cars, 10.5 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 21.8 per cent below last year.

title: Library Parley Warns of Censorship
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3Fears of government interference in free use of libraries was expressed this week at the annual conference of the American Library Association. Robert Wedgeworth, executive director of the association made an apocalyptic forecast of what libraries might be like in the year 2000.

title: Secaucus is Setting Pace In Housing for the Aged
description: SECAUCUS, July 3A $2.8million, six story apartment complex is providing housing for more than 100 older men and women here, the first in the state to be financed under the Federal Government's Housing and Urban Development Section 23 for Leased Housing for the Elderly.

title: Albany Compromise Gives City $330Million in Taxes
description: ALBANY, July 3  The Governor and the leaders of the Legislature announced the outlines of a basic agreement this afternoon to give New York City $330million in new taxing authority and the state's school districts up to $190million in increased aid.

title: Fire Aide Taken as Hostage by Crowd
description: An assistant Fire Department commissioner went out yesterday to plead with angry residents of an area of Brooklyn's Bushwick section for the release of the 14 firemen they were holding hostage in protest against the shutting down of their neighborhood firehouse. Instead of winning their release, he succeeded only in being taken hostage himself.

title: Playing Games
description: With an assist from illegally striking sanitationmen and other fractions city employes, Mayor Beame appears to have scored a victory in his stubborn fight for new taxing powersbut at heavy cost in civic disorder, continuing labor unrest and future fiscal uncertainty, to say nothing of the added burden of punitively high municipal levies.

title: South Africa Ban Balked In Davis Cup
description: LONDON, July 3 (AP)A boycott by African nations was hinted at today after the Davis Cup nations, meeting in London, agreed not to ban South Africa from the international tennis series.

title: HOMOSEXUAL HIRING IS REVISED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) The United Statei Civil Service Commission is taking a new approach on the suitability of homosexual applicants for government employment.

title: Albany Compromise Gives City $330Million in Taxes
description: ALBANY, July 3The Governor and the leaders of the Legislature announced the outlines of a basic agreement this afternoon to give New York City $330million in new taxing authority and the state's school districts up to $190million in increased aid.

title: DR. LOUIS A. BUIE, 84, PROCTOLOGIST, DEAD
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., July 3 (AP) Dr. Louis A. Buie, a Mayo Clinic pioneer and founder of the clinic's proctology section, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The State Department announced yesterday that Secretary of State Kissinger and the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, Simcha Dinitz, met secretly in the Virgin Islands Tuesday night and Wednesday morning to discuss what concessions would be made to Israel if she yielded to Egypt's insistence on Israel's withdrawal from the Mitla.and GEidi mountain passes in Sinai. The meeting was reportedly held at Israel's request. Israel, it was said, sought firm assurances of more future American economic, military and political support if she gave up the two mountain passes. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Wolf Lade jinsky, Land Reformer, Dies; Helped to Break Feudal System in Japan
description: Wolf Ladejinsky, a leading American agricultural techmcian who played a key role in agrarian reform in Asia, died yesterday in George Washington University Hospital an Washington. He was 76 years old.

title: REFINANCING SET BY FREEDOM BANK
description: The financially troubled Freedom National Bank announced yesterday a $3.7million refinancing agreement in which most of the city's major financial institutions and the Ford Foundation are primary participants.

title: FUND MISUSE LAID TO COAST OFFICIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, July 3The Los Angeles Times reported today that the Lieutenant Governor of California, Mervyn M. Dymally, had misused funds from an institute he established to help to bring minority youths into government.

title: RUFUS WESSON
description: Rufus Wesson, a retired executive of the Eastman Kodak Company, died Tuesday in Rochester, where he lived. His age was 61.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 189.8 from 189.9 last week.

title: Dow Index Gains by 1.41 In Day of Light Trading
description: Stock prices overcame early declines to close slightly ahead yesterday in quiet preholiday trading.

title: Rededication
description: On July 3, 1776, John Adams wrote to his wife: I am well aware of the toil, and blood, and treasure, that will cost us to maintain this Declaration, and support and defend these States. Yet, through all the gloom, I can see the rays of ravishing light and glory.  One year later, as Adams walked about Philadelphia on the night of July 4 and saw lighted candles in thousands windows, he said: I think it was the most splendid illumination I ever saw.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Bridge:
description: Declarers should sometimes bear in mind the legend of Robert Bruce and the spider. The Scottish hero, it will be recalled, after repeated failures against the Sassenachs to the south, was so impressed by the industry of a spider that doggedly preserved with a web that was posing construction problems that he returned to battle once more and was victorious.

title: PAN AM SIGNS PACT WITH U.S. AIR FORCE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, July 3The Air Force today signed the 23d consecutive contract with Pan American World Airways to operate the missile range from Florida to the Indian Ocean. This year's award of over $64million brings the lifetime total of this contract to $1.7billion for the airline's operation of the range.

title: Legislator and 6 Held In Firehouse Protest
description: Assemblywoman Marie M. Runyon, a Democrat who represents the West Side, and six other demonstrators were arrested last night after they blocked northbound traffic on Broadway at 113th Street for nearly three hours to protest the closing of Engine Company 47's firehouse at 502 West 113th Street.

title: US, JOBLESS RATE HELD STABILIZING; INFLATION SLOWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The nation's job picture apparently has stabilized and inflation continues to be moderate, Labor Department reports for June indicated today.

title: KILLER OF 11 GUILTY IN FAMILY MURDERS
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, July 3 (AP) A panel of three judges today convicted James U. Ruppert of aggravated murder in the Easter slaying of 11 members of his family.

title: ALL SANITATIONMEN BACK ON JOB; 2,000 OF THE LAIDOFF POLICEMEN AND 750 FIREMEN TO RETURN TODAY
