description: Even as the economy is shifting from recession to recovery some business leaders see a gathering capital crunch on the horizon.

title: CIA. PLANS TO KEEP EQUIPMENT SECRET
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)The Justice Department says it is studying the Central Intelligence Agency's refusal to comply with a requirement that Government agencies describe their electronic surveillance equipment to the Attorney General.

title: COAST LAW OPENS HOUSING TO FAMILIES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 4The Board of Supervisors here has passed an ordinance prohibiting discrimination against families with children in the rental or leasing of homes and apartments. The objective of the move is to stem the flight of families from the city.

title: Jazz Events
description: Noon to 2 P.M., Roosevelt Field, Garden City, L. I. Rudd., Rich and Orchestra.

title: ACCOUNTANT ADMITS GUILT IN CHECK PLOT
description: LOS ANGELES, July 4 (UPI) A New York accountant hasi entered a surprise guilty pleal in an alleged Mafia plot tot bilk the city of $3.5million byl cashing stolen blank checks one the City Treasury. 1

title: Issue and Debate: A Shortage of Capital?
description: Perhaps the top item on the list for many business executives is faster depreciation of capital facilities for tax purposes. They note that the rate of recapture permitted by law in the United States is among the slowest of all developed nations. The recent high rate of inflation, which some businessmen tend to extrapolate almost to eternity as ammunition for their argument, has made faster writeoffs a matter of urgency.

title: Lisbon Calls for Calm as Leftists March
description: LISBON, July 4 President Francisco da Costa Gomes tonight urgently appealed for calm and discipline after almost a week of agitation and rumors.

title: LEGAL AID BOARD READY TO BE SET UP
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The new Legal Services Corporation to provide free legal advice for the poor is scheduled to come into official being next week, a full year after Congress authorized its establishment.

title: Wall, on Third 67 Leads by 3 Shots
description: MILWAUKEE, July 4 (AP) Art Wall, who had not shot a competitive round in the 6Q's this year until two days ago, scored his third consecutive 67 today and took a threestroke lead into tomor row's final round of the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: F.B.I. Copter Crashlands During Pine Ridge Search
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D (UPI)A Federal Bureau of Investigation helicopter carrying four men crashlanded tonight 15 miles south of Oglala, S.D., where two F.B.I. agents were killed last week. A spokeman for the bureau said that no one was hurt.

title: Mrs. King Wins Her Sixth Wimbledon Singles Title, 60, 61
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 Billie Jean King trounced Evonne Goolagong Cawley, 60, 61, in just 39 minutes today to win what she says will be her last major singles tennis title and to leave Wimbledon in a blaze of glory.

title: N.A.A.0. P. Appeals to A gencies To Guard Minorities Job Rights
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, concluding its 66th annual convention here today called on civil rights enforcement agencies, the courts and Congress to protect the job rights of minorities and women during the recession.

title: Canadian Woman Ransomed
description: GALGARY, Alberta, July 4 (AP)A banker's wife was rel???ed unharmed today after a $247,000 ransom was paid to her kidnappers, the police said. G?? Tunnicliffe, 26 years old, was found handcuffed and gagged in a van near her home. Three gunmen had broken into the house yesterday and seized he???.

title: Strike Formally Called
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 4 (Reuters)  Argentine union leaders tonight ordered a 48hour general strike to begin Sunday night.

title: Orioles Down Yankees, 54
description: In what has become a familiar occurrence in the last week, the Yankees lost another lead and another game in the ninth inning last night.

title: DaimlerBenz Raises Output and Has No Layoffs
description: STUTTGART, West Germany For the last year most German auto factories have felt the fears of unemployment and shortened work hours. But there is little such anxiety at the MercedesBenz assembly plant at Sindelfingen, nestled in the forested hills near Stutteart.

title: LOWTRANSITFARES FOR POOR BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Hardpressed urban transit systems should examine the possibility of installing a twotier fare system, charging higher fares to all but lowincome passengers, William T. Coleman Jr. Secretary of Transportation, says.

title: F.P.C. HEAD BACKS PRESIDENT ON GAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) John N. Nassikas, chairman of, the Federal Power Commission, said today he did not see any fundamental differences over natural gas regulation between President Ford and the commission. Mr. Ford, in speaking appearances yesterday, attacked the F.P.C. and predicted a very serious natural gas shortage in the Midwest this winter.

title: LOAN LOSSES SEEN BY THE CITICORP
description: The Citicorp Corporation announced yesterday in its prospectus for its proposed $300million of convertible subordinated notes issue, that it may sustain some loan losses on a number of loans it has outstanding in the automobile, textile, real estate investment trust and retail industries.

title: Aunt Jin Triumphs In Jersey
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 4 Aunt Jin won the $54,300 Monmouth Oaks at Monmouth Park today as Sarsar, the highly regarded 25 favorite in the field of six 3year old fillies, finished third.

title: The Tremors in Beirut
description: A shaky peace appears to have returned to Beirut after ten weeks of fighting during which almost 300 persons were killed and over 700 wounded. The present ceasefire is still uncertain; fullfledged fighting could resume again at any time. Nevertheless there is some reason for cautions optimism to be found in the broad spectrum of Prime Minister Rashid Karami's new Cabinet. It is indicative of the pressure for reconciliation which has been generated by the crisis that Mr. Karami's Minister of the Interior is Camille Chamoun, former President of Lebanon and one of Mr. Karami's chief political foes.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: Sports Today
description: Firecracker 400 stock car race, at Daytona Beach

title: Radio
description: 6.7 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Horn Concertino in E minor, Weber; Symphony in 13 flat, Chausson.

title: Drinking and Speeding Cited In Crash Fatal to 10 Indians
description: KAYENTA, Ariz., July 4 (UPI) Drinking and speeding were blamed for the deaths of 10 Navajo Indians in a headon collision in northern Arizona today, less than five hours before the official July 4 fatality count began.

title: Chincoteague Herd Of Ponies is Periled By Swamp Disease
description: CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., July 4 (UPI)Nearly half of the famous Chincoteague pony herd is infected with swamp fever and will have to be destroyed.

title: Municipal Officials Gird for the Impact Of $384Million Gap in State Budget
description: With the Legislature in Trenton still fumbling with ways to close a $384million budget gap officials of some of New Jersey's major municipalities are reacting with uncertainty, exasperation and even outrage, to the possibility of cuts in state aid.

title: JUST THE DAY FOR A DIP: A young woman dipping her infant son in surf yesterday at Jones Beach, L.I., where Independence Day and good weather drew crowds. Page 21.
description: While thousands scurried to, summer homes and mountain and seaside resorts, the city I took on its wonderful holiday I calm yesterday, aided by a nearperfect blue sky and a bright sun that shone on the nation's 199th birthday.

title: Rumania Hit by Floods, Put on Emergency Footing
description: BUCHAREST, July 4 (UPI)President Nicolae Ceausescu proclaimed a nationwide emergency today as a result of torrential rains and widespread flooding during the last few days.

title: Free Movies in the Parks Here To Start Monday in Manhattan
description: Max is obviously unknown and not in the same movie league as, say, Jaws, which is doing recordbreaking business at $3 and $4 admission prices.

title: Anglican Church of Canada Faces Split Over Ordination of Women
description: OTTAWA, July 4A recent decision of the General Synod of the Anglican church of Canada to permit the ordination of women to the priesthood has split the communicants between an overwhelming majority who favor the change and a small but adamant minority who oppose the move so strongly that many say they willleave the church.

title: ServanSchreiber Resigns As Head of Centrist Party
description: PARIS, July 4 (Reuters)JeanJacques ServanSchreiber today resigned as president of the Radical party, apparently after failure to gain total control of the centrist group.

title: LOW TRANSIT FARES FOR POOR BACKED
description: WASHINGTON. July 4 Hardpressed urban transit systems should examine the possibility of installing a twotier fare system, charging higher fares to all but lowincome passengers, William T. Coleman Jr., Secretary of Transiportation, says.

title: Dollar Registers Advance On Europe Money Marketd
description: BRUSSELS. July 4(UPI)The United States dollar was stronger on most Europeaii money markets today for the fifth consecutive day. The price of gold also rose. The British pound fell to $2.1935 in London, from $2.1960 yesterday.

title: T.V.A. Proposal for Big Nuclear Unit Fosters a Controversy in Tennessee
description: HARTSVILLE, Tenn.There are many communities that find cause to celebrate when they can lay claim to being the biggest or first in some area of achievement. But here, where the Trousdale County welcome signs boast that this is the future home of the world's largest nuclear power plant, the atmosphere is far from one of jubilation.

title: Petty Wins Firecracker 400
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 (AP)Richard Petty slipped past Buddy Baker on the 148th lap today and held off his former teammate the rest of the way for his first victory in the Firecracker 400 stock car race.

title: Val Friedman Weds Nancy Green
description: Nancy Green of Palm Beach, Fla., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Green of Palm Beach, formerly of New York, was married in Cincinnati yesterday to Val Friedman of Cincinnati and Palm Beach, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Friedman of. Cincinnati.

title: INDIVIDUAL'S ROLE IS HAILED BY FORD
description: BALTIMORE, July 4 (UPI)In a Fourth of July speech at the birthplace of The Star Spangled Banner, President Ford said today that America must devote her next century to individual freedom if she is to remain the land of the free and home of the brave.

title: Union, Harvard Crews Gain
description: HENLEY  ON  THAMES, England, July 4The American entries at the Henley Royal Regatta celebrated the Fourth of July today with mixed emotions.

title: 3 Tons of Marijuana Seized
description: MIAMI, July 4 (AP)A patrolling United States customs pilot, curious about an aircraft that made lowItlel passes and Then landed of an isolated road, steered tht police to a seizure of about three tons pf marijuana yesterday.

title: KIDNAPPERS URGED TO FREE 4TH VICTIM
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 4 (UPI)Marxist guerrillas holding an American student hostage in Zaire agreed twice last week to release him but each time broke their word, two women freed earlier by the rebels said today.

title: National League
description: New York 4, Philadelphia 3 (n.). Chicago 6, Pittsburgh 1 (1st.). Chicago 2, Pittsburgh 1

title: GRAINTHEFT DATA GIVEN U.S. IN 1964
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 4Persuasive evidence of widespread thefts of grain of the kind that have led to a major break in the current investigation of alleged corruption in the grain export trade was presented to Federal officers as early as 1964 but was never followed up by United States investigators, according to a variety of sources.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe Bugner, returning to London yesterday after his defeat by Muhammad Ali, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, still considers himself the No. heavyweight contender.

title: 2,000 POLICEMEN AND 50 FIREMEN ARE REHIRED HERE
description: Two thousand police officers and 750 firemendismissed only four days agowere back on their jobs, 18 of 26 closed firehouses were reopened and returning sanitationmen picked up thousands of tons of piledup garbage yesterday as the city's crisis atmosphere of the last week seemed to abate for the holiday weekend.

title: Markets Were Closed
description: Securities and commodity exchanges throughout the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Independence Day.

title: Quiet City Basks in Holiday Sunshine
description: While thousands scurried to summer homes and mountain and seaside resorts, the city took on its wonderful holiday calm yesterday, aided by a nearperfect blue sky and a bright sun that shone on the nation's 199th birthday.

title: Dankworth, Cleo Laine In Jazz Duet
description: The skillfully theatrical act that Cleo Laine and John Dankworth have developed as a very successful nightclub and concert hall enter tainment did not work quite as well when it became part of the Newport Jazz Festival late Wednesday evening.

title: Events Today
description: BOLSHOI OPERA, Metropolitan Opera House, Tchaikovsky's Pique Damp, 1:30; Prokofiev's The Gambler, 7:30.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: uiveroifitO COMMON STOCK FUNDS.

title: FASHION TALK
description: George Stavropoulos designs daytime clothesfor fall, they're mostly princessshaped and gracefulbut his evening things are what put him on the map. They're usually chiffon, they're rather grand, and they grace the most elaborate parties.

title: Angola, Torn by Clashes, Drifting to Independence
description: LUANDA Angola, July 2Angola's fivemonthold transitional government, composed of representatives of the three guerrilla movements and Portuguese officials, has not been able to bring order or confidence to this territory scheduled for independence Nov. 11.

title: Man Falls Into the Hudson From a Sightseeing Boat
description: A man participating in a party on a Circle Line sightseeing boat fell or jumped from the deck of the vessel last night as the boat cruised south on the Hudson River off Grant's Tomb, the Coast Guard reported.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A bomb concealed in an old refrigerator left on the street set off a violent explosion in the heart of Jerusalem yesterday morning, killing 13 Israelis and wounding 72 persons. It was the bloodiest terrorist incident in Jerusalem since the founding of Israel. The police rounded up 300 Arabs for questioning as well as to protect them from vengeful Israelis. [Page 1, Columns 13.]

title: Deaths
description: ADLERJoseph, beloved husband of Mae, devoted father of Fred, Harriet. Rahoy, Robert, Ruth Fisk and Sally Frankel; dear, brother, grandfather enact greatgrandfather. Services Sunday, 11:30 A.M., Parkside Chapels, 251A Flalbush Ave., opposite Kings Plaza, Brooklyn.

title: Ion Lucien at Newport Jazz Festival
description: The always enthusiastic Newport Jazz Festival program gushes that Jon Lucien, the headliner at Thursday's early show in Carnegie Hall, macho clothed in velvet. Affectation clothed in rhetoric would be more like it.

title: Townsend Decision to Quit Chrysler Believed His Own
description: DETROIT, July 4After riding on the boomorbust roller coaster of Chrysler Corporation for 15 years, Lynn A. Townsend, the company's chairman of the board and chief executive, arrived at his decision to quit apparently by himself without pressure from the banks or internal pressure from the company's board of directors or top executives.

title: CRANFORD HAS DAY OF FUN AND GAMES
description: CRANFORD, July 4A quiet community of shady streets and 27,500 residents, this Union County township 21 mites from Manhattan celebrated an oldfashioned familystyle Fourth of July with gusto and good humor.

title: Iraqi Official Visits Peking
description: PEKING, July 4 (Agence FrancePresse)The Iraqi Vice President, Taha Mohieddin Marut arrived here today for an official visit at the invitation of the Chinese Government. The welcome committee at Peking airport included Deputy Premier Teng HsiaoPing.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Russell S. Crenshaw Dies; A Retired Navy Captain
description: Russel S. Crenshaw, a retired Navy captain who had been assistant commandant for operations of the MidAtlantic Sea Frontier and the Fifth Naval District, died Wednesday at his home in Virginia Beach, Va. He was in his 80's.

title: Queens Man and Daughter, 9, Die in Fire at Home
description: A Queens, man and his 9yearold stepdaughter died in their burning home early yesterday morning, but before he died, the father rescued another of his stepchildren by throwing himeoirt a window, according to a telative.

title: Peter Schladermundt, 68, An Architect and Designer
description: Peter Schladermundt, architect and industrial designer, died Wednesday in Bronxville, N.Y., where he lived. His age was 68.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor Civic union leaders, from the very nature of their jobs, automatically resist strongly any proposed changes in the established wage scale and length of workweek that would involve any sacrifice by their members. It was recently suggested that if policemen would work several extra days without pay, a large number of jobs could be saved. The union leaders rejected this.

title: Two Killed in Plane Crash
description: PORTAGEVILLE, Mo., July 4 (UPI)A small plane crashed on a highway near here today, killing its two occupants. The victims were identified as Bob Alexander, 42 years old, of Caruthersville, and Jackie Cook, 32, of Dyersberg, Tenn.

title: A Dawn of Independence Over Cape Verde Islands
description: PRAIA, Cape Verde Islands, July 4There was music in the streets here today. There were shouts of joy, parades, promises, and prayers in this capital city of the Cape Verde Islands, to which independence comes at midnight. But many officials and common folk were worried, and about grasshoppers.

title: Davis Cup Decision Stirs Reaction
description: LONDON, July 4 (AP)The South African NonRacial Olympic Committee said today it would fight the decision made in London yesterday by the Davis Cup nations to retain South Africa as a member. The committee wants all African countries to withdraw from the International Lawn Tennis Federation if South Africa is not expelled, and then it wants Asian and Latin American Countries to follow suit. A committee spokesman said the plan is in retaliation for a United States threat to withdraw from the Davis Cup if South Africa was excluded from the competitiona threat supported by France, Britain and the Netherlands.

title: Regina H. Paul Has Nuptials
description: Regina Higdon Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Robert Paul Jr. of Metion Station, Pa., was married last evening to Warren James Haas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haas of Pelham Manor, N. Y. The Rev. Jack Orr performed the ceremony in the Baptist Church of the Evangel in Narberth, Pa.

title: From Ford to Hoover
description: The Ford Administration insists it is deeply concerned about the unemployed but, alas, there is nothing more that can be done without regenerating inflation and second slump with rising unemployment. The President prefers to take his chances, economically and politically, with a long, gradual slog out of the hole, even if this leaves unemployment above 7 per cent for the next four years.

title: $175,000 in Antiques Stolen
description: An ingenious thief made off with an estimated total of $175,000 in antiques from a Madison Avenue shop Thursday night or early yesterday morning. According to the police, the thief moved a 5foothigh, pyramidal wooden box, used as a temporary base for a street lamp, against the door of the antique shop, at 854 Madison Avenue 70th Street. Then, climbing inside the box, which had an opening facing the door, he cut a square into the gate protecting the store entrance and crawled into the shop. Theresa LeBeau, wife of the owner, Jack LeBeau, said they knew just what they wanted, they took our best pieces.

title: Mets Get 3 in 9th, Win 43
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 4 With a fireworks show outshining most of their early performance on the field tonight the New York Mets rallied with some late bombs of their own in beating the Philadelphia Phillies, 43. A crowd of 55,301. largest in the National League this season, watched.

title: Soviet Union Teams Lead U.S. in Track
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 4 (AP) Track stars of the Soviet Union, led by Valery Borzov, an Olympic goldmedal winner, dominated an American men's team today, and American and Bulgarian women opponents, at the opening of a twoday track and field meet.

title: Art Villon's Prints, Sardonic, Tough, Skillful
description: Jacques Villon was Pushing 90 when he died in 1963. He was much liked in Paris, both as a man and as an irtist, but there was no denying that he had spent much. A his life in the shadow of his two brothers, Marcel Duchamp and Raymond Duchamp  Vilion. DuchamoVillon died of typhoid fever in 1918, leaving behind him at least one key work of its date the sculpture called The Large Horse of 1914. Marcel Duchamp turned out to be one of the most influential artists of our century (and, contrary to legend, one of the most substantially productive).

title: Basque Woman is Linked In London to Paris Mystery
description: LONDON, July 4 (AP) A 21yearold Spanish woman was charged with illegal possession of weapons today as an international search was stepped up for a man sought in the Paris murder of two French special police agents and a Lebanese informer.

title: Owners Strike Closes Dog Racing Track
description: MIAMI, July 4The Flagler Dog Track was shut today for the second straight day in a dispute with the Florida Greyhound Owners and Breeders Association over increased purses.

title: 50 Lawyers in City Were Disciplined By Bar in 12 Months Ended. April 30
description: Fifty Bronx and Manhattan lawyers were disbarred, suspended or censured during a 12month period ended on April 30the highest number in historyaccording to a report released yesterday by the grievance committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

title: Rev. Howard Halter, 68, Bronxville Pastor 32 Years
description: The Rev. Howard Luther Halter, who retired last year after 32 years as pastor of the Village Lutheran Church in Bronxville, N.Y., died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his summer home in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 68 years old.

title: Cities Gird for the Impact Of Cut in Jersey's Budget
description: With the Legislature in Trenton still fumbling with ways to close close a $384million budget gap, officials of some of New Jersey's major municipalities are reacting with uncertainty, exasperation and even outrage to the possibility of cuts in state aid.

title: 3 Die After Youths Seize Women in a Chicago Home
description: CHICAGO. July 4 (UPI)Three youths forced their way into a South Side home early today, tied up three women and then shot them one by one. Two of the women later died in a hospital.

title: DR. MURRAY BUELL, RUTGERS BOTANIST
description: Dr. Murray F. Buell, professor emeritus of botany at Rutgers University, was found dead yesterday in his camper in New Gretna, N.J., where he had been on a field trip. He was 69 years old and had been under treatment for a cardiac ailment.

title: Newport Jazz
description: Thelonious Monk's first concert appearance in more than two years (aside from a brief, unannounced appearance a year ago at a New York Jazz Repertory Company concert of his music) drew a predominantly yoimg and very enthusiastic audience to the Newport Jazz Festival's first sellout performance Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: The Dance
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 4With the enthusiastically received premiere here last night of a major modern dance work by Pauline Koner, the American Dance Festival at Connecticut College has returned to its source.

title: Wildlife Service Invoking Law To Protect Rare Sandhill Crane
description: WASHINGTON. July 4The Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, for the first time, has implemented the emergency provision of the Endangered Species Act, to protect the rare Mississippi sandhill crane, which the service says is imperiled by Federal highway construction.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2 No Title

title: Market Place
description: After years of staggering losses in the worst and most prolonged bear market of this generation, owners of shares in leading mutual funds have been rewarded for their patience by the vigorous stockmarket rally of the last six months.

title: Cultural Council to Open Park Programs Today
description: The North Jersey Cultural Council today will open its third summer season of free park entertainment, sponsored by 13 North Jersey communities and the Bergen County Parks Commission.

title: Downtown Cleveland A Diamond inthe Rough
description: CLEVELANDThe crowd started to gather soon after 11 A.M. on one of those muggy days of early summer, when the haze is so thick that the bluegray surface of Lake Erie merges totally with the bluegray sky above.

title: There's Joy in Brooklyn At the 3 Jolly Pigeons, As the Girls Win, 270
description: There were cheers from the bar at the Three Jolly Pigeons in Brooklyn the other night as Its women's softball team came in from the game  happy, sweaty, thirsty for their victory barrel of beer.

title: GIVE A KID A BREAK GIVE FRESH AIR FUND
description: GIVE A KID A BREAK GIVE FRESH AIR FUND

title: Dick Gregory Held in Protest Over C.I.A. at White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) Dick Gregory, comedian and activist, was arrested in front of the White House today while protesting what he described as Central Intelligence Agency involvement in domestic assassinations. Ray Lomax, a spokesman for the United States Park Police, said Mr. Gregory had been arrested for protesting without a permit. Mr. Gregory was carrying a sign saying C.I.A.Protesting Conspiracy Inside America.

title: 13 Die, Scores Hurt in Jerusalem Blast
description: JERUSALEM, July 4A huge explosion ripped through Jerusalem's main square at the height of the preSabbath shopping rush hour today, killing 13 Israelis and wounding 72 in the city's bloodiest terrorist incident since the founding of the state.

title: GARRETT T. BURNS
description: Garrett T. Burns, a certified public accountant and a partner in Arthur Andersen & Co. until his retirement in 1958, died Thursday at a nursing home in Rochester, Minn., after a series of strokes. He was 83 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Citywide Garbage Pickup to Be Completed Tonight
description: Sanitation Department officials said yesterday that they expected at least one garbage pickup to have been made by tonight in all areas of the city and two in some placescleaning up most of the more than 50,000 tons of debris that piled up during the sanitationmen's wildcat strike, which ended, in its third day, on Thursday.

title: Julius Epstein, Author, 74, Dies; Wrote of Forced Repatriations
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., July 4 (UPI)Julius Epstein, a journalist who wrote hooks about the forced repatriation of antiCommunist to the Soviet Union after World War II, died Thursday at the age of 74.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERIKANIS, Costa. Left Bermuda July 3, due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: Surge in Private Luxury Planes Attributed to Foreign Oil Boom
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 4 A $12million Boeing 707 in a private hangar at Long Beach Airport is being equipped at a cost of $2.5million with three staterooms, a bar, a lounge, six private lavatories and closedcircuit television for the Chief Minister of the oilrich Malaysian state of Sabah.

title: State Relaxes in Perfect Holiday Weather
description: New Jerseyans thronged beaches and highways yesterday, watched parades or simply basked in their backyards under a nearperfect blue sky and a bright sun in celebration of a glorious Fourth and the nation's 199th birthday.

title: No Amer Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Arms for Europe
description: The $2billion sale of 350 American F16 lightweight fighters to four NATO countries, after a bitter yearlong competition with the French Mirage F1, undoubtedly makes immediate economic as well as military sense for all concerned. But it has left a sour taste all over Europe. And it raises the serious question whether the true longterm interests of either the United States or its allies have been best served by this socalled arms deal of the century.

title: Foltz First in Pikes Peak Hill Climb
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 4 (AP)Ted Foltz of Colorado Springs covered a winding 121/2mile mountain road in 13 minutes 39.14 seconds today to win $20,000 first prize in the annual Pikes Peak Hill Climb. I'm glad I made it to the top in the number one spot, Foltz said after beating 24 other drivers in the stock car division of the race.

title: Fine Blend: Max Roach And J. C. White Singers
description: Thursday evening's Newport Jazz Festival late show at Carnegie Hall closed with a 45minute collaboration between the J. C. White Singers and Max Roach and his instrumental quartet. If the pairing smacked at first of both hip religiosity and uneasy thirdstream juxtapositions, it ended as a most fervent and convincing musical marriage.

title: California Fire Contained
description: BIG BEAR, Calif., July 4 (AP) A fire that charred about 800 acres near Big Bear Lake in southern California's San Bernardino Mountains has been contained after destroying one small cabin, the authorities said today.

title: Ryan Sets Run Mark
description: MAHOPAC, N. Y., July 4Howie Ryan of the New York Athletid Club set a course record today in winning the t8.5mile Road Runners Club race in 41 minutes 25 seconds.

title: 200 REFUGEES FLY FROM U.S. TO ASIA
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 4 (UPI)Some 200 homesick Vietnamese refugees boarded United States Air Force planes headed back to Asia today, following 50 others who started the return trip home a day earlier.

title: Antiques: A Collector's Journey Into British Silver
description: HARTFORD  Elizabeth R Milests pursuit of sterling silver marrow scoops 30 years ago represented the first lap of a wideranging journey through the history of British silver.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COME ON DOWN Tomorrow, in still another Bicentennial salute, New yotkers will have a rare chance to visit Governor's Island, the Coast Guard station off the tip of lower Manhattan. The historic spot, with its 18thcentury village green, picturesque old houses and two bastions, Fort Jay (1798) and Castle Williams (1811), is putting out a welcome mat, with special emphasis on family groups. Family residents on the island, who proudly call it Shangrila, along with the Coast Guard, are anxious to share tomorrow afternoon with New Yorkers who have curiously gazed at their home site from the Brooklyn Bridge and the Staten Island Ferry.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: New York at Philadelphia (2. twi; n)Tate (3.6) and Stone (2)) vs. Lonborg (6.6) and Schueler (26).

title: 25000 LaidOff Policemen And750 Firemen Rehired
description: Rolled out to put out a rubbish fire down the block as 50 neighborhood residents stood by cheering and applauding.

title: INDIA ORDERS BAN ON MAJOR GROUPS IN THE OPPOSITION
description: The antiGovernment groups, which have tens of thousands of members, were officially accused of indulging in activities prejudicial to the internal security, public safety and maintenance of public order.

title: Ludwig Sander, Artist, Dead; Noted for HIS Cool Abstracts
description: Ludwig Sander, a painter of the New York School, died Thursday at the Veterans Hospital here after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 345 West Broadway and in Sagaponack, L. I.

title: Bill Watrous, Trombonist on the Way Up
description: It wasn't too long ago, Bill Watrous recalls, that whenever I got called to play trombone in a nightclub I'd say, Why not take my whole band and we'll come cheap.

title: Power Outage in Queens Village
description: About 1,100 residents of Queens Village, Queens, were without electrical service for two hours when a 2,000volt feeder power line shortcircuited shortly before noon in an area from 212th to 240th Street and 92d to 100th Avenues, a Consolidated Edison Company spokesman said.

title: Upstate Stone Homes to Open for a Day
description: HURLEY, N.Y.In 1777, the settlement of Hurley became the temporary capital of New Ydrk State when the British burned Kingston, a few miles away.

title: Return to Poison?
description: In response to repeated protests by scientists and conservationists, President Nixon forbade the use poisons to control predators on the public lands. At the same time, the Federal Government withdrew the necessary registration that had made it possible for Western sheep ranchers to buy these poisons for use on their own land.

title: Chile Bans U.N. Inquiry
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 4 (Reuters)A United Nations delegation scheduled to investigate human rights in Chile will not he allowed to enter the country, President Augusto Pinochet said tonight. He gave noreason for barring the delegation, which was to have arrived here July 10.

title: British Miners Are Pivotal In Drive Against Inflation
description: LONDON, July 4  The miners emerged today as the pivotal group in the efforts of the Government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson to curb labor increases and put a lid on Britain's rapidly climbing inflation.

title: Myopia Gains Final In Polo Tourney
description: BETHPAGE, L. 1., July 4The Myopia polo team defeated Bethpage, 107, today in the semifinal round of the Northeastern Intercircuit 12goal tournament. Myopia will meet Meadowbrook Sunday for the championship.

title: Peggy Solow Married to Harvey J. Liss
description: Peggy Solow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Solow of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Harvey Joel Liss, son of Sylvia Liss Protter of Teaneck, N. J., and the late Meyer C. Liss. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony in Central Synagogue.

title: Catcher, 14, Signed By Yanks in Canada
description: THOROLD, Ontario, July 4 (AP)The New York Yankees signed a 14yearold catcher, Mark Plantery of Thorold, to a contract today. Bill Wray, the scout who first spotted Planetry in a midget league tournament last year, said the catcher was probably the youngest player ever signed by the Yankees.

title: Pentagon Reduces Estimates of Costs In Arms Programs
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)The cost of completing 41 major weaponsdevelopment programs will be $3.1billion lower than was estimated earlier, Pentagon financial specialists say.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A bomb concealed in an old refrigerator left on the street set off a violent explosion in the heart of Jerusalem yesterday morning, killing 13 Israelis and wounding 72 persons, It was the bloodiest terrorist incident in Jerusalem since the founding of Israel. The police rounded up 300 Arabs for questioning as well as, to protect them from vengeful Israelis. [Page 1, Columns 13.]

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: A 42yearold Brooklyn resident, Raul Gordon, was shot and killed by a man he was pursuing with a machete. The police said the gunman, known as Gilbert, owed Mr. Gordon's wife $30 for beauty products that she had sold him. The victim, of 366 South Fifth Street, was shot in the chest. The gunman escaped. A 26yearold Brooklyn man died in Methodist Hospital from gunshot wounds in his chest, fired by one of two unknown men while he was talking to friends in front of his home. The victim was Simroy Francis of 575 Bergen Street Forence Gray, 37yearold commonlaw wife of Lindsay Graham, 37, was pushed from a thirdstory window by her husband in their apartment at 327 Chauncey Street during an argument, the police said. She was reported as in satisfactory condition in St. Mary's Hospital.

title: Moslem Leaders Praise Gandhi Curbs
description: NEW DELHI, July 4As Indian Moslems thronged to worship in New Delhi's mosques today, several of their leaders affirmed support for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her assumption of sweeping emerzency powers.

title: A OneLegged Stool in Spain
description: MADRIDThe Spanish Army is the sole effective political institution that has survived almost four decades of Francoism although it intensely dislikes being considered political in any sense. Yes it cannot elude this description.

title: INDIA ORDERS BAN ON MAJOR GROUPS IN THE OPPOSITION
description: NEW DELHI, July 4The Indian Government, continuing its weeklong drive to disable the political opposition, today declared a ban on the activities of several important dissident organizations.

title: GLEANING OF PARKS NND BEACHES CUT
description: Laidoft maintenance crews picketed Park Department garages yesterday to prevent cleanup trucks from collecting trash at the city's parks and beaches.

title: Burns Posts a 68 in Open Qualifying
description: DUNDEE, Scotland, July 4 (AP)George Burns, member of this year's victorious United States Walker Cup team, holed a 60yard wedge shot today on his way to fourunderpar 68 as qualifying play began for the $166,000 British Open, which starts at Carnoustie, Scotland, next Wednesday. The 26yearold golfer from New York, playing in the first round of the 36hole qualifying competition over the famous old course at St. Andrews, knocked in his long pitch for an eagle 2 at the 372yard seventh hole.

title: ANITA POLLITM, SUFFRAGIST, DIES
description: Anita Pollitzer, a pioneer fighter for equal rights for women, died Thursday at the home of her nurse in Queens. She was 80 years old and lived in Charleston. S. C.

title: Ciedit Use in U. S. Gained During May
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (Reuters)Credit use in the United States rose a seasonally adju$ed $72million in May, the first such monthly increase in this figure since February, according to the Federal Reserve Bdard.

title: Alaskan Governor Chooses Fish Over Oil in Kachemak Bay Fight
description: HOMER, Alaska, July 1Gov. Jay S. Hammond has joined fishermen in opposing oildrilling operations in this fishing and shellfish community about 275 miles south of Anchorage.

title: Local Education Cuts
description: The prospect of Albany's assuming a smaller proportion of the cost of running the state's 660 local school districts is one more reason educational officials, already under pressure from homeowners to put a lid on steadily mounting school taxes, are thinking more and more in terms of how they can cut costs.

title: Savoir Wins Trot In Goshen Finale
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4 (UPI) Savoir, a 7yearold gelding, won the Titan Cup for trotters today as the Grand Circuit of harness racing concluded its sevenday stopover here.

title: New York Lottery Winners
description: The New York State Lottery had a special Fourth of July drawing at Jones Beach, L, I. The winning numbers picked are: 309682; 132415; 414248 and 364724. The tickets were part of a special milliondollar lottery offering, for which tickets cost $2.50 each.

title: Opera: Bolshoi's Onegin
description: Not long ago Tchaikovsky's Eugene Onegin languished in a cubbyhole reserved for a few operas that are beloved in their native countries but somehow do not travel well. The revisionists will have to get to work soon on this one, though. Onegin increasingly stands clear as one of the most affecting works ever written for the lyric stage.

title: John Carradine Married
description: OXNARD, Calif., July 4 (UPI)John Carradine, the actor, was married yesterday for the fourth time. Mr. Carradine, 69 years old, married Emily Cisneros, 50, mother of four children, at All Saints Episcopal Church here.

title: Spain Asks for Wide Arms Aid For Deal on U.S. Use of Bases
description: MADRID. July 4Spain has requested extensive military aid from the United Slates as part of a deal to permit its continued use of Spanish. bases though on a reduced scale, American diplomatic sources said today.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: United Press International Rescue workers searching through the rubble at the scene of the blast on historic Zion Square.

title: The Public Servant Gets His
description: The street theater that has been passing for government lately in New York City would have seemed thoroughly familiar to Romans in the declining days of the Caesars.

title: Turkey's Party Wars Mirror Social Change
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 29Turkey is involved in an increasingly angry political struggle between the rightwing Government of Premier Suleyman Demirel and its leftist critics, led by former Premier Bulent Ecevit.

title: Bridal on L. I. for Laura Jean Siegel
description: Laura Jean Siegel, daughter of Mrs. Eli H. Siegel of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Crompond, N. Y., and the late Dr. Siegel, a dentist, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Jerry Nagler, a resident in internal medicine at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nagler of Rego Park, Queens.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court has ruled that the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority may seek new bids for drainage and grading work at the East Rutherford site its sports complex. The Appellate Division of Superior Court in Trenton held that the authority had not acted with caprice in rejecting previous bids because of its concern that the contract be awarded and finished within a framework of time to coincide with other work being done. The authority earlier this year rejected three bids because there was some question about how much money the authority would spend to insure workers on the project. The authority will now seek new bids for the project.

title: Recalled Police Officers Display Distrust and Anxiety Over Jobs
description: Spirited, bitter and resentful, 2,000 casually dressed men and women walked into the Manhattan Property Clerk's office as civilians yesterday and left several hours later hearing the badges and guns that signified their reentry into the city's police force.

title: AIRCONDITIONERS IN A SALES SLUMP
description: ATLANTA, July 4This is going to be a long, hot summer for the airconditioning industry and a lot of oncecool Americans.

title: Forego Sets Belmont. Track Record
description: For a time at Belmont Park yesterday, Forego made 35,191 fans almost forget about Ruffian and Foolish Pleasure, the star filly and colt listed to compete in the celebrated $350.000 match race at Belmont tomorrow.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Rover W. Strong A participant in Round Hill Highland Scottish Games at Stamford, Conn., in cabertossing event. When tossed successfully, the caber flips over on ground.

title: Major. Shift Seen Unlikely In India's Foreign Piolky
description: NEW DELHI, July 4Though Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has promised populist measures at home in the wake of her crackdown on the political opposition, diplomats here believe that India's foreign policy is unlikely to shift dramatically.

title: Fears of a Coup in Argentina Rise as Strikes Numb Industry
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 9The political crisis in Argentina entered its second week today with most by activity paralyzed by wildcat strikes and little prospect of agreement on wages between organized labor and President Isabel Martinez de Perdn.

title: Soviet Sets Agreement To Grant Loan to Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 4 (Reuters)Turkey and the Soviet Union will sign a $700million credit deal, Government officials announced today.

title: 2 HOMOSEXUAL WACS DISMISSED BY ARMY
description: BOSTON, July 4 (UPI)Two women have been dismissed from the Army because of homosexuality.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the epilogue to this his second book of criminal cases, F. Lee Bailey, among the handful of trial lawyers known to laymen and one whose cases have a habit of turning up in newspaper headlines, makes a harsh judgment on the state of justice in this country.

title: Three Members Ares till at Large As S.L.A. Man I s Seized in T exas
description: POUSTON, July 4 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation says that the arrest of Thero Wheeler means only three known members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army are still at large, among them Patricia Hearst.

title: Suspect Wounded in Drugstore Holdup
description: A man attempting to rob a drugstore at 28 Canal Street was shot and critically wounded after allegedly pulling a handgun and pointing it at two police officers as they arrived at the pharmacy, the police said. The officers, Charles Covatti and Richard Keddy, of the 7th Precinct, were responding to a silent alarm touched off by the store's coowners after two robbers had bound them.

title: AIRCONDITIONERS IN A SALES SLUMP
description: ATLANTA, July 4This is going to be a long, hot summer for the airconditioning industry and a lot of oncecool Americans.

title: Old Old Glories Fly for Bicentennial
description: VERONAIt could vex some vexilogists, but what is flying over homes in many parts of this land isn't the New Glory of this Bicentennial but the Old Glories of America's past.

title: Lisbon Calls for Calm as Leftists March
description: LISBON, July 4 President Francisco da Costa Gomes tonight urgently appealed for calm and discipline after almost a week of agitation and rumors.

title: Mothers Ready for Long Hike
description: MADISONTwo women, each the mother of four teenagers, will spend about 45 days this summer exploring deserts, forests and mountains in California. The purpose of their hiking trip notnot just to get away it all but, rather, to earn credits toward anthropology degrees at Drew University.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The law firm of Wender, Murase and White has leased the 17th, 18th and 19th floors, comprising more than 20,000 square feet of space, at 400 Park Avenue, at 54th Street. The lease has a term of about 15 years and an aggregate rent of $3.5million.

title: Brigand Wins Tidal By Head at Belmont
description: Moving to the front at the start, and staying there all the way, Nelson B. Hunt's Brigand won the $58,250 Tidal Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Heliodoro Gustines rode Brigand, who beat Prod by a head in the 1mile turf race.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Sometimes it takes a crisis to bring good things, and the current financial instability at the Metropolitan Opera has produced at least one happy byproduct: the release of Met Saturday afternoon broadcasts on disk, available to one and all with a $100 contribution to the Metropolitan Opera Fund. The idea got started last year when by some miracle of good will, artists, orchestra, chorus and the two musicians unions (AGMA and AFM) agreed to donate the Dec. 7, 1940, broadcast of The Marriage of Figaro to the cause. This year's release is Madama Butterfly, performed on Jan. 19, 1946, with Licia Albanese, Lucielle Browning, James Melton and John Brownlee; judging from the cooperation of all parties involved and the encouraging audience response (over 1,800 Butterfly sets have been ordered to date, bringing in $200,000 toward the Met's 197475 deficit), we can expect issue

title: New Hampshire Sets Sire Stake
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 5 (AP)New Hampshire's first Sire Stakes race will be held July 15 at the Hinsdale Raceway.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: MUSIC BE DANCE

title: Corpses, cubs and kings
description: A book more likely to find a place in the black hearts of young readers than on the required reading lists of our school system is this dandy little account of the history of grave robbing. An unlikely subject for a juvenile book, I would have thought, but it works like a dream, a very bad dream.

title: Gigantic Heroin Epidemic In U.S. Seen by Legislator
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI)  Citing a new Government study, Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California, says a heroin epidemic of gigantic proportions exists in the United States and is increasing at a runaway rate.

title: GEORGE F. GENTES
description: OLD LYME, Conn., July 5George Franklin Gentes, of Flat Rock Hill Road, who retired in 1950 as executive vice president and director of the Irving Trust Company, New York City, died Thursday at the Mary Kenny Nursing Home in Waterford. He was 90 years old.

title: Polo Tournament Will Benefit Library
description: PLUCKEMINThe third annual W. Thorn Kissell Mernorial Polo Tournament will be held July 20 at the Burnt Mills Polo Club. The final match will begin at 3 P.M.; it will be preceded by a consolation contest at 1 P.M.

title: Ashe Topples Connors for Crown at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5Jimmy Connors, the man everybody thought unbeatable, was thrashed by Arthur Ashe in the Wimbledon men's final today.

title: What's Doing in ONTARIO
description: A HOME AWAY FROM HOMETwentythree million Americans cross the border into Ontario every year. Many are summer visitors who return again and again to the Canadian heartland. The Ontario frontier reaches more than a third of the way across the whole northern United States, from upper New York State to western Minnesota. Inland, the province extends from the Great Lakesfour of the five wash Ontario's shoresto Hudson Bay. For motorists, the main points of entry from the eastern United States are through Massena, Ogdensburg, Watertown, Niagara Falls and Buffalo, N. Y. The border crossing couldn't be easier for Americans. If Americanborn, all you need is some valid identification, such as a Social Security card. Ontario covers 415,502 square miles, as big as France and West Germany put together, plus Italy without Sicily. In cities like Toronto, capital of the province and the country's financial center, and Ottawa, the national capital, cultural attractions abound  plays and concerts with international stars, museums and art galleries, ethnic festivals. Add to that fishing, hunting, boating, hiking and camping in superb natural settings. The provincial government will furnish free information by mail on more than 200 suggested tours: write to Travel Services Branch, Ministry of Industry and Tourism, Queen's Park, Ontario M7A 2B5, or telephone (6139654014).

title: Ford to Meet Governors
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 5 (UPI)Gov. Robert D. Ray will lead a number of Governors to Washington Monday for a meeting with President Ford before Mr. Ford's expected delivery of a transportation message to Congress. Dick Gilbert, Mr. Ray's news aide, indicated to Governor Ray that he wanted to discuss the transportation message. Mr. Ray heads the National Governors Conference.

title: Boonton Is Offering a Cookbook and Map
description: BOONTON TOWNSHIPThe Historical Society of Boonton Township, Inc., has announced that it is now taking mail orders for its new cookbook and historical map of the township. Both items were first placed on sale at FanFair, an annual event to benefit Riverside Hospital.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: TodayNorthern Westchester Professional Horsemen's Association, Primrose Farms, Primrose Street. Somers, N.Y. Special, local and children's working hunters; adult horsemanship, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Blenda Woodard to Be Wed Aug. 16
description: Blenda Ann Prince Woodard and Bruce Chapman Armistead plan to be married on Aug. 16 in Fredericksburg, Va. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Prince Briggs Woodard of Fredericksburg, where her father is president of Mary Washington College.

title: Susan Duck Is a Bride
description: Susan Elizabeth Duck and Philip James Baum, graduates of the University of Virginia, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Charles L. Smith at the Congregational Christian Church in Franklin, Va. The bride, a registered nurse at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Needham T. Duck of Franklin. Mr. Baum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newman N. Baum of Wantagh, L.I., is his third year at the Temple University School of Dentistry.

title: Fire Island Is an R & R for Horses
description: OCEAN BEACHA handful of nervous race horses along with thousands of barefoot visitors are unwinding this summer on the sands of this barrier beach island.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONState Senator Matthew Feldman of Bergen County also heads one of the largest and most successful liquor distributorships in New Jersey. However, he usually has been able to avoid any conflict of interest charges by simply refusing to participate in discussions, or voting on legislation, pertaining to alcoholic beverages.

title: Jury Awards Going Up In Personal Injury Suits
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Across the country, in rural areas as well as big cities, juries are awarding more money than ever before to people injured because of other people's negligence or misconduct, and to the estates of people who died because of somebody else's negligence or misconduct.

title: Tacoma's Unemployed Are Reluctant to Leave the City
description: TACOMA, Wash.  Early each weekday morning one of the busiest spots in this city of 158,000 people is a strictly functional lowslung building at 1301 Tacoma Avenue situated next to two tuxedo rental stores.

title: Gilda Dalla Rizza, 82, Dead; Soprano Sang Puccini Roles
description: MILAN, Italy, July 5 (AP)Gilda Dalla Rizza, a soprano who was once considered one of the best singers of Puccini operas, died yesterday at the Giuseppe Verdi House for singers and musicians. She was 82 years old.

title: Changes Urged in Eucharist
description: HICKSVILLEThe parish council of St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church here has approved a proposal requesting that divorced Catholics living in stable second marriages be allowed to receive the Eucharist.

title: . . . Danish Example
description: When Denmark joined Israel and the United States voting against the socalled Declaration of Mexico (as distinct from the Plan adopted in Mexico City) because of its deliberately provocative political implications, the small Scandinavian country raised its voice for what it considered right, even though it has virtually no Jewish constituency of its own.

title: You have a friend in Geneva, Switzerland
description: This is a book every crook in America should read. I would also recommend it to potential crooks, such as treasurers of multinational corporations who have not yet set up a slush fund; politicians who feel they are not getting their fair share of illegal campaign contributions; just plain citizens who would like to cut back on expenses by starting to dodge taxes. For what we have here is a textbook, complete with case studies, on the management of crooked money, or, as the authors prefer to call it, a guidebook to Swiss and tax haven banks, money washing, and financial crimes.

title: 3 Die as Truck Overturns
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., July 5 (AP)Three girls were killed and seven other persons injured last night when the truck in which they were riding overturned on Interstate SO near here, the state police reported. Killed were Charlotte Deetz, 11 years old, and Marie Young, 10. both of East Stroudsburg, and Dorie McKeegan, 7, of Hazleton.

title: Yankees Fall, 52; 7th Straight Loss
description: After losing six games in a row on weak hitting and soft lateinning pitching, the Yankees lost a seventh at Shea Stadium yesterday on uncertain fielding.

title: Lung Association Offering ID Cards
description: PARAMUS  Emergency identification cards, which could help save the lives of respiratory disease patients, are being offered free by the BergenPassaic Lung Association.

title: Subtle Sylvia Syms Provides An Oasis For Hampton Drive
description: In the midst of the harddriving rhythms of Lionel Hampton's Newport Jazz Festival presentation of his Inner Jazz Circlewhich included Mr. Hampton's big band; the Three Bad Pennies, a trio led by the saxophonist Eddie (Lockjaw) Davis, and the OttoMcLawlor TrioSylvia Syms provided an oasis of subtlety and individuality late Friday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: Endpaper
description: COOKING

title: Gentlemen's agreement
description: By Laura Z. Hobson. 256 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $7.95.

title: Indians' Robinson On Disabled List
description: CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) Frank Robinson, the Cleveland Indians playermanager, was placed on the 15day disabled list today because of muscle tear in his left shoulder.

title: Role for Oil Concerns Seen After Venezuela TakeOver
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 5 (AP)Venezuela's oil industry will be administered by a new state company following nationalization, but the doors will remain open for ample cooperation with multinational companies, President Carlos Andres Perez said today.

title: New Yorkers Win 3 Regatta Events
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5The New Haven Rowing Club, with five victories, and the New York Athletic Club, with three, dominated the elite events of the Independence Day regatta on the Schuylkill River today.

title: PRISONERS PROTEST GUARDS' JOB ACTION
description: About 100 prisoners on Rikers Island set a series of small fires in two cell blocks and briefly refused to return to their cells last night to protest delays in feeding caused by a sickout of correction officers, the city's Corrections Department reported.

title: East End Beaches Will Remain Open
description: HAUPPAUGE  Lastminute agreements between the Suffolk County Department of Health and four East End towns will keep open beaches that had been scheduled to close because of sanitary and safety violations.

title: REPORT CITES RISE OF BIAS IN NORTH
description: Declaring that while the situation in the South had been improving, the North is becoming progressively more segregated, Eleanor Holmes Norton, the City's Human Rights Commissioner, released a report last week as part of a plea for an updated look at integration.

title: CHICAGO SEEKING NEW SCHOOL HEAD
description: CHICAGO, July 5As Chicago continued its search this week for a superintendent to direct its troubled school system, critics were still assessing the performance of James F. Redmond, who has filled that difficult post for nine years.

title: MiddleClass Trap: Too Poor For College, Too Rich for Help
description: Among hundreds of thousands of unsuccessful applicants for college scholarships this year was a Dartmouth freshman from Florida whose schoolteacher parents make $32,500 between them. They have a $60,000 home (mortgaged), $8,000 in savings and an older son already in college. On the basis of a formal evaluation of his family's financial circumstances, the entering freshman was told he and his parents could afford the $6,800 it will cost to keep him at Dartmouth next year. The only help available through Dartmouth was a $1,500 federally insured loan at 7 per cent annual interest the college arranged.

title: Andretti Faces Busy Weekend in Glen
description: Mario Andretti, easily one of the busiest race car drivers in the world, will he busier than usual next weekend at Watkins Glen in upstate New York.

title: British Woman Held in India Released and Deported
description: NEW DELHI, July 5 (AP)Mary Tyler, a 32yearold British woman imprisoned since 1970 on charges of political terrorism, was ordered today to be released and deported from India.

title: The Jockeys for Today's Race
This Week in Sports
description: Manager Billy Martin and his Texas Rangers play the New York Yankees at 8 P.M. tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday at Shea Stadium. Then Rod Carew leads the Minnesota Twins in for games at 8 P.M. Thursday, Friday and Saturday and 2 P.M. Sunday. Sunday is also Batting Glove Day.

title: The $1Billion Was Just a Start; Next Month, $1Billion More
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, established by the State of New York to rescue New York City from the consequences of its financial misdeeds, has borrowed $1billion and agreed to pay 9.19 per cent interest on the loan. If this was a step toward financial responsibility, it was an expensive way to begin: The rate was well above what the city itself paid last year, when all interest rates were sky high.

title: Seaver Named Top Pitcher for June
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 (AP)Tom Seaver's June record shows he is back to his Cy Young Award winning form and the National League recognized it today by naming the New York Mets' righthander as pitcher of the month.

title: BRIDGE
description: The British Parliament in London has always included a substantial number of cardplayers. In the 18th century the Earl of Sandwich, unwilling to abandon a 24hour marathon game, called for two slices of bread with a piece of meat in between and thereby created the world's most popular luncheon. Some time later the senior Baron of England, the Baron de Ros, achieved a less desirable notoriety by losing a libel suit against those who had accused him of cheating at whist. Lord Henry Bentinck devised the first signal at whist, a highlow which he called the Blue Peter. And Sir Winston Churchill was playing bridge at the Admiralty in 1914 when news from Europe caused him to depart hurriedly and mobilize the British fleet.

title: Ruffian Trails in a Match Of Their Insurance Policies
description: Regardless of how their match race turns out today, Foolish Pleasure will continue to generate more business than Ruffian for horseinsurance agents.

title: Of Men and Liberty
description: Human freedom is always a precarious enterprise. Through thousands of years in Europe, Africa and the Orient, history can tell of human beings ruled by military chieftains, small religious castes, and autocratic monarchsbut it can record only a few brief, sunlit periods of freedom in relatively isolated communities. If history is the guide, one would have to conclude pessimistically that despotism rather than liberty more nearly conforms to human nature and human capacity.

title: Katonka Coast Victor
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 5 (UPI)Katonka defeated the best 3yearold fillies in the West today in capturing the 24th running of the $55,650 Honeymoon Handicap on grass at Hollywood Park.

title: Accommodating the S.E. C.
description: Ever since the Securities and Exchange Commission set up shop in the mid1930's to drive the rascals out of Wall Street. one of (he mast consistent complaints of its highpowered staff has been not the heavy work load that it endures to keep up with rascality, but the poor conditions under which one must labor.

title: Makarova: Why No MajorBallet For Me?
description: I cannot really say that I have been fulfilled in my leap to freedom, ballerina Natalia Makarova said recently, looking back at her five years in the West. Ever since her defection from the Soviet Union in 1970, the outspoken former Kirov star has made no secret of her desire to achieve what every great ballerina wants most: to have major works choreographed for her by important choreographers. Next Tuesday, at last, she will dance the world premiere of John Neumeier's new Epilogue, made for her and Erik Bruhn, at American Ballet Theater.

title: New York at War: Where the Sites Are
description: IN 1776, Fun City was Battle City. During a nineweek period that year, from Sunday morning, Sept. 15, to Saturday afternoon, Nov. 16, armies marched along what are now Fifth Avenue and Broadway, troops were dug in at Harlem and lines of infantry traded volleys of musket fire near the Columbia campus.

title: Article 3  No Title
Ragtime
description: The problem is not so much what as how. Since the time of Henry James, at least, serious novelists have had more trouble deciding how to write than what to write about. Most have felt that the traditional methods of narration had exhausted their possibilities, that they were bound up with conceptions of exterior and interior reality we no longer share, that they were the product of vicious or extinct social conditions; and many novelists also felt that a work of art should be an object in its own right, rather than a report or illustration, that a work of art should explore, not represent, that esthetic like scientific truths can be proved only by experimentation, that, in short, new realities call for new fictions or that new fictions remake reality.

title: 4 Die in Utah Plane Crash
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 5 (UPI)  Officials of the Federal Aviation Administration say they have no clues as to the identity of four persons killed in the crash of a light aircraft north of the Utah State Capitol. The singleengine aircraft nosedived into a hillside in City Creek Canyon yesterday and exploded. The victims  a man, a woman and two chil4ren  were burned beyond recognition.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: LONDON How stands Britain's Royal Ballet? The pound is not doing too well (confidentially, the dollar is in none too fantastic shape either) and Britain's great drama companies are shivering in the genius of their timbers. Money is short, enthusiasm a little slowebbed, and London this summer seems, at least, to one observer, to be wandering through mazes of puzzlement and uncertainty. Talk of inflation seems to be on every tongue; the fact of inflation is certainly striking every pocket. What attitu?? will Britain's so far fairly generous Arts Council (the guys with the money) take? In Italywhere the inflation pattern is the only one in Europe that bids fair to rival Britain'sgovernment spending on the arts has been geared to rises in the economy. Italy has clearly decided that no matter what disaster befalls the lira, at least the average Italian will be able to go bankrupt happy in the knowledge that he can hear the best in statesubsidized music, the most stimulating in statesubsidized drama. Foolish? Not really. The actual amount the Italian government shells out for the arts is not especially large in proportion to the amounts earmarked for the country's other social programs. And yet it is money wellspent, the effect of it is immediate and, chiefly, apart from the groans of a few butterfed critics, the reaction can be nothing but good.

title: Joan Cotter Married to Peter Wibell Jr.
description: St. Isaac Jogues Parish of Valley Forge in Wayne, Pa., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Joan Street Cotter and Peter Oke Vincent Wihell Jr. The Rev. Philip C. Ricci of St. Charles Seminary in Overbrook, Pa., performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: TEENAGE COUPLE HELD IN 2 KILLINGS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5The 16yearold adopted daughter of a wealthy suburban couple and her 19yearold boyfriend are being held without bail here after being charged with the couple's murder.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The Walpack Inn, Route 615, Walpack Center. (201) 9483890 and 9489949. Louise and Adam Heigis came to this part of Sussex County 25 years ago and Opened a small bar and restaurant in what is now the front section of their quaint, rustic establishment. Also involved in operating the inn is their son, James, although he usually spends most of the winter skiing in Aspen, Colo.

title: R. B. Jones Fiance Of Katie A. Newton

description: Conservationists used to accuse builders of raping the land while developers retorted that environmentalists opposed all growth.

title: Minnesota a Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  President Ford declared major disaster status today for Minnesota as a result of floods causing extensive property damage. His action makes Federal aid available, including disaster unemployment assistance for those who lost their jobs as a result of the flooding.

title: Quiet Elegance Is the Style As Family Serves Diners
description: RINGOESWe went out to dinner a great deal, Mrs. Edward Simpson recalled as she prepared coquilles St.Jacques for her dinner guests. And we thought we could run a better restaurant ourselves, added her husband as he tore crisp lettuce leaves into bitesize pieces and tossed them into a large bowl.

title: Indians Rout Red Sox On Bell's Two Homers
description: CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) Buddy Bell belted two home runsone a grand slamand a runscoring double, and Rorie Harrison tossed an eighthitter today to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 122 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: In Celebration of a Real Dump
description: AMERICA'S Number One Dump, in Kennebunkport, Me., is celebrating Its official Bicentennial next year along with the rest of the country. The town is actually much older than the United States, having been founded in 1653, but the dump dates only to 1776, according to Ed Mayo, founder of the Kennebunkport Dump Association. The reason, says Mayo, is that the townspeople were too poor to throw away anything for the first 123 years.

title: Douglas Erwin And Mary Laws Plan to Marry
description: Mary Elizabeth Laws, a June graduate of Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., and Douglas James Erwin, who expects to graduate this month from Duke University, plan to be married in August in the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: At Last, It's a Recession Born 1973
description: It looked like a recession. It felt like a recession. And finally, the National Bureau of Economic Research is ready to announce that it really was a recession. The official starting date for the sixth recession since World War II November, 1973 according to be nation's official chronicler of such events.

title: BigCity Mayors Ask U.S. For Emergency $2Billion
description: BOSTON, July 5  The nation's bigcity mayors, complaining of recessionpinched budgets, called today for $2billion in emergency Federal urban aid as they began their annual meeting.

title: Miss Sheriff to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Sheriff of Bethlehem, Pa., have announced that their daughter, Roberta Lee Sheriff, will be married Aug. 9 to Scot Lewis Pennington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Pennington of Lafayette, Calif., formerly of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Striking Owners to Care for Dogs
description: MIAMI, July 5 (UPI)Greyhound owners began to take care of their dogs tonight after an agreement negotiated by the Circuit Court. The owners were allowed to care for and feed their animals, but agreed the 500 dogs would not be removed from Florida Kennels Inc. They were impounded on Friday when the owners struck against the Flagler dogracing track in a dispute over purses. Perrine Palmer, the courtappointed receiver, welcomed the court order, saying he had urged the owners to come in and care for the dogs.

description: CooperIngber

title: The World
description: Alternating repression of her critics with announcements of help to India's masses, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has apparently silenced much of the opposition to the authoritarian rule she invoked two weeks ago.

title: Ford to Seek Gun Control By a Reduction in Dealers
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The Ford Administration is preparing a gun control bill that seeks to limit the proliferation of handguns through changes in laws affecting gun dealers.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: PIGEONS AT A FEEDER (June 15) G. R., Valley Stream, feeds birds in her yard (17 species) but now she is concerned because pigeons are becoming nuisances at the feeders. She asked how to get rid of them. Here are some ideas. Albert Glantz, a Brooklyn reader scared them away by swishing a broom at pigeons several times each morning the appeared. The desirable birds cooperated by screeching at the pigeons. So far, it's worked. Charles Cocuzza, a Queens reader, suggests pigeons are attracted if the feed is easily accessible while the more desirable species will adapt to small eating quarters. He suggests putting up a number smaller bird feeders suited to the desirable species and not attractive to the heavybodied pigeons. Bernard Levitan, a Westchester County reader, has used an electrical shock devise, similar to electric fence, to keep unwanted birds from his feeder. Its construction is described in an outofprint Conservation Circular written by the late Dr. Peter Paul Kellogg, Cornell University.

title: City Water Supply Seen as Power Source
description: PRATTSVILLE, N. Y., July 3New York City drinking water may be used to generate electric power under a citystate proposal now undergoing extensive engineering studies here.

title: Malpractice Issue Is Tenuous
description: TRENTON  Although a major medical crisis, was averted last week, when a threatened strike by anesthesiologists was canceled, the malpractice situation in New Jersey is very tenuous and could collapse at any time, a spokesman for the state's Department of Insurance declared.

title: Peter Nix Is Fiance Of Mary C. Finnegan
description: Dr. and Mrs. John C. Finnegan of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Catherine Finnegan, to Peter George Nix, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Nix of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Wild Raspberries
description: Plant culturists have done things to domestic berries, most of them improvements. But brook fishermen and back roads walkers as well as countrymen are glad to know there still are unreconstructed raspberries.

description: Sunday, July 6, 1975

title: State Artists Display Skills
description: TRENTONThe 10th annual Art From New Jersey exhibition at the State Museum, shows 54 of the state's artists to advantage. Their work is responsive to contemporary trends and expresses an easy professionality.

title: McClory to Ask House Inquiry Into Alleged Suicide of Sailor
description: CHICAGO, July 5Representative Robert McClory said this week that he would ask the House Armed Services Committee to investigate the circumstances leading to the apparent suicide of an 18yearold Navy recruit who died June 3 after being struck by a commuter train.

title: Bullet Fired From a Mile Away Kills Jerseyan Fixing His Roof
description: A highpowered rifle slug that traveled at least one mile killed an architect Friday as he was working on the porch roof of his home in Chatham Township, N.J., authorities reported.

title: New York Man Identified As Bear Mountain Victim
description: STONY POINT, N.Y., July 5The decomposed body of a man found last April 26 in a sleeping bag in Bear Mountain State Part has been identified as that of a Manhattan resident.

title: Consumer Group Considers TipProof Shopping Carts
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission is considering whether supermarket grocery carts should he made tipproof so that children cannot fall out of them and hurt themselves.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores
PORTUGAL WILL SEIZE BIG FARM HOLDINGS
description: LISBON, July 5 (UPI) Thel Portuguese Government today announced new agrarian reform measures, expropriating large farms and abolishing private hunting estates.

title: Belmont Jockeys
ART VIEW
description: LOS ANGELES At the 70th annual conference of the American Association of Museums, which took place here late last month, there were repeated referencesnone of them favorable or sympatheticto the bad old days when art museums were commonly regarded as sanctuaries, ivory towers and snobbish enclaves (to quote only some of the gentler epithets). Museums were alleged to be indifferent, if not actually hostile, to the interests of the public, and mainly concerned with the judgment of (as one speaker put it) eternity. In session after session, day after day for the better part of a week, one speaker after another came forward to uphold what he felt to be the public interest, and was vigorously applauded for saying something nasty about the museum as citadel of privilege and elitism. The public interest was almost universally perceived by the speakers as existing in an adversary relationship to the traditional practices of museums, and the call for reform verged at times on the demagogic.

title: Mexico, Panama Bid U.S. Give Up the Canal
description: AGUA AZUL, Mexico, July 5 (AP)President Luis Echeverrf a Alvarez and Panama's chief of state, Gen. Omar Torrijos, urged the United States today to give up its hold on the Panama Canal.

title: The Guest Word
description: as much of their humiliation as possible. Materials could theoretically mean honest research, investigative thumping beneath the waterline of gaudy showboats, homework. That's not what comes in those corrugated cardboard mailers young interviewers and new secretaries always cut their fingers on. Who writes that stuff? The publisher's publicist or the author's mother? The Xeroxed reviews are sifted, culled and gerrymandered to suggest that the only possible point on which a divided world can agree is the unparallelable excellence of the enclosed book. If I ever get negative reviews from a publisher I shall go to Washington with a picture of the publicity girl, be she courageous or merely naive, and demand they put her face on a postage stamp.

title: LUTHERAN URGES AN END TO SCHISM
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 5The leader of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod urged the 2.8 millionmember denomination today to heal the divisions that have driven the church to the brink of schism.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 5 (AP)  Delegates to the Young Republicans convention today passed a resolution blaming President Ford as well as Congress for the nation's economic woes.

title: MARCHI PLAN AIMS TO RESTORE FERRY
description: State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that he would seek to amend a pending $90million masstransit bill for New York City to restore allnight service on the Staten Island ferry, now halted between 11 P.M. and 5 A.M. as part of Mayor Beame's fiscal austerity program.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Scales get away with serious trouble making long before they are detected because they are good hiders. These insects fasten to the backs of leaves, especially along the ?? and along tender bark twigs and branches. There they remain, protected by their outer shell, to suck up vital juices from plants.

title: Basically, They Say a Settlement Must Come All at Once
description: WASHINGTONThe Ford Administration has been saying that there are only two viable approaches to peace in the Middle East: either another limited IsraeliEgyptian accord or a return to Geneva where the Arab states, Israel, the United States, and the Soviet Union could seek to negotiate an overall settlement. But a growing number of distinguished foreign policy experts dispute these choices and suggest some new ones.

title: Diego Garcia May Perform the Same Facility Service for the U.S.
description: WASHINGTONFor nearly two years, Defense Department officials have been warning, on the basis of satellite reconnaissance photographs, that the Soviet Union was constructing a naval facility at the Somalian port of Berbera, which commands the strategic approaches to the Red Sea.

description: BRUSSELSThe European Economic Community, which traditionally has purchased enriched uranium almost exclusively from the United States, is turning increasingly to the Soviet Union to fuel its nuclearpower plants at least through the 1970's, while Europe develops her own production capacity.
