description: Many gardeners overlook the curious bulbs that bloom in fall. They can provide delightful pockets of color and surprises for garden visitors.

title: Winningham's Texans
description: Geoff Winninghams reputation as a perceptive young documentary photographer is based on two books, Friday Night at the Coliseum and Going Texan. in which pictures and text are intertwined in a whole that is greater than its parts. Essentially he is a photoessayist, though unlike the great photoessayists of Life he works at book length and does his own writing and editing. Few Of his pictures really stand alone, and consequently an exhibition like the one now at Witkin Gallery, where pictures from several different essays are mixed together without the sequencing and supporting text of an essay, does not really do him justice.

A trip to New England with its lush green foliage, and unforgettable vistas of the Green and White Mountains, the broad expanse of Lake Champlain and a visit to the lakes region of New Hampshire are magnets that year after year attract exhibitors.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 5 (Reuters)A bus and a truck collided headon near the port of BandarAbbas in southern Iran, killing 21 people, authoritative reports said today.

title: A Correction
description: In an article in this section last Sunday, there were several errors concerning Shoppe Village, a minimall in West Babylon. Shoppe Village has been open four weekday nights, as well as on Saturdays, since March 1. Also, the pickle outlet there is Mr. Pickle.

description: Kathleen Tatiana McKenna, a publicist here, and Sedat Pakay, also of New York and a producer at Compton Advertising, plan to be married Sept. 24.

title: FILM VIEW
description: By this time you must already know whether or not you can live another minute without seeing Nashville. Love and Death, The Fortune, Jaws and The Return of The Pink Panther The chances are this summer that you won't be able to get in to see Nashville on your first couple of attempts. There'll be lines an 1 somebody with you will say tohellwithitI'mnotgoingtostandinlineforanydamnmovie and you'll go next door, or down the highway, and you'll pay good money to see something you've only vaguely heard of. The following is a consumer's guide to nine such films, a couple of which are worth seeing, a couple of which are not at all bad, and the rest of which are to be avoided with varying degrees of resolution if not panic. They are listed in alphabetical order:

Evans in St. Paul's. Anglican Church in Paget, Bermuda. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Goerl of Anif, Austria, formerly of PoUnd Ridge, N.Y.

title: An Ancient Temple Rises at the Met
description: At first glance, the construction site reminds me of an. operating room for surgery, what with the brilliance cant by numerous 500watt latups, the circle of faces deep in concentration, and speech which is reduced to tense commands. But this image of the rebuilding of the ancient Egyptian Temple of Dendur at The Metropolitan Museum of Art gives way to others. As I make my way through the scaffolding inside a steel hangarlike enclosure for a closer look, a truck coughs raucously to life. And somewhere ??earth me, two hardnats trade jibes.

title: 32 Hurt by Liquid
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 5 (AP)Thirtytwo persons attending a Fourth of July fireworks display were treated at a hospital after three teenagers threw a liquid irritant into the crowd, at Carlisle High School football stadium, the Police said.

title: Riders in Dead Heat
description: Going into today's program, Jacinto Vasquez and Braulio Baeza, the riders in The Great Match Race, were the leading jockeys at Belmont this meeting. Vasquez, who is aboard Ruffian had won 23 of 150 races. Baeza, Foolish Pleasure's rider, had won 23 of 159.

title: Bellevue
description: Short of the Mayo Clinic and Marcus Welby's mythic miracleworks, Bellevue may well be the most famous hospital in the world. A great welter of 79 clinics and facilities, New York's one  time pesthouse along First Avenue, which recently moved into new quarters, has seemingly acquired a reputation and personality all its own. Inevitably then, Bellevue itself would become the central figure in a book. What old lady could be more deserving than this institution which can trace its history to 1658?

title: Sealing Out Moisture
description: One of the most frequent causes of paint peeling around the outside of a house is moisture working its way in behind the siding or trim, and one of the most effective weapons the homeowner can use to combat this is a calking gunan inexpensive tool that all homeowners should be familiar with.

title: U.N.'s Palestinian Refugee Agency Faces Fund Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5The United Nations' 25yearold aid program for Palestinian Arab refugees will run out of funds this fall unless additional contributions are given in the nest few weeks, according to diplomats and officials here.

description: The denouement in New York City's serial on the municipal budget has finally occurred, but in an atmosphere of bitterness in the state legislature as well as on the streets. Though political compromise provided a veneer Of normality, the resolution has left the city altered, probably irrevocably.

title: Wage Pact in Pennsylvania Approved by Largest Union
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 5 (AP)The leaders of Pennsylvania's largest union of state employes approved this afternoon a new twoyear wagel agreement designed to end a strike by 46,000 state workers that began Tuesday.

description: WASHINGTON, July 5Secretary of State Kissinger suggested today that the degree of American support for Israel would be linked to whether the Israelis take a chance and make the territorial concessions needed to bring about a new accord with the Egypians in Sinai.

title: Political Bickering Lowers Rating
description: TRENTON  When they calculate state bond ratings, organizations such as Moody's Investors Service have traditionally relied more heavily on such easily measured technicalities as debt coverage and other financial ratios than on the imponderables of politics.

description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, July 5 (AP)An interstate passenger bus carrying 36 passengers collided with a loaded truck yesterday, killing 11 persons and seriously injuring 20, the police reported.

description: TodayBaltimore at Shea Stadium, 2, 1 P.M.

title: Timbers Growing With Spectators
description: The Portland Timbers have triumphed in nine of their last 10 games and are attracting crowds in a city where no colleges have a varsity soccer program. The Timbers drew 18,278 spectators last Thursday night in beating the Vancouver Whitecaps. Coached by Vic Crowe, the Oregon team is led by Pete Withe, the English centerforward who has scored seven goals in 13 games. Withe has won two games for Portland by scoring in suddendeath overtime. Willie Anderson has also scored twice in suddendeath and the Timbers have won all their overtime games.

title: Unbuckling The Bible Belt
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.I pulled up behind an offred pickup truck the other day. The driver had attached a National Rifle Association decal to his rear window and had posted a collection of stickers on his rusty bumper: America: Love It or Leave It, Honk if you believe in Jesus, and WBAMWhere We Love our Country.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ...to Kennebunkport, you will find other attractions in town and in nearby Kennebunk besides the dump. The Seashore Trolley Museum has 80 antique trolley cars and is open seven days a week, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., with rides every halthour. Admission is $2 for adults, $1 for children (under 6 free). The museum has a picnic grove and a gift shop that sells railroadiana. Cape Porpoise is a typical Maine fishing village with lobster boats, trawlers and draggers tied up at the wharf, while Goose Rocks Beach is noted for its fine, gently sloping sand. Many old Colonial houses, and some handsome New England churches, draw admirers, and the Brick Store Museum, open Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., admission free, displays relics from the shipbuilding days of the Kennebunks. Places to stay, besides the Nonantum, site of the Miss Dumpy contest, include the vast Shawmut Inn, right on the seacoast. Rates for a double room at the Nonantum run from $48 to $70 per person a day with three meals; at the Shawmut, doubles range from $33 to $47 a person a day with two meals.R.B.

title: Mary Wenks Engaged
description: Mary Diane Wenks and Daniel Barry Dinneen, graduates of Marietta College with the class of '74, were married yesterday afternoon by Msgr. George Bardes in the Roman Catholic Church of SS John and Paul in Larchmont, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Edward Wenks of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Capt. John Hamilton Dinneen, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Dinneen of Hanover, Pa., are the parents of the couple.

title: H. L. HUNT'S PAPER ENDS PUBLICATION
description: DALLAS, July 5Lifelines, the antiCommunist newspaper founded by the late H. L. Hunt, has printed its final edition.

title: The Region
description: For years Eugene Hollander has been chief spokesman in New York City for the nursinghome industry; last week he was indicted by both state and Federal grand juries on charges that he has stolen, through nursing homes that he owns, more than $1.2million in Medicaid and Medicare funds.

title: Mary Glennon Plans Nuptials

Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Randolph Glennon of Riverside, Conn., parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall Kernochan, also of Riverside.

title: HOG CHOLERA FOUND IN TEXAS OUTBREAK
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  Hog producers throughout the Southwest and in the rest of the nation are being warned to watch for signs of hog cholera in their herds following the first confirmed outbreak of the disease in the United States in more than a year.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: TV VIEW
description: At 4:10 P.M. on Tuesday June 24, an airliner crashed on its approach to JFK International Airport. The death toll was 110 persons. By 11:30 that evening following the latenight news programs, broadcasting inadvertently had prompted several serious questions about its coverage of the gruesome event. A few of the problems were perhaps rooted in the basic process of journalism itself.

title: Taking the Lemons Out of the Warranty
description: A lemon, as everyone knows, is a somewhat bitter tasting citrus fruit (actually, it's a berry) produced mainly in Florida and California. But a lemon, as any consumer advocate will testify, is a consumer product that never seems to workit also leaves a bitter taste, and it can be produced anywhere. Now, for the first time, consumers may get a chance to have errant manufacturers eat some of the oddities they foist upon the public. The reason: the new MagnusonMoss Warranty and Federal Trade Commission Improvement Actotherwide known as The Lemon Law.

title: Harvard and Dietz Gain Henley Finals
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 5Records fell today in six of the 12 cup events in the semifinal rounds of the Henley Royal Regatta. By far the best recordshattering performances occurred in the premier event, Grand Challenge Cup for eights.

title: Saratoga Conducts Trot Circuit Card
description: Harness racing's Grand Circuit stops off at Saratoga this week. The drivers and trainers there will include Nerve Filion, Stanley Dancer, Bill and Peter Haughton, Lew Williams, Joe O'Brien and Glen Garnsey.

title: BRUTALITY IS LAID TO SUBURBAN JAILS
description: Separate Federal lawsuits have been filed charging that prisoners in Westchester and Putnam County jails are subjected to physical brutality, live in unsanitary conditions, lack proper medical care and have little recreation or exercise.

title: J.A. Clark 3d Is Fiance Of Jamesine E. Burke
description: The engagement of JamesIne E. Burke to Joseph A. Clark 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Jr. of Cliffside Park, N.J., has been announced by Eileen M. Burke, of Yaphank, L.I., mother of the future bride.

title: The Enrichment Process
description: Enriching uranium amounts to separating the naturally occurring isotopes of uranium to achieve a greater concentration of the rare U235, the only isotope that can sustain a chain reaction, which is needed to generate heat for electrical power production.

title: George Wallace Again?
description: WASHINGTON, July 5How can it be that after everything this nation has already suffered In the last dozen years, some Americans actually contemplate inflicting George C. Wallace upon the country as President?

title: Allan Jacks, 60, Reporter Led A.P. Bureau in Rome
description: ROME, July 5 (AP)  Allan Jacks, chief of the Rome bureau of The Associated Press and a veteran foreign correspondent, died of cancer at his home last night. He was 60 years old.

title: COLOMBIA INURED TO STATES OF SEIGE
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 5 (UPI)The first week of President Alfonso Lpez Michelsen's state of siege passed almost imperceptibly in Bogota, perhaps because Colombians have lived under states of siege more often than not since 1948.

title: The Opera: New Faces at the Bolshoi
description: The Bolshoi Opera's performances of Boris Godunov on Friday night and Pique Dame yesterday afternoon were both highly convincing, and cast changes in both operas didn't affect the overall impact much.

title: A Philippine City Hears From Manila That Its U.S. Base Has Unsure Future
description: OLONGAPO,the PhilippinesA short twolane bridge connects the sleek United States naval base at Subic Bay with this burgeoning city of souvenir shops, gaudy minibuses and garish night clubs.

title: A Senatorial Outdoorsman
description: ALBANYThere is still a trace of the soft, Pennsylvaniamountain accent in Bernard C. Smith's voice when, infrequently, he speaks in State Senate debate. Tanned and trim, he has the look of the outdoors.

title: Junior Track Units Beat Soviet Union
description: LINCOLN, Neb., July 5 (UPI)The American men's junior track team broke two meet records and the women's team broke two and tied one to defeat the Soviet. Union today in the United StatesU.S.S.R. junior track meet.

title: ALEXANDER CROSETT
description: Alexander D. Crosett, engineer here until his retirement in 1963, died Friday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 86 years old and also lived in Osterville, Mass.

title: Miss Bennett Wed To John F. Evans
description: The marriage of Katherine Bennett to John Frank Evans, sorb of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Evans of Hollywood, took place yesterday afternoon in Kent Cliffs, N. Y. Gen. Ivan L. Bennett, retired Chief of Chaplains for the Army and grandfather of the bride, performed the Protestant ceremony at the country home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Bennett Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Tennis in Cold Blood
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5Everything here is proper, if not genteel. At the nearby Southfields stop on the London underground, the sign reminds, Alight Here for Wimbledon. Roses bloom on the balconies of mod apartments and in the gardens of old gingerbread homes along the narrow leafy streets. Among the flowers outside the historic centercourt enclosure are porticos where strawberries and cream, champagne and bonbons are sold. Wimbledon is tennis. And tennis propriety. Not even Alfred Hitchcock would use Wimbledon as the backdrop for a murder. Unthinkable. But today Arthur Ashe stabbed Jimmy Connors in four sets and in cold blood for the men's singles championship. The traditionalists cheered.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Make this dirty ashtray beautiful! Cond Nast used to scream at the fashion photographers of Vogue. If you can't make a masterpiece out of this dirty ashtray, a picture worthy to hang in a museum, you'll never be a photographer.

title: He Is Struggling for the Survival of his Guerrilla Bases in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT When Yaser Arafat stood before the General Assembly of the United Nations daft November, many Palestinians felt that the door to international recognition had finally opened to them.

title: Daniel Yergin to Wed Angela Stent
description: Angela Evelyn Stent, a Harvard teaching fellow, and Daniel Howard Yergin, a research fellow at Harvard and a writer, plan to  marry in London on Aug. 10. Their engagement has been announced by Miss S tent's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Walter Stent of Earling, London. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Yergin of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Letters: In Behalf of Barnum & Bridgeport
description: To the Editor:

title: Maur Bettman Engaged To William D. B. Hiller
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Bettman of Petaluma, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maur Bettman, to William Douglas Bush Hiller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hiller of Honolulu. The wedding is planned for Aug. 16.

title: Catherine Godard Magruder Is Married to Peter Armour
description: Catherine Godard Magruder and Peter Hugh Armour were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hull Magruder, in Fairfield, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John H. Cole of the United Methodist Church in Rowayton, Conn.

title: Shoppers Demand Cost Cuts On Food
description: EAST ORANGEDo you find your meat and vegetable prices higher on pay day than during the rest of the week?

title: Anthony Napolitano Weds Mary Re
description: Mary Ann Re, daughter of Judge Edward D. Re of the United States Customs Court and Mrs. Re of Neponsit, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Anthony Napolitano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Napolitano of Bellerose, Queens. The Rev. John Maetta, assisted by the Rev. Anthony Logatto, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel of the Fort Hamilton Army Base in Brooklyn.

title: Driver Kills a Woman And a Man Aiding Her
description: DETROIT, July 5 (AP)A hitandrun motorist fatally struck a woman pedestrian on a city street, then turned around and fatally struck a man who had come to her aid, an eyewitness told the police. The driver then escaped, the police said.

title: J.D.L. Gets Rejected By Advisory Council On Membership Bid
description: The National Jewish Community Relations Advisory Council has rejected a bid for membership from the Jewish Defense League, charging that the league had a history of encouraging and undertaking acts of violence.

title: Elizabeth Brady Is Bride of Robert Metz
description: Elizabeth Brady and Robert Metz were married yesterday afternoon at the Scarsdale, N. Y., home of the bridegroom's brother, David Metz. The bridegroom's father, the Rev. Carl A. Metz, a retired pastor of the Brookfield (N. Y.) Baptist Church, performed the ceremony. His parents live in Lakewood, N. J.

title: Refugee Camp Doing Brisk Business in Gold Exchange
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 5Smiling nervously, a welldressed young Vietnamese woman slipped into a trailer across from a noncommissioned officers' club on this southern California Marine base the other day clutching a battered gold necklace.

title: Without Mr. Right or Miss Wonderful
description: One out of every time adults in the United States is either single, widowed or divorced. Of these, 10 million are widows, 2 million are widowers, 5 million are divorced, and have not remarried, 4 million are separated, 12.5 million are raising one or more minor children, and 90 per cent of these children are being raised by single mothers. In a country devoted to the credo that a child needs two parents and that every healthy adult needs a constant, loving mate, how do 43 million single people cope?

title: DiMaggio at 60: Baseball Was My Life
description: In March, 1974, Joe DiMagglo was in Florida for a golf tournament at the Doral Country Club in Miami, and I was at spring training with the Yankees. We made a date.

title: Honky Star, $12.20, Wins Molly Pitcher
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 Honky Star, a 4yearold filly with a special liking for Monmouth Park, won the $55,625 Molly Pitcher Handicap today, defeating the favorites, Twixt and Bundler.

title: Lara Lawrence Burns Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. Burns of Greenwich, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lara Lawrence Burns, to Thomas Donald Cunningham 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cunningham Jr. of Bedford. N.Y.

title: HUNDREDS ELIGIBLE FOR REFUND IN FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission has announced that hundreds, perhaps thousands, of former students may still be eligible to share in a $1.25million refund from a chain of computer and vocational schools that allegedly defrauded them by promising jobs they did not get.

title: A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: In the middle of that dusty, mudandconcrete sprawl called Riyadh, surrounded by camera shops, perfume bazaars and streams of Detroit's best burnished metal, there stands a little mud fort to which every visitor to the Saudi Arabian capital feels called upon to make his pilgrimage. Its name is the Musmak, and 73 years ago it was the site of the nation's birth. That was on a day in 1902 when a young scion of the House of Saud named Abdul Aziz Ibn Saud led 30 tribal warriors in an assault on the fort, put the defenders to the sword in the name of Allah and proclaimed the revival of his own clan as the lords of central Arabia.

title: Liberal College Is Denied Federal Grant
description: Franconia College, a small avantgarde institution in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, has been denied a $563,275 Federal grant to support an experimental cooperative project with a local school district, a program that was bitterly opposed by the state's conservative Governor, Meidrim Thomson Jr., and the state's largest newspaper, the conservative Manchester Union Leader.

title: 32 Hurt by Liquid
description: CARLISLE, Pa., July 5 (AP)Thirtytwo persons attending a Fourth of July fireworks display were treated at a hospital after three teenagers threw a liquid irritant into the crowd, at Carlisle High School football stadium, the Police said.

title: British Publish Papers On Early Years of Nazis
description: LONDON, July 5The attitude of officials in the British Foreign Office to the early stages of Hitlerism was illustrated in documents published here this week.

title: Article 4  No Title
2 HELD IN MURDER OF AUTO MECHANIC
description: Two men were arrested yesterday and charged with the slaying and dismemberment of a Brooklyn foreign car mechanic last June.

title: Third Avenue: A Microcosm of the Ever Changing Brooklyn Scene
description: Sing a song of Third Avenue, Brooklyn. Not so grand as Third Avenue, Manhattan. Not so rich in real estate, nostalgia, or literary lore. But a street of significance, nevertheless. A street of color. And a street of change.

title: Ford Assures Indonesian Of U.S. Asian Commitment
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., July 5President Suharto of Indonesia received assurances here today from President Ford that the United States remained committed to an active presence in Southeast Asia despite the American withdrawal from Indochina.

title: Bucky Fuller and the Final Exam
description: On a clear day, from Bucky Fuller's apartment 30 stories above Philadelphia, you can see, if not forever, at least all the way into the 19th century, demagogic, sooty.

title: Design
description: Designers have turned their attention to a neglected area, hardware for the home, and come up with a variety of shapes in new materials (colorful, antistatic nylon tubing) and old (aluminum, bronze and handforged iron).

title: Sally Behr Sets Wedding in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Karl H. Behr of Princeton, N. J., and Lake Wales, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sally Perot Behr of New York to S. Herbert Ogden Jr., son of Mr. Ogden of Ithan, Pa., and Vero Beach, Fla., and Margaret L. Ogden of Villanova, Pa., and Fishers Island, N. Y.

title: Joan Joyce: She's Softball's Catfish
description: Take the screwball of Tug McGraw, the curveball of Tom Seaver and the fastball of Nolan Ryan, add the pitching records of Sandy Koufax and Catfish Hunter and you still won't measure up to Joan Joyce. Miss Joyce, at the age of 34, has a record even those baseball standouts would envy. In her 15year career in the Women's Amateur Softball League she has won 343 of 367 games, hurled 75 nohitters, 17 perfect games, and struck out 4,860 batters. On her team, the Raybestos Brackettes of Stratford, Conn., she is known as the female Catfish Hunter.

title: Leslie Schindler Is Bride
description: In the Universalist Church of Woodstock, Vt., yesterday afternoon Leslie Schindler, daughter of Scot N. Stahl Schindler of Sharon, Vt., and Donald W. Schindler of Morristown, N. J., was married to Michael Merwin Chater, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Guy Chater of Stuart, Fla., and Bronxville, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Horace Westwood.

title: Andrea Waller Becomes Bride Of Donald Lee
description: Andrea Lynn Waller and Donald. Perry Lee, graduates of Ohio Wesleyan University, were married yesterday afternoon in Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Chalmers Coe performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: Bright Days in DoortoDoor Sales
description: The present and future health of the American ?? ??my is still open to debate, but one thing is for surecompanies involved in doortodoor selling are not unhappy with things as they are. Sales forces are swelling, and sales are expected to.

title: Cape Verde Islands Gain Freedom From Portugal
description: PRAIA, Cape Verde Islands, July 5The poor and drought plagued Cape Verde Islands became independent today, ending 515 years of Portuguese rule.

title: Doubletalk on Rights
description: President Ford's request for black support for his policy of budgetary restraint in dealing with the economy is unconvincing. In making his appeal to the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Mr. Ford not only set his sights well below the expectations of the nation's black leadership, but also fell far short of the standards he set for himself before assuming the Presidency.

title: U.S. Evaluates Strategies and Forces in PostIndochina World
description: Senior officers involved in the longterm planning of United States strategy report that friends and allies, particularly in Asia, tend to underestimate American military power, but that potential adversaries, including the Soviet Union, have a higher estimate of that power but doubt American political stability.

title: 12 Firemen Injured Fighting A Blaze on Lower East Side
description: Twelve firemen were injured last night fighting a smokey threealarm fire in a fivestory vacant tenement on the Lower East Side that forced the temporary evacuation of an adjacent tenfamily dwelling. None of the firemen's injuries were reported as serious.

title: Katrena Kerst, M. H. Engstrom To Wed Sept. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard N. Kerst of Katonah, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katrena Bolling Kerst, to Morten H. Engstrom, son of Mrs. Howard T. Engstrom of Ellisville, Mass., and the late Mr. Engstrom. The wedding is planned for Sept. 6.

title: TV VIEW
description: I met Fair Critical Comment the other day on the street. He was walking his hound, whose name is Sober Second Thought. It seems that I am always meeting Fair and Sober on what is known as The Morning After, and they are always disappointed in me. Fair said: I read your column on salaries for TV stars and L was, frankly, disappointed in you.

title: ExG.O.P. Leader Has New Party Hat
description: COPIAGUEThe man who was once the Republican chairman in Suffolk County now feels he has better prospects with the Democrats and so Robert A. Curcio has switched his party enrollment.

title: Nuggets Ticket Sales Up
description: DENVER. July 5 (AP)Denver Nuggets season ticket sales have gone over the 4,000 mark, Carl Sheer, the president and general manager, said today. The total of 4,025 season tickets already purchased for the 197576 American Basketball Association season surpasses the season total of 2,770 last year. The Nuggets will be playing in the new, 18,000seat McNichols Arena this season.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Amateur photographers who dream of turning professional often start out by trying to sell some of their pictures. With little or no idea of how and where to begin, however, they soon find that this can be a frustrating experienceas well as being mentally and physically exhausting. One way to avoid the need for endlessly toting a portfolio doortodoor is to consider putting one's pictures on file with an organization whose business it is to sell photographs in other words, a photo agency.

title: Cats and Plants Are Not Meant For Each Other
description: When it comes to plants, cats live dangerously. Whether or not endowed with nine lives, curiosity has often killed them. Bored, housebound pets may vary from the occasional nibbler to the compulsive destroyer of all greenery.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: UNEMPLOYMENT IN JUNE DROPPED to 8.6 per cent of the work force seasonally adjusted from a level of 9.2 per cent in May. Employment rose to 84.4 million workers, a gain of 42,000 from May. . . . United States car sales June were the strongest in 11 months, topping May sales by 7 to 8 per cent, but were behind June 1974 by more than 10 per cent. . . . Manufacturers' Inventories in May fell by $1.44billion, the largest ever in dollar terms. Total new orders rose 0.3 per cent, by $260million.

title: Logically, Serving Congress Is Its Primary Task
description: WASHINGTONWhat Washington institution's assets include the blueprints of a 19thcentury Russian Orthodox church in Alaska, President Harding's love letters, a Gutenberg Bible, Sigmund Freud's papers, but not, repeat not, a copy of every book published?

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange dropped the holidayweek, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing 1.33 points to 871.79. In the first half of the year the Dow rose 41.7 per cent256.88 points to 873.12.

title: Minnesota a Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  President Ford declared major disaster status today for Minnesota as a result of floods causing extensive property damage. His action makes Federal aid available, including dis??ter unemployment assistance for those who lost their jobs as a result of the flooding.

title: Canadians in Spirited Dispute Over Automating Mail Service
description: OTTAWA, July 5Canadian post office authorities and the powerful Union of Postal Workers are involved in a spirited dispute over a $120million automation program, already functioning in six cities, that is expected to give Canada the most mechanized mail service in the world.

title: Situation Wanted: Trvl Agt School Grad, No Exp...
description: IN the course of researching the accompanying article, I completed the travel agents' curriculum of the Sobelsohn School at 1540 Broadway, New York. I had learned of the school, one of six in the city, from an advertisement that proclaimed that our graduates are in demand. I chose to attend Sobelsohn because the location and class times were particularly convenient for me.

title: The Underground Looks Up
description: MADRIDNot quite thirty years ago I lunched at a restaurant opposite Madrid's main bullring with a member of the threeman delegation that ran the illegal Spanish Communist party (P.C.E.), a dapper 33yearold I knew only by the alias Felipe.

title: Our Youngest Symphonic Composer Turns 60
description: One morning late in December 1941, the young American composer David Diamond sat patiently in Carnegie Hall waiting for Dimitri Mitropoulos to conduct the New York Philharmonic in a rehearsal of his new Symphony No. 1. At the sound of the first notes, Diamond noticed a familiar figure on the opposite side of the hall leap to his feet and bolt for the exitit was Sergei Rachmaninoff, who had expected the orchestra to begin the rehearsal with his own Symphony No. 3. Please tell Diamond, Rachmaninoff later explained to Mitropoulos, that it was nothing personal and no reflection on his symphony. I simply do not have time to spend listening to new music by American composers.

title: Dedicated Officer Who Was Laid Off Is Upset and Perplexed by His Plight
description: When Police Officer Robert Usinger received his letter of regret from Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd last week, he was not surprised.

title: HorseRacing Figure Slain On Way to Track in Jersey
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 5 A. Bronx man who was a familiar figure at metropolitan race tracks, where he provided apparel for riders, was shot and killed today outside a motel here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Events
description: 10:30 A.M., 1 P.M., and 3:30 P.M., Staten Island Ferry, South Ferry: Jazz on the Hudson River Boat Ride, with Papa French and the Original Tuxedo Jazz Band from New Orleans; Michel Attenoux, Nice (France) Festival winner, and Miriam Klein, singer.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: DESPITE rather convincing evidence that the nation has recently bobbed up from the trough of its worst recession in four decades, there is no great elation in economic circles over nearterm prospects for the American economy.

title: Shorter Takes 10,000Meter Run
description: STOCKHOLM, July 5 (AP)Frank Shorter, the United States Olympic marathon champion, won the 10,000meter event here today in an excellent time of 27 minutes 57.6 seconds.

title: Troubled MobileHome Market Detects PickUp
description: In the wake of a disastrous fall and winter, mobile home sales appear to be picking up, though industry spokesmen remain cautious.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Mr. Baker, Washington State's third highest peak, has become the world's 456th currently active volcano, and scientists are gathering to study the rebirth of the 10,778foot mountain in the Cascades.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, July 5 (Reuters)Twentyfour leaders of the former Greek junta, including former President George Papadopoulos, will go on trial on charges of treason on July 28, it was announced here today.

title: State Title Archery to Begin Friday
description: A throwback to archery's earlier days, when the how and arrow was used for warfare rather than for just sport, will be in focus next Friday as the threeday New York State championships are held at Greene, N. Y.

title: The Region
description: On Monday, while Mayor Beams flew to Albany to consult with state officials on New York City's fiscal crisis, Governor Carey flew to the city and, among other things, consulted with his able media and public relations adviser, David Garth.

title: Laurie Dodge Bride of Robert Ingersoll
description: Laurie Neville  Dodge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Dodge of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Reid Ingersoll, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Ingersoll of Chicago and Lakeside, Mich. The Rev. H. Scott Tonk, en Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Ingersoll home in Lakeside.

title: Dick Gregory ReArrested After Picketing White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)Dick Gregory, the comedian and social activist, was arrested today for the second time in two days on charges of demonstrating without a permit in front of the White House.

title: SPANISH LEFTISTS GAIN IN UNION VOTE
description: MADRID, July 4Members of the opposition to the Spanish political and social system have made sweeping advances in voting for factorylevel representatives in the statesponsored trade unions.

title: Mrs. Doubleday Wed to Laurance Rand
description: Mrs. James M. Doubleday, the former Elizabeth G. Ballard of Southport, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., and Laurance B. Rand of Southport, and New York, who recently retired from LaidlawCoggeshall, Inc., brokerage concern here, were married yesterday morning. The ceremony was performed in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., by the Rev. John C. Harper, of Washington.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The degree of American support for Israel, Secretary of State Kissinger suggested yesterday, would be linked to whether the Israelis take a chance and make the territorial concessions needed to bring about a new accord with the Egyptians in Sinai. The Israeli Cabinet will meet today to decide whether to withdraw from the strategic mountain passes of Mitla and Gidi. It had refused to do so earlier because of dissatisfaction with the limited political concessions offered by Egypt. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: The Travel Agent: Tricks of the Trade
description: THE travel agent lives on commissions paid by airlines, hotels and other such providers of tourist services; he does not generally charge his clients a nickel. But in recent months, agents have been restless. Some have been lobbying intensely for higher commissions. Others have called for client fees.

title: Indian Against Indian, Indian Against Whites
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D.In Lakota, the Sioux Indian language, the word for a mixedblood or halfbreed is eyesiza. Literally translated, it means those who speak white.

title: E.P.A. ASKS COURT TO BAR CHARGES
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has asked a Brooklyn Federal Court judge to dismiss charges that it acted arbitrarily and capriciously in agreeing to finance a Long Island waste disposal system based on piping wastes into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: United Jewish Appeal Names Levy Chairman
description: The appointment of Gustave L. Levy, philanthropist and communal leader, as chairman of the 1976 United Jewish Appeal and Federation of Jewish Philanthropies campaign, was announced last night.

title: Young G.O.P. Asks Open Convention
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 5The Young Republicans in convention here, mostly deepdyed conservatives who do not like President Ford very much, called today in their most important resolution for an open party convention next yeara polite way of saying they would rather see former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California win the party's Presidential nomination.

title: All the World's a Stage
description: It wasn't in our thinking when the racing season began, LeRoy Jolley was saying while two tan stable dogs wolfed their dinner outside Foolish Pleasure's stall at Belmont Park. Not a match race, anyway. I guess we kicked around the idea that he might run against Ruffian someday, but we had plenty of other work in mind for him.

title: Sounders Top Cosmos, 20
description: SEATTLE, July 5 (AP)The Seattle defense upstaged Pel today and carried the Sounders to a 20 victory over the New York Cosmos in a nationally televised game between North American Soccer League division leaders.

title: Rosemary Corroon Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Corroon of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary V. Corroon, to Maurice Langhorne Martin Jr. He is the son of Colonel Martin, U.S. A.F. retired, and Mrs. Martin of St. Louis. A September wedding is planned in Aspen, Colo., where Miss Corroon has been working as an interior decorator.

title: The School Is a Landmark, and a Perfect Place for a Bridal Party
description: A convent may seem an unlikely place for a wedding reception. But then how many convents have a Belle Epoque ballroom, with floortoceiling windows and mirrored doors, lushly ornate ceiling and fireplace, and a hidden balcony for musicians?

title: Youth Attacked by Shark
description: INDIATLANTIC, Fla., July 5 (AP)A 16yearold youth who was attacked yesterday by a shark here while surfing at a public beach was released from a hospital today following surgery. Robert Clark, who was bitten on the foot, underwent surgery for damaged tendons.

title: Lieutenant to Wed Elizabeth A. Lough
description: Col. Frederick Charles Lough, U.S.A. professor of law at the United States Military Academy, West Point, N.Y., and Mrs. Lough, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Lough, to Lieut. Charles Carroll Thebaud Jr., U.S.A.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Naturally, one associates going away on a month's vacation with a sigh of relief. But it is surprising how many different kinds of sighs, and how many different kinds of relief, there are. For instance, though I'm gighing right now, I'm not sighing with weariness over being a reviewer who's come to the tag end of a surprisingly busy season. I'm sighing with joy over not being an actor. For some of the actorsmany of the actorswho grace our theater are just now going to work, girding themselves for bouts with summer theaters and dinner theaters and all sorts of theaters that offer them a sustenance wintertime Broadway may not provide.

title: The World
description: As has happened often in the past, when peace negotiations in the Middle East reach a delicate stage, a Palestinian terror attack threatens to disrupt the negotiations. Last week it happened again: a bomb was planted in the heart of Jerusalem, and Palestinian guerrillas took credit for the act. The bomb exploded at the height of the preSabbath rush hour, killing 13 Israelis and wounding 72 others.

title: Nicklaus Posts 65 In Practice Round
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 5 (AP)Jack Nicklaus, the 92 favorite to win the British Open golf championship starting here Wednesday, carded a sizzling sevenunderpar 65 today during a practice session.

title: House Tour Is Set For Bay Head Area
description: BAY HEADGracious living along the shores of Barnegat Bay will be the theme of a house tour that the Seaweeders Garden Club of Bay Head and Mantoloking will sponsor Thursday afternoon. Flowers grown by the occupants also will be on disolay.

title: After the Trial, Doctor Finds Peace
description: RICE LAKE, Wis.For the first time since he was acquitted of the willful murder of a terminally ill cancer patient in Nassau County on Long Island 16 months ago, Dr. Vincent A., Montemarano entered a courtroom last month and testified for the prosecution in an attempted murder case.

title: Mexico City Meeting . . .
description: Behind the rhetoric that flowed so abundantly at the United Nations Conference on Women in Mexico City, two very different sets of perceptions and priorities were seen in conflict.

title: Wisconsin Gives Convicts New Way to Get Out Early
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The Wisconsin State Reformatory is only a short distance from the new Ramada Inn here.

title: Food: The art of barbecue
description: Charcoal fires for pork barbecue

title: VISIT BY CALLAGHAN TO AMIN IS EXPECTED
description: KINSHASA, July 5 (Reuters)  The British Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan, will visit Kampala next Wednesday for talks with President Idi Amin of Uganda, in the wake of the reprieve of Denis Cecil Hills, a British lecturer, the Zaire news agency, AZAP, reported today.

title: CHESS
description: Through the 10th round of the United States championship, no one had been able to break away for a big lead, nor had anyone collapsed into the cellar. Walter Browne formally held the lead with three wins and seven draws, although Kenneth Rogoff, who had three wins and six draws, was expected to pass him by winning his superior rook, bishop and pawn ending from Lubomir Kavalek.

title: Canadians Choose Woman
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 5 (AP)Joyce Nash was chosen president of the New Democratic party today, becoming the first woman to head a national Canadian political party. The party a Socialist organization, is the third largest in Canada.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PONTIAC, Mich., July 5 (AP)The defending champion, Warren Tope, was killed today when his McLaren smashed into a guard rail on the first turn of the Wide Track II race through the streets of Pontiac. The police said Tope was dead on arrival at Pontiac General Hospital.

title: Penny Hood Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester Mathewson Hood of Barrington R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Hood to Samuel Mitchill Hoagland, son of Mr. and Mrs. LaBar Post Hoagland of Weston, Conn., and Narragansett R.I.

title: Sunday Observer
description: For years I struggled to become a successful vacationer. Nothing worked. Golf seemed a bottomless pit. Europe was bankruptcy. Fishing . Oh, I wanted to fish, all right. All the great vacationers fished, and I wanted to be one of the greats, but wanting to was not enough. I had to fake it, and the great vacationers were not deceived. They saw too clearly the glazed eye with which I contemplated combat with the cunning trout, the distaste with which I dislodged the embedded fish hooks from my thumbs. You don't know much about fishing. they said.

title: Fox, Alstott Pace Bowling Tourney
description: FRESNO, Calif., July 5 (AP)Sam Fox of Pacifica. Calif., and Bob Alstott of Kansas City, each seeking his first professional howling championship, set a torrid 248pin average today in the opening round of the $50,000 Fresno open.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil and France Entering Into Pacts On Nuclear Energy
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5Brazil, which recently reached a major nuclearcooperation agreement with West Germany, is adding to her nuclear development by entering into pacts with France.

title: U.S. Officials Say Communists Seem to Have Made Few Changes in the South Vietnamese Economy
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Few changes have been made in the economy of South Vietnam since the Communist takeover, according to Administration of?? concerned with Indochina.

title: GOTBAUM OFFERS A PLAN TO DEFER WAGE INCREASES
description: A plan for the city to defer for two years new wage increases due to its employes and to issue them bonds instead at 6 per cent interest was proposed yesterday by the head of the largest municipal union, who said it would permit the rehiring of all laidoff workers and forestall future layoffs.

title: Training Mine Goes Off In Lebanon, Killing 40
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 5 (UPI)An antipersonnel mine exploded today in a Lebanese village northeast of Beirut, killing 40 Moslem militiamen and wounding at least 80 who were watching a military teacher demonstrate how to disarm the device, police sources said.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: In its recent heyday, Fruithurst, Ala., a community of 300 people on the Georgia line, had four fulltime policemen working a 72hour week, and it kept its City Hall open 24 hours a day. That was when the town was policing United States Highway 78 with radar and catching speeders near where the highway intersects a county road. Fruithurst is said to have collected $200,000 in fines in 1974.

title: Sound Ave. Named Historic Corridor
description: JAMESPORT  Sound Avenue, a rural road that meanders through the potato fields of Riverhead Town, will not be transformed into a fourlane highway to accommodate the Long Island Lighting Company's proposed nuclear power plant here.

title: If you're drowning, don't wave Your arms!
description: On the morning of Aug. 21, 1973, several dozen people nearly lost their lives in the water off Nauset Beach on Cape Cod.

title: Thornton Wilder and the Importance Of Being Optimistic
description: At 78, fragile and ailing, almost withdrawn from the world, Thornton Niven Wilder, three times a Pulitzer Prizewinning novelist and playwright, ebullient philosopher of homespun, poet of the ordinary made extraordinary, remains very much alive. For almost half a century his eternal optimism about eternity, his sophisticated simplicity and his infallible sense of, theater have graced our stages. His plays have not so much been revived over and over again, and in all sorts of places, as they have almost continuously stayed alive among us

title: Mohawks Fight to Regain Land
description: MOSS LAKE, N.Y.  In 1797, a Britisheducated Mohawk leader named Joseph Brant went to Albany and made a treaty with New York State officials in which he signed over to them some nine million acres of Mohawk land in the Adirondack Mountains in return for about $1,500.

title: Pel: His Role, His Salary and His Legs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: There is a widely held view on Wall Streetone that I believe to be erroneousthat those who sell options regularly get the better of those who buy them.

title: 3 Puerto Rican Prisoners Say Dominicans Forced Confessions
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 5Three Puerto Ricans held in the Dominican Republic by the military authorities say they were forced into confessing that they had smuggled three armed guerrilla leaders into the country.

title: Paperbacks
description: JEFFERSON THE PRESIDENT: Second Term 18051809, by Dumas Malone. (Little, Brown, $5.95.) Four gloryless years in which the Sage of Monticello was dogged by crises in foreign relations and the machinations of Aaron Burr: fifth and latest volume in the magisterial biography that recently won Pulitzer Prize.

title: Concert
description: The Sonny RollinsBobbi Humphrey concert late Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall may have been disappointingly attended, but there was nothing disappointing about Mr. Rollins's part of it.

title: MARY HARDIN VAUGHT
description: Mary Hardin Vaught, a Christian missionary for more than half a century, died Thursday of cancer at a hospital in Livingston, N.J. She was 71 years old and lived in Lincoln Park, N.J.

description: Incoming

title: S.O.S. for Dry Cargo
description: The economic storms that have devastated much of the world's petroleum tanker fleet have also put to anchor many of the drycargo ships that carry the other half of all sea trade.

title: Soviets Top U.S. In Track
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 5The Soviet men's track team defeated a pickup American team, 129 to 89, today for its biggest victory over the United States in 13 dual track and field meets.

title: Battle Over Tidewater Control
description: ALBANYA bill that would include the tidewaters of Nassau and Suffolk Counties within the definition of navigable waters of the state and thus place them under the jurisdiction of the state rather than localities stands its best chance of passage than at any time in the last 10 years.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: In Michael Rudman's staging of Hamlet in Central Park, Denmark is a military dictatorship. Santo Loquasto's set, all rectilinear black steel and Mylar, is cold and harsh, dwarfing humans and inimical to them. Soldiers in gray uniforms guard the entrances; a squad of them follows the king wherever he goes. The Danish court, also in gray uniforms, sits at a pair of black conference tables; the youngsters, first Laertes and then Hamlet, stand braced at attention when they speak to the king. There is much giving and taking of salutes.

title: Scott Gillam Fiance Of Mary V. Hazen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hazen of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Vanderlyn Hazen, to Bennett Scott Gillam, son of Mrs. Ernest E. Gillam of New York and the late Mr. Gillam.

title: No Bipartisan Consensus Is Near
description: TRENTONThe protracted legislative deadlock over taxes has apparently seriously jeopardized the chances for a multimilliondollar state bond issue for transportation and to fight water pollution. Despite months of negotiations, the Democratic majorities in both Houses of the Legislature have failed to reach any agreement with the Republican minorities on the magnitude of a bondissue proposal or any accord on its components. In fact, Democratic leadership in the Assembly contends that it cannot get its members even to consider talking about a bond issue until the tax deadlock is broken.

title: Union City Responds to Drive for Paper
description: UNION CITY  Although the market for used newspapers is a depressed one at the moment, public participation in a recently instituted recycling program here has been called fantastic. In the first week of curbside pickups, eight tons of discarded newspapers were collected.

title: Angola's Capital Is Badly Strained by the Inflow of Refugees
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 1Al month ago, Manuel Cardoso, a merchant, and his family of six left their neat stucco bungalow in the Cazenga section of this city after guerrilla soldiers robbed and threatened to kill them.

title: OneonOne Racing Spiced by Intrigue
description: The year was 1923 and strange things were happening on an October Saturday at Belmont Park. A smoke screen belched from the far side of the course. Two huge mirror refractors threw out blinding images. Five airplanes cavorted overhead.

title: Serena Gets Lead In Race to Hawaii
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 5 (AP)Serena took the early lead today in the transPacific yacht race to Honolulu by covering 182 nautical miles in the first 19 hours of the contest.

title: The Outdoors Clinic
description: I know a female surf angler who when she wishes to tie a knot in her line simply. pyancea up to the nearest male and gets to do it for her.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONA disputed election in New Hampshire nearly eight months ago is threatening to do for the reputation of the United States Senate what the energy bill did last month for the House of Representatives.

title: MARKET NATIONS CALL BONN STINGY
description: BRUSSELS, July 1  West Germany, which has long been considered the Common Mark. et's richest country, has now also gained the reputation among diplomats from its eight partners as the stingiest.

title: What's Going On?
description: What is going on among the Ford Administration's arms strategists, who on the one hand appear to be pursuing strategic arms limitation with the Soviet Union but on the other are doing some saberrattling both as to the use and the size of American nuclear forces?

title: Cape Verde Islands Are Now a Nation
description: The Cape Verde Islands, once a staging post in the slave trade between Africa and the United States, have become independent after 500 years of Portuguese rule. A delegation from Lisbon, led by Premier Vasco Gonalves, handed over power at a session of the new 58member National Assembly yesterday in the capital of Praia. Then the 300,000 islanders began an evening of celebrations. Details on Page 3.

title: Letters
description: Abused children, troubled parents

title: PENSIONS BY CITY RATED GENEROUS
description: A study comparing New York City pension systems with those of five other major cities indicates that normal retirement allowances are generally higher here but that other cities have more generous retirement programs in Some aspects and in some employe categories.

title: Office Building Opens at Airport
description: A sixstory office building on Route 1 opposite Newark Airport has opened foe occupancy. The 250,000squarefoot structure Is on a 12acre tract at International Way, adiacent to the Howard Johnson Motor Lodge. Both properties are owned by Web Associates of East Orange, which is planning to start construction on a second office building on the site early next year. The second building is scheduled for completion in early 1977. Harold Kent of Livingston is the architect for the office buildings, and Web Development Company is the general contractor. The complex has its own heliport and offers free car service to the airport. Williams Real Estate Company, Inc., is the renting agent for the office building.

title: LakeAging System Used to Save Lakes From Early Deaths
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., July 5Scientists at Michigan State University are attempting to use eutrophication, the natural aging process of lakes, to save lakes from premature death.

title: An ID Card for Butterflies
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTSTouching doesn't hurt them, said Molly Monica as she reached into a screen cage and expertly grabbed a large monarch butterfly that had been investigating a bouquet of fresh milkweed leaves, clover and daisies. If the wing scales come off, it may affect their buoyancy a little, but they can still fly and function.

title: MRS. GANDHI SEES TOP LABOR CHIEFS
description: NEW DELHI, July 5Prime Minister Indira Gandhi met with several of India's top labor leaders today in a continuing effort to broaden support for her Government's authoritarian new posture.

title: Fashion
Terminal for Buses Begun in Flushing
description: On a sultry afternoon late last month, Mayor Beame, joined by other officials, operated a jack hammer in a sprawling parking lot in Flushing, Queens, to break ground for the longtalked about Flushing Bus Terminal.

title: Spoleto: A Bridge Between Worlds
description: The Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds is an asseveration of old and new, a renewal of antiquity, an affirmation of the present, a bridge between the occasional newness of an old world and the occasional oldness of a new world. Its focus is Italy and America, but the object of that focus is man and his cultural world. Should all that sound solemn, let it be insisted that the Spoleto Festival is fun. Or usually fun.

description: The engagement of Margaret MaryAnn Shean to Howard C. Ris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ris of Garden City, L.I., has been announced by her father, H. Philip Shean of De Witt, N.Y. Miss Shean, daughter also of the late Rita Shean, and her fianc plan to be married Aug. 23.

title: Who did what, how and where, but not why
description: Crime, as defined by the dictionaries, is a gross violation of human law; an unjust or senseless act that is injurious to the public welfare. This is fundamental. Like birth, death, love, or fear.

title: Forrest Anthony Will Marry Kathryn Kinney in September
description: The engagement of Kathryn Lee Kinney to Forrest Harold Anthony has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Marks Kinney Jr. of Westfield, N. J., and Hilton Head Island, S. C., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Chase Anthony of Orting, Wash.

title: Headliners
description: Columnist Ann Landers has informed the readers of her widely syndicated column of personal advice, that her 36yearold marriage to Jules Lederer, by her description one of the world's best marriages, was ending in divorde. But Mils Landers had no answers for those of her readers who might have wondered why. The lady with all the answers does not know the answer to this one, she wrote in a column. For those who might have wanted to inquire further, Miss Landers had already established ground rules: Sorry, this is a personal matter, she said in her column, adding that she would not respond to any further inquiries on the subject.

title: America Loves a Parade, And Her Firemen Oblige

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Tomorrow is DDaydelivery dayfor the first halfmillion packages containing three of the U.S. Mint's four different types of Bicentennial coin sets: the threecoin 40 per cent silver proof set, the threecoin 40 per cent silver uncirculated set and the six  coin cupro  nickle proof set. After that initial 500,000unit shipment, the rate will drop to 35,000 packages per day and continue at that pace until the order backlog is eliminated. (It should be noted that the figures of 35,000 and 500,000 packages represent a substantially larger number of sets, since many packages contain orders for more than one set.) Shipping of the Mint's fourth Bicentennial coin offeringthe 12coin cupronickel uncirculated set (also known as a Mint set) will get under way in August.

title: U.S.E.T. Selects 6 for Mexico City
description: Headed by Bruce Davidson, the reigning world champion, six riders have been named to the United States Equestrian Team's threeday squad for the Pan American Games. Whitney of chairman of the Equestrian Games Committee of the United States Olympic Committee, made the announcement yesterday. Other riders named were Kevin Freeman of Portland, Ore., a member of the 1964, 1968 and 1972 Olympic teams that won silver medals; Tad Coffin of Strafford, Vt., Beth Perkins of South Strafford, Vt., Mary Ann Tauskey of New Vernon, N. J., and Tad Zimmerman of Newtown Square, Pa.

title: Medical Aid At Dog Shows
description: The need for making medical attention available to exhibitors at dog shows was manifested again last weekend. At SusqueNango, in Whitney Point, N.Y., Eunice Gies slipped while showing a dog and fractured her ankle. A volunteer rescue squad on the grounds gave emergency aid and she was taken to Binghamton General Hospital, where a cast was applied.

The policy could be described as watch the statistics and veto Congressional spending bills.

description: COMMACKA new college center directed primarily to the needs of adults will open its doors here tomorrow in a building that served elementary school children for 50 years.

description: The New York area office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has reported that there are 50,000 homeowners in the area with unsubsidized mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration who may qualify to have structural or other defects repaired at Government expense.

title: STAMPS
description: Countries sharing with the United States in the celebration of the Bicentennial of the American Revolution have begun to issue commemoratives marking the achievement of the dearlywon freedom that Independence Day annually recalls.

title: Russian Liner Rescues Crew of American Yacht
description: The sixman crew of the 42foot cutter Shamrock spent the Fourth of July at home safe and sound thanks to the seamanship of the crew of the Mikhail Lermontov, the Soviet passenger liner. The Lermontov, a 19,860ton motorship, operated by the Baltic Steamship Company, and at present in cruise service to Bermuda, spotted the sailing yacht's red distress flares early Tuesday morning at a point some 250 miles northwest of Bermuda. The liner was returning here from Bermuda.

title: Wedding Is Held For Miss Field
description: Katherine Elsworth Field, bookclubs editor with Parents Magazine Enterprises, was married yesterday afternoon to James Montgomery Graves. Both are of New York, where Mr. Graves is a vice president of ShearsonHayden Stone, stockbrokers.

description: TOKYO, July 5Premier Ta keo Miki said today that his visit to Washington next month would be of utmost impor tance to a strengthening of relations between Japan and the United States and thus would contribute more to both countries and the world.

description: The only oppressed minority that hasn't caught on yet is the broadcaster who gives authors free air time to emblazon the glories of their new books.

description: Virginia Anne Zabriskie and Christopher Bumstead Goble, graduates of Ohio Wesleyan University, were married yesterday afternoon in Ridgewood, N. J. The Rev. Marshall T. Rice performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 5  The famous Rod Jenkins equestrian production line continues unabated.

description: From Tanglewood to Ravinia to the Hollywood Bowl the story is the same. Advance ticket sales for American summer music festivals are higher than ever before.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 5yearold Bronx girl was shot accidentally and killed by her cousin while playing with a 38caliber revolver in her cousin's bedroom at 406 E. 160th Street, the police reported. The dead girl, Maria Cruz of 687 Cauldwell Avenue, her brother and her cousin, whose name was not disclosed because of her age, had gone into the bedroom get some clothes, leaving her parents downstairs talking to some friends, the police said.

title: Doggy Bank
description: In the way of gimmicks to attract new business, the Shawmut First Bank & Trust Company of Massachusetts may have outdone them all. For the last two months, tellers at 17 of the hank's 21 branches have been handing out dog hiscuits25 to 30 a dayto dogs.

title: Jazz Hall of Fame Plays
description: The first 11 jazz musicians chosen for the Newport Jazz Festival's Jazz Hall of Fame gave onthespot demonstrations of the reasons for their selection as they received their Hall of Fame plaques Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Rehearing Is Sought By U.S.P.S.
description: For the United States Power Squadron, the count is one down and two to go. The New Jersey Appellate Court has unanimously ruled against the U.S.P.S.'s appeal of a state civil rights division order to admit women.

title: Senetta Hill Wed To Donald Koch
description: Senetta Louise Hill, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Warren G. Hill of Denver and North Saco, Me., was married yesterday afternoon to Donald Frederick Koch, son of Mrs. Ferdinand Koch of Kew Gardens, Queens, and the late Mr. Koch. The Rev. Kenneth Brookes, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Tory Hill Meetinghouse in Buxton, Me.

title: A difficult poet who often looks easy
description: That Herbert is a great poet who has been regularly misread or underread; that he is a very difficult poet who often looks easy, and so has often been patronized or even corrected by people who assume they have better taste, or know more than he did what good devotional poetry should be: these are propositions implicit in Helen Vendler's book, and they are entirely acceptable. As will shortly appear, I do not by any means invariably agree with her, but Vendler is undoubtedly a finely trained and extraordinarily resourceful reader, and I cannot imagine that anybody who cares for Herbert, or more generally for poetry, will fail to learn something from this book. Her meditations are nearly always faithful to their textsshe very rarely succumbs to the vice of the close reader, which is to speak more wonders than the poem he is considering; and she has brought off a quite notable feat of construction in making a collection of disparate commentaries stand up as a book. I read it virtually straight through with Canon Hutchinson's edition open beside it, on an eighthour plane trip, unseduced by inflight movies or alcohol. My copy is overlaid with comments, a good many of them exclamations of pleasure at passages that struck me as especially ingenious or just. Only a few are cross or impatient.

title: DRUG STUDY FINDS USE CONTINUING
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 5Five years ago newspapers and magazines were filled with reports about the rise of the drug culture and of a widening epidemic of drug abuse by adolescents. What has happened to these young people as they have matured into young adults?

title: Newport Jazz
description: The 1975 installment of the Newport Jazz FestivalNew York is winding down ?? and naturally there were a number of highlights. This observer got a good deal of pleasure from Miles Davis, George Benson, Milt Jackson, Max. Roach, the J. C. White Singers and Sonny Rollins. And John S. Wilson has had warm things to say about all sorts of participants.

title: Criminals At Large
description: When John Wainwright's The Hard Hit was reviewed here, only a couple of months ago, it was not received with rapture. The writing was all but a burlesque of the American toughguy school. And when Wainwright was not trying to create literature with absurdly overwritten set pieces about London, the philosophy of life and other such weighty matters, he was getting bogged down in a psychological mishmash. No, The Hard Hit was not a very good book. Now comes SQUARE DANCE (St. Martin's, $6.95), and the only remaining question is how an author can write so poorly in one book and so competently in his next.

title: Training Seminar Set at Health Unit
description: DUMONT  All aspects of volunteer service, as it is utilized at the Community Center for Mental Health, will be explored during a daylong training seminar to be held at the center on Thursday.

title: CHURCH IN BRAZIL SUPPORTS INDIANS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5Roman Catholic leaders have declared support for the selfdetermination of this country's dwindling Indian population and the Indians' right to recover their lands.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: There must have been a great deal of soulsearching and a fortune in transAtlantic cables and phones before the repertory of the Bolshoi Opera in New York was fixed. It was, after all, the company's first visit to the United States (it previously had come to Montreal in 1967), and the Bolshoi has a rather large list of operas at its disposal.

title: Notes: Lisbon Tries To Woo Wary Tourists
description: TOURISM is down in Portugal. In part the decline reflects the general drop in American travel to Europe because of inflation and recession. In part it stems from tourist uncertainty over conditions in Portugal in the wake of that country's revolution and current political tensions. In an effort to remedy the situation. Lisbon is instituting a program of travel bonuses. The bonuses, which go into effect Aug. 1, are available to tourists entering or leaving Europe by way of Portugal.

title: The Gun
description: The idea that a President of the United States might be killed and history altered by means of a $19.95 rifle, bought through the mails and fired by a nut, is almost as offensive as the Kennedy assassination itself. Probably this is why, after more than a decade, both Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin, and Carcano No. C2766, the gun, remain the subjects of investigations, speculations and conspiracy theories. Like Oswald himself, the Carcano was basically a loser, an undistinguished, obsolete Italian army rifle worth little more than a footnote in either military or smallarms history.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Ferguson Jenkins of the Texas Rangers, after John Mayberry of the Royals hit three homers off him in a game: I should have knocked him on his can after the first one, but that would have been too obvious.

title: Turning Away From Trading Stamps
description: Trading stamps bloomed in the prosperous 1960's with consumers flocking to redemption centers like Plaid Land, S.&H., and King Korn.

title: Miss Kertzman Leads by Two
New Federal Jail Here Offers AirConditioning as a Feature
description: A new Federal jail that was dedicated here last week has equipment for educational programs for inmates, central airconditioning and no bars on the windows.

title: JOSEPH ZEPPA
description: TYLER, Tex., July 5 (AP)Joseph Zeppa, who rose to head one of the world's largest oil drilling businesses, died here yesterday at the age of 81.

description: Elmer Q. Oliphant, whose athletic prowess became a West Point legend, died at his home in New Canaan, Conn., on Thursday, a week short of his 83d birthday.

title: INFLUX TO ISRAEL IS CUT SHARPLY
description: TEL AVIV, July 5 (AP)Fears of war, recession and Arab guerrilla attacks have severely reduced immigration to Israel. So few Ambrican Jews are moving here that the Jewish Agency is closing three immigration centers in the United States.

title: The Natural Comparisons of the Two Most Populous Nations
description: WASHINGTONAccording to a theory that had a brief vogue about 15 years ago, the future of Asia in this century would be settled in a contest of ideologies and development strategies supposedly being waged by the two most populous nations in the world, China and India.

title: A False Navy Report Alleged in Sub Crash
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The commander of a Navy submarine on an intelligence patrol inside Soviet waters was ordered to file a Series of falsified reports in late 1969 after a collision at sea with a Soviet submarine, according to former crew members.

title: The Young Thomas Hardy
description: Solid in construction if somewhat phlegmatic in voice, this book takes the story of Thomas Hardy from his birth in 1840 into a family of Dorset craftsmen and laborers to the point in the late 1870's where he had established himself as a writer of modest achievement and large possibility. Robert Gittings, a veteran biographer who has written extensively on Keats, knows how to gather facts and is scrupulous in distinguishing them from fancies; he writes with a strong feel for the passage and texture of common life. If his book lacks verbal flare and critical sharpness, it is nevertheless the richest account thus far of Hardy's childhood, youth and literary beginnings.

title: Miss Winslow Wed To Norbert Donelly
description: Eugenie Ann Winslow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Winslow of Casey Key, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Norbert P. Donelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert E. Donelly of Lawrenceville, N. J. The Rev. Joseph Drawdy performed the ceremony in St. Boniface Episcopal Church on Siesta Key, Fla.

title: They Used to Save the Best Line for Last
description: I used to hate the water, says the hero of Jaws, paddling ashore after an extended but invigorating skirmish with a slippery killer shark. It's a snappy, ironic line to end a film full of bloody mutilations, a surefire candidate for the hall of fame of memorable last lines. But it's up against some formidable competition; through the years, there have been scores of movies whose final words have been worth the price of admission.

title: Stephen Boatti Fiance of Linda Digrande
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sal Digrande of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Susan Digrande, to Stephen John Boatti, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Boatti, also of, New York. A wedding next month is planned.

title: Supreme Court's Term Marked by Caution in Making New Law and by Refusal to Review Some Major Issues
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The closing ceremony of the 197475 Supreme Court term was somehow appropriate. Before a rearly empty courtroom for 23 minutes the Justices announced eight decisions, only one or two of much interest, and then quietly adjourned.

title: To Achieve the AllAmerican Mouth, Adults Are Wearing Braces
description: The broad, brave smile of the grownup in braces is stretching from coast to coast. Patients well past puberty are flocking to the orthodontists in search of the better bite, the straighter tooth, the healthier, happier, sexier mouth.

title: Local Corn and Tomatoes Now on Sale
description: TRENTONRoadside stands and farmers' markets once again are adding color and customers as Jersey tomatoes and sweet corn make their initial annual appearance.

title: Connally Returns to Political Trail Ready to Follow Many Paths
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 6John B. Connally is back on the political trail, without a map but chargedup for the trip wherever it turns.

title: DR. FRANKLIN HO, ECONOMIST, DIES
description: Dr. Franklin L. Ho, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University, who played a key role in developing economic research in China before the Communists took over the mainland, died Saturday it his home, 464 Riverside Drive. His age was 80.

title: Match Race Chart
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racinz Form)

title: Article 4  No Title
Argentina's Dulcia Wins Coast Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 6 (AP)Argentinebred Dulcia made a stirring stretch run and beat the favored Susan's Girl in the $112,500 Vanity Handicap today. The race decided the championship for older fillies and mares at Hollywood Park.

title: STEINGUT EXPECTS A SESSION IN FALL
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut said yesterday that the Legislature would probably have to meet in the fall to deal with the state's budget gap for the current fiscal year, a gap that the Governor has projected at more than $60??million.

title: Purchasers Discern Pickup in Economy
description: The nation's purchasing agents, encouraged by an influx of new orders from their customers and by a growing volume of production in their factories, said yesterday that the economic recovery had gained momentum in June.

title: Morgan Beatty, Broadcaster, Newsman for 50 Years, Dead
description: ST. JOHN'S, Antigua; July 5 (AP)  Morgan Beatty, prominent broadcast and print news correspondent for more than 50 years, died Friday night at the age of 72.

title: Bridge:
description: When a group of experts Is gathered together they are usually out for blood, which may take the form of cash, trophies, master points, or qualification for a higherlevel event. But once in a while they enjoy a social evening without blood, and did so last Thursday at the Old Oaks Country Club, Purchase, N.Y.

title: Article 3  No Title
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Many Bettors Repudiate Sexism and Follow Form
description: Mrs. Pat Menafra patted the Ruffian button pinned to her handbag and said she thought the whole issue went. way beyond a horse race.

title: Peron Cabinet Resigns
description: The entire Cabinet of President Isabel Martinez de Pern resigned in Argentifia hours before the beginning of a planned general strike. Unions and others had demanded the removal of a key. Presidential adviser. Page 5.

title: OPPOSITION GROWS ON EQUAL RIGHTS
description: TRENTON, July 6A coalition of women's groups, determined to add an Equal Rights Amendment to the New Jersey Constitution this year, has already encountered so much opposition from other women and from some State Senators that the success of the drive appean doubtful at this time.

title: Horsemen Reject Offer
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., July UPI)The Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association has rejected the Narragansett Park Owners' latest offer of $175,000, saying the park owes horsemen $327,000. The union voted, 121 to 73, yesterday to reject the offer and decided to put a minimum acceptance figure at $277,000. The track has been closed for almost two weeks.

title: Key Mafia Figure Tells of Wars And GalloColornbo Peace Talks
description: A key figure in the recent Mafia gang wars has offered a rare view into the inner workings of Mafia families in New York, including new details about the shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the murder of Joseph Gallo, the spate of killings that followed the Gallo murder, and the current negotiations between the Colombo family and its Gallo faction.

title: Massachusetts Needs Blood
description: BOSTON, July 6 (AP)  A blood shortage throughout Massachusetts worsened today as thp collection of blood fell far behind the need, American Red Cross officials said. A spokesman said that more than 130 blood units, about a pint each, were collected across the state today, far short of the 300 units usually collected on a summer weekend day.

title: Miss McAllister Posts First Victory on 70212
description: WHEELING, W. Va., July 6 (AP)  Susie McAllister charged out of the pack in the final round of the Wheeling tournament today and recorded her first victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Article 2  No Title
National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Amy Crean Bride Of Richard F. Corn
description: Amy Ann Crean and Richard Franklin Corn were married yesterday morning at the home of the bride's mother, Mri. Robert J. Crean, in Larchmont, N.Y., by Maurice L. Royer, acting Village Justice. The bride also is a daughter of the late Mr. Crean, a television and stage playwright, who died last year.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Lou Piniella has been restored to the active list. The outfielder had been recovering from surgery to correct innerear trouble that affected his balance.
