Last week's illegal sanitation strike, a wretched charade in which every step was apparently orchestrated by the union leadership, with the Beame administration a benign coconspirator, was the end product of three decades in which one New York mayor after another systematically fostered the growth of centralized union power. The rationale always was that strong, secure unions would bring cooperation for a more efficient civil service. Instead, it delivered into union hands ironclad control over every essential civic department, with a precipitous increase in personnel and payroll and a steady shrinkage in standards of performance.

title: Gamble in Argentina
description: The relative stability Argentina has enjoyed since President Juan D. Pern's death is gravely threatened by the general strike that is now under way and by previous worker demonstrations directed against the Government headed by Pern's widow, President Isabel Martinez de Pern. Mrs. Pern had been forced by Argentina's rapidly deteriorating economic situation to take a historic gamble. She is gambling that she can retain power despite measures aimed at cutting the standard of living of Argentina's unionized workers in an effort to cure the hyperinflationary illness of the Argentine economy.

title: Poor Example
description: In an editorial Sunday entitled Danish Example, we complimented the Danish delegation to the United Nations Conference on Women in Mexico City for having voted against the Declaration of Mexico because it contained irrelevant and deliberately provocative Arabinspired political implications directed against Israel. We have since learned, however, that although Denmark was indeed one of only three states to vote against the declaration at first, (the United States and Israel were the others), Denmark subsequently announced that it had intended to abstain, and was so recorded.

title: Fed Group Allowed ShortTerm Growth In Supply of Money
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided at its midMay meeting to permit the nation's money supply to grow more rapidly in May and June to accommodate the tax debates then being mailed out by the Treasury.

title: Belly Dancer Sways Crowd to Shimmy Up for Class
description: The trim little septuagenarian in blackandorange basketball sneakers hovered at the edge of the crowd in Central Park's East Green. She was there to watch a free bellydancing class given by Serena, a Middle Eastern dance teacher and performer.

title: Wilson B. Folmar, 63, Dies; Women's Wear Designer
description: Wilson B. Folmar, a retired designer and manufacturer of women's wear for the couturier retail trade, died Wednesday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his Manhattan home. He was 63 years old.

title: PRICES PLUMMET ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dropped sharply yesterday in slower trading.

title: In Memoriam
description: DAVISGertrude. We miss our loving mother and grandmother on her birthday and every day.

title: To Recommend U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON July 7 (AP)  Senator Bartiett said here today that he would recommend aid to assist Somalia in resettling droughtstricken refugees.

title: C.I.A. Allegedly Flew Unwitting Officials
description: WASHINGTON, July 7Intelligence sources said today that members of Congress, two Vice Presidents and other politicians had flown chartered flights on a Washingtonbased airline, unaware that the line was owned and operated by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Election of Panel To Rule a City Ward Reported by Saigon
description: The following dispatch was filed in Saigon last Saturday and received yesterday.

title: QffDuty Cabby Is Slain in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn cab driver was slain early yesterday morning by a knifewielding assailant the victim apparently believed was stalking and about to mug an elderly man, the police reported.

title: Eastland Breaks Three Ribs
description: CLEVELAND, Miss., July 7 (AP)Senator James O. Eastland, 71yearold Democrat of Mississippi was hospitalized today after he broke three ribs in a fall at his Doddsville home, relatives said.

title: Judges Uphold City On Higher Charges For Court Services
description: A threejudge Federal court in Brooklyn has upheld the right of New York City to charge higher courtfiling fees than any of the state's other communities because costs here are higher.

title: Consumer Organizations Over Nation Hurt by a Loss of Grants
description: The financial difficulties that recently forced Consumers Union to lay off employes are having a ripple effect on many of the nation's consumer organizations.

title: Blaming the City Books
description: If you are a politician in trouble, the first rule of thumb is to try to blame your opponents. If that doesn't work, blame your predecessors. And if all else fails, blame your subordinates. The city's fiscal crisis would seem to have enough blame to go around. But so far the only clearcut culprit that has emergedaccording to the conflicting pronouncements of the politiciansis the city's accounting and bookkeeping systems, now almost universally acknowledged as inadequate, antiquated, and downright erroneous.

title: Kennecott Petitions F.T.C. To Modify Peabody Order
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday it had petitioned the Federal Trade Commission seeking to have the agency modify its order calling for Kennecott divestiture of the Peabody Coal Company. Kennecott acquired Peabody in March, 1968, for $285million plus production payments of $300million.

title: MARY H. CROSS
description: Mary Hochlerner Cross, a retired teacher of physically handicapped children in the public schools here, died Saturday in Piestany, Czechoslovakia, where she had gone for medical treatment. She was 82 years old and lived at 215 West 98th Street.

title: Otto Skorzeny, Nazi Commando, Dead; Rescued Mussolini From Italian Peak
description: Otto Skorzeny, the hulking, scarfaced Nazi Elite Guard colonel who bedeviled the Allies in World War II with a daring rescue of Mussolini, with confusing subterfuges and with a false assassination plot, died Saturday at his home in Madrid of bronchial cancer, it was reported yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800: CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Oil Nationalization Is Debated in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 7  The Government's Democratic Action party and opposition forces have hardened their positions during congressional debate on a bill to nationalize the country's foreignowned petroleum industry.

title: UptoDate Rules Block an OldFashioned Log Cabin
description: OSO, Wash., July 7The way O, C. Helton sees it, he was just atrying to build his family, a home, a log cabin to live in same as his father did for him and his Grandpa Charlie before that.

title: Dick Gregory Released
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) A Federal magistrate released Dick Gregory, the comedianactivist, without bail today on charges of parading without a permit Saturday in front of the White House.

title: SOVIET OIL OUTPUT ROSE 6.9% IN HALF
description: MOSCOW, July 7 (Reuters)Soviet oil production in the first half of this year was 6.9 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year, the newspaper Pravda reported today.

title: The End of a Gorgeous Beast
description: I was against a match race but I couldn't say much because I was riding both horses then, Jacinto Vasquez was saying in the jockeys' room at Belmont Park the day after the tragedy. You ride in a field of 12 horses, you worry about getting good position. In a match race, you just let her roll. It's tough on a horse. He is a calm. smoothfaced man, just 5 feet 3 inches tall, who was born in the interior of Panama 31 years ago and was cast by a strange quirk of fate in the leading role in the racing drama that came to be known as The Great Match. He was the regular rider on Foolish Pleasure, the great colt who won the Kentucky Derby and was described by his trainer as a kind, gentle horse who does nothing wrong. And he also was the regular rider on Ruffian, the great filly who won 10 straight races and was, described by her veterinarian as this gorgeous beast.

title: Weekly Steel Output Slides by 4.3%
description: Steel production continued its downward trend in the week ended July 5, according to weekly figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Paris:
description: PARISIf you visit the Muse Marmottan this summer, get set for a surprise: Monet's paintings have been sent off to Albi to make room for work, mostly recent, by Giorgio de Chirico. Though temporary, the move is significant of the current trend. The French, who have always subscribed to Poussin's definition of painting as the representation of all that is visible beneath the sun, are suddenly and belatedly becoming infatuated with night and with the invisible monsters it begets.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JULY 8, 1975.

title: Canada's Third Party Picks New Leader
description: OTTAWA, July 7The New Democratic party, a Socialist group that stands third in strength in the Canadian Parliament and governs three of the country's 10 provinces, elected a new leader today in a convention that appeared to turn the party further left than before.

title: 14 KEY AIDES LOSE ENVIRONMENT JOBS
description: TRENTON, July 7Fourteen prominent employes of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, including at least two highlevel officials, received termination notices from Environmental Commissioner David J. Bardin today. Twenty summer employes were also laid off, all part of the department's plan to reduce salary expenditures by $420,000.

title: STATE TO TELEVISE 1MILLION LOTTERY
description: In what is described as an experiment possibly leading to a weekly televised drawing in the fall, the New York State Division of the Lottery has arranged with WABCTV here to broadcast the July 24 Grand Tier drawing of the $1million lottery.

title: Jaws, Setting Records, Helps Revitalize Movies
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 7Hol lywood, which has uncovered a vein of gold in the past with movies about collies, stallions and animated ducks, mice aid bunnies, appears to have discovered a new hero with a gilt edge: a 25footlong killer shark.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state's denial of Medicaid payments to a welfare mother for a trip to Houston for her son's heart pacemaker operation was upheld by the Appellate Division of the State Superior Court in Trenton. The court backed a ruling by the Department of Institutions and Agencies that the woman could not be reimbursed for transportation costs because the operation could have been performed in New Jersey. Joan Brown of Fair Lawn took her son to the clinic of the heart specialist Dr. Michael E. De Bakey for a pacemaker implant and two subsequent operations to replace pacemakers. Her son, John, was born in 1961 with a heart murmur. Dr. De Bakey implanted the pacemaker to regulate the rhythm of the heart. The Morris County Welfare Board paid the transit costs for the first two operations in 1970 and 1971, refused to pay for the third trip in 1972. A doctor said an operation to replace a pacemaker after its batteries ran down can well be done in New Jersey.

title: BEAME RESTORES 2,600 MORE JOBS; ASKS PAY FREEZE
description: Mayor Beanie restored the jobs of 2,600 more city workers last evening and further confused the city's already muddled layoffrehiring picture.

title: Subway Cars for Boston
description: BOSTON, July 7 (AP)  A $70million grant to purchase new subway cars for Boston's transit system was announced today by William T. Coleman Jr., the Secretary of Transportation. Almost half the money comes from Federal highway funds. Massachusetts was the first state to transfer this money to mass transit.

title: UptoDate Rules Block an OldFashioned Log Cabin
description: OSO, Wash., July 7The way O. C. Helton sees it, he was just atrying to build his family a home, a log cabin to live in same as his father did for him and his Grandpa Charlie before that.

title: Aide Says Ford Reads 10 Papers Regularly
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI)President Ford regularly reads 10 daily newspapers, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today in response to a question during the daily White House news briefing.

title: Cabinet Resignation Fails To Halt Argentine Strike
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 7Argentine workers went ahead with a twoday general strike today despite a lastminute Government effort last night to avert the nationwide shutdown by announcing the resignation of the entire Cabinet.

title: The City Plays Host at a Sidewalk Cafe
description: A cheerful outdoor cafe sprouted yesterday on the pedestrian thoroughfare between the Federal Courthouse and the Municipal Building, and from all appearances, it became an instant success.

title: GUARDS AT PRISON PROTEST LAYOFFS
description: Correction officers who had been laid off because of the Mayor's budget cuts, angered by what they said were misleading reports that 150 would be rehired, staged a demonstration early yesterday on the Queens side of the Rikers Island bridge and cut off accessi to the island for about 40 minutes.

title: Albany Nursing Home Bill Is Getting Final Touches
description: ALBANY, July 7The counsels of the legislative health committees are putting the finishing touches to a strong compromise bill designed to curb abuses in the nursinghome industry.

title: Court Again Refuses to Bar Services by Black Church
description: CAMDEN, July 7Judge Louis L. Goldman of State Superior Court today again refused to bar a black congregation from holding religious services in a church in the Borough of Woodlynne. Borough officials contended the congregation was violating local zoning laws.

title: RUMANIA DEFIES SOVIET AT THE U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7  Rumania has quietly but firmly gone against the wishes of the Soviet Union and staked a claim to an Eastern European seat on a committee beginning a longrange review of the United Nations Charter.

title: Canadian Price Index Up
description: OTTAWA, July 7 (Reuters)Statistics Canada said today the general wholesale price index rose 0.4 per cent in May to 484.8 (193539 equals 100) from a revised 482.9 in April. The index was 6.7 per cent higher than in May, 1974. The industry selling price for manufacturing rose 0.8 per cent in May to 190.6 (1961 equals 100) from a revised April index of 189.1 and was 13.1 per cent higher than May 1974.

title: Algeria Firm on Price
description: ALGIERS, July 7Algerian oil will continue to cost $11.75 a barrel (f.o.b. Algerian ports) throughout the third quarter of 1975, A.P.S., the official Algerian news agency, has reported.

title: Belmont Jockeys
PAUL TO FASHION SYSTEM IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L. I, July 7 Justice Joseph Lift of the State Supreme Court said today that he would appoint a commission to devise a plan for a constitutional form of government for Nassau County.

title: DISSIDENTS HIDING IN BOOM DRIVE
description: BOMBAY, July 7A noted woman Socialist and other opposition political figures in the Bombay area have gone into hiding to escape arrest, antiGovernment informants reported today.

title: Byrne Is Pressing To Limit Enactment Of Nuisance Taxes
description: TRENTON, July 7Governor Byrne met with Assembly leaders today in an effort to limit the Legislature's enactment of more than $300million in nuisance taxes so that pressure for adoption of a state income tax later this year would remain.

title: Lunch, for Them, Is on the House
description: Milton Marcus had a nice surprise when he reported to his new job at Ries Cappiello Colwell yesterday: a free lunch.

title: DR. A. G. M'ELDOWNEY
description: Dr. A. Genevieve McEldowney, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in practice here since 1959, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 74. She lived at 1230 Park Avenue.

title: Chess:
description: The 1975 United States championship produced an unusually shortspread of 3 points between Walter Browne's winning score of 8 and Pal Benko's last place tally of 5. Overall, it was not caution that was responsible for this curious result, but a dogeatdog approach on the part of the combatants.

title: Official Departs
description: VIENTIANE, July 7 (AP)Phoumi Vongvichit left the country today and two other Pathet Lao leaders were scheduled to leave Vientiane shortly. Mr. Phoumi, who left with his wife, said that he was leaving for Hanoi and Peking for medical treatment.

title: RIVAL OF SHANKER BEATEN IN RUNOFF
description: LOS ANGELES, July 7  A small group of New York teachers received wide support here from teachers in other states In opposing the Albert Shenkerbacked leadership of their state organization at the National Education Association's annual meeting.

title: CANADA TO OUST EXSAIGON AIDE
description: OTTAWA, July 7  The Canadilan Government has ordered the deportation of Lieut. Gen. Dang Van Quang, who has been accused by other South Vietnamese refugees here of involvement in heroin traffic and other misdeeds ranging from smuggling to torture and murder.

title: Politics Seems to Doom Disclosure Bill
description: ALBANY, July 7The Assembly approved today and sent to nearcertain oblivion in the Senate a bill requiring financial disclosure by legislators and some state employes.

title: EXHEAD OF KALVEX ENJOINED BY COURT
description: Judge Richard Owen of the Federal District Court here, signed yesterday an order permanently enjoining Robert L. Ingis, former director, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Kalvex, Inc., from violating the Federal securities laws.

title: Kaat, White Sox Bow, 21, As Tigers Extend String to 6
description: ?? yesterday Jim Kaat of they Chicago White Sox was named to the American League AllStar squad. Perhaps it was a small jinx because last night in Tiger Stadium Detroit beat the lefthander, 21, sending him to only his fifth loss of the season. He has won 13 games.

title: EUGENIO LOPEZ SR., FILIPINO LEADER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July (AP)Eugenio Lopez Sr., selfexiled former industrial, broadcasting and publishing executive in the Philippines and a leading critic of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, died yesterday of cancer at French Hospital here. He was 74 years old.

title: Expert Doubts U.S. Can Substantially Cut Oil Imports by 1985
description: WASHINGTON, July 7When the United States Geological Survey acknowledged a few days ago that for years it had been overestimating the nation's oil and natural gas resources, M. King Hubbert might have allowed himself a discreet smile of satisfaction.

title: 2 Give Up to F.B.I. In 3 Murder Cases After Exile in Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) A former executive with the Commerce Department and his son, accused of three murders and the hijacking of an Eastern Air Lines plane, surrendered here today after having spent nearly three years in Cuba, according to the F.B.I.

title: NoFrills Fares Called Big Success by National
description: MIAMI, July 7The nofrills airplane fare, under which passengers on selected routes receive no inflight amenities but pay 35 per cent less for travel, was described today as an unqualified success by National Airlines, which introduced the controversial plan in March.

title: Venezuela Oil Debate
description: Debate has intensified in Venezuela over nationalization of foreignowned petroleum companies. Page 51.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Concert Mixing Jazz With Soul Closes Festival
description: The Newport Jazz Festival in New York closed in Uniondale, L. I., on Sunday with the Stylistics, a soul group complete with snappy choreography and a falsetto lead singerhardly the traditional image of the festival.

title: Specialty Types Raised $3 by Top Refiner
description: Grocery sugar prices, which have dropped 67 per cent from their peak last November, are on their way up again. The Amstar Corporation, the country's largest sugar refiner, and the Sucrest Corporation, a leading refining company, announced yesterday price rises of $2 per hundred pounds on grocery sugar and $3 per hundredweight on specialty sugars. Specialty sugars are defined as brown sugar, tablets and sugar in small cartons.

title: W. Clifford Shields Jr., 75, Of Farrell Lines Is Dead
description: W. Clifford Shields Jr., who retired in 1962 as a vice president of Farrell Lines, Inc., and then continued until 1966 as a director, died Saturday at his home, 5 Tudor City Place. He was 75 years old.

title: People and Business:
description: The vacancy in the chairmanship of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has been filledat least temporarily by President Ford. Yesterday, he named Garth Marston of Seattle as acting chairman of the board.

title: ExTreasurer of West Virginia Pleads Guilty in Bank Extortion
description: BALTIMORE, July 7The former West Virginia State Treasurer, John H. Kelly, pleaded guilty here today before United States District Judge Joseph E. Young to charges of fraud, extortion and misuse of bank funds.

title: Article 1  No Title
EXPLOSION STRIKES FACTORY IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, July 7 (UPI)An explosion ripped through an industrial plant here today, killing one person and injuring three others, authorities reported.

title: Shift of Times Sq. Project For Use by Poor Decried
description: A coalition of community groups yesterday denounced a Beame administration proposal to convert a cityfinanced apartment development being built near Times Square from an uppermiddleincome complex to one in which poor and moderate  income families would live with Federal subsidies.

title: Cabinet Resignation Fails To Halt Argentine Strike
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 7Argentine workers went ahead with a twoday general strike today despite a lastminute Government effort last night to avert the nationwide shutdown by announcing the resignation of the entire Cabinet.

title: BERME RESTORES 2,600 MORE JOBS; ASKS PAY FREEZE
description: Mayor Beanie restored the jobs of 2,600 more city workers last evening and further confused the city's already muddled layoffrehiring picture.

title: Weeden Holding Registers A FiscalQuarter Profit
description: The Weeden Corporation, parent of Weeden & Co., the thirdmarket brokerage firm, said yesterday it earned $2.03million, or $1.22 a share, in the third fiscal quarter ended June 30 contrasted with a loss of $1.15million a year earlier.

title: Newport Jazz
description: There Was never any question that this year's Newport Jazz Festival mould be basically conservative. The advance programming of the 10day, festival made that plain.

title: George Morgan, 50, Wrote Candy Kisses, Hit of 1949
description: NASHVILLE, July 7 (UPI)George Morgan, a Grand Ole Opry singer best known for his recording of Candy Kisses, died today in Baptist Hospital. He had undergone heart surgery last week and was 50 years old.

title: Tourists Delayed in Finland
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 7 (UPI)Thousands of tourists are stranded in Finland, many camping at harbor terminals, because of a fourday strike by ship engineers that has tied up 50 vessels.

title: Reply From Hanoi On the U.S. Missing Angers Legislator
description: WASHINGTON, July 7A request by members of Congress to North Vietnam seeking an accounting of Americans listed as missing in action in the Indochina war has elicited a familiar response from Hanoi and an angry rejoinder from one of the legislators.

title: Both Sides Ready to Talk In Electric Boat Co. Strike
description: GROTON, Conn., July 7 (AP) The union representating 10,000 striking workers at the Electric Boat Company shipyard demanded today immediate resumption of bargaining, and a company official indicated the concern was willing to do so.

title: State to Televise $.1Million Lottery As an Experiment
description: In what is described as an experiment possibly leading to a weekly televised drawing in the fall, the New York State Division of the Lottery has arranged with WABCTV here to broadcast the July 24 Grand Tier drawing of the $1million lottery.

title: Texas MilkFund Case
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. July 7 (UPI)The Government rested its case today against an Oklahoma City lawyer, Stuart Russell, who allegedly funneled more than $150,000 in corporate milk funds illegally into political campaigns from 1968 to 1971.

title: Reality Has the Last Word
description: Why New Jersey? Because people make such a funny face when you mention New Jersey. And it's where I'm going and seeing what it's all about. And you see all the tensions in New Jersey, the differences are so strong. It's a kind of shortcut through America, in a way. If we hadn't taken New Jersey, I would have thought of San Diego County, or something like this, in Southern California, something very...where you find extremes.

title: Sex Discrimination Rules Face Test in House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 7Representative James G. O'Hara said today that he would ask Congress to reject two portions of the sex discrimination rules written by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and signed by President Ford last month.

title: A Barber Shop Quartet In a Women's Salon? It's Possible Nowadays
description: It wasn't as momentous as the repeal of Prohibition, but a recent court decision has removed a speakeasy aspect that has been prevalent in beauty salons for nearly a decade.

title: REDS IN CONTROL, LAOTIANS BELIEVE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 6The Pathet Lao takeover of this country, and with it the completion of the Communist victory in Indochina, is now accepted as an accomplisbed fact by most Laotians and foreign observers.

title: Con Edison Has Cut Its Capital Budget $20Million for '75
description: The Consolidated Edison Cornpany of New York, the, nation's largest investorowned electric utility, has cut its 1975 capital budget by $20million, according to the testimony filed with the New York State Public Service Commission.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A coalition of community groups yesterday denounced a Beame administration proposal to convert a New York Cityfinanced apartment development being built near Times Square from an uppermiddleincome complex to one in which poor and moderateincome families would be federally subsidized.

title: Trial Will Proceed In Deaths of Twins Born After Shooting
description: CAMDEN, July 7 (AP)  A Camden County Judge refused today to dismiss double murder indictments against a man charged with killing twin in fants who died soon after birth following the shooting of a woman who was seven months pregnant.

title: Miss Teeguarden Scores in Tennis
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 7 (AP)Douglas Palm of Sweden eliminated Fred McNair of Chevy Chase, Md., 62, 62, in the first round of the $50,000 Swedish open tennis championships today.

title: Scientist Doubts Spray Cans Imperil Ozone Layer
description: A British scientist, here under the auspices of the chemical industry, yesterday described as utter nonsense the argument that fluorocarbons such as those used in some spray cans present a serious threat to the ozone layer.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which rarely gives shows to living America?? artists, will honor the paint er Andrew Wyeth with an exhibition in the fall of 1976.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Economic Development Authority said it had completed the financing of loans totaling $3.7million for six business expansion projects. The loans went to: Atlantic City, $350,000 to the Gurwicz N Partnership to renovate the Hotel Jefferson, and $700,000 to 100 Park Place, Inc., to buy and renovate the Mount Royal Hotel; Edison Township, $750,000 to National Color Laboratories, Inc., to buy and renovate a building to expand its photo processing business; Plainsboro, $1million to Firmenich, Inc., to build a regional office and manufacturing complex for the Swissbased manufacturer of flavors and fragrances; South Hackensack, $665,000 to the Windsor Products Company, Inc., to acquire and equip a building for its auto parts distribution business, and Pennsauken, $280,000 to Roberts Food Products to acquire and renovate a building for its meatprocessing business.

title: Japanese Jobless Down
description: TOKYO, July 8 (AP)The number of jobless in Japan in May totaled 910,000, down 70,000 from April, the statistics bureau of the Pemier's office said today. The unemployment rate stood at 1.7 per cent, down 0.2 per cent from April, the bureau said. The number of employed in May totaled 52,810,000 or 290,000 less than in May of last year.

title: MRS. PERON YIELDS TO WAGE DEMANDS IN GENERAL STRIKE
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 8Argentine labor leaders today called off a general strike after the Government had agreed to wage demands ranging in many cases to 100 percent above previous salary levels.

title: Teachers' New Leader
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8John E. Ryor, a mathematics teacher from Michigan who was elected president of the 1.7 millionmember National Education Association yesterday at its annual convention here, shrugs off the fact that he is from the same state as the President of the United States. We're of a different political persuasion, he says, and besides, he's a Neanderthal when it comes to aid to education.

title: U.S. Team Victor In Prague Track
description: PRAGUE, July 8 (AP)The United States track and field team, winning eight of the 16 final events, defeated favored Poland and Czechoslovakia today, three days after its crushing loss to the Soviet Union.

title: WINE TALK
description: SONOMA, Calif.There is a lot of gloom in the California vineyards these days what with talk of bankruptcy, falling prices and dropping sales.

title: State Seeks Advice on 3 Mental Hospitals
description: TRENTON, July 8The State Department of Institutions and Agencies, disturbed by the denial of accreditation for a third mental hospital in New Jersey, is seeking a meeting in Chicago with the Accreditation Council for Psychiatric Facilities to explore ways to improve the deficient state institutions.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A woman's size isn't important at the Farmer's Daughter. The Lexington Avenue boutique has onesize garments that can be worn equally well by a 6 or a 16.

title: On Behalf of the Public's Right to Know
description: WASHINGTONIn June, 1974, Representative Michael J. Harrington was permitted to read the transcript of a secret briefing by the Director of Central Intelligence, William E. Colby, on American covert intervention in Chile.

title: Charges of N.M.U. Graft Investigated by U.S. Jury
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark is investigating allegations of widespread corruption among present and former leaders of the National Maritime Union.

title: 8 Die in Oregon Hotel Fire; Skid Row Resident Arrested
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 8 (AP) The police arrested John J. Newvine, a 61yearold skid row resident, today on murder and arson charges in the wake of a fire that ripped through a rundown hotel, leaving eight persons dead and 26 injured. Eight of the injured were listed in critical condition.

title: TREASURY ISSUES SHOW PRICE RISES
description: An casing trend in moneymarket rates produced a fairiy buoyant showing in Treasury securities yesterday. The corporate bond sector, taking its cue from the Government market overcame its nervousness of recent sessions to close slightly higher. Significant declines occurred in the yield of Treasury bills. The threemonth bill, which had an average return of 6.20 per cent in the Monday auction, thus registering its top yield since January, closed on the sheets of some dealers at 6 per cent on the offered side.

title: Mets' Records
FORD AND MAYORS WILL MEET ON AID
description: BOSTON, July 8President Ford has invited a delegation of bigcity Mayors to the White House on Thursday.

title: The Bookkeeper and the Engineer
description: DETROIT, July 8In John Joseph Riccardo's early days as a top executive of the Chrysler Corporation, he was called the flame thrower in recognition of the tough, aggressive way in which he approached his job and demanded performance from those under him.

title: FourDay Week Is Proposed to Save Library Jobs
description: The union that represents about 1,600 New York Public Library employes is taking a poll of its members to find out whether they would favor a four or a fourandahalfday work week to avert layoffs.

title: Eton, Pinched by Costs, Taking Summer Guests
description: LONDON, July 8Eton, an ancient symbol of privilege and upperclass exclusiveness, has fallen victim to inflation and decided to take in paying guests from abroad who want to learn English.

title: SUFFOLK INDICTS 3 UNION LEADERS
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. L, July 8Three union officials were indicted today, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office announced.

title: A Master of Bonsai Visits Brooklyn
description: The small, exquisite trees that Kyuzo Murata nurtures, patiently transforming nature into art, evoking timelessness through simplicity, are just like children to him.

title: ROBERT M'QUINN
description: Robert McQuinn, an artist and stage designer, died June 24 in Pineville, Pa., at the age of 92.

title: Senate Panel to Ask Nixon if He Knows of Plots Against Castro
description: WASHINGTON, July 8Senator Frank Church. Democrat of Idaho, who is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that former President Richard M. Nixon would be asked if he had any evidence regarding Central Intelligence Agency plots to assassinate Premier Castro of Cuba. Such plots allegedly began in the last year of the Eisenhower Administration, when Mr. Nixon was Vice President.

title: Trolley Staging Comeback Over Nation
description: A desire named streetcars is, growinga desire for the return of one of America's oldest forms of urban public transportation.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: SHOOT IT: BLACK SHOOT IT: BLUE, directed by Dennis McGuire, starring Michael Moriarty and SUPER BROOK, directed by Anthony Major, both at neighborhood theaters.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rail Safety Bill Passed
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The Senate sent to President Ford today a bill to authorize $52,5million for continuing the Government's, railroad safety programs in the next year. The measure would also authorize 150 additional Federal safety inspectors, raising the total to 500.

title: SWISS EXPECT TO BUY 72 NORTHROP PLANES
description: GENEVA, July 8The Swiss Defense Department expects to sign a $500million contract with the Northrop Corporation next April for the purchase of 72 Tiger F5E fighter planes, Government sources said today.

title: DOW DROPS 3.29; VOLUME CLIMBS
description: For the second consecutive day the doldrums after the Fourth of July forced stocks lower on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 9, 1975

title: Leaders Nearing Ocean Race Finish
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 8The leaders in the Marblehead  Halifax ocean race were about 70 miles from the finish line this afternoon and sailing in light southwest winds amid heavy fog. The first finisher was expected to cross the line at Chebucto Head after midnight.

title: REPORT ON SPYING RELEASED BY C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Central Intelligence Agency made a major buildup of its domestic intelligence operation during the Administration of President Nixon, according to documents released by the C.I.A. for the first time tonight.

title: FORD ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR '76 TO FINISH THE JOB
description: WASHINGTON, July 8President Ford announced formally today that he would seek the Republican nomination for the Presidency in 1976 in order to finish the job I have begun.

title: Books of The Times
description: People have always thought of me as an intellectual comedian, and I'm not. I'm a oneliner comic like Bob Hope and Henny Youngman. I do the wife jokes. I make faces. That is Woody Allen, straight, on Woody Allen, as reported by Eric Lax in On Being Funny, a sort of stabatabiography cum home movie of the comedian in action.

title: Cambodia's Crime . .
description: Some twelve weeks after the Communist entry into Phnom Penh and the forced exodus on foot of millions of urban Cambodians to distant countrysides, a veil of silence still cloaks the full horror of what has happened with the worst yet to come in predicted deaths from hunger and disease.

title: A Dance of the 60's Illustrates the Path Of Phoebe Neville
description: Reviving older works is a chancy but necessary exercise for the choreographer. One always learns a hit about the present and possibly the future from a careful examination of the past.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WAILUA, Hawaii, July 8 (AP)Allan Yamamoto of Honolulu took a twostroke lead with a threeunderpar 69 in the first round of the United States Golf Association amateur public links championship today.

title: 2 Clouts Win, 43, For Mets
description: ATLANTA, July 8Dave Kingman, who has been alternating strikeouts and homers with increasing ferocity on the Mets' current trip, hit one of the latter for three runs and a 43 New York victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight.

title: FOOD TALK
description: The price of fresh squid has declined recently, making it a relatively cheap source of quality protein. Prices currently range from 60 cents to $1 a pound.

title: GRACE CRANE MOORE
description: Grace Crane Moore, manager of the credit and adjustment department of the Paramus (N.J.) branch of B. Altman & Co., died Monday at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. She was 71 years old and lived at 362 East Glen Avenue, Ridgewood.

title: School Fund Suit Filed
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8 (AP) The American Civil Liberties Union has filed suit asking that funds to Los Angeles city schools be cut off unless the schools are desegregated. The class action suit was filed in United States District Court yesterday.

title: Former Mental Patients Waiting for Foster Homes
description: DUMONT, July 8As a result of difficulties encountered in trying to find foster homes for them, patients at Greystone Psychiatric Hospital in Morris Plains who have been deemed sufficiently well to be released are being held there.

title: The Disposable Issue
description: WASHINGTON, July 8One day last week President Ford flew into Cincinnati through a dense smog to dedicate the National Environmental Research Center. Although a pollution alert was in effect, Mr. Ford delivered a speech that thickened the air with additional noxious materials.

title: Boston Schools Ask Delay On Step to Desegregation
description: BOSTON, July 8 (UPI)The Boston School Committee has asked Judge W. Arthur Garrity of the United States District Court to postpone for a year the school building alterations required as a step toward desegregation.

title: Israeli Says Censor Clears Revision of Kissinger Book
description: TEL AVIV, July 8A revised manuscript of a banned book describing Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East mediation will be cleared by the Israeli military censor, the author said in Jerusalem today.

title: C. I. A. PAYMENTS WENT TO ASHLAND
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 The Central Intelligence Agency secretly paid Ashland Oil, Inc., nearly $99,000 in five recent yearsmore than $50,000 of it in cash  for undisclosed purDoses.

title: Makarova's Grace Shines in 2 Roles
description: Natalia Makarova has made it clear to the world at large that she considers that American ballet has done her wrong; has, in effect and in fact, failed to give her the opportunities she needed to develop as an artist. Is this true? It might be.

title: Beame Gets a Big Welcome at the Mayors' Conference in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 8  Mayor William McNichols of Denver had just sunk his spoon into a bowl of oatmeal this morning when he spotted Mayor Beame leaving the hotel dining room. He leaped up and offered a combination handshake and pat on the back.

title: Rabin, at BergenBelsen, Says It, Belongs to Past
description: BERGENBELSEN, West Germany, July 8His face pale, his voice grave, Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel stood solemnly before a small stone monument here today and read a prayer to the memory of the lens of thousands of Jews who perished in this vast concentration camp 30 years ago.

title: Cities That Go Broke
description: While New York City has taken a lot of criticism over its money troubles, it has never defaulted on its obligations or filed for bankruptcy under the Federal bankruptcy law. The same cannot be said of a great many other places. The national titleholder for fiscal irresponsibil i t y appears to be Ranger, Tex., a town of 3,004, not far from Abilene. Ranger has gone broke not once but three timesmost recently in 1971.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY STARTS NEW WING
description: Construction has begun on a $1.9million expansion of the Pierpont Morgan Library on the east side of Madison Avenue at 36th Street.

title: Gambling Charges Hold Reputed Mafia Member
description: Two men, including a reputed Mafia member, were arrested on gambling charges here, the federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday.

title: President Is Designated By the Comoro Islands
description: MORONI, Comoro Islands, July 8 (Reuters)  Ahmed Abdallah today became President of the Comoro Islands, which uniliaterally declared independence from France Sunday. He was designated by the Chamber of Deputies.

title: CLOSURE REJECTED ON NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: WASHINGTON, July 8As tempers began to wear thin, the Senate failed today for the fourth time to limit debate on the disputed New Hampshire Senate election and Republicans rejected a compromise proposal by Democratic leaders aimed at breaking the impasse.

title: Food Prices Rise To Record Levels
description: Food prices rose in New York City to a record level last week, as an advance of 0.9 per cent the week before, was followed by an increase of 1.0 per cent.

title: BEAME DISPUTED ON JOB VACANCIES
description: A Federal Labor Department official yesterday questioned whether the city had the estimated total of 1,500 to 2,000 vacancies in the Federal public employment program Mayor Beame had said would be used to rehire some dismissed city workers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: BENJAMIN MOED
description: Benjamin Moed, founder and president of Mott Haven Truck Parts, Inc., in the Bronx died yesterday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Volpe, Marketing Expert, Hired to Reshape L.P.G.A. Image
description: The Ladies Professional Golf Association introduced yesterday its new chief executive, Ray Volpe, and with him a preview of what women's professional golf will be like in the near futurenot the quality of the golf, but the intensity of the hard sell.

title: Albany Acts to Ease Curbs to Employing Of Former Convicts
description: ALBANY, July 8A bill that removes dozens of legal prohibitions against the employment of exconvicts received final passage in the Assembly tonight and was sent to the Governor for his signature.

title: Conviction of J. J. Kenny Dismissed by High Court
description: TRENTON, July 8 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that John J. Kenny, a former Hudson County Freeholder, was protected from prosecution by the state because he had been granted immunity by the Federal Government to testify in a political corruption case. The court, in a 70 decision, dismissed state convictions against Mr. Kenny for extortion and misconduct in office.

title: Adoption, Film From Hungary, Wins Top Award in West Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, July 8The Hungarian movie Adoption, which was directed by Marta Mezaros, and which tells the story of an unmarried woman who adopts a baby, won first prize, the Golden Bear award, at the close of the 25th Berlin Film Festival today.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Aerosol cans are a convenience but they come to the Consumer usuallybut not alwaysat a higher cost, a research project of the New York Public Interest Research Group found.

title: DELTA STEAMSHIP IN TRADE PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Government has received its first complaint under the sweeping unfair trade practices section of the new trade law enacted by Congress late last year.

title: 3 Oil Companies Consent To Bar on Price Rigging
description: A State Supreme Court Justice dismissed yesterday pricerigging charges against three major oil companies after the companies agreed to an order barring them from arranging to fix prices to restrain competition from independent gasoline dealers in the state.

title: A Maverick Priest Loses to Democrat In Chicago Election
description: CHICAGO, July 8 (UPI)Not enough of the white bluecollar voters that the Rev. Francis X. Lawlor calls my people turned out today to save him from defeat in a Congressional election likely to be his last hurrah as a maverick priest in politics.

title: L. I. TOWNS FIGHT A TOLL RISE OF $1
description: MINEOLA, L I., July 8The Town of Oyster Bay said today that it would join the Town of Babylon in Suffolk County in a suit to prevent the State Department of Parks and Recreation from doubling the $1 toll on the Jones Beach State Park complex.

title: People and Business.
description: The big question at a press Iuncheon, held by the Manufacturers Hanover Bank yes terday was: Is the recession over? Gabriel Hauge, chairman of the bank, answered: Yes, if you mean the end of the down.

title: FORD ANNOUNCES CANDIDACY FOR '76 TO FINISH THE JOB
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 President Ford announced formally today that he would seek the Republican nomination for the Presidency in 1976 in order to finish the job I have begun.

title: Court in Bordeaux Cuts Terms In WineAdulterating Scandal
description: PARIS, July 8The Court of Appeals in the famed winegrowing district of Bordeaux today reduced the penalties imposed on the principal defendants in a wineadulterating trial last December.

title: Nursing Home Reforms
description: As this session of the Legislature draws to a close, some life still remains in the effort to achieve effective nursing home reform.

title: Captive Politicians
description: There's no question about it, the chairman of the Municipal Labor Committee told a Times reporter last month, we have the ability, in a sense, to elect our own boss. Victor Gotbaum was talking about the Mayor of New York but the electoral power of the municipal unions extends to other city officials as wellin the Council, in the Board of Estimate and in the State Legislature.

title: People in Sports
description: Bob Hayes, the former world recordholder in the 100yard dash, is on the trading block, according to Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys. The 32yearold wide receiver caught 365 passes for 7,295 yards and scored 76 touchdowns in his 10year National Football League career with Dallas. But he lost his starting position to Golden Richards last season, catching only seven passes for 118 yards and touchdown.

title: I.R.S. Disallows Tax Exemptions For Gifts to Hospital Near Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Internal Revenue Service, in what appears to be a reversal of established policy, has ruled that it will no longer permit tax deductions for contributions to the Bach Mai Hospital Emergency Relief Fund.

title: Sturgeon Are Returning to the Hudson
description: The sturgeonlong thought to be almost extinct in waters around New York City is apparently thriving in the Hudson River in such numbers that it would appear to offer a potentially large source of proteinrich food in sturgeon steaks and the possibility that New York may once again become a major exporter of caviar.

title: SUIT OVER 11 MURALS IN HOTEL IS SETTLED
description: A legal battle over the ownership of 11 murals painted by the late Howard Chandler Christy was settled out of court yesterday when the Hotel Des Artistes filed a notice that it was dropping its suit against the Cafe Des Artistes and its former operator, Romeo Sterlini.

title: Article 3  No Title
Ford Hopes to Sway House on Weapons Aid to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Ford Administration is mounting a largescale lobbying effort among members of Congress in the hope that a vote next week will overturn the embargo imposed by Congress last winter on military assistance to Turkey.

title: Advertising
description: Hoards of auto racing enthusiasts will be converging on Watkins Glen, N. Y., this weekend for the World Championship of Manufacturers. And, if they are typical fans, they'll probably be almost 90 per cent in the 18to34yearold set, practically half of whom are making more than $15,000 a year and more than threequarters of whom have attended college.

title: Brazil Easing Some Curbs, but Arts Stay Under a Stern Censor
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6Brazil has fiery debates in Congress on human rights, newspaper denunciations of political corruption and even incipient student strikes, but a political song or a racy play is still taboo.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHTS MATCHES

title: She Died on the Lead
description: After the burial, some of the mourners stopped off at a bar near the Belmont Park stable area.

title: Trolley Staging Comeback Over Nation
description: A desire named streetcars is growinga desire for the return of one of America's oldest forms of urban public transportation.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON OIL RESERVES
description: Oil Reserve Bill Voted The House voted yesterday to permit commercial production of oil in the reserve naval oil fields of Elk Hills and Buena Vista, Calif., and Teapot Dome, Wyo. Page 47.

title: Rabin, at BergenBelsen, Says It Belongs to Past
description: BERGENBELSEN, West Germany, July 8His face pale, his voice grave, Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel stood solemnly before a small stone, monument here today and read a prayer to the memory of the tens of thousands of Jews who perished in this vast concentration camp 30 years ago.

title: A CITY FIREMAN DIES ON RETURN TO DUTY
description: A 32yearold Brooklyn fireman, back on duty only a few hours after a threeweek vacation, collapsed while fighting a twoalarm fire in the BedfordStuyvesant section early yesterday and died three hours later.

title: WINE TALK
description: SONOMA, Calif.There is a lot of gloom in the California vineyards these days what with talk of bankruptcy, falling prices and dropping sales.

title: For a Summer Meal, a Bounty of Seafood and Smoked Pheasant
description: DERINGRARBOR, Shelter Island, N.Y. If the meal seems somewhat incongruous in midsummer, it could not be faulted from the standpoint of taste. It began with mackerel caught in front of the house last May; cold sliced smoked pheasant from last November's hunt, and a casserole of wild rice with oysters, the oysters also fresh from the waters in front of the house.

title: Prices Are Mixed On Amex and OTC In Slow Trading
description: Prices on the American Stocks Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed narrowly mixed yesterday in slow trading although volume rose on the counter markets.

title: Riccardo Named Chrysler's Chairman
description: DETROIT, July 8The Chrysler Corporation announced today its new management team.

title: Article 2  No Title
CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times last Saturday on plans for the annual Stone House Day celebration in Hurley, N.Y., the Col. Gerhardus Hardenburg House was incorrectly included among those that would he open to the public. The Hardenburg House will not he among the 10 homes on the tour, which is to be held Saturday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Jersey's highest court affirmed the dismissal of the extortion conviction of John J. Kenny, former Hudson County Freeholder, on the ground that Federal immunity protected him from state prosecution. Mr. Kenny and 11 others were indicted by a Federal grand jury in 1970 on 34 counts involving extortion and bribery in connection with public construction projects in Jersey City and other parts of Hudson County. A state grand jury had also indicted Mr. Kenny on charges of extorting $50,000 for changing a deed restriction on a piece of property, and he was subsequently convicted. At the Federal trial, Mr. Kenny was granted immunity from prosecution and compelled to testify.

title: LONG BEACH UPHELD IN COURT ON LAYOFFS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 8Ruling on a petition by 22 members of the Long Beach Fire Department a State Supreme Court justice declared today that municipalities had the power to consolidate and abolish positions for economic reasons.

title: 28% Decline Is Found In Mergers From '74
description: There were 1.203 merger announcements in the first six months of 1975, a decline of 28 per cent from the 1,669 announcements made in the corresponding period of 1974, W. T. Grimm & Co.. merger consultants in Chicago, announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Alters Military Stance as Deadlier Arms Spread
description: Doctrine and tactics in the United States military forces are changing rapidly and significantly in view of the global proliferation of sophisticated one shot, one kill weapons whose effectiveness was demonstrated in the 1973 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Mass Transit Agency Awaiting a New Chief
description: With the departure June 30 of Frank C. Herringer as urban mass transportation administrator to take over as head of the Bay Area Rapid Transit District in San Francisco, the future of the trolleyand other urban transit developmentsbecomes the concern of a new administrator.

title: Bridge
description: Some bridge writings, like some wines, travel well. Others do not. The general rule is that books on play and defense are exportable, while books on bidding are not.

title: Three Gibb Brothers Are the Core Of Bee Gees in Wolltnan Concert
description: The Bee Gees concert Monday night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Parkthey'll be there again tonightwas a feast for people who like lush, romantically inflected poprock. The Woilman Rink wasn't full, but the crowd was respectable, given the two shows and the threat of rain, and the surrounding rocks and hills were covered with embracing couples.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON OIL RESERVES
description: The House voted yesterday to permit commercial production of oil in the reserve naval oil fields of Elk Hills and Buena Vista, Calif., and Teapot Dome, Wyo. Page 47.

title: Thailand Warned by Laos Against Border Incidents
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 8 (Reuters)Laos warned Thailand today that her people would punish any encroachment on her independence and sovereignty.

title: Hunter Captures 12th In Yanks' 40 Victory
description: Billy Martin, a member of six pennantwinning Yankee teams in the nineteenfifties, expressed his displeasure last night at not having been invited to the Yankees' oldtimers game that will recall that decade of glory. That was before the game.

title: REPORT ON SPYING RELEASED BY C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Central Intelligence Agency disclosed tonight portions of an internal report on its domestic spying operations in the late nineteensixties and the early nineteenseventies. The report was provided for President Ford last Dec. 24.

title: About Education
description: A student learning to read comes upon the sentence, The boy jumped on the horse and rode off. But instead of saying horse, the student substitutes pony. Should the teacher correct him?

title: Lutheran Schism Nears As Doctrinal Rift Grows
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 8A major split in the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod appeared nearer today as efforts at compromise failed to soften a longstanding conflict between moderates and conservatives.

title: House Panel Rejects Some Rules On Sex Discrimination in Schools
description: WASHINGTON, July 8A House subcommittee voted today to reject portions of the school sex discrimination rules that have been written by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The panel also voted to amend the law under which the rules were written to exempt revenueproducing college sports from having to comply and to allow physical education classes to segregate on the basis of sex.

title: A New Look Leader Faces Uneasy Tulane
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 8When the liberal new president of Tulane University says, I think of myself as a member of the faculty, the words have special meaning.

title: The Church Against The State
description: MADRIDA revolution has already occurred in Spain and almost everyone in the country knows it except for Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the handful of conservatives with whom, by preference, he surrounds himself at the sunset of his life. When he dies, a prominent Spaniard confided to me, the nineteenth century will finally be over.

title: MRS. PERON YIELDS TO WAGE DEMANDS IN GENERAL STRIKE
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 8Argentine labor leaders today called off a general strike after the Government had agreed to wage demands ranging in many cases to 100 percent above previous salary levels.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JLRSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3481767.

title: Police Who Halted Greenburgh Traffic Facing Discipline
description: GREENBURGH, N. Y., July 8 Disciplinary charges of disorderly conduct, harassment, dereliction of duty and misconduct have been filed against 41 Greenburgh Town policemen who participated in a demonstration that tied up traffic at a major intersection for two hours on June 25.

title: Soviet Said to Seek U. S. Grain Supply
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) The Soviet Union, suffering from drought, is preparing to purchase large quantities of grain from the United States and Canada, according to reports in two London newspapers today.

title: F.D.A. BACKS 2 DRUGS DESPITE DEATH RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The head or the Food and Drug Administration testified today that two powerful substitutes for penicillin were related to 13 additional deaths but that adequate warning language was being required on labeling and in advertising.

title: About New York
description: When he changes from his brown habit into blue jeans and leaves the shadowed peace of the Church of St. Rtancis of Assisi for the thronged sidewalks of West 31st Street, the Rev. John McVean is covering 700 years in a single step.

title: Lucia Burbadge Donnelly, Editor of Westport News
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 8Lucia Burbadge Donnelly, editor of The Westport News, was found dead in bed at her home yesterday. The police say she died of natural causes. She was 64 years old and lived at 2 Scherer Court.

title: Rockefeller Aide Bars A Quest for Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON, July 8You don't run for the Vice Presidency, a spokesman for Vice President Rockefeller said today, insisting that Mr. Rockefeller had no plans to announce his candidacy to be President Ford's running mate next year.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PIONEER'S DAY One of the historic names in jazz, Eubie Blake, will appear in today's 90minute free concert at 4:30 P.M. at McGrawHill Park, Rockefeller Center. In this third program of Jazz for City Evening, the ragtime pianist will reprise highlights of a career that began in the honkytonk bars of Baltimore, and yielded his first hit, in 1899, The Charleston Rag.

title: Notes on People
description: A reporter on assignment for the weekly National Enquirer who had an extraordinary interest in Secretary of State Kissinger's trash was questioned for twoandahalf hours by Secret Servicemen and Washington policemen Monday night after he picked up five bags of the Kissinger garbage.

title: Drut First In Hurdles; Foster 2d
description: PARIS, July 8 (AP)Guy Drut of France beat Charles Foster of the United States by more than six feet today as he won the 110meter hurdles, the opening event of a track meet at JeanBouin Stadium.

title: 2 Quakes, Far Apart
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) Two earthquakes, each measuring 6.8 on the Richter Scale, occurred within hours of each other today in Mexico and Burma, the United States Geological Survey said The first quake occurred in the Gulf of California at 2:37 A.M. Eastern daylight time, a spokesman said. He said the second quake took place at 8 A.M. in Central Burma near Mandalay.

title: House Votes Wetlands Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The House passed 400 to 0 today legislation to extend for seven years the act under which wetlands are purchased as refuges for waterfowl. The bill, which now goes to the Senate, would authorize an additional $95million.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Sanok Captures Ike Golf Playoff
description: CLIFTON, N. J., July 8Chet Sanok, who won his fifth state amateur crown last month here on his home course, Upper Montclair, captured his first Ike golf tournament today. He defeated Jay Blumenfeld of East Orange and George Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE SUED OVER ETHNIC DATA
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 8 (AP)  The Federal Government sued the state of New Hampshire today over Gov. Meldrim Thomson's refusal to provide information on the racial and ethnic backgrounds of state workers.

title: 9 Slain Here in 24 Hours, the Most in One Day This Year, as July, a Peak Month for Murder, Begins
description: Nine persons were killed in murders and murdersuicides during a 24hour period Monday and yesterdaythe most homicides on one day in the city this year, occurring during a month that is generally one of the peak times for homicides in New York.

title: City Hospital Chief Sees Cuts Costing 1,000 Jobs
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation has begun implementing city budget cuts that Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., its president, estimated yesterday would require 14 affiliated hospitals to lay off 1,000 professionals and others.

title: Hudson Brothers Blend Hard Rock At the Bottom Line
description: Rock on television normally consists either of established stars performing late at night or pallid imitations of the real thing. The Hudson Brothers, who have won whatever fame they possess through their own television series and who opened Monday at the Bottom Line for a threenight run, don't really fit that pattern. They make a hard rock sound and, at least in a club context, they try to project a raunchier image than television might lead one to expect.

title: Mrs. King Leads Sets to Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., July 8 Playing with the decisive accuracy that carried her to the Wimbledon championship last week, Billie Jean King led the New York Sets to a runway 2613 victory over the San Diego Friars in World Team Tennig tonight before 2,048 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Campaign '76: Ford Starts as Favorite
description: WASHINGTON, July 8President Ford entered the 1976 Presidential campaign today as the clear favoritethe favorite not only to capture the Republican nomination, bat also to win the 1976 election. For a man who took office under the most trying of circumstances, and whose early actions were derided by many members of his own party, that is no small feat.

title: Yonkers Results
JERSEY WILL CUT RAILBUS SUBSIDIES
description: TRENTON, July 8  State transportation officials today announced plans for a sharply reduced rail and bus subsidy (program by the state that could eliminate service for tens of thousands of commuters and result in higher fares for thousands of others.

title: Business Briefs
description: The United States Railway Association has reached agreement with the trustees of the Penn Central Railroad, under which the Government will provide the railroad with a $56million grant to cover the cost of repairing 8,000 freight cars, 500 cabooses, 200 locomotives and 300 maintenanceofway work cars.

title: Strike Shuts Paper
description: WESTFIELD, Mass., July 8 (AP)The strikesbound Westfield Evening News remained shut down a second day today, but the presses continued rolling at the Winsted (Conn.) Citizen, a sister newspaper. Reporters and production workers struck both papers yesterday in a bid to gain recognition of Retail Employes Union Local 1459 as their bargaining agent.

title: Soviet Dollar Interest Cited
description: LONDON, July 8 (Reuters)Signs of growing Soviet activity in Western currency, Eurodollar and gold markets provide evidence that the nation may be seeking substantial dollar balances for North American grain purchases, London bankers report.

title: The Incumbent
description: By the standard of recent decades, President Ford's announcement of his candidacy is extraordinarily early. But in the absence of his formal permission, the legal and financial reporting requirements of the new Campaign Finance Act make it difficult for the President's friends to conduct the lowkeyed preliminary campaign usually organized in behalf of an incumbent.

title: Paternity Leave for Teaching Fathers: An Idea That Has Not Caught Fire
description: More than two years after a ruling that all New York City school teachers were entitled to leaves of absence to bring up their new babies, teaching fathers apparently are passing up the chance to be at home with their dren.

title: Thompson, Top Collegian, Will Join A.B.A. Nuggets
description: The National Basketball Association suffered a second major blow yesterday when David Thompson decided to play for the Denver Nuggets of the rival American Basketball Association rather than the Atlanta Hawks of the N.B.A.

title: Charges of N.M.U. Graft Investigated by U.S. Jury
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark is investigating allegations of widespread corruption among present and former leaders of the National Maritime Union.

title: Wheat Estimates Made
description: LONDON, July 8 (UPI)The Soviet Union may double its wheat imports this year to million tons or more, the International Wheat Council said today, compared with 2.5 million last year.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 9, 1975

title: LABORITE AFFIRMS EUROPEAN GOALS
description: STRASBOURG, France, July 8Sir Michael Stewart, head of the British Labor party's first delegation to the European Parliament here, said today that his country was now determined to make a success of the European Economic Community and its efforts to move toward union.

title: Ford Fails to Recommend Ways To Provide Capital Incentives
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Ford Administration declined today to make a specific recommendation for tax reductions designed to increase the money available for business investment in new plants and equipment, although it has Said for months that increasing such capital formation was one of the most urgent economic problems facing the nation.

title: . . . Indochina's Future
description: The political orientation of Indochina, in both domestic and foreign policies, semains enigmatic. The disciplined Vietminh movement of Hanoi is the dominant force, but it is doubtful that Hanoi can exert nearly as much influence over the authorities in Laos and particularly in Carnbodia as in South Vietnam.

title: 3 Oil Companies Consent To Bar on Price Rigging
description: A State Supreme Court Justice dismissed yesterday pricerigging charges against three major oil companies after the companies agreed to an order barring them from arranging to fix prices to restrain competition from independent gasoline dealers in the state.

title: College Names President
description: HUNTINGDON, Pa., July 8 (UPI)Dr. Frederick M. Binder, president of Whittier College in California, was named today as president of Juniata College. He will assum his new post Sept. 1 succeeding Dr. John N. Stauffer, who is leaving for health reasons.

title: Islanders Acquire No. 1 Draft Choice
description: FARMINGDALE, LI., July 8Legend has preceded Shaun (Pat) Price. The 20yearold defenseman, who was the New York Islanders' No. 1 selection in last month's amateur draft, signed a multiyear agreement today with the club at a salary he acknowledged to be close to $60.000 a season.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The New York Times last Saturday on plans for the annual Stone House Day celebration in Hurley, N.Y., the Col. Gerhardus Hardenburg House was incorrectly included among those that would be open to the public. The Hardenburg House will not be among the 10 homes on the tour, which is to be held Saturday.

title: U.S. COURT ORDERS REHEARING ON WEIS
description: A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled here yesterday by 2 to 1, that a lower court erred in refusing to hear a case brought against the New York Stock Exchange after the financial collapse of Weis Securities, Inc., a former brokerage house.

title: Art Museum Asks For 2 Taxi Designs Geared to the City
description: The Museum of Modern Art has invited Volvo of Sweden and Volkswagen of West Germany to design and build taxicabs suitable for use in New York City.

title: Pavel Virsky, 70, Choreographer Of Ukrainian Dancers, Is Dead
description: The death of Pavel Virsky, leading Soviet choreographer, was reported yesterday in Moscow by Tass, the Soviet press agency. He was 70 years old.

title: Last Trolleys Rolled in the City in 1957
description: The trolley car, which made its first New York City appearance in 1832, ended its days here in 1957, a victim of the awesome power of the automotive interests and the metamorphosis of American life that they engendered.

title: Albany Acts to Ease Curbs to Employing Of Former Convicts
description: ALBANY, July 8A bill that removes dozens of legal prohibitions against the employment of exconvicts received final passage in the Assembly tonight and was sent to the Governor for his signature.

title: Rep. Harrington Defends His Disclosure of Secret Colby Testimony Implicating the C.I.A. in Chile
description: WASHINGTON, July 8Representative Michael J. Harrington today defended as appropriate and responsible his disclosure to follow Congressmen last year of details of sworn secret testimony on the Central. Intelligence Agency's political activities in Chile.

title: Legislature Approves, and Governor Signs, New City Tax Authority
description: ALBANY, July 8The State Legislature, finally arriving at what Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal called the end of a long and tortuous road, voted today to authorize New York City to raise $330million in new taxes and also to give the state's school districts more than $200million in additional aid.

title: Sutton Hurt, Marshall Saves Dodgers
description: Don Sutton and Mike Marshall, named to the National League AllStar pitching squad earlier in the day by their manager Walter Alston, combined on a fourhitter to live the Los Angeles Dodgers a 3.0 victory over the Pirates in Three Rivers Stadium last night.

title: Brooklyn Grocer Wins New Trial On Drag Charges
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has ordered a new trial for an East New York grocer convicted on drug charges declaring the credibility of the major Government witness in doubt. According to the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, a police informant gave the authorities the information that led to the conviction of the grocer, Robert Vasquez, 34 years old, of 620 East 51st Street on a charge of criminal possession of a dangerous drug.

title: Rail Safety Bill Passed
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The Senate sent to President Ford today a, bill to authorize $52.5Million for continuing the Govehment's railroad safety programs in the next year. The measure would also authorize 150 additional Federal safety inspectors, raising the total to 500.

title: New Museum Traces Black Stage History
description: A worndown black shoe with wooden taps on the heel and toe that belonged to John Bubbles when he danced with Judy Garland at the Palace . . .

title: Carnoustie Tough Golf Test
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 8The greats of golf begin play tomorrow in the 104th British Open, last held on this tiger of a course in 1968 when Gary Player got around in 289 shots, the highest Open score in the last 28 years.

title: 2 Students Set Up a Sidewalk Clinic
description: Two young men wearing white jackets and holding stethoscopes set up a specialized practice on Fifth Avenue and 53d Street yesterday with a card table, a little black bag and a pail for contributions.

title: Market Place
description: Some purchasers of municipal bonds, alarmed by the plight of the nation's cities, are turning to hospital bonds for taxexempt income.

title: Kissinger Assures Panama He Seeks Solution on Canal
description: PANAMA, July 8 (Reuters)Secretary of State Kissinger has told Panama that he will not give up the search for a solution to their differences over the Panama Canal, it was announced here today.

title: TV Season Will Offer 70 Series, Few New Faces
description: With summer comes the selling of the new television season. Now begins the flood tide of promotional spots: Welcome to the bright new world of ABC, Catch the brightest stars on CBS, Superseason on NBCyou're gonna like it a lot.

title: Coal Company Fined
description: CATLETTSBURG, Ky., July 8 (AP)A Federal judge has levied fines totaling $122,000 against the operators of a Ryden (Ky.) coal mine for safety violations that occurred a week before an explosion that claimed the lives of 38 miners. Charles Finley and the Finley Coal Company were fined yesterday in United States District Court on three counts of violating Federal mine safety laws, The company was also fined on a fourth count involving willful misuse of explosives.

title: MetroGoldwynMayer Registers Gains in Revenues and Profit; Other Companies Report
Postal Service Questions A.M.A. on Its CutRate Mail
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The United States Postal Service is investigating the American Medical Association to determine whether its journal should lose a special mailing rate because of the activities of its political arm.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: China Completes Pipeline
description: TOKYO, July 8 (AP)A 221mile oil pipeline has been completed from the North China port of Chinhuangtao to Peking, the official Hsinhua news agency reported today. Hsinhua said it is part of a 937mile pipeline from the Taching oil field in northeast China.

title: The Collected Political Letters of Martin Bear
description: Martin Bear, a nineyearold who lives in San Francisco, spent a few months recently with a relative in New York who describes him as an exuberant political novice. While here, Martin sent a number of letters to officeholders in Washington. Those letters and excerpted replies appear below.

title: BEAME DISPUTED ON JOB VACANCIES
description: A Federal Labor Department official yesterday questioned whether the city had the estimated total of 1,500 to 2,000 vacancies in the Federal public employment program Mayor Beame had said would be used to rehire some dismissed city workers.

title: ACCORD ANNOUNCED IN WORST AIR CRASH
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8 (UPI) A settlement on general damages was announced today in billiondollar lawsuits based on the crash of a Turkish airlines DC10 in France a year ago, the worst air crash in history.

title: Compromise Is Hinted On Issue of Oil Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, July 8A key Republican Congressman, Clarence J. Brown of Ohio. suggested today that President Ford might cut in half his fee of $2 a barrel on imported crude oil if he and Congressional Democrats could agree on a formula for gradual decontrol of domestic crude oil prices.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 9, 1975

title: JERSEY WILL CUT RAILBUS SUBSIDIES
description: TRENTON, July 8  State Transportation officials today announced plans for a sharply reduced rail and bus subsidy program by the state that could eliminate service for tens of thousands of commuters and result in higher fares for thousands of others.

title: Volkswagen Tells Stockholders Company May Make Profit in 1976
description: BONN, July 8  Toni Schmcker, managing director of Volkswagenwerk, A.G., said today at a stormy meeting of shareholders in Wolfsburg, West Germany, that recent actions to steer the automobile manufacturer back to financial health were taking effect. He said that, although he hoped it could report a profit for 1976, he expected the company to have another loss this year.

title: Critic's Notebook: Measuring the Intensity of Concert Applause
description: If everyone could agree beforehand that the results were essentially meaningless, wouldn't it be fascinating to apply a decibel meter to concert and recital audiences throughout one whole season? The urge to measure the immeasurable, to try to take accurate soundings of unfathomable depths, does exert its pull in our quantifying age. Here, just for fun, is one constant listener's guess as to what such a decibel count might show.

title: Hamilton M. Warren, 77, Dies; Union Carbide Sales Executive
description: Hamilton M. Warren, a retired vice president of sales and advertising of the National Carbon Company, a former division of the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: Miners' Vote Aids Wilson In Fight to Curb Inflation
description: SCARBOROUGH, England, July 8Prime Minister Harold Wilson's efforts to control Britain's soaring inflation made progess today when mineworkers voted against demanding an immediate 60 per cent wage increase in next winter's round of negotiations.

title: Article 1  No Title
Barger, Executive of News, Will Retire at End of Month
description: Floyd Barger, editor and senior vice president of The Daily News, will retire on Aug. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: State Layoffs Can Lead to Bumpings
description: TRENTON, July 8Layoff notices now being delivered to thousands of state employes will result in a chain reaction of bumpings of less senior employes in jobs governed by Civil Service regulations, state officials said today.

title: Grain Inspectors' Group Terms Supervision by U.S. Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, July 8A spokesman for a national grain inspectors' group told a Senate hearing today that a lack of adequate Federal supervision was responsible for the grain export industry's problems, but he opposed having the Federal Government take over the inspection.

title: Chinese Crop Expected To Equal Last Year's
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) China is expected to have a good harvest this year, Congress was told today, one as good as last year, when 255 million tons of foodgrains were produced.
