title: Robber's Wife Helps Him Flee Paris Courtroom
description: PARIS, July 8, (Reuters)A convicted robber escaped today during his trial in a Paris criminal court when his wife, disguised in lawyers' robes, handed him a revolver and then brandished a hand grenade, the police said.

title: Odds Against Repealing of OTB Surtax
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation's campaign to remove the 5 per cent surtax on payoffs moved forward yesterday when the City Council approved the necessary homerule message to enable the State Legislature to consider a repeal measure.

title: Miners' Vote Aids Wilson In Fight to Curb Inflation
description: SCARBOROUGH, England, July 8Prime Minister Harold Wilson's efforts to control Britain's soaring inflation made progess today when mineworkers voted against demanding an immediate 60 per cent wage increase in next winter's round of negotiations.

title: Wartime Security Measures Are Augmented in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, July 9 (AP)Three controversial wartime security bills were passed by the South Korean National Assembly before dawn today.

title: SYRIA OUSTS IRAQI AS RIFT WORSENS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 8The Syrian Government today ordered Iraq's military attache and his staff to leave Damascus in 48 hours, deepening a political quarrel between the two countries.

title: Young Germans Say Time Has Come For More Normal Ties With Israel
description: BONN, July 8Premier Yitzhak Rabin's visit to West Germany is, from the German point of view, a turning point.

title: Another Ruffian on Way?
description: PARIS, Ky., July 8 (AP)A full brother or sister to Ruffian will be foaled next year, but the Claiborne Farm master, Seth Hancock, says it just won't be the same.

title: Corn, Soybean and Wheat Prices in Chicago Climb
description: Amid reports that the Soviet Union is about to buy grains in the United States, prices for wheat, corn and soybeans jumped by their daily permissible limits yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: In Memoriam
description: ROSENBERGBill, Darling you were always thee sunshine of my life. We will miss you forever. 793.

title: Gandhi Opponent in 1971 Asks Further Court Action
description: NEW DELHI, July 8The obscure country politician whose lawsuit against Prime Minister Indira. Gandhi touched off India's political crisis filed an appeal in the Supreme Court here today, seeking additional judgments against her.

title: Miami Archdiocese Denies Chancellor Wrote About Cuban
description: MIAMI, July 8The Roman Catholic archdiocese of Miami said today that its chancellor. Msgr. Noel Fogarty, had neither written nor signed a letter criticizing a young dissident Cuban priest who left the area in a dispute over the policy of the archdiocese toward Hispanic priests.

title: A Glance at Noteworthy Shows
description: A sampling of the opinion of network officials, advertising agency executives, station operators and critics has found the following to be the new season's noteworthy entries:

title: $20Million Refunds Due For Drug Overcharges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 8Nearly a million citizens in six states will receive over $20million in refunds this week as a result of legal action begun over 20 years ago charging that drug companies had overcharged consumers.

title: Albany Sees Adjournment Ahead
description: ALBANY, July 8Never mind the passage today of the raucously negotiated package on the New York City fiscal crisis. There is a whole faction of political observers who feel that the 1975 legislative session really is going to end this week because the Bleecker Bar, a nocturnal haunt of legislators, just closed for vacation and the Metropolitan drycleaning store will shut this Friday for a rest. Without enough clothes and refreshment within a beeline of the Capitol, this irreverent theory goes, it becomes pointless to extend thii year's experiment in selfgovernment.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Sturgeon Are Returning to the Hudson
description: The sturgeonlong thought to be almost extinct in waters around New York City is apparently thriving in the Hudson River in such numbers that it would appear to offer a potentially large source of proteinrich food in sturgeon steaks and the possibility that New York may once again become a major exporter of caviar.

title: Blast Hits Basque Building
description: HENDAYE, France, July 8 (Reuters)  An explosion today blew out the doors and windows of a building housing Basque political refugees. No one was injured. The building also housed the office of Benito Del Valle, one of the founders of the Basque separatist movement E.T.A., who left the organization in 1967.

title: GIFTS ARE OPPOSED FOR CONVENTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Federal Election Commission was urged today to bar political parties from accepting halls, security guards and transportation for national conventions that are paid for by private business interests.

title: PETER M. M'GAVIN
description: Peter M. McGavin, executive secretary treasurer of the A.F.L.C.I.O. Maritime Trades Department, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 66 years old.

title: Marijuana Study by U.S. Finds No Serious Harm
description: A federally contracted study of marijuana smoking in Jamaica, where the consumption by heavy users is said to be 10 to 25 times that of their American counterparts, has failed to confirm any serious adverse effects.

title: Personal Finance: MarriedCouple Business Deals
description: Business transactions between husbands and wives receive extremely close scrutiny from the Internal Revenue Service on the ground that they may be attempting to evade income taxes.

title: Rabin Says 3 Key Issues Remain for Sinai Accord
description: BONN, July 9Premier Yitzak Rabin of Israel said today that differences remained to be resolved with Egypt on three key issuest before a new Sinai disengagement accord could be concluded.

title: 2 CORRECTION AIDES AMONG 13 INDICTED
description: Thirteen men, including two employes of the State Department of Correctional Services, were indicted yesterday on charges ranging from loansharking to kidnapping to tampering with the state parole system, according to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The director of the State Division of Weights and Measures reported in Trenton that on the first day of an enforcement campaign on the Jersey Shore, inspectors filed citations for 60 violations. The director, William J. Wolf Sr., said the special enforcement program was being carried out in supermarkets, at gasoline stations and at roadside produce stands as a consumer protection measure during the summer. He said there were plans to expand the steppedup weights and measures enforcement program into mountain and lake resorts.

title: Onegin for Bolshoi Matinee
description: Tchaikovsky's Eugene Onegin will replace Prokofiev's The Gambler as this Saturday's matinee of the Bolshoi Opera. Ticket holders for The Gambler on that day may either use them for Eugene Onegin or turn them in for refunds at the box office or by mail, it was announced by Hurok Concerts, which is presenting the company here. The Onegin cast will include Nina Lebedeva as Tatiana, Aleksel Maslennlkov as Lensid, Andrei Fedoseyev as Onegin, and Aleksandr Ognitsev as Gremin. Fuat Mansurov will conduct.

title: Public vs. Private Collection of Refuse: In Some Cities, It's No Longer a Debate
description: In San Francisco, where private carters pick up all the trash, S. M. Tatarian, the director of the Public Works Department, which is charged With keeping the city's streets clean, says: I shudder to think of what would happen if my department was responsible for collecting garbage.

title: Notes on People
description: Some historic mid19th century wallpaper depicting battle scenes from the American Revolution, installed in the White House in 1961 by Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis when she was First Lady, has been removed from the family dining room on orders from Betty Ford, who found the wallpaper kind of depressing.

title: TAX HEARING STIRS HEATED DEBATES
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 9Tempers flared, and debate sometimes turned to sarcasm today. as a special state legislative emergency committee sounded out the views of the publicfrom bankers to politicians to educators to elderly retired citizenson new taxes necessary to close a $384million state budget gap.

title: 15 Vietnamese Exchange Students Stranded
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I., July 9 The buses roared off today with 2,600 foreign students, waving and cheering and crying, on their way home. But 15 South Vietnamese students stayed behind in a country they had never planned to make their own.

title: GASOLINE SUPPLY IS DOWN SHARPLY
description: Supplies of gasoline in the United States fell sharply last week despite an increase in output by the nation's refiners. Consumer demand appeared to be outdistancing attempts to prevent spot shortages of motor fuel this summer.

title: Indian Sought by F.B.I. Surrenders in Dakota
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., July 9 (AP) The last of four persons who were being sought by two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation when the agents were gunned down on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation has surrendered to authorities.

title: Thai Reports Mao Thinks Well of Nixon And Defends Taping
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 9 (AP)Mao Tsetung still thinks well of former President Richard M. Nixon and says the Watergate scandal was the result of too much freedom of political expression in the United States, Premier Kukrit Pramoj reports.

title: GRANT SALES DOWN 14.5% IN 4 WEEKS
description: The W. T. Grant Company announced yesterday that its sales in the four weeks ended July 3 dropped 14.5 per cent to $120.2million from $140.7million in the same 1974 months.

title: Opera: War and Peace
description: On the face of things, Prokofiev's War and Peace cannot fail to make an ovelwhelming impact. The composer has turned out to be one of the most popular in 20thcentury music. The score combines lyricism with spectacular set pieces, such as the burning of Moscow. The stage is thronged with heroes and villains, including Napoleon and Marshal Kutuzov. Behind it all is the Tolstoy novel and its epic sweep.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: The Boonkers and Burns of Carnoustie
description: The charm of Carnoustie is its treachery. Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player call the site of the British Open the toughest golf course in the world, which is indictment enough. Not that they discovered its deception. Horton Smith, a Masters champion of another era, once hit what he thought. was a perfect drive on the par4 second hole.

title: Syce Cup Won By Mrs. Comfort
description: RYE, N.Y., July 9Mrs. Lyn Comfort, taking over as helmswoman when a fivetime former winner suffered a heart attack and had to be hospitalized, won the 42d annual women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound for the Syce Cup today at the American Yacht Club.

title: HOSPITAL PLANS MANY DISMISSALS
description: Roosevelt Hospital disclosed plans yesterday to lay off 10 per cent of its 2,400 employes during July and August because of a very bad financial situation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Army Corps of Engineers said that a recent study indicated that benefits of the proposed Tocks Island dam on the Delaware River outweighed adverse environmental impact. The study recommended that construction of the longdelayed dam begin promptly unless the Delaware River Basin Commission objected. If the commission objects, the study added, the Corps should take away the authorization for the $400million project so that alternative plans to meet the needs of the region may be developed.

title: RUMANIAN TRADE GAINS IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Congressional committees moved today to grant trade benefits to Rumania after having heard testimony that the Bucharest Government was making it easier for citizens to emigrate.

title: Millions in Medicare Fraud Unrecoverable
description: Because of the expiration of the civil and criminal statutes of limitations, the Federal Government is unable to collect millions of dollars of overpayments of Medicare funds to nursing homes or to prosecute operators for an unknown number of frauds.

title: Turks Get Soviet Credit
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 9 (Reuters)Turkey and the Soviet Union today signed a $700million credit deal. Under the accord, Soviet parts and machinery will be supplied for an expansion of the Iskenderun steel plant, for an aluminum plant and for two thermal power stations.

title: CBS, Inc., Earnings Rise 15.7% to Reach Record in Quarter
description: CBS, Inc., achieved record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended with June, with broadcasting and recorded music businesses contributing the major gains, William S Paley. chairm'n, and Arthur R. Taylor, president, reported yesterday.

title: Fingerprints Bring Arrest In Assault on a Woman, 85
description: Ten months ago, the police said, two young men pushed 85yearold Rose Wilson into her Bronx apartment, slipped a pillow case over her head, bound her hands and feet, punched her several times, took $275 from a small metal strong box, turned on the gas jets on her stove and fled.

title: BYRNE PLANS VETO OF SALESTAX RISE
description: TRENTON, July 9Governor Byrne said today that he would veto an increase in the state sales tax if it was enacted alone by the State Legislature or as the centerpiece of a nuisancetax package designed to restore $384million in budget cuts made by the Governor to balance the current state budget.

title: CLOSURE REJECTED AGAIN BY SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) For the fifth time, the Senate rejected today a Democratic move to shut off debate on the contested New Hampshire seat.

title: A Teaneck Boy,17, Is Held in Murder Of Woman Neighbor
description: The 17yearold Teaneck High School student who was arrested Tuesday night after the police alleged he had fatally shot a 22yearold daughter of a neighbor, was given a preliminary hearing in Bergen County Juvenile Court yesterday and will be arraigned before Judge Charles DiGisi there tomorrow.

title: FORMULA ON SINAI UNDER DISCUSSION BY U.S. AND ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The United States and Israel were reported today to be working on a formula to break the deadlocked EgyptianIsraeli negotiations and to solve a controversy over whether Israeli forces should completely evacuate two strategic Sinai passes as part of an agreement.

title: Solzhenitsyn, in City, Warns of Soviet Danger
description: A great writer, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn wrote in his novel The First Circle, is, so to speak, a second government of his country. It was as the exiled voice of the second government of his native Russia that the Nobel Prizewinning novelist and political dissident spoke in New York yesterday, calling upon the American people to understand the worldwide, danger that Soviet power poses to their own freedom and security.

title: PORTUGAL PLANS TO BYPASS PARTIES
description: LISBON, July 9Portugal's military rulers, decided today to give the people a direct role In government that would by pass the political parties.

title: Panamanian Vietnam?
description: The House vote to bar the use of funds for negotiation of a new Panama Canal treaty involving the surrender or relinquishment of United States rights is an invitation to disaster. Secretary Kissinger's letter to Panama's leader, General Torrijos Herrera, indicates that the Ford Administration properly will reject this affront to the President's constitutional power to make treaties and the Senate's exclusive mandate to approve them. But the unrest stirred in Panama by the House voteand endorsement by more than onethird of the Senate of a resolution opposing the treaty revision negotiationsrecalls a recent warning from Ellsworth Bunker, former Ambassador Vietnam, who has been directing the Panama negotiations for almost two years.

title: ClevelandCliffs Iron Raises Price of Ore Pellets by 4%
description: The ClevelandCliffs Iron Company increased yesterday its price of iron ore pellets by 4 per cent.

title: Judge Frees Man Convicted on a Bomb Charge
description: Carlos Feliciano, a selfdescribed Puerto Rican Nationalist convicted of bomb charges 21 months ago; was set free yesterday.

title: Ray Bolger, at 71, Still Fast on His Feet
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9Gentlemen, Mr. Ray Bolger, Marvin Hamlisch, the composer, said, and musicians in the pit of Lindy's Opera House burst into applause.

title: One Killed and 20 Injured as Bulls Charge Crowd at Pamplona Festival
description: PAMPLONA, Spain, July 9 (UPI)Eight fighting bulls charged into the crowd in the street at Spain's most famous fiesta today, killing one person and injuring 20, including at least five young Americans.

title: ECUADOR PLANS CUT IN OIL PRICE OF 43C
description: QUITO, Ecuador, July 9 (UPI)Ecuador, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, cut oil prices by 43 cents per barrel today.

title: State Suburbs Face Rise in School Tax
description: Because of a combination of actions in Albany and local decisions not to reduce levels of school spending, residents of suburban areas face substantial schooltax rises this year20 per cent and more in some areas.

title: CORPORATE BONDS SHOW FIRM TREND
description: Prices of recently issued new corporate obligations firmed in late trading yesterday after a syndicate led by Blyth Eastman Dillon tentatively priced an offering of $300million of Standard Oil of California 30year, tripleA rated debentures. The issue carries an 8 per cent coupon at 99 to yield 8.833 per cent.

title: 'World's Young Ballet,' '69 Competition
description: "The World's Young Ballet," the Russian documentary that opened at the Bijou yesterday, is a vivid, if black-and-white, illustration of artistry that ignores geographical boundaries. Although this record of the 1969 ballet competition in Moscow's Bolshoi Theater that drew entries from 20 countries is fragmentary, it projects striking impressions of the talent of potential heirs to the golden slippers of even the likes of Rudolf Nureyev and Dame Margot Fonteyn.If they haven't reached the magnitude of such stars, some appear to be on their way. Mikhail Baryshnikov, who, of course, has since defected and is now with the American Ballet Theater, is eye-catching as a dancer and actor in his award-winning performance in "Vestris." And Japan's Fukagawa seems to be his strong competitor in fluid leaps and turns.While there is a mere glimpse of Helgi Tomasson, the American entrant now with the New York City Ballet, the film's international cast is ably represented. Ludmila Semenyaka, a petite ballerina from Leningrad, shows versatility in a gold-medal stint in both "Giselle" and in "We," a charming pas de deux in modern, jazz style. France's Francesca Zumbo and Patrice Bart combine difficult Indian, modern and classical idioms in Maurice Bejart's "Bakti." And Cuba's Loipa Araujo and her Russian partner, Azari Pliset-sky, delicately glide through the classic, if standard, "Swan Lake" pas de deux.If the long parade of dancers is a mite confusing, Boris Lvov-Anokhin's American-accented narration is helpful. And a viewer is given some offstage peeks at rehearsals, at the judges including the famed retired prima ballerina Galina Ulanova and such activities as anxious competitors in the wings and a tour of Leningrad's ballet school.This "Ballet" is, of course, largely for special tastes. But even if Arkadi Tsineman's direction is somewhat disjointed and weighted in favor of the Soviet contingent, his documentation, even in excerpts, is captivating proof of the worldwide wealth of dedicated dancers.

title: Ford Endorses Bill to Ease Arms Embargo on Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 President Ford today accepted a compromise with Congress for a partial lifting of the fivemonthold United States embargo on arms aid to Turkey.

title: 'Shoot It' and 'Super Spook' Open
description: As disparate approaches to seriousness and clownish crime and punishment, respectively, "Shoot It: Black Shoot It: Blue" and "Super Spook," the double bill that arrived at local houses yesterday, rate high for their cooperative, independent efforts. But if the good intentions of both troupes are obvious, the results are varying disappointments.Call "Super Spook" a good deal less than persuasive as comedy or a lampoon of the black private-eye movie. Filmed in Harlem by a black team headed by Anthony Major, director, these antics are slavishly dedicated to the crack, "If 'Shaft' can't, 'Hammer' won't, the 'Spook' will," delivered by Leonard Jackson, as its fumbling, titular sleuth. He's a good-natured buffoon, as are the others in an athletic cast, including Bill Jay, the lover-bad guy who rips off, a numbers bag woman. But their genial, raunchy, muscular capers quickly become as tiringly repetitious as a succession of burlesque skits they seem to resemble.No comparisons are intended but "Shoot It" is, naturally, stern, often provocative fare. In tackling the cold-blooded killing of a black mugger by a white policeman, director - writer Dennis McGuire, who shot the feature in and around Kansas City, is perhaps too perplexingly involved with racial antagonisms, clashing personalities and a young, black film student who has surreptitiously recorded the Crime and ensuing events in a movie to be used in a $1-million suit against the errant policeman.If the principals and their dialogue are naturalistic, their drives and character are, on occasion, shadowy and unconvincing. Among them are Linda Scruggs, as a rich flower girl who denounces our harried hero after a desultory affair, Eric Laneuville, as his young moviemaker-nemeses, and Paul Sorvino, as the square, white lawyer handling the case for the slain man's widow.However, Michael Moriarty (following such fine roles as those in "Bang the Drum Slowly" and the Tony Award-winning stint in "Find Your Way Home") gives a realistically underplayed performance as the handsome but biased and beleaguered, ill-fated policeman gnawed by rising doubts and guilt. If the somewhat ill-defined causes, effects and points of view tend to flaw "Shoot It," it nevertheless emerges as provocative, if not fully satisfying social melodrama.

title: Streaking Tigers Capture 8th in Row
description: With the help of Bill Freehan's threerun homer, the Detroit Tigers won their eighth straight game last night by beating the Chicago White Sox, 62, in Tiger Stadium.

title: Jury for Forbes Told of Threat
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 9 (AP)Dave Forbes, the Boston Bruins hockey player, definitely went out of his way to get Henry Boucha, former Minnesota North Stars player, during a National Hockey League game last Jan. 4, the Hennepin County Attorney argued today.

title: Family Plans to Sue C.I.A. Over Suicide in Drug Test
description: FREDERICK, Md., July 9The widow and children of a researcher who committed suicide in 1953 after being made an unwitting participant in a Central Intelligence Agency drug experiment said today that they planned to sue the agency over his wrongful death.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: School Board Head Scores Mayor's Fiscal Priorities
description: Isaiah E. Robinson Jr., who was sworn in only a week ago as Board a Education president assailed Mayor Beame yesterday for having succumbed to what he termed coercive threats from carpetbaggers working in the uniformed services for the restoration of budget cuts.

title: Kart Brandt, Economic Adviser On President's Council, Is Dead
description: Dr. Karl Brandt, who served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers from 1958 to 1961, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: File Said to Indicate C.I.A. Had a Man in White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The staff director of the House Select Committee on Intelligence has seen documents indicating that a highlevel member of the Nixon White House staff was reporting to the Central Intelligence Agency on activities in and around the Oval Office, according to a source close to the committee's investigation.

title: Arabs and Africans Open Cairo Talks on Closer Ties
description: CAIRO, July 9 (UPI)Foreign ministers or their representatives from 12 African and 12 Arab countries met today to prepare a draft declaration on principles and guidelines for closer ties.

title: Staub Homer in 10th Decides
description: ATLANTA, July 9Rusty Staub, who says it's always nice to do something to help the team, hit a home run in the 10th inning at friendly Atlanta Stadium tonight to lift the Mets to a 21 victory over the Braves.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Cosmos 31 Victors Before 18,126 Here
description: After a halftime lecture by Coach Gordon Bradley, the New York Cosmos scored three goals last night to defeat the Boston Minutemen, 31, and take first place in the North American Soccer League's Northern Division.

title: Europe in Black Light
description: BELGRADE, YugoslaviaFlick on a black light and take a different look at the play of power in Europe. Set aside national boundaries and standard animosities to view, in black light, the changing relationship of the Communist parties of East and West.

title: House Education Panel Rebuffs Efforts to Curb Sex Bias Rules
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The House Education and Labor Committee turned back today efforts by some of its members to dismantle the school sex discrimination regulations that have been written by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and signed by President Ford.

title: East German Farmers Hard Hit by Drought
description: BERLIN, July 9East German farmers have started emergency harvesting on some of their scorched, sandy fields to save at least part of their crops endangered by severe drought.

title: ASHLAND EMPLOYE HELD EXC.I.A. SPY
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Ashland Oil, Inc., permitted a spy from the Central Intelligence Agency to operate in Western Europe for some five years as an official of the company, authoritative sources said today.

title: Carey Fills Labor Department Job
description: Governor Carey yesterday named G. Douglas Pugh, a 51yearold laborrelations specialist with a background in minority affairs, as the No. 2 man in the State Labor Department.

title: 4 Reds, 3 Dodgers AllStar Starters
description: For the third consecutive year, Johnny Bench of the Cincinnati Reds was the leading votegetter for the National League AllStar team, this year drawing 2,930,147 votes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JULY 10, 1975

title: Argentina, in Respite From Political Crisis, arks Independence
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 9President Isabel Martinez de Pern enjoyed a brief respite today from the political crisis that has shaken the Government, as Argentina observed the 159th anniversary of her independence.

title: Stock Prices Show 14.08 Gain on Dow
description: The stock market moved out of the doldrums yesterday and posted a gain of 14.08 points.

title: The Teller Of Truth
description: Last Dec. 22 The New York Times published a story by Seymour M. Hersh saying that the Central Intelligence Agency had conducted a massive illegal domestic intelligence operation. The story created a great stir, leading to Congressional and Executive investigations of the C.I.A. But it also aroused extraordinarily sharp attacks on Mr. Hersh and The Times, and not only from the predictable right.

title: Evolution Theory Still Disputed 50 Years After Monkey Trial
description: DAYTON, Tenn., July 8Fifty years agoon July 10, 1925in this languid little town in the Cumberland Hills, William Jennings Bryan and Clarence Darrow faced each other on the opening day of the celebrated trial of John T. Scopes, a young Dayton teacher accused of the crime of expounding in school Darwin's theory of evolution.

title: Article 2  No Title
British Union Chiefs Bach Curbs on Wage Increases
description: LONDON, July 9  British trade union leaders today supported Prime Minister Harold Wilson's efforts to curb inflation by voting in favor of limiting wage increases.

title: Court in Lesotho Convicts 18 of AntiGovernment Plot
description: MASERU, Lesotho, July 9 (AP)Eighteen supporters of the opposition Basutoland Congress party were found guilty of treason in the Lesotho High Court today. The charges involved a reported conspiracy to overthrow the Government of Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan a year and a half ago.

title: China, GuineaBissau Pact
description: HONG KONG, July 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  China and GuineaBissau signed an economic and technical cooperation agreement today in Peking, it was reported by Hsin Pua, the official press agency.

title: Whitlam Discloses A Search for Loans From Arab Agents
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 9 (UPI)Prime Minister Gough Whitlam said at an emergency session of Parliament today that his Labor Government had sought a $4billion loan from unofficial Arab sources partly to nationalize and develop Australia's vast energy resources.

title: Housing Chief Guarded After Reporting Bribe
description: JERSEY CITY, July 9 (UPI) Neil S. Piro, executive director of the Jersey City Housing Authority, has been placed under protective custody after telling authorities he was offered a bribe.

title: BEAM SUSPENDS SUMMER HOURS FOR 100,000 HERE
description: Mayor Beame, asserting that the shortened hours of the city's summer work schedule were indefensible to maintain because of the budgetary crisis and the large number of city layoffs, last night ordered summer hours suspended for 100,000 workers.

title: A New, GungHo justice Official
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 He has not always been a quiet man but he has been an effective one. So, with characteristic understatement, Attorney General Edward H. Levi spoke yesterday of Richard L. Thornburgh, to whom he moments later administered the oath as head of the Justice Department's Criminal Division.

title: New Saudi Budget a Record, With $6.5Billion for Defense
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 9 (Reuters)King Khalid of Saudi Arabia announced today a record budget for the fiscal year beginning tomorrow, and declared that about a fifth of it would be spent on defense.

title: STATE SEEKS CUTS IN MEDICAID COSTS
description: TRENTON, July 9Reductions in Medicaid costs totaling $15.3million would be implemented later this summer by cutting back physician fees and requiring New Jersey's 600,000 recipients to pay more, according to a plan proposed today by Ann Klein, the Institutions and Agency Commissioner.

title: Lynn Paces Regatta for Youngsters
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 9 A fleet of 222 boats competed in the 30th annual New York Yacht Club junior regetta here today. Over 500 sailors aged 13 through 17 raced in Fireballs and Blue Jays.

title: U.S. Embassy Aruiex in Nigeria Seized Briefly in Lease Dispute
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 9 (AP)  A dozen armed Nigerian troops seized the grounds of a united States Embassy annex early today in a bid to force the Americans out, then withdrew after 22 hours.

title: WIRETAP DISPUTE WIDENS IN TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, July 9A Federal grand jury investigating charges of widespread illegal telephone wiretapping by the Houston police will reconvene here tomorrow, 13 days after the abrupt resignation of Houston's chief of police.

title: THE LEADERS
description: FIREBALLS, OddNumbered Sails1, Craig Sinclair; 2, Stewart Neff; 3, Peter Hinrichs; 4, Chris Danilek; 5, Robert GentWinger.

title: Vote Pushes Lutherans Closer to an Open Schism
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 9The 51st convention of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod moved to the brink of open schism today by passing a resolution that could remove from office eight district presidents accused of breaking church law.

title: About the Yankees
description: Billy Martin, the Rangers' outspoken manager, will have a chance to play in the Yankees' OldTimers Game Rug. 2 after all. Martin was upset because he didn't receive an invitation to the game, but the Yankees extended one last night. The game will honor the eight pennantwinning Yankee teams of the 1950's. . . . Yankees will give away batting gloves to children 14 and under before Sunday's game with Minnesota. . . . Largest attendance increasa in the majorsabout 250,000belongs to Yankees. They went over 700,000 mark last night on 35th Shea date. That total wasn't reached last year until 46th date.

title: International Paper's Earnings Decline 37.2% in Second Quarter
Public vs. Private Collection of Refuse: In Some Cities, It's No Longer a Debate
description: In San Francisco, where private carters pick up all the trash, S. M. Tatarian, the director of the Public Works Department, which is charged with keeping the city's streets clean, says: I shudder to think of what would happen if my department was responsible for collecting garbage.

title: GIFTS TO PARTIES BACKED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON. July 9The Federal Election Commission, rejecting more rigorous limits on political conventions, tonight handed down regulations that will permit the Republican an Democratic parties to continue to accept many of the free services that have been provided for their conventions in the past.

title: South Vietnamese Are Said to Pledge Religious Freedom
description: HONG KONG, July 9 (AP)The new Communist Government of South Vietnam has reaffirmed its determination to uphold religious freedom, Hanoi's official Vietnam News Agency reported today.

title: Jobless Suspect Said to Confess To Central Park HoldupKilling
description: A 26yearold unemployed man was arrested last night and charged with the robbery and stabbing Monday night in Central Park of Victor Lane, 70, a retired autocompany executive.

title: A. C. L. U. Study Finds Wide Easing of Job Bias Against Homosexuals
description: The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday reported widespread easing of job discrimination against homosexuals at Federal, state and municipal levels.

title: BEAR SUSPENDS SUMMER HOURS FOR 100,000 HERE
description: Mayor Beame, asserting that the shortened hours of the city's summer work schedule were indefensible to maintain because of the budgetary crisis and the large number of city layoffs, last night ordered summer hours suspended for 100,000 workers.

title: Tocks I. Dam Benefits Will Outweigh Any Harm, Says Corps of Engineers
description: EWING TOWNSHIP, N. J., July 9The Army Corps of Engineers said today that recent sutdy indicated that benefits of the proposed Tocks Island dam outweigh adverse environmental impacts and that construction of the longdelayed dam on the the Delaware River at Tocks Island should begin promptly unless the Delaware River Bain Commission objects.

title: Market Place
description: Wall Street shares one curiosity with Main Streetnamely, how rich people invest their money. Some light on this littleresearched subject is shed by a study done by Ira H. Bernstein, an account executive for Oppenheimer & Co.

title: REPORT BY C.I.A. PUZZLES CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 There is growing confusion in Washington over why the Central Intelligence Agency made a midevening release yesterday of its internal report on domestic spying and exactly when President Ford authorized the intelligence agency to make the documents public.

title: Goldin Denies Allegations Of Illegal City Borrowing
description: City Controller Harrison J. Goldin responded to a state audit yesterday by denying that the city had ever borrowed illegally and by asserting that he agreed with the need to overhaul the city's accounting and budgeting systems.

title: Bridge:
description: Ground that other bridge writers fear to tread is favored territory for Robert Ewen, a former New Yorker who now makes his home in Miami. To his two previous books, original and effective treatments of opening leads and doubling, he has now added a third, Preemptive Bidding. This excellent 162page monograph is published by PrenticeHall at $7.95 in hardcover and $3.95 in paperback,

title: Israel Under Pressure
description: Heavy pressure is bearing down upon the Government of Israel to make further concessions toward achieving a new interim agreement with Egypt. Some of this pressure undoubtedly stems from the Ford Administration's desire to further the United States' role as Middle East mediator; but much of it derives from the objective situationeconomic, military and diplomaticin which Israel finds itself today. The psychological and practical consequences of failing to reach a limited accord now must be weighed at least as heavily as the specific military risks of a further Sinai withdrawal.

title: Chess:
description: In end games involving bishops of the same color it is wrong to place the pawns on the same color squares as the bishops. There they are subject to attack by the opponent's bishop and while they may be defended by one's own bishop, the result does not cancel out to equality since there is always the danger of the defender's drifting into a passive position, perhaps into zugswang.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: About Trout
description: LORDVILLE, N.Y.  We crept from our tents after a night of thunderstorms and intermittent rain to be greeted by a brilliant dawn and mist rising from the Delaware River.

title: New Godf ather Part of TV Film Deal
description: Paramount Pictures has leased tothe television networks for about $76million the rights to 42 recent motion pictures, including The Godfather and The Godfather, Part II, in a new treatment that will turn the two movies into a miniature television series.

title: OIL TAKEOVER BILL GAINS IN VENEZUELA
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 9 The Venezuelan Chamber of Deputies tonight approved the most controversial section of a Government bill to nationalize foreignowned oil companies here this year.

title: Democratic Mayors Lose 2 Big Tests as Talks End
description: BOSTON, July 9The Democratic mayors of the nation's biggest, oldest cities were defeated today in a major policy battle with a wellorganized minority of Republican mayors, who were aided by divisions among the Democrats.

title: Military Plot in Macao Thwarted, Lisbon Says
description: LISBON, July 9 (Reuters) A military plot to seize power has been thwarted in the Portuguese enclave of Macao on the coast of China, the Portuguese press agency said today.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Reversing the trend of the previous two sessions, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market climbed sharply yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Books of The Times
description: The hope, naturally, was for a fictional blockbusterthe sort of oldfashioned squarerigged story that transports you out of yourself into a world of the imagination more real than heat, humidity, sanitation strikes and other crises. And James Clavell's latest adventure, Shogun: a Novel of Japan, seemed like the most promising prospect. Three pounds heavy and 800 densely packed pages long (nearly a half  a  million words, by snap calculation), it was easily the biggest book I could find on the fiction shelf. To judge by the commercial success of Mr. Clavell's first two novels, King Rat and TaiPan, it is by an author with a solid track record for yarnspinning. And the storyabout an English ship's pilot who in the year 1600 lands in Japan and gets himself heroically embroiled in a struggle among various warlords for the Shogunate, or military rulership, of the empirewould seem to have everything anyone could possibly ask for in the way of romance, violence, sex, blood, guts, exoticism, violence, suspense, sudden reversals of fortune, violence, or whatever it is one looks for in a novel to transport one away from reality.

title: People and Business
description: Albert Rees, who heads the Council on Wage and Price Stability, said yesterday that he asked and obtained a 30day delay in price increases by major aluminum producers last week in an effort to head off a possible epidemic of price rises.

title: Jenkins Excels for Rangers
description: Opposing batters have hit home runs off Ferguson Jenkins this seasona leagueleading 25 in his first 19 eames to be precise.

title: Ford's '76 Manager Bars Giving Aid to Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, July 9President Ford's new election campaign organization will make no effort to win delegate support for Vice President Rockefeller for the second spot on the 1976 Republican ticket, the President's campaign chairman said today.

title: It's Still Possible to Look Chic on a Shoestring
description: Marion. York loves clothes. Naturally. She's a fashion model. As long as she can remember, she's had the long, rangy body that shows off clothes best Her red hair, which she wears closely cropped, doesn't hurt the effect.

title: Russian Novelist's Travels Across the U. S. Left Fond Impression
description: When Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn accepted the key to the city from Mayor Beame yesterday, in a brief ceremony preceding the novelist's speech at the Americana Hotel, it marked the end of monthlong, crosscountry travels that took him from Russian colonies in Alaska and Oregon and the campus of Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., to the Lincoln Memorial in Washington and the Virginia countryside, with visits to the Middle West heartland, as he called it, along the way.

title: Being a Mayor in Algeria Is No Easy Job for a Woman
description: ALGIERS  Rabia Ferhat, an energetic 33yearold,. has four children, is a school teacher and runs the local branch of the Algerian National Women's Union in the little market town of Hamadia. On March 30 she was elected president of the Hamedia Popular Communal Assembly, roughly equivalent to a New England town council, the first time a woman has been elected to this position in Algeria. For the com ing five years Mrs. Ferhat will be the administrative head of Hamadia, center of a farming community on the windswept Sersou high plains, about 160 miles southwest of Algiers.

title: Alleged Mafia Man Is Sought as Leader In Postal Robbery
description: An alleged member of the Joseph Colombo Mafia family was being sought yesterday by Federal authorities and the police as the leader of four armed men who held up the Times Square Post Office at 340 West 42d Street in May and fled with 11 mail sacks containing about $300,000 worth of valuables.

title: Health Institute Gives Guideline On Behavior Modification Issue
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The National Institute of Mental Health issued today the Federal Government's first policy position on the issue of behavior modification, stating that the technique is worthwhile in treating some ailments, but must be used with caution, heeding the legal rights of subjects.

title: School Board Head Scores Mayor's Fiscal Priorities
description: Isaiah E. Robinson Jr.,, who was sworn in only a week ago as Board of Education president assailed Mayor Beame yesterday for having succumbed to what he termed coercive threats from carpetbaggers working in the uniformed services for the restoration of budget cuts.

title: Solzhenitsyn in City, Warns of Soviet Danger
description: A great writer, Aleksandr I. Splzhenitsyn wrote in his novel The First Circle, is, so to speak, a second government of his country. It was as the exiled voice of the second government of his native Russia that the Nobel Prizewinning novelist and political dissident spoke in New York yesterday, calling upon the American people to understand the worldwide danger that Soviet power poses to their own freedom and security.

title: 4 MIDWEST STATES HIT BY EARTHQUAKE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 9 (AP) Books fell off shelves, buildings shook and swayed and office workers were startled today as an earthquake of moderate force shook a 60,000squaremile area of four states in the Middle West.

title: In Memoriam
description: BESOZZJewel (nee Farrington), July 10th. ist anniversary in loving memory of my dear sister. BROTHER PARNELL

title: Daddy Tucked the Blanket Around Mama's Shoulders. Tears Were Dropping Off His Cheeks.
description: MONTGOMERY, ALA. About the time I turned 16, my folks began to wonder why I didn't stay home any more. I always had an excuse for them, but what I didn't say was that I had found my freedom and I was getting out.

title: LOG CABIN BUILDER WINS PERMIT FIGHT
description: ARLINGTON, Wash., July 9O. C. Helton, 39 years old, of nearby Darrington, won a court battle last night that may enable him to finish the log cabin that he is building with the technique taught to him by his grandfather.

title: DR. ROBERT COLLINS
description: Dr. Robert Collins, assistant professor of modern language at Fordham University, died Sunday. He was 64 years old and lived in Lynbrook, L.I.

title: Ford Motor Kept Warranty Program On Rust a Secret
description: DETROIT, July 9 (AP)The Ford Motor Company said today that it had repaired rust damage to 69,000 cars and trucks under a previously secret rust warranty program covering 12 million Ford vehicles built between 1969 and 1972.

title: Jockey Dies of Injuries
description: OMAHA, Neb., July 9 (AP) Mike Phelps, a 22yearold jockey from Sioux Falls, S.D., who was critically injured in a racing mishap at AkSarBen on June 18, died today in a hospital here. He suffered a broken leg, fractured ribs and internal injuries. Last Saturday doctors amputated Phelps's left leg below the knee, after gangrene set in.

title: Russian Novelist's Travels Across the U. S. Left Fond Impression
description: When Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn accepted the key to the city from Mayor Beame yesterday, in a brief ceremony preceding the novelist's speech at the Americana Hotel, it marked the end of monthlong, crosscountry travels that took him from Russian colonies in Alaska and Oregon and the campus of Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., to the Lincoln Memorial in Washington and the Virginia countryside, with visits to the Middle West heartland, as he called it, along the way.

title: FORMULA ON SINAI UNDER DISCUSSION BY U.S. AND ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The United States and Israel were reported today to be working on a formula to break the deadlocked EgyptianIsraeli negotiations and to solve a controversy over whether Israeli forces should completely evacuate two strategic Sinai passes as part of an agreement.

title: Strike Snarls Work At Yankee Stadium And Sewage Plants
description: A strike by crane operators has vistually halted construction of two new city sewage plants, impeded the rehabilitation of 12 others, slowed the renovation of Yankee Stadium and halted some street paving.

title: BROKERAGE PROFITS SOAR FOR REYNOLDS
description: Reynolds Securities, Inc., reported yesterday that its secondquarter profit soared to $3.14million, or 59 cents a share, on record revenues of nearly $33million. This was up from the brokerage house's yearearlier profit of $110,000 on revenues of nearly $22million.

title: Air Force Shifts Generals
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Gen. Richard H. Ellis, now Air Force vice chief of staff, was named yesterday as commander of United States air forces in Europe and of allied air forces in Central Europe. He will replace Gen. John W. Vogt Jr., who is retiring. Gen. William V. McBride, now head of the Air Force logistics command at WrightPatterson Air Force Base, Ohio, will take General Ellis's old post.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JULY 10, 1975

title: Screen: 'Strongest Man':Disney Comedy Brews Superhuman Formula
description: "The Strongest Man in the World" is a Walt Disney comedy based on the old magic-formula story that's served the company well through thick ("The Absent-Minded Professor") and thin ("The Computer Wore Tennis Shoes"). The new film, which opened at theaters throughout the city yesterday, is nowhere near as funny as the first but a lot better than the second.The setting once again is Medfield College, where the students look old enough to be junior executives on Wall Street, and behave like grade-schoolers. This time the magic formula is for a liquid that so fortifies a person that he has superhuman strength. In less time than it takes to tell it, the formula becomes the object of frantic competition between two breakfast-food companies, and the thing that will save the job of Medfield's nutty Dean Higgins, played by the late Joe Flynn."The Strongest Man in the World" has a lot of cheerful things in it, including a scene in which Dean Higgins must upbraid the school fat boy for always eating in class. "All this bag rattling and cracker crunching has got to stop," says the furious dean, which makes one long for a world in which cracker crunching might be the paramount problem.Also reassuring are the appearances of Eve Arden and Phil Silvers, as the chiefs of the rival breakfast-food companies whose industrial spy networks recall the worst bungling of the Watergate burglars.For a film designed for very young children, the movie contains one appalling scene that is meant, I assume, to be funny. When a couple of villains prepare the hero for hypnosis, they use acupuncture. They nail a long pin into the young man's skull, which may or may not give some members of the audience ideas. Vincent McEveety, the director, may not have been on the set that day.

title: New Bond Issues
Muskie Says Proposal by Ford On Cruiser Upset Budget Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Senator Edmund S. Muskie, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, protested today that President Ford had engaged in unsound budgetary practices in making a last minute proposal for construction of a nuclearpowered cruiser costing $1.2billion.

title: 3 OIL EXECUTIVES INDICTED IN THEFTS
description: ELIZABETH, July 9 (UPI)The top three executives of a New Jersey heatingoil company, including one who served as a state senator, were indicted today on charges of conspiracy and stealing more than $4million in heating oil from the Exxon Corporation. Also Molted were five former Exxon employes who worked on piers at the corporation's Linden refinery and three employes of the Empire Oil Company of Elizabeth.

title: Student Is Shot to Death In West Side Apartment
description: A 35yearold student from Liberia studying accounting at Pace University was found shot to death in his West Side apartment last night, the police reported.

title: Now Is the Time for All Pet Bills To Come Before the Legislature
description: ALBANY, July 9 There is a bill to put a Manhattan Senator's home into his district and one that could add a $100million burden to New York City's fiscal tribulations.

title: Stones Takes High Jump In Denmark
description: AARHUS, Denmark, July 9 (AP)  The world recordholder, Dwight Stones of the United States, cleared 7 feet 2 inches to capture the men's high jump today at an international track and field meet.

title: India's Parliament Called To Vote on Crisis Decrees
description: NEW DELHI, July 9The Indian Parliament will hold a weeklong session beginning July 21, the Government announced today, presumably to consider the sweeping state of etergency declared late last month and the subsequent political crisis.

title: Article 3  No Title
TAKEOVER IS URGED FOR HONDURAN UNITS
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 9 (AP)An advisory commission has recommended that the Government nationalize the Honduran properties of the United Brands Company and the Standard Fruit & Steamship Company and cancel their banana concessions because of the banana bribery scandal.

title: France Is Willing to Keep One of the Comoro Islands
description: PARIS, July 9The French Government decided today to recognize the wish of the people of one of the four main islands of the Comoro chain off East Africa to remain under French rule, despite the overwhelming vote of the total population for independence.

title: Invitation to Mayhem
description: Everyone who uses. the interstate highway systemespecially those who now drive or soon will be driving smaller cars because of steeply rising automobile and gasoline priceshas a lifeordeath interest in an amendment to a transportation appropriations bill that Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan, is introducing in the House today.

title: An Exhibit On Sports At Garden
description: The grace, violence, color and drama of the American sports scene form the theme of an exhibit, Images of Sport, that was previewed yesterday in the National Art Museum of Sport at Madison Square Garden.

title: Safeway Net Up Sharply; A.& P. Has Quarter Loss
description: Safeway Stores, Inc., and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's first and second largest supermarket chains in volume, respectively, reported yesterday sharply different results in their most recent fiscal quarter.

title: Callaghan Reported Assured by Mobutu On Briton's Release
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, July 9 (Reuters)  Britain's Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan, has received a categorical assurance from President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire that the British lecturer, Denis Hills, imprisoned in Uganda, would accompany him home to London tomorrow, the Zaire press agency AZAP said tonight.

title: Consumer Affairs Agency Reopening Local Offices
description: The city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Elinor C. Guggenheimer, said yesterday that $300,000 was being restored to her department's budget and that this would make possible the reopening of neighborhood offices.

title: Strike Talks Break Off
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 9 (AP)Negotiations aimed at ending a strike by 12,000 state welfare and unemployment workers broke off tonight, and union officials said that they would not resume until Saturday. The talks were halted after state negotiators rejected a union proposal for a 6.5 per cent pay rise.

title: Epilogue Given World Premiere by Ballet Theater
description: John Neumeier is a choreographer dangerously in love with concepts. There have been times in the past where the very brilliance of his narrative insight into a ballet has almost outweighed its dance interest. He has produced ballets that you can virtually read as a novel. Yet Mr. Neumeier does have a simple and honest choreographic talent that revealed itself very clearly with Epilogue, which was given its world premiere by American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night.

title: NADJARI TO RECEIVE $1MILLION FROM U.S.
description: Maurice H. Nadjari the special state prosecutor, said yesterday his office was scheduled to receive a total of 1.05million in Federal funds.

title: SUSPECT ARRAIGNED IN DEATH OF SINGER
description: LOS ANGELES, July 9A suspected drug pusher believed to have sold Tim Buckley, 28yearold folk singer and composer, heroin that resulted in his death by drug overdose, was arraigned today on murder charges in a Santa Monica courtroom.

title: At Children's Zoo: Mankind on View
1,200 Flowers for Ruffian
description: A wreath of 1,200 white carnations was placed on the grave of Ruffian yesterday at Belmont Park. The wreath, in the shape of a horseshoe, 8 feet high and 8 feet wide, dominates the other floral tributes to the 3yearold filly who died of injuries suffered in her match race with Foolish Pleasure on Sunday. She was buried at the track Monday.

title: Reports to Be Investigated
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (Reuters)A Congressional committee plans an investigation into reports that the Soviet Union is planning another grain deal, committee sources said today. The investigation will be conducted by the trade subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, the sources added.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Hypertension Detection and Treatment Program at Gimbels Is Successful
description: A novel medical program in which Gimbel's workers with high blood pressure were treated at the department store has achieved such favorable results that it is viewed as holding promise as a practical way of treating larger groups of patients all over the world.

title: State's Suburbs Face School Tax Rise
description: Because of a combination of actions in Albany and local decisions not to reduce levels of school spending, residents of suburban areas face substantial schooltax rises this year20 per cent and more in some areas.

title: Tennis Results
description: EASTERN SENIORS

title: NEGOTIATIONS SET ON DC10 DAMAGES
description: The way was cleared yesterday for fullblown outofcourt negotiations on damages to be awarded survivors of most of the 346 persons killed in the DC10 crash near Paris in May, 1974.

title: Bulaich and Lane In Football Trades
description: Two big deals were completed in professional football yesterday. The Miami Dolphins acquired Norm Bulaich, a running back from the Philadelphia Eagles, and the Green Bay Packers sent MacArthur Lane, a firststring running back, to the Kansas City Chiefs. Both went in exchange for undisclosed draft choices.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON A NURSING BILL
description: ALBANY, July 9Legislative leaders in the fight to curb abuses in the nursinghome industry reached agreement tonight on a compromise bill that would impose stronger regulations on nursinghome operators and insure better care for residents.

title: NEW RULES URGED ON GRAIN PROTEIN
description: HELENA, Mont., July 9Gov. Thomas L. Judge of Montana called an emergency meeting this afternoon on the growing discrepancies in protein grading by grain companies in the Northwest.

title: I.R.A. Leader Is Captured By Dublin WithoutStruggle
description: DUBLIN, July 9 (AP)David O'Connell, chief of the Provisional Irish Republican Army, was arrested here yesterday after years of evading British and Irish authorities, the Irish police said.

title: Family Plans to Sue C.I.A. Over Suicide in Drug Test
description: FREDERICK, Md., July 9The widow and children of a researcher who committed suicide in 1953 after being made an unwitting participant in a Central Intelligence Agency drug experiment said today that they planned to sue the agency over his wrongful death.

title: COMMODITY PACTS TERMED UNLIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Recent speeches by Secretary of State Kissinger suggesting new moves to aid the world's lessdeveloped countries amounted to a rejection of broad scale commodity agreements aimed at fixing prices, Congress was told today.

title: JORDAN QUARTET AT NEW JALL FETE
description: Hard on the heels of the 10day Newport Jazz Festival, which ended last Sunday, another jazz festival started on Tuesday. This one is at the Seafood Playhouse, 209 West 48th Street, where two jazz groups will perform twice a night, Tuesday through Sunday, this week and next. Different groups will appear each evening.

title: Byrne Pledges Veto Of a SalesTax Rise
description: TRENTON, July 9Governor Byrne said today that he would veto an increase in the state sales tax if it was enacted alone by the State Legislature or as the centerpiece of a nuisancetax package designed to restore $384million in budget cuts made by the Governor to balance the current state budget.

title: NEW MINERAL CODE ENACTED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, July 9 (UPI)The Soviet Parliament today approved legislation aimed at using mineral resources efficiently.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIALS GET CAREY DATA
description: WASHINGTON. July 9The Federal Energy Administration has sent to the Justice Department, without any recommendation, the results of its investigation of alleged intervention by Governor Carey, while he was a member of Congress, to obtain a Federal license in an oil deal involving a brother, Edward M. Carey.

title: U.S. Study Accuses Beef Packers Chief Of Deceptive Acts
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) An Agriculture Department report today charged the head of American Beef Packers, Inc., with sending more than $1.1million in certified checks to close associates when the meat packing plant was in dire financial straits and contemplating bankruptcy.

title: T.V.A. Cancels Bid For Peabody Coal
description: The number of bona fide bidders for the Peabody Coal Company once again dwindled to two yesterday with the withdrawal of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Butz Believes Soviet Is Seeking Wheat; Sharp Early Gains in Grain Futures Cut
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 9 (UPI)  Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today he believed the Soviet Union was in the market to buy a large amount of wheat but did not know of any specific purchase from American traders.

title: Ford Endorses Bill to Ease Arms Embargo on Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 9President Ford today accepted a compromise with Congress for a partial lifting of the fivemonthold United States embargo on arms aid to Turkey.

title: GOLD
description: By The Associated Press

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: FREDERICK W. KRUMPE
description: Frederick W. Krumpe, father of John H. Krumpe, executive director of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority and former president of the New York Racing Association, died yesterday at his home in Warrensburg, N.Y. Mr. Krumpe, a retired employe of the International Paper Company, was 89 years old.

title: 9 NAMED TO STUDY SYSTEM IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 9Justice Joseph Liff of State Su preme Court appointed a ninemember citizens' commission here today to devise an interim plan for a constitutional form of government for Nassau County.

title: William Downes Jr., Air Aide In Chicago, Football Official
description: CHICAGO, July 9 (AP)William E. Downes Jr., Chicago's aviation commissioner and a longtime official of the National Football League, died today in his sleep. He was 66 years old.

title: Drought Is Parching the Emerald Isle
description: CLIFDEN, Ireland, July 9For weeks now the Emerald Isle has been turning a delicate shade of khaki.

title: House Votes to Let Ford Increase TopLevel Staff
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The House of Representatives voted tonight to permit President Ford to increase substantially the number of toplevel White House staff members.

title: Ford's '76 Manager Bars Giving Aid to Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, July 9President Ford's new election campaign organization will make no effort to win delegate support for Vice President Rockefeller for the second spot on the 1976 Republican ticket, the President's campaign chairman said today.

title: Ford Endorses Bill to Ease Arms Embargo on Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 9President Ford today accepted a compromise with Congress for a partial lifting of the fivemonthold United States embargo on arms aid to Turkey.

title: OFFER FOR APCO APPEARS LIKELY
description: A competitive tender offer to gain control of the Apco Oil Corporation appeared likely yesterday with the report that the Northwest Energy Company plans to purchase common shares of Apco.

title: The Screen:In 'Race With Devil,' Witches Are Hunters
description: "Race With the Devil," the title of the film that opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, tell the whole story more or less.It starts when a couple or pals, played by Peter Fonda and Warren Oates, partners in a San Antonio motorcycle shop, set out with their wives for a vacation in Aspen, Colo. The first night out, camped off the highway in their $36,000 mobile home, they become the occidental witnesses to a local witches' rite, a human sacrifice. Thereafter "Race With The Devil" turns into a highway chase film as the vacationers try desperately to outdrive if not outwit the witches, who include farmers, policemen, service-station attendants, truck drivers and senior citizens.This is a ridiculous mishmash of a movie for people who never grew up, which is not so say it's for children. One would think that Mr. Fonda and Mr. Oates had better things to do, but perhaps not. American movie production is in a bad state.

title: State Prison Reform
description: Governor Carey has a rare opportunity to make civilizing inroads into the traumatized and overburdened state prison system. His bill to create a new State Commission of Corrections has passed the Legislature; now he must give life and direction to the new group.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CAMERA EYE A retrospective program of documentary movies by Emile de Antonio begins showings today through July 20 at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: PORTUGAL PLANS TO BYPASS PARTIES
description: LISBON, July 9Portugal's military rulers decided today to give the people a direct role in government that would bypass the political parties.

title: Albany G. O. P. Sues to Overturn Regents Vote in Rump Session
description: ALBANY, July 9Republican legislators sued today to overturn the election of three Regents who were chosen last March in a raucous evening legislative session that the Republicans denounced as a rump meeting.

title: Newcombe to Do Telecast
description: John Newcombe will he the color commentator for Saturday night's telecast of the World Team Tennis EastWest AllStar match from the Los Angeles Sports Arena.

title: Carr TwoStroke Victor
description: DANVERS, Mass., July 9 (AP)  Joe Carr of Worcester carded a threeoverpar 75 today for a 36hole total of 143 at Ferncroft Country Club to Win the New England Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: Institrite for Mediation Official Named Urban Coalition Head
description: Arthur H. Barnes, vice president of the Institute for Mediation and Conflict Resolution, was named president and chief operating officer of the New York Urban Coalition yesterday.

title: TV: The Chicago Conspiracy Trial
description: Public TV's Hollywood Television Theater, produced by KCET in Los Angeles, is reverting to an acquisition, a twoandahalf hour dramatization of The Chicago Conspiracy Trial. Culled by Christopher Burstall and Stuart Hood from 23,000 pages of the original transcript, the program is a 1970 coproduction of the British Broadcasting Corporation and Bavarian Television. Mr. Burstall also served as producer and director.

title: La Forza Is First To Reach Halifax
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 9La Forza del Destino, the black, 52foot sloop that has been called the pirate ship on account of her blackness and has been called a comic opera on account of being named after Verdi's epic, was first to finish a slow ocean race from Marblehead here today at noontime.

title: Toying With Success
description: The toy dog long has been a favorite with the city dweller, including the senior citizen. The vast majority of the tiny pets are papertrained, so that in inclement weather, the owner doesn't have to take his little companion outdoors. Although the toy is small, its sharp bark makes it good watchdog.

title: P.L.O. REPORTS BID TO FREE AMERICAN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, July 10The Palestine Liberation Organization said yesterday that it had demanded the release of the United States Army colonel who was abducted by guerrillas June 29 but that the kidnappers had refused to free him.

title: U.S. Acts to End Permit Of Grain Inspection Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Agriculture Department has asked its general counsel's office whether a private inspection agency under investigation in New Orleans can legally be put out of business, according to official sources here.

title: Plea for the Cities
description: America's bigcity mayors at their assemblage in Boston renewed the refrain which is all but automatic whenever two or more of them get together: The cities need more help from the Federal Government. The specific emphasis this year was on: (1) changing the revenuesharing formula so that payments will, in some measure, reflect a city's needs; and (2) passage of an emergency antirecession aid measure.

title: P.L.O. REPORTS BID TO FREE AMERICAN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, July 10The Palestine Liberation Organization said yesterday that it had demanded the release of the United States Army colonel who was abducted by guerrillas June 29 but that the kidnappers had refused to free him.

title: Opel Warranty Extended
description: RUESSELSHEIM, West Germany, July 9 (Reuters)Adam Opel, A.G., said today it would extend the guarantee period on new cars delivered from today to 12 months without mileage limit from six months previously. Volkswagenwerk, A.G., yesterday became the second Germanbased car manufacturer to offer a 12month guarantee after Ford Werke, A.G.

title: Article 1  No Title
Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Vote on Oil Reserves a Bitter Defeat for Hebert
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Representative F. Edward Hbert had hoped to steer through the House yesterday a bill to authorize production of crude oil from the naval petroleum reserves, retain the Navy's jurisdiction and restore some of the prestige Mr. Hbert lost in January when he was ousted as chairman of the Armed Services Committee.

title: Evolution Theory Still Disputed 50 Years After Monkey Trial
description: DAYTON, Tenn., July 8Fifty years agoon July 10, 1925in this languid little town in the Cumberland Hills, William Jennings Bryan and Clarence Darrow faced each other on the opening day of the celebrated trial of John T. Scopes, a young Dayton teacher accused of the crime of expounding in School Darwin's theory of evolution.

title: File Said to Indicate C.I.A. Had a Man in White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  The staff director of the House Select Committee on Intelligence has seen documents indicating that a highlevel member of the Nixon White House staff was reporting to the Central Intelligence Agency on activities in and around the Oval Office, according to a source close to the committee's investigation.

title: Topps Called Off Base
description: The Topps Chewing Gum Company of Brooklyn, whose mixture of bubblegum and baseball cards has exercised the jaws and acquisitive inclinations of nearly a generation of youngsters, has been accused of taking an unfair bite of its business.

title: Carey, Defending Record, Cites Unpopular Positions
description: ALBANY, July 9Governor Carey today defended his freshmanyear record, saying he had taken fiscally sound, if unpopular, positions and had given as much consideration to upstate as to New York City.

title: The Stage: Inge's Love Death Plays
description: Acclaimed in the nineteenfifties, neglected in the sixties, and an apparent suicide in 1973, William Inge has, since his death, been undergoing something of a comeback. His successes, such as Come Back, Little Sheba, Picnic and Bus Stop, are often revived, and his seemingly countless unproduced plays are constantly being discovered and produced.

title: Advertising
description: MBA Communications, which grew out of the entrepreneurial thinking in 1966 of four students at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, has been acquired by Rupert Murdoch, the Australianborn international publishing baron.

title: Garden to Back Summer Test Of Friday Night Fights on TV
description: Madison Square Garden. in an effort to recapture the past, is bringing back televised Friday night boxing for a sevenweck summer tryout. The Garden will act as promoter and matchmaker, but none of the five programs already scheduled will emanate from the Garden, once the mecca of boxing.

title: Mrs. King Turns Back Mrs. Cawley Again, 75
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. July 9A timely, oneset grudge match between Billie Jean King and Evonne Goolagong Cawley, the Wimbledon finalists, drew 5,394 persons to Nassau Coliseum tonight and highlighted a World Team Tennis contest between the New York Sets and Pittsburgh Triangles. It was the Sets' largest home crowd of the season.

title: Oosterhuis Cards 68 for Lead
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 9With a fourunderpar 68 that held off the challenges of Jack Nicklaus and Hale Irwin, Peter Oosterhuis of Britain claimed the firstround lead in the British Open golf tournament today. Nicklaus and Irwin shot 69's and were in a sixway tie for second with Andries Oosthuizen of South Africa, Jack Newton and Bob Shearer of Australia and David Huish of nearby North Berwick.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS LAW ON OIL SPILLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9President Ford sent to Congress today a proposal for legislation to fix liability for and guarantee payment of damages from all oil spills. He said it would help protect the environment while the development of the nation's energy resources is being speeded up.

title: Arab Finds and Returns Secret Israeli Telegram
description: TEL AVIV, July 9 (UPI)An Israeli Government official confirmed today that a copy of a topsecret telegram to Defense Minister Shimon Peres about IsraeliEgyptian peace negotiations was lost last week in Jerusalem, and later found and returned by an Arab hotel worker.

title: June Sales Off 3% at Major Retailers Here
description: June sales of seven of New York's largest department stores averaged 3 per cent below a year ago, continuing a 1975 trend that was interrupted by an advance in May, when sales had hit their best stride of the year.

title: British Union Chiefs Back Curbs on Wage Increases
description: LONDON, July 9  British trade union leaders today supported Prime Minister Harold Wilson's efforts to curb inflation by voting in favor of limiting wage increases.

title: Operating Profit Rises at Morgan
description: J. P. Morgan & Co., Inc., reported yesterday that income, for the quarter ended June 30 rose to nearly $45million before securities transactions and almost $44million afterward.

title: Open Interest
Argentina, in Respite From Political Crisis, Marks Independence
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 9President Isabel Martinez de Pern enjoyed a brief respite today from the political crisis that has shaken the Government, as Argentina observed the 159th anniversary of her independence.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (Reuters)The Senate Banking Committee, by a 9to4 vote, defeated today a bill that would have imposed an 18month delay in Federal regulations covering transfers of funds by electronic means.

title: Natural Wonders of Adirondacks Inventoried
description: COREYS, N.Y.Taking inventory seemed somehow an inappropriate description of what Clarence Petty was doing as he guided his canvas canoe through the cool, clear Ampersand Brook, past magnificent stands of white birch, cedar and hemlock.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Police Department announced that 11 sergeants assigned to its Fourth Division who were on duty when ethnic slurs were directed at Mayor Beame over patrol car radios on June 12 were being subjected to disciplinary proceedings. The proceedings, known as command discipline, areaccording to the departmentpredicated on the responsibility of the sergeants for incidents involving men under their command. Further investigation by the commander of the Manhattan precinct involved will determine the extent of their fault, if any, and the punishment, which can consist of a fine, restriction of duties or revocation of vacation or days off. Meanwhile, the Police Department seeking to determine who actually made the remarks. The Fourth Division precincts are on East 67th Street, West 82d Street, East 102d Street and in Central Park.

title: Offbeat AuthorLecturer
description: LONDON, July 10He has been portrayed as a restless loner, an adventurer, an upperclass Englishman who rejected convention and defiantly found his personal peace in Turkey and Africa.

title: Amid a Troubled Economy, Schmidt Relishes Combat
description: BONN, July 10  On a hot Monday in June a highlevel delegation from Washington flew to Bonn to deliver a message from President Ford to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. The United States Secretary of the Treasury, William E. Simon, and the head of the Federal Reserve Bank. Dr. Arthur F. Burns, told him that all the signs pointed to an economic recovery soon on the other side of the Atlantic.

title: Giap Says Even U.S. Troops Could Not Have Saved Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10, (UPI)North Vietnam's two top ranking generals, in a lengthy analysis of the Communist victory in South Vietnam, say that even direct. American intervention could not have prevented the Saigon Government from toppling this year.

title: OVER CHARGES LAID TO 12 OIL CONCERNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10In a major investigation that has been going on for 16 months, the Government made public today the names of 12 United States oil companies alleged to have overcharged the public by $165million during the 197374 Arab oil embargo.

title: Politics of Money
description: For months the Ford Administration has been whetting the appetite of business groups and the securities industry by proclaiming its conviction that the most urgent economic problem facing the nation is the need for tax incentives and tax cuts to stimulate greater business investment Yet when Secretary of the Treasury Simon went before the House Ways and Means Committee this week, he said he had no specific proposals for promoting saving and investment, but only a set of options to discuss.

title: Sir Francis Meynell Dies at 84; Founder of the Nonesuch Press
description: LONDON, July 10Sir Francis Meynell, book designer, publisher and poet, died today at his home in Suffolk after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Impact of Jaws Has Anglers and Bathers on Lookout
description: The impact of the motion picture Jaws is being felt all along the East Coast where town authorities and lifeguards are being besieged with reports of sharks.

title: State's High Court Upsets Convictions On Sunday Closing
description: The Court of Appeals yesterday expressed grave dissatisfaction with the state's blue laws, but by a onevote margin found the Sabbath closing laws constitutional.

title: Ford to Sell Stock
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to sell 8 million shares of stock it purchased from the Ford Foundation. The aim is to acquire additional revenue. Page 39.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y.Larry Middleton, 216 pounds, Baltimore knocked out Rochelle Norris, 206, Atlantic, N.Y., 9 rounds.

title: AMEX REJECTING IDEA OF MERGER
Carey Submits Added Budget Of $38.7Million to Legislature
description: ALBANY, July 10Two new legislative commissions and $3.2million added appropriation for the Legislature are among the items in a $38.7million supplement to the state budget disclosed today by the legislative leaders.

title: 2 Surprises at British Open: Huish Leads Cole Sets Mark
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 10In a day of golf scores that brought the great Carnoustie, course to its knees, David Huish of Scotland fashioned a 67 for a halfway total of 136 in the British Open today and for a twostroke lead over Torn Watson, Peter Oosterhuis of Britain and Andries Oosthilizen and Bobby Cole of South Africa.

title: Business Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 10 (UPI)Valentin Hernandez, Minister of Mines, said in an interview published today that key issues involved in the nationalization of oil companies by Venezuela appeared to be nearing mutually satisfactory solutions.

title: U.S. and Russian Crews Ready for Space Mission
