description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 10After nearly five years of delicate negotiations and careful preparations, the United States and the Soviet Union are now poised for a space mission unlike any before a manned flight involving a linkup of American and Soviet craft in earth orbit.

title: Former Navy Pilot Makes an Emergency Landing on a West Side Pier
description: A former Navy pilot made an emergency landing on a West Side pier yesterday after a cylinder exploded In his singleengine Stinson 108 airplane. The pilot H. Lewis Merton, 56 years old, his daughter, Holly, 16, their cat, Mozart, and their dogs, Little Pete and Rembrandt, were uninjured.

title: Rosenbergs' Sons Will Be Given Access to Files on Their Parents
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Attorney General Edward H. Levi has overruled both the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorney in New York and ordered them to supply files on the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg to the Rosenbergs' sons as quickly as possible.

title: U.S. and Russian Crews Ready for Space Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL Fla., July 10After nearly five years of delicate negotiations and careful preparations, the United States and the Soviet Union are now poised for a space mission unlike any before a manned flight involving linkup of American and Soviet craft in earth orbit.

title: People and Business
description: A group of nationally prominent business, labor. science and professional leaders have organized an energy independence advocacy association in Washington and hired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the retired Chief of Naval Operations, as their president.

title: Coleman Concedes Views Exceeded His Race Data
description: Dr. James S. Coleman, the sociologist who provoked national debate recently by saying his new research showed that courtinduced school segregation had served only to swell the white exodus from the big cities  now concedes that his public comments went beyond the scientific data he had gathered.

title: A.M.C. TO PURCHASE LIGHT VOLKS ENGINES
description: DETROIT, July 10  The American Motors Corporation in an effort to save time and money in making available to purchasers of its automobiles a fourcylinder engine announced today that it had reached an agreement to buy the small engines from Volkswagenwerk. A.G.

title: S. Klein's on Union Sq. and Last 3 Branches Will Close
description: S. Klein's department store on Union Square, a magnet for bargainhunters for 65 years, will close within a few weeks after a long period of losses.

title: Ban on Pay Toilets Passes
description: ALBANY, July 10The Legislature today voted final approval of a statewide ban on pay toilets, a public facility assailed by feminists as a humiliation and denounced by male legislators as an inconvenience.

title: NIXON COMMITTEE GETS LEGAL BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) The 1972 campaign committee for former President Nixon reported today that it was considering claims for legal fees by former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans, who was finance chairman of the Nixon campaign, and Kenneth W. Parkinson, who was a lawyer for the Committee for the ReElection of the President.

title: Heroin Suspect Is Held in $5Million Bail
description: Franois Rossi the reputed kingpin of the LatinAmerican connection in heroin, was held in record bail yesterday$5millionfollowing the opening of his sealed indictment on a charge of smuggling into this country more than $1.5billion worth of heroin during an eightyear period.

title: Oliva Gets 4 Hits as Twins Defeat Yankees, 63
description: The Yankees didn't have as much success with lightning last night as Ben Franklin and Dr. Frankenstein (young and old) had in days gone by.

title: LAWRENCE LIPTON, WROTE OF BEATS
description: Lawrence Linton, poet, novelist, lecturer and chronicler of the beat generation, died Wednesday at his home in the onceBohemian area of Venice, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
Brokers Say Rate War Cost $25Million in May
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed today that brokerage houses lost about $25million of revenues during May as a result of the Governmentordered imposition of price competition on Wall Street.

title: Met Museum Sets 2 Closings a Week In Budget Cutback
description: Starting next Tuesday, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be closed to the public two days a week. The additional shutdown, which adds Tuesdays and Tuesday evenings to the regular Monday closings, is a result of the city's fiscal plight, which has caused a 20 per cent reduction in the museum's security force, the Metropolitan says.

title: CITY UNIONS JOIN TO FIGHT LAYOFFS
description: Leaders of the oftenfeuding unions of city employes are trying to work together once again in the Municipal Labor Committee headed by Victor Gotbaum, executive director of the largest union, District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employes.

title: New Start For Track In Suffolk
description: TAPHANK, L. I., July 10 Ronald J. Parr, the developer of the controversial, $22million Suffolk Meadows quarterhorse race track, has concluded an agreement with his associates under which they will discontinue their association with the track and drop litigation against him in exchange for more than $1million in compensation.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
City Employes Sweat Out Time to Quit
description: You know something? When you're really working, you don't feel the heat, Ruth Levine said yesterday as she sat in a 23dfloor office in the Municipal Building.

title: Thai Smugglers Still Conduct Brisk Trade With Cambodians
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, July 9  However completely Cambodia would like to isolate herself from the world, an active border traffic links her to Thailand.

title: NEW PANEL URGED IN SPYING INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The House Rules Committee moved today to abolish the striferidden House Select Committee on Intelligence and to replace it with a larger, newly constituted panel that would retain the same authority.

title: FRANCE EXPELLING 3 CUBAN OFFICIALS
description: PARIS, July 10France expelted three highranking Cuban diplomats today in connection with the worldwide search for a man called Carlos, who is believed to be an important link in an international terrorist network.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Unions Plan Strikes In Layoffs by Jersey
description: TRENTON, July 10  Two unions representing more than 75 per cent of the state's employes today attacked the layoffs being announced by the Byrne administration to balance the state budget, and said they were prepared to call strikes.

title: Lawyers Must Register
description: TRENTON, July 10 (AP)The Department of Transportation says that lawyers who plan to represent organizations at a public hearing Monday on the effects of state railroad and bus subsidy cuts must register by tommorrow. Registrants must get in touch with the Division of Commuter Service, the department said.

title: Nations Cup Put Up for Men's Team Tennis
description: Superbly dressed in a black blazer, multicolored shirt and his usual cool, innocent expression yesterday, Arthur Ashe, the Wimbledon champion, announced details of the Nations Cup tennis tournament sponsored by the Association of Tennis Professionals.

title: Borg, Koch Are Victors In Sweden
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 10 (AP)Topseeded Bjorn Burg of Sweden moved into the quarterfinals of the $30,000 Swedish open tennis championships today with a 63, 75 victory over Rolf Thung of the Netherlands.

title: Developer Obtains Extension of Options On Times Sq. Hotel
description: The developer of a proposed 54story hotel on Times Square, has obtained extensions on his options to purchase land assembled for the project.

title: Mayors Are Told Recession Aid for Cities Will Be Restudied
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Top officials of the Ford Administration promised a group of the nation's mayors today to take a new look at a project that it previously rejected as too costlya special program of revenue sharing for cities hardest hit by the recession.

title: Books of The Times
description: Cesar Chavez, the MexicanAmerican leader of the United Farm Workers of America, has always seemed to provoke strong emotions among friends and foes. To those who believe he is seeking social justice for the rural poor and who admire his dedication to the principles of nonviolence, Mr. Chavez has been an almost saintlike figure. But to the big corporate farmers and their allies, he is a kind of demona revolutionary demagogue intent on destroying American agriculture.

title: Move Accomplished Without Increasing Interest Rates
Citicorp and Chemical Report Sharp Gains in Quarter Earnings
description: Two of the nation's largest banking concerns  Citicorp and the Chemical New York Corporation  yesterday reported sharp gains in their second quarter and first half earnings. Both made substantial charges to earnings by additions to their loan loss reserves.

title: Portugal's Socialist Party Pulls Out of Government
description: LISBON, Friday, July 11The Socialist party resigned from the Portuguese Government early today, giving as the reason the military takeover of the Socialistcontrolled newspaper Repblica.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Reports Net Off
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 14.2 per cent in secondquarter net income as sales dipped by 5.6 per cent. Kaiser was the first of the aluminum companies to report on its secondquarter operations and it pointed out that aluminum division operations made no measurable contribution to earnings.

title: Rabin and West Germans Talk On Issues for Peace in Mideast
description: BONN, July 10Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel plunged into a busy round of meetings with Government officials, Opposition figures and leading businessmen today on the third day of his visit to West Germany.

title: Traviata in S.I. Tonight
description: The Metropolitan Opera concert performance of La Traviata scheduled for performance at Clove Lakes Park, Staten Island, last night was canceled because of rain and will be given in the same location tonight.

title: FRANK KAPPLER, 85, EXNEWSPAPERMAN
description: Frank J. Kappler, who had been a New York newspaperman for many years before his retirement in 1958, died Wednesday in Huntington (L. I.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 47 North Woodhull Road, Huntington.

title: Citicorp and Chemical Report Sharp Gains in Quarter Earnings
description: Two of the nation's largest banking concerns  Citicorp and the Chemical New York Corporation  yesterday reported sharp gains in their second quarter and first half earnings. Both made substantial charges to earnings by additions to their loan loss reserves.

title: Silk Stockings Beats Tarport Hap by 4 Lengths in N.Y. Sire Stakes
description: YONKERS, N. Y., July 10 America's two fastest pacing fillies, Silk Stockings and Tarport Hap, met tonight in a ninehorse $53,434 New York Sires Stakes event, but the mile contest, while producing a track record of 1:58 2/5, proved to be onesided.

title: Connecticut Is Worried By Strike of Shipbuilders
description: GROTON, Conn., July 10The largest strike to hit Connecticut in 15 years has idled 10,000 skilled shipbuilders and threatened 7,000 or more other workers with layoffs. It promises to bring hard times to a corner of New England that had been enjoying solid prosperity while the rest of the country went through the recession.

title: Loss Reserves Are Set Up By Investors Diversified
description: Investors Diversified Services, Inc., of Minneapolis said yesterday that it had set up loss reserves of about $4,875,000 for some segments of its business in June. A report filed yeterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission shows that the loss reserves were established primarily for real estate investments held in the I.D.S. real estate and mortgage banking subsidiaries.

title: Fonteyn and Nureyev Renew a Legend
description: WASHINGTON, July 10It is called, quite simply, An evening With Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, but here at the Opera House of the John F. Kennedy Center of the Performing Arts last night it all added up to quite a night. Indeed, if anything, this is a betterjudged and bettervaried program than the earlier ballet sampler we had in New York, called Nureyev and Friends. The present program has something for everyone, and also the opportunity to see the amazing, untiring Mr. Nureyev in four diverse, and one would have imagined diversely exhausting, roles.

title: Article 16  No Title
description: EMPLOYMENT AGENCIES

title: Bickering Legislature Stumbles Toward Adjournment
description: ALBANY, July 10The Legislaturepostponing action on a welfare penalty plan that could cost financially pressed New York City millions of dollarslurched tonight toward a preweekend adjournment.

title: PRESIDENT URGES REGULATORY UNITS TO RESTRICT CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 President Ford summoned the chairmen of the Federal regulatory agencies to the White House today and, in the name of maximum freedom for private enterprise, asked them to dispense with as much regulation as possible.

title: Heroin Suspect Is Held in $5Million Bail
description: Franois Rossi the reputed kingpin of the LatinAmerican connection in heroin, was held in record hail yesterday  $5million  after the opening of his sealed indictment on a charge of smuggling into this country more than $1.5billion worth of heroin during an eightyear period.

title: Brokers Say Rate War Cost $25Million in May
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed today that brokerage houses lost about $25million of revenues during May as a result of the Governmentordered imposition of price competition on Wall Street.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Film

title: Drug Agency's ExHead Denies Corruption Charges
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) John R. Bartels Jr., who was dismissed as head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, testified today that he believed his two main accusers made charges against him to conceal their own shortcomings.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 9%
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.05billion, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $945million.

title: McGinnis Signs $3.2Million 76er Pact
description: George McGinnis signed with the Philadelphia 76ers early yesterday and the Knicks began looking to Wilt Chamberlain.

title: JUNE GAIN SHOWN BY RETAIL STORES
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Retail sales rose again in June and sales figures for both April and May have been revised upward, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CARROLL PEACOCK
description: LUBEC, Me., July 10Carroll B. Peacock, president of the R. J. Peacock Canning Company, a member of the Governor's executive council from 1954 to 1956 and a Republican Representative to the State Legislature in 1931 and 11933, died yesterday at a hospital in Ellsworth. He was 75 years old.

title: The City Layoffs Raise Questions
description: There was no way, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said, in his most understated manner, no earthly way to reduce our force by 5,000 people without it having a noticeable impact on crime prevention. It was early in the morning of June 19, the day on which the city was to pass its new budget, and Commissioner Codd stood in the rotunda beneath the dome of City Hall, saying that the budgeteven with $150million added in new city taxing powersnecessitated that 5,034 police officers be dismissed.

title: Achille van Acker Is Dead at 77; ExSocialist Premier of Belgium
description: BRUSSELS July 10 (AP) Achille van Acker, former Socialist Premier of Belgium, died at his home in Bruges today. He was 77 years old.

title: KISSINGER REPORTS PROGRESS ON ARMS IN GROMYKO TALKS
description: GENEVA, Friday, July 11Secretary of State Kissinger met for seven hours here last night with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and made progress on nuclear missile negotiations, Mr. Kissinger said.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: All 4 Klein's Stores To Be Closed Soon
description: S. Klein's department store on Union Square, a magnet for bargainhunters for 65 years, will close within a few weeks after a long period of losses.

title: Mayor Rejects Immediate Arbitration On Length of City's Summer Workday
description: Mayor Beanie rebuffed Victor Gotbaum yesterday on the union leader's request to go immediately to arbitration for a speedy resolution of the dispute over ending of shortened summer hours for 100,000 city employes.

title: G.E. EARNINGS OFF 13% IN FOR QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of electrical products and power generation systems, reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter were 13 per cent below the corresponding quarter of 1974.

title: The Pop Life
description: With popular music I have generally operated on the assumption that good stuff will reveal itself right away. By that I mean that popular music's popularity is in part a function of its ready accessibility. An unfamiliar disk must appeal to a lot of people right away if it is to be a success at all. Records that take several listenings to get into run the risk of not being gotten into at all.

title: KISSINGER STARTS TALKS AT GENEVA ON HOPEFUL NOTE
description: GENEVA, Friday, July 11Secretary of State Kissinger met for seven hours here last night with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and made progress on nuclear missile negotiations, Mr. Kissinger said.

title: Article 12  No Title
Drowned Editor's Funeral Is Scheduled in Bridgeton
description: BRIDGETON, July 10 (UPI)Funeral services were scheduled for tomorrow at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church for Joseph H. Garwood, managing editor of The Bridgeton Evening News, whose body was found in Delaware Bay six days after his fishing boat capsized in a sudden squall. He was 58 years old.

title: HighLevel Backing Cited In C.I.A. DrugUnit Spying
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, and Richard Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence, authorized a secret program to infiltrate the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs with agents, a program that the Rockefeller commission later found illegal, authorative sources reported today.

title: Twitty Posts 66 at Moline In Pro Start
description: MOLINE, III., July 10 (AP) Howard Twitty Jr. carded a fiveunderpar 66 today and took the firstround lead in the $75,000 Quad Cities open.

title: Torture and Harassment in Brazil
description: Of a thousand grotesque incidents In Brazil in April, here are three that have not yet found their way Into the censored Brazilian press:

title: GRAINS, SOYBEANS ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Grain and soybean prices took what one analyst called a last fling yesterday on the strength of the recent rumors about Soviet grain purchases.

title: Emory U. Professor Picked To Head Union Theological
description: The board of directors of Union Theological Seminary yesterday elected as the seminary's president Donald W. Shriver Jr., a professor at Emory University. The board said Dr. Shriver was uniquely equipped to meet morale, fiscal and other difficulties that have beset the institution.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A conference on film and the university sponsored by the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York and the National Endowment for the Humanities, will be held Tuesday through Friday at the C.U.N.Y. Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. Film educators, writers and others will discuss the place of film studies in colleges and universities. The conference, which will be directed by Gerald Mast and Marshall Cohen, S.U.N.Y. professors, will include discussions of film as an object of university study, film institutions and film scholarship, and the application of the theory of linguistics and the theory of meaning to film. Among the educators scheduled to speak are Stanley Cavell of Harvard, Edward Pincus of M.I.T., Ronald Gottesman of the University of Wisconsin, Yon Barna of the University of Michigan, Gilbert Harman of Princeton and Umberto Eco of the University of Bologna, Italy.

title: STATE CURB VOTED ON NURSING HOMES
description: ALBANY, July 10The Assembly late today passed a series of comprehensive bills designed to end widespread abuses in the nursing home industry, including neglect and mistreatment of the elderly and mismanagement and misappropriation of millions of dollars in Medicaid funds.

title: The Jets' Rookie From Harlem
description: Outside, the streets of Harlem had their summer look. Old men in old shirts were drinking wine on doorsteps, teenagers in sneakers were wandering through the traffic. No jobs. So the streets mean mostly temptation and trouble. But yesterday in the cool dimness of the Flash Inn off the 155th Street Bridge, as if he were insulated from the street, Jon Bradford was smiling. He has a job. He also has a purpose.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIGH AND EXOTIC The remote regions of the Himalayas remain strange and unfamiliar to most of us, except for occasional pictures and camera footage. A new exhibition, Photographs From the Himalayas: Abode of the Snows, has been assembled here to provide an intimate view of the awesome, craggy area and its littleknown people through 75 pictures, mostly in color, taken by prominent, visiting photographers during the last decade. This is the first summer project of the Asia House Gallery (PL 14210), at 112 East 64th Street, which has extended its regular programs for the show, which opens today and runs through Aug. 25. The display has been organized jointly by the gallery and the Internationa Center of Photography.

title: 13% Rise in Quarter
description: The Burroughs Corporation, major producer of computers and business machines, reported yesterday profit increases of 13 per cent for the second quarter and 16 per cent for the first six months, setting new records. Revenue in both period salso reached record levels.

title: Amex Rejects a Merger With Big Board
description: Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, an nounced yesterday that its 21member board of governors had voted unanimously that a merger of the Amex and the New York Stock Exchange was not in the public interest.

title: STATE'S BIRDERS, UNION IN ACCORD
description: Striking operating engineers in New Jersey yesterday reached tentative agreement ona contract to end a 10day walkout that had stopped all highway construction in the state and had slowed work on the new football stadium in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Con Edison Granted Rate Rise to Cover Higher Land Taxes
description: The Public Service Commission said yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company had been authorized to raise electric rates by $29million to cover the cost of higher real estate taxes being imposed by New York City.

title: K. D. Verner Weds Kerry L. Gruson
description: Kerry Lewis Gruson of New York and Kenneth David Verner, a graduate student in the department of marine biology at the University of Puerto Rico in La Parguera, were married there yesterday morning by Judge Israel Irizary.

title: OVER CHARGES LAID TO 12 OIL CONCERNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10In a major investigation that has been going on for 16 months, the Government made public today the names of 12 United States oil companies alleged to have overcharged the public by $165million during the 197374 Arab oil embargo.

title: Article 18  No Title
Natural Wonders of Adirondacks Inventoried
description: COREYS, N.Y.  Taking inventory seemed somehow an inappropriate description of what Clarence Petty was doing as he guided his canvas canoe through the cool, clear Ampersand Brook, past magnificent stands of white birch, cedar and hemlock.

title: Ford to Sell Stock
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to sell 8 million shares of stock it purchased from the Ford Foundation. The aim is to acquire additional revenue. Page 39.

title: About New York
description: Marvin Manheirner drove slowly going out to Belmont Park on Wednesday morning, as though he weren't in any hurry to get there, which he wasn't.

title: Novelist Syncopates History in Ragtime
description: For a long time after finishing his novel The Book of Daniel. E. L. Doctorow sat at his desk in his home in New Rochelle, N. Y., contemplating what to write next. I became aware of the room in which I was sitting, and I began the first lineI live in a house built in 1906. Teddy Roosevelt was President.

title: WALTER E. ROBB
description: Walter E. Robb, a retired Boston investment banker, died there Wednesday. He was 75 years old and lived in Vero Beach, Fla., and Weston, Mass.

title: Vasquez Asks End to Mishap Talk
description: Jacinto Vasquez, who rode Ruffian in all but two of her races, summed up yesterday the matter of the filly's tragic end in a conclusion manner. It's about time we stopped talking about it, he said. It was just a freak accident, and nothing else, not even pigeons had anything to do with it.

title: China Intensifies Denunciation of Soviet
description: HONG KONG, July 10Chinese denunciations of the Soviet Union have increased dramatically in recent days, reaching their most sustained level since the armed clashes on the ChineseSoviet frontier in the winter of 1969.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE ON HEAVY VOLUME
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose again yesterday for the second straight day as volume increased to the second highest level on record. In the overthecounter market, prices also were higher and volume was heavy.

title: Jackson's '75 Fund Close to Wallace's; Both Over a Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama have raised more than $1million each this year toward their 1976 Presidential campaigns.

title: STOCKS STABILIZE FOLLOWING SURGE
SENATE UNIT BARS LOCKHEED DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 10  A Senate subcommittee has turned down the private appeals of William P. Rogers, former Secretary of State and Attorney General, for a delay In furnishing the Senators with information that he has reportedly described as having the potential to ruin the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Peak Corn, W heat Crops Seen, Weather Permitting
description: CHICAGO, July 10If the weather continues in near normal patterns for the next five weeks, American farmers are now expected to produce the largest corn and wheat crops in the nation's history.

title: The Truman Theft
description: The pictures of the ceremony at which Gerald. Ford announced his formal entry into the Presidential race told a good deal about the kind of campaign he will wage. All the pictures included Howard (Bo) Callaway, a millionaire Georgia segregationist, and David Packard, a millionaire mogul of the militaryindustrial complex. Mr. Packard and Mr. Callaway both have done their turns in the Pentagon and now they are to be the leading officials of Mr. Ford's election committee.

title: House Refuses to Prohibit Concordes From Landings at Kennedy and Dulles
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The House of Representatives refused today to prohibit a limited number of BritishFrench Concorde airplanes from landing at airports in New York City and Washington.

title: Money Supply Reduced by Fed; Stocks Fall Back After Surge
description: Stock prices surged in a rush of early trading yesterday, only to be deflated in subsequent profit taking.

title: Drug Maker Is Accused Of Falsifying Test Reports
description: WASHINGTON. July 10A major drug manufacturer was actused today of giving the Government false information about the number of cancer tumors found in animal tests of two drugs sold to million of Americans. The case was referred to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution.

title: A Bronx Nosh Caterer To Yankee Fans to Quit
description: For 30 years Hyman and Dorothy Garber have sold hot dogs and Yankee souvenirs in the shadow of the El, they have sold coffee to stalwarts waiting on line to buy Yankee World Series tickets on bitter October nights and they have listened to Yankee fans argue and exult and, very often, celebrate.

title: No.Amer.SoccerLeague
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: 13% Rise in Quarter
Allied Chemical Net Falls
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday earnings declines of more than 20 per cent in both the second quarter and first half despite higher sales in both periods.

title: Notes on People
description: The black comedian and actor, Godfrey Cambridge, said yesterday that his dispute with three real estate agents in Hartford, where he maintains a home, has no racial overtones. Money is where it's at, said Mr. Cambridge. Black and white, forget that. It's green and white. Mr. Cambridge made the comment as he was about to take part in a hearing of the state Real Estate Commission, which is investigating his complaint that he was bilked by a real estate firm when he bought a $125,000 house that was full of concealed building defects.

title: Hussein Says Jordan Will Protect Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10King Hussein of Jordan said today that he was buying sophisticated American weapons for his armed forces to defend Syria against any flanking attack by Israel through Jordapian territory.

title: Bolshoi Opera's War and Peace' Misfires
description: On the face of things, Prokofiev's War and Peace cannot fail to make an overwhelming impact. The composer has turned out to be one of the most popular in 20thcentury music. The score combines lyricism with spectacular set pieces, such as the burning of Moscow. The stage is thronged with heroes and villains, including Napoleon and Marshal Kutuzov. Behind it all is the Tolstoy novel and its epic sweep.

title: Once There Was an Ideal Known As Blood, Sweat and Tears
description: The British have been lolling on their couches like the selfindulgent patricians of the crumbling Roman Empire when the barbarian horde was nearing the walls.

title: Soviet Seeks 10 Million Tons of Grain
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (Reuters)The Soviet Union has started negotiations for another major grain purchase from the United States, and it could total 10 million metric tons, a senior agriculture department official said today.

title: FARM HAND, 20, HELD IN 2 WOMEN'S DEATHS
description: BRIDGETON, July 10 (UPI)A high school dropout and farm hand was arrested today and charged with the deaths of a woman and her 19yearold daughter, who were found slain in their bedrooms, the police said.

title: Amin Releases Briton He Had Doomed
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 10 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda today freed Denis Cecil Hills, the British lecturer he twice threatend to execute by firing squad. The President took the action while discussing future relations between Kampala and London with Foreign Secretary James Callaghan of Britain.

title: STATE CURB VOTED ON NURSING HOMES
description: ALBANY, July 10The Assembly late today passed a series of comprehensive bills designed to end widespread abuses in the nursing home industry, including neglect and mistreatment of the elderly and mismanagement and misappropriation of millions of dollars in Medicaid funds.

title: In Memoriam
description: CANTORJoseph. A practical dreamer, your sand Jewish heart, zest for life, and warm sense of humor are greatly missed by your Daughter, Aviva.

title: BEVERAGE AGENCY BACKED BY COURT
description: TRENTON, July 10 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that community sentiment could be given consideration in the form of special conditions attached to liquorlicense transfers.

title: DOLLAR AND POUND RISE AGAINST FLOAT
description: LONDON, July 10 (AP)The dollar and the British pound rose sharply today against the joint European currency float on the first day it was expanded to include the French franc.

title: KEY WORD IN INDIA NOW IS DISCIPLINE
description: NEW DELHI, July 10In the tumultuous two weeks during which Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has brought fundamental changes to the world's most populous democracy, discipline has emerged as the watchword of the new order.

title: Hearing Scheduled For Youth, 17, Held In Death of Woman
description: HACKENSACK, July 10A hearing will be held here tomorrow to determine whether a 17yearold Teaneck youth, accused of the fatal shooting of a 23yearold woman, should be treated as a juvenile offender or as an adult and charged with criminal homicide.

title: Bridge:
description: The European Championships beginning tomorrow in Brighton, England, will determine part of the opposition that the American representatives will face in the 1976 world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl.

title: Nigeria Apologizes to U.S. For Occupying a Building
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  The Nigerian Government apologized for the 24hour occupation of a United States Embassy annex in Lagos, the State Department said today.

title: Impact of Budgetary Cuts On Institutions Detailed
description: TRENTON, July 10Budget cuts in the Department of Institutions and Agencies totaling $17million would seriously curtail care of the state's emotionally disturbed and phycically abused children, and also the poor and the retarded, Commissioner Ann Klein warned today.

title: Parliament of Common Market Bids It Form a Political Union
description: STRASBOURG, Prance, July 10 (Reuters)The European Common Market's Parliament proposed today that the community expand into a political union, with members gradually integrating foreign affairs and defense policies as steps along the way.

title: Fad for Indian Jewelry: Unethical Are Moving In On a Lucrative Market
description: GALLUP, N.M.  Tourist beware. That authenticlooking, expensive Indianhandcrafted squashblossom necklace you're eyeing may be fake. Or stolen. Or both.

title: Amex Rejects a Merger With Big Board
description: Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that its 21member board of governors had voted unanimously that a merger of the Amex and the New York Stock Exchange was not in the public interest.

title: PRESIDENT URGES REGULATORY UNITS TO RESTRICT CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 President Ford summoned the chairmen of the Federal regulatory agencies to the White House today and, in the name of maximum freedom for private enterprise, asked them to dispense with as much regulation as possible.

title: G.E. EARNINGS OFF 13% FOR QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of electrical products and power generation systems, reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter were 13 per cent below the corresponding quarter of 1974.

title: World Team Tennis
description: World Team Tennis

title: New Coffee Blend Helps State to Tighten Its Belt
description: TRENTON, July 10Economy in government, spurred bythe state's fiscal crisis, is producing daytoday austerities such as cheaper coffee and makeshift scratch pads, according to state officials here.

title: A Cotton Promotion Group May Lose Its U.S. Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) A private cotton promotion and research group that is partly financed by the Government may lose its $3millionayear Federal grant because it pays its president $121,275 annuallytwice as much as the Agriculture Secretary.

title: Patricia L. Barker Is Wed in Suburb
description: Patricia Louise Barker, daughter of Lieut. Col. Herbert R. Barker, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Barker of El Paso, Tex., was married yesterday at noon to Peter Powers Goodman of Las Cruces, N.M., son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren H. Goodman of Ossining, N.Y.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Detective Said Scientist Had Severe Psychosis
description: A civilian scientist who had unwittingly participated in a Central Intelligence Agency drug experiment had been diagnosed as suffering from severe psychosis and delusions before he plunged to his death from a 10th floor window of the Statler Hotel in midManhattan 22 years ago, according to a police report of the incident.

title: PAYCABLE LEASE 13 FILMED DRAMAS
description: The 13 productions of the American Film Theater, which were shown at motion picture theaters on a subscription basis during the last two years, have been leased to paytelevision and will begin to be exhibited in the spring.

title: Coop City Tenants Withhold Payments On 25% Rent Rise
description: Resuming their defiance of the state, leaders of tenantcooperators at Coop City yesterday delivered to Governor Carey's office here July maintenancecharge payments from residents that did not include required 25 per cent increases.

title: NIXON SEES FAILURE BY U.S. ON SAIGON
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., July 10 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nion concurs in the view that the United States should not have permitted the fall of South Vietnam to the Communists and that as an unfettered President he could nave prevented it, a former top Nixon aid reports.

title: FORD WILL SELL 8 MILLION SHARES
description: DETROIT, July 10The board of directors of the Ford Motor Company decided today to start selling off a block of eight nutlion shares of the company's stock that it had purchased from the Ford Foundation to provide added revenue for future products and facilities.

title: Salmonella in Roast Beef Found by Jersey Agency
description: TRENTON, July 10 (AP) State health officials warned that cooked roast beef prepared by the Cardinal Food Corporation of Brooklyn, N. Y., contained salmonella that caused food poisoning.

title: Stiff Rules Passed to Limit Political Activity of Judges
description: Stiff new rules that limit political activity of judges and their appointees were approved yesterday by the policymaking body of the state court system.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Crawdaddy, a spanking new restaurant at 45 West 45th Street has a long way to go until it can stimulate enthusiastic notices for the food. But in the meanwhile the decoration is attractive enough to keep the place booming until the kitchen catches up.

title: Money Supply Reduced by Fed; Stocks Fall Back After Surge
description: Stock prices surged in a rush of early trading yesterday, only to be deflated in subsequent profit taking.

title: TV Review
description: As a producer of documentaries, RICO Television can hardly brag about quantity. Prestige and browniepoint bets are therefore placed on quality, on the occasional program such as Three Women Alone, which was broadcast last year and eventually won a New York Emmy. This seasonspecitically, this Sunday at 8 P.M. on WOR/Channel 9the candidate is Middle Age Blues with Art Carney as host. There is a pronounced dip in the quality level.

title: TANIA MARIA SINGS SONGS FROM BRAZIL
description: Tana Maria, a singer and pianist from Brazil, is showing the patrons of Michael's Pub that there is more to contemporary Brazilian popular music than wistful bossa novas.

title: Dance: Tetley's Gemini
description: Like all Russians, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn is a ballet lover, apparently. Finding himself with a free evening, the Nobel prizewinning author decided to spend it at American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Colonel Seized in Beirut Asks U.S. to Pay Ransom
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10 A kidnapped American Army colonel appealed today to the United States to meet his abductors' demands for distribution of food and clothing to the poor in a Beirut district. The kidnappers postponed their deadline for killing the colonel until Saturday night.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Leftist Terrorists Attack in Cordoba
description: CORDOBA, Argentina, July 10 (AP)  Leftist terrorists attacked police stations, news agencies and businesses in downtown Crdoba today with gunfire and firebombs. They apparently escaped aftor gun battles with the police.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Day's Pay, Day's Work
description: New York's arrogant municipal labor chiefs, who have been kicking this stricken city and its people around for years, have finally pushed even this timid Mayor too far.

title: A Top I.R.A. Figure Is Charged by Court After Dublin Arrest
description: DUBLIN, July 10  David O'Connell, often described as the most wanted man in Ireland, was charged today with being a member of the Irish Republican Army.

title: The Issue in Jersey
description: Faced with drastic cuts in state aid and services, the New Jersey Legislature appears finally to be headed for action on new taxes to help balance Gov. Brendan T. Byrne's tight austerity budgetbut not on the tax reforms that the Governor has been demanding.

title: CALIFORNIANS FORM FORDIN1976 GROUP
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (UPI) Formation of a 44member California Republican organizing committee for the election of President Ford in 1976 was announced today, and among its members were a number of longtime supporters of former Gov. Ronald Reagan.

title: JERSEY BUILDERS, UNION IN ACCORD
description: Striking operating engineers in New Jersey yesterday reached tentative agreement on a contract to end a 10day walkout that had stopped all highway construction in the state and had slowed work on the new football stadium in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: House Testimony Split on Aid to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 An Administrationbacked bill that would end the fivemonthold embargo on sales of American arms to Turkey was both defended and attacked today in House testimony.

title: People in Sports
description: I'm not saying think they're prejudiced because I'm black, but I am saying they are so aware of my situation, with all the hoopla that goes with it, that they are determined to not let me get away with anything to keep me in my place.

title: 225 PROTEST CUTS IN HOSPITAL JOBS
description: More than 225 Roosevelt Hospital workers marched yesterday in the third day of protests over budget cuts that hospital officials have said will result in a loss of 215 jobs.

title: Simon Optimistic Deficit Will Be Held to $60Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Secretary of the Treasury Wilham E. Simon said today, that he no longer fears a budget deficit in the present fiscal year of $80billion to $100billionsomething he said seemed a certainty six months ago.

title: Violent Schools
description: Recent Congressional studies indicate a serious nationwide increase of crime, violence and vandalism in the schools. It is difficult to determine the extent to which the sudden upturn is caused by more diligent reporting and greater public awareness; but even allowing for such factors, the overall picture is disconcerting.

title: Allied Chemical Net Falls
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday earnings declines of more than 20 per cent in both the second quarter and first half despite higher sales in both periods.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: An apocryphal story has it that alligators roam the sewers of New York. More likely, there are turtlesflushed away by their owners when they learned these popular children's pets might be carriers of salmonella and Arizona organisms which, transmitted to humans in mild form, often lead to infections that can cause diarrhea and more severe complications if the organism gets into the bloodstream. Most seriously affected are children aged 5 and younger who handle their pets in play, then touch their mouths or food without washing.

title: Peak Corn, Wheat Crops Seen, Weather Permitting
description: CHICAGO, July 10If the weather continues in nearnormal patterns for the next five weeks, American farmers are now expected to produce the largest corn and wheat crops in the nation's history.

title: La Forza Takes Sailing Honors
VICTOR BORELLA, ROCKEFELLER AIDE
description: Victor Borella, the chief labor consultant to Vice President Rockefeller and a longtime aide of the former New York Governor, died of heart failure Wednesday night at Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover, N. H. He was 68 years old and lived in semiretirement on a farm near Enfield, N. H.

title: Yacht Racing Results AT INDIAN HARBOR Y. C.
description: Division I (sail numbers ending in digits 1, 3 and 5; 20 started)1, Jim Miller, Manhasset Bay; 2, Todd Elhers, Manhasset Bay; 3, Robert Howard, Manhasset Bay; 4, Jim Manning; 5, Bill. Drews; 6, Robert Ehrlich; 7, William Newkirk; 8, Paul Strauch; 9, Mindy Katz; 10, Tom Keogh.

title: Advertising
description: After 16 years of use, the You've got a friend at Chase Manhattan line will disappear next week as a theme line in the bank's advertising. It was probably the best known bank slogan around these parts, but did it have a meaning?

title: Britain's Hopeful Tack
description: A new factor is emerging on the British scene to help Prime Minister Harold Wilson in his effort to curb the country's runaway inflation by holding wage increases to 10 per cent. For the first time, mounting public concern about inflation appears to have stirred feelings of responsibility, and even guilt, within the trade unions, whose wage demands have been the chief motor in accelerating the retail price increase to a current annual rate of 48 per cent.

title: World Price Level Seen on Oil Despite Moves by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) President Ford's top energy policy makers said today that United States oil prices are bound to rise to near the worldwide level regardless of what Congress tries to do to contain them.

title: WILSON TO OFFER PAY PLANS TODAY
description: LONDON, July 10  The British Cabinet put the final touches today on measures aimed at reducing inflation by imposing a 10 per cent limit on new wage increases.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The police in Trenton were searching for two men wanted in connection with the beating of a legless 78yearold man in a $2 robbery. According to the police four young men beat and robbed Alphonso Clark Wednesday night after they accosted him as he was sitting in a wheelchair in his home.

title: Court's Obscenity Ruling Is Still Producing Confusion
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10Two years after the Supreme Court handed down a pornography ruling, its obscenity guidelines are creating problems for the lower courts, frustrating both prosecutors and defense attorneys and causing confusion in the thriving pornography industry.

title: 2 Bond Issues Find Willing Buyers, Lifting Sales of New Corporate Issues Above $1Billion in 2 Days
description: Underwriters found willing buyers yesterday for two large offerings, thereby lifting their sales of new corporate issues above the $1billion mark in the last two days. Snapped up yesterday were $300million of debentures for Standard Oil of California and a financing package of $250million for Ford Motor Credit.

title: Money
description: Money

title: About Real Estate
description: To 57th Street has fallen an unusual distinction. A new building, the Galleria, is making the exclusive, cosmopolitan shopping and residential thoroughfare a frontier in exotic forms of realestate development.

title: Coleman Concedes Views Exceeded His Race Data
description: Dr. James S. Coleman, the sociologist who provoked national debate recently by saying his new research showed that courtinduced school desegregation had served only to swell the white exodus from the big cities  now concedes that his public comments went beyond the scientific data he had gathered.

title: Senate Rejects Sixth Attempt To Stop New Hampshire Debate
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Senate, failing for the sixth time to shut off debate on the disputed New Hampshire Senate election, decided today to shift its attention to other legislation, such as a series of energy bills the Democrats want to pass before Congress starts la onemonth recess Aug. 1.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: LOG CABIN BUILDER WINS PERMIT FIGHT
description: ARLINGTON, Wash., July 10 O. C. Helton, 39 years old, of nearby Darrington, has won a court battle that may enable him to finish the log cabin that he is building with the technique taught to him by his grandfather.

title: Stargell's Bat Beats Dodgers
description: Willie Stargell of Pittsburgh hit his 15th home run of the season last night in Three Rivers Stadium, a tworun blow in the eighth inning that gave the Pirates a 4.1 victory over the faltering Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: FRANCE EXPELLING 3 CUBAN OFFICIALS
description: PARIS, July 10France expelled three highranking Cuban diplomats today in connection with the worldwide search for a man called Carlos, who is believed to be an important link in an international terrorist network.

title: Conflict of Interest Laid to Congressman
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 The chairman of Common Cause, the selfdescribed publicinterest lobbying group, called today for the resignation of Representative Robert L. F. Sates from his chairmanship of a House Appropriations subcommittee because of clear conflicts of interest.

title: PROJECT SOUGHT BY SOLZHENITSYN
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn proposed yesterday that Columbia University participate in a multivolume history project that would correct what the exiled Russian author considers to be the false view of the Russian revolution that exists in the West.

title: Portugal's Socialist Party Pulls Out of Government
description: LISBON, Friday, July 11The Socialist party resigned from the Portuguese Government early today, giving as the reason the military takeover of the Socialistcontrolled newspaper Repblica.

title: New View of Women and Power
description: Two feminist educators said here yesterday that because of the impact of the women's movement, many women have lost their fear of power and are no longer reluctant to use it for change.

title: Met Museum Sets 2 Closings a Week In Budget Cutback
description: Starting next Tuesday, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will he closed to the public two days a week. The additional shutdown, which adds Tuesdays and Tuesday evenings to the regular Monday closings, is a result of the city's fiscal plight, which has caused a 20 per cent reduction in the museum's security force, the Metropolitan says.

title: London Search Intensifies
description: LONDON, July 10The search for antiIsraeli terrorists intensified here today with the disclosure that the man known as Carlos was seen in London on Sunday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JULY 11, 1975

title: The Jewish Radical: A Crisis of Conscience
description: Where is the Jewish radical of the sixties? What has become of him?

title: HighLevel Backing Cited In C.I.A.DrugUnit Spying
description: WASHINGTON, July 10John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, and Richard Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence, authorized a secret program to infiltrate the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs with agents, a program that the Rockefeller commission later found illegal, authoritative sources reported today.

title: Amin Releases Briton He Had Doomed
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 10 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda today freed Denis Cecil Hills, the British lecturer he twice threatend to execute by firing squad. The President took the action while discussing future relations between Kampala and London with Foreign Secretary James Callaghan of Britain.

title: BROKERS ESTIMATE RATE WAR'S COST
MRS. LUDWIG ERHARD
description: KREUTH, West Germany, July 9 (AP)Louise Erhard, the wife of Dr. Ludwig Erhard, who was Chancellor of West Germany from October, 1963, to December, 1966, died yesterday in this village in southern Bavaria. She was 82 years old.

title: CATHOLIC UNIT ENDS DEAL WITH INDIANS
description: KESHENA, Wis., July 10The Alexian Brothers, a small Roman Catholic religious order, told the Menominee Indian tribe here today that it was canceling its agreement to give the Indians a huge monastery near their reservation.

title: GOLD
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: Party Faithful and the Favored Count Bonuses and Blessings
description: ALBANY, July 11The final secret of the legislative session who are those favored politicians receiving bonus money from their leaderswas unveiled today in the fine print of the supplemental budget and the private griping of envious lawmakers.

title: Tourists Flock to New York
description: New York City played host to 16 million visitors in 1974, including 1.6 million from oversey, according to Preston Robert Tisch, chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. He estimated the visitors spent a total of $1.25billion.

title: Market Place
description: The stock market's snappy comeback in the first half of 1975 clearly indicates that investors still like best the companies marked by supergrowth in the pastcompanies such as I.B.M., Eastman Kodak, Sears, Procter & Gamble, Merck, American Home Products, Xerox, Johnson & Johnson and Coca Cola.

title: Dr. Ralph Ogden, 77, Dies, ExHead of Radium Society
description: SPRINGVALE, Me., July 11 (AP)Dr. Ralph T. Ogden, a former president of the American Radium Society, died yesterday at Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 77 years old.

title: Saigon Denies It Killed Officers During Reeducation Program
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 (Agence FrancePresse) The ruling military committee said today that people should not believe false rumors aimed at sowing suspicion among the families of persons undergoing reeducation. The statement followed persistent rumors that dozens of former South Vietnamese officers had been killed while attending reeducation courses organized by the revolutionary administration.

title: POLICE HEAD CITED IN SUFFOLK INQUIRY
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 11.The Suffolk District Attorney disclosed today that he was investigating the county's Police Commissioner on charges of corruption, misconduct in office and other, more serious crimes.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Cole, 66204, Leads by Shot; Miller 2 Behind, Nicklaus 4
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 11  A 100to1 shot when the British Open golf tournament began, Bobby Cole of Boksburg, South Africa, came in today with his second straight round of 66 for a threeday total of 204 and a onestroke lead over lack Newton of Australia.

title: CASTRO RECALLS DOZENS OF PLOTS
description: SANTIAGO, Cuba, July 10 (Reuters)Premier Fidel Castro said today that he knew of plans for dozensmaybe 40 to 60attempts against his life by counterrevolutionary groups controlled by the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: GRAINSAL TALKS GOING ON IN SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (Reuters)United States businessmen are negotiating in Moscow a new massive grain sale to the Soviet Union, Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JULY 12, 1975

title: In India Village, Drought Eclipses Crisis
description: CHHAPRAULI. India, July 11To the 7,000 people of this dustblown farm village 50 miles north of New Delhi the price of fertilizer and the coming the rains are much more pressing concerns than whatever Prime Minister India Gandhi may or may not have done to the democratic ideal.

title: Islanders Want to Pack More In
description: More than finding a high scoring forward and an answer to Kate Smith, the New York Islanders' competitive future is resting heavily on the ability to satisfy one other crying needadditional seats in Nassau Coliseum.

title: Cuba Protests to France On Expulsion of 3 Diplomats
description: HAVANA, July 11 (Reuters) The Cuban Foreign Ministry today issued a strongly worded denial of illegal activities by any of its diplomatic personnel in France.

title: SCIENTIST SCORES CYCLAMATES BAN
description: BETHESDA, Md., July 11 (AP) The scientist whose research helped influence the Federal Government to ban cyclamates said today that that decision was not justified on the basis of his study.

title: Bill on Oil Agency Advances in Ottawa
description: OTTAWA, July 11Legislation establishing Canada's first Governmentowned company to produce oil and natural gas was passed by the House of Commons last night.

title: Excerpts From Wilson's Report on Pay Limits
description: LONDON, July 11Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Harold Wilson's statement to the House of Commons today describing the contents of his white paper limiting new wage increases:

title: LOUIS KRAFT, 84, OF JEWISH AGENCY
description: Louis Kraft, former executive director of the National Jewish Welfare Board, died yesterday at his home, 225 Central Park West. He was 84 years old.

title: C.I.A. in the Early NineteenFifties Was Among Pioneers in Research on LSD's Effects
description: The Central Intelligenc Agency was one of the pioneers in studying the drug LSD, having begun its research eight years before Dr. Timothy Leary swallowed his first dose of the powerful mindaltering substance.

title: Africa Can't Afford Him
description: President Idi Amin of Uganda became furious a few months ago when Denis Hills called him a village tyrant, so he arrested Mr. Hills and began an episode which served very dramatically to prove the British writer's point. Before releasing his prisoner this week after a protracted campaign by the British Government and the constructive intervention of President Mobutu of Zaire, President Amin played juvenile, sadistic and totally irresponsible games with Mr. Hills' life. Perhaps this disgraceful drama will be the catalyst for overdue action against President Amin by the Organization of African Unity.

title: U.S. Rebukes Chile
description: Robert S. Ingersoll, the Deputy Secretary of State, strongly admonished the Deputy Foreign Minister of Chile about the Chilean decision to deny entry to United Nations investigators of reported violations of human rights. Page 7.

title: Argentine Strongman Out In a Shuffle by Mrs. Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 11President Isabel Martinez de Pern today named a new eightman Cabinet that did not include Jos Lpez Rega, the controversial rightwing strongman who has been the focal point of the political and economic crisis that has engulfed Argentina during the last two weeks.

title: BRITAIN GETS PLAN LIMITING PAY RISES TOMB INFLATION
description: LONDON, July 11  Prime Minister Harold Wilson set forth a series of measures today aimed at limiting wage increases for nearly 25 million British workers to 6 ($13.20) a week for the next year at least.

title: WHEAT AND CORN SHOW PRICE GAINS
description: Prices of wheat, corn and soybeans leaped ahead yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, still influenced by reports that private grain companies were negotiating in Moscow to sell grams to the Soviet Union.

title: Julian Bond Rules Out Presidential Bid in '76
description: ATLANTA, July 11 (UPI)Julian Bond has ruled out a possible bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination, citing a lack of campaign funds.

title: CONTROL OF SMOKE NOW UNDER STUDY
description: A study on ways to control heavy smoke in highrise building fireslike the one that trapped hundreds of people in a 33story office building on 57th Street yesterday  has been undertaken for the city by the Center for Urban Environmental Studies of the Polytechnic Institute of New York.

title: ENERGY CONCERN IS NAMED IN SUIT
description: The Alaska Interstate Company of Houston said yesterday that it had filed a suit in the United States District Court in Delaware seeking to enjoin the Northwest Energy Company of Salt Lake City from acquiring any shares or a group of companies that jointly control the Northwest Pipelines Company, a principal asset of Northwest Energy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of Statement by Portugal's Socialists
description: LISBON, July 11 (Reuters)  Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of the Portuguese Socialist party's announcement yesterday of its withdrawal from the Government:

title: The Hustle Restores Old Touch to Dancing
description: At Marion's Manor in Bushwick and the Library discotheque near Central Park South, at graduation parties, weddings, sweet sixteens and proms, dance partners are doing the hustleand touching each other once again.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly stated in an article in the New York Times Thursday that a special study by two consulting concerns had recommended that construction of the proposed rocks Island Dam on the Delaware River be started promptly. The recommendation was made by the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: *Won playoff.

title: Value of Jack Benny Estate Disclosed to Be $5,852,000
description: LOS ANGELES, July 11 (Reuters)Jack Benny, the late comedian who based his comic career on impersonating a penny pincher, left $5,852,000 when he died last December at the age of 80, it was reported here today.

title: Chinese Discover A Pottery Army Buried 2,000 Years
description: PEKING, July 11The Chinese have discovered a pottery army of thousands of lifesize figures of warriors and horses that has been buried near Sian, in the northwest, for more than 2,000 years.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: DR. NICHOLAS CHUBATY
description: Dr. Nicholas D. Chubaty, founder and until 1957, editor of the Ukrainian Quarterly here, died Thursday in Bergen Pines Hospital, Paramus, N.J. He was 85 years old and lived in Wyckoff, N. J.

title: Opera: Bolshoi's 2d War and Peace
description: For half of the distance, Prokofiev's War and Peace sounds like an opera of the first importance. The Peace scenes, which come first, contain lovely music, and the Bolshoi Opera's production, at the second performance here on Thursday night, radiated a Tolstoyan sincerity in spite of staging and acting that vacillated between being charming in a faded style to being downright primitive. The work has a great deal to offer, make no mistake, and until the War breaks out it stands up beautifully.

title: Theater: New Saroyan
description: William Saroyan's new play, The Rebirth Celebration of the Human Race at Artie Zabala's OffBroadway Theater, is about what Mr. Saroyan thinks the theater has become in the absence of Mr. Saroyan. The play opened Thursday for a limited run at the Shirtsleeve Theater.

title: Antiques. Gunsmith Skill
description: Ironically, both the revulsion for guns and the reverence for period pistols and rifles have grown phenomenally over the last decade.

title: Tennessee Judge Jails Editor For Printing Article on Slaying
description: MADISONVILLE, Tenn., July 11Dan Hicks Jr., a country editor who has won national awards for courage in journalism, was put in jail today for publishing an article about a youth charged with murder.

title: African Women: Their Occupations Range From Magazine Editor to Fish Seller
description: LAGOS, NigeriaThe status of its women provides some of the clearest evidence that Black Africa has one foot in the jet age and the other in ancient times.

title: V.A. UNABLE TO FIND LOSTPATIENT CAUSE
description: CHICAGO, July 11 (UPI)A monthlong investigation has been unable to determine why the Veterans Administration hospital in suburban Hines, Ill., lost a speechless patient in a wheelchair for 25 hours or who was responsible for his disappearance, the V.A. conceded today.

title: Staten Island Gets a Commuter Yawl
description: With three sails aloft and 13 passengers on board, a 70foot yawl dating from Franklin D. Roosevelt's second term left the Battery at 5:15 P.M. yesterday for Staten Island to start what could be the world's zaniest commuter service.

title: REPAYING U.S. AID BY DOCTORS VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The House overwhelmingly approved today a bill that requires doctors and other health professionals to pay back to the Government in dollars or service a portion of The Federal subsidy for their education.

title: Red Sox Win, 118, For Fifth Straight
description: The Boston Red Sox won their fifth straight game last night by beating the Texas Rangers, 118, after overcoming an early 51 deficit at Fenway Park.

title: Miss Mann's 66 Leads by Shot
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 11 (AP)Carol Mann smashed one Ladies Professional Golf Association record and tied another today en route to a sixunderpar 66 for the firstround lead in the $65,000 tournament.

title: JOSEPH A. BROWNE
description: Joseph A. Browne, Who retired in 1974 after 37 years as a meteorologist for Trans World Airlines, died Tuesday. He was 63 years old and lived at 109 Wyatt Road, Garden City, L.I.

title: J. WILSON GADDIS
description: J. Wilson Gaddis, author of books on Korea and a former newspaperman, died Wednesday at his home, 117 Waverly Place. He was 65 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Terming President Ford's sidestepping of a meeting with Aleksandr I. Solzhezdtaim last week an embarrassment to the United States Government, Senator Ernest F. Hollings introduced a resolution yesterday urging that the dissident Soviet author be invited to address a joint session of Congress.

title: DETAILS CLARIFIED ON FORD STOCK SALE
description: DETROIT, July 11In an article in The New York Times yesterday it was reported that the Ford Motor Company would start selling off a block of 8 million shares of its stock acquired from the Ford Foundation to gain added revenue.

title: POLICEMAN SEIZED ON HEROIN CHARGE
description: A Manhattan police sergeant who won 20 awards for outstanding service, was arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court here on heroin charges.

title: Caterpillar Tractor Net Soars 116.8%
description: Earnings of the Caterpillar Tractor Company soared 116.8 per cent in the second quarter on a 35.9 per cent sales rise, the company reported yesterday.

title: Fiery Yet Quiet Chief
description: In public, fighting a union cause, Victor Gotbaum can be strong, harsh and determined, a street fighter, as befits a man who comes from a background of hard work. But in pri vote, his shoes off, the leader of 125,000 city workers who is battling with Mayor Beame is thoughtful and quiet, almost teddybearish, and, he says: I happen to like the Mayor. I happen to think he's a very decent guy.

title: Minting Approved For '76 Olympics.
description: OTTAWA, July 11 (UPI)Parliament adopted today legislation to permit the minting of gold coins which could increase sagging funds for the 1976 Olympic games by $60million.

title: Reader's Digest Accused Of Violating F.T.C. Order
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Julys. 11 (AP)The Federal Government has accused Reader's Digest of violating a Federal Trade Commission order to stop using deceptive practices in the sale of magazine subscriptions.

title: Peopleand Business
description: Leslie O. Barnes, who resigned this week as president and chief executive officer of Allegheny Airlines after almost 23 years in those posts, next week will be appointed president, chief executive officer and a member of the board of Ryder Systems, Inc., the Miamibased transportation vehicle leasing company.

title: KISSINGER CRITIC WINS A KEY POST
description: WASHINGTON, July 11John D. Hemenway, a former foreign service officer who has been a critic of the State Department, was elected the new president of the American Foreign Service Association today.

title: New Fighting in Angola Leaves About 200 Dead
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 11 (AP)Rival black liberation groups staged heavy attacks on each other's strongholds last night and early today. Authorities estimated that 200 people were killed and scores wounded.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed higher yesterday in active but decreased trading, despite profit taking late in the session. Similar conditions prevailed in the OvertheCounter market.

title: 18Member Groap Is Set Up by GATT To Handle Crises
description: GENEVA, July 11An 18member unit that is to serve as a highlevel task force to meet emergency situations in world trade relations has been established under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: Argentine Strongman Out In a Shuffle by Mrs. Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 11President Isabel Martinez Pern today named a new eightman Cabinet that did not include Jos Lpez Rega, the controversial rightwing strongman who has been the focal point of the political and economic crisis that has engulfed Argentina during the last two weeks.

title: Bread Prices Investigated
description: White bread, selling In the New York area for 65 cents the 1pound 6ounce loaf47.2 cents a poundhas come down only 2 cents a loaf since it rose to a record level last January.

title: Pelican Population Drops
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. (UPI) The brown pelican population in California has dropped to only 300 pairs because environmental pollution has caused thinshelled eggs that prevent proper birth of offspring.

title: Forbes Said to Jab Stick
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 11 (UPI)Robert Utecht, the North Stars' public address announcer, testified today Dave Forbes of the Boston Bruins drove his hockey stick into the eye of Henry Boucha of Minnesota with a jabbing motion in a fight during a game Jan. 4.

title: NEW RIGHTS GIVEN BIKERS PRISONERS
description: Additional rights for inmates at the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island were granted yesterday by Judge Morris E. Lasker in Federal District Court here.

title: 90Minute Blaze Traps 400 in Skyscraper
description: Four hundred people were trapped for an hour and a half in the 33story Squibb building at 40 West 57th Street yesterday after a fire broke out on the 18th floor. The fire filled the upper floors with smoke and stranded terrified office workers who could not make their way down the smoky staircases.

title: A $2 Toll at Jones Beach Is in Effect After Struggle
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 11 The Jones Beach State Parkway Authority began collecting an extra $1 fee for the State Department of Parks and Recreation at midnight tonight after a day marked by legal maneuvering.

title: F.A.A. Orders Jumbo Jet Changes to Avert Crashes
description: The Government ordered ma jar design changes yesterday for all United States jumbojet airliners to enable them to withstand the kind of damage that led to the crash of a McDonnell Douglas DC10 outside Paris in May, 1974. All 346 persons on board were killed in the disaster.

title: Body of L.I. Doctor's Wife Exhumed in Death Inquiry
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 11The body of the wife of a surgeon from Kensington, L.I., was exhumed from a cemetery in Hazelton, Pa., today to determine whether she had died of a stroke, as her husband had sworn in signing her death certificate, or as a result of a fatal injection of Demerol, a painkilling drug.

title: Bridge:
description: A declarer who has two suits to develop in a notrump contract often has to think carefully about the timing of his plays. If the opponents are threatening to establish their own suit he may need a switchback play, which consists of stealing a trick in one suit and then developing the other.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Greg Luzinski of the Philadelphia Phillies, who leads the National League in home runs and runs batted in, was cnosen yesterday by Manager Wait Alston as one of the league's reserve outfielders for the AllStar game against the American League on Tuesday night in Milwaukee. The starting teams had been selected earlier in fan balloting.

title: U.S. Plans to Sell Jordan $350Million in Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Ford Administration informed key members of Congress today that it would sell Jordan a modern airdefense system costing about $350million, more than three times what had initially been disclosed.

title: Malta Still Holding Out Special to The New York Times
description: GENEVA, July 11  Malta continued to hold out alone against strong American and Soviet pressure by refusing to endorse July 30 as a target date for a ceremonial closing session of the European security conference.

title: U.S. Aide Rebukes Chile For Barring U.N. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Deputy Secretary of State Robert S. Ingersoll, strongly admonished Chile's Deputy Foreign Minister Wednesday and again today over the decision of his Government to deny entry to a United Nations panel seeking to investigate charges of violations of human rights.

title: Suburban Real Estate Rises
description: CHICAGO (UPI)Real estate assessments in Chicago rose 3.4 per cent in 1973, but assesments for the Chicago suburbs jumped 10.8 per cent, according to Cook County Assessor P. J. Cullerton.

title: Clouds May Be Seeded for Apollo Shot
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 11American space officials laid plans today to alter the Apollo, launching time slightly and to seed storm clouds should it become necessary to get the spacecraft into orbit on schedule Tuesday for its planned rendezvous with a Soviet Soyuz spacecraft.

title: Callaghan Asserts Uganda Was Given No Concessions
description: LONDON, July 11 (AP)Foreing Secretary James Callaghan of Britain says he made no concessions to President Idi Amin of Uganda to win freedom for Denis Cecil Hills.

title: Article 3  No Title
Recession Changes Public's Food Choices
description: The recession, coupled with higher prices, is affecting eating habits and causing changes in the demand for certain types of food.

title: Star Game In W.T.T. Set Tonight
description: LOS ANGELES, July 11The first AllStar game ever staged by World Team Tennis, and the first national telecast of any of the twoyearold league's events, will take place tomorrow night at the Los Angeles Sports Arena.. It will be shown live by the National Broadcasting Company at 11:30 P.M., New York time (Channel 4).

title: Senate Backs Tuna Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) The Senate passed legislation today that would put into effect a 1966 agreement between the United States and 17 other nations on the management and conservation of Atlantic tuna. Under the legislation representatives of 18 nations would meet every two years to review the number of tuna in Atlantic schools.

title: John Jablow Weds Sande Robinowitz
description: Sande Gerth Robinowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Gerth of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married here yesterday afternoon to John George Jablow, head of the economics department at Heald College in San Francisco, where he also teaches engineering. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Jablow of New York, at whose home Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Nuclear Cruiser
description: President Ford's strange effort to slip a $1.2billion nuclearpowered cruiser into the $25billion military procurement bill after its preliminary passage by both houses of Congressdisguising the announcement as an initial $60million request for longlead itemsis worse than the fiscal irresponsibility of which he has accused Capitol Hill. It deserves a veto from Congress.

title: Art: Myriad Microdramas of Jacques Callot
description: WASHINGTON  If the mark of a great artist is to be found in his ability to create a distinctive world of his ownto impose on our consciousness a network of images so comprehensive and so dramatic that we can never again imagine a historical reality entirely separate from his own encompassing vision of it  then Jacques Callot is surely one of the greatest artists who ever lived.

title: Chinese Discover A Pottery Army Buried 2,000 Years
description: PEKING, July 11The Chinese have discovered a pottery army of thousands of lifesize figures of warriors and horses that has been buried near Sian, in the northwest, for more than 2,000 years.

title: Wajima Choice In Dwyer Today
description: Wajima has yet to win a stakes race, but the Kentuckybred son of Bold Ruler is favored today to take the Dwyer Handicap at Belmont Park. Steve DiMauro, who trains Wajima, the otterea two reasons yesterday as to why the colt should score. First, said DiMauro, he cost $600,000, and second, he comes from the last crop of Bold Rulers. The $600,000 Was paid for the horse at the Keeneland yearling sales by a syndicate of eight, four Japanese and four Americans. Now the syndicate is made up of Harold Snyder, Jim Scully, James Welsh, Americans, and Zeny Yoshida, a Japanese.

title: Wallace Vows Injury Won't Hurt His Style
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 11 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace, his broken, paralyzed left leg in a hiphigh cast, came out of 10 days of seclusion today vowing that the injury would not interfere with his political style.

title: HETTY V. M. BARRATT
description: Hetty Vincent Marshall Barratt, a portrait painter who had been on the educational staffs of the Metropolitan Musem of Art and the Boston Museurn of Fine Arts, died Friday at her home in Southport, Conn. Her age was 85.

title: Eichelberger Takes Lead By 5 Shots
description: MOLINE, Ill., July 11 (UPI) Dave Eichelberger, with sharp putting, ripped open a fivestroke lead today at the halfway point of the $75,000 Quad Cities open with a sixunder par 65. His total for the 36 holes was 132,

title: Death Inquiry Is Reopened in LSD Case
description: A man believed to have been a Central Intelligence Agency employe withheld major facts from the Manhattan Medical, Examiner's office about the death of a biochemist who was surreptitiously given LSD in an agency drug experiment 22 years ago, the authorities said yesterday.

title: $7.5Billion Appropriation Approved by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The House approved today a $7.5billion appropriation for the Treasury, White House and other agenciesafter trimming the amount requested for former President Richard M. Nixon's staff.

title: Ivens Sherr, 88, Chairman Of a Glove Manufacturer
description: Ivens Sherr, chairman of Fownes Brothers & Co., Inc., died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 18 East 82d Street.

title: Ankara Newsman Arrested, Security Breach Charged
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 11 (AP)  Mehmet Ali Kislali, publisher of the Turkish newsweekly Yanki, has been arrested on charges of violating national security, martial law, court authorities said today.

title: Paterson Again Under the Kliegs for a New Movie
description: PATERSON  First bitten by the movie bug following World War I when it was the site of several episodes of the silentscreen serial Perils of Pauline, this 200yearold industrial complex is currently the locale for yet another film, to the delight of city officials, local merchants and many residents.

title: Sugar Prices Increased For 2d Time in a Week
description: Grocery and industrial sugar prices were raised again yesterday for the second time in less than a week. An increase Monday ended a long downward trend in sugar prices during which prices plummeted 67 per cent from their peak last November. Citing rising costs of raw sugar as it did on Monday, the Amstar Corporation, the country's largest, refiner, announced wholesale price rises of $5 per 100 ??ounds of grocery sugar and ?? per 100 pounds of ipdus trial sugar. The price rises were effective at the close of business yesterday.
