title: Stock Market Eases 0.78 In Relatively Heavy Day
description: Stock prices milled around for the second consecutive day yesterday despite relatively heavy trading.

title: U.S. Plans to Sell Jordan $350Million in Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Ford Administration informed key members of Congress today that it would sell Jordan a modern airdefense system costing about $350million, more than three times what had initially been disclosed.

title: Play: Skin of Our Teeth
description: WASHINGTONThe John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is undertaking a most ambitious Bicentennial program at its Eisenlower Theater, where it is spresenting a whole year of American plays, a few new but most old. It has started with a revival of Thornton Winder's 1942 comedy, The Skin of Our Teeth. Written at a time in World War when optimism must have seemed a patriotic duty, this cartoonstrip story of Mr. Antrobus and his family with their neversaydie ability for survival may seem a little simplistic, even panglossian, today.

title: Contaminated Water Closes Crater Lake National Park
description: CRATER LAKE, Ore., July 11A contaminated water supply resulted in the closing today of Crater Lake National Park.

title: Ford Indicates Its Prices On Autos May Rise by 6%
description: DETROIT, July 11The Ford Motor Company, in an action similar to one taken by the General Motors Corporation last week, notified its dealers today that they would be protected for any price increase of more than 6 per cent on cars and light trucks and 7 per cent on heavy trucks on orders for 1976 models taken for fleet buyers. The step by Ford and G.M. does not indicate what the expected final price increases will be next fall.

title: Curfew Set for Menominees After Blasts
description: KESHENA, Wis., July 11A dusktodawn curfew was ordered by law enforcement officers here today for the Menominee Indian reservation in northern Wisconsin and tourists were told not to venture onto Indian land after a series of fire bombings and shooting incidents.

title: POLICE HEAD CITED IN SUFFOLK INQUIRY
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 11The Suffolk District Attorney disclosed today that he was investigating the county's Police Commissioner on charges of corruption, misconduct in office and other, more serious crimes.

title: END OF RECESSION IN STATE IS SEEN
description: TRENTON, July 11 (UPI)The end of the recession is in sight in New Jersey, the state's Labor and Industry Commissioner, Joseph A. Hoffman, said today.

title: Yankees Crushed, Then Win
description: With two pitching specialists and their schizophrenic defense working, the Yankees divided a doubleheader with the Minnesota Twins last night at Shea Stadium.

title: BOTTLE HILL GIVES BLUEGRASS CONCERT
description: Bottle Hill, a sixpiece bluegrass group that started in New Jersey but now works out of upstate New York, had a hard time Thursday evening on Pier 15 at the South Street Seaport, what with rain, thunder and lightning to distract the audience. In addition, the amplifying system (the group's own) was fuzzy an full of static, although Doug Tuchman, producer of the outdoor concert, managed to replace it with a vastly better system after only half an hour.

title: Rosenbergs' Children Plan Suit to Obtain Trial Files
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The sons of convicted atomic spies Julius and Ethel Rosenberg say they still plan a law suit to obtain secret Government files on their parents' case despite a Justice Department offer of many of the files.

title: Top Award Reported In Thalidomide Births
description: MONTREAL, July 11 (Reuters)A company that manufactured thalidomide has offered what were termed the largest settlements ever in such cases to 28 Quebec children bor deformed after their mothers had taken the tranquilizer, their lawyers announced here today.

title: Laboratory Method Is Utilized to Test Tires
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Allied Chemical Corporation has developed a laboratory method that tests tires by measuring their sidewall temperatures and simulating the strain that the cords undergo in service on the road. The invention is expected to end industry's heavy dependence on tire tests through actual highway use, and to reduce both testing time and the related cost.

title: Worldwide Explorers In a Subatomic World
description: Oh, my God! said Wolfgang Kurt Herman Panofsky of Stanford University, as he paced in front of the computer display that showed what was happening inside a ring where beams of atomic particles blasted into each other.

title: Article 2  No Title
Carman H. Messmore, 93, Dies; Art Dealer to Lehman, Mellons
description: Carman H. Messmore, an art dealer instrumental in forming many wellknown collections of old masters, died yesterday in Southampton (L.L) Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in Southampton and at 655 Park Avenue.

title: German and Swiss Bankers Skeptical on London Moves
description: BONN, July 11Bankers in Dsseldorf, Frankfurt and Zurich were generally skeptical today that the British Government's wagecontrol package would achieve its goal of bringing the nation's inflation rate down to 10 per cent by this time next year.

title: I.B.M PROFIT OFF 2.9% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday a 2.9 per cent decline in net income for the second quarter.

title: Lone Island Town Has Identity Crisis
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L. I., July 11  This growing community on Long Island's North Shore has four names and is now searching for a fifth.

title: MORTGAGE LENDERS GIVEN GUIDELINES
description: Guidelines for allocation among mortgage lenders of the $1billion worth of 7 per cent conventional home loans it will purchase for the Government National Mortgage Association were issued yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation in Washington.

title: For Many, Lunchtime Is a Time for More Than Just Eating
description: Where is it written that lunchtime is the time to eat lunch?

title: Somali Nomads Being Shifted to New Lives
description: KUTWARI, Somalia  Last fall, when the rains failed to come for the fourth consecutive year, the famine among the Somali nomads who are grazing their camels, sheep and cattle in the highlands near the Ethiopian border reached disaster proportions.

title: Freshman Democrats Plan Classes in House Problems
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Trying to escape the intensity of. Washington, a group of freshman Democratic members of Congress are taking a class trip this weekend to the Virginia countryside for a series of conferences on their first six months in office.

title: Income Tax Is Backed By Mayors at Hearing
description: CAMDEN, July 11 (AP)Mayors of some of the state's big cities called today for the Legislature to display courage and leadership and approve an income tax proposed by Governor Byrne.

title: Oliphant & Co: Raises Profits and Revenues
description: Despite the price war among stockbrokers for the business of big financial institutions, Jas H. Oliphant & Co., Inc., a brokerage house that does most of its business with institutions, reported yesterday that its earninp and revenues advanced in the second quarter.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP) Money rates for Friday.

title: BRITAIN GETS PLAN LIMITING PAY RISES TO CURB INFLATION
description: LONDON, July 11  Prime Minister Harold Wilson set forth a series of measures today aimed at limiting wage increases for nearly 25 million British workers to 6 ($13.20) a week for the next year at least.

title: Shift by Utilities to Coal Is Uncertain
description: The Government's program to reduce the use of oil and natural gas and increase the use of coal by electric utilities is being given a questionable chance of success by many energy, industry and Government officials involved in the project.

title: STATE IS CHALLENGED ON LIST OF DOCTORS
description: The New York Public Interest Research Group has filed suit in Federal District Court in Utica against the State Education Department and the Board of Regents to strike down a ruling that physicians may not cooperate with the compilation of doctors' directories.

title: Holtzman Bill Designed To Defuse Arab Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, in a bill with nearly 100 cosponsors in the House, is seeking stiff criminal and civil penalties for companies that engage in secondary boycotts of American businesses. The Brooklyn Democrat told the Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on Monopolies and Commercial Law at a hearing here that Arab nations and businesses had not only refused to deal with American companies with Jewish owners or employes or those that trade with Israel, but that they also had tried to force other American concerns to discriminate against these companies.

title: Portuguese Yielding 2 Tiny Cocoa Islands
description: SAO TOME, July 11 (Reuters)Tomorrow Portugal is to hand over So Tom and Principe, her tiny islands of the central west coast of Africa, to one of Africa's leastknown liberation movements.

title: C.I.A. Report Says Aides Worked at Other Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Central Intelligence Agency had detailed its employes to serve for various periods in the White House and in such executive departments as Commerce and Treasury, according to a 1973 report of the agency's Inspector General.

title: A.F.T CONVENTION BEGINS IN HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, July 11Albert Shanker, the president of the Amerikan Federation of Teachers opened his organization's annual convention here yesterday advocating that he and the newly elected head of the rival National Education Association discuss the possibility of merging the two groups.

title: AGENCIES TO REQUIRE MORE DATA BY BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (Reuters)Banks will be required to make public more information about their operations under tentative guidelines adopted by four Federal agencies, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FACADES Two new art exhibition indicate something different in visual exploration this weekend at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle. One show features drawings and photographs by Roger Dean, the British artist who has designed more than 60 record covers and posters for British rock bands, including Yes and Osibisa. The other show, Illusion In Nature and Art, sets up a deceptive miniworld in science and the arts for audiences of all ages.

title: Kissinger Will Meet Rabin Today for Talks on Sinai
description: BONN, July 11Secretary of State Kissinger flew here tonight for talks with Israel's Premier, Yitzhak Rabin, on issues holding up a new IsraeliEgyptian agreement on troop withdrawals in Sinai.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Brendan Gill has been sgned to prepare a 100,000word life of Charles A. Lindberet, which Harcourt Brace Joyanovich plans to publish in the spring of 1977 to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Mr. Lindbergh's nonstop solo flight from New York to Paris. Mr. Lindbergh died of leukemia last August in Hawaii at the age of 72.

title: Highways vs. Rails
description: President Ford has proposed a modest but still useful step toward further diluting the sacrosanctity of the massive Highway Trust Fund. We hope he gives more than lip service to this measure, which could become something of a breakthrough in principle even if it scarcely begins to address the larger necessity of strengthening the nonhighway components of the nation's transportation system.

title: The Lutheran Dispute: Opposing Factions Move Toward Schism
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 11Prospects for a major schism within the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod rose critically this last week as the 51st convention of the church meeting here appeared to set the two sides in the dispute even farther apart. But it remained unclear how a formal split would come about or whether a dissident church could muster enough support to succeed.

title: U.S.Soviet Inspection Gain Confirmed
description: BONN, July 11Secretary of State Kissinger flew here today after completing talks in Geneva with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, which he said produced progress on a nucleararms pact.

title: A STATE JUSTICE IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: A State Supreme Court justice here, whose name has not been divulged, is under investigation by the Temporary StateCommission on Judicial Conduct on charges that he accepted gifts from a Brooklyn law firm. The gift allegedly included a weekend stay with his wife at a resort hotel.

title: Unveilings
description: SHAPIROFrieda. The Unveiling of a memorial, in the memory of Frieda Shapiro; will take place at Beth Moses ?? Firelawn, L.I., N.Y., Sunday, July 13, 1 P.M., on the grounds of Huron Club.

title: Sirica Cuts 4 Watergate Terms To the Periods Already Served
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) United States District Judge John J. Sirica, following a pattern he has set for major Watergate figures, today reduced to time already served the sentences of four CubanAmericans involved in bugging Democratic party headquarters.

title: House Unit Approves, 16 to 11, Renewed Arms Flow to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The House International Relations Committee voted 16 to 11 today to approve a bill today that would end the embargo on sales of American arms to Turkey.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JULY 12, 1975

title: As Turkish Cities Swell, Old Patterns Break
description: IZMIR, TurkeyWhen Osman Kibar was Mayor of Izmir a few years ago, a delegation visited him from one of the ramshackle areas that have sprouted around every Turkish city to house newcomers from the countryside. At the bus stop, the men complained, the curb is so low that when their wives step into the bus, idlers at a nearby coffee shop can see their legs.

title: Breast Cancer Linked to Drug Used to Treat Swollen Ankles
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Five Washington women have developed cancer of the breast after taking a drug used by millions of Americans for the treatment of swelling of the ankles, according to a brief report in the June 28 issue of The Lancet, a British medical magazine.

title: BENTSEN REPORTS $500,000 RAISED
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen raised nearly $500,000 in the first half of 1975 to finance his Presidential campaign but he spent only about $78,000 of it, saving the rest for crucial competition ahead.

title: Alaska Ending Plea Bargaining To Raise Confidence in Justice
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, July 11 (AP)The practice of negotiating pleas and sentences in criminal cases will end in Alaska Aug. 15 in a move Attorney General Avrum Gross calls to some degree experimental.

title: DRUG LAW EASED AS ALBANY NEARS CLOSE OF SESSION
description: ALBANY, July 11The Legislature headed tonight for adjournment of its longest session in 64 years, after a long day that included a rollback of one of the most controversial provisions of the state's twoyearold drug law and final passage of a bill to authorize the destruction of all arrest and trial records of people who are not ultimately convicted.

title: PARKING OFFICIAL TARGET OF INQUIRY
description: The director of the city's Pariting, Violations Bureau, Elbert C. Hinkson, was suspended yesterday following an inquiry into allegations that his office had solicited and received $700 in contribution, for a political dinner in his honor.

title: Astroland Park At Coney Island Damaged by Fire
description: An earlymorning fire destroyed a bar and restaurant and damaged several rides yesterday at the Astroland amusement nark in Coney Island.

title: Cycle Stage to Van Impe
description: PUY DE DOME, France, July 11 (UPI)  Lucien Van Impe of Belgium won the 14th stage of the 2,483mile Tour de France cycle race today in a breakaway ride up the Puy De Dome Mountain, where a countryman, Eddy Merckx, lost 32 seconds of his overall lead after he was punched in the ribs by a French spectator at the side of the road. About 160 yards from the line a spectator stepped out in the road and hit Merckx. The world champion, seeking a record sixth victory in this classic, lost important seconds as he fought to regain control of his bike.

title: BENJAMIN PECHMAN
description: Benjamin Pechman, founder and president of the Willmark Sales Company in Brooklyn, manufacturers and distributors of bakery and food specialties, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: CPC Data Clarified
description: In listing a decline of 13.3 per cent in earnings for CPC International far the second quarter of this year as compared with the same period in 1974, the Profit Scoreboard in yesterday's editions of The New York Times should have indicated that the decline occurred because of an extraordinary gain of $9.4million included in the 1974 figures.

title: Virginia Hamill Wed in London
description: Virginia Hamill, London news editor of The Washington Post, was married yesterday afternoon to John McCaughey, an editor on the foreign desk of The Financial Times of London. The Rev. Brian Daley performed the ceremony in London in the Farm Street Church of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Byrne Schedules Parleys To End Impasse on Taxes
description: TRENTON, July 11Governor Byrne and legislative leaders have scheduled continuous meetings beginning early Monday in an attempt to reach some accord on a tax package designed to close a budget gap that could curtail masstransit services by the end of the week.

title: Hear Ye!!! King William Bares His Soul
description: A dream: If I were king....

title: Giants' Twins' Hope to Double as Starters
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 11Pete Athas is close to signing a new contract with the Giants, but the guesing game continues over the Gold Dust Twins, Bobby Brooks and Clyde Powers.

title: C.I.A. Report Says Aides Worked at Other Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Central Intelligence Agency had detailed its employes to serve for various periods in the White House and in such executive departments as Commerce and Treasury, according to a 1973 report of the agency's Inspector General.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that Monmouth County had the right to take possession of private property that was to be used for a park without formally completing condemnation proceedings. The sevenmember court said in a unanimous decision that under the state's eminent domain laws a county, as much as a city, had the power to take lands immediately when it instituted condemnation proceedings.

title: PROFITS ADVANCE FOR FOOD CHAINS
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Large food chains have returned to their customary moderately high income levels after a period of low profits caused by a price war begun about three years ago by the Gerat Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Helen Wright Wed to P. H. Granger 3d
description: Helen Hudson Wright, daughter of Mrs. Maurice Katz of Mexico City and Cuernavaca, Mexico, and the late Harry Wright, was married yesterday afternoon to Percival Harkness Granger 3d, son of Prof. and Mrs. Bruce I. Granger of Norman, Okla. The Rev. Howard Moody performed the Episcopal ceremony in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League.

title: On History, Foolishness and Vietnam
description: In these last weeks I've come to Wonder if historians are not the needed resource in our time. We've been treating our misfortunes in Vietnam as though they were a peculiarly modern and American disaster. They are, in fact, merely the last in a long and remarkably consistent historical experience.

title: Cotton Markets
description: Sales 1,450.

title: Commodity Price Index Up During the Latest Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 193.5 from 189.8 last week.

title: BEIRUT BID SEEN TO FREE COLONEL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, July 12Anonymous donors distributed approximately 12 tons of food in an impoverished port neighborhood of Beirut yesterday in what was apparently an attempt to bring about the release of a kidnapped American Army colonel. Rumors swept the city that he would soon be freed.

title: Miss Phillips, Little Esther Of 1950's, at Bottom Line
description: Esther Phillips has moved a long way from the days when she was known as Little Esther and worked and suffered on the nineteenfifties rock 'n' roll, rhythm and blues circuits. The Esther Phillips who appeared Thursday at the Bottom Line is a fully matured singer, aware of and in control of her considerable vocal talents.

title: 5 Die as 4 Spanish Jets Fall
description: MADRID, July 11 (UPI) Four Spanish Air. Force C10 Saeta jets, flying in close formation, crashed into the Mediterranean off southeastern Spain today, killing four pilots and a crewman, the Air Force Ministry said.

title: Final Work for Liftoff of Soyuz Is Begun at Desert Base in Asia
description: MOSCOW, July 11  Space technicians at the Baikonur launching center in Soviet Central Asia, working in a scorching desert heat, have begun the final preparations for next week's SovietAmerican space mission.

title: In Memoriam
description: ALEXANDER Russel C. Forever ?? bared, forever loved. Mina.

title: HAZEL ERSKINE
description: RENO, July 11 (AP)Hazel Erskine, polls editor of Public Opinion Quarterly, a journal of opinion studiest died here yesterday. She was 67 years old.

title: U.S. Rebukes Chile
description: Robert S. Ingersoll, the Deputy Secretary of State, strongly admonished the Deputy Foreign Minister of Chile about the Chilean decision to deny entry to United Nations investigators of reported violations of human rights. Page 7.

title: Dressed to Kill
description: In the name of fashion, glamour and  the latestalleged masculinity, the fur models have been slithering down the runways again, adorned in the hides of practically any wild animal small or large that is not on the official endangered species list.

title: HIJACKING SUSPECT IS ARRAIGNED HERE
description: Some of the Americans live in hotels, some are kept in jails; some work and some don't, but all want to come back home.

title: BEIRUT BID SEEN TO FREE COLONEL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, July 12Anonymous donors distributed approximately 12 tons of food in an impoverished port neighborhood of Beirut yesterday in what was apparently an attempt to bring about the release of a kidnapped American Army colonel. Rumors swept the city that he would soon be freed.

title: Glen Curtails Bog Revels
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 11  The Bog, one of American auto racing's famous landmarks, has gone to weed. But all the traditions have been saved for this weekend's sports car races here.

title: MALAGASY STATION TO BE SHUT BY NASA
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 11 (AP)The space agency said today that it would close its tracking station in the Malagasy Republic on Monday, the day before the scheduled launchings of American and Russian spacecraft for rendezvous in space.

title: Dragon or Handshake?
description: I have come to you as a witness of what it is like there in the red burning stomach of the dragon, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn told a New York audience a few days ago. But Mr. Solzhenitsyn's image of the Soviet Union as the deadly, implacable foe of the United States contrasts strikingly with the very different image projected by the handshake Soviet and American astronauts are scheduled to exchange next week when their Apollo and Soyuz craft meet in outer space.

title: People in Sports
description: A minor league slugger who thinks there's no place like homehis homeis 21yearold Jim Smoak of the Auburn Phillies of the Class A New YorkPenn League. Smoak, who had hit safely in all 19 games he played and who was leading the circuit's batters with a .500plus mark, has decided that baseball is not for him and has returned to his home in Pinewood, S.C.

title: Byrne and Congressmen Press U.S. Aide on PATH Extension
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 Governor Byrne and members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation met today with Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman and his aides to urge approval of an 18mile extension of the PATH subways to Plainfield, N.J.

title: Books of The Times
description: From the earliest days of the Republic, Paris has exerted a special fascination for Americans as a place to visit, to tarry in or to live. The city's sparkle has drawn and dazzled all kinds, from men and women of serious mind to dedicated scamps and those down on their luck and hoping for a fresh start. The 10 years from 1785 to 1795 was no exception, as Yvon Bizardel's string of anecdotes suggests.

title: SEGREGATED DORMS ARE DEEMED ILLEGAL
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 11 The president of Rutgers University, Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, told the university Board of Governors today that five segregated student dormitories at Livingston Collegefour housing only black students and one only Puerto Ricanwere considered contrary to existing civil rights laws by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: HENRIETTA HARVIN
description: Henrietta Harvin, registrar of Union Theological Seminary since 1958, dide Thursday at her home in Northport, L.I. She also lived here.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 11, (Reuters)Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, introduced a bill today to repeal President Ford's $2abarrel tariff on imported oil.

title: 11TH BILL IS PASSED ON NURSING HOMES
description: ALBANY, July 11The Senate today unanimously approved the last of the bills for this session designed to end the abuse of patients in nursing homes and the misappropriation of millions of dollars in Medicaid funds by some unscrupulous people who operate them.

title: 2 Former Kennedy Aides Deny Assassination Plots
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Neither President Kennedy nor his brother Robert F. Kennedy nor senior members of the Kennedy Administration authorized assassination plots against foreign leaders, according to two key aides to the former President.

title: Tharp Qualifies No. 1 in Dragster
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., July 11  Richard Tharp, a 32yearold journeyman racer from Dallas, set a Madison Township Raceway Park track record today and qualified first for the National Hot Rod Association Summernationals drag races.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A meeting in Washington between Governor Byrne of New Jersey, the state's Congressional delegation and Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman on behalf of a proposed 18mile PATH extension to Plainfield, N. J., was termed indecisive.

title: U.S.MANILA PACT MAY BE REVAMPED
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The United States plans to meet Philippine requests and begin talks soon that may lead to the most significant changes in the 28yearold agreement that has allowed American forces to control key naval and air bases in the Philippines.

title: Two Vesper Pairs Gain In Rowing
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, July 11The first round of the Lucerne international regatta got under way today with qualifying and repechage or second chance heats. The regatta, which is held annually on Lake Rotsee the week after the Henley Royal Regatta, has been expanded to three days this year because of the record number of entries from 21 countries.

title: Portuguese Socialist Chief Says Party Is Still a Force
description: LISBON, July 11Portugal's Socialist party followed up its resignation from the coalition Government today by serving notice that it would not be shunted aside from the revolution.

title: Reds Sweep Mets, 43, 41
DRUG LAW EASED AS ALBANY NEARS CLOSE OF SESSION
description: ALBANY, July 11The Legislature headed tonight for adjournment of its longest session in 64 years, after a long day that included a rollback of one of the most controversial provisions of the state's twoyearold drug law and final passage of a bill to authorize the destruction of all arrest and trial records of people who are not ultimately convicted.

title: Citibank's Rate for Loans Raised to 7% From 7%
description: The First National City Bank yesterday raised its base lending rate on corporate loans to 7 per cent from 7 per cent.

title: New Beach Restrictions Imposed by Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 11  This exclusive shorefront community has imposed stringent regulations limiting access to its beaches by outsiders following three visits of up to 60 children from minority groups in Hartford in the last three weeks.

title: Despite Outward Amity, School Board Seems Torn
description: In recent years the annual election meetings of the New York City Board of Education have become carefully arranged events designed to present to the public a positive image of a united school board. The July 1 election followed the script as Isaiah E. Robinson was elected president and Dr. Robert J. Christen vice president, both by the unanimous vote of the sevenmember board.

title: Borg Put To Rout By Koch
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 11 (AP)Thomas Koch, the 30yearold Brazilian tennis star, whipped top  seeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden, 62, 63, today in quarterfinal round of the $50,000 Swedish open Championships. It was the first major upset of the tournament.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Now the New York Knicks are thinking about Wilt Chamberlain again, which means they can't be accused of not thinking big. And knowing Wilt, he'll think about the Knicks; he might eventually decide against making a comeback at age 39 after having missed two seasons, but he'll think about it. He was thinking about it when last sighted. In the hours after the Muhammad AliRon Lyle world heavyweight title fight in Las Vegas two months ago, he was striding through the lobby of the Tropicana Hotel when he stopped to taut to some people from New York that he knew. One of them recalled how the Knicks had pursued his services prior to the start of the National. Basketball Association season last year. He nodded and his deep voice rumbled. Wilt always sounds as if he's reading a proclamation.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: The Spanish Succession
description: MADRIDThe most striking thing about contemporary Spain is the generation gap that divides every aspect of society. There is a contrast in attitude between younger priests and older bishops. Army officers are split between coming youngsters and the last of the Civil War's crop of generals and colonels.

title: India Opposition Reports Arrest of Leading Reds
description: NEW DELHI, July 11 (UPI)The police arrested two Communist leaders during demonstrations protesting Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's stateofemergency decree, according to opposition sources.

title: Senate Unit Backs Oil Production Plan For Elk Hills Site
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) A Senate Armed Services subcommittee approved today oil production from the Navy's Elk Hills Petroleum Reserve, in California but refused to go along with a House decision to transfer control of the reserve to the Interior Department.

title: Ford, on a Midwest Tour, Lauds Old Virtues as Cure for U.S. Ills
description: CHICAGO, July 11President Ford counseled adherence to such traditional values as moderation, restraint, reason and steadiness as the cure for the nation's ills in a speech tonight that set the tone for his coming campaign.

title: C.A.B. Experiment
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board and the entire system of close Government regulation of domestic air transport for which the C.A.B. stands have come under increasing attack recently. In the White House, in Congress and among consumer groups doubts have been expressed with increasing frequency about the continued utility of the C.A.B.'s traditional approach, which is based upon limiting the number of airlines permitted to operate on particular routes and upon required Government, approval of fares.

title: Daytime Soap Operas on Radio Return to WOR, 14 Other Spots
description: The daytime soap opera, which disappeared from radio about 15 years ago, will return for an hour a day Aug. 4, on a new independent network that will include WORAM here.

title: 90Minute Blaze Traps 400 in Skyscraper
description: Four hundred people were trapped for an hour and a half in the 33story Squibb building at 40 West 57th Street yesterday after a fire broke out on the 18th floor. The fire filled the upper floors with smoke and stranded terrified office workers who could not make their way down the smoky staircases.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended July 11, 1975

title: Legislators, Near End, Play for the Cameras
description: ALBANY, July 11  The glowing red lights of live television cameras stimulated legislators to oratorical overkill today but failed to shame them out of political maneuverings not customarily practiced in onscreen color.

title: CORRECTIONS
Worldwide Explorers In a Subatomic World
description: Oh, my God! said Wolfgang Kurt Herman Panofsky of Stanford University, as he paced in front of the computer display that showed what was happening inside a ring where beams of atomic particles blasted into each other.

title: Sets Win, 2919, From Lobsters
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., July 11 The New York Sets defeated the Boston Lobsters, 2919, in World Team Tennis at the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Death Inquiry Is Reopened in LSD Case
description: A man believed to have been a Central Intelligence Agency employe withheld major facts from the Manhattan Medical Examiner's office about the death of a biochemist who was surreptitiously given LSD in an agency drug experiment 22 years ago, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Elizabeth Hispanic Group Plans Parade
description: ELIZABETH, July 11The HispanicAmerican committee of Elizabeth, representing some of the younger, more militant members of this city's sizeable Cuban population, will hold a parade and demonstration here Monday to show that the Spanishspeaking community is united, two committee members said today,

title: DISMISSAL ASKED IN MIGRANT SUIT
description: CAMDEN, July 11Attorneys for the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico asked Federal Judge Mitchell R. Cohen today to dismiss a suit alleging that the island conspired with South Jersey farmers and the state of New Jersey to send migrant workers illegally to substandard farm labor camps.

title: U.S. SHIP ATTACKED OFF THAILAND COAST
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (Reuters)An unidentified fishing vessel fired shots Tuesday at an American, ship off the coast of Thailand, the State Department said today.

title: The Screen:'Cleopatra Jones and the Casino of Gold'
description: "Cleopatra Jones and the Casino of Gold" is a trashy black exploitation movie, but its six foot two inch star, Tamara Dobson, who plays the title role, forestalls all criticism by coming on like one of nature's androgynous wonders.No one in his right mind would attempt to criticize a mountain peak, a sunset or hurricane. Miss Dobson is a large, beautiful, overwhelming presence whose real sexuality is denied by her movie role (that of a karate-chopping narcotics agent) and by costumes that seem to have been designed for a female impersonator.The setting is Hong Kong. The adversary is the Ms. Big of the international drug trade, a lesbian known as Dragon Lady, a character that the irrepressible Stella Stevens plays for something more than the little it's worth.The film, which opened yesterday at the Criterion, Apollo and 86th Street East Theaters, is a sequel to "Cleopatra Jones," the 1973 film that was defended in some quarters as being an example (though admittedly a fantastic one) of how black brothers and sisters might get together to clean up the hometown neighborhood. In this expansionist nonsense, the hometown neighborhood has been reinterpreted to include a British Crown Colony.

title: SENATE TO CONSIDER REQUEST BY WYMAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) After 17 days of debate, the Senate agreed today to consider the first issue in the New Hampshire election dispute.

title: SHORTER WORKDAY STILL UP THE AIR
description: An angry dispute over Mayor Beame's emergency powers developed yesterday into a muddled contretemps that left open the question whether 100,000 city workers would or would not leave their jobs for the day at 4 P.M. Monday.

title: ARTICLE SAYS ISRAEL GOT C.I.A. ATOMIC AID
description: The Central Intelligence Agency provided technological support in 1957 and 1958 to help Israel manufacture the atomic bomb, according to an article in Penthouse magazine.

title: Joseph M. Bernstein Dies; Translator and Editor, 66
description: Joseph M. Bernstein, translator and editor, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 3347 14th Street, Astoria, Queens. His editorial office was at 350 West. 31st Street.

title: A Wake for The Living
description: Andrew Lytle, fresh out of Oxford, Vanderbilt and Yale, must have been one of the youngest contributors to that classic 1930 symposium, I'll Take My Stand, in which John Crowe Ransom, Stark Young, Allen Tate, Robert Penn Warren, Donald Davidson and haifadozen other Southerners, at the outset of the Great Depression, told what was wrong with an increasingly industrialized, urbanized, secularized America. Since then, as teacher, novelist (The Long Night, The Velvet Horn etc.), critic, author of an outstanding biography of Bedford Forrest, editor of the Sewanee Review (from 1961 until two years ago), Lytle has continued to explore, expand and document the human and spiritual concerns on which that memorable 1930 stand taken.

title: Engagements
description: DanzyGreenidge

title: Charter Group Bid To End Plan Unit For City Is Scored
description: The Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday that a recommendation by the State Charter Revision Commission that the City Planning Commission be eliminated would blur a distinction between the legislative and executive branches of New York City government.

title: Boredom Lengthens Refugees' Days on Army Base
description: FORT INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., July 10Half a world away from home, the lovely little girl with a woman's eyes stands silently alone, a miniature Asian madonna on an old Army parade ground.

title: To Former Saigon Policeman, Home Is a Marine Tent in California
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 12Nguyen Van Khang came home this week. Sort of.

title: Dr. Coleman's Evidence
description: Dr. James S. Coleman has acknowledged that his public claim for his new research is based on an interpretation that goes beyond his evidence. He had said his research showed that massive courtordered desegregation, particularly busing, hastens white flight from the cities.

title: Theorem Paintings Shown in Princeton.
description: PRINCETONThe entrance hall of Bainbridge House, a facility of the Historical Society of Princeton, now boasts a display of theorem paintings handcrafted by Dorothy Plaganis, a Princeton area resident.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: It lives! There's one publication that's been selling so furiously in book stores during recent weeks that it would be included on the list above except for one fact. It's not a book. Star Trek Blueprints is a set of 12 reproductions of precise designs by Franz Joseph Schnaubelt showing every foot of every level of the fabulous starship Enterprise. Since midMay BaHantine Books has sold 150,000 sets, enclosed in a plastic and leatherette portfolio, at $5. This week it goes back to press for 100,000 more.

title: A Law to Help ExConvicts
description: The Legislature in Albany has voted to remove most of the state's legal prohibitions against the employment of former convicts, but any meaningful job increase is not expected overnight. The vote left standing a number of powerful obstacles to employment of the former prisoners. Nevertheless, civil libertarians and others who fought for passage of the measure believe it is a significant step toward ending recidivism.

title: Harriet L. Van Deren Is Remarried
description: Harriet Lyons Van Deren of Greenwich, Conn., widow of J. Franklin Van Deren, who was a senior partner in Cadwalader, Wicker.sham & Taft, New York law firm, was married yesterday afternoon to Constable MacCracken, who retired from the practice of law with Curtis, MalletPrevost, Colt & Mosle, lawyers here.

title: Hope Freeman Bride of Michael Hudner
description: Elizabeth Hope Freeman, daughter of Charles Wellman Freeman of Providence, R.I., and the late Mrs. Freeman, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Sweeney Hudner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Kennedy Hudner of South Swansea, Mass.

title: Edison Lore Lingers in West Orange
description: WEST ORANGE  Residents of this Essex County municipality say that, in terms of income and land usage, theirs is a very mixed community.

title: Despite 128 New York City Arrests, Real Change Is No Certainty
description: In October, 1972, Anthony Zecca was given a job as a construction inspector in the city's Buildings Department. Mr. Zecca is an undercover police detective working for the city's Department of Investigation. His assignment: To gather evidence substantiating charges that builders and developers customarily bribe city inspectors to overlook code violations and cut through red tape.

title: Luxury Comes to a Potato Field Gone to Seed
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.Large, luxurious houses are not exactly a novelty in this wealthy resort community. Housing starts are running ahead of last year, and real estate agents report brisk sales in the $100,000plus category.

title: BENJAMIN PECHMAN
description: Benjamin Pechman, founder and president of the Willmark Sales Company in Brooklyn; manufacturers and distributors of bakery and food specialties, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: Mrs. Peron Says She Will Not Step Down, But the Divisions Are Deep
description: BUENOS AIRESI am warning you, President Isabel Martnez de Pern told a group of dissident Peronist legislators. I have not packed my bags to leave the country and I will not surrender without a fight. I am going to oblige you to hang me on the Plaza de Mayo.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: FASHION
description: The women on these pages are all musicians. They sing rhythmandblues, rock, country and pop. Though they're more concerned about their performances than their clothes, each has developed her own onstage look. For some, that means blue jeans or black velvet pants, for others, a bejeweled transparent shirt or a slinky satin dress.

title: Stock Racer Toils In USAC Vacuum
description: Is it better to be a big fish in a small pond, or a small fish in a big pond? Well, said Butch Hartman, the stockcar race driver, there are two things you can do in racingmake money and be well  known. I guess I am a big Sports fish in a little pond, but at least I'm not broke, and that's more than I can say about some of my cousins in the South.

title: Moise and The World Of Reason
description: What is the future of a being with a chronically inflamed libido when the bird of youth has flown out of body and spirit? Bleak, one is inclined to reply, while looking for a way to escape the questioner as swiftly as possible. But this is not some aging barroom bore bemoaning his flimsy fate, this is Tennesse Williams and he has good re??son to wonder. Age brings wi?? it great rewards, we're tol?? The crepey throat is accomp?? vied by Wisdom, the rottin?? teeth by Acceptance of Thing Past. Surely the more bizarr proclivities of Williams's chat acters, such as the breakin of bones and devouring ?? flesh, are too enervating, to?? unrewarding, to carry int?? middle age, The question the?? and it is worth examining, i?? what finally comes out of al?? that grotesquerie? In this novel not much.

title: Lois Cobb Bride of Donald T. Rave Jr.
description: Lois Ann Cobb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Cobb of Port Washington, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Donald Theodore Rave Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rave of Brookville, L. I. The ceremony was performed in the Congregational Church, Manhasset, L. I., by the Rev. Raymond Fenner, the minister.

title: Reds Top Mets for 9 in Row
description: CINCINNATI, July 12 If Abner Doubleday had experimented with AstroTurf, Jerry Koosman said tonight, he never would have invented the game of baseball.

title: Far in the Future, Cooperation on the Grand Scale Will Be Needed
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  A flight into space is an exercise in optimism. Good, it is assumed, will somehow come of it. Success is a step into the future.

title: Atlantic City Aides Are Sued
description: ATLANTIC CITYA suit to force the Mayor and City Commissioners of this resort to take salary cuts of $15,000 a year each, and to repay the city about $250,000 in alleged overpayments over the last five years, has been filed in State Superior Court here.

title: Tuition Increase Rejected
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 12 (AP)The board of trustees of the University of New Hampshire has voted unanimously against raising instate tuition this fall.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Mendham Debates a Historical Area
description: MENDHAM  Councilmen and other officials here are reviewing plans to implement an ordinance that would designate several blocks of this Morris County town as a historical district. The area includes the central business section and a number of blocks adjacent to it.

title: Joint Space Shot: Its Meaning Is in The Groundwork
description: Though the drama in this week's scheduled rendevous of a Russian and an American space ship is to be played more than 100 miles above the earth, its real meaning is to be read on the ground, in the five years of negotiations, diplomatic and technological, that led up to the mission.

title: Marian Gillam Is Wed
description: Marian Stabler Gillam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Riggs Gillam Jr. of Norristown, Pa., and Gerald Arthur Gochennur, son of Mrs. Lewis Gochenour of Springfield, Ohio, and the late Mr. Gochenour, were married yesterday afternoon in the Providence Friends Meeting House in Oaks, Pa., in a Quaker ceremony. Mr. Gillam is vice president and secretary of the Philadelphia National Bank. The bride is a granddaughter of Clifford Riggs Gillam, retired president and chairman of the Buck Hills Falls (Pa.) Corporation, a private resort and country inn.

title: REVOLUTION OF THE
description: LISBON. A diffident little country, surrounded by Spain and the Atlantic, almost as big as Indiana, the poorest in Western Europe, a third of whose inhabitants are illiterate, is being courted by Moscow, anxiously warned by Washington and ostracized by Peking. Why are the three biggest powers so concerned? Because Portugal is going through a revolution, and not a superficial one, either, a change of Colonel Tweedledum for General Tweedledee, but a politicalsocialeconomic upheaval that could end up making Portugal the first Communistruled nation in Western Europe and a Moscoworiented one at that.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: $350.663 Raised by Carter In Campaign for Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Jimmy Carter, former Governor of Georgia, announced today that he had collected $350,663 for his Democratic Presidential campaign, with $125,179 received during the April 1 through June 30 reporting period.

title: R.W. Quackenbush Weds Miss Graham
description: Lesley Jeanne Graham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Graham of Briarcliff Manor, N, Y., was married there yesterday afternoon to Richard William Quackenbush, son of Col. Roger Quackenbush, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Quackenbush of Salem, Ore. The Rev. William Arnold performed the ceremony in All Saints Episcopal Church in Briarcliff Manor.

title: HALDEMAN VERDICT ASSAILED BY JUDGE
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 12 (AP)  A Federal judge says that a jury's decision not to assess damages against H. R. Haldeman in a $1million lawsuit went against weight of the evidence. But the judge refused yesterday to set aside the verdict or to order a new trial.

title: Wyckoff Park Approved
description: The creation of a twoacre park around the Wyckoff House in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn has been approved by the City Planning Commission. The Wyckoff House, believed to be the oldest existing dwelling in New York State, is a designated city landmark. The proposed park is bounded by Clarendon Road, Ralph Avenue, East 59th Street and the rerouting of a section of Ditmas Avenue.

title: The High Confidence That Followed the '67 War Has Been Chipped Away
description: BONN  Complete with moat and drawbridge, set in a deep wood northwest of Bonn, the 800yearold Gymnich Castle is the West German Government's most elegantly appointed guest house. Last week's tenant was Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, and he used the baroque setting for a meeting with Secretary of State Kissinger on the same thorny, frustrating issue that has absorbed them for months:

title: Bank Offers Help, but Not Money
description: A service publication of the First National City Bank is branching out into the world of bread and butter, specifically 426 supermarkets in the New York City area.

title: Jersey Weighs LandUse Shift
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey State Legislature is working on revisions of landuse laws that could give municipalities greater control of construction regulations and a larger role in protection of the environment

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Women in Classrooms, Not the Principal's Office
description: Those who contend that the public schools teach sexism have generally concentrated on examinations of the textbooks the schools use for signs of sexrole stereotyping. Now, however, their inquiries are taking them to a more obvious place: the principal's office.

title: HATHAWAY BACKS COAL LEASE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 12In his first important decision on an issue involving the conflict between energy development and environmental protection, Secretary of the Interior Stanley K. Hathaway has ordered the final preparation for a controversial environmental impact statement that seeks to justify the massive leasing of more federally owned coal deposits in the West.

title: The Boating Clinic
description: Almost anyone who owns a boat can make use of it in conjunction with a vacation trip, giving the added dimension of a cruise to holiday enjoyment, if planning and preparation are carried out properly.

title: CORRECTION
Miss Burns Engaged To Mark B. O'Brien
description: Mr. and Mrs. William George Burns of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Marot Burns, to Mark Bennett O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Joseph O'Brien of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: The restrooms along the way were cleaned up just in case
description: This book has been cast as humor but it is more than that. It is an offhand exercise in cultural anthropology, an unorthodox study of the worship rituals and intergroup relations of a fantastic totem society still functionine in postindustrial America.

title: Rhodesia's Black Leaders Agree to Agree
description: Black nationalist groups seeking to replace the white, supremacist regime of Premier Ian Smith in Rhodesia have once again patched up differences that have been hampering their efforts.

title: Timothy Douglas Kelly Weds Martha Varsha
description: Martha Irene Varsha and Timothy Douglas Kelly were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Graham Walworth at Trinity Episcopal Church in Northport, L.I.

title: Teachers Gain From New Tenure Law
description: TRENTONTeachers in New Jersey, plagued by employment uncertainty and cutbacks in education funds, have won a major victory. It came earlier this month, when Governor Byrne signed a bill requiring three yearly evaluations of those teachers who are not under tenure.

title: 4 Watergate Burglars Plan to Press Appeals
description: MIAMI, July 12 (UPI)Four of the Watergate burglars said today they were pleased that United States District Judge John J. Sirica had reduced their sentences to time already served, but added that they still planned to appeal their convictions.

title: Scare Economics
description: In determining great matters of statewhether in foreign affairs, national security or economic policythere have always been two schools of thought: One holds that analysis should provide an objective and independent basis for policy; the other that policy should call forth the analysis it requires, especially the analysis to be disclosed to the general public.

title: Goldin Says That He Is Opposed to Imposition of Nuisance Taxes
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that he would oppose the levy of nuisance taxes that were under consideration by the City Council as a way of avoiding perhaps thousands of employe layoffs.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Point of View
description: The housing shortage in New York City is over, but the city's housing problems are just beginning to come to the surface. No longer, in the future, will the simplistic belief that shortage is the main problem be able to dominate the thinking of housing policymakers.

title: BRIDGE
description: Within the past year slow play has become a controversial issue in New York tournaments. What action, if any, should be taken against a player who takes substantially more than his fair share of the time available for a deal or a group of deals? Unfortunately there is no solution of the type adopted in chess tournaments where a player who exceeds his time allowance automatically forfeits.

title: Steve Cady
description: Long before the puddles from the thunderstorm dried up, the players were back on the asphalt basketball court.

title: Paperbacks
description: CHALLENGE, by Vita SackvilleWest. (Avon, $1.50.) Revolution on an Aegean island brought to a disastrous climax by a Byronic Englishman and his lovesmitten cousin. A fine early (191819) work by one of the ornaments of the Bloomsbury set long suppressed because of the scandalous conditions under which it was written.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: With more Americans vacationing in their own backyards this year, you might expect the nation's swimming pool makers to be making quite a splash.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe oil industry is about to receive one of its occasional floggings on Capitol Hill.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The lease signed by this advertising firm of Doyle Dane Bernbach for 185.000 square feet of office spare at 437 Madison Avenue has an aggregate rent of approximately $42.5million.

title: Mr. Ford's Plan To Rearrange the Highway Fund
description: Since its creation in 1956, the Federal Highway Trust Fund, the repository of billions in gasoline taxes, has kept the nation's transportation policy firmly fixed on road building. President Ford has now proposed that the fund be drastically reduced and that most of its revenue be made available for nonhighway expendi tures.

title: New & Novel
description: In the year covered by this large but anemic novel, a British laborer named John Stevenson rises to become an independent contractor and makes his fortune as the builder of a railway tunnel on the Manchester and Leeds line. The year is 1839, a big one for Charles Dickens (Nicholas Nicklebv and Oliver Twist) on whose heels Malcolm Macdonald follows in exposing early Victorian social conditions. Life for the average workingman is rotten indeed, but a kindhearted scoundrel like Stevenson, with an eye for the main chance and a hand for forging letters of credit, can go far in a jungle economy.

title: SOVIET SEES GAINS IN WOES OF WEST
description: MOSCOW, July 9There is cautious but growing optimism among Soviet and East European leaders that the long unfulfilled Marxist prediction, of a spontaneous collapse of capitalism may finally be at hand

title: Not with a bang or a whimper but a shrug
description: There was a brief time, at the turn of the century, when the British Empire seemed to make sensethat is, seemed to be subject to normal laws of logic and economics, so that men could accurately assess its status in the world and plan for its developing future. Acquired by the British, so the historian J. R. Seeley said. in a fit of absence of mind, by 1900 it had become the greatest of all Empires ever known to man, had patterned the globe with its possessions and consciously thought of itself as an entity, a superPower, peer in form as in scale to Russia or the United States.

title: Bomb Threat Against Ford
description: CHICAGO, July 12 (AP)An anonymous phone call that a bomb had been planted in the Palmer House. Hotel was received while President Ford was holding a news conference at the hotel today, the abthorities said. No bomb was found, they said. The police said that a phone operator had traced the call to a downtown tavern.

title: The Therapeutic Value Of Placebos
description: Although it was the physician's principal tool until the development in the midnineteenth century of systematic pharmacology, the placebo has not been in good odor in the practice of modern medicine. Two Boston researchers have suggested, however, that the effect of the proverbial sugar pill may be a neglected therapeutic asset.

title: Film Notes: Hollywood Focuses on Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES Hollywood movies about Hollywood often have a bizarre fascination; it is intriguing to see how the filmmakers perceive themselves. Yet only a few of these insideHollywood moviesSunset Boulevard and The Bad And the Beautiful among themhave managed to find a large audience, and over the last decade, the genre has just about vanished. All at once, however, a large number of HollywoodonHollywood movies is in preparation.

title: Military TakeOver Is Seen In Shuffle Of Uganda Cabinet
description: NAIROBI. Kenya, July 12 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda shuffled his Cabinet today, giving the military effective control of the Government for the first time in the country's 13year history.

title: If You Go
description: . . . to the D.A.R. museum, you have to go around the corner to the small side entrance at 1776 D Street; the columned main entrance to Memorial Continental Hall, which faces 17th Street, has been closed since the 1968 riots.

title: Lenin smiled for him, Eleanor Roosevelt vouched for him
description: Robert Bernard Considine has written 20 books, 10 of them collaborations. They began in 1942 with MacArthur the Magnificent and include works on Babe Ruth, Jack Dempsey, Toots Shor, Harold Stassen (Where I Stand), Robert L. Ripley, Nikita Khrushchev, the Maryknoll Sisters,

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. In the dramaturgy of history, every hero must be provided with an appropriate villain. This villain must, moreover, be possessed of sufficient strength and ruthlessness to inspire a certain awe and admiration; otherwise the splendor of the hero's triumph is compromised by suspicion and doubt. The fables of history require, it seems, not only a feeling that victory has been achieved and calamity avoided but a conviction that something difficult and momentous has been permanently safeguarded in the encounter.

title: Unveilings
description: STOL??TZIrving. Unveiling in memory of Irving Stolnitz, 13 July, 1 P.M. sharp. Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey. Workmen's Circle Block 19, Section M, Row 4. Rain or shine.

title: SUMMER CLASSES CURTAILED HERE
description: Summer programs in the city schools, which have traditionally served scores of thousands of pupils with needed credits, remediation or training, have been drastically reduced this year, and some eliminated completely, because of recent budget cuts.

title: Anne Cushman Wed To Julien F. Begien
description: Anne Adams Cushman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Cushman, was married yesterday afternoon to Julien F. Begien, son of Ernest J. Begien of Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mrs. Begien. The Rev. Donald Bitsberger performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: 7 QUIT U.S. BOARD OVER DISMISSAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Seven members of the Foreign Service Grievance Board have resigned to protest the refusal of the Agency for International Development to follow the board's order for reinstatement of an employe who had been laid off.

title: Altering of Weather Widened Last Year To 5% of Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) The Federal weather service says that the area of the United States affected by rainmaking and other weather modification activities increased about 12 per cent last year. Participants received high marks for safety and environmental consideratons.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He should be elated, but Thurman Munson is tormented by doubt. He will be the American League catcher in the AllStar game, but he wonders if the voters loved him for him.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Blood of Israel

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Tullers Surrender
description: Charles A. Tuller, a former Commerce Department official, surrendered in Washington last week after having spent nearly three years in Cuba. He had been sought in connection with the hijacking of a jetliner. A son also surrendered. The Tullers, together with another son, are accused of commandeering an Eastern Airlines jet in Houston on Oct. 29, 1972, and forcing the crew and passengers to fly to Havana. An airline employee was shot to death during the seizure. The Tullers are also accused of an attempted hank robbery in Virsinia four days before the hijacking. Two men were killed during the attempt. The Tullers face three counts of murder and charges of kidnapping, air piracy and interstate flight to avoid prosecution.

title: A kiss should be freely given, not stolen
description: This is medieval history with verve, a merry jaunt into the land of the troubadours and jongleurs, a journey with knights and noblemen across that enchanting territory of southern France where langue d'oc was spoken and through which pilgrims and crusaders passed en route to the Holy Land or, more frequently, to the shrine of Santiago de Compostela in the Spanish province of Galicia. In his colorful retrospective Claude Marks portrays the scene in the hues of a rare tapestry, en??ching it with photographs and line drawings and reliable translations of the songs sung by wandering minstrels and musicians.

title: Arms to Turkey: A Compromise?
description: One more attempt is being made in Washington to lift the arms embargo enforced against Turkey since Feb. 5. After a breakfast meeting with about 140 members of Congress, President Ford last week announced his acceptance of a compromise to resume arms shipments, but the plan still faces considerable opposition in Congress.

title: ... $60Billion Deficit
description: In now scaling his deficit projection back to $60billion, Mr. Simon appears to be trying to reassure the financial community and prevent a sharp runup in interest rates that could surely cause recovery to founder. But the Secretary is loath to give up his controlbyscare tactics; the $60billion forecast, he said, still depends on several assumptions, including the willingness of Congress to let the 1975 antirecession tax cuts expire next March. If the Administration is doing any advance planning against the possibility that the recovery may drag too much, there is no sign of it. Far from worrying about a slow recovery, Mr. Simon positively wants one since it will hold down interest rates.

title: In Hot Pursuit Of Stolen Art
description: PARIS Dedicated to the proposition that you can't tell a stolen work of art without a reproduction of it, an international monthly publication has been launched for the chief purpose of reproducing and describing paintings, sculpture, and other art objects stolen anywhere in the world, and likely to turn up anyplace. The hope is that galleries, museums and other regular purchasers of art will clip oat and file the magazine's reproductions, which are printed between dotted lines on one side of the page to facilitate clipping and indexing, so that they will be able to spot a hot property the instant it is offered to them.

title: Cost of Beer to Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP)Beer distributors say they will increase the price of cases from 25 to 60 cents by the end of July because of the costs of a new labor contract negotiated with teamsters.

title: Britain's Militant Miners Go Along
description: British Prime Minister Harold Wilson has emerged with at least a symbolic victory after taking his case for restraint in union wage demands directly to the militant coal miners' union.

title: Raking the ashes of the epidemic of flame
description: Fire marshal: The title conjures up an image of a strong, square forensic scientist, ferreting out arson at a glance or even a sniff, employing the latest and most sensitive detection equipment to sift through the remains of a charred and possibly still smoldering building for hard evidence, then striding out with an expert's knowledge of where the fire was set, how it spread and the brand name of the gasoline that fueled it; in the crowd watching the fire, he finds several helpful witnesses and a trail that leads straight to a quivering, deranged, and soon handcuffed, pyromaniac.

title: Melinda Gow Wed To David L. Dame
description: Melinda Govt. daughter of Mrs. Frederic FL Williams Jr. of Oyster Bay Cove, LI., and William C. Gow of Plainfield, N.J., and David Leo Dame were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Clifford FL James, pastor of the Interlaken Chapel, a nondenominational independent Christian church in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Roosevelt Spa in the Saratoga State Park.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Unless otherwise noted, the critical judgments in this Guide reflect the published views of Times critics.

title: Miss Gordon, Radcliffe 1973, Becomes Bride
description: Kathleen Anne Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven S. Gordon of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married there yesterday afternoon to Alfred Wynne Putnam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Putnam of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

title: Mary Caroline Baker Bride of T. M. Hunt Jr.
description: Mary Caroline Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Stuart Baker of Chicago, was married yesterday afternoon to Torrence Miller Hunt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hunt of Pittsburgh, and a greatgrandson of Capt. Alfred E. Hunt, a founder and first president of the Aluminum Company of America.

title: Soviet Assails Schlesinger On Nuclear Arms Remark
description: MOSCOW, July 12The Soviet Union today denounced Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, accusing him of playing a dangerous game by making belligerent statements about American policy on the use of nuclear weapons.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Park Holding Festival Of the Arts
description: Dancing, costume creations and individual musical expressions are among the events in a Participation Arts Festival that will be held this afternoon at Floyd Bennett Field in Gateway National Park.

title: Role of State Sports Authority Shifting in Political Uncertainty
description: The New York State Sports Authority, which was created to encourage professional and amateur sports by financing municipal arenas, has moved through a metamorphosis in which its role changed from that of a bonding agency to one of planning winter sports and possibly, managing some of the state's ailing stadiums.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Strong U.S. Swim Team In World Aquatic Meet
description: CALI, Colombia, July 12 (AP)Two of America's top performers won't be here, but the United States is expected to be a strong contender in the second world aquatic championships beginning Friday.

title: Shipping/Mails
MARCHERS BACK HOMOSEXUAL BILL
description: Two hundred people demonstrated peacefully for an hour and a half yesterday afternoon, across the street from St. Patrick's Cathedral in support of a bill to guarantee the rights of homosexuals that is before the City Council.

title: Andrew Cordier Dies
description: Dr. Andrew Cordier, president emeritus of Columbia University and former executive assistant to the Secretary General of the United Nations, died. He was 74. Details are on Page 39.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. Each generation brings its own sense of catastrophe to The Skin of Our Teeth, Thornton Wilder's enduring comedy about man's ability to suffer the crunch. The most rueful laugh in the Kennedy Center's current revival is triggered by a line tucked away .in the third act, after the Antrobus family has escaped the ice, the flood and the bombs and is piecing life together again. Henry, the obdurate son, has struggled home, dragging his selfpity behind him, whereupon Sabina, the maid, eyes him coolly and snaps, The war's over, Henry Antrobus, and you're not any more important than any other unemployed.

title: Daughter to the Gellers
description: A daughter was born June 29 to Dr. and Mrs. Markham J. Geller in London, where Mrs. Geller, the former Donna Hirsh of Pound Ridge, N.Y., teaches mathematics and social studies at the American School. Dr. Geller is a teaching fellow at the University of London's School of Religion. This child is named Hanna Claire.

title: Adjusting to Cutbacks Will Be Painful
description: For months, Mayor Beanie's layoffs remained almost wholly in the realm of bookkeepers' abstractions. Of the more than 12,000 persons whose layoffs were announced last winter, for instance, fewer than 2,000none of them civil servantsare known to have left the payroll because of dismissal. Not surprisingly, there were doubts that the 50,000 additional layoffs proclaimed for the 197576 crisis budget this year would take place.

title: Evonne Cawley Faced By a New Situation
description: Evonne Goolagong, the graceful, honeyskinned tennis star who came from the Australian outback to win Wimbledon at the age of 19, is all grown up now.

title: Bikers' Way Eased In Prospect Park
description: By this time last year, 140 personsmainly bicyclistshad been mugged on the rambling, treelined lanes of Brooklyn's Prospect Park. Word got around and the traffic began to thin out.

title: James Murphy 3d Marries Miss Baratelli
description: Roberta Lynn Baratelli, daughter of Mrs. Almo Baratelli of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Baratelli. was married yesterday morning to James Joseph Murphy 3d. son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy 2d of New Orleans.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Although the job of photographing domestic pets can often be quite simple, tinder the wrong conditions it can be as tricky as trying to photograph a wild animal. It helps if the photographer has a walled or fencedin garden or lawn area or a small room with lots of good natural lightand, of course, if the pet is cooperative.

title: Miss Howard Is Bride of Carl Thomsen
description: Catherine M. Howard, a social worker in Arlington County. Va., was married yesterday afternoon to Carl T. Thomsen, who is with the International Business Machines Corporation in Washington.

title: Crockett Johnson, Cartoonist, Creator of Barnaby, Is Dead
description: Crockett Johnson, creator of the comic strip Barnahy. died Friday of cancer in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 24 Owennice Road, Westport, Conn.

title: Delayed Medals
description: Rear Adm. James B. Stockdale, who was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for seven and a half years, has been presented with eight medals, for, among other things, resisting all attempts by the North Vietnamese to use him ... In 1973, after his release, Admiral Stockdale wrote of his experience, When I ejected from that airplane in 1965, I left my world of technology and entered the world of Epictetus. I was alone and crippled; selfreliance was the basis for daily life. Admiral Stockdale is now commander of the Pacific antisubmarine warfare wing.

title: Program to Keep Young Offenders Out of Jail Is Set
description: YORKERS, July 12A pilot program designed to keep young offenders out of jail will start here in early September.

title: Theater Notes: Some Straws in the Wind
description: Is the Straw Hat circuit going to provide any bright new feathers for Broadway's cap? Well, the 150 or more summer theaters in the northeast aren't exactly overstocked with new shows that aspire to bigger things, but here and there among the retreads and revivals are some pretty fair contenders for a booking on or Off Broadway next season.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE GREAT VICTORIAN COLLECTION, by Brian Moore. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $7.95.) A man's dream becomes a reality outside his morning window, leading the reader into an entertaining, insoluble mystery.

title: Cabinda Group Seeks Break With Angola
description: LUANDA, AngolaAt least one point on which Angola's three competing guerrilla movements agree is that the exclave Cabinda is an integral part of Angolan territory.

title: Can Shakespeare, Ibsen, Shaw and Pinero Save Joseph Papp?
description: On a speaking trip to Cleveland in midApril to address college groups, Joseph Papp was dismayed for once to find himself at a loss for words. The busiest and most voluble theater producer in the country delivered two speeches that, by his own admission, were the worst of his career.

title: Apollo Is Reported Ready for Launching
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 12  The rockets, spacecraft and astronauts for the joint AmericanSoviet mission were reported ready today for launching on Tuesday.

title: Kissinger Steals Schmidt Show
description: BONN, July 12Henry Kissinger flew into Bonn in a torrential thunderstorm last night and stole the show.

title: SQUIBB BUILDING CLEANS UP DEBRIS
description: Smashed windows were restored, hundreds of gallons of water drained out and mounds of debris removed yesterday from the scorched 18th floor of the Squibb Building at 40 West 57th Street where 60 people suffered smoke inhalation and minor injuries from a fire last Friday.

title: Life Booming for Fireworks Family
description: BELLPORTFireworks is a family affair for the Gruccis here. For fiveandahalf generations they have combined family ingenuity with hard and hazardous work to turn out dazzling special effects for the Fourth of July.

title: Gozzi Takes Lake Placid Hunter Title
description: LAKE PLACID. N.Y., July 11  Winter Place Farms' Gozzi, unbeatable all season, won the regular working hunter championship today with a minimum of effort at the Lake Placid horse show.

title: Anthropologist Gets Top French Award
description: NEWARK  Dr. Pierre Szamek, an anthropologist and a former faculty member at Kean College in Union, has received the Order of the Academic Palms, a French Government award that Napoleon established in 1808.

title: In Memoriam
description: FRIEDBERGCharles K., M.D. Always loved and remembered.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Wagner's Ring Comes To Seattle
description: SEATTLE Ninety  nine years after Wagner's Ring first resounded In an opera house, this epic tetralogy remains the ultimate challenge for any ensemble, and undertaking it confers a cachet on any company. So it is worth noting that the Seattle Opera is about to mount Der Ring des Nibelungen both in German and English versions (July 1520 for the former, and July 2227 for the latter). Though the scale of the project may seem overly grand for a company founded a decade ago, it reflects the ambitions of Glynn Ross, the company's general director and the most affable megalomaniac in opera today.

title: Antique Bikes Are Riding High Again
description: Before the turn of the century young gentlemen in the East liked to pedal down city streets and country roads atop the elegant highwheeled bicycles that were all the rage.

title: A Fallen Model For Deregulation
description: SAN DIEGOThere is a frown these days on the grinning birds of Pacific Southwest Airlines, a California company that has suddenly lost its mystique as the airline that did everything right.

title: GAG ON LAWYERS EASED BY COURT
description: In a major decision affecting a gag rule on criminal trial lawyers in the city, an appeals court has ruled that bar associations can discipline actor neys for outofcourt statements only when there is a clear and present danger to the judicial process.

title: Swedish Hospital May Close
description: The State Department of Health has requested a hearing for sometime this summer for the purpose of revoking the operating certificate of the Swedish Hospital of Brooklyn on the ground of structural and safety deficiencies, an action that would very likely close the hospital, which is the only medical facility in the city devoted exclusively to problems connected with alcoholism.

title: Building in Paramus To Open in the Fall
description: This twostory office building at 6 Forest Avenue in Paramus, N.J., is scheduled for completion late in the fall. The 22,000squarefoot structure is being developed by the Allied Securities Company of Paramus, which also owns the adjacent Garden State National Bank Building, completed last year. The architect for the new structure, which will cost less than $1million, is Telefsen and Mader of Teterboro. The Ferguson Construction Company of Wayne is the contractor.

title: Navy and Shipbuilder in Impasse Periling A tomPowered Vessels
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Navy has reached an impasse with one of its major contractors over construction of a nuclearpowered frigate that raises serious questions about future shipbuilding plans of the Navy.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Alert for eorwigs, cabbage worms and dapanese beetles; handpick and trap when possible or use Sevin or malathion: ... Divide iris and plant new varieties... Last call tit feed and prune established evergreens.... Be alert for squash or vine borer; watch base of plants for holes and frass; spray Sevin at base. of vines, only, not on flowers.

title: NEEDS OF ARTIST FOCUS OF PARLEY
description: CLEVELAND, July 12The problems and needs of the individual artist were for the first time the major subjects of discussion at the conference of the Associated Councils of the Arts. This year's conference ended here today.

title: Napoles Keeps Title On Decision
description: MEXICO CITY, July 12 (AP) Jose Napoles, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, retained his crown tonight by pounding out a 15round decision over Armando Muniz of Los Angeles.

title: FRANK LETTIERI
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., July 12 Frank Letteri, who operateda drug store on Grand Street and the Junction in Jersey City for 46 years before retiring in, 1967, died at his home here Thursday of a heart attack. He was 52 years old.

title: Notes: Niagara Falls Receives a Facelift
