description: NIAGARA FALLS, the honeymoon capital of the world when mother was a girl, has had her face lifted, and the treatment seems to have worked miracles: Last year the resort in western New York attracted a record 16 million tourists.

title: For Mrs. Peron The Signs Are Not Good
description: Isabel Martnez de Pern has survived another week as President of Argentina but, after being forced to cancel a program designed to control the chaotic economy and to discharge her most trusted Cabinet minister, her Presidency may have been damaged beyond repair.

title: Annie Gordon, 25, begins to grow up
description: I remember fondly a Peanuts cartoon of several years ago in which a little boy is sitting on a stoop next to a little girl. Wouldn't you like to have your life to live over, knowing what you know now? he asks her, and she, after thinking it over, replies, What do know now? Just that point in life is beautifully captured in Sara McAulay's appealing, fresh first novel, Catch Rides. What we know is mainly that we don't know much. Pretty scan it's going to be time to move on, to start real life, with all its ominous implica

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Apropos the Bolshoi Opera: a book named Stanislayski on Opera, to be published early next month by Theatre Arts Books, has a direct bearing on the ounrent visit of the famous Russian company to the United States. Stanislayski (18631938) still is a legend for his work with the Moscow Art Theater; he was of course one of the greatest stage directors of history. But as a young man he studied singing and considered an operatic career before settling on being an actor. He was cofounder of the Moscow Art Theater in 1898, and worked with it for the rest of his life. It is not generally known, however, that, starting in 1918, he also had an association with the Bolshoi Opera, and his ideas about opera were just as revolutionary as his ideas about the legitimate stage.

title: Rutgers Offers Offbeat Art
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Unlike Princeton or Yale, Rutgers University does not have the benefit of generations of wealthy alumni to enrich its art gallery. Nevertheless, it has managed to assemble an interesting and offbeat group of paintings, sculpture and graphics, all of which can be viewed in a summer exhibition entitled Selections from the Permanent Collection.

title: Clay Pigeon Crown To Army Sergeant
description: CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP)  Donald Haldeman of Al??entown, Pa., fired a finalround 98 today and captured the national clay pigeon championship. Audrey Grosch of Minneapolis won the women's title.

title: Miss Kerrigan Becomes Bride
description: In St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in Milwaukee at noon yesterday, Laura Austin Kerrigan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Kerrigan of Milwaukee, became the bride of Kenneth Goodrich Appel, son of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Appel of Philadelphia.

title: Ruffian's Death: Whose Fault Was It?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Bayreuth Will Make Diaries Of Wagner's Widow Public
description: The intimate diaries of Cosima Wagner, mistress and then second wife of Richard Wagner, will he disclosed in their entirety after having been kept secret almost 100 years. Publication of the diaries, heretofore closed to scholars and biographers, should lead to reinterpretations of a major period in the composer's life.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayDrag racing, National Hot Rod Association Summernational finals at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road. Englishtown, N. J., 1 P.M.

title: Doubts Rise on Site For Olympic Sailing
description: Doubts persist whether the preparations at Kingston, Ontario, will be ready for the preOlympic regatta starting Saturday and the Olympics next year. Dr. Benne Croce, head of the International Yacht Racing Union, said he would attend the preOlympic regatta to assess the situation and advise Kingston organizers.

title: FREEDOM OF BEACH
description: Ned Coll is a fasttalking, relentlessly cheerful humanist who loves putting groups of total strangers face to face to make them try to love one anotheror at least to talk things over. He's had fearful old ladies dancing with prisoners at a hootenanny inside a jail, affluent college students tutoring slum schoolchildren, and  most notoriouslyhe's tried to get the summer residents who own all but six miles of the Connecticut shoreline to accept busloads of black and Puerto Rican children on their exclusive beaches. Coll believes there are no real private rights to any beaches anywhere and he will fight for free access to them for all the people by any means that work persuasion, sixtiesstyle demonstrations or surprise invasions by land, sea and air (he once used a parachutist who floated himself gently down upon the aristocratic sands of the Madison Beach Club).

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  For Governor Byrne, it was a week that was.

title: Shrinking Households
description: A report released by the United States Census Bureau has provided new evidence in support of an assertion that has become the sociologist's stock in trade: The way that Americans live together is changing, and the changes have something to do with the family.

title: Legislature Increases Aid for Elderly; Longest Session Since 1911 Is Ended
description: ALBANY, July 12After an 18hour marathon that included the final passage of higher Supplemental Security Income benefits and of a bill to allow some witnesses to bring lawyers into the grand jury room, the longest legislative session in 64 years ended just before dawn this morning.

title: Time for Clarification
description: LISBONThe United States would be insane not to oppose a European security conference and block the scheduled summit, whichalthough delayedremains Mr. Brezhnev's favorite project, unless it is preceded by a Soviet pledge not to interfere by any means in Portugal. In making such an attitude clear, Washington should meticulously explain it to states concerned, above all its allies.

title: HERBERT G. KING, 73 BROKER, OPERA FAN
description: Herbert G. King, a member of the New York Stock Exchange from 1929 to 1968, and an outstanding opera fan, died Friday at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: Headliners
description: As of Oct. 1, the chairman of the board of the Chrysler Corporation will be John J. Riccardo. Mr. Riccardo, now the corporation's president, is a close associate of the man he succeeds as chairman, Lynn A. Townsend, who is taking an early retirement. Of the big three car makers, Chrysler has taken the worst losses during the current down period in the auto industry, with a record $94.1million loss during the first quarter of this year. Though Mr. Riccardo said he planned no major policy changes, he added that the industry is operating in a radically different world. The organization that will survive, he said,  will be the one that can move very quickly yet have some continuity.

title: An Indian Summer
description: Ten years ago, when he returned from Hanoi and reported that the American bombing had unified the North Vietnamese much as the Blitz had unified Britain, James Cameron, the English journalist, did a media tour of North America to explain himself. A sprightly television interviewer, strained by the painful subject of war, asked how it felt to be in New York. All right, he said, New York was all right for a threeday town.

title: LESLIE LESTER
description: Leslie Lester, a lawyer specializing in real estate, died Friday in New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 41 West 96th Street.

title: Rock Gives Solid Base To a Poor Soccer Club
description: LONDON  Nearly 120,000 people showed up recently at Wembley Stadium for a benefit concert for the Watford Football Club, but most of them hadn't heard of the team.

title: The birds and the bees were never like this
description: I opened Show Me! a photographic sexinstruction manual for children and their parents, with enthusiasm. It had occurred to me that such a book was needed; the cutouts, cartoons and drawings which illustrate most mating and reproduction books For children make sex whimsical and distant, and thus do not satisfy the needs of some children for realistic sexual information. But is Show Me! realistic? Is it for children? And if so, what are children?

title: Nickawampus, $10, Takes Glory Pace
Winning: It Means Not Losing
description: Flathead Lake, Mont. Sometimes the beauty of it hushes the mind's activity and one can just be.

title: JUDGE BARS MOVE TO NURSING HOME
description: A lawsuit brought on behalf of three Brooklyn mental patients by a Staten Island nursinghome operator who was seeking to admit them to his institution was dismissed in Staten Island Supreme Court Friday by a judge who said that the three patients did not know about the suit.

title: Kathryn Ritchell To Be Wed Sept. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Ritchell of WinstonSalem, N. C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Ann Ritchell of New York, to H. Jay Sornmerkamp, also of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Sommerkamp of Sea Island, Ga.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Seeks Approval
description: India's Parliament has been called back into session July 21, apparently to put legal force behind the state of emergency instituted late last month by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Will New England Get Its Refinery?
description: PORTLAND, Me.  The, Pittston Company, primarily a coal producer, has stolen a march on the oil industry. After two years of hearings, the Maine Board of Environmental Protettion has voted to allow Pittston to go ahead with plans to build the East Coast's first supertanker port and a 250,000barreladay refinery complex in Eastport, Me.

title: Ferries Emphasize the Island in Long Island
description: HAUPPAUGEWhen Mrs. Douglas Graham Sr. of Mastic Beach expressed her support for expanded ferry service between Long Island and Connecticut at the recent public meeting here, she did so with the comment, This is the original way; the way the pioneers came.

title: Horton, Former Cosmo, Is Harboring No Grudge
description: In the history of the New York Cosmos, the player blamed and booed more than anyone was Randy Horton, their leading scorer for four years, who was sold last year to the Washing ton Diplomats. Horton holds no grudge. After the Cosmos had defeated Horton's current team, 92, in Washington recently, Horton seemed to be as happy for the Cosmos, Pel and the North American Soccer League as any of the 35,000 people who watched that game.

title: Motorbike Racing Starts at Age
description: HOUSTON, July 9Although her son is something of a veteran of dirttrack motorcycle racing, Mrs. John Belisle still feels a bit anxious every time he rolls up to the line. She checks his crash helmet, rock shield and goggles, glances at the steeltoed racing boots rising kneehigh over his leather trousers, and then, before he begins winding up the engine, gives him a little kiss for luck.

title: Miss Byrne Married To James P. Minardi
description: Claudia Byrne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. X. Byrne of Westbury, L. I., was married yesterday morning to James Paul Minardi, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Minardi of Hicksville, L. I. The Rev. George Reilly, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, concelebrating the nuptial mass with the Rev. Louis Newman and the Rev. John Martin, at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Westbury.

title: The Dance: Les Noces
description: It is rare for lightning to strike once in artistic matters. In the unusual but welcome case of Stravinsky's Les Noces, it has defied augury and defeated the proverb by striking twice. Bronislava Nijinska's original setting of this great Stravinsky score was in 1923. It was one of the great ballets of its time.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States is considering the possibility of American technicians taking over electronic surveillance stations maintained by Israel in the strategic Sinai mountain passes. This could remove one of the principal issues preventing Egypt and Israel from reaching a new agreement on disengagement in Sinai. Israel insists on control of earlywarning radar and monitoring stations that she has in western Sinai. Egypt apparently suggested, as a compromise, that the United States man the stations. The United States reluctantly agreed to con Sider the proposal, newsmen on Secretary of State Kissinger's BonnLondon flight were told. (Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Letters
description: Getcha!

title: Tuition Increase Rejected
The Tough Drug Law Is Changed
description: The heavy penalties called for in New York State's controversial drug law have been sharply reduced by the Legislature for the majority of cases. The action is expected to free an overburdened court system of minor drug cases, and to permit a greater number of serious criminal cases to get to trial.

title: YankeesTwins Halted After 14th
description: Less than half of a soggy crowd of 13,573 at Shea Stadium early today saw the New York YankeeMinnesota Twins game suspended by an American League curfew rule after 14 innings. The score was tied, 66.

title: FORD TO PROPOSE TIMED DECONTROL OF U.S. OIL PRICES
description: CHICAGO, July 12President Ford said today that he would send to Congress next week a proposal for a responsible, welltimed decontrol of domestic oil prices that would lead to a gradual rather than sudden removal of controls.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: A recent boobytrap hunt in Nassau County by the Insurance Information Institute turned up all kinds of road hazards, including the one pictured above, which shows the intersection of Little Neck Parkway and Jericho Turnpike in Floral Park.

title: With Congress Somewhat Disenchanted, He Needs a Power Base
description: WASHINGTONHenry Kissinger has embarked on a national speaking tour remarkable for a Secretary of State. Major foreign policy pronouncements are made almost invariably from pulpits in Washington. But Mr. Kissinger has been taking his messages directly to the peoplein Milwaukee, Minneapolis, St. Louis, Kansas City, New York City and Atlanta, and with more to come when he returns from his present European meetings. Why?

title: Large Women's U.S. Open Field Requires Qualifying Tomorrow
description: It could be considered a sign of the times, that the women's United States Open golf championship will be forced to hold its first qualifying round in its 23year history. With a record field of 185, a qualifying round will be played tomorrow to narrow the starting field to 150.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: There is probably no such thing as a perfect numismatic bookspecially true where advance, specialized collectors are concerned. But for beginning and even intermediate collectors of American coinage, the one indespensable reference work is A Guide Book of United States Coins. It is familiarly known as the Red Book (the color of its hard cover), or simply as the Guide Book.

title: Thousands Exhaust Jobless Benefits
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12 Thousands of jobless Americans the first victims of the recession and the epidemic of layoffs that began with the Arab oil embargo late in 1973are running out of the unemployment benefits that have kept them financially afloat until now.

title: Hudson Tolls Facing Inquiry
description: TRENTONThe Federal Highway Administration has begun an investigation into the higher tolls imposed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey at the crossings it operates between the two states.

title: Vilas Upset by Meiler; Orantes in Tennis Final
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 12 (AP)Karl Meiler of West Germany upset topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 63, 64, 46, 64, today and reached the final of the Swiss international open tennis championship.

title: The Battle Over Going Private
description: Wells, Rich, Greene, Inc., the advertising agency heretofore renowned for the razzledazzle of its campaigns and the glamour of its chairman, Mary Wells Lawrence, now seems destined for fame of a duller, longerlasting sort.

title: Quiet Culebra
description: The controversy between the tiny Puerto Rican island of Culebra and the United States Navy over the use of the island as a gunnery range has finally been resolved: The Department of Defense has announced that Culebra will no longer be used as a practice target island. Since the late 1930's, a section of Culebra a 7,000acre island off the east coast of Puerto Rico, had been shot at by the United States and a dozen other nations. Culebra's 800 inhabitants, confined to a small, tightly fenced part of the island, had protested the operation for years.

title: CHESS
description: Acquiring experience with the white side of the Ruy Lopez is hard to do these days because of the marked preference of so many players for semiopen defenses to I PK4..Thus, paradoxically, an occasional defense to the staid Lopez can be attempted, not with the object of merely holding on, but to take advantage of an unpracticed opponent.

title: How Mosquitoes Select Targets
description: From the ancient Egyptians' use of the smudgepot to the modern insect repellent, upon the recorded history of man's effort to tame nature appear his attempts to avoid a persistent pest, the mosquito. Now scientists are beginning to learn what attracts the ubiquitous insect to its prey.

title: How the Privacy Act Is Supposed To Work
description: The Privacy Act of 1974 has given citizens a right they have not had before: to find out, within limits, what personal information the Federal Government has on file about them, and how that information is used.

title: Valerie Ruggieri Wed
description: Valerie Ruggieri, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Ruggieri of Bayside, Queens, was married there yesterday in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church to Dr. Saqib Siddique Chaudhry, son of Dr. and Mrs. Muhammad Siddique Chaudhry of Lahore, Pakistan. The Rev. John Connally performed the ceremony. The bride is on the nurses' staff of Flushing (Queens) Hospital, where her husband is a surgical resi??nt.

title: AllStar Umpires Headed by Haller
description: Bill Haller of the American League will be the home plate umpire at the AllStar Game in Milwaukee Tuesday night.

title: School's On at St. Benedict's
description: NEWARK  For students attending St. Benedict's Preparatory School here, the school year has just begun, not ended.

title: Jazzworkshop at Ramapo
description: MAHWAHA jazz workshop that was started at Ramapo College last summer has blossomed into a concert series that will feature Buddy Rich's orchestra and Arthur Godfrey, among others.

title: New Scale Helps To Judge Athletes
description: Out of commercial promotion, intended to do no more than call attention to and build favorable attitudes toward a common product, a revolutionary approach to sports statistics is developing, one that can increase immensely the value of information sports statistics can convey.

title: Red Sox Rout Rangers, 104, for 6th in Row
description: BOSTON, July 12 (AP) Carl Yastrzemski drove in three runs and Jim Rice belted his 14th home run today as the Boston Red Sox won their sixth straight game with a 104 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Mail Order Sales Barred
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)A final mailstop, order has been issued against Bejuvnir, Inc., of Santa Monica, Calif., for its mail order promotion of a facial cream product, the United States Postal Service says. Postal officials said that Rejuvnir has misleadingly promoted the product in national magazines by saying that Dr. Benjamin S. Frank's nutritional facial cream 'reduces wrinkles in depth and width 30 to 60 per cent, smooths acne scare, and decreases the size of keloids.

title: A Fond Farewell to Matt Dillon, Dodge City and Gunsmoke
description: Gunsmoke, television's longest running dramatic serial, will fade into history this fall. Beginning on Sept. 1, fans of the 20yearold Western will no longer find the adventures of Matt, Kitty and Doc broadcast over CBS on Monday at 8, although they may be able to discover replays of old shows in the programming of local stations.

title: U.S. Steel Under Fire as a Problem Polluter
description: WASHINGTONAsked at a recent news conference which industry was the most laggardly in meeting the requirements of the 1970 Clean Air Act, Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, replied, The steel industry is at the top or close to the top of the list.

title: Student Sues a Town on Fees
description: CAMDEN  A 23yearold Rutgers law student has filed suit in Superior Court here, charging that Haddonfield Borough is preventing him from earning a living as a newspaper reporter because of excessive fees for photocopies of official documents.

title: The Story Of Laggard Price Cuts
description: Producers of basic materials have been holding a brave front against pressure to cut prices in this recession, but it is beginning to look as if some of them may finally be yielding ground.

title: Somalia Visitors Found Something Else
description: Two United States Congressional groups have visited Berbera and confirmed that there are indeed Russians end Soviet facilities in the remote Somalian port. But the members of Congress also were able to see that the East African country has been ravaged by drought, and they are likely to suggest increased American aid.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: In the nineteenfifties, as the harddriving chief of the Army's ballistic missile program, Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris directed the launching of the first United States satellite, Explorer I. He worked with Dr. Wernher von Braun and others to put life into the United States space effort after the Soviet Union had upstaged it by orbiting Sputnik I.

title: Boom Times for Jail Fixtures
description: Broken locks, bars and cells, have taken the back seat to broken sales records in the last year for manufacturers of detention equipment.

title: U.S. AND CANADA NEAR GAS ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Canada and the United States expect to sign in two or three months a treaty regarded in both countries as an essential step toward the construction of a natural gas pipeline from Alaska and Canada's Mackenzie River Delta to the main part of the United States.

title: K. J. Kjartansson, Teacher, a Bride
description: Anna Kjartansson, whose father, the late Hanne Kjartansson, was Iceland's representative to the United Nations, was married yesterday in Rochester to John Macko, a financial planner there with the Xerox Corporation. Monroe County Judge Donald Mark performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. William Brown, friends of the couple.

title: Alabama Officiai Aral Utility Officer Accused of Bribery
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 12 William J. Baxley, Alabama's Attorney General, announced today that he had issued warrants charging bribery against the president of the Alabama Public Service Commission and a senior vice president of the state's leading telephone utility.

title: Haydeen DiazComacho Engaged
description: Mrs. Manuel J. Diaz of Miami Beach, formerly of Havana. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Haydeen DiazComacho, to Mark Robert von Sternberg, son of Dorothy von Sternberg of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Jule R. von Sternberg of Garden City. L.I. The wedding is planned for Oct. 25 in Palm Beach.

title: Washington School Chief Gets $50,000 Truce Offer
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The District of Columbia Board of Education is trying to negotiate a $50,000 truce with Barbara A. Sizemore, the school superintendent here whom the board has voted to dismiss midway through her threeyear contract.

title: BRITISH ARE WARY OF PAY PROGRAM
description: LONDON, July 12  Prime Minister Harold Wilson's newly announced program to restrain inflation brought relief and some skepticism from most segments of British society today.

title: A Bill Calling Nursing Homes To Account
description: Legislation to end the abuse of patients and the mismanagement of government funds in the nursinghome industry has been passed in Albany, and the program is expected to bring about the substantial reform it promises. It incorporates the proposals of the industry's major critics, Assem blyman Andrew J. Stein, whose investigation brought attention to the scandal, and Morris Abram, whose Moreland Act Commission verified many of the Assemblyman's charges.

title: Crime Rises 21% in England and Wales
description: LONDON, July 12A disturbing picture of an apparently inexorable rise in the number; of crimes has been drawn by a top police officer for England and Wales.

title: L.I. Unit Suit Against Kiwanis Seeks Right to Enroll Women
description: MINEOLA L. I., July 12The Great Neck Kiwanis club, which had its charter revoked in 1974 for admitting female members, obtained an order in State Supreme Court here last week requiring Kiwanis International and its New York regional office to show why the local club should not be reinstated.

title: Two Advance to WaterSki Finals
description: PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., July 12 (UPI)  Liz Allan Schetter, a winner the eight previous times she had appeared in the tournament, and Ricky McCormick, the only man to have won it twice in a row, appeared on their way toward taking the master's water ski championships today. Mrs. Schetter, 24yearold instructor from Groveland Park, Fla., reached the finals in all three events  jump, slalom and tricks. McCormick, from Hialeah, Fla., made the three finals with Mike Supderhoud.

title: The Country Is Overrun with Refugees
description: Somalia is no longer the Land of Punt, the legendary fertile home of the incense tree, immortalized in the wall drawings of ancient Egypt. The eastern Horn of Africa is the land of the Somalis. It is predominantly a harsh and arid area, isolated from its neighbors by forbidding semidesert. In recent years it has become the last stop on the trek of Africa's drought victims.

title: Gael Towey Fiancee Of W. G. Dillon 3d
description: Gael A. Towey and W. Gregory Dillon 3d, graduates of Boston University, plan to be married. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh T. Towey of Short Hills, N. J., where Mr. and Mrs. William G. Dillon, parents of the prospective bridegroom, also live.

title: After 1,000 Tranquil Years, Will Success Spoil Alpbach?
description: PEOPLE named Moser run the village of Alpbach in the Austrian Tyrol the way the Bourbons once ran France. And like the Lodees and Cabots of Boston, the Mosers speak mostly to each other. They have to, since a third of the people in the village phone book (10 small pages) are named Moser. Toni runs the taxi service; Koni is Tourism Director, Georg bakes the bread, including the best rolls in Austria; Gabriel organizes day excursions to Innsbruck, Salzburg, Venice; Alois leads the village band and Alfons is Mayor and owner of the most prestigious hotel.

title: Suffolk Gets Funds To Assist Services
description: HAUPPAUGEA $900,000 Federal grant has been awarded to Suffolk County and the state, which will enable the county to eliminate a maze of application forms, requirements and duplications that people seeking assistance now face.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Sunday erroneously reported that Leon Botstein was leaving Franconia College this month to become president of Union College in Schenectady, N.Y. He will become president of Bard College at AnnandaleonHudson.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: TODAY  Lake Placid, Lake Placid Showgrounds, Lake Placid, N. Y. Grand Prix for open jumpers, 3 P.M.

title: Opera: Eugene Onegin
description: Tchaikovsky's Eugene Onegin, given by the Bnlshni Opera at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday afternoon, replaced Prokoviev's The Gambler, which had been previously announced for the matinee but was withdrawn in favor of Tchaikovskv's popular work.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today Twin Brooks KC. allbreed, The Malt, Route 24 and John F. Kennedy Parkway, Short Hills, N.J.; 1.276 dogs, 9 AM.

title: In a Sometimes Bitter Fight, States and Cities Are Easing Marijuana Laws
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The criminal penalties for the private possession of marijuana are beginning to fall; so are the crimiral sanctions for smoking marijuana, at least at home.

title: EXXON GIFT LINKED TO REDS IN ITALY
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The Exxon Corporation made from $46million to $49million in political contributions in Italy over a nineyear period, apparently including $86,000 to the Italian Communist party.

title: THADDEUS Z. ORSKI
description: Thaddeus Z. Orski, retired editor of Engineering Index, a monthly technical journal, died Thursday evening in Polyclinic Hospital after a fall. He was 75 years old and lived at 221 East 78th Street.

title: FloodControl Tunnel Urged
description: WASHINGTONNew Jersey's Congressional delegation is being urged to promote a $500million floodcontrol program for three counties in the northern part of the state.

title: FILM VIEW
description: These are the dog days, a time when one starts wondering what it's all about. That is, writing about films. Also, wondering about some of the side effects of writing about films.

title: Time Ripe Again For Homemakers To Think About Preserving Fruit
description: PORT MONMOUTHNew Jersey berries are back. And judging from the statewide spurt in the sales of Mason jars and lids, coupled with every homemaker's need to economize, just about every kitchen in the state must be permeated by the sweet but salivating aroma of fresh fruit cooking in huge kettles.

title: Honorary White
description: Would he live in the Alexandra slum even for a day? If he couldn't, how could he really claim an identity with the South African blacks? The thought of carrying and fetching for the white boos terrified him. These and other questions assailed E.R. Braithwaite when he visited South Africa in 1973. Black, A native of Guyana.

title: Queens Bus Map Shows All Routes
description: A pocketsize map showing every local bus route in Queens has been put out by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Ford Strategists Expect House To Block Decontrol of Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Administration strategists privately acknowledge that they expect the House to block President Ford's 25month decontrol proposal, discussed at his news conference today, by mustering a simple majority for a resolution of disapproval. Such a resolution must be passed within five working days.

title: Exxon's New Top Two
description: Clifton C. Garvin is taking over as bead of the Exxon Corporationthe World's largest industrial companyat a juncture in history when both the oil industry and the very concept of multinational enterprises are being severely challenged at home and abroad.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: spores. All these are harmless enough and, I suppose, have a right to exist, but some people must be paying for them.

title: Buck's Bid Neck Victor In Jersey
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 12 Buck's Bid, a 4yearold colt that fared poorly in last year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness, won the $40,500 Longfellow Handicap today at Monmouth Park.

title: WaterSupply Hearing Set
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A public hearing on a proposal to develop a statewide watersupply master plan at a cost of $1.2million will be held Tuesday at Rutgers University.

title: Free Cape Verde Faces An Economic Struggle
description: MINDELO, Cape Verde, July 9Scribbled on one wall of this port city, gaily decorated but adorned almost everywhere with slogans, are the words: We are independent, but the struggle continues.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: STAMPS
description: Most of the 1975 Europa issues, which this year are devoted to the common theme of painting, are now out. No longer bound by a common design, the issues provide an opportunity for European countries to display national art that is regarded with pride, rather than the masterpieces of art so often depicted on stamps.

title: Church of England Book Offends Common Market
description: LONDON, July 12 (Reuters)The Church of England has offended the Common Market by its advice on the construction of tombstones.

title: Turning, turning to the sound of Allah
description: Whirling dervishes have always captured the fancy of the world, even of people who have never seen them in action. Until recently, many Americans thought of them as madmen out of some cartoon version of the Arabian Nights. Now, partly as the result of increased interest in all forms of Oriental mysticism and partly as the result of a spectacular visit to the United States two years ago of a touring company of whirling dervishes, more and more of us have learned that these graceful spinners are members of an Islamic sect, the Mevlevi order of Sufis, who are based in Turkey and who perform their sema or whirling dance as a religious ritual to achieve union with the divine.

title: Book Ends
description: A.A.U.P. We recently paid a quick visit to the convention of the American Association of University Presses, which was held at a Ramada caravansary near Nashville, Ind., a pretty, sleepy town of 700 souls nestled in the rolling hills of Brown County. The host of this year's symposium was Indiana University Press, which was celebrating its 25th anniversary. The recently defuncted Northwestern and CaseWestern Reserve University Presses should have lived so long.

title: What's Doing in VENICE
description: THE SCENEIs it possible that there is someone somewhere ignorant of the splendors of Venice and on whose personal list it is not one of the seven or 70 wonders? This island city has more museums and churches than a visitor could see in a month or more. The Grand Canal, its main thoroughfare, is lined with palaces and other impressive buildings in gothic, Renaissance, baroque and neoclassic styles. The Piazza San. Marco is perhaps the most magnificent public square in the world with the medieval ducal palace and the Byzantine cupolas of St. Mark's Basilica standing side by side as architectural testimony to the meeting of East and West that took place here during the centuries when Venice dominated the trade routes between Europe and the Orient. The piazza is a constant spectacle, with three competing outdoor cafe orchestras, automatons in the clock tower striking the hour, the eternal tourists' feeding the eternal pigeons (a practice tolerated by the city even as it attempts to reduce the pigeon population to protect the city's fragile monuments), the goings and comings of a dozen kinds of small boats at the water's edge. Sometimes there is a theatrical or musical event on the square, a concert in the basilica; at all times the piazza is the center of life for Venetians and their guests.

title: Who Authorized This Trip?
description: Paul Revere didn't work for nothing. ...Official records in the archives of the Massachusetts State House show Revere submitted an expense account for 10 pounds 4 shillings for services performed as a messenger during the first two weeks of the American Revolution. He was paid by the Massachusetts House of Representatives.

title: British Builder Alters Course
description: Cecelia Benatlar, a maverick from Manchester, England, who became a force in Manhattan land development in the nineteensixties, is changing the focus of her operations.

title: States Warned to Withhold Data on Deserting Parents
description: WASHINGTON July 12 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is requiring law enforcements agencies to withhold from the public any information they use in a new program to track down parents who have deserted their families.

title: Miss Chatfield Wed to F. W. Schwerin Jr.
description: Judith Spencer Chatfield, daughter of Mrs. Sherwood Clarke Chatfield of Sharon, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla.. and the late Mr. Chatfield, was married yesterday afternoon to Frederick Woodbury Schwerin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schwerin of Locust Valley. L. T.

title: Victoria E. Manes Married in Suburb
description: Victoria Elizabeth Manes and William Elton Larzelere, graduates of Union College, were married yesterday in CrotononHudson, N. Y., at the home of the bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Manes.

title: A Museum for Play and Learning
description: If one is young, black and living in Brooklyn, he is probably aware of the automobile showroomturnedmuseum at 1530 Bedford Avenue, where Swahili feastdays are celebrated and African heritage is an integral part of a multitude of museum workshops.

title: Death Sentence Given
description: SARASOTA, Fla., July 12 (UPI)Glenn Stark Chambers, an admitted sadistdrug addict was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair for the fatal heating of his girlfriend last January.

title: Nuptials Sept. 6 For Sue Mills
description: Martha Beard Casey of Louisville, Ky., and Col G. M. Dailey, U.S.A., retired of Marbella, Spain, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sue Dailey Mills of Greenville, Del., to Albert Cununins Oehrle, son of Mrs. Albert C. Oehrle of Gladwyne, Pa., and the late Mr. Oehrle.

title: Larchrnont Sailing Is Won by Ogilvy
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 12Larchmont Race Week. a midsummer yachting institution that preceded the automobile, the airplane and television, started up in Western Long Island Sound today for the 77th time. A fleet of 234 boats came nut on a damp, gray afternoon to make use of a moderate but steady easterly breeze of seven knots. For Race Week, it was a fine day.

title: Answers / Questions
description: RHODODENDRONS (June 29)

title: European Horses Help Outlook For U.S. Showing in Dressage
description: Mario and Leopardi, two of the horses the United States hopes will do well in the Olympic Games in Montreal in 1976, have been unbeatable so far this season. The two mounts, Horse owned and ridden by John Show Winnett of TuxNews edo Park, N.Y., have been in three dressage events and have been first and second in the Grand Prix test in all three.

title: Slurb and Sprawl
description: In contrast to many other parts of the world, the relentless flow of population to the citiesa trend that has dominated American growth and life since the eighteenth centuryhas been finally reversed. American cities are growing old. Rural areas are developing more rapidly than metropolitan centers in an acceleration of urban sprawl. In terms of life style, energy and transportation, of environmental and operating costs, of the soundness of cities and the use and abuse of land, the implications are profound and disturbing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Nassau County Board of Supervisors will appeal the naming by State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Liff of a ninemember citizen's commission to draft an interim plan for a new county legislature. The hoard's legal counsel said that under earlier court decisions any plan for a county legislature would have to be presented to the voters by the Supervisor.

title: Watson, Newton In Open Play off
LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: FREE TESTS GIVEN ON CAR POLLUTION
description: SPRING VALLEY. N. Y. Among the drivers who pulled Into the Spring Valley High School parking lot on Route 59 for a free autopollution test the other day was Elbert. Abramson of Monsev, N. Y., a salesman who drives 1,000 miles a week.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Criminals At Large
description: Good writing plus information: that's what you get in the Dick Francis books. True, the information concerns, almost always, race horses and other things equestrian, but it is information delivered by an authority. The new one, KNOCKDOWN (Harper & Row, $6.95), is very much in line with its predecessors. It is horsy, it contains agreeable characters and despicable villains and is written with the literary finish one always associates with Dick Francis.

title: Right Primer Is Needed When Painting Metal
description: Although painting metal surfaces is in many ways no different than painting wood or other materials, it does require careful preparation of the surface beforehandand it is important that the right type of primer be applied first.

title: Bergen County Fair To Begin Thursday
description: LEONIAThe annual Bergen County 9H Fair will be held at Overpack County Park next Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

title: TV VIEW
description: Several of my recent columns have questioned current attempts in Congress to repeal the Fairness Doctrine, which, as embodied in Section 315 of the Communications Act, directs broadcasters to afford reasonable opportunity for the discussion of conflicting views on issues, of public importance. Responses from readers indicate the overall debate may have fallen into argumentative grooves that are overly confining and ultimately distorting. Assumptions have become too simplified. Reactions are too automatic. On one of the more prominent levels, Senator William Proxmire not only would abolish the Fairness Doctrine but would remove all Federal Communications Commission authority to regulate broadcast content in any manner. In effect, station licenses, now renewed every three years, would be granted in perpetuity. In a letter printed on this page last Sunday, Senator Proxmire explained that the purpose of my proposal is to give broadcast media the full First Amendment rights that are now enjoyed not only by the printed media but even by the movies.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... to Alpbach by car, it's roughly oneandahalf hours southeast of Munich, an hour or less northeast of Innsbruck, or an hour west of Kitzbhel. Map your route as far as Brixlegg, from which there's one road up to Alpbach, about a 15minute drive. Brixlegg is a local stop on the Arlberg Express railroad route between Innsbruck and Salzburg. The nearest express stops are Jenbach and Wrgh from either of these you take a connecting local train to Brixlegg. Accommodations: The Alpbacherhof and Bbglerhof are both Class A hotels where about $20 a day per person (midsummer rate) covers a charming room with bathroom and rustic balcony and three generous meals. Both have heated outdoor swimming pools. Mayor Moser's Boglerhof is on the whole rather sleeker and is the more favored by chic Austrians. The Alpbacherhof has the more hideaway feeling. There are also the Hotel Post (a fullpension room with bathroom and balcony costs about $15 a day); the Messnerwirt Gasthaus (full  pension room without private bathroom, about $11 a day), and the Haus Andreas, the newly built jewelbox annex of the Messnerwirt (fullpension room with bathroom, under $15 a day). At all three, the food is not up to the standard of the Alpbacherhof and Bglerhof, and there is not much in the way of comfortable lounge facilities. But Messnerwirt and Haus Andreas guests have access to the Andreas's indoor swimming pool; and Post guests have a large heated outdoor swimming pool. Both the Post and the Messnerwirt are utterly echt traditional Tyrolean inns in atmosphere and dcor. You can also stay at one of the bedandbreakfast chalets for anywhere from $3 to $8 a night. In that case, you can lunch on picnic cheeses and sausages bought at the village shops, and dine (for $3$7 a person, including wine) at any of the hotels and inns. If you have a car, you can stay outside the village proper at places like the Roosmoos Gasthaus (fullpension but without private bathroom, $4$8 a day) or in one of the upmountain farmhouses (bed and breakfast, $3).

title: Riverboat Restaurant Running Against the Tide
description: BABYLONI'm really involved with boats, Bob Meyer explained. It's like with Jonah and the whale; they swallow you mentally, physically and financially.

title: Easy Death
description: Last Tuesday was a banner day for violent death in New York City, and guns in private hands contributed substantially to the macabre scorecard. Of the nine victims of murder or murdersuicide incidents that day, four were killed by handguns and two by a shotgun. The fact that twothirds of the violent deaths resulted from gunfire was not aberrational. Killing people with gins is quite easy. In 1973, handguns alone were used in almost 10,000 homicidesincluding those of 127 police officersand in almost 9,000 suicides.

title: Zoe King Is Bride Of Hollis Jacobie
description: Ze King, daughter of Carol Fritz King of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Kerryn King of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Hollis Wilford Jacobie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Jacobie of Dallas. The Rev. Cleve Wheelus performed the ceremony in the Preston Hollow Presbyterian Church in Dallas.

title: In Search of A FreeMarket Economy
description: President Ford last week called in the chairmen of the Federal regulatory agencies, along with the Washington press corps, to emphasize that he wanted his Administration to cut back controls over business wherever possible. While there may have been a splash of campaign thinking behind the announcement Mr. Ford apparently is intent on getting back to some version of a freemarket economy.

title: Metric Track New Problem for Coaches
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP)The mile run and the 100yard dash, two of track's glamour races, may join the horsedrawn carriage and the 5cent beer as relics of days gone by.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's news conference in Chicago yesterday morning, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities, of ABC News:

title: Anne Lesica Is Bride Of Amos J. Eslieb
description: Anne Louise Lesica, daughter of Anthony J. Lesica of Graniterille, S. I., and the late Mrs. Lesica, was married yesterday morning to Amos J. Eslieb of Bethlehem. Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Eslieb of Nesquehoning, Pa.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Concedes 1,200 Political Detentions
description: NEW DELHI, July 12Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that the number of people arrested in India in the last two weeks had been very meager, compared with the total population, and that in any case threefourths of those arrested were common criminals, not political prisoners. The population of India is estimated at nearly 600 million.

title: 11 N.F.L. Camps Open This Week
description: Veteran players for 11 National Football League teams report to training, camps this week, with the remaining 15 clubs due in the following two weeks to begin preparations for the 1975 season.

title: This is a Liberal?
description: The lingering power of an image was never better demonstrated than in the decision of the President Ford Committee to make no effort toward the nomination of Nelson Rockefeller for Vice President next year. Howard Callaway, the campaign chairman, said he had no intention of alienating persons who don't want Rockefeller obviously meaning conservatives who have been demanding an open convention for the choice of a Vice Presidential nominee.

title: At Project In Harlem, It's a Time Of Pride
description: The trees have now grown full at Harlem River Houses, the nation's first federally financed public housing development. But for many of the original, tenants, a reunion picnic the other day was an occasion to remember treeless times.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN TWO SLAYINGS
description: A 39yearold man with a long police record was charged with homicide early yesterday after the police reported he had hunted down and shot on West Side streets two men he said had robbed him and had sexually abused his wife.

title: The Adirondack: Remembrance of Trains Past
description: COMFORTABLY nestled in a spankingnew club chair aboard the dinerlounge Saratoga Inn, I kloked ?? over Willsboro Bay, an arm. of Lake Champlain. I was aboard the Adirondackthe New York CitytoMontreal passenger train run by Amtrak and the Delaware and:HudsonRailway which just then was snaking through the rugged, spectacular Red Rocks, high above the deep blue of the lake. It was a blustery spring day, and a powerful west wind textured the water. Clouds of spray gusted from the frothy chop.

title: Data Show Kissinger Had Aide Tapped, Then Urged Him to Stay
description: WASHINGTON July 12Three months after Henry A. Kissinger ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to wiretap Morton Halperin as a potential security risk, he was recorded on the tap pleading with Mr. Halperin to remain In government, bureau documents disclosed today.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Wimbledon Tickets/ Obesity and Jogging
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Towns Told: No More SalesTax Money
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Mayors throughout New Jersey received a Dear John letter last week, advising them that their municipalities no longer would receive a share of the state's salestax receipts. Their reaction to the letter  it was from the Division of Local Government Services in the Department of Community Affairs was one mostly of cynicism, disgust and despair.

title: Sao Tome and Principe Celebrate Independence
description: SAO TOME, July 12 (Reuters)The tiny islands of So Tom and Principe, off the west coast of Africa, became independent today after nearly 500 years of Portuguese rule.

title: Gail Underwood, Bank Aide, Married to H. Elliott Rogers Jr.
description: Gail Marie Underwood and H. Elliott Rogers Jr., who received M.B.A. degrees in May from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday afternoon.

title: MAIL TO ASTRONAUTS BACKS SPACE PRAYER
description: HOUSTON. July 12 (AP)A rumor about an attempt to prevent prayer in space has resuited in a heavy volume of [mail to the nation's astronauts.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The formidable outer coverings of certain delectable naturalfoods, among them the quahog, or hardshelled clam, and the oyster, defy the clumsy thrusts of the novice harvester who, in desperation, often attacks them with a hammer or a tire iron.

title: Alabama Official And Utility Officer Accused of Bribery
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 12 William J. Baxley, Alabama's Attorney General, announced today that he had issued warrants charging bribery against the president of the Alabama Public Service Commission and a senior vice president of the state's leading telephone utility.

title: A Rookie Tackles English
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 12Even before he received his playbook from the New York Giants, Jos Lopez was buried in another book today in his dormitory room at Pace University; the book was New Horizons in English.

title: The Silent G. O. P.
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Why are the progressive Republicans silent?

title: Baseball to Confront Problems in AllStar Game's Backroom
LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: England Trails at Cricket
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, July 12 (Reuters)  Forced to follow on, England scored 93 runs for five wickets in its second innings at the close of play today on the third day of the first cricket test match against Australia. Australia's first innings score was 359 all out, while England's first innings total was 101.

title: Art Reproductions Debated by a Panel
description: PORT WASHINGTONAre painting reproductions as esthetically valuable as original prints? What tire the semantic and qualitative differences between prints and reproductions? What artistic creativity goes into a print and into a reproduction? Is it necessary for an artist to participate in a mechanical process for the product to be called a work of art? Is the public being duped by reproductions, thinking they are prints or a form that the art word has considered more worthwhile?

title: Phone Services for Runaways
description: HOUSTON. July 9A 16year  old youth named Jim stood in a telephone booth beside Highway 41 north of Tampa, Fla., yesterday afternoon and dialed 18002316946.

title: CHARLES WESTON
description: BOSTON, July 12  Charles Weston of Brookline, Mass., retired executive vice president of the Guy Gannett Publishing Company of Portland, Me., died Thursday in Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Nora Ephron on women and Nora Ephron
description: Nora Ephron, daughter of two Hollywood screenwriters, knew by an early age that all she wanted in this world was to come to New York and be Dorothy Parker . . . the woman who made her living by her wits. As readers of Esquire, New York magazine and the Book Review are well aware, Ephron has made it as a journalist not only through her wit, which though offhand and irreverent is without the Parker bite, but through the particular sensibility which infuses her pieces with a freely acknowledged moral bias ambivalence that nonetheless is seldom allowed to Mice over the whole show (unless she is describing her own pratfalls, which the does with splendid lan).

title: Britain Plans to Increase Rates for Postal Services
description: LONDON, July 12The British Post Office, faced with increased manpower costs, has announced a round of price increases and measures designed to save time for mailmen and make it possible for them to deliver more letters. At present, mail is delivered at every doorstep and, in large buildings, to individual apartments and offices.

title: Explorers Get Firsthand Look at Criminal Justice
description: The victims never had a chance. With speed and cunning sifted from years of experience, the two muggers pounced on their prey, grabbed wallets, cash and small change, and raced off into oblivion. The hitandrun tactic had worked again.

title: $15,000 DEAL CITED IN GRAINSALE SUIT
description: MIAMI, July 12 (UPI)A grain dealer paid $15,000 to a representative of the Government of El Salvador to persuade him to accept a $2.9million shipment of South African corn, the Miami Herald reported today.

title: Dr. Andrew W. Cordier Dead at 74; Columbia President and U.N. Leader
description: Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, president emeritus of Columbia University and former executive assistant to the Secretary General of the United Nations, died Friday night in the Manhasset (L.I.) Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

description: Mr. an Mrs. Thorl, as F. Swan of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Swan's daughter, Jacqueline Ann Van Cleve, to Joseph McMillan Hinshaw 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hinshaw Jr. of Chatham, Mass., formerly of New Vernon, N. J. An October wedding is planned.

Fallon of Burlington, Mass. The Rev. Edward Atkinson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Fitzgerald home in Cohasset.

title: A State Insect? The Fight Goes On
description: Different bugs for different folks?

title: Byrne Will Turn Back $5,000 Salary Increase
description: TRENTON, July 12  Because of New Jersey's financial crisis, Governor Byrne said today that he would turn back his $5,000 salary increase for the present fiscal year.

title: Behind the Flight: 5 Years of Joint Efforts
description: CAPE CANAVERAL. Fla., July 12One of the broadestranging technological collaborations ever undertaken between two nations prepared the way for the ApolloSoyuz linkup in space that is scheduled next week.

title: Beame Takes An Action, All on His Own
description: New York City's Mayor Beame, having exacted all the help he could from the state government but still deep in red ink, has turned again to the city's labor force to try to effect economies. Without consulting the unions, he has trimmed one of the key benefits in a union contract affecting 100,000 city employes.

title: Education Appears Destined To Bear Brunt of Budget Cuts
description: TRENTONWith their incometax battles a bitter memory, Governor Byrne and legislative leaders are scheduled to enact this week a compromise package of stopgap levies. These taxes are designed to restore part of the $384million in cuts that the Governor made to balance the state's current budget.

title: Western Travel Agencies Are Warned by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 12 (Reuters)A Soviet journal has warned that. Western travel agencies sending tourists here to try to promote Jewish emigration will face reprisals from the Soviet Government.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Delaware
description: LORDVILLE, N.Y.,  As night came down on the Delaware River, skeins of mist rose over the dark water and flickering hosts of fireflies vied with the stars for our attention.

Presented by American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater. With Karens Brock, Buddy Balough, Bonnie Mathis, Jonas Kaue. Sallie Wilson, Marcos Paredes, Ruth Mayer, Frank Smith, Melissa Hale, Marie Johanson, William Carter, Keith Lee, Amy Blaisdell, Susan Jones. title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WHILE Government officials, economists and others have been caking comfort from the big drop in the nation's inflation rate this year, there are some other analysts of the business scene who are fording cause to worry over the same issue because of a few straws they see wafting in the winds. At this point it is difficult to determine the validity of either position.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Manager Sparky Anderson of the firstplace Cincinnati Reds dismisses the pennant race: There ain't no way we can lose this thing anymore. We can only give it away. The players aren't worrying about L.A. anymore.

title: The Decision to Try for a Really Big Ship
description: President Ford has given crucial support to proponents of a nuclearpowered Navy by requesting funds for an atomic cruiser which defense and budget officials believe would consume an inordinate share of the naval construction budget.

title: Morris Parks' Unit Slates a Trail Walk
description: CHESTER  The Outdoor Education Center of the Morris County Park Commission is offering an interpretive trail walk today, starting at 2 P.M. Participants will be taught how to identify wildflowers and trees common to the area.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The finding of solutions to the great problems of inflation now plaguing us has been long regarded as a matter for economic analysis and for learned experts. But it is obvious that whatever solutions may be devised they are of no use unless they are put into effect.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JULY 13, 1975

title: CONFLICT ALLEGED IN RACING STUDY
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., July 12Eugene R. Kelley, the Suffolk County Police Commissioner, tonight reacted to one aspect of the charges of corruption, misconduct in office and what were termed other more serious crimes raised against him by the Suffolk District Attorney.

title: Sunny (Rainy) Days for Umbrellas
description: Tuesday is St. Swithin's Day, and umbrella makers' pulses surely quicken at the thought. Legend has it that if it rains on July 15  the saint's day of this obscure ninth century Bishop of Winchesterit will rain for the next 40 days.

description: A pilot program to rehabilitate 80 rundown buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn for occupancy by moderateincome families under the new Small Home Improvement Program has been approved by the City Planning Commission.

title: Six Months After the Cyclone, Darwin Has a Slum Mentality
description: DARWIN. Australia (AP)Children in Darwin still wake tip screaming when the wind picks up. Alleys are full of rubble behind poorly patched homes and shops. Chunks of sheet metal from destroyed buildings blow across highways.

title: Endpaper
description: It is for others to explain the mystery of why New York City's brush with bankruptcy occurred when it did, linking the city's new state of perpetually threatening insolvency with the whole history of the decline of New York (you knowdwindling revenues, rising crime, the flight of the middle class, and all that).

title: Joanne Ziebarth, Teacher, Wed Eliza J. Jewett, To Leo Corbett, Budget Analyst Stephen D. Gray
description: Joanne Ziebarth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. Ziebarth of Basking Ridge, N. J., was married to Leo Joseph Corbett yesterday afternoon in the Presbyterian Church in Basking Ridge. The Rev. Dr. Calvin Jackson performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. John Howard

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Farewell to Uganda
description: British author Denis Cecil Hills has been freed by President Idi Amin of Uganda. Mr. Hills spent 101 days under sentence of death for referring to President Amin as a village tyrant in an unpublished manuscript. The British lecturer was flown home to London where he told reporters that he regretted his characterization of General Amin and that he had written to him to apologize. Negotiations to obtain Mr. Hills' freedom, including a personal plea from Queen Elizabeth, had been conducted between Uganda and Britain for weeks.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: SPOLETO, ITALY Almost surprisingly, Spoleto's Festival of Two Worlds is now in its 18th yearduring which time everyone has gotten older, except for its founder, president and guiding force, Gian Carlo Menotti, who seems to reject calendars. But over the years, the rest of us who have been associated with the festival as either a participant or partaker have acquired many memories along with a few silver hairs. Spoleto means many things to many people. For example, most who have ever attended a festival in this peculiarly beguiling Umbrian townwhich is close to Rome on the map but centuries away in timewill carry memories of Charles Wadsworth's chamber music concerts in the flamboyantly baroque Caio Messina Theater in the Duomo Square, with Wadsworth's highflying pidgin Italian being almost as memorable as the gorgeous music floating negligently in the matutinal air.

title: TV Notes: Why CopsandRobbers Shows Are on the Way Out
description: What the near future holds  as near as 1976  is more family comedies and fewer police  adventure shows. This is not the glib prediction of some network chief; it is the common knowledge of the television marketplace. The coming decline in copsandrobbers fare will not be, for once, a reflection of diminishing ratings, since gunplay and mayhem are still as popular with viewers as ever. Rather it results from a crucial change in the economic system that governs television programing, one which is causing producers to shy away from the hardaction genre as fistancially risky. The bloodline of Kojak and S.W.A.T. faces extinction because;, it is losing its resale value.

title: Melissa Hunt Dempsey Wed to J. F. Gerrity 3d
description: Melissa Hunt Dempsey and James Francis Gerrity 3d were married yesterday afternoon at St. Christopher'sby??River Episcopal Church in Gates Mills, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the

description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Perline of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lea Perline, to Neil Jeffrey Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schwartz of Livingston Manor. N. Y.

title: SUMMER CLASSES CURTAILED HERE
description: Summer programs in the city schools, which have traditionally served scores of thousands of pupils with needed credits, remediation or training, have been drastically reduced this year, and some eliminated completely, because of recent budget cuts.

title: The D. A. R. Museum: A Small Mystery in the Heart of Washington
description: WHAT we have is a free museum with no crowds, about 50,000 items in the field of American decorative arts  all historical ma some of them really dynamiteand a small mystery as to why so few people know about us.

title: C.I.A.'s Reach Is Apparently Boundless
description: Among the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency that the Rockefeller Commission censured was the agency's infiltration of domestic political groups. The agency now stands accused of another form of domestic infiltration, in this case reaching into the executive branch up to the level of the Oval Office.

title: Tristate Unit Is Revising Transit Plan For Region
description: NEWARK  The TriState Regional Planning Commission is nearing the completion of a revised fiveyear transportation plan that calls for capital expenditures of approximately $2.5billion.

description: Susan Elizabeth Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Richards of Huntington and Quogue, I., I., and Timothy Robert Harvey were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev, Thomas Truscott at the Westhampton Presbyterian Church in Westhampton Beach, L. I. Mr. Harvey a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Harvey of Kenmore, N. Y., and Thunder Bay, Ontario.

title: Tita Beal Bride Of Eric Kruger
description: Tita Beal, daughter of .john Beal and Helen Craig of the stage and screen, was married here yesterday afternoon to Eric Kruger of New York, an economist with the Department of Social and Economic Affairs of the United Nations

title: Nations ReThink the Approach to Labor
description: BRUSSELSUnemployment, for almost two decades a distant concern in Western Europe, has become a political and social problem forcing new thinking about issues such as migrant workers, job training for youth and unemployment benefits.

title: LEO REISE SR.
description: BRANTFORD, Ontario, July 12 (AP)Leo Reise Sr., who played in the National Hockey League with the old New York Americans, died Tuesday. He was 83 years old.

title: Charles O. Finley: One Man or Two?
description: Charles O. Finley, the outspoken owner of the Oakland A's, is one of baseball's most controversial figures. These views of Finley are taken from Charlie O, a new book by Herbert Michelson (BobbsMerrill, $7.95). They are reprinted here with permission of the publisher.

title: Mary Hon Is Married to Paul Oldshue
description: Mary Elizabeth Holl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Holl of Inlet and Utica, N. Y., and Paul Frederick Oldshue, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Y. Oldshue of Rochester, were married yesterday at noon.

title: Smorgasbord of Things to See on L.I. Described in Book
description: The remnants of a 19thcentury community that practiced free love; a tiny primitive mill in a relatively undeveloped state park; a dazzlingly modern university modeled on a medieval hill town; architecture from every period in American history, from Dutch Colonial to I.M. Pei  the wealth of things to see on a day trip to Long Island is staggering.

title: HUNTS' LAWYER SAYS C.I.A. ASKED SPY AID
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., July 12 (UPI)Two sons of H. L. Hunt, the late oil billionaire, told the Central Intelligence Agency to get lost and are being prosecuted on Federal wiretapping charges because they refused to help the agency rune a spy ring, according to their attorney, Phillip Hirschkop.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Challenge Of Guerrilla Tactics
description: OXFORD, England  Ever since Scythian guerrillas kicked hell out of Emperor Darius's magnificent army in 512 B.C., orthodox military commanders have had their hands full in dealing with peoples who refused to fight by their standards.

title: On Socialist Democracy
description: In contrast to the diversity of unofficial opinion heard over the past 10 years, Soviet officialdom seems notably singleminded and united. Internally, like most political establishments, it is a divided world of competing ideals and aspirations.

title: For My Eyes Only
description: Most fledgling writers who perform their stint in the service are sustained by the hope that some day they'll get a book, or at least a short story, out of the experience. So you can imagine the unhappiness of all of us who did time in the various military intelligence branches when the Supreme Court recently refused to review a lowercourt ruling upholding the C.I.A.'s right to censor The C.I.A. and the Cult of Intelligence.

title: Tudor Returns With a New Ballet
description: It has been seven years since Antony Tudor created a new ballet. This long choreographic silence by one of the world's most important and enigmatic choreographers will be broken next Thursday, when American Ballet Theater presents The Leaves Are Fading . . . Tudor's new 30minute work set to music by Antonin Dvorak.

title: Mozambique to Concentrate on Tribal Reform
description: Before Mozambique gained full independence last month there was much speculation that the new Communistoriented Government would be preoccupied with furthering black nationalism in neighboring areas, particularly in Rhodesia.

title: Two Fire Marshals Shot In Bronx Gun Theft Arrest
description: Two city fire marshals attempting to arrest a man at a Bronx apartment yesterday were shot and seriously wounded by a suspect who then fled to the building's roof and was critically wounded there in an exchange of gunfire with backup marshals.

title: Susan Toliver, Alvin Robinson Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earl Van Dyke. Toliver of Brooklyn and Westhampton Beach, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Diane Toliver, to Dr. Alvin Tascoe Robinson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Franklin Robinson of McLean, Va. The couple will be married Aug. 2 in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Westhampton Beach.

title: The Restaurant Where Duck Reigns Supreme
description: SOUTHAMPTON  You know the secret in preparing duck?

title: Outgrowing SelfDeception
description: When some nuclear or ecological catastrophe whispers its greetings to our children there will probably be a psychologist among them who will devote his expiring moments to writing a selfimprovement book. The ancient, endless lust for easytoread recipes for wisdom and tranquillity will not be slaked by those two short volumes. On the other hand, given the shortage of paper and the strains on the publishing business, maybe we will have been blessed with them as a kind of anguished gasp.

title: Dance
description: The effect was tumultuous. The 49 Amid, as they were called in Spoleto, were naturally recruited from here and everywhere and included Menotti himself, presumably making his dance debut! The program was completed with a complexly beautiful duet, danced to a Bach cantata, that also shows Tharp's architectural regard for dance form and structure.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Our garage is in need of a new shingle roof. Can the new shingles be laid directly on top of the old roof or must the old shingles be treated or removed before the new shingles can be installed?R.D., Jackson Heights, N.Y.

title: Recession? New Private Clubs Shrug It Off
description: The lure of exclusivity, of lunches, dinners, cards, backgammon and dancing far from the madding crowd, has drawn more than 2,200 apparently recessionproof men and women to two recently opened private clubs, and a third that is still on the drawing board.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, July 13, 1975

title: Kristine Karen Pustay Wed to Peter Furey
description: Kristine Karen Pustay, a media buyer for Kallir, Philips, Ross, Inc., was married yesterday to Peter James Furey, an assistant planner for the Ocean County Planning Board in Toms River, N.J.

title: Town Council's Loss Is TeenAgers' Gain
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIPThree years ago, the Franklin Township Council moved its meetings to spacious new chambers in the recently completed $1.65million Municipal Building. The council has now vacated that meeting room in order to make way for another segment of Franklin's population: its teenagers.

title: Soviet Weather Satellite Up
description: MOSCOW, July 12 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has launched what appears to be a new type of weather satellite, designated Meteor 2, intended to study cloud formations and natural resources on earth, Tass, the official press agency, reported today. The agency said that the satellite was launched yesterday.

title: PORTUGUESE CALL A MILITARY ALERT
description: LISBON, July 12  Military units were placed on an alert today as the split in Portugal widened, with the Communist party and its military allies on one side and moderate and conservative forces on the other.

title: Bail Reform Order Upset by U.S. Court
description: A courtordered reform of bail procedures for inmates in Brooklyn jails has been overturned by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: PublicInterest Law: The Underpaid Bar
description: Their names are imposing, like those of large wellheeled research institutes. But the Center for Law and Social Policy, the Natural Resources Defense Council, and more than a dozen other organizations with similar names are law firms, of a very particular kind, that did not exist six years ago. They ??.

title: Wolff Sees Shift In Power Base
description: MINEOLARepresentative Lester L. Wolff, who represents the Sixth Congressional District in Nassau and Queens Counties, said last week that the focus of power within the 33member state Democratic Congressional delegation has shifted from the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan to Queens and Long Island.

title: G. P. Basset 4th Weds Nancy Wilson
description: Nancy Hamill Wilson, who teaches music and drama at the Hartridge School in Plainfield, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to George Pomeroy Basset 4th, a teacher of English and Latin at the Peck School in Morristown, N. J.
