description: A Brooklyn husbandandwife teamJan Barry, writer, and Paula Kay Pierce, director and actresscon eluded last year that, as Miss Pierce explained, they did not like the way things were done in the socalled professional theater.

title: Debby Watts Wed to Richard Wild
description: Deborah Ashley Watts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Watts of Wayne, III., was married there yesterday afternoon to Richard Dawson Wild, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wild of Erie, Pa. The Rev. V. Wayne Barton of the United Church of Christ performed the ceremony in the Little Home Church by the Wayside.

title: G.O.P. Names Spanish Aide
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) Jasper Garcia of Topeka, Kan., was named director of the Spanishspeaking division of the Republican National Commitee Tuesday, fir. Garcia, 36 years old has been field representative for Senator Bob Dole, Republican, Kansas.

title: Portugal's Army Sidesteps the Socialists
description: Antagonism between Portugal's increasingly radical military leadership and the country's moderate political groups has become an open break following the announcement last week by the armed forces that they plan to govern with the aid of popular assemblies that exclude political parties.

title: Amy Jill Schonenberg Is Married
description: Amy Jill Schonenberg and Mark Dryfoos were married at noon yesterday in the United Methodist Church in Setauket, L. L, by the Rev. Philip Schnell.

title: Hasidic Youths Leave for Camp for Both Fun and Learning
description: Through last weekwith the exception of Friday sundown, the beginning of the Sabbath and on Saturdaychartered buses gathered outside of 770 Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, the international headquarters of the Lubavitcher Movement, the worldwide body of Hasidic Jews.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE SOVIET UNION HAS BEGUN NEGOTIATIONS for a major purchase of grain that could total 10 million metric tons, the Agriculture Department said. . . This year's American corn crop was estimated at 6.04 billion bushels, up 30 per cent over the year before; the wheat crop at 2.18 billion bushels, up 22 per cent, and oats at 731 million bushels, up 19 per cent.

title: Valid Appeal, $30.80, Equals Stakes Mark in Dwyer
description: Valid Appeal took the lead in the stretch and went on to win the $84,000 Dwyer Handicap by three lengths at Belmont Park yesterday. The outcome was a distinct surprise to most of the crowd of 27,746 on the rainy afternoon, for the bettors had installed the EastWest Stable's Wajima the oddson favorite in the 1mile race for 3yearolds. Wajima was sec ond, four lengths ahead of Hunka Papa.

title: Design: Two solutions at the Waterside
description: Geoffrey Freeman and Hugh Hardy are two architects who, guided by a spirit of experimentation, decided to move to Waterside Plaza. Designed by the firm of Davis Brody Associates, the apartment towers (three middleincome, one low and moderateincome) sit on a sixacre deck that juts out over Manhattan's East River at 26th Street. Freeman, partner in charge of the New York office of the ELS Design Group, and Hardy, a partner in the firm of Hardy, Holzman and Pfeiffer, shared similar motives that prompted their separate moves. First, they totally endorsed the Waterside concept: an urban residential community placed at Manhattan's waterfront, with planned open spaces, retail and recreational facilities, and no cars (a garage lies beneath the plaza). Since both architects lived in brownstones, they looked forward to the stunning views afforded by the buildings location and height, plus the privacy. In addition, each architect could easily walk to work. However, their disparate lirestyles ana aesign preferences have generated quite different responses to the Davis Brodydesigned apartment layouts (most of which would not be called extraordinarygenerally they feature the room dimensions, including the eightfoothigh ceilings, and closet space typical of new luxury buildings).

title: Ycaza Junior Net Victor
Mideast Nuclear Peril Seen by Private Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)Two researchers said today that it is now so certain that Israel possess nuclear weapons that the United States and Soviet Union should decide how they will react if atomic warfare breaks out in the Middle East.

title: The Admiral Knows a Great Deal About Civilian Politics, Too
description: WASHINGTONIn his customary civilian attire, which he wears in symbolic separation from the Navy, Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover appeared last week before a secret session of the House Appropriations Committee to deliver his annual lecture on the state of the world as seen by the father of the nuclear Navy.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING PROPOSAL THAT IT MAN POSTS IN SINAI
description: LONDON, July 12The United States, seeking to facilitate a new disengagement agreement between Israel and Egypt, is considering the possibility of having American technicians man electronic surveillance stations in the strategic Sinai passes, reporters traveling with Secretary of State Kissinger were told today.

title: The Communists simply took over and refined the machinery
description: This book is an ambitious attemot to summarize the main forces and influences which had shaped Imperial Russia as it existed on the eve of the Revolution. To read and enjoy it requires some background in the subject; as the author rushes through 10 centuries of Russian history the general reader may feel occasionally lost, even though he will still appreciate Richard Pines's vigorous style.

title: MitchellLama Rent Rises Protested
description: Residents and community leaders called yesterday for a rent strike against several MitchellLama buildings on the Upper West Side after having been informed that the rents and maintenance charges for five of the 20 middleincome, Federal or city subsidized dwellings, housing more than 15,000 people, would increase sharply this month.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: The Family Ghetto: A LoveHate Affair
description: ABOUT a century ago my greatgrandfather boarded one of the old intercoastal steamships at Boston and started up the coast toward Maine. When he got to Rockland, he got off and took a horse and buggy south down one of those long fingers of land which jut out into the Gulf of Maine. He was looking for vacation land. Someone had told him that just beyond the village of Tenants Harbor there was a tolerable looking slice of coastline. Apparently, he liked what he saw at the mouth of Penobscot Bay, for he purchased a sizable chunk along the shore for less than a dollar an acre. Then he packed his bags and went back to Boston.

title: Hang Ripe Onions In A Braid
description: Onions easy to grow, We start with onion sets in spring and plant them in good, loose soil as soon as the ground can he worked. These early ones are ready to harvest by midsummer. We have found that one pound of sets will plant 50 feet of row adequate for a moderate family supply.

title: Dom Minasi Quartet Plays Rocky Jazz At the Shirtsleeve
description: Since the Shirtsleeve Theater at 321 East 73d Street opened its summer season of plays last month, it has been adding jazz to its theatrical presentations on Thursdays and Fridays, beginning at 10 P.M. This weekend, after the set on the Shirtsleeve stage for William Saroyan's new play, The Rebirth Celebration of the Human Race, had been struck, Dom Minasi's quartet set up its electric piano, drums, bass and a high stool for Mr. Minasi, a guitarist.

title: St. Kilian Boychoir Joins Federation
description: FARMINGDALE  The St. Kilian Boychoir here has been admitted to the International Federation of Boychoirs, John B. Shallenberger, the federation's president has announced.

title: Letters: Stewardess Fingers a Smuggler
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Observer
description: Everybody said King Arthur was a swell guy. He reminded people of Jerry Ford. So open and aboveboard. Not like that swine Merlin, who had always played his cards so close to his chest. Doesn't King Artie remind you of old Jerry? everybody said. Everybody called him King Artie, and sometimes just plain Art.

title: Rewards of Ambiguity
description: Displaying mastery of the creative ambiguity that is becoming Taipei's diplomatic hallmark, Taiwan and Japan have quietly repaired an economically disastrous anomaly in their delicate relationship. Direct air links by national carriers of the two countries are to be resumed, fourteen months after they were broken off in a threesided clash of national honor.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Live Off the Land
description: WASHINGTONMoney is a real problem, Jimmy Carter concedes cheerfully. With a campaign payroll grown suddenly to 18 men and women, Mr. Carter has to raise $2,000 a day, on the average, to stay even. He is managing to do just that, but he has no cash reserve yet. He got only $30,000 back on his first $50,000 investment in directmail fundraising, so he makes lots of personal appeals for money these days and misses no opportunity in his travels to schedule paid lunches and receptions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Puts Its Oil Together
description: A major plan for both energy conservation and oil production is under way in the Yates field in West Texas. the nation's second largest oil reserve.

title: Dietz Is Eliminated At Lucerne Regatta
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, July 12The Americans rowing in the Lucerne international regatta were struck down today by intestinal influenza as much as by the competititon.

title: Alfas Finish 1, 2 in Watkins Glen Rain
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 12The fastest driver lost interest in the race, the winning driver said it was stupid to let it go on and the Six Hours of Watkins Glen ran only 4 hours 49 minutes today.

title: End of Laos War Has Brought No Peace to Thousands in Meo Clans
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  The war in Laos is over, and still the Meo mountain tribemen are on the run. Caught in the crossfire of the Indochina struggle since the nineteenforties, organized into an army by the Central Intelligence Agency, they continue to try to escape the war's consequences though the guns have fallen silent.

title: Chief Awards at Riverhead Show
description: VARIETY GROUPS

title: The President's Announcement
description: While President Ford's announcement of his candidacy for the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination has caused little surprisehis decision was made and publicly acknowledged last Novemberit has nevertheless affected the actions of Vice President Rockefeller and of Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California.

title: Mary Carmody Bride of Francis Ryan
description: Mary Ann Carmody and Francis Xavier Ryan were married yesterday at noon in SS. Peter and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The Rev. Francis X. Ryan, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Army Colonel Freed By Kidnappers in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12Col. Ernest R. Morgan of the United States Army, who was kidnapped by leftists 13 days ago, was released unharmed this evening to Premier Rashid Karami of Lebanon.

title: Voice of Turtle Heard in Chester
description: CHESTER  The starter raised his arm, and the crowd surged forward to get a better view of the track. Crack The sound of the blank being fired cut through the nervous chatter of the spectators, and the starting gate was lifted.

title: Army Training Accord
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) The Army signed an agreement with the Labor Department this week that gives Army commanders authority to sponsor apprenticeship programs patterned after those in private industry and approved by the Labor Department's Manpower Administration.

title: Taquin, a Bouvier, Gains Best at L.I. Dog Show
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 12 A rainy day field of over 800 dogs was led today by an imported Bouvier de Flandres, Ch. Taquin du Posty Arlequin at the Riverhead Kennel Club show.

title: A talk with the Communist leader
description: The man who counts most in presentday Portugal, the man who influences the army's power machine, the man, in one sense, who has emerged the winner, although he was beaten at the elections, is Alvaro Cunhal, the Portuguese Communist party leader. It isn't too easy to obtain an interview with him. If one succeeds, however, one has only to listen to him in order to grasp what is happening in that country, to obtain a clear picture.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed a shade lower in an irregular trading pattern after reaching a new 1975 last week. Many investors appeared reluctant to make major commitments, given uncertainty on the market's ultimate direction.in two weeks. The prime rate is considered a barometer of stock activity in that it tends to point the way for other interest rates and thus indicate how attractive alternate forms of investment may become.

title: INVESTING
description: When interest rates hit a ninemonth slide that carried the bellwether bank prime lending rate from 12 per cent last summer to 7 per cent last April, the money market funds faced a moment of truth.

title: Fishermen Form Coop to Eliminate Middlemen
description: AMAGANSETTLong Island has had a cauliflower growers cooperative and a duck farmers cooperative for many years. Now, the first fisherman's cooperative to be chartered in the state has been organized on the Eastern end. It is a combined wholesale  retail enterprise and offers several advantages to its members. According to Robert Martin, president of the cooperative, fishermen of Eastern Long Island have always functioned with an 18th  century individualistic frame of mind.

title: The Mideast: Lines Still to Be Drawn in Sinai
description: The elusive search for a new ceasefire agreement between Israel and Egypt remains elusive, despite another round of personal diplomacy which has taken Secretary of State Kissenger to Europe for meetings with Israeli Premier Yitzhak Rabin and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko.

title: Save Some Vegetable Seeds for Next Year
description: Save those halfempty vegetable seed packets because many kinds can be used next year or even longer.

title: The High Court And Its Policy On Mr. Douglas
description: The United States Supreme Court Justices during the last six months have apparently adopted a policy of counting the absentee vote of their ailing colleague, Associate Justice William O. Douglas, only when it failed to affect the outcome of cases.

title: Sloop Ragtime Pacific Race Leader
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12 (UPI)Pushed by 20knot northeast trade winds, the 62foot sloop Ragtime reported today she was 593 miles from Honolulu in the 2,225mile transPacific yacht race. Her run in the previous 24 hours covered 267 miles. The 79foot ketch Ondine, out of New York, made a strong bid with a 300mile run and moved to within 59 miles of Ragtime. Windward passage from Portland, Ore., reported a 250mile run putting her 739 miles from the finish at Diamond Head.

title: WIDE IMPACT SEEN IN ATTICA VERDICT
description: Like almost every event associated with the 1971 prison uprising at Attica. the recent acquittal of Bernard Stroble, ?? the inmate leaders, has taken on a symbolic, magnified importance.

title: Rhodesia Plans a New Drive To Suppress Black Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 12The stalemate in negotiations between the Rhodesian Government and black nationalists seemed as if it might soon develop into another fullscale confrontation.

title: Food
description: Quick breads are perfect for summer baking because they require only a small expenditure of time and energy. They keep well, and in fact improve in flavor if wrapped and stored for a day or two. On this page are three regional specialties: a lemon bread from the Midwest, an apple bread from Oregon's fruitgrowing Hood Valley, and hot bread puffs (called sopaipillas) from New Mexico.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass market paperbacks are sold an newsstands, in supermarkets and variety stores, as well as bookstores. This analysis is based on reports from representative whosesalers and chains with more than 9.000 outlets in the United States.

title: Memorial Services
description: WAKSMANDeborah B. Memorial services Saturday, July 19, at 2:00, Fisher House of The Church of The Messiah, 22 Church St., Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Dorothy Ann Jannarone Plans Wedding to David W. Kemper
description: Brig. Gen. John Robert Jannarone, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jannarone of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Ann Jannarone, to David Woods Kemper. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Madison Kemper Jr. of Kansas City, Mo.

title: Survey Yields Beneficial Results in Combating Dog Heartworm
description: From time to time this column has warned about heartworm. It has pointed out that the dreaded word in the lexicon of the Gulf Coast and Southern fancier now is appearing with greater frequency in the metropolitan area. This is the disease where parasites lodge in a dog's heart. If left untreated, the disease may prove fatal.

title: Indian State Is Wary of Mrs. Gandhi
description: MADRAS, India, July 12The police of this proud old port, which is feeling pressure from India's central Government, yesterday arrested seven persons who were promoting a timehonored local cause: independence for the state of Tamil Nadu, of which Madras is the capital.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Picture Credits

title: Stable Rates Expected Despite Citibank Move
description: Money market rates are likely to remain stable this week, despite the primerate increase to 7 per cent from 7 per cent announced last Friday by the First National City Bank. This was the most widely predicted increase of the Year in the basic lending charge of a major bank. In Wall Street it is viewed as a lagging event rather than a leading move.

title: ITALIAN REDS DENY $86,000 EXXON GIFT
description: ROME, July 13 (Reuters)The Italian Communist party today denied having received $86,000 earmarked for it by the Exxon Corporation.

title: BUTTERFIELD DENIES HE WORKED FOR C.I.A.
description: Alexander P. Butterfield, a former White House aide, strongly denied last night that he had served the Central Intelligence Agency as a contact or in any other capacity while on the personal staff of President Nixon.

title: Release of 8,000 Is Begun by Taiwan In Honor of Chiang
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, July 14The Government early today began releasing nearly 8,000 prisoners under an act of comhutation that is being carried out in memory of President Chiang Kaishek on the 100th day after his death of April 5.

title: Blackmun Suggests Mon Public Contact by Justices
description: ST. PAUL, July 13 (AP)Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court says that he and his fellow Justices should keep in constant touch with the grassroots sentiment in the country.

title: Screen: Claude Jutra's 'Kamouraska'
description: Claude Jutra's "Kamouraska," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is a French-Canadian melodrama that is too fastidious and tasteful in some of its parts to qualify as pulp fiction, but too sentimental and foolish to be tragic or even romantic.When the film's illicit lovers misbehave to the point of murder, you don't respond to the grandeur of their passion. You think, instead, that they have dangerously short fuses. What's worse, they are careless. No wonder their lives are blown to bits.The time is the late 19th century, and the setting is rural French Canada. Elisabeth (Genevieve Bujold), a pretty, virginal child of good family, brought up by her widowed mother and maiden aunts, is married off to Antoine Tassy (Philippe Leotard), the young, vigorous lord of Kamouraska, a remote but rich estate that overlooks the St. Lawrence River and even includes some of its islands.The neighbors remarkas neighbors are wont to remark in this kind of moviethat Elisabeth and Antoine make a handsome couple and Elisabeth's first weeks at Kamouraska are blissful. Then, helas, the dream turns into a nightmare.Antoine has terrible table manners. He slurps his food. He eats with his fingers and never, never uses a napkin. He drinks too much, uses gross language and takes his pleasure from Elisabeth in the thoughtless manner of a live-in rapist. But that's not all. Antoine is also certifiably nuts.One night, he scrambles out of bed and tearfully confesses his sins as a drunkard and fornicator, all the while banging his head against a mirror that finally shatters.The next day, when Antoine stands mute in the living room, deep in catatonia, his mother is no help to Elisabeth. "All he needs is a little black coffee," she says with confidence  which is where the movie and I began to lose touch with each other."Kamouraska" was adapted for the screen by Mr. Jutra, the director (whose "My Uncle Antoine" was shown here in 1972), with Anne Hebert, who wrote the original novel. It's a number of stories awkwardly ellipsed into onethe story of Elisabeth's desperate attempts to get away from Antoine, of her romance with Georges Nelson (Richard Jordan), a moony country doctor, of their various plans to murder Antoine and of Elisabeth's later marriage to a rich, cranky, sick old man who, despite Elisabeth's trial and apparent conviction for complicity in the murder of one husband, depends on her to fetch his life-sustaining medicine.Mr. Jutra is an able director, and he has a much more than able cast of players, but none of them are able to give emotional urgency to material that depends so heavily on our believing in these characters and sharing their sense of sin and guilt. Perhaps the form of the film, which is fractured into bits of time, works against a convincing, cumulative impact. The flashbacks and flashforwards have the effect of distancing us from the events, which is all right in social comedy but is fatal to this kind of headlong melodrama.It's not enough that the film looks very good with all its moody landscapes and snowscapes, its fine country houses and its awareness of the seasons. The characters, too, look absolutely right, especially the mad Antoine of Mr. Leotard, who was so fine in Alain Tanner's "The Middle of the World."Miss Bujold is a skilled, sometimes wonderfully surprising actress, but like Mr. Jordan, who gave an especially good supporting performance in "The Friends of Eddie Coyle," she is pretty much mired in the requirements and conceits of second-rate gothic fiction.

title: Proxy Fight Seen at Hoerner Waldorf
description: A proxy battle for control of the Hoerner Waldorf Corporation is planned by a group headed by Alvin J. Huss, its former chairman, and Richard N. Hoerner Jr., a director, who favored the company's merger with the Champion International Corporation, a major forest Products concern. That $234 million deal was terminated abruptly by a majority of the Hoerner Waldorf board without explanation on June 30.

title: Carol Mann Leads
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 13 (AP)  Carol Mann held a oneshot lead over Jan Ferraris today when play was suspended in the final round of the rainmarred $65,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: ISRAELI PLANES HIT PALESTINIAN CAMP; ARABS RETALIATE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13  Israeli planes raided the largest Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon twice today, and Palestinian guerrillas retaliated with rocket attacks on Israeli communities near the border.

title: Existence of an Atomic Particle Supports the Charm Hypothesis
description: After months of hectic effort on both sides of the Atlantic to find the answer to last fall's perplexing discovery of two atomic particles that fit into no generally accepted theory, a group in Germany believes it may have found the answer.

title: City Realty Tax Outpaces Values
description: The true value of real estate in New York City increased less than 1 per cent in the last 10 years, but the taxes levied on the properties rose 21 per cent, an analysis of the city realty rolls shows.

title: Soviet Cautions Asian Nations On Permitting American Bases
description: MOSCOW, July 13The Soviet Defense Ministry warned Asian nations today that they could be drawn into military conflicts by permitting United States military installations on their territory.

title: Apollo Starts Countdown for Tomorrow; New U.S.Soviet Flights Are Considered
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 13As the countdown began today for the first SovietAmerican space mission, a United States space agency official disclosed that the two nations expected to begin negotiations this fall leading toward more ambitious joint flights in the early nineteeneighties.

title: Where Fun and Games Are Taken Seriously
description: In the old days, you went to summer camp to learn swimming from Uncle Buddy and arts and crafts from Aunt Joanne. But these days, it is possible to go to a sports camp and learn from such milliondollar celebrities as Doctor J or Joe Willie. Within the last week, Julius Erving was teaching basketball to small groups in the Catskills; Joe Nemeth was supervising his football camp in the Berkshires; and members of the Stanley Cup champions, the Flyers, were working in a hockey camp outside Philadelphia. While respectful of the stars, the youngsters generally listened and learned, rather than swarmed over them for autographs.

title: Maltbie Triumphs On 64275
Fisk U. Cutting Faculty and Salaries
description: NASHVILLETen years ago, Fisk University was a thriving black college that was attracting government and foundation money to serve students representing a good portion of the country's best black students.

title: Secret Asian Space City Is Not on Russian Maps
description: The Central Asian space city of Leninsk, from which a Soviet manned craft is scheduled to be launched tomorrow for an orbital rendezvous with an Apollo capsule, is so secret that it has been omitted from published Soviet maps and its estimated 50,000 residents were not even listed in the results of a national census taken in 1970.

title: Living in New York: Writer Finds World in Harlem
description: Frank Hercules is a widely traveled black man  an essayist, novelist and lecturer who could live, anywhere in the world. But he chooses to live in New York. And for him, the only place to live in New York is Harlem.

title: ISRAELI PLANES HIT PALESTINIAN CAMP; ARABS RETALIATE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13  Israeli planes raided the largest Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon twice today, and Palestinian guerrillas retaliated with rocket attacks on Israeli communities near the border.

title: Reds Score, 53, As Seaver Fails
description: CINCINNATI, July 13The Mets, who arrived in this city brighteyed and hopeful on Friday, left town tonight morose, bedraggled and 10 games out of first place.

title: TV to Show TakeOff Of Apollo and Soyuz
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 13Television viewers around the world will get a look at the launching of the Soviet Stiyuz spaceship on Tuesday as well as telecasts from the astronauts in orbit and of their landing next week.

title: Heart Medication Will Go Into Orbit With Slayton
description: Tucked away in the medical kit aboard the Apollo spacecraft that is scheduled to rendezvous with the Soyuz capsule are potent heart pills that Donald K. Slayton is ready to swallow in the unlikely event that his heart suddenly beats as erratically as it once did.

title: Herbicide Use in Ozark Forests Challenged
description: RUSSELLVILLE, Ark., July 11A group of mountain people and enviromentalists have obtained a temporary Federal Court injunction to stop the United States Forest Service from using a controversial herbicide in the Ozark and. St. Francis National Forests in Arkansas.

title: Weaver Is Narrow Victor In Wet 5,000Meter Run
description: Tim Weaver of the New York Pioneer Club, splashing in ankledeep water over the final 300 yards, won the Steve Prefontaine Memorial 5,000meter run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: State Senate Unit to Hold Inquiry on Abortion Clinics
description: TRENTON, July 13A special Senate committee will meet bere Thursday to begin an investigation of abortion facilities and procedures in New Jersey.

title: PATMAN SCORES SPENDING BY FED
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) A House. subcommittee staff reported today that the Federal Reserve System last year spent $4,749 for Christmas decoratons at its New York branch, $14,000 to transfer an employe from Miami to Atlanta and $10,074 to pay one of its former officers as a consultant.

title: Caesar Captures Jump
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 13  Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Butler's Caesar, the only mount in the field to negotiate the course in faultless fashion in the third round, won the Lake Placid Grand Prix for open jumpers today.

title: Latife Usaki, Formerly the Wife Of Kemal Ataturk, Is Dead at 77
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 13 (AP)Latife Usaki, former wife of President Kemal Ataturk, founder of the Turkish Republic, died yesterday. She had lived in the fashionable Harbiye district of the city since their divorce in August, 1925, two and a half years after their marriage. She was believed to be 77 years old.

title: Stein gut Says State Deficit Is Growing
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut estimated yesterday that the state faced a deficit that had grown by a couple of hundred million dollars since adoption of the budget last March 25, when his estimate was an imbalance of $300million to $400million.

title: Market Watches British Inflation Curbs
description: PARIS, July 13London's struggle against inflation is being closely watched from here and other Continental centers for effects it could have on economic and political development in Europe.

title: Legislature in Its 1975 Session
description: Still scrabbling to learn and control the massive network of state government, Hugh L. Carey finally was left to himself by the Legislature last weekend to govern alone and deal with a worrisome aftermath of budget problems, vetoes and enactments, and the resetting of his course toward the coming state and national election year.

title: A Section of Fort Lee Is to Become a Fort Again
description: FORT LEEThe fortifications of Fort Lee, from which the Continental Army fired on British ships in the Hudson River below, are being restored to resemble what they looked like 200 years ago during the Revolutionary period.

title: RAINS POUND CITY FOR A 2D SUNDAY
description: Torrential rains hit the metropolitan area for the second successive Sunday yesterday, flooding highways and cutting electricity. High winds felled trees and lifted parts of roofs in New Jersey.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Ballet: 2 Kinds of Swan Lake Triumph
description: American Ballet Theater led off its Swan Lake season Saturday afternoon and evening at the New York State Theater with two fine casts an opinion obviously shared by a public responding in its own not entirely unprepared way.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: slowed up. He made it to the pits and finally got under way almost two laps behind the leaders.

title: $15Million HotelResort Center Opened by New Mexico Apaches
description: MESCALERO, N. M., July 13A $15million luxury tourist and recreation complex on the sprawling, 719  square  mile Mescalero Apache Reservation, described by the Bureau of Indian Affairs as the nation's largest Indianowned and operated yearround resort, quietly opened its doors to guests here Friday,

title: Elusive Figure Hunted in Europe as Terrorist Key
description: LONDON, July 13Scotland Yard and other European police forces are conducting one of the biggest hunts in years for a 25yearold Venezuelan sought on charges of murder, bombing and links to international terrorist groups.

title: Talks Opening on State Budget
description: Governor Byrne and members of the New Jersey Legislature will begin formal meetings today that are designed to solve the state's budget problems, and once again they will start their talks far apart on key issues.

title: It Is Not Behind Us
description: If Mayor Beame really believes that the municipal fiscal crisis is reasonably behind us, as he insisted repeatedly to newsmen the other day, the outlook for New York is even grimmer than it need be. The crisis that carried this city to the brink of default as recently as last Monday is by no means resolved. Saying it is won't make it so and could make it worse.

title: Lockheed Wins Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The United States Air Force has announced a $24.7 million contract for the LockheedGeorgia Company to build live C130 Hercules transport planes. The planes will replace American military planes previously sold to the Royal Canadian Air Force, the Pentagon said.

title: Fugitive Surrenders
description: HONOLULU, July 13 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation has announced the arrest of Richard Dean Holton, 40 years old, one of its 10 most wanted fugitives. He was wanted for bank robbery and murder. The F.B.I. said today that Mr. Holton turned himself in to police on the northern Hawall island of Kauai.

title: As Golf Is Halted
description: Country Club course when play was called off. The nine pros will return at 10 A.M. tomorrow, picking up where they left off when darkness set in.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JULY 14, 1975

title: Macao's Intrigues Thwart Lisbon's Plans for Reform in the Colony
description: MACAO, July 11Up to a year or so ago, a group of Chinese strongmen ran the gambling, gold smuggling and opium trade, on which this small Portuguese enclave in the South China Sea survived. A Portuguese colonial government ran the city, and a Chinese Communist Government across the border looked on benevolently. It was all very complicated, but the arrangement seemed to please everyone.

title: Violent 30Second Storm Strikes Paramus
description: PARAMUS, N.J., July 13Highvelocity winds chopped a twomile swath through the west side this Paramus for 30 seconds this morning, damaging homes, tearing down power lines and uprooting hundreds of trees.

title: Bolshoi Opera's Chorus Is a Star in Its Own Right
description: Can a star ever be a constellation or a constellation a star? In astronomy the answer is no, but in opera it is yes when the constellation is the chorus of the Bolshoi Opera.

title: Luxembourg Tares Stir Over Ambssador Farkas in Stride
description: LUXEMBOURG  In the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, an independent nation smaller than Rhode Island in the center of Western Europe, American Ambassadors who get their posts through political contributions are almost as much a part of the scene as the tangy white wine from the steep slopes of the Moselle River.

title: Rosewall Captures Swiss Tennis Final
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 13 (AP)Ken Rosewall, 40yearold Australian, defeated Karl Meiler of West Germany, 64, 64, 63, to win the Swiss international open tennis championshin today.

title: Played Part with Style
description: The wedding of Latife Hanim the latter word is a title of respect meaning lady, by, which she was known in Turkeywas symbolic of the Turkish leader's determination to bring women out of the privacy of the traditional Turkish home. It was performed by a civil official at a reception at her father's home.

title: A Filly Wins 5th In Row
description: Richard E. Bailey's Dearly Precious extended her victory streak to five in winning the $27,600 Astoria at Belmont Park yesterday. Mike Hole, who had ridden two winners earlier on the program, rode the daughter of Dr. Fager to a 2length triumph in the 5furlong sprint for 2yearold fillies.

title: U.S. Open Tennis Officials Considering Night Matches
description: Night matches may be added to the United States Open tennis championships this year.

title: Hrabosky Helps Cards Repeat Over Dodgers, 21
description: In what could almost be considered a repeat of the nationally televised game played 24 hours earlier between the same teams, the Cardinals edged the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday for the second straight day in St. Louis.

title: Police Functions Hard Hit As Layoffs Curb Activity
description: In the two weeks since dismissals began in the city, the Narcotics Division has stopped arresting streetlevel drug dealers and officials have sharply reduced undercover surveillance of organized crime.

title: Bcston's School Budget Cut $30Million by Mayor
description: BOSTON, July 13 (UPI) Mayor Kevin H. White said today the Boston School Committee's $177million budget for the 197576 fiscal year was wasteful and he has cut it by $30million.

title: Captive Nations Week Opens
description: A mass at. St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday marked the opening of Captive Nations Week. In his sermon, Msgr. John Balkunas, a priest of Lithuanian ancestry who is pastor emeritus of the Church of the Transfiguration in Maspeth, Queens, came to the defense of Aleksandr T. Solzhenitsyn and criticized those who have said that the Nobel Prizewinning author, now on a tour of this country, had been fomenting a cold war.

title: APCO OIL FAVORS NORTHWEST OFFER
description: The Apco Oil Corporation, Houston, announced yesterday it had decided to recommend the second, and higher of two competitive tender offers made last week for the majority of its stock offer. It was from the Northwest Energy Cornpany, which is offering $20 a share for 1.5 million shares, about 51 per cent of the total Apco shares outstanding.

title: Coffee Council Agrees On Principles of Treaty
description: LONDON, July 13 (UPI)Coffeeexporting countries and their major customers agreed today on the principles of a new treaty to regulate the coffee trade.

title: Despite Huge Outlays, Iranian Forces Are Far Short of Goals
description: TEHERAN, IranDespite the billions of dollars spent on them, Iran's armed forces are about five years away from a credible military organization capable of achieving the Shah's strategic goals.

title: 2d Sailing Victory For Thunderhead
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13The second day of the 77th annual Larchmont Race Week drew 193 yachts despite miserable weather.

title: Catherine Jones Is Bride at Yale
description: Catherine Ann Jones, a music instructor at Guilford (Conn.) High School, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. David Pickar, a resident in the department of psychiatry at the. Yale School. of Medicine, of which he is a graduate.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Economy Reported Rising In the Metropolitan Area
description: The New York metropolitan area's economy was reported yesterday to have taken a turn for the better since latel 1974 compared with the nation as a whole, while the region's competitive ability has improved with wage, and price changes.

title: Redman Easy Victor in Lola at Watkins Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 13Mario Andretti missed the start, Jackie Oliver failed to reach the finish and nice things continued to happen to Brian Redman today.

title: Treasury Weighs Investigation Of Prices of Foreign Cars Here
description: DETROIT, July 13 (AP)The United States Treasury Department is considering a formal investigation into charges that foreign car makers are selling cars in this country at illegally low prices.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Israeli planes attacked the largest Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon twice yesterday, and Palestinian guerrillas retaliated with rocket attacks on Israeli communities near the border. Israeli fighterbombers attacked the Ein al Helweh camp, which shelters about 20,000 refugees just south of the southern Lebanese port city of Saida. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: MATTHEW HUTTNER, LED PYRAMID BOOKS
description: Matthew Huttner, president of Pyramid Communications, Inc., a paperback book publishing concern, which he founded in 1949, died yesterday of a heart attack suffered while playing golf in Greenwich, Conn. He was 59 years old and lived at 911 Park Avenue.

title: SHUT FIREHOUSES TO BE REOPENED, DESPITE JOB CUTS
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the Fire Department would reopen all seven of the fire companies that were disbanded when 1,000 firemen were laid off earlier this month.

title: U.S.S.R. Wins in Rowing
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland, July 13The Lucerne international rowing regatta concluded today under ideal conditions that saw teams from Eastern European countries set three course records and win five of the eight events on Lake Rotsee.

title: Robert Kennedy's Son, 20, Is Held on Speeding Charge
description: WOODSTOCK, Va., July 13 (AP)David Kennedy, 20 years old, son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was arrested and accused of driving 92 miles an hour down Interstate 81 near here last night.

title: Police Functions Hard Hit As Layoffs Curb Activity
description: In the two weeks since dismissals began in the City, the Narcotics Division has stopped arresting streetlevel drug dealers and officials have sharply reduced undercover surveillance of organized crime.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: We had a letter a short while ago from Ruth Donnelly of Manhattan who asked if we could recommend a good, reliable knife grinder.

title: Living in New York: Writer Finds World in Harlem
description: Frank Hercules is a widely traveled black man an essayist, novelist and lecturer who could live anywhere in the world. But he chooses to live in New York. And for him, the only place to live in New York is Harlem.

title: Article 4  No Title
Lower Manhattan Makes A Fine Exhibition of Itself
description: Picking up a catalogue at a corner newsstand is not the normal way to begin viewing a museum exhibition  but then again, Immovable Objects is hardly a normal exhibition.

title: Dr. Henry J. Dillemuth, 76, Otolaryngologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Henry J. Dillemuth, an ear, nose and throat specialist in the Bronx for 40 years, died Saturday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Mountainside. N.J.

title: Lying In State: I
description: In 1972 Cambridge Survey Research, public opinion analysts, asked people whether they agreed with this statement: Over the last few years this country's leaders have consistently lied to the American people. Of those asked, 38 per cent agreed. A similar Roll was taken in 1974, and 55 per cent agreed with the statement. This spring, 68 per cent agreed.

title: Joan Little Slaying Trial Starts Today
description: RALEIGH, N. C., July 13A dozen attorneys and others of a 35member defense team will go into Wake County Superior Court tomorrow armed with the most advanced courtroom techniques in their efforts on behalf of Joan Little, accused of firstdegree murder.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The true value of real estate in New York City increased less than 1 per cent in the last 10 years, but the taxes levied on the properties rose 21 per cent, an analysis of the city realty rolls shows.

title: Wilson's AntiInflation Plan: Big Unions Hold the Key
description: LONDON, July 13Although public opinion polls and other data indicate that most British wage earners support Prime Minister Harold Wilson's newest plan to fight raging inflation, their support may not be enough. Mr. Wilson also needs the consent, by no means guaranteed, of a few powerful trade unions, as well as considerable personal courage. Recent history here has shown that without these no incomes policy can work.

title: Lutheran Split Unmended As Delegates Head Home
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 13As delegates headed home this weekend from the 51st convention of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod, they weighed admonitions from their leadership that the church was in for difficult times in attempts to solve the issues dividing them.

title: Half of Police force Is Out In Albuquerque Over Wages
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 13More than half the 500member Albuquerque police force walked off the job yesterday in a dispute with the city over wages and threatened layoffs, and remained out today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip E. Rollhaus, 78, Aided SyntheticRubber Research
description: Philip E. Rollhaus, a chemical engineer who helped develop transparent plastic and synthetic rubber during World War transparent plastic and synthetic rubber during World War II, died Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhasset. L.I.

title: The Corning Agreement
description: JERUSALEM, July 13Now that the Israelis no longer feel they are being stampeded, into making onesided concessions by an impatient American Secretary of State, an interim agreement with Egyptwhile not at handis likely to be worked out by the end of the summer.

title: Watson Beats Newton By Shot on Last Hole
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 13  Thomas Sturges Watson, who in the past has come oh so close to winning his first major golf championship, finally did it today. In a marvelous round that went down to the wire, he twoputted for a par on the 48th hole to win the 104th British Open by a stroke from Jack Newton, who was bunkered at greenside and took a bogey 5.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Rabin's Trip to Germany Evoked the Past
description: LONDON, July 13When the chartered jetliner carrying Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and his party taxied to a halt at Berlin's Templehof Airport last week, there was a fulldress official reception waiting on the runway. Mayor Klaus Schutz and several top city officials were there, along with an honor guard and red carpet.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Is Vague On Holding '76 Election
description: LONDON, July 13 (UPI)Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, in an interview published here today, left open the possibility that next year's national elections might be delayed because of India's domestic crisis.

title: Advertising
description: I think it's crazy, said Alvin H. Schechter, president of Schechter & Luth, talking about the way companies are adopting initials as their corporate names.

title: Valerie J. Pennisi Bride of Paul Parker
description: Valerie Jean Pennisi, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Pennisi of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there yesterday to Paul Michael Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. George Parker of Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: JOHN H. CALLAHAN
description: John H. Callahan, president sine 1942 of the Hearst International Employes Association, died Saturday of a heart attack in Woodside, Queens. He was 66 years old and lived at 6215 53d Avenue, Maspeth Queens.

description: Some leading private economistsmost of them identified with Democratic adwareto one that requires ministrations  have opened serve Board. They fear that the Fed is set on a path of relatively tight monetary policy that could take the steam out of the nation's anticipated economic recovery.

title: Israel Stands Firm On Terms for Pact With Egypt on Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, July 13  The Israeli Government today stood firm on its terms for an Americanmediated interim agreement with Egypt and decided to continue negotiations and seek clarifications without haste.

description: LUANDA, Angola, July 13 (Reuters)  Fighting between rival Angolan liberation movements intensified today, and Portugal's Foreign Minister was flying here from Lisbon in an effort to end the bitter conflict in this African colony.

description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 13  An elegant white toy poodle, Ch. Peeples Sahara, owned by the New York lawyer, Robert A. Koeppel, and handled by Richard Bauer, strutted to her fourth top award today. She was named best of the 1,274 dogs in the Twin Brooks Kennel Club show on The Mall.

Thomas of Wilmington, Mass. The Rev. Angelo Arrando performed the ceremony in the St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

GOING OUT Guide
description: LATIN LATITUDE The new cocktail lounge performer reflects the conservative taste of the Gramercy Park Hotel, 2 Lexington Avenue, in a singular way. Mondays through Thursdays, from 7 P.M. to 11 P.M., Luis Neves plays the piano in this informal candlelit room off the lobby. The music is also piped into the connecting bar, a bit too strongly. Even so, in this adjoining room a window table looking out on the, quiet, treeshaded street is a nice listening and sipping post. (Vermouth is $1.08.)

description: IZMIR, TurkeyAt my age, mused Dorothe GouldPratt as she watched the sun set behind Izmir Bay from her rooftop, I should be sitting on the porch in a rocker, instead of being off my rocker.

title: DOTT HALSEY
description: Dott Halsey, a supervisor in the Greenwich Village office of the city's Social Services Department, died Friday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 31 Bethune Street.

description: Efforts of New York and other urban areas to meet Federal Clean Air Standardsand, not incidentally, to protect their citizens from a serious health menacewill be vitally affected by a decision expected this week from the Senate subcommittee on environmental pollution.

description: Julius L. Kuffler, former president of I. Wohl, Inc., wholesale dry cleaners, and a past president of the Wholesale Cleaners and Dyers Board of Trade, died Saturday at his home, 100 West 58th Street. His age was 83.

description: I have only one subject  myself said William Saroyan, with becoming immodesty. If I'm going to reveal something about all of us, then it has to be through me. I have that limitation, or advantage.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 13 (UPI)  Rear Adm. Jesse Dale Jewell, who received the Navy's highest honor for disregarding his own injuries to attend men wounded during the Pearl Harbor attack on his ship, died Friday. He was 83 years old.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 13The concept of SWAT, an acronym for Special Weapons and Tactics, is catching on with police departments across the United States in a manner that some police experts suspect is more faddish than essential.

title: Kuwaiti Oil Production Declined in First 5 Months
description: KUWAIT, July 13, (Reuters) Kuwait's oil production during the first five months of this year averaged 2.1 million barrels a day, a fall of more than 17 per cent from last years figures.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Despite pouring rain, 3,000, people gathered in Wurtsboro, N.Y., to mark the 150th anniversary of the Delaware and Hudson Canal, which ran 108 miles from Honesdale, Pa., to Kingston, N.Y., but went cut of operation in 1899 when rail freight proved cheaper. In New Jersey, Senator Clifford P. Case joined history buffs for a similar celebration in honor of the 100mile Morris Canal, along which mules used to haul barges on 10day round trips between Philipsburg, N.J., and Newark.

title: SHUT FIREHOUSES TO BE REOPENED, DESPITE JOB CUTS
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the Fire Department would reopen all seven of the fire companies that were disbanded when 1,000 firemen were laid off earlier this month.

description: Torrential rains hit the metropolitan area for the second successive Sunday yesterday, flooding highways and cutting electricity. High winds felled trees and lifted parts of roofs in New Jersey.

title: Save The Schools
description: At its recent annual convention, the National Education Association expressed deep concern over the impact of current reductions in school expenditures on the quality of public education. The most obvious effect any budget squeeze is the demand to eliminate from the curriculum any subject that cannot easily be identified as part of the three R's. Under such pressure, the ax threatens to fall on art, music, foreign languages and a variety of other fields of study, to the detriment of the country's future intellectual strength.

title: Socialist Realism Comes to Met Stage
description: Presumably, there was a political reason for the Bolshoi Opera to bring The Dawns Are Quiet Here, by Kirill Molchanov to the Metropolitan Opera. It is hard to think of any other.

title: SAIGON LABORERS COMPLAIN OF BOSS

description: Hirsch Jacobs used to call them perishable goods, and every horse trainer knows what he meant.

description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 13 (UPI)Fred Samara of the New York Athletic Club won the national Amateur Athletic Union decathlon championship today with 8,061 ponts.

title: Starvation In Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON  The evacuation of Cambodia's larger cities has been sensationalized in the Western press as a death march. In fact, it was a journey away from certain death by starvation, for at the time the former Phnom Penh Government surrendered, starvation was already a reality in the urban centers, and widespread famine only a matter of weeks away, while in the countryside there was a sizable food surplus.

description: MAESTRIDante. In memory of our beloved grandfather. He was loved deeply and will be truly missed. Robert, Deborah and Anthony.

title: E.E.C.'s Multinationals

These corporations are at once a response to global change and a spur to still greater change. They require new social and legal approaches to assure that the efficiency gains of which they are capable are realized in ways that advance the general welfare, not profits alone.

title: Panel Urges Army to End Assigning on Ethnic Basis
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI)A committee of generals has officially reported that the Army does not assign Jewish soldiers to Saudi Arabia, will not send GreekAmericans to Turkey or TurkishAmericans to Greece, and has a disproportionate number of personnel with Spanish surnames assigned to Latin America.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 13 When Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said last Friday that the Soviet Union was negotiating to buy American grain once again, it confirmed what Midwestern wheat And corn traders have known for Many weeks.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED, POLICE ARE PELTED

title: Minutemen Take Lead In N.A.S.L. North Race

title: About the Giants . . .
description: I was stunned, said BruceNeville, the 6foot5inch, 235pound defensive tackle from Fairleigh Dickinson, after being released yesterday by the Giants on the advice of the club's medical staff. I guess they felt they didn't want to take a chance because I was a diabetic. But I had never had any problems in the past, even when I played lacrosse. . . . Another free agent, Robert Colbert, a defensive back, also failed the physical because of an irregular heart beat. . . . Two rookie linebackers, Terry McClowery and John (Wildman) Tate, have left camp and joined John O'Bradovich, the tight end on the College AllStar team.... George Ludwigsen, the wristwrestling champion, again showed he is the strongest man on the club when he benchpressed 475 pounds, as high as the Machine would go, during the battery physical tests yesterday. The 248pound Ludwigsen was signed as a free agent.

title: TEACHERS URGING PRESCHOOL PLAN
description: HONOLULU, July 13A national education program reaching every child in the country, starting at 3 years of age, and providing tens of thousands of new teaching jobs, has emerged as a top priority among American teachers.

title: CARL SHAPELY, 80, FOOTBALL COACH

title: MURRAY ROSOF
description: Murray Rosof, a lawyer and accountant here, who ran unsuccessfully for Representative from the Ninth District, Brooklyn, on the American Labor party ticket in 1948 and on the Republican ticket in 1934, died Saturday on vacation in Margaretville, N. Y. He was 73 years old and lived in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Yankees, Twins Washout Victims
description: The Yankees and the Minnesota Twins returned to Shea Stadium yesterday to finish off what they had begun Saturday night. But just 12 hours after they had been forced to suspend play at 1:06 A.M. on Sunday, it was judged that the field was so rainsoaked that it was unplayable.

title: Existence of an Atomic Particle Supports the Charm Hypothesis
description: After months of hectic effort on both sides of the Atlantic to find the answer to last fall's perplexing discovery of two atomic particles that fit into no generally accepted theory, a group in Germany believes it may have found the answer.

title: Books of The Times
description: It will be said that this book about the Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman heavyweight fight in Zaire, Africa, is a case of Norman Mailer temporizing once more that to put between hardcovers an account of a boxing match is again to delay the serious work he has been promising these many years (that epic novel, that consummation!), and to indulge yet again in clowning, false bravado, and mystical trivia. And a casual browser in these pages will quickly find support for this impression. Here on Page 31 is Mr. Mailer debating what to call himself and settling, ever so humbly, on Norman, because he was feeling a little bored with his presence lately and besides that's what everybody in the fight game called him. Elsewhere is Mailer taldng on the familiar selfgenerated psychic daresto do a mile or so of roadwork with All (with the exception of Erich Segal and George Gilder, he had never heard of a writer who liked to runwho wanted the brilliance of the mind discharged through the ankles?); or to take a modestly risky step between two balconies seven stories above the ground (Of course he had done it all in freedom from fear. The freedom that drinking brings). Here is Mr. Mailer discovering in African philosophy a mirror of his beliefs that humans are fortes, not beings, and that history is, an organism, and reveals a sense of style. And everywhere else is the familiar Mailer style, stuffed with rhetorical queries and exclamations beginning with the words What a. . . with an occasional metaphorical intimation of electricity and cancer thrown in for old times sake.

title: G.A.O. Evaluating Report for Army On Fort Monmouth
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The General Accounting Office has agreed to help members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation compile a report to Acting Secretary of the Army, Norman P. Augustine, that will evaluate an Army Department proposal threatening 1,700 civilian jobs at the Fort Monmouth Materiel Command.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13 (UPI)Ragtime reported today it was just 325 miles from Honolulu at the rollcall of the 65boat fleet in the transPacific yacht race. However, Ondine was making a strong move to he first to finish the 2,225mile contest. Ondine, a 79foot ketch with considerably more waterline length and sail area than the 62foot sloop Ragtime, was 354 miles out according to the 8 A.M. report. She was gaining 30 miles a day on the leader in strong northeast trade winds up to 20 knots.

title: Oil Executive Backs Ford on Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, July 13John E. Swearingen, board chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said today that he favored President Ford's proposal yesterday for a gradual elimination of price controls on domestic oil.

title: Article 3  No Title
Bridge:
description: Planning ahead in the bidding can sometimes cause an expert to abandon routine paths and emerge with a startling sequence. This year's prize for imaginative bidding ought to go to John Percy of New York for his effort on the diagramed deal played recently at the Gallerie of Bridge and Games, 345 East 80th Street.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Newark man surrendered to authorities yesterday, saying he had shot and killed a man and wounded another during an argument Saturday. The police said the man, Eddy Rivers, 43 years old, gave himself up at noon and underwent questioning in connection with the shooting death of Cole Shepard, 48.

title: VALHALLA GUARDS IN PRISON PROTEST
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., July 13A work slowdown by guards the Westchester County Jail that has caused delays in the transporting of prisoners to County Court went into its second week today.

title: Bicentennial Barge to Make 32 Stops
description: The New York State American Revolution Bicentennial Commission's major undertaking for 1976 will put a special 250 foot Bicentennial Barge within easy reach of 9 out of 10 state residents. The Commission announced last week the schedule for the craft. It will have 10,000 square feet of exhibition space that will be devoted to showing New York and the life of New Yorkers, at the time of the American Revolution.

title: Personal Finance: Breaking One's Lease
description: In these days of aggressive consumerism the old rule of caveat emptorlet the buyer bewarehas been changed sharply. More and more courts have placed responsibility on sellers to make good on guarantees, to replace shoddy or defective items, to make sure that advertising tells the truth.

title: Mali and Upper Volta Sign Pact to End Border Dispute
description: DAKAR, Senegal, July 13 (AP)Mali and Upper Volta have signed a peace agreement to settle a decadeold border dispute.

title: Philip Morris Net Climbs
Charter New York And Manufacturers Increase Earnings
description: The secondquarter surge in earnings reported by the nation's banks continued yesterday, with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Charter New York Corporation announcing strong gains.

title: JACK BROWN
description: Jack Brown, assistant track coach at Fordham University from 1957 to his retirement in 1974, who specialized in field events, died Friday in Huntington Beach, Calif., where he had been living. He was 84 years old.

title: C.I.A. Predicts Success For Apollo and Soyuz

title: GEORGE W. M'CARTHY
description: George W. McCarthy, director of the Long Island Council on Alcoholism, Inc., in Garden City, and its predecessors since 1956, died Sunday at the East Meadow Division of the Nassau County Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Westbury, L. I.

title: Rosenbergs' Innocence Asserted In Sons' Suit to Open Case Files
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Declaring that they were firmly convinced of the innocence of their executed parents, the sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg filed suit today in an attempt to make public all the Government's files on the celebrated espionage case.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JULY 15, 1975

title: H in H.E.W. Means Headaches
description: Forrest David Mathews must be a very brave man. At the relatively tender age of 39, he is about to end his career as president of the University of Alabama to wrestle with the jungle of very thorny problems that beset the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: SUSPECT GIVES UP IN HUGHES THEFT
description: LOS ANGELES, July 14 Donald Ray Woolbright surrendered today and pleaded not guilty to charges arising from a 1974 burglary of Howard R. Hughes's headquarters here.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford, who said he felt about 40, celebrated his 62d birthday yesterday. He began the day with a 35minute physical examination in his White House study and went on to a surprise party in the East Room.

title: AEROSOL SPRAY BAN REJECTED BY AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it had turned down a petition for a ban on aerosol sprays, which critics contend may be destroying portions of they earth's atmosphere.

title: Reynolds Tobacco Pact Set
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 14 (UPI)The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company of WinstonSalem, N.C., announced today it had licensed a Bulgarian Government concern, Bulgartabac, to manufacture and market its Winston brand of cigarettes. It is the fink American brand license the Bulgarian company has taken out.

title: Trade Terms for Rumana Approved by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 14(AP) A Ford Administration proposal to grant regular trade, terms to Rumania was approved 24 to 3 today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallace Raises $1.3Million, Widening Fund Lead
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama raised $1.3million more for his undeclared Presidential campaign in the last four months, increasing his fundraising lead over the wide field of 1976 candidates.

title: OREGON PARK ACTS TO CLEAN UP WATER
description: CRATER LAKE, Ore., July 14 (UPI)A watertreatment plant on loan from the army tomorrow will begin flushing out a contaminated, water system that forced the closing of Crater Lake National Park.

title: ExColonel Backtracks on C.I.A. Contact Charge
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 14 (UPI)The retired Air Force colonel who unleashed a storm of controversy last week by charging that a highranking laid in the Nixon White House. was a C.I.A. contact man said today that he may have been fed misleading information to protect the identity of the real contact.

title: Reuss and Blue to Open AllStar Game
description: MILWAUKEE, July 14The American League, which hasn't done too well with its AllStar bats in the last 15 years, will try to win tomorrow night's game with philosophy.

title: A BIG U.S. AID OFFER TO ISRAEL REPORTED
description: TEL AVIV, July 14 (Reuters)  Secretary of State Kissinger has assured Premier Yitzhak Rabin of $1.8billion in aid if Israel reaches an interim agreement with Egypt, an Israeli newspaper reported today.

title: JURY SEATED IN SUIT OVER STERILIZATION
description: BARNWELL, S.C., July 14 (AP)A Federal court jury was chosen today for a $1.5million civil suit brought on behalf of two welfare mothers, one who claims she was sterilized to obtain treatement under the Medicaid program and another who says she was threatened with the operation.

title: Up From the Basement
description: WASHINGTON, July 14You might run for mayor of a small city or even for Congress out of a makeshift headquarters in the basement of your house. But everybody knows you can't run for President that wayeverybody but Fred Harris.

title: U.S. Disarmament Chief Seeking Law Against Divulging Monitoring Secrets
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 The director of the United States disarmament agency is pressing Congress to make it a crime to divulge or publish secret information on how this country monitors Soviet military developments.

title: Squalls Mar Larchmont Junior Sail
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 14Squalls and postponements marked the first racing today in the Larchmont Junior Regatta.

title: Zutty Singleton, 77, Dies Jazz Drummer of 2 Eras
description: Zutty Singleton, one of the most celebrated jazz drummers to come out of New Orleans, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He had suffered a stroke several years ago. He was 77 years old and lived at the Woodward Hotel, Broadway and 55th Street.

title: Grain and Soybean Prices Drop; Sugar Futures Off 1c a Pound
description: Grain and soybean prices swung over a wide range yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade before closing lower. Wheat futures lost from 6 to 19 cents, corn was off 3 to 5 and soybeans were down 11 to 13 cents from Friday's closing prices.

title: TV Networks to Cover BlastOffs
description: Television coverage of the SovietAmerican space missions is scheduled to begin today with live views of the Soyuz launching from the Soviet Union, set for 8:20 A.M., Eastern daylight time.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 14Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: MAN GETS 14 YEARS IN MONTANAFRAUD
description: HELENA, Mont., July 14A man found guilty of falsifying forms of the Montana Workmen's Compensation Division was given the maximum sentence of 14 years in prison today.

title: Open Interest
Article 3  No Title
PRESIDENT URGES DECONTROL OF OIL OVER 30 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14President Ford announced today a plan to remove gradually all price controls on domestic oil over a 30month period. He said it was a reasonable compromise that would stimulate production of oil in this country.

title: Israelis in Tel Aviv Stone U.S. Embassy
description: TEL AVIV, July 14Israelis resentful of American pressurel for an Israeli pullback in occupied Sinai stoned the United States Embassy here tonight.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Luring Bass
description: WOLF ISLAND, St. Lawrence River, Canada  Although my companions had warned me that the smallmouth bass of the St. Lawrence River would probably not take a surface lure at this time of year, I stuck with a flyrod popping bug to the point of absurdity. Meanwhile, they hauled in enough bass for a noon fish fry put on by our skipper, James Brabant of Clayton, N. Y., on the north end of Wolf Island.

title: Commuters Score BusRail Aid Slash
description: TRENTON, July 14Two dozen representatives of commuter groups and transportation unions, faced with the possibility of drastic cutbacks in bus and railroad subsidies begin ning midnight Sunday, denounced the state's cutback plan at a public hearing today din the State House complex.

title: Williams Still Hopes to Bring The Red Devil to Broadway Despite Boston Closing
description: Tennessee Williams's The Red Devil Battery Sign opened June 18 at the Shubert Theater in Boston and closed 10 days later. Thirtyfive years ago, Mr. Williams's Battle of Angels also opened and closed, prematurely in Boston.

title: City Health Agency Duns 9 Unions for $4.6Million
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation is dunning nine unions in an effort to collect more than $4.6million in services already rendered to their members for about the last year.

title: Science Museum in Virginia Plans to Use Solar Energy
description: RICHMOND (AP)The proposed new Science Museum of Virginia has been designed to make use of solar energy for heating and cooling, and when completed it will he the world's largest public building to utilize this energy source, according to Dr. Paul Knappenberger Jr., the museum's director.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Turbo Power and Marine Systems, Inc., a subsiadiary of United Technologies Corporation, has received a letter of intent from the Union Electric Company for six Twin Pac gas turbine electricity generating systems valued at more than $30million.

title: Big Banks Outside City Go to 7%
description: Several large banks outside New York, including the First National Bank of Chicago, the Continental Illinois National Bank, the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh, the Union Bank of Los Angeles and the Bank of California, yesterday increased their prime, or basic lending rate, to top corporate customers to 7 per cent from 7 per cent.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The French have picked up more fashion ideas from us than simply blue jeans. One is the whole concept of resort clothes. That is, sun clothes to be sold in the middle of the winter and worn by women who live in warm climates or are fortunate enough to travel there when snow is on the ground.

title: DR. JUDITH G. POOL, HEMOPHILIA EXPERT
description: Dr. Judith Graham Pool, professor of medicine at the Stanford University School of Medicine, died Sunday at Stanford University Hospital after an illness of several months. She was 56 years old.

title: West German Groups Revive Hope for the Zeppelin's Comeback
description: FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, West GermanyOn July 2, 1900, a strange cigarshaped object, designed by a local eccentric named Count Ferdinand Zeppelin, emerged from a floating wooden shed on Lake Constance near here and sailed into the air, silhouetted by the Thurgau Alps rising from the far shore.

title: PRESIDENT URGES DECONTROL OF OIL OVER 30 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14President Ford announced today a plan to remove gradually all price controls on domestic oil over a 30month period. He said it was a reasonable compromise that would stimulate production of oil in this country.

title: Bill Calls on Agencies To Hold Open Meetings
description: TRENTON, July 14 (UPI)The State Senate passed a sunshine bill today requiring governing bodies at all levels to open their meetings to the public.

title: F.H.A. Mortgages Denounced as Path to Windfalls
description: CHICAGO July 14The Federal Housing Administration's, program of lowcost mortgages for lowincome and moderateincome families was denounced at a Congressional hearing today by critics who charged that it provided lucrative financial windfalls for private mortgage concerns while contributing to the creation of urban slums.

title: Advertising
description: Compared with most consumer magazines, which are off in advertising, the socalled city magazines  the independent city magazines are doing great. Generally speaking they are up in advertising pages and revenues as well as in circulation.

title: Business Briefs
description: IROQUOIS FALLS, Ontario, July 14 (AP)Some 1,000 Canadian Paperworkers Union members struck the Abitibi Paper Company, Ltd.'s 17,000tonayear newsprint mill here last night, a mill spokesman confirmed today.

title: MANILA PRESSES REBEL CAMPAIGN
description: MANILA, July 14The Philippine Government has reportedly taken advantage of a lull in fighting with insurgents in southern Mindanao Island to press its campaign to win over Moslem rebels while sending troops to clean out scattered areas of continued resistance.

title: Mrs Doerner Victor
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 14Cynthia Doerner of Australia fought back tonight to win the $10,000 Ms. America circuit tennis tournament with a 57, 60, 62 victory over Barbara Downs of Alamo, Calif.

title: FRANCIS FITZPATRICK
description: Francis J. Fitzpatrick, senior partner in the law firm of Boal, McQuade & Fitzpatrick, died yesterday in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 71 years old and lived at 163 Brite Avenue, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: I.C.C. DRAFTS A PLAN TO HELP BUS RIDERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission proposed today regulations designed to improve service on interstate buses.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger warned the third world majority of the United Nations yesterday that its arbitrary tactics in the General Assembly were alienating the support of the American people for the organization. He made the statement in a speech at the Institute of World Affairs in Milwaukee. It appeared to he an oblique warning to the third world nations that if they suspend Israel from the General Assembly this fall, as they did South Africa last year, the United States might withhold financial support from the United Nations or withdraw from the session. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Court Translation Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Senate passed legislation today providing for simultaneous translation into relevant languages of Federal Court procedings involving persons who do not speak English.

title: Mississippi Editor Slain
description: JACKSON, Miss, July 14 (UPI)Frank Hains. 49 years old, arts editor of The Jackson Daily News, was found dead in his apartment early today, the victim of a crushing blow to the head. He had been bound and gagged. Mr. Hains wrote an entertainment column, On Stage. Before coming to Jackson, he worked a number of years in radio and at newspapers in Vicksburg.

title: West Side Highway Plan. Faces Hurdles That May Kill It
description: The extensive concept of a new West Side Highway, 39 months in preparation by a select planning group, has become pockmarked by legal, financial and environmental pitfalls that threaten to cancel or delay it interminably.

title: PROTEST CANCELED BY HISPANIC UNIT
description: ELIZABETH, July 14The Hispanic American Committee of Elizabeth said it had canceled a demonstration scheduled for today against the administration of Mayor Thomas G. Dunn because of an appeal by a local newspaper for moderation through July 21, the end of a previously set coolingoff period.

title: Justice Agency Accedes To Request for F.B.I. Data
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Justice Department has broadened its response to requests from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence for classified F.B.I. documents, following an assertion by Senator Frank Church, the committee's chairman, that the department's sluggishness had severely hampered the committee's work.

title: Ailing Bayi to Miss Meet at Durham
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 14 (AP)Filbert Bayi of Tanzania won't compete for PanAfrica this weekend during the United StatesPan AfricaWest Germany track meet, the meet coordinator, Leroy Walker, said today.

title: The Summer Stars
description: In the night skies of midsummer, it may be hard to find familiar groups at first sight.

title: Soviet Giving a Lift to Marxist Junta Trying to Pull Somalis Out of Poverty
description: MOGADISHU, SomaliaMonsoon winds from the Indian Ocean whip the bright green filigree of the trees, and driving rain bounces off the walls of aging Italianstyle buildings.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: NOVA, Ohio, July 14 (UPI)Martin Cox, the longest surviving livertransplant patient in the United States, died two days before the sixth anniversary of his operation. The 17yearold patient died Friday night in Cleveland. He will be buried tomorrow.

title: AUG. 11 DATE IS SET IN GANDHI APPEAL
description: NEW DELHI, July 14The Supreme Court of India today set Aug. 11 for the start of the appeal in the electoral corruption case against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Israelis in Tel Aviv Stone U.S. Embassy
description: TEL AVIV, July 14Israelis resentful of American pressure for an Israeli pullback in occupied Sinai stoned the United States Embassy here tonight.

title: Laos Yields U.S. Warehouse Seized by Reds
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 14 (AP)The Laotian Government ordered armed Pathet Lao guards out of a United States warehouse today after an informal meeting at the Foreign Ministry between American and Laotian officials, a United States spokesman said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 14 (AP)Chris Kupec lost another round today in his attempt to play football at the University of North Carolina for one more season. Judge J. Braxton Craven of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit upheld a lower court ruling denying a preliminary injunction against the Atlantic Coast Conference. Rupee, a quarterback who played three seasons at North Carolina, was seeking a fourth year of eligibility to compensate for 1973, when he was injured and played briefly in two games. He indicated today he might now play for the Charlotte Hornets of the World Football League.

title: KISSINGER WARNS MAJORITY IN U.N. ON U.S. SUPPORT
description: MILWAUKEE, July 14Secretary of State Kissinger warned the third world majority of the United Nations today that its arbitrary tactics in the General Assembly were alienating the support of the American people for the world organization.

title: London Journalist Barred From India as Undesirable
description: NEW DELHI, July 14 (UPI)The Indian Government barred a correspondent of The Financial Times of London from entering the country today as an undesirable.

title: Buggs Off to a Fast Start In Giants' Training Camp
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 14Danny (Lightning) Buggs, who has succeeded Henry Carr and Rocky Thompson as the new speed king of the football Giants, does not intend to waste his time or talent running up and down in front of the bench this season.

title: French Here Celebrate Bastille Day
