description: What do Frenchmen, who number 40,000 here, do when they are away from home and it is le Quatorze Juillet Bastille Day  their Day of Independence?

title: Carey Vetoes an Increase In Fees of Harbor Pilots
description: ALBANY, July 14Governor Carey today vetoed a bill that would have increased fees paid by shipping companies to pilots in New York Harbor.

title: Youth Slain, 4 Are Injured In Fight in Pittsburgh Parks
description: PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP) One youth was shot to death and four others beaten today in apparent racial fighting in the city's Beltzhoover section, the police said.

title: MICHAEL P. CASEY
description: Michael P. Casey, a Brooklyn artist and a past president of the Richmond County Junior Chamber of Commerce, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan after being stricken with a heart attack at his home, 561 Hendricks Street, Brooklyn. His age was 35.

title: LISBON CONDITION FACES NEW SPLIT
description: LISBON, July 14Leaders of the Popular Democratic party, the second largest electoral force in Portugal, predicted today that a military government, with some civilian economic experts, would be established here by Wednesday night.

title: Auto Insurers, Citing Inflation, Seek Increase in Rates of 34.1%
description: TRENTON, July 14 (UPI)Citing the sharp impact of inflation, 250 auto insurers writing policies in New Jersey asked today for a 34.1 per cent increase in their rates.

title: ALFRED L. ELLS
description: Alfred Lingley Ells, a retired supervisor of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died Sunday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 1199 Park Avenue.

title: 2 Fires in Wisconsin Linked To Violence Over Novitiate
description: KESHENA, Wis., July 14 (UPI)Two suspected arson fires caused $100,000 damage in neighboring Shawano County today and appeared to be connected with violence that started last week, Menominee County Sheriff Kenneth Fish said.

title: Auto Workers Idled
description: DETROIT, July 14 (AP) About 285,000 of the nation's 712,000 bluecollar auto workers were off the job today  more than half of them because of model changeover or summer vacation periods.

title: Madeline Helium Mihok Married
description: St. Elizabeth's Memorial Episcopal Chapel in Tuxedo, N. Y., was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Madeline Helium Mihok, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Helium of Tuxedo, to L. Gordon Hamersley Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Alfred J. Miller.

title: Coast Avocado Center Faces People Peril
description: FALLBROOK, Calif.Harry Parker isn't quite sure what presents the greatest threat to his avocado grovea root disease that has killed off some of his neighbors' trees or people blight.

title: Market Place
description: Investors, given the gains and opportunities that have developed in the stock market, are not exactly falling over themselves to buy Treasury bills these days.

title: Florida Weather Improves
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 14The American astronauts, spacecraft and rockets were ready tonight for the scheduled launching tomorrow of the first international manned space mission, the planned rendezvous flight between, Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft.

title: Soviet Union Publicizing the Mission
description: MOSCOW, July 14With a flourish of publicity previously unknown in this country before a space mission, the Soviet Union discarded, temporarily at least, its policy of prelaunching secrecy. In the past, the public and the world have never been told when this country would launch a space vehicle, manned or unmanned.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Robert J. Helstoski, the brother of Representative Henry Helstoski, a New Jersey Democrat, pleaded not guilty to charges he had failed to list contributions to his brother's campaigns on his incometax returns. He made the plea before United States District Court Judge Frederick B. Lacey and was freed in $25,000 personalrecognizance bond, pending trial.

title: 2 HOMES FOR AGED CLAIM INSOLVENCY
description: The owners of two privately owned facilities housing nearly 275 elderly people have filed petitions for bankruptcy in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, contending tha they could not continue to operate under the present rate of reimbursement.

title: Chess:
description: The third annual World Open tournament, July 26 at the Roosevelt Hotel, established a new record of 815 entrants for Swiss system events, thus indicating that the shock of Bobby Fischer's refusal to defend his title and its consequencethe decline in player turnoutsis at an end.

title: Carol Mann, On 209, Wins By a Stroke
35Nation Agreement on Security Years in the Making
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The European security conference, now heading toward a conclusion in Helsinki, Finland, is designed to document the intention of the 35participating countries to live in peace and a spirit of cooperation.

title: HOUSE UNIT REJECTS SEXBIAS REVISIONS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14A House subcommittee agreed today not to delete three school's sex discrimination rules from the regulations that are scheduled to become law next week.

title: People and Business
description: President Ford, who recently has been making his first official visits to faroff places, became yesterday the first Chief Executive in 38 years to visit the marble headquarters of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington.

title: Scott Scores. 76. 76
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 14 Gene Scott had a close escape in the first round of the Valley Circuit of Charhpions tennis tournament today as he edged Bob Millington, a South African, 76, 76.

title: Mrs. Munro Takes Medal by 2 Shots
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 14Mrs. Alexander Munro Innis Arden won the medal by two strokes today in the annual Women's TriCounty golf championship at the Scarsdale County Club. She carded a 423981 in the round played in intermittent heavy rain.

title: On the Wrong Side
description: India's Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has summoned Parliament to meet in a few days to pass judgment on the state of emergency under which she has jailed thousands of political opponents, muzzled the press and clamped down on demonstrations and other expressions of dissent. The session will offer a critical test of the commitment of India's political leaders to the freedoms which Mrs. Gandhi has recklessly cast aside in panicky reaction to recent legal and political challenges to her rule.

title: GUARDSMAN FOUND NO REASON TO FIRE
description: CLEVELAND, July 14 (UPI)Capt. John Martin, the commander of a group of Ohio National Guardsmen who fired into a group of student antiwar demonstrators at Kent State University on May 4, 1970, testified today that he saw no reason to fire during the demonstration.

title: Burglaries by F.B.I. Conceded by Kelley
description: WASHINGTON, July 14Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today that during the postWorld War II period, F.B.I. agents had committed breakins and burglaries to secure information relative to the security of the nation.

title: ProReds Urging Refugees In U.S. to Return to Vietnam
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 14 (UPI)ProCommunist Vietnamese students have been trying to persuade refugees here to return to South Vietnam.

title: NEW LAW SHOWS SCOTTO'S POWER
description: The political influence of Anthony M. Scotto, the union boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, was demonstrated when a bil introduced at his behest was passed as the final measure of the 1975 State Legislature in Albany.

title: Jury Selection Challenged By Joan Little's Lawyers
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 14Defense attorneys for Joan Little made clear as her trial opened today that they were putting the Southern system of justice on trial as much as they were defending a young black woman accused of firstdegree murder.

title: Cambodian Refugees Tell Of Revolutionary Upheaval
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 14 Dozens of recent Cambodian refugees, some of whom escaped from the country as late as last Tuesday, are telling of a nation in a state of total revolutionary upheaval that is rapidly returning to its undeveloped past of a century ago.

title: Commuting Byrne Counsel Denies State Tax Liability
description: TRENTON, July 14Governor Byrne's chief counsel, Lewis B. Kaden, said today that he did not pay a special New Jersey commuters tax last year even though he lives in New York and works in New Jersey, and conceded that this had raised a number of questions concerning his residence and its effect on his state tax liability here.

title: F.B.I., for First Time, to Expunge Record of Legal Federal Arrest
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The shadow that had darkened the life of a respected school administrator for 24 years has been lifted by a recent agreement of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to expunge her arrest recordthe first time this has been done in a legal, Federal arrest.

title: 23 Food Businesses Named as Violators Of City Health Code
description: The Health Department has named 23 more food businesses for failing their second healthcode inspection and warned that they face closing if violations persist upon a final visit by its inspectors. The names of the establishments and the results follow.

title: EXREP. W. S. BARING OF NEVADA, 63, DIES
description: RENO, July 14 (UPI)Former United States Representative Walter S. Baring, who served a record 20 years as Nevada's lone Congressman, waging war against the New Frontier and Great Society programs, died yesterday at Hollywood Pres byterian Hospital of cardiac pulmonary complications. He was 63 years old.

title: Democrats Fear Inflation From Oil Price Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Congressional Democrats reacted sharply and negatively today to President Ford's proposal to lift price controls on oil and moved ahead with plans to act this week on legislation that puts Congress on a collision course with the President over energy policy.

title: Russians Are Confident
description: MOSCOW, July 14Top officials of the Soviet Soyuz space program confidently asserted today that they were ready to loft a twoman crew into orbit tomorrow on a historic space rendezvous with an American Apollo spaceship.

title: Burglaries by F.B.I. Conceded by Kelley
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today that during the postWorld War II period, F.B.I. agents had committed breakins and burglaries to secure information relative to the security of the nation.

title: Workers Resentful on Loss of Short Summer Day
description: The 9to5 workday returned to the Municipal Building after a twoweek absence yesterday and most city clerical workers seemed resigned to the prospect of putting in an extra hour for the rest of the summer, but resentful at losing the 9to4 day that they regarded as a contractual right.

title: Judge Thomas W. Swan Dies; Led U.S. Appeals Court Here
description: Judge Thomas W. Swan, who retired in 1953 as Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here, died at his home in New Haven. He was 98 years old.

title: Soyuz Is Mainstay Of Soviet Program
description: The Soyuz spacecraft that is to be launched today is a modernized version of a standard orbital vehicle that has been the mainstay of the Soviet Union's manned space program since 1967.

title: Vienna: A Year for Wallowing in Waltzes
description: VIENNAOccasionally, at the end of a concert, Karl Rhm will turn and announce the Austrian national anthem. Then he will swivel back to the orchestra and conduct

title: U.S. Court Voids Sections Of State Campaign Code
description: Some of the major provisions of the state's Fair Campaign Code were declared unconstitutional here yesterday by a special Federal court that assailed the restrictions on election campaigning as repugnant to the right of freedom of speech.

title: JULY 30 SUMMIT IN EUROPE SOUGHT
description: GENEVA, July 14  After nearly two years of negotiations, the 35 countries attending the European security conference decided today that they could set July 30 as the target date for a meeting to sign a charter on EastWest relations.

title: Angolan Faction Drives Rivals From Capital as Fight Steps Up
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 14 (UPI) Troops of one Angolan faction drove a rival group from the capital of Angola today as the Portuguese Foreign Minister arrived here in an attempt to prevent fullscale civil war.

title: Books of The Times
description: When someone said that dead writers were remote from us because we know so much more than they did, T.S. Eliot responded, Precisely, and they are what we know. The three 20thcentury American poets Louis Simpson writes about in Three on the TowerEliot, Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williamshave become, by now, sturdy pilings sunk in the river of the past, on which current poets can build. Although critical contention still swirls about themand where can you find a more factious lot than poets?they are a part of what we know.

title: Democrats Fear Inflation From Oil Price Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Congressional Democrats reacted sharply, and negatively today to President Ford's proposal to lift price controls on oil and moved ahead with plans to act this week on legislation that puts Congress on a collision course with the President over energy policy.

title: NEW LAW SHOWS SCOTTO'S POWER
description: The political influence of Anthony M. Scotto, the union boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, was demonstrated when a bile introduced at his behest was passed as the final measure of the 1975 State Legislature in Albany.

title: People in Sports
description: Henri Richard, a veteran of 20 National Hockey League campaigns with the Montreal Canadiens, announced his retirement yesterday. The 39yearold center, who performed on a record total of 11 Stanley Cup championship teams, missed most of last season because of a broken ankle.

title: U.S. Seeks Agreement With Oil Lands To Confer on Energy and Materials
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 14  The United States is hoping to reach agreement with the major oilproducing countries by next month on the holding of an international conference on energy and raw materials.

title: KISSINGER WARNS MAJORITY IN U.N. ON U.S. SUPPORT
description: MILWAUKEE, July 14Secretary of State Kissinger warned the third world majority of the United Nations tonight that its arbitrary tactics in the General Assembly were alienating the support of the American people for the world organization.

title: Stock Index Is Up 4.77 Despite a Retreat at Close
description: Despite mixed economic news, stock prices struggled ahead yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Rain Here Helps to Raise Bumper Crop of Sneezes
description: The days of heavy rain are causing more sneezing in New York, not because of colds or hay fever, but because of molds, according to an allergy expert at the Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center.

title: Events Today
description: Movies

title: Manufacturer Is Concerned Over Uranium Cost
description: The Westinghouse Electric corporation, the nation's leading manufacturer of nuclear power plants for the production of electricity, reported yesterday a 75 per cent increase in earnings in the second quarter Compared with the like period a year ago.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: Boccaccio, a musical based on The Decameron, Giovanni Boccaccio's classic, 14thcentury collection of bawdy short stories, will be presented at the Edison Theater on Oct. 13 by Rita Fredericks, Theater Now, Inc., and Norman Kean.

title: Trade Talk Involves Bing, Van Lier and Porter
description: A possible trade involving Dave Bing, Norm Van Lier and Kevin Porter was the most interesting report yesterday as a number of outstanding players turned out for the promotion of the 21st Century Invitation Tournament Aug. 19 and 20 at Madison Square Garden. Bing, of the Detroit Pistons; Porter, of the Washington Bullets, and Van Lier, of the Chicago Bulls, are rated as three of the National Basketball Associaction's top penetrating guards.

title: Connecticut Track Plan Rebuffed
description: HARTFORD, July 14 (AP)A plan to build a race track, Connecticut's first, received a setback today. The State Department of Environmental Protection issued a report saying that the track, which would be next to New Britain's reservoir at Wolcott, would pollute the reservoir. The report recommended that permission to build the track be denied. It will now be up to D.E.P. Commissioner Joseph Gill to make a decision.

title: Families Are Going to School  for Vacation
description: ITHACA, N.Y.Visit exotic Cornell University. Canoe Cayuga's waters. Hike Cascadilla Gorge. See the famous college cow with the porthole in its stomach. Hear moog synthesizers, pileated woodpeckers, learned professors. Eat cafeteria food. Sleep in dormitory beds. Or sit up all night debating things cosmic...

title: DAVID ISRAEL
description: David Israel, hoard chairman and cofounder of Davids Specialty Shops, Inc., died Sunday at his home, 575 Park Avenue. He was 89 years old.

title: SAIGON PUBLISHES OFFER OF AMNESTY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (UPI)As part of a campaign to establish security, military authorities have promised amnesty to soldiers of the defeated South Vietnamese Army who turn themselves in now, even though the deadline has long passed, but have warned that anyone who opnoses the new Government will be severely punished.

title: CITY'S EMPLOYES WORK UNTIL 5 P.M,
description: More than 100,000 city employes stayed at their jobs until 5 P.M. yesterday after their union leadership agreed not to defy Mayor Beame's order canceling the 9 A.M.to4 P.M. summer work schedules. The issue will be submitted to binding arbitration, under an agreement reached yesterday.

title: A Tigress Role for Lola Falana
description: Faberg, which in May signed up Margaux Hemingway as exclusive spokesman for its line, announced yesterday a new talent in its promotion stableLola Falana, the singer, dancer and actress, who will promote only its Tigress fragrance. The brand is 37 years old but Faberg has just added musk to the formula so that makes it new.

title: Sales AdvanceSarnoff Cites Improvement
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday sizable declines in earnings for both the second quarter and first half despite slightly higher sales in both periods.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) /4/0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Stockton Triumphs By 61, 61
description: CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) Phil Dent of Australia moved into the second round of the $50,000 Chicago international tennis tournament tonight by defeating Dick Dell, 57, 62, 61, Dick Stockton breezed past Syd Ball of Australia, 61, 61.

title: Japan and Soviet Loan Pact
description: TOKYO, July 14 (Reuters)Japan and the Soviet Union have initialed agreement on two Japanese loans totaling $2.59billion for Soviet projects to explore natural gas deposits and fertiliser plants from Japan, a joint announcement said today. The initialing of the loan agreements was announced by President Satoshi Sumita of the semiofficial Japan ExportImport Bank and Vladimir Alhimov visiting Deputy Foreign Trade Ministet.

title: Byrne Counsel Says State Commuter Tax Leaves Him Exempt
description: TRENTON, July 14Governor Byrne's chief counsel, Lewis B. Kaden, said today that he did not pay a special New Jersey commuters tax last year even though he lives in New York and works in New Jersey, and conceded that this had raised a number of questions concerning his residence and its effect on his state tax liability here.

title: Namath to Hold Conference With Press, Not Jets, Today
description: The Jets open training camp today, which is obviously why Joe Namath will be at the Four Seasons restaurant.

title: ExChief of Drug Agency Denies Corruption Charges
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) John R. Bartels Jr., former Federal drug enforcement chief, winding up three days of testimony before a Senate subcommittee, said today that there was no proof of widespread corruption under his leadership as charged by two former aides.

title: PRINCE MAY PLAN CAMBODIAN VISIT
description: HONG KONG, July 14 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's nominal head of state, has told diplomats in North Korea where he is staying that he plans to return to Phnom Penh soon, knowledgeable sources said today.

title: JULY 30 SUMMIT IN EUROPE SOUGHT
description: GENEVA, July 14  After nearly two years of negotiations, the 35 countries attending the European security conference decided today that they could set July 30 as the target date for a meeting to sign a charter on EastWest relations.

title: EXXON'S RED GIFT CALLED INDIRECT
description: The $86,000 payment earmarked for the Italian Communist party by the Exxon Corporation's Italian affiliate was to have gone to the party through a Communist newspaper or front organization, according to authoritative sources.

title: DOLLAR AT A HIGH; GOLD PRICE RISES
description: LONDON, July 14 (AP)The dollar rose today to another 1975 high against the West German mark and other European currencies.

title: Seniors Tee Off in City Tourney
description: Despite the rain, senior golfers teed off yesterday in the New York City public links championship, which is being conducted on all'13 municipal courses by the Department of Recreation in cooperation with the Manufacturers Hanover Bank. Seniors may play their 18hole rounds any day through Sunday on any course. Men over 55 years of age and women over 50 are eligible to take part in qualifying.

title: Chicago ExPoliceman Slain
description: CHICAGO, July 14 (UPI)A former Chicago policeman with reputed crime syndicate connections was shot to death today in an apparent gangland execution. Chris Cardi, 43 years old, who was released from a Federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., last month, was shot at his son's restaurant in suburban Melrose Park by a gunman who fired through a takeout window and fled.

title: Beame Asks End of 5Cent Ferry Fare
description: Mayor Beanie submitted a resolution to the City Council yesterday calling for repeal of the law that limits the oneway fare on the Staten Island ferry to a nickel. The Mayor also was reported seeking funds from state masstransit operating subsidies as part of a plan to restore full service on the ferry.

title: Beame Moves Hurriedly On His Nuisance Taxes
description: Mayor Beame hurriedly submitted resolutions to the City Council last night seeking approval of 4 per cent nuisance taxes on personal services such as haircuts, laundering, dry cleaning and shoeshines as well as on admissions to entertainment and sporting events.

title: Airless Paint Spray Guns Could Prove Hazardous
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. (AP)Consumers have been warned by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission that high pressure airless paint spray guns may be hazardous under certain conditions.

title: Meeting in Space
description: In one of those unplanned coincidences, the scheduled launchings today of the Apollo and Soyuz astronauts will take place just one day before the thirtieth anniversary of the first nuclear explosion on this planet. The coincidence underlines the extreme choices before humanity: nuclear devastation or intimate cooperation of the kind required to make the present AmericanSoviet space mission possible. It is a significant and hopeful sign that man' exploration of space, which began on both sides in an atmosphere of fierce coldwar rhetoric and competition, has now culminated for the moment in the effort to achieve the friendly meeting in orbit planned for later this week.

title: Use of 2 Languages Set As Communications Aid
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 14  ApolloSoyuz, the first international space flight, will inaugurate a new etiquette among astronauts: Speak in the listener's tongue.

title: Senate Unit Limits Inquiry to 6 Covert C.I.A. Actions
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will limit its investigation of covert activities by the Central Intelligence Agency to a halfdozen or so representative cases, including the intervention in Chile, the committee chairman said today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: IMPRESSIONS Two new exhibitions running tomorow through Sept. 14 in the Metropolitan Museum's Prints and Drawings galleries highlight subjects the way they wereto some. Images of the New World depicts the way Europeans perceived America and Americans in the years between its discovery and the Revolution of 1776. The other show. George Washington: Icon for America, is a lighthearted selection of objects showing his face as a symbol for the United States here and abroad.

title: Nadjari Names ExState Aide
description: Ronald Maiorana, former press secretary to Vice President Rockefeller when he was Governor, was named directorof special projects and comImunications for Special State Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari. Mr. Maiorana, 45 years old, will be paid $40,000 a year. He is a former reporter for The New York Times.

title: In Memoriam
description: KINGBenjamin. To live in the hearts of those he left behind is not to die.

title: Bridge:
description: A clear indication that international wounds are healing nicely was provided by a recent exhibition match in Switzerland. Teamed together against a group of Swiss experts were two pairs who were on opposite sides in the ItalianAmerican foottapping controversy in Bermuda five months ago.from the dummy, and East was squeezed, giving South his doubled contract. And if the defenders' hearts had been evenly divided, the ending would have been double squeeze.

title: Cambodian Refugees Tell Of Revolutionary Upheaval
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 14 Dozens of recent Cambodian refugees, some of whom escaped from the country as late as last Tuesday, are telling of a nation in a state of total revolutionary upheaval that is (rapidly returning to its undeveloped past of a century ago.

title: Hey, Scoop, Distract That Fireman a Minute So I Can Interview the Hysterical Lady
description: I was at the Squibb building fire in New York last Friday. Luckily I was on a lower floor anddespite an appalling absence of a fire alarm or of any clear signs indicating how to evacuate the buildingescaped safely. (Not without a moment of near panic on smokefilled fire stairs when someone yelled that the exits were locked. I did what you are supposed not to do, dove into an elevator.)

title: Instant Lottery Drawing Set
description: TRENTON, July 14 (UPI)The New Jersey Lottery Commission today announced that it would hold its first Instant Lottery grandprize drawing, with a maximum payoff of $1million, next Saturday at the Atlantic City Race Track. A special 10horse race will he run at 4:30 P.M. to determine the winner.

title: Municipal Employes Remain on the Job Until 5 P.M.
description: liminary judgment from John T. Burnell, director of the city's Office of Labor Relations yesterday morningwhich supported Mayor Beame's emergency right to cancel the summer hours schedule and which Mr. Gotbaum said was expected because Mr. Burnell was the Mayor's manthe union leader requested that his membership stay on the job until 5 P.M.

title: Angels, Dodgers In Boom
description: LOS ANGELES, Ally 14Things are not so good for the two baseball teams here right nowbut then, they are not so bad, either.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: NOVA, Ohio, July 14 (UPI)Martin Cox, the longest surviving livertransplant patient in the United States, died two days before the sixth anniversary of his operation. The 17yearold patient died Friday night in Cleveland. He will be buried tomorrow.

title: Kialoa First To Finish Ocean Race
description: Kialoa, the new 79foot ketch from Los Angeles, finished the trans  Atlantic yacht race yesterday at the Nab Tower off England's Isle of Wight. Kialoa took 15 days to complete the passage from Newport, R.I., and apparently was far ahead of the eight competitors remaining in the race.

title: Florida Weather Improves
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 14The American astronauts, spacecraft and rockets were ready tonight for the scheduled launching tomorrow of the first international manned space mission, the planned rendezvous flight between Apollo and Soyu spacecraft.

title: Bowling Green IRT Work
description: The $16.8million reconstruction of the IRT station at Bowling Green, including a newt platform, passenger mezzanine below track level and new entrances, will be finished by next March, David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday.

title: AMEX STOCKS UP; TRADING OFF A BIT
description: Reversing an early trend, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed higher yesterday in slightly decreased trading. Prices also closed higher in the overthecounter market as volume also fell slightly.

title: CITY'S EMPLOYES WORK UNTIL 5 P.M.
description: More than 100,000 city employes stayed at their jobs until 5 P.M. yesterday after their union leadership agreed not to defy Mayor Beame's order canceling the 9 A.M.to4 P.M. summer work schedules. The issue will be submitted to binding arbitration, under an agreement reached yesterday.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Mayor Asks Taxes

title: Rugby to Admit Girls
description: RUGBY, England, July 14 (AP)After 408 years the school that gave the world rugby football and Tom Brown is going coed. Sir Patrick Dean, chairman of the governors of Rugby School, announced that 10 girls would be admitted in September, 1976. The vowing demand for places for girls is attributed to the quality of science and mathematics teaching in the private preparatory schools.

title: Critic's Notebook: Camera, Lights, Nuisance
description: What do theaters in New York, London, Stratford, Ontario, Washington, Spoleto, Chichester, Stratford, Conn., and NiagaraontheLake, Ontario, all have in common, apart from higher prices than last year? The answer is a plague of illmeaning, selfish and incompetent amateur photographers. Soon we should hold a theatrical Break a Camera for Freedom Week! Meanwhile, we seem helpless, able only to look on appalled as more and more of these camerawielding fiends invade the theaters of the world.

title: 9 States Charge President Abused Power on Oil Fees
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) Nine states charged today that President Ford had abused his power in imposing a $2abarrel fee on imported oil.

title: U.S. Recognizes Cape Verde
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (Reuters)President Ford announced today that the United States had recognized the Republic of Cape Verde, a group of islands lying off the west coast of Africa, which were recently granted independence by Portugal.

title: Mayor Is Killed in Ambush In City Near Buenos Aires
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 14 (AP) Mayor Ruben Cartier of La Plata was killed last night in an ambush when machinegun fire struck his car, police sources said. La Plata, 35 miles southeast of Buenos Aires, is the capital of Buenos Aires Province.

title: OneDay SignUp By 18YearOlds Planned for Draft
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Selective Service System, sharply reduced in size, is busy planning its new method of registering men for the standby draft. The rrew method is a oneday affair each year for men who turned 18 years old the previous year.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's Milwaukee Speech on the U.N.
description: MILWAUKEE, July 14Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State Kissinger, as prepared for delivery tonight before the Institute of World Affairs here:

title: Court Finds Insufficient Data on Boeing Debentures
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday that the Boeing Company was liable for damages to 56 debenture holders for failure to give sufficient notice of a call to redeem the debentures in 1966, the Associated Press reports.

title: These Reds Are Soaring in Space, Too
description: In their liftoff into the space of a 12game lead in the National League West, the Cincinnati Reds are surprising even themselves. After the fourgame sweep of the New York Mets last weekend. Pete Rose shook his head.

title: CLARK HOWELL JR.
description: Clark Howell Jr., an Atlanta banker and member of a family long prominent in Georgia journalism, died Sunday at his home in Atlanta. He was 50 years old.

title: Forego Assigned 134 for Suburban
description: Forego of the Lazy F Ranch, the horse of the year for 1974, was assigned high weight of 134 pounds yesterday for Saturday's $100,000 added Suburban at Belmont Park. Kenny Noe, the racing secretary and handicapper for the New York Racing Association, has assigned the the nextweighted runner, Stonewalk of the Timberland Stable, 121 pounds. A field of seven is expected for the Suburban, the 1mile test that makes up the third part of the handicap triple crown, after the Metropolitan Mile and the Brooklyn. Forego won the Brooklyn under 132 pounds.

title: Creditable Session
description: Despite faltering leadership from a new Governor and bitter partisan divisions between a Democratcontrolled Assembly and a Republicandominated Senate, the secondlongest session of the State Legislature that ground to a halt last week leaves a fairly respectable record.

title: 125,000 Said to Leave Saigon For New Life in Rural Area
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 15 (Agence FrancePresse)More than 125,000 people have left Saigon for a new life one the land in a provincial center, Vietnamese Communist press and broadcast media reported today.

title: Ford Leads Kennedy in Poll
description: President Ford holds a 50 to 43 per cent lead over Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, for the Presidency, according to a Harris Poll released yesterday, United Press International reports. The poll of 1,303 voters showed that Mr. Ford had made his greatest gains in the Middle West. The latest poll gives the President the greatest margin he has held over Senator Kennedy since his appointment as Vice President.

title: FRANCE AND GUINEA END 10 YEAR BREACH
description: PARIS, July 14 (UPI)France resumed normal relations with Guinea today, ending a 10year break filled with mutual recriminations.

title: Continued Rains Damage Jersey Crops And Cause Flooding of Homes and Roads
description: Sporadic but heavy rains struck the sodden metropolitan area again yesterday, sending rivers and streams over their banks, flooding highways and some homes in outlying sections and causing millions of dollars of crop damage in New Jersey,

title: Los Angeles Police Dropping Its List of Black Juveniles
description: LOS ANGELES, July 14 (UPI) Public disclosure last year lof the police department's socalled Alpha filea list of alleged dangerous black juveniles has led to virtual abandonment of the program, it was reported today.

title: Ethiopian Rulers to Form A Governing Socialist Party
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 14 (UPI)Ethiopia's military rulers have announced the formation of a political party guided by the aims of Ethiopian socialism to govern the country.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: LAURENCE JONES, EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 14 (AP) Dr. Laurence C. Jones, who founded the Piney Woods School near Braxton in 1909 and dedicated his life to helping educate young blacks, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 92 years old.

title: REFUGEES QUERIED BY LATINS FOR SKILLS
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., July 14 (AP)  A representative of several South American nations is at Fort Chaffee interviewing Vietnamese refugees for possible sponsorship by the countries.

title: Former Prisoners In Washington Open A Security Agency
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) A group of former convicts has persuaded the District of, Columbia police department to let them establish a security agency in the nation's capital.

title: ExNASA Aide Dies
description: SAN DIEGO, July 14 (AP)Dr. John M. Coyne, a former researcher with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, died here yesterday trying to save his 15yearold stepson in the Pacific Ocean. Dr. Coyne, who was 53 years old, was a senior psychologist at the San Diego County Community Mental Health Services. He was with NASA from 1959 to 1963. His widow, a daughter and two stepchildren survive.

title: No Plan, No Land
description: The Interior Committee of the House of Representatives is scheduled to vote today on whether or not to give the Congress another chance to pass a national landuse planning bill. Although this same committee last year favored such legislation overwhelmingly  and few observers doubt that this year's more liberal House would pass it easily  the committee's decision is expected to go either way by a very narrow margin. The explanation for this anomaly lies in one of the most shameless campaigns of misrepresentation to which Congress has been subjected in recent years.

title: U.S. SEES NO NEED FOR SUGAR CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI)  An Agriculture Department spokesman told Congress today the Administration saw no need for a revival of the Government's sugarcontrol program.

title: Pennsylvania Judge Refuses To Order State Aides Back
description: HARRISBURG, July 14 (AP)  A Commonwealth Court judge refused today to order striking unemployment office personnel, back to work, ruling that their walkout was causing inconvenience and annoyance but not grave danger to the public.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Mayor Asks Taxes

title: French Here Celebrate Bastille Day
description: What do Frenchmen, who number 40,000 here, do when they are away from home and it is le Quatorze JuilletBastille Day  their Day of Independence?

title: LAW FIRM TO YIELD DATA IN N.M.U. CASE
description: A Philadelphia law firm being investigated for alleged criminal wrongdoing in connection with the National Maritime Union was ordered yesterday to turn over extensive records to a Federal grand jury in Newark.

title: Heavy Rains Cause Floods And Great Crop Damage
description: Sporadic but heavy rains struck the sodden metropolitan area again yesterday, sending rivers and streams over their banks, flooding highways and some homes in outlying sections and causing millions of dollars of crop damage in New Jersey.

title: Suffolk Prosecutor Sued By Police Commissioner
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 14Eugene R. Kelley, the Suffolk Police Commissioner, filed a $20million lawsuit today against the county's District Attorney and the chief assistant prosecutor, charging them with libel and slander for announcing that he was being investigated for corruption, misconduct in office and other, more serious crimes.

title: Russians Are Confident
description: MOSCOW, July 14Top officials of the Soviet Soyuz space program confidently asserted today that they were ready to loft a twoman crew into orbit tomorrow on a historic space rendezvous with an American Apollo spaceship.

title: KOPPERS SEEKING SPROUT, WALDRON
description: The Koppers Company, Inc., a Pittsburghbased manufacturer of tar and asphalt products, coke, machine parts, forest products and plastics, said yesterday that it planned to acquire Sprout, Waldron & Co. of Muncy, Pa., for 214,176 shares of Koppers common stock worth about $14.8million.

title: Stein Finds Fraud in Medicaid Mills
description: Investigators who have already found widespread abuses in the nursinghome industry are beginning to find evidence. of apparent fraud in some storefront offices, often called; Medicaid mills, where groups, of doctors treat patients whose, bills are paid for by the Government.

title: 2 HOMES FOR AGED CLAIM INSOLVENCY
description: The owners of two privately owned facilities housing nearly 275 elderly people have filed petitions for bankruptcy in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, contending that they could not continue to operate under the present rate of reimbursement.

title: May Inventories Cut Is Record Steel Production Declines 0:3%
description: WASHINGTON, July 14Total business inventories were reduced by a record total of $3billion in May, twice as much as in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. TEAM ABANDONS EFFORT TO CLIMB K2
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 14 (Reuters)An American expedition has failed in the first attempt in 13 years to climb 1i2, the world's second highest mountain, according to a message received today.

title: North Korea Rebuffs Move By South to Reopen Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 14, (Reuters)North Korea rejected today a South Korean proposal for a reopening of the stalled dialogue between the two Governments about reunification, a South Korean spokesman said.

title: Killer of 11 Is Given 11 Life Sentences
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, July 14 (UPI)James Ruppert, convicted of killing 11 of his relatives the largest mass murder of members of one family in United States historywas sentenced today to 11 consecutive terms of life in prison.

title: A New Tax Package Presented to Byrne
description: TRENTON, July 14  The leadership of the State Assembly presented a tentative tax package to Governor Byrne this evening that would restore $250million of the $384million that the Governor had to cut from the current fiscal budget to balance it.

title: A Mature Apollo Required No Tests
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 14The 16ton Apollo spacecraft scheduled to rendezvous Thursday with a 7.5ton Soviet Soyuz is virtually identical with the 14 previous Apollos that astronauts flew around the earth and the moon starting in 1968.

title: BANKRUPTCY ACTION FILED BY KING KORN
description: CHICAGO, July 14 (UPI)The King Korn Trading Stamp Company filed today a voluntary petition in Federal District Court for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Stein Finds Fraud In Medicaid Mills
description: Investigators who have already found widespread abuses in the nursinghome industry are beginning to find evidence of apparent fraud in some storefront offices, often called Medicaid mills, where groups of doctors treat patients whose bills are paid for by the Government.

title: Minister's Ouster Approved In Australian Parliament
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 14 (AP)Members of the ruling Labor party voted 55 to 33 in Parliament today to approve the dismissal by Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of his Deputy Prime Minister and Environment Minister, James F. Cairns. Mr. Whitlam ousted Mr. Cairns on July 2 because of charges of improprieties in the raising of foreign loans. Mr. Cairns, who has not admitted any improper activities, asked the parliamentary caucus to reelect him to the Cabinet today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn that is investigating the theft of $70million worth of socalled French Connection drugs from police custody has turned its attention to possible incometax violations. Indictments are expected in about six weeks. The targets of the indictments were said to be several major narcotics dealers.

title: Jersey Judge Rules Fetus May Be a Murder Victim
description: CAMDEN, July 14In an apparently unprecedented ruling, Judge Leon A. Wingate, Jr. of Camden County Court told a jury today that fetuses that are a victim of a criminal blow or wound upon their mother and later born may be found to be murder victims if they die from the wounds.

title: REYNOLDS CITES DROP IN EARNINGS
description: The Reynolds Metals Company reported yesterday declines of 66.2 per cent and 52.5 per cent in earnings for the second quarter and first half respectively. Sales in both periods fell by more than 17 per cent.

title: VICE IN TIMES SQ. TARGET OF DRIVE
description: Massage parlors, peep shows, socalled adult bookstores and hotels in the Times Square area suspected of catering to prostitutes will be visited starting next September by a special team of city inspectors searching For violations that might close them, under a grant announced yesterday by Governor Carey.

title: A Bookshop for Feminists
description: There it is, bravely rippling in a breeze or hanging with simple dignity in the summer heata big red banner proclaiming WOMANBOOKS. And it's a good thing the banner is there because a surprising number of wouldbe customers of this new feminist shop, at 255 West 92d Street, arrive in the neighborhood, look around a bit, and then from a telephone booth call and say, Where are you?

title: Laborers' Strike in Birmingham Curbs City Garbage Collections
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 14 (AP)  City sanitation, airport and parks workers struck today in a pay and benefits dispute.

title: Output of Metal for Week Is Listed at 1,906,000 Tons
description: Despite reports of the turnaround in the economy, steel production continued its decline in the week ended July 12, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Common Cause Mel Quits After Getting C.I.A. Counsel Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 14Common Cause, the public interest lobbying group, anflounced today the resignation of Mitchell Rogovin as general counsel and as chairman of its litigation committee.

title: Brokerage Firms Set Profit Records
description: Continuing a widespread upward trend on Wall Street, record profits for the June quarter were reported here yesterday by the parent companies of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., and E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., both major brokerage houses.

title: World Team Tennis
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: U.S. Court Voids Sections Of State Campaign Code
description: Some of the major provisions of the state's Fair Campaign Code were declared unconstitutional here yesterday by a special Federal court that assailed the restrictions on election campaigning as repugnant to the right of freedom of speech.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 16, 1975

title: U.S. CRAW INQUIRY IS WIDENING SCOPE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15At least a dozen executives and former executives of three large corporations are under investigation in a spreading deral inquiry into alleged corruption in the gramexport trade, according to sources close to the case.

title: Coleman Triumphs In Sailing
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y.. July 15The second day of racing at the 21st annual Larchmont junior regatta drew 342 Fireballs, Lasers and Blue Jays for a drifting match.

title: Consumer Resistance Halts The Climb of Meat Prices
description: Consumer resistance to the rising prices of red meat halted their upward climb last week, at least temporarily, and declines In other categories of foodstuffs cut the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City by 0.6 per cent, according to the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: About the AllStars . . .
description: Charles O. Finley appeared in the American League dugout an hour before the game and shook hands with two of his players on the A.L. squad, Rollie Fingers and Bert Campaneris, who were sitting on the bench. However, he walked right past Catfish Hunter, his former player, who was sitting on the dugout steps, without saying a word. ... A few minutes later, when Finley was talking to Manager Alvin Dark, Hunter approached Finley and said, How ya doin', Mr. Finley? Congratulations, Jim, the Oakland owner said, shaking his hand. You have a nice lookin' green hat there, the Yankee pitcher commented.... Finley, who later gave out orange baseballs to members of the news media, wore a bright green cowboy hat and matching blazer. Of the various A's players on the A.L. squad, most divided their uniform choices between gold and white and green and white. However, Claudell Washington wore all white and Vida Blue wore all gold. . . . Bob Watson Houston sported the most colorful of the mostly drab National League road uniforms. He wore the Astros' multicolored shirt that resembles a television test pattern.

title: Democrats Leaning to City As Site of '76 Convention
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Democratic National Committee is prepared to hold the party's 1976 Presidential Convention in New York City if mechanical problems involving facilities at Madison Square Garden can be worked out in the next month.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday.

title: Notes on People
description: There's no chance I'll retire, said 76yearold Associate Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas. I'll be there in October, positively.

title: WINE TALK
description: CALISTOGA, Calif.Here on a wooded knoll rising from the floor of the lush Napa Valley is one of the four or five most beautiful wineries in the world.

title: Text of Letter to Waldheim From the Egyptian Foreign Minister
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Following is the text of a letter from the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, to Secretary General Waldhelm of the United Nations, as broadcast by the Cairo radio and monitored here:

title: Bronx Boy Says He Set 40 to 50 Fires for $3 Up
description: For the last three years, 15yearold Hector Rivera has been a paid arsonist, burning tenements in the South Bronx for as little as $3.

title: Campaign Opens to Keep Military Bases
description: FORT DIX, July 15A bipartisan Congressional campaign to mobilize the northeastern part of the country against further closings of military installations in the region was begun here today.

title: Times Names Book Review Editor
description: Harvey Shapiro, a poet and assistant editor of The New York Times Magazine since 1964, has been appointed editor of The Times Book Review, it was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, Sunday editor.

title: Democrats Prefer to Hold Their '76 Convention Here
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Democratic National Committee is prepared to hold the party's 3976 Presidential Convention in New York City if mechanical problems involving facilities at Madison Square Garden can he worked out in the next month.

title: Detente in Space
description: In Soviet Central Asia the Soyuz rocket took off perfectly yesterday morning; in Florida yesterday afternoon the Apollo rocket carried out a similarly splendid launch. For the first time, Soviet and American astronauts are speeding toward a rendezvous in space.

title: BYRNE SEEKS AID AS RAINS CONTINUE
description: Torrential rains pounded the metropolitan area for the seventh straight day yesterday, with New Jersey hearing the brunt of their impact.

title: Dallas Paper Plans Change
description: DALLAS, July 15 (AP)The Dallas Times Herald said today that it would replace its Saturday afternoon newspaper with a morning edition beginning Sept. 6. The edition will carry a new nameThe Saturday Times Herald.

title: Strikes Shut 2 More Units Of Abitibi Paper Company
description: TORONTO, July 15 (UPI)Strikes closed two more plants of the Abitibi Paper Company today, lifting to seven the number of sites shut by walkouts against the world's largest newsprint producer.

title: About New York
description: To many New Yorkers the city's museums, no matter how brightly lighted, always seem damp and gray. The reason, of course, is that as children they were taken to one museum or another in their afterschool and daycamp groups where bad weather prevented outdoor recreation.

title: '79 Class Shapes Up At Marine Academy
description: The U. S. Merchant Marine Academy yesterday welcomed aboard approximately 355 plebes of the Class of 1979. The class includes 27 women. Last year 15 women were enrolled in the academy for the first time. The members are selected through Congressional nomination from throughout the United States and its possessions. The plebes will undergo two weeks of indoctrination before the rest of the 1 000 midshipmen report on July 27th and 28th. The Kings Point studies lead to a merchant marine license as either a Third Mate or a Third Assistant Engineer.

title: BOYCOTT IS ENDING FOR SEOUL PAPER
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 15 Advertisers appeared today to be ending a sevenmonth boycott of South Korea's largest national daily that had reportedly been inspired by the Government.

title: Soviet Space Lab Spins On In a Quiet 52d Day in Orbit
description: MOSCOW, July 15 (AP)While the launchings for the SovietAmerican joint mission captured a world's attention, the twoman crew of the Soviet space lab Salyut 4 spent a quiet 52d day in orbit, making routine medical tests.

title: Democrat Virtually Concedes Defeat in a Maine Election
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Former Democratic Representative Peter N. Kyros virtually conceded defeat today in his effort to unseat Representative David F. Emery, a Republican, in the disputed Maine Congressional contest.

title: Space Institute Set Up
description: WASHINGTON, (AP)  Dr. Wernher Von Braun, the man who directed much of the U. S. space program in its early years, announced the formation of a space institute to serve as a forum on space goals.

title: Federal Election Agency Yields To Pressure to Open Meetings
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Bowing to pressure from Congress and citizen groups, the Federal Election Commission announced today that its future business meetings would be oven to the public and press. Former Representative Thomas B. Curtis, chairman of the new agency, said that all decisions of the sixmember group would be reached at open sessions unless there was a very specific reason for a closed meeting.

title: Honduras Says 2 Priests And 2 Nuns May Be Dead
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 15 (AP)The Honduran Government says that two Roman Catholic priests and two nuns missing since June 25 may have been killed.

title: Chessie Hits Snag Over Erie Payment
description: The proposal of Chessie System, Inc., to buy most of the lines of the bankrupt ErleLackawanna and Reading railroads has struck a snag over the mode of payment.

title: Advertising
description: Sometime in August New Yorkers should be introduced to a brand new medium in their midstvery much in their midst.

title: Waldheim Reacts to Letter
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15  Secretary General Waldheim said tonight that Egypt wanted the Security Council to call for the withdrawal of Israel from her territory as a condition for agreeing to the continued presence of the United Nations buffer force in Sinai. The Council is expected to meet in the next few days because the situation is urgent, he said.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: The Russian Visitor
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn steps into American life out of the pages of a Dostoyevsky novel. A deeply religious man and a moralist, he is preoccupied with fundamental questions of what is truth and what is justice. He sees every issue, large and small, personal and political, in terms of good and evil.

title: 40 More Days of Rain (If the Legend Is Right)
description: Yesterday was St. Swithin's day and, according to legend, if it rains on St. Swithin's Day, it will rain for 90 days more.

title: Philadelphia Concern Gets Jersey Aid for Relocation
description: TRENTON, July 15 (AP)The State Economic Development Authority said today it had completed financing to help a Philadelphia company acquire a new plant in Camden.

title: ROCKWELL NET OFF 26.5% IN QUARTER
ANDERSON GUILTY IN FETUS SLAYINGS
description: CAMDEN, N. J., July 15After deliberating for nine hours, a jury found Winfield Anderson guilty today of murdering twin fetuses by shooting their pnegnant mother in the abdomen.

title: Dividing a Room With a Tapestry
description: If you have to use your living space in multiple waysa familiar problem for city dwellerssome kind of space divider can be almost essential.

title: A Call to Oust Israel
description: A conference of 40 Islamic countries called for the expulsion of Israel from the United Nations and all other international bodies. Page 7.

title: City Borrowing to Pay Policemen $31Million Retroactive Raises
description: The city will use the borrowing powers of its 197576 capital budget to pay retroactive raises of about $31million to its 23,000 police officers.

title: Stein's Medicaid Inquiry Focuses on 13 Doctors
description: At a raindrenched news conference in Brooklyn's East New York section in front of a cluster of doctors' offices where he said nearly a million dollars in Medicaid funds went to 13 doctors last year, Assemblyman Andrew Stein declared that more than $250million tax dollars are being lost every year through fraudulent billing by Medicaid mills.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Article 3  No Title
Wilson, Steingut, Hurd, Marchi Called in NursingHome Inquiry
description: Morris B. Abram, chairman of the Moreland Commission on nursing homes, said yesterday that three televised hearings next week would explore what he called a classic case of political interference that reached into the office of the Governor and the legislative leadership.

title: Few High Buildings Have Full Fire Protection
description: Of the city's 938 highrise office buildings required to comply with the 1973 fire code, 766, or 81.7 per cent, have had their plans for compliance approved by the Buildings Department.

title: STATE LIFTS PERMIT OF INSURANCE FIRM
description: TRENTON, July 15 (AP)The state today lifted the license of the Sutz & Sutz insurance brokerage firm, which had been accused of numerous violations of state insurance laws and regulations.

title: Plan Reached to Finance Schools Till End of Year
description: TRENTON, July 15Governor Byrne and State Assembly leaders agreed today on a plan designed to insure the return of the State Legislature in November or December to deal with the problems of finding the money for a $400million program of tax reform and school financing.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Nominee to Head H.E.W. Questions Value of Busing
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) F. David Mathews, secretarydesignate of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, told Congress today that he questions the value of school busing.

title: MOSLEMS PROPOSE U.N. EXPEL ISRAEL
description: JIDDA Saudi Arabia, Wednesday, July 16A conference of 40 Islamic countries called early today for the expulsion of Israel from the United Nations and all other international bodies.

title: Key Index Climbs 5.95 Volume Is Hefty
description: Buoyed by continuing reports of a bottoming out of the recession, the stock market closed yesterday with a gain of 5.95 at 881.81, the highest closing for the DowJones industrial average since March 26. 1974, when it closed at 883.68.

title: Suddenly, Shark Fisherman Is Center of Attraction
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 14I noticed it last weekend when we brought our fish back to hang up at the pier, Tommy Sealy said. Everybody kind of looked at us like we were the devil's disciples or something.

title: China Cuts Arms Spending, C.I.A. Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Peking has been cutting back substantially in the last three years on its expenditures for military equipment, according to experts on China from the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: JOSEPHP. WARGROVE, INVESTMENT AIDE, 49
description: Joseph P. Wargrove, senior vice president in charge of the investment department of the General Reinsurance Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., died Monday of cancer at New York Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LANDUSE BILL GIVEN A SETBACK IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The House Interior Committee today defeated a motion to report a landuseplanning bill to the floor and thereby almost certainly killed any prospect for such legislation in this Congress. The vote was 23 to 19.

title: American Cyanamid Net Off Despite Peak Sales
description: The American Cyanamid Company reported yesterday that net income for the second quarter trailed the yearago level, despite record sales in the quarter and half. The earnings decline was attributed to loss of earnings from discontinued operationsthe Jefferson Chemical Groupand to losses from unconsolidated realestate subsidiaries.

title: Teacher Fights Compulsory Mental Test
description: NEWARK, July 15The constitutionality of a New Jersey law empowering local school boards to order psychiatric and physical examinations for teachers was challenged here today before a special threejudge Federal court.

title: EARNINGS DECLINE AT REPUBLIC STEEL
description: The Republic Steel Corporation reported yesterday lower sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half. The company also announced, plans for cutting steel output at three plants.

title: TV: Zoo Gang on NBC
description: In searching for something that is not a repeat on television these days, there is, of course, the ApolloSoyuz space spectacular. But even that production cannot escape a sense of dj vu as one space launching looks, remarkably like another, even though it is carried on Russian television, which seems to transmit pictures similar to those on any other nountry's television.

title: Plumbers' Pay Cited
description: The White House has sent a delegation to Seattle to focus attention on plumbers who earn $14.10 an hour in an effort to contain an outbreak of high wage settlements in the economicallystrategic construction industry. Page 55.

title: 40 More Days of Rain (If the Legend Is Right)
description: Yesterday was St. Swithin's day and, according to legend, if it rains on St. Swithin's Day, it will rain for 40 days more.

title: BUTTERFIELD REPORT IS DENIED BY PROUTY
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 15 (AP)L. Fletcher Prouty, who identified a former Presidential aide, Alexander P. Butterfield, as a Contact man for the Central Intelligence Agency at the White House, has denied a newspaper report that he may have been given false information about Mr. Butterfield.

title: Connors Sidelined With a Cast on Leg
description: The story about Jimmy Connors's leg injury at Wimbledon appears to be true. Bill Riordan, Jimmy's manager, said yesterday the 22yearold star was in Los Angeles with his right leg in a cast, and it was questionable that he would be able to defend his United States Open title at Forest Hills later next month.

title: WHEAT AND CORN ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Wheat and corn futures prices rose sharply yesterday and soybeans gained a few cents, but only after prices had swung widely in nervous reaction to a lack of firm news yet on the size of Soviet grain purchases.

title: M.A.C. AIDES URGE ACTION BY MAYOR
description: Executives of the Municipal Assistance Corporation have appealed personally to Mayor Beanie to produce and publicize very promptly a formal fiscal plan to win the confidence of investors and facilitate the future sale of the corporation's bonds.

title: State Democrats Will Seek Diversity in '76 Delegates
description: To avoid the credentials challenges threatened by the Democratic party's quasiquota system, the New York party proclaimed yesterday plans to encourage widespread primary participation that could avoid a homogeneous delegation to the Presidential nominating convention.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: To the auto industry, the idea that a buyer has the right to return a defective car and get a refund has always been unthinkableand too often the consumer, with his auto in the shop, is left riding the bus, missing work and gnashing his teeth over his expensive but useless investment.

title: Swimmers More Timid
description: The Great Shark Scare on the nation's ocean beaches this summer is turning out to be just a little finneyphobia.

title: U.S. Focuses on Plumbers Contract In Move on High Construction Wages
description: SEATTLE, July 15 The White House sent a delegation to the hinterlands today to focus attention on plumbers who earn $14.10 an hour, in an effort to contain an outbreak of high wage settlements in the economicallystrategic construction industry.

title: U.S. GRAIN INQUIRY IS WIDENING SCOPE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15At least a dozen executives and former executives of three large corporations are under investigation in a spreading Federal inquiry into alleged corruption in the grainexport trade, according to sources close to the case.

title: The Financial Times, One of Britain's Top Papers, Plans Staff Cuts and Computerization
description: LONDON, June 15The Financial Times, one of the most successful and financially secure newspapers in Britain, is planning to reduce its staff by onethird and computerize production in a dramatic move that is viewed with broad interest in the ailing newspaper industry here.

title: Some Phone Users Must Pay on Sept. 1 For Directory Help
description: Customers of the New York Telephone Company will start paying for directory assistance calls on Sept. 1 for the first time since telephone service, was inaugurated here in 1878.A bill directing the State Publid Service Commission to rescind its permission for th?/ new charge was passed by the State Assembly but died in the Senate.

title: About the Giants ...
description: The wet weather even caught up with Coach Bill Arnsparger. We were doing jumping jacks during calisthenics, I slipped and did a split, the Giant coach related. I called off the rest of calisthenics and said, let's go to individual groups . . . . Jim O'Brien on the plight of placekickers: It seems the linemen are getting taller every year. ... Frank LaRusso, a rookie tackle, left camp. Other training cuts were Joe DiVincenzo and Mark Nordeen, rookie quarterbacks, and Bernard Thomas, defensive tackle . . . . The first full intrasquad scrimmage will be held Saturday 3:30 P.M. at Briarcliff High School behind the Giants' training camp facility.

title: New $1 Jones Beach Toll Now Due at Parking Lots
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 15The State Department of Parks and Recreation today withdrew its request that the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority col(feethe state's vehicularuse Ifee at the three entrances to the park complex and will, instead, erect additional toll booths at the beaches parking lots to collect the extra $1.

title: Saigon General Files Appeal Against Ottawa Ouster Move
description: MONTREAL, July 15 (Reuters)Lieut. Gen. Dang Van Quang, an official in the former South Vietnamese Government, has petitioned to have a deportation order quashed by the Canadian Immigration Appeal Board.

title: Alioto Rent Veto Overriden
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP)A city ordinance requiring landlords to rent to families with children has been enacted by the Board of Supervisors over a veto by Mayor Joseph L. Alioto. The supervisors voted 9 to 2 last night to approve the measure which Mayor Alioto had warned could lead to high??.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, July 15, 1975

title: Korvette Profit Increases As Quarterly Sales Decline
description: The Korvette, Inc., division of Arlen Reality and Develop. ment Corporation, had net profit of $1.97million in the first quarter ended May 31 against $159,000 in the same period last year. However, sales declined to $138.9million from $142.8million the year before.

title: Jury Begins Its Deliberations In the Murder of Joan Kramer
description: NEWARK, July 15 (UPI)A jury deliberated for two hours today without reaching a verdict in the murder trial of Otto N. Nilson, an accountant and former Sunday school tteacher accused of strangling a wealthy South Orange woman.

title: Westbury Drops Daily Double And Installs New Track Surface
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 15Although its 72night meeting does not start until Monday, the wheels began turning Roosevelt Raceway today. The track announced the elimination of daily double wagering, its new racing surface and the installation of a new lighting system.

title: A.F.T. Blacks Lose on Bid For Strong Busing Stand
description: HONOLULU, July 15The American Federation of Teachers dealt yesterday at its annual convention with two of the most controversial issues facing the schools: busing and bilingual education.

title: Bridge
description: The young generation of New York experts has been sweeping all before it in regional championships this year. It was no surprise, therefore, that the New England Swiss team title early this month was won by Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag, both of New York City, and Neil Silverman of West Orange, N. Y., and Merle Ton of Cedar Grove, N. J., ail of whom make bridge headlines with almost monotonous regularity.

title: SENATE BARS PLEAS OF WYMAN IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) In a series of close votes, the Senate turned down today, a Republican request to broaden its recount to determine the winner of last November's senatorial election in New Hampshire.

title: Developer at Hunts Point Said to Face Jury Inquiry
description: The city's Department of Investigation will recommend that evidence it has developed about a $37million city project being built in the Bronx by Christopher Boomis, a realestate developer, be submitted to a grand jury, law enforcement sources reported yesterday.

title: May Craig, Feisty Capital Writer, Dies
description: May Craig, whose hats and tart questions to Presidents and politicians made her one of the country's bestknown news women for several decades, died yesterday in a nursing home in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Best Shark Waters 5 to 10 Miles Out
description: The fisherman who wants to catch a shark on rod and line and is willing to spend a day or two afloat has an excellent chance of success.

title: Kissinger Stresses Perils
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Secretary of State Kissinger said today that Egypt's announcement of conditions for a renewal of the United Nations force was an example of the precariousness of the Middle East if no settlement is reached.

title: PHRASE BOOK AIDS THE FIVE IN SPACE
description: HOUSTON, July 15Soviet and American astronauts seeking to link up their spacecraft on Thursday will have the help of an EnglishRussian phrase book in communicating with one another.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, July 15, 1975

title: OutofPlace Tropical Air Blamed for Recent Rains
description: An unusual weather pattern, similar to that which on occasion has swept hurrcanes up the East Coast, has been responsible for the torrential rains and the tornado that hit the New York metropolitan area in recent days, according to a weather specialist.

title: Investors Welcome Pennsylvania Bell Debentures
description: Prices of Government securities weakened yesterday in light trading. In the corporate sector of the bond market, however, good demand for longterm issues developed after a Halsey Stuart syndicate sold all but the tag ends of a new offering of $100million of triple Arated, 40year 8 per cent debentures of the Bell Telephone Company  of Pennsylvania.

title: Market Place
description: Stock prices boiled upward yesterday on heavy volume, reaching a new recovery high and sending thrills through the tapewatchers. The DowJones industrials finished with a rise of 5.95 at 881.81.

title: DESERT LIFTOFF
description: MOSCOW, July 15With a mighty jet of white flame, a Soyuz spacecraft blasted off from its desert launching pad in Soviet Central Asia today, carrying two Soviet astronauts toward a rendezvous in space with three American astronauts.

title: THE MOOD IN INDIA: CAUTION AND FEAR
description: NEW DELHI July 15An Indian diffidently approached a group of American and British reporters standing outside a courtroom and interviewing a lawyer involved in the suit against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Maurice McLoughlin, 68, White & Case Partner, Dies
description: Maurice E. McLoughlin, a senior partner of White & Case, New York law firm, died yesterday at his summer home in Cohasset, Mass. He was 68 years old and lived also at 560 First Street, Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JFRSEY'S FARMERS HIT HARD BY RAINS
description: The storms that have been pummeling New Jersey were among the worst ever experienced by farmers in the state, the Secretary of Agriculture, Philip A. Alampi, said yesterday.

title: Cairo Warns It May Refuse U.N. PeaceForce Renewal
description: CAIRO, July 15Egypt said today that she would refuse to renew the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sinai unless the Security Council took action to assure speedy Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab territories. The mandate expries July 24.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Output Up 0.4% in June, Reversing 8Month Drop
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Industrial production, one of the most important statistical indicators of the economy, turned upward in June after eight months of mostly steep decline, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: WALTER HUNT DIES; FOIL PIONEER WAS 95
description: Walter Y. C. Hunt, a pioneer in the development of aluminum foil into a packaging material, died Monday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J. He was 95 years old and a resident of Summit.

title: Place of Film in a University Is Debated at Conference Here
description: Should a Hollywood comedy he given the same academic scrutiny and respect accorded an ancient play by Plautus? Is film like a wild stag running loose on the campuses and in need of taming? Or should academia leave the genre alone to go unbridled down its own paths?

title: BYRNE SEEKS AID AS RAINS CONTINUE
description: Torrential rains pounded the metropolitan area for the seventh straight day yesterday, with New Jersey bearing the brunt of their impact.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: TOKYO, July 15 (UPI)The Kyodo News Service reported today that Japan would give the United States a $3million theater on the top floor of the Kennedy Center in Washington and a cherry blossom park on the West Coast to mark its 200th birthday.

title: Sketches of the 5 American and Russian Astronauts
description: Once, in 1973, during early preparations for the Apollo Soyuz Test Project, Brig. Gen. Thomas Patten Stafford really got his back up. He was in Moscow with his Apollo crew and other American officials. He enjoyed all the ceremony, the effusive toasts and flowing vodka, and found his Soviet hosts most agreeable  except on one important point. They refused to permit him to visit the Baikonur launching site and see the Soyuz spacecraft.

title: CannedGoods Price Cuts Announced by Green Giant
description: The Green Giant Company, one of the country's largest marketers of canned vegetables, announced yesterday that it was rolling back the prices of its major canned vegetables from 6 to 13 per cent.

title: People in Sports
description: Sol Berg, owner of the New York Sets, threw a party yesterday to celebrate the Wimbledon tennis victories of two of his players, Billie Jean King and Sandy Mayer. Mrs. King won the women's singles and Mayer teamed with Vitas Gerulaitis to capture the men's doubles.

title: AGREEMENT DELAYED ON SUMMIT PARLEY
description: GENEVA, July 15 (AP)Delegates to the European Security conference were unable today to reach a final decision on holding a summit conference July 30 in Helsinki, Finland, to sign a document on EastWest relations.

title: PRAGUE ACCUSED BY ITALIAN REDS
description: ROME, July 15  The Italian Communist party accused the Czechoslovak Government today of striking at one of the foundations of Socialist democracy, the freedom of culture, by mistreating dozens of intellectuals.

title: Jet Passenger Dies in Fire He Apparently Set Himself
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 15 (AP)A male passenger on a National Airlines jet apparently burned himself to death late today while the aircraft was en route from New York to Miami, the police said.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER GAIN
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market continued to rise yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Six Form a 1976 Group for Reagan
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Former Governor Ronald Reagan of California moved closer to contesting President Ford for the Republican nomination next year with the formation today of a Citizens for Reagan committee.

title: Defendant Guilty In Camden Trial On Fetus Slayings
description: CAMDEN, N. J., July 15After deliberating for nine hours, a jury found Winfield Anderson guilty today of murdering twin, fetuses by shooting their pregnant mother in the abdomen.

title: Shedding Blinders
description: The United States Civil Service Commission has struck an important blow against the glacier of bias that imprisons the vast majority of homosexuals in America. It issued new guidelinesaffecting the great bulk of Federal civilian employeswhich forbid employment discrimination solely on the basis of homosexual conduct, and require that there be no differentiation in treatment between homosexuals and heterosexuals.

title: Tuesday Closings, Inevitable for Met
description: Last week's decision by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to shut down on Tuesdays and Tuesday evenings in response to cuts in its financial support by the city reduces to five days a week the availability to the public of a great visual resource and the city's foremost tourist attraction. It means the turning away each week of some 5,500 daytime visitors and between 1,500 and 2,000 who come in the eveningmany from out of town and abroadplus 1,000 children normally admitted free during the school year. The museum estimates that 50 per cent of these lost visitors will return on other days, but since yesterday was the first day of the new closing there is no way to tell for sure as yet.

title: Article 2  No Title
Kissinger Sees No Path But Coexistence Policies
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Secretary of State Kissinger saidtoday that there is no alternative to coexistence with the Soviet Union and challenged critics to come up with a better policy in the nuclear age.

title: Refugee Relief
description: The shirking of rightful responsibilities by various members of the United Nations, including those of the Third World, is certainly nothing new; and so it is a relief to comment on one case in which a wealthy Arab state has at last taken a step in the opposite direction. Saudi Arabia has become the first of the oilrich Arab countries to make a major contribution to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine refugees.

title: 2 Die in Dayton Shooting
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 15 (UPI) Two men were killed and a woman was wounded by shotgun blasts from a passing car today. The police said the shootings occurred in separate areas of the city but were believed committed by the same gunman.

title: Mrs. Peron's Changes Fail to Satisfy Her Critics
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 15President Isabel Martnez de Pern has won another temporary respite from her political crisis in the last few days after ridding here Cabinet of Jos Lpez Rega, the rightwing strongman.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Defends Curbs to Dr. Spock
