description: Their hips swiveled and thtir legs wriggled. Some frowned in concentration. Others, more poised, pleased the crowd with calm smiles. They were the Hula Hoop champions of the city and they had come for titles and trophies.

title: Silver Lining: Reservoirs Are Full
description: New Yorkers may have been inconvenienced and depressed by the recent rains here, but they stand to benefit from the copious rainfall upstate.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Movies

title: JOAN LITTLE CASE GETS BLACK JUROR
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 16 The first black juror was selected today in the murder trial of Joan Little.

title: Tomahawks Beaten By Caribous, 1711
description: QUEBEC, July 16Brian Wilson scored three goals in the first period and finished with six over all tonight to lead the Quebec Caribous to a 1711 victory over the Long Island Tomahawks in a National Lacrosse League game.

title: Williams Runs 9.9, Ties Mark
description: SIENA, Italy, July 16 (AP) Steve Williams of ?? United States equaled his world record in the 100 meters tonight, clocking 9.9 seconds in a windless but humid stadium. He shares the record with six Americans.

title: CHASE NET GAINS 38,5% IN QUARTER
description: The Chase Manhattan Cor poration, New York's secondlargest banking organization alter the First National City Bank, reported a major improvement yesterday in its earnings for the second quarter and first half of 1975, confirming a nationwide upsurge in bank profits.

title: City Productivity Drive Assailed as Meaningless
description: Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr. charged yesterday that the Beame administration's efforts to raise the productivity of city agencies was really no more than a publicrelations program.

title: PROF. HIRSCHFELD OF RICHMOND, DEAD
description: Dr. Charles Hirschfeld, professor of social studies at Richmond College of the City University of New York, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 630 Victory Boulevard, St. George, S. I. He was 62 years old.

title: Alexander, Gottfried Net Victors
description: CHICAGO, July 16 (UPI)John Alexander led the way into the quarterfinals of the 50,000 Chicago international tennis tournament tonight with a 63, 62 victory over Bill Brown at Soldier Field.

title: In West Germany, Real Bread by Real Bakers
description: MUFFENDORF, West Germany  Lorenz Zavelberg gets up every day at 4 A.M. sometimes 4:30 is close enough, he admitted  to light an ancient coalfired baking oven, mix about 50 pounds of fragrant wheat flour dough and bake 500 brtchen biscuits, without which breakfast would be unthinkable in Muffendorf.

title: Navy's Estimates on F18 Found $1.6Billion Short
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The Defense Department has concluded that the Navy, which was under instructions to come up with a lowcost fighter, has understated by at least $1.6billion the longterm cost of its program to build a new carrier plane.

title: Cuba Is Again the Main Issue As O. A. S. Meets in Costa Rica
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 16Delegates of 24 member countries of the Organization of American States convened here today to seek ways to accommodate Cuba once more in the hemisphere body, ending 11 years of boycott.

title: Games Nations Play
description: STANFORD, Calif.The basic problem of United States foreign policy is our relationship with the Soviet Union. The outcome of the joint space mission should not divert attention from this point. One would assume that the subject would be covered with the utmost care by the press and in our universities. Such, unfortunately, is not the case. There is evidence that all the news is not being told, and that those responsible range from businessmen eager to conclude deals with Moscow to individuals or groups who have in dtente a pretext to close their eyes or to promote a cause.

title: Personal income Up Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Personal income rose strongly in June, even apart from a big onetime increase resulting from the special $50 bonus to Social Security and many welfare recipients, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Bridge:
description: Some brilliant defensive plays slip past experts who are fully capable of making them because the effectiveness of the play depends on making them without the slightest pause for thought. One of these fish that got away occurred on the diagramed deal two months ago when the Lancia touring team slaved in Los Angeles.

title: Navy's Estimates on F18 Found $1.6Billion Short
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The Defense Department has concluded that the Navy, which was under instructions to come up with a lowcost fighter, has understated by at least $1.6billion the longterm cost of its program to build a new carrier plane.

title: MRS. EUGENE MORI
description: UPLAND, Pa., July 15 (AP)Olive Mori, wife of Eugene Mori Sr., founder of the Garden State Racing Association, died today in the CrozierChester Medical Center here of burns she sustained last week. She was 74 years old.

title: CrossTown Busing, Begun in '71, Is Working Well in Charlotte
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 15Back in 1965 a black father named James E. Swann led a group of nine other black parents into court here and won from a Federal judge an order for widespread crosstown busing to desegregate the CharlotteMecklenburg County school system.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Was Finley Culprit In League's Loss?
description: MILWAUKEE, July 16When Lee MacPhail, president of the American League, introduced Alvin Dark at a news conference the other day he referred to him as the manager of the 1975 AllStar winners. When Charles Feeney, president of the National League, introduced Walter Alston, he referred to him as a manager who has made a living out of outsmarting Alvin.

title: TANKER IN DISPUTE SAILS FOR EGYPT
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 16The Porto, the oil tanker that has been the subject of a twomonth dispute here over whether its tanks were clean enough to carry grain, is finally on its way to Egypt with a cargo of American wheat.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: Vote on Sex Bias

title: Kroger Accused of Advertising Items Not Maintained in Stock
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Kroger Company, the nation's thirdlargest supermarket chain, of advertising products not in stock and charging more than advertised prices.

title: Surefire Hanover is Favorite In Yonkers Trot on Saturday
description: YONKERS, July 16To buy or not to buy That was the question facing Stanley Dancer last December as he contemplated the purchase of Surefire Hanover for $130,000. After having the 3yearold trotter examined thoroughly, the outstanding trainerdriver bought the colt for his wife.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Northrop Chairman Quits, Remains Chief Executive
description: Thomas V. Jones, head of the Northrop Corporation who has been under fire for bribing Saudi Arabian Air Force generals, resigned yesterday as chairman of the company's board of directors. Mr. Jones, 54 years old, remains president, chief executive officer and a director of the Los Angelesbased aerospace company.

title: State Lottery to Give Out $2.5Million in Next Week
description: TRENTON, July 16 (UPI)The New Jersey Lottery Commission said today it would give away at least $2.5million over the next week in the richest bonanza in its fiveyear history.

title: GROVE SUES CIA.; SEEKS $10MILLION
description: A suit that charges the Central Intelligence Agency with infiltrating, wiretapping and bombing the offices of Grove Press, Inc., will be filed in Federal District Court here today.

title: I.D.S. VOTES TO OMIT QUARTERLY DIVIDEND
description: Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the nation's largest mutual fund complex, disclosed yesterday that board members had voted to omit the thirdquarter dividend. Charles R. Orem, president, linked the move to continued uncertainties in its mortgage banking and real estate operations.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL PLANS STOCK SALE
description: The Crocker National Corporation, holding company for the Crocker National Bank of San Francisco, announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the proposed offering of 1.5 million shares of common stork.

title: Seoul Enforces Defense Tax To Reduce Reliance on U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 16The South Korean Government put into force today a newly enacted national defense tax with the avowed aim of eventually making United States military aid unnecessary.

title: Film: 'The Bears and I':Modest Disney Effort on Bill with 'Bambi'
description: It's a measure of the appeal of Michel Deville's "The Bear and the Doll," a witless romantic fable about two perfectly mismatched lovers, that for most of its running time Brigitte Bardot is the bear and Jean-Pierre Cassel is the doll.Miss Bardot plays what used to be calledat least in movies of the Great Depression  a tempestuous, headstrong heiress, but with such dumb intensity that the effect is less vivacious than voracious. Cassel, who has been an excellent comedian in the films of De Broca, is the mild-mannered cellist whose ancient Renault one day bump into her Rolls thereby prompting the kind of courtship that only the talent of the late Ernst Lubitsch might have elevated into fabulous farce.In effect, she chases him until he catches her, but the maneuverings are mostly the tactics of coy moviemaking here involving several awful child actors, windshield wipers that comment on the action, a huge but gentle dog, a Siamese cat named Prudhomme, and endless little rages between the lovers that define their real affection.Several years ago, Deville made "Benjamin," in which his appreciation for the classic comedy of manners was charmingly apparent, Charm is the ingredient that is in singularly short supply in "The Bear and the Doll," largely, I suspect, because Miss Bardot, once a sex kitten, now approaches middle age with all of the grace of a seasoned predator.The film, which is in French with English subtitles, opened yesterday at the Paris.

title: APOLLO AND SOYUZ SHIFT THEIR ORBITS FOR LINKUP TODAY
description: HOUSTON, July 16Apollo and Soyuz, two spaceships on separate courses but with one common goal, maneuvered smoothly into new orbits today in preparation for tomorrow's first international rendezvous in space.

title: Flood Insurance and Other Federal Aid Will Help Jersey Recover From the Rain
description: Federal officials said yesterday that they believed, most New Jersey home and business ptoperty owners in the state's floodprone communities were protected by the new Federal program of flood insurance.

title: DR. LUPU CATZ
description: Dr. Lupu Catz, a physician, died Tuesday at University Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 40 Waterside Plaza.

title: Kennel Club Flourishing In Mexico
description: Both North and South of the border women head the national kennel clubs. Indeed, three women have been president of the Canadian Kennel Club. Down Mexico way, a New Jersey native, Mrs. Thelma von Thaden, is serving her third year as the Mexican K. C. chief executive, the first woman to hold the post.

title: Postal Service and Four Unions Seeking to Avert Monday Strike
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The United States Postal Service and four union bargaining units were locked in virtually roundtheclock negotiations today, trying to avoid disruptions in mail service next Monday, when the present twoyear contract expires.

title: Byrne Gives List of Taxes To Restore Budget Items
description: TRENTON, July 16Governor Byrne presented to the Democratic Assembly majority today lists of budget restorations and nuisance taxes that he would sign if voted by the State Legislature.

title: Columbia Names Yavitz Business School Dean
description: Columbia University named Boris Yavitz, a 52yearold expert on management, planning and information systems, as dean of its Graduate School of Business yesterday, Dr. William J. McGill, Columbia's president, announced the appointment, which formally went into effect on July 1.

title: Article 3  No Title
WALDHEIM CITES MIDEAST DANGER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16Secretary General Waldbeim said today that the Middle East situation looked especially dangerous now that Egypt had announced she might not renew the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sinai.

title: WHEAT AND CORN SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Expectations of Soviet purchases of United States grains and soybeans kept prices rising yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Theater: Oklahoma! Upon the Water
description: In its early days the Jones Beach Theater (wasn't it once called the Marine Theater?) presented musicals that were decidedly nautical in atmosphere. In recent seasons the shows have edged away from the sea while remaining steadfastly pastoral. This summer Jones Beach moves all the way west to Oklahomar! The result is pleasurable family entertainment. Admittedly, Rogers and Hammerstein's modern classic is an unusual choice for this openair amphitheater. What do you do with the moatlike body of water between the orchestra pit and the main stage? Instead of the usual showboats and paddlewheelers steaming into port, here comes the scenery!

title: EMERGENCY POWERS EXPANDED BY INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, July 16The Indian Government, acting by decree, announced an expansion today of the emergency powers under which it has arrested thousands of its political opponents in the last three weeks.

title: In Memoriam
description: WITCHELLIra S. M.D. Always remembered, ever loved.

title: MARKET DECLINES BY 9.70 FOR DAY
description: The stock market could get no closer to the soughtafter 900 level than 885.25 in trading yesterday. It opened on a continuing upbeat and reached the 885.25 level, up 3.44, at 11 A.M. Then profit taking set in and the gains turned to losses.

title: JACK D. CUMMINGS
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 16 Jack D. Cummings, president Qf the Traveletter Company, a creditcard concern, died today at his home on Prudence Drive. He was 53 years old.

title: HOUSE WEAKENS SEXBIAS RULES
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The House voted 212 to 211 today to forbid the Department of Health. Education and Welfare to spend any money this fiscal year to enforce the sex integration of physicaleducation classes.

title: City Will Pay Police Raises Out of Its Expense Budget
description: In reversal of one of the city's traditional bookkeeping gimmicks, Mayor Beame announced yesterday that the longdelayed raises for 23,000 policemen would be paid with $31million from last year's expense budget rather than with borrowings from the current capital budget.

title: EILEEN DAVENPORT
description: Eileen Creelman Davenport, a former newspaper woman, died Tuesday at her home. She was 73 years old and lived at 1115 Fifth Avenue.

title: LegalFee Payment By State Is Barred In All Custody Cases
description: TRENTON, July 16 (AP)The State Division of Youth and Family Services won a court test case today against payment of legal fees for indigent parents in child custody cases filed by the division.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The New York Philharmonic will open its 11th season of free concerts in city parks at Central Park's Sheep Meadow on July 29. Andre Kostelanetz will conducts program consisting of Rossini's Semiramide Overture, Mendelssohn's Italian Symphony, Stravinsky's Suite from Firebird and Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture (with fireworks display).

title: Lying In State: II
description: Ron Nessen, the President's press secretary, complained recently that the White House press was not treating his word with due respect. Some reporters had even accused him of lying. President Ford had been in office for ten months, he said, and it was time for an end to this blind, mindless, irrational cynicism and distrust.

title: Nassau Supervisors Fail To Block Judicial Panel
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn rejected unanimously a move by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors to abolish a judicial commission named to draw up a new county government that would be in compliance with the Supreme Court's one man, one vote concent.

title: FORD AND SENATE CONFLICT ON OIL
description: WASHINGTON, July 16president Ford and Congress took steps today to advance their conflicting energy policies, but each was expected to block the other's program.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JULY 17, 1975

title: GURNEY DEFENSE COMPLETES CASE
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 16Defense lawyers concluded their presentations today at the trial in United States District Court of former Senator Edward Gurney and three codefendants on charges stemming from an election campaign fundraising operation.

title: Unlisted Gifts Gifts to Congressmen Questioned in Light of New Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Several members of the House are quietly collecting donations for which they make no public accounting, sometimes treating the proceeds as personal income.

title: General Foods Changing Sanka and Brim Solvent
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 16The General Foods Corporation, one of the nation's largest makers of packaged foods, told Its shareholders today that it was discontinuing use of the solvent trichieroethylene, known as TCE, in its decaffeinated coffees, because of a recent study by the National Cancer Institute indicating that TCE may be a possible cancer of cancer.

title: Kuhn's Job as Commissioner in Danger
description: MILWAUKEE, July 16A palace revolt flared in professional baseball tonight when Bowie Kuhn found himself fightingand apparently losingfor reelection as commissioner in the face of an outbreak of opposition within the American League.

title: Court Backs Closed Trial To Shield a Police Witness
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled here yesterday that a defendant might be denied a public trial when It was necessary to protect the identity of undercoveragents.

title: Polaroid Reports Fivefold Increase In Quarterly Profit
description: The Polaroid Corporation lived up to anlysts' forecasts of a turnaround in earnings, as the company reported more than a fivefold gain from a year ago. The company said yesterday that net income in the second quarter rose to $13.4million, or 41 cents a share, against $2.2million, or 7 cents a share, in the like 1974 period.

title: STEELMAKERS SEEK RELIEF ON IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Nineteen makers of stainless and other specialty steels filed today the first major escape clause case, seeking relief from rising imports, under the new trade law passed by Congress last year. The United Steelworkers of America joined in the petition to the International Trade Commission.

title: Italian Hotel Workers Strike
description: ROME, July 17 (AP)Hotel workers staged a oneday nationwide strike today at the height of Italy's tournist season. Most restaurants, except familyrun places, were also closed in the dispute over renewal of contracts.

title: 2 in Salyut 4 to Return Soon After 55 Days
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (UPI)Two astronauts who have been aboard the Salyut 4 space station for 55 days will return home in a day or two, the Tass press agency said today.

title: PARK CONCERT GIVEN BY THREE DOG NIGHT
description: Three Dog Night's appearance at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Wednesday was its first Manhattan concert in three years. It seemed remarkably unchanged and, as one of the more durable rock groups of the decade, was content to add to its repertory rather than create anything startling or new. This is the same kind of formula used by groups that have instant recognition and identifiable sounds that wear well, such as Chicago and the Beach Boys.

title: Sucrest Increases Prices For Its Industrial Sugar
description: The Sucrest Corporation, a leading sugar refiner, increased its industrial sugar prices yesterday by 61 cents per hundred pounds, continuing a trend of higher prices in both grocery and industrial sugar in the last 10 days.

title: Estimate Board Assuming Sharper Role With Mayor
description: A week ago Mayor Beame was assuring his fellow political leaders that the city's crisis had lifted, at least for a while. But within the last 48 hours he has found himself in something approaching a state of seige, faced with demands for drastic steps to bring the city, for the second time in a month, back from the brink of possible default.

title: RARE SHEEP ESCAPE FIRE IN CALIFORNIA
description: WARNER SPRINGS, Calif., July 17 (UPI)Flocks of rare desert bighorn sheep escaped the flames of a brush fire that has devoured more than 8,600 acres of their habitat, wildlife biologists said today.

title: SURGERY ASSESSED IN HOUSE REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 A House subcommittee investigating unnecessary surgery has found that Medicaid patients have two and a half times more operations than the American population as a whole.

title: ExC.I.A. Aide Says Scientist Who Died Knew About Experiments With LSD
description: A former employe of the Central Intelligence Agency said yesterday he believed that a scientist who plunged to, his death from a Manhattan hotel window 22 years ago had knowingly participated in a C.I.A. experiment with LSD shortly before.

title: Richard Conlon, Managed Gallagher's Steak House
description: Richard Conlon, general manager until he retired recently of Gallagher's Steak House, a Times Square gathering place for sporting and theatrical personalities, died yesterday in his home in the Pare Vendome, 340 West 57th Street., He was 60 years old.

title: Virginia Friedland's Wedding Held
description: Virginia Friedland of Miami Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Maj. Gen. Donald Shelton Dawson, Air Force Reserve, retired, senior partner in the Washington law firm of Dawson,i Riddell, Taylor, Davis & Holroyd. Judge Edwin S. Maimed of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Mann of Bryn Mawr, Pa., friends of the couple.

title: Industrial Thefts Costly
description: CLEVELAND (UPI)Industrial Construction magazine says industrial thieves, professional and intracompany, cost U.S. businesses more than $0billion in goods and equipment last year.

title: A.T&T. DISCLOSES SAUDI FINANCING
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has placed la $100million note issue with the Government of Saudi Arabia, the giant telecommunications company said yesterday.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN TRIAL OF GURNEY
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 17 (UPI)Government prosecutors rested their briberyconspiracy case against former Senator Edward J. Gurney of Florida today without calling rebuttal witnesses.

title: ISRAEL GIVES U.S. NEW PROPOSALS FOR SINAI ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel today gave Secretary of State Kissinger the latest Israeli proposals for breaking the deadlocked talks with Egypt on a new Sinai agreement. Americans and Israelis said later that progress had been made toward an accord.

title: Bluefish Are Plentiful
description: Improved weather found anglers moving in boats and along the beaches in much greater number yesterday. Similarly, fish again began showing greater interest in shopping. Blues, weaks, porgies and sea bass were reported in worthwhile quantities frequenting their favorite haunts.

title: Penn Central Running Againt
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP)  Penn Central Railroad commuter trains were running normally today, one day after an electrical fire knocked out power and stopped all service in and out of Philadelphia. The fire yesterday severed the main rail passenger corridor between New York and Washington since there was no power to move the trains through Philadelphia.

title: BEATRICE IMBERMAN
description: Beatrice Hertz Imbermane an English teacher at Stuyvesant High School in the nineteenforties, died yesterday, apparently of a stroke, at Long Island Jewish Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 41 Auerbach Lane. Lawrence, L.I.

title: AllMale Senate Rebuffs House On SexSegregation School Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Senate refused today to go along with House efforts to allow separate physical education classes and professional honorary societies for men and women in federally aided schools at all levels.

title: HOUSE APPROVES OILCOST ROLLBACK
description: But Bill on Domestic Output Faces Veto by PresidentOverriding Is Seen Unlikely WASHINGTON, July 17The House of Representatives passed today and sent to the White House a bill that would troll back the price of oil prodiked in the United States.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, July 17 (Reuters)Marty Liguori ran two miles in 8 minutes 17.12 seconds at an international meet here tonight. It was the best twomile ever by a United States runner. The previous record of 8:18 was set by the late Steve Prefontaine here last year. The world record of 8:13.8 was set by Brendan Foster of Britain almost two years ago. Liquori outran New Zealand's John Walker and Anders Garderud of Sweden. In the high jump, Dwight Stones finished second to a United States teammate Tom Woods who had a jump of 7 feet 3 inches.

title: Corporate Sector Is Hit
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, New York's second largest bank, raised yesterday its base I landing rate on corporate loans to 7 per cent from 7 per cent, following the lead of the First National City Bank, the largest bank in the city, which last Friday adopted the the 7 per cent rate. While during the last week a number of big banks throughout the country adopted the 7 per cent rate for their most creditworthy customers, until the Chase acted yesterday, Citibank was alone with the 7 per cent rate here in New York City. Under a formula based on a threeweek average of commercial paper rates, tinder which it sets its prime rate, Citibank this morning could move its

title: Judy Rankin Leads by Stroke On 72 in Women's Open Golf
description: NORTHFIELD, N.J., July 17Judy Rankin, an established golf professional who began her career by winning peewee tournaments at the age of 8, led the opening round of the United States Women's Open Championship today, but the star of the afternoon was an 18yearold amateur who trailed by only one stroke.

title: Juvenile Offenders At Rikers I. Accuse Guards of Brutality
description: A group of inmates complained in a lawsuit yesterday that young adolescents live in fear at a detention facility on Rikers Island because of a pattern and practice of physical brutality by guards.

title: Owners Reelect Kuhn As Finley's Coup Fails
description: MILWAUKEE, July 17 Bowie Kuhn survived the palace revolt and won reelection as commissioner of baseball today when the New York Yankees and Texas Rangers quite the rebels after a night of nonstop counterattacks.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: HERBERT KAUFMAN
description: Herbert Kaufman, a partner in the law firm of Kaufman & Siegel, 10 East 40th Street, died Wednesday evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 975 Park Avenue.

title: In Memoriam
description: CLARKEugene, M.D. July 18, 1972. In memory of my beloved husband.

title: CAPT. H. G. MUNSON, ENGINEER, WAR HERO
description: Henry Glass Munson, a retired Navy captain who had headed the School of Electrical Engineering at the submarine base in. Groton, Conn., died of pneumonia Wednesday in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 18 Dodds Lane in Princeton. N.J.

title: Events Scheduled on the Joint Flight
description: Soviet astronauts are scheduled to pay their first visit to the Apollo spacecraft this morning in the first of four crew transfers that, by 5:52 P.M., will have permitted each astronaut to visit the other spacecraft at least once.

title: MAIL SEIZED IN '72 IS FOUND BY C.I.A
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar disclosed late today that 85 postcards and 25 letters intercepted more than three years ago by the Central Intelligence Agency had just been found on a shelf at an agency office.

title: Lutheran Woman Is Chaplain
description: ST. PAUL (UPI)The American Lutheran Church has announced that Christine Miller, a graduate from Luther Seminary, will become the first woman to serve as a Lutheran military chaplain and the sixth woman ordained in the American Lutheran Church.

title: People and Business
description: Three accountants, the last remaining defendants in the $2billion Equity Funding fraud, received prison sentences of three months each in a Los Angeles Federal court yesterday.

title: Influx of Mosquitoes Feared From Floods
description: State and county mosquitocontrol officials said yesterday that they had become increasingly concerned that the recent drenching rains might help spawn vast swarms of mosquitoes by late next week.

title: LSD Report Disputed
description: Robert V. Lashbrook, a former employe of the Central Intelligence Agency, said he believed Frank R. Olson, a scientist who committed suicide in 1953, had knowingly participated in an experiment with LSD. The statement appeared to contradict the Rockefeller commission's finding that Mr. Olson had been given the drug surreptitiously. Page 6.

title: North Vietnamese Apply For Membership in the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17North Vietnam has applied for membership in the United Nations, two days after South Vietnam requested admission.

title: A.T.&T. DISCLOSES SAUDI FINANCING
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has placed a $100million note issue with the Government of Saudi Arabia, the giant telecommunications company said yesterday.

title: About Real Estate
description: Strange are the workings of housing subsidies. They can be fiscally essential and socially disastrous at the same time. This was hardly the intent of Congress, but it is often a result in New York City.

title: New Square: Poorest, but Its Hasidim Do Not Live by Bread Alone
description: NEW SQUARE, N. Y., July 17To step into this village, which has only one access road, is to step into the East European villages of the last century.

title: 151 Split Infinitive Shows How to Quickly Win
description: Split Infinitive of the Greentree Stable contributed a surprise at Belmont yesterday when he won the Queens County Chamber of Commerce Purse. He paid $32.60 for $2 after finishing threequarters of a length the better of Hawaiian Love in the sixfurlong sprint. Among those in the crowd of 19,892 who was just as surprised as anyone was Jack Gayer, who saddled the 3yearold colt.  I just didn't know what to expect from him, said Gayer, the son of the Greentree trainer, John Gayer. We had tried him on the grass before, and he didn't show anything. So we put him on the main track, and up he came, a winner. You don't know how many surprises there are in this game.

title: Mets Down Braves, 4  3, on 3 Homers
CANADIAN WHEAT IS SOLD TO SOVIET
description: OTTAWA, July 17The Soviet Union has purchased two million metric tons of high grade wheat from Canada for delivery in the fall, the Canadian Wheat Board announced today.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: JAVITS CRITICIZES VIEV OF MATHEWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Senator Jacob K. Javits today reprimanded Dr. F. David Mathews, President Ford's nominee for Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, for the statements of Dr. Mathews earlier this week on school busing.

title: Dr. Ikl Raises A Problem
description: Dr. Fred S. Ikl, the director of the United States Disarmament Agency, is a Government official who wants to muzzle the press. So what else is new? Only that unlike most of his peers, Dr. Ikl just may have a point; in any case his concern precisely illustrates the difficulties that can arise in an open society with a free pressand those that would result from legislation limiting that freedom.

title: Forbes Jury at Impasse
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 17The jury in the case of the State of Minnesota versus David S. Forbes deliberated almost seven hours today, then retired to a hotel late tonight after reaching an impasse in determining the fate of the Boston Bruins' hockey player. It will reconvene here tomorrow morning.

title: Open Interest
Reds' Streak Is Halted at 10 by Expos
description: The Montreal Expos are last in the National League's Eastern Division. They are a young club and are rebuilding, so there is no pennant pressure on them. They are, as the clich goes, playing loose.

title: SAMUEL POMERANTZ
description: Samuel L. Pomerantz, president and founder of Victoria, Vogue, Inc., manufacturer of powder puffs in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 77 years old.

title: SYNDICATE RIGHTS OF PAPER LIMITED
description: The Boston Globe's exchisive rights to syndicated newspaper features have been limited to a sixcounty area under an agreement approved by a Federal judge Wednesday ending eights years of litigation, United Press International reported.

title: LEVELING IS FOUND IN NATION'S OUTPUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The nation's total output of goods and services was essentially flat in the second quarter, providing further evidence that the recession has hit bottom, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Buddy Rich said yesterday that his band would not go to South Africa because the South African Government would not issue his black bass player a work permit

title: City's Biggest Scofflaw: U.S., at $6Million a Year
description: The Parking Violations Bureau here has disclosed that the biggest scofflaw in the city is the Federal Government, which is running up unpaid bills estimated at. $6million a year.

title: City Will Dismiss 1,434 In Sanitation Force Today
description: Mayor Beame said late yesterday that 1,434 sanitationmen would be dismissed this afternoon, and that 750 others would have to be laid off at the end of the month because the unusual $1.6million fund pledged By their union to pay their wags was running out.

title: VARIED DANCES MARK JOINT N.Y.U. CONCERT
description: Annabelle Gamson, Linday Tarnay and Rachel Lampert were united Wednesday evening only by their desire to give a joint concert. In all other matters each maintained her own distinctive approach. The impressively varied concert was given at the New York University School of the Arts Theater and will be repeated Friday.

title: LILLY FUND GIVES TV WRITING PRIZES
description: The Humanitas Prizes, created last year to improve the moral tone of network television, were won today by David Seltzer and Joel Olianski.

title: COURT BIDS NIXON OFFER TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON. July 17 (AP) Richard M. Nixon was ordered today to give testimony before lawyers seeking access to White House papers and tapes accumulated while he was President.

title: Books of The Times
description: A number of things kept me reading Reynolds Price's new navel, The Surface of Earth, which is a history of four generations of a Southern family spanning the years 1903 to 1944. One of them, of course, was respect for the author, who over the last dozen years or so has gathered many literary honors and whose three novels  A Long and Happy Life, A Generous Man and. Love and Workand two collections of stories The Names and Faces of Heroes and Permanent Errorshave established hip as one of the leading current practitioners of the great Southern narrative tradition. But far more important were certain magnetisms within the fiction itself. One of them was the promise of the charactersthe sheer force of their love, their hunger for one another, their selfishness and, paradoxically, their determination to be good people. The long chronicle begins with a family tragedy in which a 16yearold girl, Eva Kendal, elopes on the night of her graduation from high school with her 32yearold Latin teacher, Forrest Mayfield; then nearly dies while bearing their son; and then, upon learning that her mother, has committed suicide Gut of shame and anger at her daughter's act, permanently abandons her husband to look after her father in his loss. This may sound like a story suitable for framing in a doleful go Southern Appalachian bellad, but Mr. Price has so highlighted the virtues of his characters' behavior that we cannot help being drawn into their subsequent histories, to learn why it is they must hurt one another.

title: PHILIPPINES DETAINS AMERICAN JETGINER
description: A United Air Lines DC8 jet carrying 142 Asian exchange students on a charter flight from Bangkok to the United States was ordered by Philippines authorities to land in Manila late Wednesday.

title: Curb on Electronic Banks Expected to Be Contested
description: TRENTON, July (UPI)The recent signing into law by Governor Byrne of a Banking Department bill banning electronic branches has set the stage for a possible confrontation between the state and New York City's banks.

title: U.S. Convicts Fruehauf
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, a major builder of truck trailers, and its two chief officers were found guilty yesterday in Detroit of conspiring to cheat the Government of $12.3million in taxes. Page 37.

title: Article 1  No Title
LSD Report Disputed
description: Robert V. Lashbrook, a former employe of the Central Intelligence Agency, said he believed Frank R. Olson, a scientist who committed suicide in 1953, had knowingly participated in an experiment with LSD. The statement appeared to contradict the Rockefeller commission's finding that Mr. Olson had been given the drug surreptitiously. Page 6.

title: BAKER OK TOOLS PLANS A MERGER
description: Baker Oil Tools, Inc., of Los Angeles and Reed Tool Cornpany of Houston announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement In principle to menge. The agreement provides for an exchange of comon stock0.735 shares of Baker for each share of Reed. To effect the exchange, Baker expects to utilize 2.2 million of its shares valued at 8120.7million, based on yesterday's closing price of 54 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ColorCoordination Set On Journal's Covers
description: Magazine covers that coordinate with a woman's wardrobe. Is that the publishing breakthrough of the century?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislature's Legal Advisers Divided on Whether City or State Has Power to Freeze Municipal Wage
description: Lawyers for the politically divided Legislature offered differing opinions yesterday of whether the city or state would have the authority to suspend raises promised to employes in city contracts.

title: CHARLES B. COLLINS
description: Charles Bertine Collins, a senior partner in the law firm of Carpenter, Bennett & Morrissey of Newark, died Wednesday at his home, 20 Woodhill Drive, Maplewood, N. J. He was 70 years old.

title: The Story Of an Angry Designer
description: Barry Kieselstein isn't flattered when his jewelry designs are copied. He's indignant. Last year, the indignation boiled over. He instituted two civil actions for infringement of his copyright designs.

title: $217Million Slide Reported
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that business loans at leading New York City banks declined for the second consecutive week, indicating that economic activity remained sluggish despite widespread anticipation of a national recovery.

title: Hospital Employes Stage Protest on Budget Cuts
description: Sitins, begun earlier this week, continued early today at the Health and Hospitals Corporation offices at 93 Worth Street and at Morrisania Hospital, 168th Street and Gerard Avenue in the Bronx, to protest proposed budget cuts in hospitals services.

title: China Agrees to Buy Thai Rice Despite Expected Surplus Crop
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 17 Thailand said today that China had agreed to buy 200,000 tons of Thai rice in what was clearly a move to cement economic relations between the two countries.

title: GLAD TO SEE YOU
description: HOUSTON, July 17Astronauts of the United States and the Soviet Union united spaceships today and then joined hands in the first international meeting away from earth, a symbolic gesture of the two nations' expressed desire to cooperate in the exploration of space.

title: PAUL M. LUND DIES; A.T.&T. EXECUTIVE, 50
description: Paul M. Lund, a vice presi dent of the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company in charge of public relations and employe information since June, 1971, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: P.E.A. GIVES OUT LEAFLETS AGAIN
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which led last month's Fear City campaign, has resumed distributing leaflets warning that the city is unsafe because of the dismissal of 3,000 police officers.

title: Tomahawks Triumph
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., July 17 The Long Island Tomahawks scored seven goals within a span of 7 minutes 46 seconds of the second period tonight to erase a 75 deficit and defeat the Montreal Quebecois, 1410, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Propaganda vs. Land
description: Succumbing to a bombardment of false propaganda, the Interior Committee of the House of Representatives has defeated by four votes a modest bill calling for landuse planning. Three Democrats, Representatives Melcher of Montana, Howe of Utah and Taylor of North Carolina, turned against the measure after, having previously given it their support.

title: Notes on People
description: John Stonehouse, fugitive member of the British Parliament, and his secretary, Mrs. Sheila Buckley, left Melbourne, Australia, yesterday under the escort of four Scotland Yard detectives and began the 23hour flight back to England. There they face criminal charges of theft, fraud and forgery.

title: Col. SoI P. Fink Dies at 77; Saw Action in 4 Conflicts
description: Col. Sol P. Fink, U.S.A., retired, a veteran of four wars and a former New York stockbroker, died yesterday in Lawrence (Mass.) General Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in North Andover, Mass.

title: Trial of Reputed Crime Figure Is Told He Paid for F.B.I. Files
description: NEWARK, July 17 (AP)The prosecutor in the Federal trial, of John DiGilio, ar eputed underworld figure, said in an opening statement today that Mr. DiGilio paid a stenographer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation to slip him secret investigative reports from the bureau's files.

title: Italian Freed, One Seized
description: MILAN, Italy, July 17 (AP)Kidnappers released Giuseppe Ferrarini, 69yearold owner of a Milan transport company, early today after holding him for eight days, the police announced. A few hours earlier a Rome construction executive, Fabrizio Andreuzzi, was kidnapped near the Vatican.

title: Egypt's View Is That Warning On U.N. Force Is Peace Spur
description: CAIRO, July 17Egypt, in the official view, has instilled a new sense of urgency in the search for a Middle East setilement and has closed no doors.

title: M.A.C. Urges Dramatic Cuts on City to Reopen Bond Market
description: The directors of the Municipal Assistance Corporation told Mayor Beame yesterday that the city must immediately undertake a series of dramatic measureseven beyond a wage freeze for city employes  to reopen the moneylending market to the city and the corporation.

title: ISRAEL GIVES U.S. NEW PROPOSALS FOR SINAI ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel today gave Secretary of State Kissinger the latest Israeli proposals for breaking the deadlocked talks with Egypt on a new Sinai agreement. Americans and Israelis said later that progress had been made toward an accord.

title: Israel Looks to a Formula on U.N. Force
description: JERUSALEM, July 17Senior Israeli officials said today that the future of the IsraeliEgyptian negotiations toward a new Sinai accord hinges on whether a way could be found to extend the mandate of the United Nations Emergency Force in the Sinai buffer zone.

title: City and Jersey Suffer 9th Rainy Day in Row
description: For the ninth consecutive day, the moist tropical air mass stalled over the metropolitan area produced more brief, sporadic downpours and thunder showers yesterday over waterlogged portions of New York City and New Jersey.

title: The Pop Life
description: Periodically, samples are taken of what passes for water off our beaches to decide where bathers can swim uncontaminated. On the same theory, this column proposes to sample the top 10 pop singles periodically, in order to ascertain if there's anything out there on the airwaves worth listening to. The water has reportedly improved; maybe the music has, as well.

title: Books of The Times
description: A number of things kept me reading Reynolds Price's new novel, The Surface of Earth, which is a history of four generations of a Southern family spanning the years 1903 to 1944. One of them, of course, was respect for the author, who over the last dozen years or so has gathered many literary honors and whose three novelsA Long and Happy Life, A Generous Man and Love and Workand two collections of stories The Names and Faces of Heroes and Permanent Errorshave established him as one of the leading current practitioners of the great Southern narrative tradition. But far more important were certa?? magnetisms within the fiction itself. One of them was the promise of the charactersthe sheer force of their love, their hunger for one another, their selfish??less and, paradoxically, their determination to be good people. The long chronicle begins with a family tragedy in which a 16yearold girl, Eva Kendal, elopes on the night of her graduation from high school with her 32yearold Latin teacher, Forrest Mayfield; then nearly dies while bearing their son; and then, upon learning that her mother has committed suicide out of shame and anger at her daughter's act, permanently abandons her husband to look after her father in his loss. This may sound like a story suitable for framing in a doleful Southern Appalachian ballad, but Mr. Price has so highlighted the virtues of his characters' behavior that we cannot help being drawn into their subsequent histories, to learn why it is they must hurt one another.

title: Hats Are Back: Not for Style, But for Fun
description: Straw in the wind? Well, yes. There are signs that the hat is again becoming part of the city scene. Milliners, who have been starving through more than a decade of hatlessness, can takeheart at the sight of brimmed straws Sailing around New York. But they should be cautious about embarking on the expensive confections they sold in the nineteenfifties.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly described Paul Crook as playing a mime in the opera Siegfried. Mr. Crook plays the role of Mime, the dwarf.

title: The deathly stillness of the Florida night was broken only by a cicada's rasp. Offshore, the great white shark cruised, hungry. Richard Bach, nerves taut, sat at the home computer terminal. Armageddon, he thought. Breakfast was far off.
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N. Y.We know that this century is run by enormous computers, and that computers, the big ones, do not fail unless they are deliberately unplugged. Let us come facetoface with a giant computer that is firmly plugged in and that is programed to totally destroy us and we learn how rabbit feels, hypnotized by cobra: It is frozen in a kind of horrified awe.

title: State Granted Court Order To Bar Civil Service Strike
description: The state yesterday obtained a temporary restraining order against a strike threatened for next Monday by 115,000 members of the Civil Service Employes Association.

title: JUDGE SAYS BOARD MAY SUE INSURER
description: Judge Jacob Fuchsberg ruled in the New York State Court of Appeals yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange had a right to sue a subsidiary of the Continental Insurance Company for $47.5million in damages arising from the collapse of the Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Corporation in the saladoil swipille of 1963.

title: Advertising
description: During the first six months of this year, only 29 of the top 100 national consumer magazines showed increases in advertising pages from the yearearlier period. And only six of those showed increases of more than 10 per cent.

title: Rangers Conquer Yankees
New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners granted a 5cent fare increase to the Downtown Bus Company of Jersey City, which operates buses within the city and to Hoboken and Weehawken.

title: U.S. SEES GAS WOES IN CANADA WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (Reuters)The State Department said today that Canada's warning of some curtailment in natural gas exports had serious implications, and the Ford Administration hoped American customers would not bear the full burden of decreased Canadian supplies.

title: Why Bowie Kuhn Rose From the Dead
description: Although he gives impression that even his undershirt is stuffed, Bowie Kuhn deserved to continued as the Commissioner of Baseball more than Charles. O. Finley deserved to be hailed as his assassin. In the end, that is why Bowie Kuhn rose from the dead yesterday.

title: City's Biggest Scofflaw: U.S., at $6Million a Year
description: The Parking Violations Bureau here has disclosed that the biggest scofflaw in the city is the Federal Government, which is running up unpaid bills estimated at $6million a year.

title: New Square: Poorest, but Its Hasidim Do Not Live by Bread Alone
description: NEW SQUARE, N. Y., July 17To step into this village, which has only one access road, is to step into the East European villages of the last century.

title: POLICE INDICTED IN DRUG ARREST
description: A 40yearold Bronx woman was freed from state prison yesterday shortly after four police officers were indicted on charges of illegally obtaining the evidence that led to her arrest on a narcotics violation nearly four years ago.

title: Bridge:
description: The second of New York's three major annual tournaments begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: The Highest and Lowest
description: A newly released Federal census report shows that the New York State communities with both the highest and the lowest percapita incomes are suburbs of New York City. Calculations from the census data, compiled for Federal revenuesharing allocations, indicate an average income of $4,248 for state residents during the 1972 calendar year.

title: U.S. Radio in Nigerta Assailed
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 17 (AP)

title: New SexualAssault Unit Is in Operation in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 17A new sexualassault and rapeanalysis unit operated by the New sis unit operated by the Newark Police Department and the Essex County Prosecutor's office was announced here today.

title: 2 NursingHome Aides Indicted, One on Assault, 2d in Theft Case
description: Charles J. Hynes, a special state prosecutor, announced the indictment and arrest of two nursinghome employes yesterday, one for the alleged abuse of a patient, the other charged with the theft of $46,700 from a nursing home.

title: Larchmont Sail Won by Harris
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17The Larchmont Race Week senior onedesign competition resumed today after a threeday break for the Larchmont Junior Regatta. Because of the lack of wind, however, the Ensign. Class was the only one of nine classes to complete its course within the time limit. The 96 yachts that raced in eight other onedesign classes today are listed as did not finish.

title: HERBERT KAUFMAN
description: Herbert Kaufman, a partner in the law firm of Kaufman Siegel, 10 East 40th Street, died Wednesday evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 975 Park Avenue.

title: Yonkers Trot Shifted From 8th to 3d Race
description: Because of a decision by Yonkers Raceway officials to advance tomorrow night's $200,000 Yonkers Trot from the eighth to the third spot on the program, OTB is changing its schedule for that night's Yonkers wagering.

title: I.R.S. Is Studying Gifts By 111 U.S. Companies
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Commissioner, Donald Alexander, said today 111 American corporations are under investigation for alleged illegal domestic and foreign political contributions.

title: Stocks Decline on Credit Doubts
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange were pushed lower yesterday, largely by the weight of uncertainty over the future course of credit rates.

title: Canadian Quotas on Eggs Upset U.S.
description: OTTAWA, July 17  A few days before an official advisory body urged free trade as a better way than traditional protectionism for Canada to gain economic independence from the United States, the Canadian Government imposed stiff new quotas on American eggs.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: City, Proposes to Grant Builders Option of Hiring Own Inspectors
description: The city's Department of Buildings, with 45 of its 270 inspectors and 15 other employes charged with graft, is planning to seek authorization to give builders the option to hire their own inspectors.

title: Jersey Assemblymen Divided On Taxes to Add Budget Funds
description: TRENTON. July 17  The State Assembly appeared today to be undecided on how to go about restoring tomorrow the budget cuts made by Governor Byrne. Assemblymen have filed 13 tax bills and one supplemental appropriation bill for possible votes

title: Professor Is Working to Revive Adult Concert Bands
description: EVANSTON, Ill.I want royal purple, pompous, unbelievably snotty, John Philip Paynter said as he mopped his brow with a small terrycloth towel and raised his baton.

title: LEVELING IS FOUND IN NATION'S OUTPUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The nation's total output of goods and services was essentially flat in the second quarter, providing further evidence that the recession has hit bottom, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Alcoa, Armco and Inland Report Lower Earnings
Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The American Arbitration Association has ruled in favor of the Anaconda Company in its claim against the Government's Overseas Private Investment Corporation for $154million, it was announced today.

title: Vilas, Pecci Reach Tennis Semifinals
description: HILVERSUM, The Netherlands, July 17 (AP)  Topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina and 18yearold Victor Pecci of Paraguay won quarterfinal matches today in the Dutch open lawn tennis championships.

title: New York Riders Hit the Old Competitive Trail
People in Sports
description: For Muhammad Ali every bout calls for a brand new production number, and the world heavyweight champion was in town yesterday to announce formally his title defense against Joe Frazier on Oct. 1. Ali billed the fight, which could earn him $8million and Frazier $5million, as a killer, of a chiller in a thriller in Manila with the gorilla. He displayed a coupie of new props, a tennis net, which he said Frazier would need to catch a butterfly [Ali], a small gorilla doll peeking from his breast pocket, which he insisted was Frazier's conscience.

title: Cuba, Again
description: No one can accuse the Organization of American States of rash or impulsive decisions on the Issue of permitting Cuba to rejoin the hemisphere. For the coming two weeks in Costa Rica delegates of 24 active member statesCuba is listed as inactivewill deliberate the parliamentary problems of lifting 11yearold trade and political sanctions against the Castro Government. This is the third major convocation of the O.A.S. in the past eight months in which the Cuban connectionor lack thereofhas dominated the discussion.

title: Hewlett Bay Park: Richest Of the State's Communities
description: HEWLETT BAY PARK, L.I., July 17Let Fitzgerald cast his eyes across the waten at East Egg. Let Cheever, Updike, O'Hara and Oates examine the gilded suburbs of America. Hewlett Bay Park does not care to be discovered.

title: CLEVELAND. FAVORED FOR G.O.P. '76 PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Cleveland, where Republicans nominated Alfred M. Landon for President in 1936. is now a leading bidder for the G.O.P. convention next year, party sources said today.

title: About New York
description: It would be exaggeration bordering on hyperbole to describe the Municipal Building as a hive of activity at any hour of the day or month of the year, but on Wednesday at 4:30 P.M. it looked like a wax works.

title: Prisoners Can Buy Time
description: THE HAGUE (UPI)  State Secretary of Justice Jan Glastra van Loon has announced that people who are waiting to serve jail terms will be allowed to buy off up to 14 days at 25 guilders ($10) per day. He hopes it will cut the prisons' waiting list.

title: Oldest Declaration Copy Is Traced to Philadelphia
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)The Library of Congress has determined that the oldest copy of the first published version of the Declaration of Independence is in Philadelphia, according to two historical authorities.

title: Meetings Called of Angola Factions and Portuguese
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 17Meetings of Angola's three feuding black liberation movements and Portuguese authoricuss the crisis here.

title: ITALY UNDER GOING POSTVOTE SHIFTS
description: ROME, July 17Just a month after the regional and municipal elections throughout most, of the country, Italians are, looking with some interest at the first tangible results of their votes.

title: 1760 Hit Opera Charms at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, July 17The world of pop music thinks it's getting positively historical when it exhumes a big hit of 20 years ago. But last night at Yale's University Theater here, a big hit of 215 years ago was brought to life, and it turned out to be a mostly charming affair.

title: Lisbon Asking Calm as Military Seeks a Government
description: LISBON, July 17Portugal's rulers cast about today for an effective government following the collapse of the Lisbon coalition early this morning.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Ethics in Government
description: Watergate has now become a catchall word that covers a complex of scandals that did more than force the resignation of both a President and a Vice President. It also brought about a healthy new sensitivity to ethics in government, a realization that mere adherence to the letter of the law is no longer enough for those in public office. Three recent cases present examples of failure to meet the new higher standards of postWatergate America.

title: Ambiguities of Detente
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The successful linkup today of Apollo and Soyuz has visibly demonstrated the ambiguity of SovietAmerican relations. It has underscored that the two superpowers can turn their militaryindustrial power to cooperation instead of confrontation, but it has also pointed up the fact that despite dtente such cooperation is Still lacking on most of the important issues of war and peace.

title: GLAD TO SEE YOU
description: HOUSTON, July 17Astronauts of the United States and the Soviet Union united spaceships today and then joined hands in the first international meeting away from earth, a symbolic gesture of the two nations' expressed desire to cooperate in the exploration of space.

title: U.N. Seeks a Way to Keep Peace Force in Sinai
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17Security Council members began private consultations today seeking a formula that would persuade. Egypt to agree to extend the mandate of the United Nations peace force in Sinai. After an hourlong meeting, they agreed to meet tomorrow.

title: Ballet: Lander's Etudes Is Good Art and Bad Art
description: That there is good art and bad art may be held to be selfevident, but to recognize the more subtle distinctions of goodbad art and badgood art requires some degree of sophistication and a sensibility unusually wellattuned to the art form under consideration. Harald Lander's Etudes is a superb example of the goodbad ballet. Etudes was given for the first time this season by American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night, and Gelsey Kirkland made her debut in it on Wednesday night.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OPEN HOUSE The time: 2 to 6 P.M. today. The place: The House That Jazz Built, at 1312 Stebbins Avenue (near Jackson Avenue) in the Bronx. The hostess: Maxine Sullivan, who needs no introduction as a durably popular balladeer.

title: BLACKS LOSE SUIT ON JOB SENIORITY
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 17 (AP)  Blacks who lost their jobs in the current recession, because they had low seniority have not been discriminated against a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: City Will Dismiss 1,434 In Sanitation Force Today
description: Mayor Beame said late yesterday that 1,434 sanitationmen would be dismissed this afternoon, and that 750 others would have to be laid off at the end of the month because the unusual $1.6million fund pledged by their union to pay their wages was running out.

title: Byrne Signs Law To Provide Funds For Water Projects
description: TRENTON, July 17Bondissue funds totaling $137.5million will become available for waterpollution control and watersupply projects in New Jersey as a result of legislation signed into law today by Governor Byrne.

title: The Highest and Lowest
description: A newly released Federal census report shows that the New York State communities with both the highest and thelowest percapita incomes are suburbs of New York City. Calculations from the census data, compiled for Federal revenuesharing allocations, indicate an average income of $4,248 for state residents during the 1972 calendar year.

title: Estimate Board Assuming Sharper Role With Mayor
description: A week ago Mayor Beame was assuring his fellow political leaders that the city's crisis had lifted, at least for a while. But within the last 48 hours he has found himself in something approaching a state of siege, faced with demands for drastic steps to bring the city, for the second time in a month, back from the brink of possible default.

title: 4 Soldiers Killed in Ulster by Bomb in a Milk Can
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 17Four British soldiers were killed today by a bomb hidden in a milk can near the border with the Irish Republic.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 750
description: MOSCOW July 17 (UPI)The Soviet Union launched an unmanned earth satellite today Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced. The new satellite, Cosmos 750, carries a radio system for precise measurement of orbit elements and a radiotelemetric system to advise ground stations on the functioning of onboard systems.

title: FRUEHAUF IS CITED FOR TAX EVASION
description: DETROIT, July 17(UPI)The Fruehauf Corporation, one of the world's largest builders of truck trailers and containers, and its two chief officers were found guilty today of conspiring to cheat the Government of $12.3million in taxes.

title: Prices Decline on Amex and Counter
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell again yesterday on a lack of bullish news.

title: Wisconsin Publisher Named
description: BELOIT, Wis., July 17 (UPI) Donald J. Byrne has been named publisher of The Beloit Daily News, succeeding C. Patrick King, who has been named publisher of The Daily Inter, Lake at Kalispell, Mont. Mr. Byrne had been publisher of the Pullman, Wash., Herald.

title: U.S. Defends Stand on Indian Ocean Base
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The State Department has informed Congress that the Administration deliberately chose not to approach the Soviet Union on possible navalarms limitations in the Indian Ocean before deciding to proceed with construction of a naval base on the island of Diego Garcia.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JULY 18, 1975

title: F. EDWIN CHURCH, PAINTER, 98, DIES
description: F. Edwin Church, an artist and a founder of the North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary, died Tuesday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 98 years old and had lived here and in Locust Valley for the last 45 years.

title: General Phone Net Off 6.8%
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the nation's largest independent telephone system and a major manufacturer of electronic equipment, reported yesterday a decline in earnings of 6.8 per cent in the second quarter and 10.1 per cent for the first half from the records achieved in the 1974 periods.

title: Bridal for Tobe Hait And Leon S. Kanon
description: Tobe Hait, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Hait of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Leon S. Kanon, a junior accountant with the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, and son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kanon, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Stephen C. Lerner, assisted by Cantor Louis Moss, performed the ceremony in the Town and Village Synagogue.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.Angel Mayoral, 137 pounds, Las Vegas, outpointed Mike Mayon, 137, San Diego, 10 rounds.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly described Paul Crook as playing a mime in the opera Siegfried. Mr. Crook plays the role of Mime, the dwarf.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Astronauts of the United States and the Soviet Union met in space yesterday and joined hands, symbolizing the two nations' expressed desire to cooperate in space exploration. The American Apollo made physical contact with the Soviet Soyuz at 12:09 P.M., Eastern daylight time, about 140 miles above the Atlantic Ocean and about 620 miles west of Portugal. Three and a half minutes later the two ships achieved a firm linkup. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: F.C.C. CITES STATION FOR MARTIAN SCARE
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI)Acting on complaints of seriously frightened listeners, the Fedral Communications Commission sharply admonished today Radio Station WPRO in Providence. R. I. for broadcasting an updated version of the H. G. Wells classic War of the Worlds.

title: Big Mac Takes Charge
description: Big Mac laid down the law in a series of meetings with Mayor Beanie and other city officials yesterdayand it was about time.

title: Rooking the King
description: PARISThe title of the world chess champion has been usurped to the accompaniment of guilty silence on all sides.

title: D.A.R. Museum Staff of 3 Quits in Bookend Furor
description: WASHINGTON, July 17A furor over the deaccessioning or disposal, of a pair of castbronze bookends from the Museum of the Daughters of the American Revolution has led to the resignation in protest of the three professional staff members of the museum.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: Jazz Band Is Solid Favorite at Races
description: Alonzo Stewart of New Orleans and Jeannette Luchesi of Yonkers are not the usual type of race track habituds, but both have been going to Belmont Park lately, Mr. Stewart to play with the Preservation Hall Jazz Band and Mrs. Luchesi to listen to it.

title: Ford Now Trying to Arrange Solzhenitsyn Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, July 17President Ford, having first avoided a proposed meeting with Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, is now trying to arrange one. But the exiled Soviet author is reportedly insisting on a written invitation to the White House.

title: TWO JURORS ADDED IN JOAN LITTLE CASE
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 17 Two more jurors were selected in the murder trial of Joan Little today, bringing the total to six.

title: Grand Jury May Weigh Woman's Death
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 17Testimony is expected to be presented to a Nassau County grand jury next week following an investigation into the death of the wife of Dr. Charles Friedgood, a source close to the case said today.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Le Colisee, which opened June 26 at 36 East 60th Street, still has a few rough spots to smooth out, but after less than a month of operation it is already wellestablished with an enthusiastic clientele, and gives promise of pulling itself together as a fourstar establishment.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 10%
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.08billion, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $1billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.46billion, up 10 per cent from last year's $10.41billion.

title: UAL Quarterly Net Tumbles by 84.3%; Fuel Cost Is Cited
description: UAL, Inc., the corporate parent of United Airlines and Western International Hotels, reported yesterday that its secondquarter net income plunged to $5.5million, or 22 cents a share, from $35million, or $1.40 a share, a year ago.

title: Union Carbide Earnings Drop as Sales Advance
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday a drop of slightly more than 30 per cent in secondquarter earnings although sales ran 7.7 per cent higher than in the like 1974 period.

title: SEABOARD PARENT HAS DROP IN NET
description: Seaboard Coast Line Industries, Inc., parent of the railroad of similar name, as well as of the Louisville & Nashville Railroad and several other Southeast carriers, reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in. the second quarter fell to $6.3million, or 44 cents a share, after a tax credit of $1.7million. For the same period a year ago, the holding company reported a net income of $29.4million, or $2.02 a share.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: The proprietor of the comic book store watched the two boysone blond, one darkhaired come into his shop. The name of the private school both attended was clearly stamped on the canvas book bag each wore strapped to his back. He judged them to be no more than 12. For five minutes, they riffled through the racks of comics. Then the blond boy approached, commanding the owner's attention, wanting to know about an old copy of a Marvel classic, while his friend continued to browse. Oh, ohthe owner recognized the ploy in an instantthe kids are setting up.

title: A NEW SPY PANEL IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 Hoping to end the disputes that have stalled its investigation of the Federal intelligence agencies, the House of Representatives took the unusual step today of abolishing its Select Committee on Intelligence and replacing it with a new, larger panel with the same authority.

title: Cracks in Indian Democracy Linked to a Thin Shell
description: NEW DELHI, July 16One rainy August day 26 years ago India's constituent assembly sat in an ornate hall here work. ing over the draft of a federal constitution.

title: NIXON STAFF FUNDS REDUCED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The House passed today by a vote of 393 to 18 a $7.5billion measure to fund the Treasury, White House and other agencies and cutting requests for funds for former President Richard M. Nixon's staff by $81.848.

title: Prince and Princess of Japan Attacked by Okinawa Radicals
description: TOKYO, July 17  Crown Prince Akihito and Princess Michiko of Japan were attacked by two young radicals today on Okinawa, but were unhurt. A policeman suffered minor burns.

title: Pennsylvania Talks Held
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 17 (UPI)  Pennsylvania officials resumed talks with representatives of a social workers union whose 16day strike has slowed the flow of unemployment compensation checks in the state's major cities. The fivehour session was held yesterday in the offices of Lieut. Gov. Ernest Kline. Both sides refused detailed comment on the meeting.

title: Dollar Reaches 9Month High in Markets
description: The dollar reached a ninemonth high in foreignexchange markets yesterday, in a continuation of a dramatic upward movement that began a few weeks ago.

title: Muscovites Watch LinkUp On TV With Little Emotion
description: MOSCOW, July 17A heavyset Russian woman in a beige dress watched the ApolloSoyuz docking on a color television set in a Gorky Street shop today, blocking with her bulk many of the other wouldbe viewers, who grumbled and pushed closer.

title: Senators Defeat Attempts To Dilute Vote Rights Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Senate Judiciary Committee turned aside attempts today to amend and weaken a bill to extend the Voting Rights Act for 10 years and appeared ready to approve the measure tomorrow.

title: RAILWAY CLERKS THREATEN STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Contract talks between the railroads and the railway clerks union broke down today and the union called for a strike July 28.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Estimate ratified the designation of the interior of the Federal Hall National Memorial, at Broad and Nassau Streets, as a city landmark, along with two other historic interiors, those of the MorrisJumel Mansion in Washington Heights and the BartowPell Mansion in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. The exteriors of all three buildings had previously been designated by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Destruction of LSD Data Laid to C.I.A. Aide in '73
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The staff of the Rockefeller commission concluded that the chief of the Central Intelligence Agency's testing of LSD deitroyed the drug program's records in 1973 to hide the details of possibly illegal actions, commission sources said today.

title: Assemblyman ls Cleared on Use of Carey Fund
description: The State Board of Elections announced yesterday that it had not found any criminal violations in an upstate Assemblyman's use of a Governor Carey campaign fund to finance underhanded tactics against former Gov. Malcolm Wilson in the 1974 gubernatorial contest.

title: Rendezvous in Space
description: The spaceships of the United States and the Soviet Union yesterday docked peacefully and softly at their appointed rendezvous. After appropriate maneuvers, astronauts from one nation passed into the spaceship of the other; and in an environment of smiles, handshakes and bear hugs the longawaited SovietAmerican meeting in space took place at the human level. Inevitably Communist party General Secretary Brezhnev and President Ford felt moved to break in and thus personally reap some of the goodwill and glory of the event. But perhaps that was a small price to pay for this step forward.

title: REPORT ON RONAN DRAWS A DENIAL
description: Hugh Morrow, Vice President Rockefeller's press secretary, yesterday denied a widely pub??ished report that Dr. William

title: Mother of 3 Wins Jackpot
description: ASBURY PARK, July 17 (AP) A 29yearold Jamesburg, N.J., woman won $250,000 today in the Jersey Jackpot lottery drawing here. The winner, Irene Sikorski, said she planned to use the money to finance college educations for her three young children

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, July 17, 1975

title: Europe Asks U.S., Japan For New Currency Ties
description: BRUSSELS, July 17Leaders of the nine European Conmon Market countries decided today to seek American. and Japanese help in dealing with what they described as the internal tional, monetary disorder.

title: U.S AND TURKEY DISCUSSING BASES
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 17Turkey and the United States began talks today on the future of American bases here, and the Turks put off plans to give the installations provisional status pending the outcome of the negotiations.

title: TIMBER CASE FINDS 5 COMPANIES GUILTY
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 17 (UPI)Five timber companies and two executives were found guilty yesterday of violating Federal antitrust laws in bidding on timber in the WilHamette National Forest.

title: Curl's 66 Leads by A Stroke
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 17 (AP)Rod Curl, on the comeback trail, shot a fiveunderpar 66 today and took a onestroke lead in the first round of the $200,000 Pleasant Valley Golf Classic.

title: Ford to Talk in Rhode Island
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 17 (AP)President Ford will speak at the Republican State Central Committee's Aug. 30 fundraising dinner in Newport, state Republicans announced today. The dinner will be held at the home of Mrs. John J. Slocum, who is cochairman of the state party.

title: Jones Intends to Stay on Top at Northrop
description: BEVERLY HILLS. Calif.Thomas V. Jones, the Northrop, Corporation's embattled chief executive officer, said today that he intended to stay in charge of the scandalridden company indefinitely despite a stinging rebuke by the company's executive committee that led to his resignation as chairman yesterday.

title: AID TO CAMPAIGNS FROM TAXES RISES
description: WASHINGTON July 17The Income tax checkoff begun two years ago is expected to produce more than $100million in Federal funds to help to finance the 1976 Presidential election, the chairman of the Federal Election Commission said today.

title: The Small Hotel of Song to Reopen
description: STOCKTON, July 17 (AP)Rodgers and Hart are long gone from here but the wishing well that inspired their hit song still stands on the grounds of a small hotelrestaurant in this tiny Hunterdon County community.

title: RODNEY'S JAZZ TONE LIFTS DANCE MUSIC
description: Red Rodney, the peppery little trumpet player who was a mainstay of Charlie Parker's quiete 25 years ago, is back in town after 17 years on the West Coast. There he made his living playing in society bands rather than jazz groups, so it is not surprising now to find him at the Riverboat, fronting Big Julie Epstein's house band, which plays for dancing between performances by Helen Schneider, a singer, and Cricket Hill, a rock group.

title: Air Force Major Sentenced
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., July 17 (UPI)A courtmartial has mustered Maj. Louis F. Wailly out of the Air Force for refrauding the military and stealing Government property.

title: Head of John Jay College To Take U. of Illinois Post
description: Donald H. Riddle will leave the presidency of the City Unversity's John Jay College of Criminal Justice next January to become chancellor of the University of Illinois's Chicago Circle campus, the college announced yesterday.

title: Wheat Men Ponder Soviet Deal
description: When the Department of Agriculture confirmed yesterday that the Soviet Union had bought 3.2 million metric tons of wheat from two American grain exporters, it answered one question ?? raised a number of others vital to the trade and consumers. The news, which was followed by a Canadian Wheat Board announcement that Moscow, had bought 2 million long tons of wheat in that country, served to confirm recent reports that the Soviet Union is in the world market for grain.

title: City Cites Rising Recovery Of Padded Medicaid Bills
description: Top officials of the city's Health Department said yesterday that while there still was a fraud in Medicaid they were recouping more mispayments than in the past and that they were doing the best they could with a staff limited by the fiscal crisis.

title: MOBIL ITALY GIFTS PUT AT $2MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 17The Mobil Oil Corporation disclosed today that it had made contributions averaging more than $500,000 a year from 1970 through 1973 to Italian political parties and had disguised the payments on its books.

title: SYRIANS CONSULTING CAIRO ON U.N. FORCE
