description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. July 17Syria has been in close consultation with Egypt since Cairo's threat not to extend the mandate of the United Nations Emergency Force in Sinai beyond July 24, Arab diplomats said here today.

title: Ribicoff Bids I.R.S. Speed Inquiry Into A.M.A. Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Senator Abraham Ribicoff asked the Internal Revenue Service today to make an immediate investigation of possible tax violations by the American Medical Association.

title: CITY MAY ALTER INSPECTION SETUP
description: The city's Department of Buildings, with 45 of its 270 inspectors and 15 other employes charged with graft, is planning to seek authoriaztion to give builders the option to hire their own inspectors.

title: Market Place
description: Jay B. Leonard is a tall, outgoing man who wears aviator glasses and works as the research specialist covering foods and beverages for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. When he talks about a foodprocessing company, he's apt to whip out a package for frozen pizza covered with salami slices.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world sold prices. Thursday.

title: Maye Upsets Vizzini in the Runoff For Presidency of Firemen's Union
description: Michael J. Maye scored an upset victory here over Richard J. Vizzini yesterday in a runoff election to become the new president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association as all Your of the union's top officers went down to defeat.

title: Architecture of Paris: New Vista Is Narrow
description: PARISWhen skyscrapers began to edge their way into Paris a few years ago, there was a predictable outcry. Paris is being destroyed, said the preservationists, and they foresaw that the City of Light would be indistinguishable from Manhattan in no time. Enough has gone up in Paris to make the city ripe for reevaluation, and the outcome is not quite what one might have expected.

title: Hornig Quits as Brown U. Head Amid Rising Financial Problems
description: PROVIDENCE. R. L. July 17 The president of Brown University, Donald F. Hornig, announced his resignation today.

title: Laotian Government Stiffens Rules for Foreign Newsmen
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 17 (UPI)The Communistdominated Laotian Government took its first major step against the foreign press today, banning a Thai newspaper and setting up stiffer entrance requirements for newsmen.

title: $1BILLION SAVING
description: Mayor Beame proposed yesterday to the city's highest elected officials and its municipal union hierarchy more than $1billion worth of economy optionsincluding a wage freeze, the layoffs of 27,500 additional city workers and a 10 per cent acrosstheboard salary cut for all city employes as a way to restore the city's credibility nationally and avert insolvency.

title: OIL DRILLING SLATED OFF SANTA BARBARA
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 18 (AP)  Atlantic Richfield has been granted a permit to drill 17 new oil wells in the Santa Barbara Channel, the first new drilling in the waterway since a 1969 oil spill blackened beaches and killed wildlife.

title: Braves Triumph, 43, Despite 15 Mets' Hits
description: Those weren't AllStars backing Jon Matlack last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Closing Checkpoint Gives Youths Access to Tijuana
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., July 18 The bawdy temptations of Tijuana and Mexico's tourista border zone were thrown wide open to swarms of vacationing American youths yesterday when a juvenile checkpoint here was closed down after 17 years of operation.

title: Imports and Food Subsidies Strain Egypt's Finances
description: CAIRO, July 18After the issue of war or peace with Israel, the greatest single problem facing President Anwar elSadat is money.

title: Israel Reports 3 Arabs Killed at Border
description: TEL AVIV, July 18The military command said today that Israeli troops had killed three Arab infiltrators from Lebanon, blocking an attempt to seize hostages in the frontier area.

title: Elder Leads Trevino by One Stroke With 67135 That Includes an Eagle
House Reverses Itself to Allow Integration of Sexes in Schools
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The House reversed itself today and voted to allow the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to integrate by sex hysical education classes and honorary societies in federally aided schools and colleges.

title: . . . Let the SandwichMaker Take Note
description: Summer season of canoes, watermelons, hammocks, beach umbrellas, honeysuckle, country roads, corn on the cob, swimming holes, romance in the moonlight. And food poisoning.

title: BID BY MRS. PERON FOR LEAVE HINTED
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 18Reports that President Isabel Martinez de Peron was seeking temporarily to leave the country flooded the capital today as Argentina's economic and political crisis deepened.

title: Joseph McCarthy Weds Mrs. Wilson
description: Annabelle d'Arche Wilson of New York widow of Webster Hill Wilson, was married here yesterday afternoon to Joseph Paul McCarthy of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Frederick Hill performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Thud Drills, Not Glory, Mark Day in Life of Jets' Linemen
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 18 They call it the thud drill, presumably because that is the sound helmets make when they collide.

title: MOODY'S DELAYS RATING OF NOTES
description: Mayor Beame's willingness to consider a broad package of economies for New York City appears to have forestalled, at least for the moment, action by a financial rating service that would have been another serious blow to the city's standing in the financial community.

title: ROTHSCHILD BANK IN TAKEOVER DEAL
description: Amex International, Ltd, the American Express Company's banking subsidiary in London said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Rothschild International Bank, Ltd., by purchasing all of its issued share capital. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed but as of September, 1974, the Rothschild Intercontinental Bank had a capital base of $47.31million and total assets of $835.2million.

title: Market Place
description: The movement of the prime rate has again become a critical factor for the stock market, which often goes down when the banks' basic lending charge goes up.

title: U.S. COAL EXPORIS INCREASE BY 27.9%
description: Americanbased coal companies exported 27.5 per cent more coal from the United States during the first five months of 1975 than during the comparable period last Year.

title: U.S. Consumer Protection Unit Approved by House Panel, 3010
description: WASHINGTON. July 18 (AP) The House Government Oper ations Committee approved bill today that would create an independent Federal agency to give consumers a voice in government decision  making. The vote was 30 to 10.

title: CLERK ADMITS GIVING F.B.I. FILES TO DIGILIO
description: NEWARK, July 18(UPI)A former clerktypist for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that she smuggled secret files on John DiGilio, a reputed Mafia enfoorcer, out of the office by stuffing them into her purse and girdle.

title: Summary of City's Cutback Plans
description: The economies being considered by Mayor Beame and city fiscal experts are tentative and the details of how much they might save and how they might be put into effect are still vague.

title: Church Doubts Plot Links to Presidents
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 Senator Frank Church said today that the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence had thus far found no hard evidence linking any former Presidents to alleged attempts by the Central Intelligence Agency to assassinate foreign heads of state.

title: ASTRONAUTS SAY THEIR GOODBYS; PARTING IS TODAY
description: HOUSTON, July 18The astronauts of Apollo and Soyuz visited each other's spacecraft twice today, sharing meals and speaking of friendship and further cooperation, and then closed the hatches on the first international meeting in space.

title: Kallinger Ordered to Be Extradited to Hackensack
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 18Judge William W. Caldwell of the Dauphin County Court of Common Pleas ordered today that Joseph Kallinger be extradited to New Jersey for trial on charges of murdering a 21 yearold practical nurse in Leo nia last January.

title: Report Deepens Mystery on Northrop Consultant
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 18The mystery about the activities of one of Northrop's highly paid European consultants was intensified by a special report filed this week by the company's executive committee with the Securities and Exchange Commission in a Los Angeles Federal court.

title: Mistrial In Forbes Case
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 18A mistrial was declared today in the case of Dave Forbes, the Boston Bruins' hockey player, when the jury announced it could not reach a verdict.

title: The Poppy Whose Sap
description: WASHINGTON  The deadly red opium poppies of Turkey are again in full bloomlegally.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Crocker National Bank confirmed yesterday that it expects its net loan chargeoffs this year to reach $43million. The disclosure was made in a preliminary prospectus for a Crocker stock offering.

title: DANIEL MOORE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP) Daniel Moore, a specialist in education and former head of The Los Angeles Times's education services department, died here yesterday. Fie was 51 years old.

title: Army Seeks 1,500 to Check Aftereffects of LSD Tests
description: WASHINGTON July 13 (AP) The Army said tonight that it would try to find nearly 1,500 persons who were subjects of LSD experiments it conducted in the nineteenfifties and nineteensixties and have them undergo medical evaluation to determine whether there have been any aftereffects.

title: 7BANK DEAL ASKED BY BANK OF NEW YORK
description: The Bank of New York Company proposed yesterday ta merge seven member banks into the Bank of New York when the new state law permitting statewide branching becomes effective next Jan. 1.

title: A Flying Apple in '73 Is Seed for Suit in '75
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 18, (UPI)A New Jersey woman who was hit by an apple core thrown from a moving school bus has filed suit because the fruit hit her in the mouth, causing her to suffer great pain and extensive medical bills.

title: Floods Hit Northeast Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 (Reuters)Torrential rains today flooded the usually droughtridden northeastern region of Brazil and snow fell in the south. In Recife. the Capibaribe River flooded residential districts. There were no reports of casualties.

title: Poor of Hartford Invited to Share Kennedys' Beach
description: HYANNISPORT, Mass., July 18An interracial group of children and adults seeking support for a program to get summer vacations for city children of poor families won a sympathetic hearing at the Kennedy compound here.

title: People in Sports
description: A delayed induction into the Black Athlete's Hall of Fame was held for Joe Frazier, the former world heavyweight champion, at the Americana Hotel yesterday. Frazier, unable to attend the formal ceremonies in Las Vegas's Caesars Palace in March, was presented his Hall of Fame plaque and ring by Charlie Mays, the executive director of the Hall. Frazier is the eighth boxer among the 44 inductees.

title: Stage: Part Two of Inge Love Death
description: Seeing The Love Death Plays of William Ingethe second part of this series of six oneact plays opened Thursday at the Billy Munk Theaterone is reminded of the fact that Mr. Inge's death was a loss not only to the American theater, but also, specifically, to the American actor and actress.

title: Bridge:
description: Following the conclusion of a major pair championship, there is usually a period of confusion. For an hour or so hundreds of players mill around the playing area, waiting nervously for the scores and discussing hands.

title: 2 UNION LEADERS CHARGE FLIMFLAM
description: Two of the city's municipal union leaders characterized Mayor Beame and First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh as flimflam men yesterday and outlined a fourpoint plan they said would save the city $300million.

title: SCIENTISTS ASSAY TESTS ON MONKEYS
description: DAVIS, Calif., July 18Scientists at the California Primate Research Center here have reported the results of three longterm experiments using monkeys as models in a search for better understanding of human health problems.

title: Furniture for Wooing and Winning!
description: For every 10,000 people who would like to own an original drawing by Watteau (and wouldn't actually turn down the offer of Fragonard's Fete at SaintCloud), how many have heard of Bernard Van Risen Burgh 2d? One, at most. Yet B.V.R.B. (as he signed himself) was an artist of the first rank. His work speaks out for a particular moment in French historythe seventeenfiftieswith an ideal eloquence. Looking at it, we sense instinctively for what manner of human beings he worked. His art is their monument, and we shall not get one as good.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JULY 19, 1975

title: African Unity Group Admits 4 New Nations
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 18 (Reuters)The Organization of African Unity today admitted four new nationsMozambique, Cage Verde, Sao Tome and Principe, and the Comoro Islandsraising its membership from 42 to 46.

title: 32,000 Old Bridges Are Termed Unsafe
description: RUSHSYLVANIA, Ohio, July 18Since the days of Henry Ford I, the inhabitants of the American countryside have depended on tens of thousands of little onelane bridges to get them across countless creeks and rivers. to tie their communities together, and to link those communities to the larger world.

title: A Home Is a Home for 34 at Towers Fighting Ouster From the Dingy Hotel
description: George Roulez, one of 34 tenants remaining at the West Side Towers after it was cleared of a hardcore criminal element, lives in a tiny, filthencrusted room. And although Mr. Roulez says he has not been living, but rather just existing for the last 22 years in the singleroom occupancy hotel at 230 West 76th Street, he, like most of the other tenants, opposes a court decision of last Wednesday that ruled that they would have to leave because of hazardous electrical conditions there.

title: Most Buses and Trains Aided by State Expected to Continue Service Monday
description: TRENTON, July 18State Transportation Department officials said today that most bus and rail service subsidized by state funds would continue operations through Monday even though the subsidies cut by the Governor have not been fully restored.

title: Laos Bans Bangkok Paper
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 18 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Bangkok Post has been banned in Vientiane for publishing inexact and misleading reports about Laos, it was reported here today.

title: Youth Electrocuted in Boat
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me., July 18 (UPI)  Robert Cobb, 17 years old, was electrocuted when his sailboat's aluminum mast touched a 7,200volt power line yesterday, officials said. The police said Mr. Cobb lived in Belgrade Lakes and Princeton. N.J.

title: SALES OF GRAINS DEPRESS PRICES
description: Brisk selling by farmers of wheat, corn and soybeans to grain elevators and the movement of the commodities into major grain terminals helped depress prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. There was also substantial selling attributed to disappointment over lack of confirmation of further sales of wheat or corn to the Soviet Union.

title: Books of The Times
description: Not everybody understood Mary Wigman, the virtual inventor of the German modern dance. She knows what she is doing but I can't figure it out, Albert Einstein was reported to have told a California paper in 1932 during a Wigman tour of the United States. The quotation, presumably, was apocryphal. Like all innovative a artists, the late Mary wigman was an object of ridicule and the apparent obscureness of her somber rituals made it easier to mock than to appreciate her new kind of dancing in the nineteentwenties and thirties.

title: DRILLING FOR GAS OFFSHORE URGED
description: Representatives of public uti lities and business spokesmen, fearing a naturalgas supply crisis next winter, urged a Congressional committee yesterday to concentrate on expediting exploration and development of the Outer Continental Shelf in the Atlantic Ocean from Nantucket to Maryland.

title: Files Record the Pinkertons' Greatest Triumphs
description: Pinkerton's the oldest and largest private security company in America, hardly ever chases desperadoes anymore, although it still keeps files on the desperadoes it once did. Pinkerton's does not do this because it is sentimental; it does it because of history. The desperadoes' names have come down through the years.

title: Astronauts Will Produce An Artificial Solar Eclipse
description: HOUSTON, July 18  The Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft, in periods when they are separated, are scheduled to perform tomorrow two experiments designed to take advantage of two craft circling the earth in formation.

title: ... Labor's Role ...
description: Locally, the biggest remaining obstacle to a credible selfhelp effort is the attitude of municipal employes and their unions. Ignoring fiscal realities, union leaders have stubbornly insisted that their members are entitled not only to job security but to all the extraordinarily generous benefits they have extracted from compliant politicians during more than a decade of municipal mismanagement.

title: M.A.C. in Trouble, Too
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, the giant that was created five short weeks ago to rescue New York City from the unthinkable specter of default, is now in need of rescue itself. Its first issue of $1billion in bonds, floated 18 days ago, is still $50million short of being sold out. Its second round of $1billion, even now in preparation, is said to be unmarketable under current conditions. And there is still a third $1billion issue to come, to raise cash that the city  unable to borrow on its own  needs by September.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIBANK RAISES PRIME TO 7%
description: The First National City Bank of New York, the nation's second largest bank, after the Bank of America, raised its prime lending rate yesterday for the third time this month and again found itself virtually alone with the highest basic lending charge in the nation.

title: CAREY COOL TO AID
description: Governor Carey considers talk of a special legislative session on the city's renewed fiscal problem premature and counterproductive and intends to press for Mayor Beame to have the city stand on its own feet without another prop from the state, according to key aides in his office.

title: 9,000Acre Brush fire Is Overcome in California
description: WARNER SPRINGS, Calif., July 18 (UPI)  Firefighters overcame today a fivedayold brush fire that scorched almost 9,000 acres of desert brush land, threatened rare wild. sheep and may have killed some wild Hereford's in Hellhole Canyon.

title: POLYGLOT BABBLE FLOODS AIR WAVES
description: HOUSTON, July 18To a listener at the Johnson Space Center here, a surprise of the Apollo Soyuz test project has been the babble of intermingled Russian and English that floods the elaborate communications network linking the two spacecraft and their control centers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Officials of the Civil Service Employes Association, representing 115,000 state workers, postponed until today a decision on whether to carry out their threat to strike against state agencies and institutions beginning Monday. The officials said that fewer than half the mail strike ballots had been returned by yesterday's deadline, with the votes for and against a strike running very close.

title: ARTS MONEY VETO UPHELD BY COURT
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 18Federal District Judge Hugh J. Bownes ruled today that Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. and his executive council enjoyed discretionary authority to block Federal arts money for a poetry magazine.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Hospital Employes Stage Protest on Budget Cuts
description: Sitins, begun earlier this week, continued early today at the Health and Hospitals Corporation offices at 93 Worth Street and at Morrisania Hospital, 168th Street and Gerard Avenue in the Bronx, to protest proposed budget cuts in hospitals services.

title: GARBAGE PICKUPS TO BE IN CUT IN HALF
description: Garbage pickups will be cut in half in the city's most congested areas and street sweeping on secondary arteries will virtually come to an end as a result of the economy layoff of 1,434 sanitationmen yesterday, Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh said.

title: Tim Moore and Judith Cohen Sing Here
description: Two pop singers appearing in Manhattan clubs both show unusual promise without yet fully realizing that promise.

title: Beame Lists the 32 Appointed Officials Being Ousted
description: Mayor Beame yesterday made public the names of 32 appointed officials to be discharged in response to economy demands by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: Envoy to Africa Retiring
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) President Ford announced today he has accepted the resignation of William N. Dale, Ambassador to the Central African Republic since 1973. He is retiring from the Foreign Service.

title: 10 STATES CALLED LAX ON MEDICAID
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Ten states could lose up to $47million in Medicaid funds beginning in August for not complying with a 1972 law requiring states to monitor Medicaid programs adequately.

title: Space Events Scheduled For U.S.Soviet Flights
description: The Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft are scheduled to undock today, redock a second time to test the mechanisms again, and then undock permanently, ending the joint phase of the international space mission.

title: Beame Lists the 32 Appointed Officials Being Ousted
description: Mayor Beame yesterday made public the names of 32 appointed officials to be discharged in response to economy demands by the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: GARBAGE PICKUPS TO BE CUT IN HALF
description: Garbage pickups will be cut in half in the city's most congested areas and street sweeping on secondary arteries will virtually come to an end as a result of the economy layoff of 1,434 sanitationmen yesterday, Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh said.

title: Separating American Messages
description: The Commission on the Organization of the Government for the Conduct of Foreign Policy, appointed by the Congress and the President, issued its report on July I. Among its many recommendations, a section on the American overseas informational and cultural programs endorses the findings of an independent nongovernment panel.

title: MISS LITTLE ASKS CASE BE DROPPED
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 18 (UPI) Defense attorneys requested today that murder charges against Joan Little, a 21yearold black woman, be dismissed on the ground that lie detector tests had borne out her story that she killed a white jailer while fighting off a rape attempt.

title: CAREY COOL TO AID
description: Governor Carey considers talk of a special legislative session on the city's renewed fiscal problem premature and counterproductive and intends to press for Mayor Beame to have the city stand on its own feet without another prop from the state, according to key aides in his office.

title: Edwin Roos Marries Miss Peluchova Here
description: Milena Peluchova, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Peluchova of Prague, was married here yesterday to Edwin G. Roos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Roos of Rockville Centre, L.I. Acting State Supreme Justice Louis Kaplan performed the ecremony at the Plaza.

title: Medical McCarthyism
description: That Medicaidthe program of governmentallypaid medical care for the poorhas been subjected to widespread corruption and abuse is an unfortunate but wellknown fact. What is needed is a systematic policing of the Medicaid operation so that wrongdoing by both patients and providers will be discouraged by the certainty of being caught.

title: Ann Medina Is Married in Toronto
description: Ann Hillyer Medina, who has been named a network producer for special events for CBSTV, Toronto, was married in Toronto yesterday afternoon to John Howard David McGaw, a network producer of documentaries for CTV, Toronto. The Rev. Catherine Cook of the First Unitarian Church of Toronto performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Drugs Whose Flowers
description: To all our other troubles, add one morea crisis in the discovery of valuable and needed new drugs.

title: 23 Food Businesses Named as Violators Of City Health Code
Angered Portuguese in a Farming Town Turn on Communists
description: LISBON, July 18  The aroused people of the little farming town of Rio Maior have driven the Communist party virtually underground, displaying the same reaction to Communist advances that has been noted in Lisbon and other parts of Portugal.

title: NICHOLAS LoBUGLIO
description: Nicholas LoBuglio, retired secretary of the city's Sanitation Department and a former president of the department's Columbia Association, died Wednesday at his home in slushing, Queens. His age was 75.

title: Daniel Brodsky Weds Estrellita Bograd
description: Estrellita Bograd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Miguel Bograd of Caracas, Venezuela, and New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Daniel Brodsky of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs, Nathan Brodsky of New York and Morristown, N. J. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

title: Anderson Golf Marked By Upsets
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 18Pete Bostwick Jr. and James Bostwick of Meadow Brook, the defending champions, and Mark McBride and Jay Johnston of Stanford University Golf Club, the medalists, were defeated today in the first round of the 39th Anderson Memorial Golf Tournament. The fourball invitation event at Winged Foot always has some of the nation's finest amateur golfers and seldom runs to form.

title: Church Doubts Plot Links to Presidents
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Senator Frank Church said today that the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence bad thus far found no hard evidence linking any former Presidents to alleged attempts by the Central Intelligence Agency to assassinate foreign heads of state.

title: CONTRACT RATIFIED BY FARM WORKERS
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 (UPI)  Rankandfile farm workers in California and Arizona today ratified by a 4 to 1 margin a threeyear contract with the Western Growers Association.

title: PRICES IRREGULAR ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market closed mixed yesterday.

title: Sakharov Says Moscow Relents on Wife's Visa
description: MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters)Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, said today that his wife, Yelena, had received permission to go to Italy for treatment of an eye condition she feared could make her blind.

title: HELEN HENNESSY, 59, AN N.E.A. COLUMNIST
description: Helen Hennessy, women's editor of the Newspaper Enterprise Association, a syndicate serving newspapers throughout the United States and abroad, died of a liver ailment Thursday evening in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived at 77 Seventh Avenue.

title: British Inflation Rate Up To Record 26.1% in June
description: LONDON, July 18Inflation, which has begun to abate in most major industrial countries, rose to still another record M Britain last month, the Government reported today.

title: REFUGEE PROGRAM IS BEING EXPANDED
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) The United States resettlement program for Asian refugees is being expanded to include Laotians and an additional 7,000 to 9,000 Cambodians and Vietnamese.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The column headings in the report of company earnings in The New York Times on Thursday were transposed. The lefthand column should have read 1975 and the righthand column 1974.

title: ExC.I.A. Employe Took LSD as a Guinea Pig
description: A former employe of the Central Intelligence Agency says that he reluctantly agreed to serve as a guinea pig in agency experiments with LSD because he was made to feel it was expected of you.

title: Pennsylvania Strike Terms Reached
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 18 (AP)A tentative agreement to end an 18day strike by state unemployment and welfare workers was reached early today, Gov. Milton J. Shapp said.

title: CANADA TIGHTENS INVESTING SCREEN
description: OTTAWA, July 18New foreign investments in Canada will be screened by a Government board beginning Oct. 15 to insure that the proposed enterprise is of significant benefit to the country.

title: All Italian Industries Said to Aid Parties
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Vincenzo Cazzaniga, a central figure in recent disclosures concerning payments by American oil companies to Italian political parties, said today thatin one way or anotherall major industries in Italy, and the American companies in those industries; made. political payments.

title: Investigator With Wit
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 Not many members of the House of Representatives can claim to have killed a bill on the House floor with a single humorous speech. But there was Representa tative Otis Grey Pike standing in the well of the House floor a couple years ago, ridiculing a pending bill giving flight pay to deskbound admirals and generals.

title: Greenwich and Airport Reach Accord on Noise
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 18  The Town of Greenwich agreed here this morning to drop its $20million noisepollution suit against nearby Westchester County Airport in return for an agreement to negotiate a reduction in noise from the airport, which is the New York metropolitan area's third busiest.

title: JUDGE GIVES UNION MINORITIES' PLAN
description: A local sheetmetal workers union was ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to increase the number of nonwhites in the union and its apprentice program from about 4 per cent at present to 29 per cent within six years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The column headings in the report of company earnings in The New York Times on Thursday were transposed. The lefthand column should have read 1975 and the righthand column 1974.

title: 2 UNION LEADERS CHARGE FLIMFLAM
description: Two of the city's municipal union leaders characterized Mayor Beame and First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh as flimflam men yesterday and outlined a fourpoint plan they said would save the city $300million.

title: Forego Is Favored In Suburban Today
description: All that Forego needs to reach the $1million plateau in thoroughbred horse racing is to run the Suburban Handicap at Bemont Park today. If the overnight betting line is correct, the 5yearold gelding, owned by the Lazy F Ranch, is as good as there.

title: M.A.C. in Trouble, Too
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, the giant that was created five short weeks ago to rescue New York City from the unthinkable specter of default, is now in need of rescue itself. Its first issue of $1billion in bonds, floated 18 days ago, is still $50million short of being sold out. Its second round of $1billion, even now in preparation, is said to be unmarketable under current conditions. And there is still a third $1billion issue to come, to raise cash that the city unable to borrow on its own needs by September.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Opposes Change in U.N.'s Mideast Stand
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The State Department said today that the United States would oppose any revisions in United Nations Security Council resolutions dealing with the Middle East to speed a renewal of the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sinai.

title: INQUIRY PROMPTED BY DEATH OF PONY
description: One pony was found dead and another was ordered shot yesterday at riding stables inside Steeplechase Park in Coney Island that health officials described as filthy and hazardous.

title: RATE RISES GRANTED TO 2 AUTO INSURERS
description: TRENTON, July 18 (UPI)The New Jersey Insurance Department granted rate increases today on auto premiums for the Hartford and the Travelers companies.

title: European Security Conference Confirms July 30 Helsinki Date
description: GENEVA, Saturday, July 19 (Reuters)The 35nation European security conference confirmed early today that it will conclude its two years of intermittent meetings at a summitlevel session in Helsinki. Finland, beginning on July 30.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Superior Court judge in Woodbury denied motions to dismiss attempted bribery charges against James Joyce, Democratic chairman in Camden County. Superior Court Judge Philip A. Gruccio denied the motions by Mr. Joyce's attorney, Thomas Higgins, and ordered Mr. Joyce to stand trial on the charges Sept. 8. Mr. Higgins argued that there was inadequate evidence to substantiate the charge that Mr. Joyce had sought a $75,000 bribe, and that the state's case was based on the uncorroborated testimony of one witness. The indictments charged that Mr. Joyce allegedly attempted to solicit a $.100,000 bribe and later a $75,000 bribe from Mario Iavicoli, an attorney for the firm of John J. Reutter Associates, which is involved in a civil suit against the Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority. Mr. Joyce is vice chairman of the authority.

title: RevenueSharing Director Will Leave Position Aug. 2
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Graham W. Watt today resigned as Director of the Office of Revenue Sharing, effective Aug. 2. The announcement was made by Treasury Secretary, William E. Simon.

title: Soviet Crew's Wives' Anonymity Ends
description: MOSCOW, July 18 (AP)Svetlana Leonov was sitting tensely in front of the television set, waiting to watch her husband hurtle into space, when the telephone rang.

title: In Embattled Beirut, Nerves Are Taut and the Future Is Uncertain
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 A distraught woman tells a radio moderator that every time she hears a car backfire at night she thinks the fighting has started again. I almost have a nervous breakdown, she says.

title: ROBERT T. CRANE JR.
description: Robert T. Crane Jr., a former New York lawyer and more recently an associate of the law firm of Truscott & Erisman of Philadelphia, died Wednesday at his home in Gladwyne, Pa. His age was 65.

title: Maude McCarthy Bride of T. R. Tomai
description: St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Louisville, Ky., was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Maude McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McCarthy of Louisville, to Timothy Robert Tomai of Hawthorne, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Tomai Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Joseph I. Mouser performed the ceremony.

title: ASTRONAUTS SAY THEIR GOODBYS; PARTING IS TODAY
description: HOUSTON, July 18The astronauts of Apollo and Soyuz visited each other's spacecraft twice today, sharing meals and speaking of friendship and further cooperation, and then closed the hatches on the first international meeting in space.

title: Local Resistance Deters Flood Control in Jersey
description: TRENTON, July 17  New Jersey has been hit by major floods at least five times since 1968, and, according to state disastercontrol officials, the destruction has run into the hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: ApolloSoyaz Cocktail Is Concocted in London
description: LONDON, July 18 (UPI) Joe Gilmore, head barman at the Savoy Hotel, announced today the creation of a cocktail in honor of the ApolloSoyuz space flight. He said the drink, called the Link Up, is made of equal parts of Southern Comfort and Russian vodka with a teaspoon of fresh lime juice shaken well with ice.

title: FLOOD POSSIBILITY CROWING IN STATE
description: TRENTON, July 17  New Jersey has been hit by major floods at least five times since 1968, and, according to state disastercontrol officials, the destruction has run into the hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: WHEAT DEAL SEES GOLD SALES SPUR
description: PARIS, July 18Purchase of American wheat by the Soviet Union raises prospects of further large Soviet gold sales in the West to help cover the cost.

title: Erik Sjoqvist, 72, Archeologist Who Found Ancient City, Dies
description: Dr. Erik Sjqvist, the archeologist who discovered the ancient Greek city of Morgantina on a Sicilian mountaintop, died Wednesday in Drottningholm, Sweden. He had marked his 72d birthday Tuesday.

title: Paul Nickel, Ballet Soloist, A Nutcracker Prince at 13
description: Paul Nickel, a ballet soloist who at the age of 13 was the first to perform the role of the Nutcracker Prince in George Balanchine's 1954 version of The Nutcracker, died here June 24. He was 34 years old and lived here.

title: STRIKE IS AVERTED ON NATION'S RAILS
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Railroad and union negotiators averted a nationwide rail strike today by agreeing suddenly on what the union president called a most satisfactory labor contract.

title: Summary of City's Cutback Ideas
description: The economies being considered by Mayor Beame and city fiscal experts are tentative and the details of how much they might save and how they might be put into effect are still vague.

title: Polo Now Woos Bourgeois
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 18The question was once asked of Terence Preece, When does a man give up polo? Preece, a sixgoal man in his prime, answered: When he runs out of money.

title: O.A.S. Split Over Timing of Cuba Vote
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 18Fifteen of the 24 members of the Organization of American States are prepared to support a resolution lifting the hemisphere grouping's embargo against Cuba, the Foreign Minister of Costa Rica said today.

title: On Order on Kennecott Kennecott Copper Oredr
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has said that it sees no reason for the commission to review its controversial order to the Kennecott Copper Company that it divest itself of the Peabody Coal Company, the nation's largest coal producer.

title: BID BY MRS PERON FOR LEAVE HINTED
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 18Reports that President Isabel Martinez de Pern was seeking temporarily to leave the country flooded the capital today as Argentina's economic and political crisis deepened:

title: Ford Moderates Coyote Poison Ban
description: WASHINGTON, July 18President Ford issued an executive order today that moderates a threeyearold ban on the use of toxic chemicals to kill coyotes and other predators on Federal lands.

title: Congressional Dilemma
description: Speaker Carl Albert did well to appoint Representative Otis G. Pike of New York to head the House of Representatives' revised Select Committee on Intelligence. He is a middleoftheroad Congressman who has never allowed his concern for national security to cloud his perception of excesses in the executive branch. The question is whether the House did well to reconstitute the committee at all instead of trying to merge it with its Senate counterpart in a joint panel for keeping watch on the country's intelligence agencies.

title: Some Warning Hints On Preserving Foods
description: The United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following recommendations for safe canning:

title: At Simplicity, Pattern Is Still OneMan Rule
description: The short tenure of Mary Joan Glynn in the presidency of the Simplicity Pattern Company may have surprised some corners of the business world but not those familiar with the background of the company or its founder.

title: PORTUGAL ALERTS FORCES AS FEARS OF A COUP SPREAD
description: LISBON, July 18Portugal's military forces were put on full alert today as the conflict between the Communist Party and its rivals began to move into the streets amid reports of a possible coup.

title: Helsinki Meeting
description: The 35nation European security conference formally decided to hold its summitlevel final session in Helsinki, Finland, July 30. A compromise on the issue of troop maneuvers cleared the way. Detatils on Page 3.

title: Bonn Plans Projects to Spur Economy
description: BONN, July 18The West German Government, faced by a continuing recession, plans to start a $2billion program of public works this fall.

title: Buckley War Chest Far Exceeds Prospective Foes'
description: WASHINGTON  Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, who is planning to seek reelection next year, has far outstripped two prospective opponents in fund  raising. His campaign organization, Friends of Jim Buckley, has told the Secretary of the Senate in its latest report that it raised $183,464 this year while spending $166; 096. Last year it collected $55,105 and spent $29,487.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ART IN ACTION There is indication of some lively musical activity tonight in the downtown and midtown areas.

title: PORTUGAL ALERTS FORCES AS FEARS OF A COUP SPREAD
description: LISBON, July 18Portugal's military forces were put on full alert today as the conflict between the Communist Party and its rivals began to move into the streets amid reports of a possible coup.

title: Rumania Hard Hit by Floods
description: GENEVA, July 18 (Reuters)Twentyfour of Rumania's 39 provinces have been severely affected by floods and torrential rains, a Red Cross official reported here.

title: About the Jets...
description: Earlie Thomas will not report with the majority of veterans today. He was traded yesterday to the Buffalo Bills for a draft choice. The 29yearold cornerback, perhaps the only entomologist in the National Football League, had played five seasons here. The Jets' media guide probably explains why Thomas was dealt: Known as outstanding oneonone coverage man, but has had trouble with zone defenses. The Jets are using more zone defenses. . . . An usually high number of regulars turned up for yesterday's workouts. They included John Riggins, who was unsigned in his option year; Steve Tannen, Richard Caster and Al Woodall.

title: HENRY W. STOCK
description: MAIDEN BRIDGE, N. Y., July 18 (AP)Henry W. Stock, former general manager of The Albany Knickerbocker News and a retired Navy commander, died yesterday at his home here. He was 76 years old.

title: Stefan A. Sopkin, a Violinist And Teacher, Is Dead at 75
description: Stefan A. Sopkin, a concert violinist and teacher, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospita after a series of strokes. He was 75 years old and lived, at 365 West End Avenue.

title: Nixon Gives Aid at Auto Wreck Scene
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 18 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon happened upon an auto accident here and spent an hour directing unsuccessful efforts to save the lives of three marines, his soninlaw Edward F. Cox said today.

title: MANILA GROUNDS, THEN FREES U.S. JET
description: MANILA, July 18The Philippine Government released early this afternoon a United Air Lines DC8 charter plane that it grounded for 15 hours for alleged violation of air space.

title: Appeal by National Gypsum Set in PriceFixing Case
description: BUFFALO, July 18 (AP)The National Gypsum Company said today it would appeal the conviction of the company and two of its executives on charges of conspiring to fix prices.

title: Ballet: A Tudor, at Last
description: It has been a long time since Antony Tudor offered the world a new work. His very last ballet was Knight Errant for Britain's Royal Ballet in 1968. His last new ballet for American Ballet Theaterthe home base for this Britishborn choreographerwas, even more remarkably, Nimbus. created in 1950. Ballet Theater, which happily still maintains a practically complete collection of the Tudor masterpieces, has thus patiently waited a quarter of a century for its principal choreographer to produce a new work. It was quite a hatching, and quite an act of patience.

title: $1BILLION SAVING
description: Mayor Beame proposed yesterday to the city's highest elected officials and its municipal union hierarchy more than $1billion worth of economy optionsincluding a wage freeze, the layoffs of 27,500 additional city workers and a 10 per cent acrosstheboard salary cut for all city employes as a way to restore the city's credibility nationally and avert insolvency.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday.

title: Jersey Assembly Restores $189Million, But Senate Leader Says It Is Not Enough
description: TRENTON, Saturday, July 19 The State Assembly, in a lengthy session lasting into early this morning, passed bill restoring $189million of the $384million cut from the current state budget by Governor Byrne, and then began discussion on tax bills to finance the restored appropriations.

title: Bailing Out Big Mac ...
description: Only last month, the State Legislature created the Municipal Assistance Corporation Big Macto bail out a nearbankrupt New York City. Today the question is, how to bail out Big Mac?

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Retrial Ends in Conviction
description: SPOKANE, Wash., July 18 (UPI)  Ricky Anthony Young, 23 years old, was found guilty last night of first degree murder for having mailed a pipe bomb that killed Judge James Lawless of Pasco on June 3, 1974. It was the second trial for Mr. Young on the charge. The first trial ended in a hung jury last October.

title: LowProfile Common Market Talks Have Proved Effective in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, July 18  The heads of government of the nine Common Market countries met in Brussels this week to discuss their economic and political problems. But, competing for headlines with the United StatesSoviet space linkup, the Portuguese Government change and the climax of the year's biggest cycling race in France, they were virtually neglected by the European public they govern.

title: FORD'S OIL PROPOSAL SET FOR HOUSE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for a House vote next Tuesday on President Ford's plan to allow the price of domestic oil to rise.

title: Commodity Agency Authorizes Trading Under the New Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Commodity Futures Trading Commission formally authorized today continued trading in 46 futures contracts on 10 commodity exchanges that had previously been unregulated.

title: Environmental Success
description: One of the outstanding accomplishments of the legislative session that ended last week is a package of environmental bills that will powerfully reinforce efforts of New Yorkers to protect the state's air, water and other natural resources.

title: Dance Company Association Elects Gingrich President
description: The board of the Association of American Dance Companies, whose honorary chairman is Betty Ford, has announced the election of John Gingrich as its president. He will succeed Adam Pinsker, who became president in April, 1970, and has now resigned.

title: 2 Women Share 2Shot Lead
description: NORTHFIELD, N.J., July 18 Nancy Lopez, a plump 18yearold amateur golfer who still is not sure what it's like to choke, and Sandra Post, a veteran of seven years on the professional tour, shared a twostroke lead today after the second round of the United States Women's Open.

title: ... and Washington's
description: Since selfhelp alone may still not be enough to save the state corporation at this late date, both city and state must look once more to that court of last resort, the Federal Government. Big Mac director Felix G. Rohatyn proposed to a Congressional committee last month a system of Federal insurance for municipal bonds which, he said, would assure their marketability and substantially reduce interest rates. Mr. Rohatyn suggested that, in order to qualify for such insurance, municipalities should be required to adopt basic budgetary reforms.

title: Townsend Back in Camp; Athas Near Giants' Pact
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 18Ricky Townsend returned to the New York Giants' training camp tonight, and Pete Athas set up a meeting here tomorrow morning to iron out details on his new contract.

title: JEAN M. GOODKIND
description: Jean Morgenthau Goodkind, a teacher of gifted children at Hunter College Elementary, School and Lincoln School in the early nineteenforties, died Thursday in Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 57 years old and lived in IrvingtononHudson. N.Y.

title: Sets Triumph, 2820, in W.T.T.
description: ST. LOUIS, July 18The New York Sets and the Los Angeles Strings met on a neutral court tonight and the Sets won, 2820, in World Team Tennis competition. The match drew 3,518 people in Kiel Auditorium.

title: Let City Gardeners Exercise Ingenuity
description: The Tar Beach image Is changing in New York, and these days the summer move to the roof has greening more often than tanning as its goal.

title: Hospital Demonstrations. Protest $10Million in Cuts
description: There were sporadic demonstrations at several hospitals yesterday as workers protested the $10million cutbacks in Programs run by the Health and Hospital Corporation.

title: BOLSHOI SHIFTS CAST FOR WAR AND PEACE
description: In the performance of Prokofiev's War and Peace by the Bolshoi Opera on Thursday night, Vladimir Malchenko took the part of Andrei and Galina Borisova the part of Helene for the first time here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Apollo and Soyuz astronauts visited each other's spaceships twice yesterday, sharing meals and speaking of friendship and further cooperation. The spaceships, which were united in orbit Thursday, were scheduled to separate at 8:04 AM., Eastern daylight time, today. They will practice one more brief docking before going their separate ways 140 miles above the earth. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: Sy Oliver Playing Lunceford Tunes
description: Sy Oliver joined the Jimmie Lunceford orchestra in 1933 and, through his arrangements, shaped the distinctive Lunceford sound: crisp, clipped trumpets, smooth, stretchedout saxophones aid an easy, propulsive twobeat. Now Mr. Oliver is using the occasion of the anniversary of Mr. Lunceford's death (July 13, 1947) for a monthlong tribute at the Rainbow Room to this celebrated band.

title: OLAF RAVNDAL
description: Olaf Ravndal, who retired as a senior vice president and director of the American Express Company in 1966, died Wednesday at Orange Memorial Hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Lake City, Fla.

title: Stock Market Finishes With 1.87 Drop in Dow
description: The third quarterpoint increase in the prime rate this month by the First National City Bank, the nation's secondlargest bank, took the steam out of yesterday's stock market. The bank raised its prime rate yesterday to 7 per cent

title: Triangular Track Meet Summaries
description: MEN'S EVENTS

title: British M.P. Who Vanished Returns to Face Charges
description: LONDON, July 18John Stonehouse returned to London today, closing a chapter in the bizarre story of the British Member of Parliament who disappeared in Miami Beach last year and was arrested in Australia where he had turned up under an assumed name.

title: Notes on People
description: The Order of Lenin, the highest honor in the Soviet Union, was presented yesterday to Mikhail A. Sholokhov, author of the Nobel prizewinning novel, And Quiet Flows the Don, to mark his 70th birthday.

title: Rail Loss $10Million
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., which operates more than 23,100 miles of railroad, reported yesterday a $10.3million loss for the quarter to June 30. For the first half, the company had a loss of $4.3million, after a $3.6milion accounting credit.

title: Red Sox Joining Other Division Runaways
description: The major league owners set up divisional playoffs in 1969, hoping to create closeraces throughput the season and, not incidentally, to earn larger gate receipts.

title: Rangers Set Back Yanks, 10
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 18  For perhaps 10 minutes after the game tonight, the only noise in the Yankee clubhouse was the scraping sound of a pink tub full of ice being dragged across the floor by Catfish Hunter.

title: A Little Advice On Roof Gardens
description: The New York City Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance makes the following suggestions in regard to apartment house roof gardens:

title: 9 to Start Rich Trot Tonight
description: YONKERS, July 18With Mrs. Stanley Dancer's Surefire Hanover expected to go postward as the favorite, the $200,000 Yonkers Trot; the first jewel in trotting's triple crown, will be featured tomorrow night in the closing program of Yonkers Raceway's 54night meeting.

title: Lisbon's Shrinking Nest Egg
description: LISBON  Portugal's revolution, whose ultimate course remains unclear, was historically both prompted and financed by the rightwing, armysupported dictatorship created by Antonio de Oliveira Salazar. The revolution has so far succeeded only in creating a leftwing military dictatorship.

title: Shapp to Join Democratic Race in Fall
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Democratic Presidential field, already crowded with a halfdozen early entries, gained still another contender today as Gov. Milton J. Snapp of Pennsylvania announced that he would become an active candiate.

title: Inquiry in Honduras Uncovers Death of 7
description: TEGUCIAGALPA, Honduras, July 18The Government announced today the discovery of seven bodies, including those of two priests who had been missing since the army clashed last month with 12,000 peasants demanding land.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY VOTES ADDED FUND
description: TRENTON, July 18  The State Assembly passed a bill this evening restoring $189million of the $384million cut from the current state budget by Governor Byrne and then began discussion on tax bills to finance the restored appropriations.

title: Canada Tightens Rules
description: Canada's Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce announced yesterday in Ottawa that new foreign investments will be screened by a Government hoard beginning Oct. 15 to insure that the proposed enterprise iF of significant benefit to the country. Page 33.

title: DUTCHESS COUNTY IS HIT BY STRIKE
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 18Almost 1,000 civil service employes of Dutchess County went on strike here today in a wage dispute. But before the day was out a judge issued an order directing union officers to send the employes back to work.

title: Brazil Train Toll Put at 11; Derailing Laid to Speeding
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 (Reuters)Brazil's State Railway Board said today that 11 people were killed and 219 injured in last night's train crash in a suburb of this city.

title: Mountain Air Flow Used In Generation of Power
description: WASHINGTON, July 18A powergenerating system invented for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Burbank, Calif., is designed to make use of a large volume of air flowing down a mountainside. Patent 3,894,393, assigned to the company by Phillip R. Carlson, an engineer, envisions the construction of a tunnel with a diameter from 100 to 1,000 feet and length between 5,000 and 10,000 feet. A large volume of water must be accessible, so that quantities can be pumped to the open upper end of the tunnel at the mountaintop. The aeroelectric stystem, as planned, provides for a spray to be directed at the air in the tunnel top.

title: Jones Disobeys Berra; Mets Huddle
description: The Met are at a loss over what to Go with Cleon Jones, their frustrated outfielder. Last night, Jones, who has been in and out of the Mets' lineup for two seasons with an injured left knee, pinchhit in the seventh inning against the Atlanta Braves. After swinging meekly at pitch and lining softly to the shortstop, he stomped back to the dugout, threw his helmet and bat and refused take the field when Manager Yogi Berra asked him to play left field.

title: Golliwogg Is Victor at Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18The fourth day of senior racing at Larchmont Race Week drew 119 onedesign craft and 60 cruising boats. The winds were light to moderate but the competition was hot enough among the cruising boats to produce three protests.

title: Roosevelt Hotel Robbed By 3 of $7,000 Cash
description: At the height of the noontime lunch hour yesterday, three armed men slipped quietly into, the cashier's office of the Roosevelt Hotel, at Madison Avenue and 45th Street, and stole $7,000 in cash. Scores of guests in the crowded hotel lobby were unaware of the theft.

title: GEN. IVAN F. KHALIPOV
description: MOSCOW July 18 (UPI)Lieut. Col. Gen Ivan F. Khalipov, deputy head of the political board of the Soviet Army and Navy, died Tuesday at the age of 61 after a serious illness, the Communist party newspaper Pravda said today.

title: PETER BRIGGS, 54, WROTE OCEAN BOOKS
description: Peter Briggs, author of more than a dozen books concerned with oceanography and the forces of nature died Thursday of cancer in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 240 East 35th Street.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Try Again For a Strip Mine Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)  A Senate committee has voted to try one more time to get a strip mine control bill enacted, despite two vetoes of the legislation by President Ford.

title: People and Business
description: Despite disagreement by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, Carla A. Hills, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, insisted yesterday that, even with the 5 per cent decline in housing starts in June, recovery was under way in the housing industry.

title: ExFord Aide Sues Over Alcoholism
description: DETROIT, July 18 (UPI)A 56yearold former Ford Motor Company executive has sued the No. 2 automaker for $1.3million, contending his job turned him into a alcoholic who was forced into premature retirement.

title: Mayor Is a Little Brusque but He Is Bearing Up
description: Before yesterday morning's meeting at Gracie Mansion, Mayor Beame invited the conferees to have coffee and Danish.

title: Amex Is Embarking on a 5Year Expansion Program
description: Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, disclosed in an interview yesterday that the Amex was embarking ona fiveyear program to expand its facilitiesincluding the possibility of double: decking its 5story trading floor.

title: Wooers of Convention Count Their Chickens
description: When officials in charge of selecting the site for next year's Democratic National Convention let it be known a few days ago that there was a definite tilt toward New York City; news, of their inclination cheered the city officials and businessmen who have been working for months to lure the gathering.

title: Profit for June
In Memoriam
description: DRUCKHarry, July 19, 1972 Forever, in loving memory.

title: So. Africa Trails, 20, In Davis Cup
description: South Africa, the Davis Cup defender beleaguered in international sports because of her racial policies, was one match away from elimination in the tennis competition yesterday.

title: American Men Take Lead in Track Meet
description: DURHAM, N.C., July 18 (AP)Walter Schmidt of West Germany threw the 16pound hammer 249 feet 7 inches today in the United StatesPan AfricanWest Germany track meet. Schmidt's throw is the longest recorded in the Western Hemisphere.

title: 2 in Salyut Eavesdrop On Colleagues in Space
description: MOSCOW, July 18, (Reuters)The Soviet and American space crews at present locked in earth orbit have a pair of enthusiastic eavesdroppers  the astronauts aboard the Soviet Salyut4 space station.

title: As Tomatoes Ripen, and Picnics Are a Summer Way of Life...
description: With millions of Americans who never before wielded a hoe now harvesting homegrown foods and canning them for yearround consumption, the nation is experiencing a sudden increase in outbreaks of botulism, a deadly form of food poisoning.

title: Speaking Freely
description: The recent Federal court test of New York State's Fair Campaign Code provided a clash of two strong but competing citizens' interests: the interest in fair, clean elections on the one side and the interest in free and untrammeled competition of ideas on the other. A threejudge Federal court decided, correctly in our view, that the interest in the free clash of ideas as protected by the First Amendment prevailed. Accordingly, it struck down portions of the New York code.

title: This Recipe Yields Three Suspects
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 18Yorktown detectives appeared today to have solved the Great Cupcake Caper alter a neighborhood youngster reported that he had sampled a piece of evidence.

title: Hanoi Tells Banker It Is Willing to Trade With U.S.
description: HONG KONG, July 18An official of America's biggest bank has visited Hanoi at the invitation of the. North Vietnamese Chamber of Commerce and discussed possible trade between the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Files Record the Pinkertons' Greatest Triumphs
description: Pinkerton's the oldest and largest private security company in America, hardly ever chases desperadoes anymore, although it still keeps files on the desperadoes it once did. Pinkerton's does not do this because it is sentimental; it does it because of history. The desperadoes' names have come down through the years.

title: SENATE CALLS UP VOTING RIGHT BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)  Senate Democratic leaders, facing a bitter dispute with Southern legislators, unexpectedly called up the Housepassed voting rights bill for action today and immediately filed a petition to shut off any attempt to filibuster it.

title: A Time for Miracles
description: Unless baseball's runaway pennant races tighten up, hometown fans by the millions may need a psychiatrist before the end of July.

title: French Jobless Rate Rises In a Month It Usually Falls
description: PARIS, July 18For the first time in 27 years, unemployment in France rose instead of falling during the month of June, and now stands at almost 900,000, an estimated 4.5 per cent of the labor force, according to figures made public by the Ministry of Labor.

title: Five Timber Companies Fined for Rigging Bid Prices
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July, 18The Champion International Corporation and four other timber companies were fined a total of $105,000 today on their conviction of rigging bid prices in Federal timber sales.

title: Philip T. Dalsimer, 62, Dies; Senior Law Partner Here
description: Philip T. Dalsimer, a senior partner in the New. York law firm of Kane. Dalsimer. Kane. Sullivan & Kurucz, died yesterday afternoon. He was 62 Years old and lived at 860 United Nations Plaza and in Southampton. L.I.

title: The Zulu Kings
description: One of the great black leaders of recorded African history was Shaka, the creator of the Zulu nation in the southeast of the continent. Coming to power in 1817, this tall, handsome, talented monarch from an insignificant clan forged a domain of some 11,500 square miles with a fighting force of up to 40.000 disciplined war?? imposed a single language and nurtured a remarkable prosperity among the disparate chiefdoms over which he reigned supreme until his assassination in 1828.

title: Man Seized in Plot to Hire His Brother to Slay Woman
description: A 29yearold father of four is under arrest in Fairview, N. J., on charges of trying to hire his brother to slay a woman while she was on a weekly shopping trip in Hackensack.

title: Namath Enjoys His Camp
description: DUDLEY, Mass. Surrounded by rolling hills, clear lakes and a few hundred screeching youngsters, Country Joe Namath lopes easily here while a half  hour's plane ride away his New York Jets teammates report to training camp.

title: Judge Quits Tax Case
description: CHICAGO, July 19 (AP)Citing personal friendship with the defendant, Federal District Court Judge Abraham L. Marovitz has declined to hear the tax fraud trial of Ralph G. Newman, who is charged with conspiracy in backdating Richard M. Nixon's Presidential papers. Mr. Newman, president of the Chicago Library Board, was indicted Feb. 19 in Washington by the Watergate grand jury

title: Sunday Observer
description: The nineteenseventies are boring. The decade is already half over and its chief legacy is an engulfing swamp of boredom. Americans are bored by Watergate, bored by Richard Nixon and bored by the endless tale of skulduggery in the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and the I.R.S.

title: Donna Lee Kennah Wed to James Quinn
description: Donna Lee Kennah, a representative for Pan American, World Airways, was married here yesterday afternoon to James C. Quinn of New York, who is on the English faculty of Sleepy Hollow High School in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Peter J. Murray performed the ceremony in the St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church here.

title: The Vigor And Sumptuousness Of Arab Art
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.

title: Boardwalk Games Losing Their Punch
description: Feeling the Pinch

title: Food News
description: SUMMITThe head Italian pastry baker at the Summit Bakery cannot speak a word of English. What is more, he will not even divulge his secret Neopolitan recipes to his boss, Jerry Natale.

title: The Region
description: New York district attorneys, who usually agree on legal policy, are divided in their attitude toward recently approved legislation that eases the state's stringent drug law.

title: Layoffs Keeping Pace With Jobs
description: The number of Nassau and Suffolk County residents on payrolls increased in May but so did the number of residents who had lost their jobs on Long Island and elsewhere in the New York metropolitan area.

title: With South Vietnam Markets Cut Off, Drug Smugglers Turn to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 19 In the aftermath of the Indochina war, Thailand has become the production and distribution center of a drastically revised international trade in narcotics.

title: 3 Share Women's Golf Lead
description: NORTHFIELD, N. J., July 19The third round of the United States Women's Open ended this afternoon in one of the tightest bunchings in recent years, with three players sharing first place and another three tied one stroke behind.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It hasn't happened yet, but the way the world is going It may be something to be anticipated in the near future. Charles Templeton and Ted Willis think soTempleton in THE KIDNAPPING OF THE PRESIDENT (Simon and Schuster, $7.95) and Willis in WESTMINSTER ONE (Putnam's $7.95). Templeton's title tells what his book is all about. Willis ploughs the same field on the other side of the ocean; his book has to do with the kidnapping of the Prime Minister.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Hartford police arrested two men on charges of shooting an offduty detective when he chased the suspects out of a bar after they stole $500. Linwood Hick's and Bradley Bell were charged with attempted murder and firstdegree robbery. Willard Fullard, the detective, is in satisfactory condition, suffering a shoulder wound.

title: Wilt: Good Time for a Bad Idea
description: When I read that my embattled New York Knickerbockers are negotiating with such an impossible individualist as Wilt (The Stilt) Chamberlain, it struck me as incongruous a prospect as Gerald Ford as President seemed at the second Nixon inauguration. Wilt just didn't belong with the KnicksWilt the enforcer, Wilt the coach's nightmare; Wilt the standaround flagpolemessing up the finest and most subtle basketball machine in the history of the sport.

title: Church in Philippines Split Over Role in a Developing Society Under Martial Law
description: MANILA, July 19The Ro man Catholic Church here is engaged in a bitter controversy over the role it should play in a developing society under martial law.

title: The World
description: The chances for an orderly transition to independence for Angola have diminished following new battles between two of the black nationalist groups competing for dominance.

title: Ford to Veto Bills to Control Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 19President Ford announced today that he would veto Congressional legislation to extend price controls on domestic oil and roll back current oil prices.

title: New & Novel
description: He loved me enough to steal me, reflects the narrator about his father. But why did Buck Hansen need to abduct his son to demonstrate his love? For the answer to this we hark back to the summer of 1946, when the narrator was 9 and his father was 50, divorced and down on his luck.

title: Organic Farms Pound Efficient
description: ST. LOUIS, July 18Research scientist here have found that a test group of organic farmers who used no inorganic fertilizers or synthetic pesticides made as much money last year as did a comparable group of conventional farmers who used those substances.

title: Tax and Budget Problems Now a Political Issue
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's tax and budget problems should stop being a crisis this week and turn, instead, into a political issue.

title: London Denies Bail To Returned M.P.
description: LONDON, July 19A London magistrate denied bail today to John Stonehouse and ordered the member of Parliament and former Labor Government minister imprisoned until July 28,

title: Bass River's Secession Gains
description: BASS RIVER TOWNSHIP  The movement for this township's secession from Burlington County advanced last week with a prod from Burlington County itself.

title: A.H.S.A. Is Upheld by Courts In Its Suspension of Dennehy
description: Wilson Dennehy, a jumper rider from Denver, has been suspended for three months by the American Horse Shows Association after a yearlong legal dispute that reached the New. York State Supreme Court. It all started at a benefit for the United States Equestrian Team in Denver on June 20, 1974. Two other exhibitors, F. J. Arend ?? and Cynthia N. Gray, complained that they had seen Dennehy use an electrical device while he was schooling his mount, Orpheus. This is prohibited under A.H.S.A. rules. The show committee after hearing the complaint, found Dennehy not guilty. But Arend and Miss Gray appealed the decision to the A.H.S.A.'s Zone 8 hearing committee, which then looked into the case. The hearing, committee agreed with the complainants.

title: PartyBoat Fishing Beset by Scarcity
description: MONTAUK  Partyboat fishing is still a popular sport along the South Shore of Long Island from Sheepshead Bay to Montauk, but because the fish are getting harder to find a number of fishingboat skippers are converting to larger and faster boats.

title: Ann C. Butler Married to Richard Guest
description: Ann Christine Butler, daughter of Dr. Robert N. Butler of Washington and Diane McLaughlin Butler of Colorado Springs, was married, yesterday morning to Richard Mark Guest. He is a on of Rear Mm. Frank B. Guest Jr., U.S.N.R., commandant of the Third Naval District, and Mrs. Guest of Brooklyn.

title: WRITER IN SOVIET STIRS A DISPUTE
description: MOSCOW, July 19A lively controversy has sprung up around the recent anniversary issue of a popular Soviet youth magazine, Yunost, providing intellectuals here with one of the most entertaining litersry squabbles in recent years.

title: The Carpathian Caper
description: Within the past decade the British not only invented Mary Quant but also came up with the descriptive phrase a good read. This latter was and is intended to draw the distinction between the kind of novel one takes out to the hammock on a summer's day along with a crock of sangria and the kind that gets solemn reviews in Britain's Times Literary Supplement as an entrant in the Powerful and Enduring class. To cut it even finer, as the jacket copy on comparative texts often demonstrates, a writer provides us with a good read, while an author produces a powerful and enduring work. Exactly where this leaves a sometimes writer and sometimes author like Graham Greene is a can of worms that the Nobel Prize Committee on Literature has been nervously sitting on for a long time now.

title: Forstadts Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born July 4 in New York Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Forstadt of New York. The child has been named Erica Beth. Mrs. Forstadt is the former Sally Beckerman of Philadelphia. Her husband is a lawyer with the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.

title: 3 Penn Central Cars Derailed Near Stratford; No Injuries
description: Three Penn Central passenger cars derailed near Stratford, Conn., yesterday morning but none of the 125 passengers aboard were injured, according to a spokesman for the railroad.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The fivestory building at SO East 42d Street, on Park Avenue directly south of Grand Central Station, has been leased from Wellington Associates, of which Sol Goldman is a principal, by a company that plans to create in the structure a suburbanstyle shopping mall.

title: India Gets More LowPrice State Stores
description: HYDERABAD, India, July 16 The templedotted countryside around this former princely capital is to be embellished at Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's request with 200 lowpriced stores called superbazaars.

title: The Great Toozy Takeover
description: The Good Old Days. They fall in and out of favor with the same rapidity as Henry VIII's wivesfor reasons as diversedepending primarily on how confused, impoyerished, or threatened we feel at a given time. During the sixties the Good Old Days were high camp; during the forties, bunk; during the thirties, they were anytime but the presentnot excluding the Inquisition. And now? Amid the rude realities of the seventies, are the simpler ways of this century's first two decades relevant, remarkable, of any lasting value in dealing with our present problems and psychoses?

title: Brookdale Clinic Offers Counseling On Career
description: LINCROFTThose people who cannot decide what career to pursue can be pointed in the right direction by a new counseling service at Brookdale Community College.

title: Watergate Assurances
description: A House subcommittee has voted to ask Special Watergate Prosecutor Henry Ruth Jr. to come before a closed session to give a status report on his workan idea that seems both appropriate and useful, without in any way impugning Mr. Ruth's integrity.

title: Sports In America: Baseball, Democracy, Prizes and the Rat Race
description: Changesometimes violent, sometimes insidious, sometimes welcomed, sometimes resistedhas been the key process of the twentieth century. No where has it done its work more thoroughly than in the United States. Any thing new has been so automatically admired that the very word itself has come to be almost synonymous with better. This has led to a widely held view that Americans do not give a fig for tradition, that they will gleefully trample all over it merely for the sake of doing something differently.

title: Miss MacMillan To Wed Aug. 23
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ladd MacMillan of Duxbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ladd MacMillan, to Walter Whitman Arensberg, son of Mrs. Simon E. Bourgin of Washington and of waiter Eveleth Arensberg of Pittsburgh and Montevideo, Uruguay.

title: The science of sight is progressing, but still dimly understood:
description: In 1951, when Gen. Douglas MacArthur delivered his famous old soldiers never die speech to Congress, he astounded his listeners by removing his glasses to read the manuscript Many Congressmen remembered this bit of heroics longer than the contents of the speech. What better proof that this 71yearold general was not fading away! Perhaps notbut MacArthur's eyesight certainly was. Ophthalmologists who watched the event on television recognized one of the early signs of cataractsa sudden improvement of near vision in old age.

title: Why Ashe Won and Connors Won, Too
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Landmark Panel Is Considering 3 Brooklyn Sites
description: Two historically rich waterfront sites a mile apart in Brooklyn will be considered for landmarks designation on Tuesday at a public hearing before the Landmarks Preservation Commission at City Hall.

title: Nassau's Youngest Planner
description: MINEOLAAt the age of 18, Charles John Jordan Jr. is probably the youngest person in the country to ever have been named to a panel to plan for a constitutional form of municipal government.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CAMDEN, N. J., July 19Jim Dietz of the New York A. C., recovering from virus pneumonia, easily qualified today for the semifinals of the lite heavyweight singles in the world championship rowing trials on the Cooper River. Two of Dietz's major challengers, Neil Halleen of the University of Wisconsin and Bill Stout of Long Beach, Calif., wound up in the same heat but were outdistanced by last year's silver medal winner.

title: Vacancies in Supermarkets On Rise in Nation
description: The for rent sign is going up in supermarkets across the country, giving rise to problems for neighboring merchants, inconvenience for shoppers, new opportunities for independent operators and, perhaps, fresh approaches to food retailing.

title: A.M.A. Joined Drug Makers in '70 Drive to Kill Bill Setting Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The American Medical Association several years ago joined the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in a secret, successful drive to kill a bill aimed at reducing the costs of drugs, according to confidential A.M.A. documents.

title: Welfare Recipient Abortion
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 19 (AP)United States District Court Judge Hugh Bownes ordered the State of New Hampshire Wednesday to pay for an abortion for a welfare recipient. Judge Bownes also called for a threejudge panel to consider whether the state's regulation against such payments is constitutional.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Mickey Mantle, on how he misses baseball: I have a nightmare almost every night. I'm on the bench and they won't let me play. The young guys are a lot better than I am. Then if I do get in, say in the late innings, I hit a line drive to right field. I'm running like hell to get to first and I get thrown out. You know what I do? I wake up sweating.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Once upon a time the New York Mets were a baseball team good for laughs, win or lose. In their infancy, it was mostly lose. Their original manager, Casey Stengel, labeled them My Amazin' Mets and the world laughed., At them. In those years Casey Stengel often wondered, Can't anybody here play this game? He meant can't anybody play it well; he knew they were playing it badly. And in their childhood, when Gil Hodges took charge, the Mets were truly amazin' in winning the 1969 World Series, and the world laughed again. With them this time. The world laughed briefly in 1973 when they, almost won the World Series again with Yogi Berra as manager. But nobody laughs much about the Mets now. As teenager, the franchise is sophisticated, spoiled and smug, the way some rich kids are. It's not a coincidence. In recent years the Mets have been the rich kids in town while the old Yankee franchise made do with welfare checks. But now the Yankees, as if reincarnated, are trying to make things happen while the Mets sit back in their corporate pose. Too serious, too conservative, too quiet. Too unamazin'.

title: Apollo Begins Busy Round Of Solar and Cell Studies
