description: HOUSTON, July 19  The Apollo astronauts, their Joint flight with Soyuz concluded, began today to operate their spacecraft as a combined observatory and laboratory, as they are scheduled to do until shortly before splashing down in then Pacific Thursday afternoon.

title: Woman Auto Racer Deeds Some Luck
description: Long before Shirley Muldowney pulled up irr a hot rod, took off her helmet and proclaimed in a recent television commercial, All my men wear English Leather, she was known as the top woman hotrod driver in the country. But more people seem to recognize Miss Muldowney, who is the National Hot Rod Association's only licensed woman driver, from what she says on the commercial than from what she has done on the drag strip. It just goes to prove the power of television, said Miss Muldowney, who was among the top contenders last week in the N.H.R.A. Summemationals in Englishtown, N. J. Maybe now, more people will concentrate on my efforts as a driver. That was the purpose of my doing the commercial in the first place.

title: Northwest and Pilots Accord Barely Averts a Walkout
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 19 (UPI) Northwest Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association agreed to a new contract early today, averting a strike just as Northwest's more than 1,550 pilots took to the picket line.

title: DR. DAN CHRISTIE, 59, BOWDOIN PROFESSOR
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., July 19  Dr. Dan E. Christie, Wing Professor of Mathematics at Bowdoin College, died yesterday while cutting the lawn at his home. He was 59 years old.

title: Pointers on Repairing Window Screens
description: Window screens do get lots of exposure and hard wear, so they will periodically need some kind of maintenance or repair. These repairs will fall into one of two broad categories  repairs to the screen frame and repairs to (or replacement of) the screen wire or mesh.

title: The Nation/Continued
description: During the last few months, President Ford on at least five occasions has attempted to bundle the conflicting pressures exerted by industry, labor and the affected public into a single votegetting package. His aim has been to reverse the 88yearold trend of more inclusive Government regulation, in order, as the President sees it, to generate more competition while protecting the pocketbook, health and safety of the American consumer.

title: Stony Brook Resisted on Sewer Link
description: SETAUKETIf members of the Strong's Neck Civic Assocation have their way, the new Health Science Center at the State University of Stony Brook will not open next month.

title: Papers Director to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) John S. Prescott Jr., a director of the Washington Post Company and president of its newspaper division, will leave his job Sept. 1. Mr. Prescott said he was investigating some offers within the newspaper industry, as well as the prospect of going into a business of my own.

title: Show Time on the Palisades
description: CLIFFSIDE PARKProfessional theater has come to this borough in the form of performances of a new play, a revival and an evening of cabaret theater. The setting is the Palisadium, an elaborate recreational and entertainment complex attached to Winston Towers, a condominium  apartment development overlooking the Hudson.

title: Soviet Plans Census in 1979
description: MOSCOW, July 19. (UPI)The Soviet Union will conduct a population census in 1979, the first in nine years, the Moscow radio has reported. The latest interim count of Soviet citizens, made public last Jan. 1, was 253.3 million, up 2.4 million over the previous year.

title: MAIL UNIONS SEEK TO AVOID A STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Postal union leaders said today that they would be willing to extend the contract to avoid a mail strike if satisfacory progress was made in negotiations before the deadline of midnight tomorrow.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JULY 20, 1975

title: Marx's Daughters
description: Someone else will have to write the book Ronald Florence tells us he set out to writean examination of the way the Socialist movement in the late19th and early20th centuries dealt with its women leaders. Were they to be treated as men'? Or should they be accorded special status...?

title: Midsummer
description: Dusk comes a few minutes earlier now, and sunrise a few minutes later, than they did a month ago. Summer divides the 24hour day to its own dimensions, and off there in the distance, a few hills away, lies autumn. Change, the eternal constant, subtly chapes days.

title: Pentagon Challenges Navy On  SuperCarrier Future
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Defense Department, in what could develop into a major policy. controversy within the Pentagon, is challenging the Navy's plans to build a fleet of 12 nuclear  powered super  carriers at a cost of tens of billions of dollars.

title: Wallace Cancels F.L.U. Talk; Opposition of Blacks Hinted
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 19 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace, of Alabama, saying he did not want to contribute to, or cause any discord, has canceled plans to address delegates at the International Longshoremen's Union convention.

title: $10Million Rent Subsidies Set Aside
description: The Federal Government is reserving more than $10million in annual rent subsidies for use in nine housing projects in Brooklyn and one in queens.

title: Of Things To Come
description: John Brunner specializes in a subgenre of science fiction that might be called sliceoffuturelife. Where most S.F. authors are content to sketch in a futuristic background with a few technological wonders, some aliens or mutants, and perhaps a cultural break through of two, Brunner writes about the future as if he and the reader were already living in it.

title: Virginia F. Orzac Plans Nuptials
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. Orzac of Hewlett Harbor, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Fleiss Orzac, to Solomon Secemsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Secemsky of Chicago.

title: When in Rome...
description: There can be little doubt that big business has fallen to a low level in public esteem. A recent Gallup poll shows that big business came in last, in terms of the degree of confidence it inspired, among all institutions comprising what is sometimes called the United Stats power structure; at the top of the list were organized religion and education with scores of 68 per cent and 67 per cent resnectively and at the bottom were big (organized) labor with 38 per cent and big business with 34 per cent. Business's loss public respect has been precipitate in recent years; in 1965, 55 per cent of those interviewed in a Harris poli expressed confidence in businesscompared with 18 per cent in 1975.

title: Even as Amended, It's the Toughest in the United States
description: The goal of Governor Rockefeller in 1973 was nothingless than to eliminate drug abuse. Faced with a growing crime problem, sensing a more conservative political atmosphere and feeling that the state had tried every possible approach to stop addiction without success, the Governor argued that only increased penalties for pushers would stop the flow of drugs and reduce crime. He asked the Legislature to establish mandatory life prison terms for all drug pushers, whether they were largescale traffickers or smalltime operators.

title: Ann Wilson Is Bride of Randy Wilson
description: Ann Marie Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Wilson 3d of Ridgefieldr Conn., and Brownsville, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to Henry Randolph Wilson Jr., son of Comdr. Henry R. Wilson, U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. Wilson of Ridgefield. The families are not related.

title: I'm O.K. Means Elderly Are All Right
description: TEANECK  The signs read: I'm O.K.However, behind the doors on which they hang at the Dr. Norman Cotton housing complex in Paterson, a development known as the Graham Avenue apartments, are stories of fear, pathos and security involving the elderly.

title: Dace: A Rare Giselle
description: There are many reasons why Giselle, a ballet that had its premiere in 1841 at the Paris Opra, has survived in the international repertory. As Natalia Makarova proved again in the tine role or American Banet Theater's production Friday night at the New York State Theater, the ballet is a superb vehicle for a ballerina, and its very ability to survive is almost wholly dependent upon that ballerina.

title: Floating Through the Bachyard of France at Four Miles an Hour
description: A WORLD in slow motion: Floating softly into focus, dissolving gently from view ... a dream ... an illusion. This Is the world of lickyard France, as seen from its waterways. Along some 3,000 miles of canals linking 25,000 miles of rivers, rented craft ranging from luxury barges to inexpensive driveityourself cruisers make it possible for the foreign visitor to experience a different France.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have recently purchased a new home with what appears to be natural wood cedar shingles on the outside. I have noticed that on some houses these shingles turn very dark after a few years. People tell me this is caused by some kind of fungus, but I would like to preserve mine, as light as possible, and in the natural state. Do you know what I can do before the wood gets too dark to do anything?P. S. S., Perth Amboy, N. J.

title: Crochet: Not Just Doilies and Lace
description: During the part six or seven years, crochet has been transformed from a favorite of grandma to a quicktodo rewarding activity for young as well as old, and for men as well as women.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: CHARLES L. STEEGAR

title: The Ballet: Do Svidaniya
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., July 19Tomorrow night the Bolshoi Ballet leaves New York on its homeward trip to Moscow after a threemonth crosscountry tour that opened April 22 at the Metropolitan Opera House. The Bolshoi's performing schedule finished here at the Garden State Arts Center today with a program of divertissements in the afternoon, and Natalya Bezmertnova and Mikhail Lavrovsky in Giselle in the evening.

title: In California, Sellers Hold Open House
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. They say no one walk's in this expensive residential enclave surrounded by the city of Los Angeles. It's so quiet, they say, that you can hear a palm leaf drop.

title: Soviet Union Diver Leads Qualifiers
description: CALI, Colombia, July 19 (AP)Irina Kalinina of the Soviet Union and Christine Loock and Carrie Irish, two Americans, led eight qualifiers today into the final of the women's springboard diving competition at the World aquatic championshins.

title: Encounter: Beware of Greeks Bearing the Best of Intentions
description: IT was spring and we were in Greece, driving to Salonika. The road we traveled was being resurfaced; when we saw a crossroad ahead, which seemed to offer an escape from our bumpy route, I stopped the car and my husband and I studies the map.

title: Schedule for Space Events
description: Following is a summary of Apollo Soyuz mission highlights

title: An Unclear Law
description: WASHINGTONDespite revelations that the Central Intelligence Agency has inspired coups and assassination plots, Congress still has not come to grips with the problem of overseeing the agency's covert operations abroad. Legislators still find themselves caught between a belief in the protective value of covert operations and a conviction that this kind of protection could endanger democratic processes at home.

title: CARLOS EPISODE AROUSES FRENCH
description: PARIS, July 19France's counterintelligence agency has aroused a storm of public recrimination for letting slip the suspected terrorist known as Carlos, now the object of a worldwide hunt.

title: Protest Bombing In San Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, July 19 (Reuters)A bomb exploded in the center of the capital of El Salvador today, apparently in protest against the Miss Universe finals to be held here in a few hours.

title: ART VIEW
description: There is always something disconcerting in the spectacle of immensely sophisticated technology, which artists sometimes call scienceserving as the vehicle for some perfectly trivial conception. Depending on the character of the result, such discrepancies between means and ends tend to induce either laughter or anger orwhat may come to the same thinga woeful sense of wasted opportunity. In art, if not always in life, we expect method and medium to bear some meaningful or intelligent relation to an accomplished, result. There is a difference, after all, between the laboratory and the exhibition gallery between, as Picasso once put it, seeking and finding.

title: Cinda P. Savage Plans Marriage For September
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Tristram Savage of Lawrence, LI., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cinda Priscilla Savage, to Frederick Hadley Campbell ad son of Dr. and Mrs. Campbell Jr. of Sandston, Va. A September wedding is planned.

title: Picture Credits
description: 9THE NEW YORK TIMES/GEORGE TAMES

title: Migrant Case Resumes Aug. 4
description: NEWARKThe issue of whether Assemblyman Byron M. Baer and other migrantfarm reformers had a right to make an unannounced visit to the Rosario Sorbello & Sons farm near Swedesboro last July 16 will be met headon in a new trial scheduled for Aug. 4.

title: Deborah B. Hinckley Is Fiancee Of David Theodore Berghorst
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Frederic Hinckley of Riverside, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Burnham Hinckley, to David Theodore Berghorst of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Ofen Berghorst of Cadillac, Mich.

title: PLAN ON DUMPING IN SOUND SCORED
description: DARIEN, Conn.  A hotly contested plan to dredge 250,000 cubic yards of mud from the bottom of the Hutchinson River near Coop City in the Bronx and dump it in Long Island Sound near here this fall will probably be abandoned, the United States Army C??ps of Engineers indicated ast week.

title: How Fast a Recovery, and What's a Safe Speed?
description: WASHINGTONThe funny thing about recessions is that they always end. They did even before the economists began to use modern devices of Government stimulus for a sliding economy, but now they probably end sooner because of these devices, mainly big Federal budget deficits. In any case, the distressing 197475 decline in the economy is no exception; it has evidently come to an end, leaving the wreckage of a 9 per cent unemployment rate in its wake.

title: The Butterfield exchange
description: On recent afternoons, Alexander P. Butterfield has been sitting for his portrait. Sixfoottwo, lean, tanned, he is at 49 an attractive subject, with a certain pensive quality about the eyes that makes his flyboy good looks the more interesting. The portrait will hang in a Government hall, memorializing his service as head of the Federal Aviation Administration, the job from which he has been fired, perhaps the crowning irony in the career of a man hailed as a Watergate hero two years ago. If he had not accepted H. R. Haldeman's offer to join Richard Nixon's White House staff in 1969, he might today be Major General Butterfield rather than a maligned displaced person in Gerald Ford's Washingtonand his Commander in Chief might not be Gerald Ford.

title: STAMPS
description: This is the peak time for issues from countries depicting the splendors of nature, the glories of the past, the comforts and diversions of the present, all intended to attract the tourist Europe, the area increasingly being shunned by the American tourist, is a good place to start on a bargain philatelic tour.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: This is a tale of two cities, one man and a hundred or so of his friends. The cities are New York and Washington, the man is Rudolf Nureyev, and his friends are American Ballet Theaterthe company for which he has just mounted Ravmonda at the New York State Theaterand the special pickup groupincluding such very special pickups as Margot Ponteyn, Paolo Bortoluzzi and Karen Kainwith which he has been dancing one of his own repertory programs for the past two weeks at Washington's John F. Kennedy Center. Next Tuesday it is back to Lincoln Center for the flying Russian, where his production of The Sleeping Beauty, starring Nureyev himself, opens the National Ballet of Canada's threeweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: British AntiInflation Plan Gets 2 Key Endorsements
description: LONDON, July 19Without much fanfare, Prime Minister Harold Wilson's plan to bring down the rate of inflation by restraining wages received two important endorsements this week.

title: Twin Brothers, Both East Side Gynecologists, Apparent Suicides
description: Identical twin brothersdoctors who shared a gynecology practice, an office and hospital facilities as well as their living quarterswere found dead in their Sutton Terrace apartment on Manhattan's East Side last Thursday, the apparent victims of a suicide pact, the police reported yesterday.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Virginia Haight To Be Wed Oct. 12
description: Mr. and Mrs. John McVickar Haight Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Thorne Haight, to Richard D. Stevenson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevenson of Lake Forest, III.

title: CONCERN SEEKING TO END PARK DEAL
description: A statecreated Corporation seeking to bow out of its obligation to build a park for the city, which it had undertaken in return for the right to sell zoning concessions to the New York Telephone Company that allowed the company to erect a more economical building.

title: Youth Killed in Police Station
description: PORTLAND. Me., July 19 (AP)James G. Shiplett's threehour spree of car and motorcycle thefts and two shootings ended early today when he was shot and killed by a patrolman in the city's police station. The authorities said the 18yearold Portland youth, who had led the police on a chase through the city, was shot in the station lobby minutes after he called headquarters threatening to kill a policeman. He entered the station brandishing a revolver, according to officials.

title: Albert Schweitzer
description: By 1913 Albert Schweitzer had become three times a doctorof philosophy, of theology, and of medicine and an expert musician. He then left Europe to found as an improvisation the famed mission hospital at Lambarn in West Africa's Gabon. When visiting medics were critical because it was primitive and not hygienic, he responded simply, All the same, it is a charming hospital!

title: President of Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 19  The oil problem is essentially political in nature and can only be overcome by the power of Government. But the United States has been unable to cope with the problem because the Nixon and Ford Administrations insist upon treating it as an economic issue that can be resolved by the natural play of market forces.

title: Contracting Firms Get More Work Overseas
description: With construction activity in the United States slow, major American subcontractors have begun an active search for work overseas. And some are finding it.

title: Money Supply: A Growing Muddle
description: WASHINGTONAlthough hardly anyone has noticed it the great and continuing theoretical muddle about monetary policy and the nation's money supply is about to become more muddled still.

title: Miss Flanagan Engaged to John Sharkey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Flanagan of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Alethea Flanagan, to John Kevin Sharkey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Sharkey of East Norwich, L.I.

title: INDIANS PLAN START OF A RADIO STATION
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 19A federally funded multicultural radio station that will broadcast news and educational programs in Indian dialects, English and Spanish will begin operation Under the supervision of the AllIndian Pueblo Council in September, Ernest L. Lovato, the council's executive director, announced this week.

title: The Bad Boy Of American Ballet
description: Fernando Bujones, the 20yearold wunderkind of the American Ballet Theater who will dance his first Prince Siegfried in Swan Lake, Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, is the kind of dancer who makes audiences gasp. He is a natural Classicist In matters of style and a cocksure pusher in matters of temperament. The chief question is whether a combination of aggressiveness and nobility are contradictory or whether they define a new and interesting dancer's personality.

title: India Union Leader Urges Secret AntiGandhi Drive
description: NEW DELHI, July 19One of India's top labor leaders has made a call for the mobilization of an underground resistance movement to overthrow what he called the fascist dictatorship of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Petty Is Set to Reach 2d Million at Pocono
description: The Aug. 3 Purolator 500 at Pocono Raceway could be a milestone in the already legendary stockcar racing career of Richard Petty. It appears that this will be the race in which Petty raises his career price earnings past the $2million mark. Petty will be the first stock car racer and only the second American driver in history after A. J. Foyt, to top that figure.

title: NEWS OF BROOKLYN, QUEENS AND LONG ISLAND
description: NEWS OF BROOKLYN, QUEENS AND LONG ISLAND

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: Pele Hurt As Cosmos Lose, 3 to 0
description: TORONTO, July 19Pel injured his left thigh tonight after he was pulled from behind early in the second half of the New York Cosmos' 30 loss to the Metros before a sellout crowd of 21,725 at Varisty Stadium.

title: Shop Talk
description: CEDAR GROVE  At the House of The Orient here, the specialties are the foods that transplanted Filipinos sometimes yearn for and a somewhat limited, but reasonably priced, selection of handcrafts from the Far East.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In What's Doing in Ontario [July 6], the dates of the Canadian National Exhibition in Toronto were transposed. The correct dates are Aug. 13 to Sept. 1.

title: Sex Manuals Issue By China Sell Fast; Favor Birth Control
description: PEKING, July 19 (Agence FrancePresse)  A series of manuals that has appeared recently in bookstores deals with contraception, sterilization of men and women and the sexual problems of teenagers.

title: Lowry Igleheart, Smith Alumna, Married to Aubrey Keach Jr.
description: Lowry Igleheait, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bridwell Igleheart of Evansville, Ind., was married there last evening to Aubrey Houston Keach Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Keach of Henderson, Ky.

title: Ida Baron Fiancee of Dr. Peter Starke
description: Ida Sue Baron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Baron of New York and Washington, and Dr. Peter Richard Starke, son of State Sunreme Court Justice George Starke and Mrs. Starke of New York, plan to be married Aug. 3 in Washington. Justice Starke and_ Rabbi Samuel Volkman of Kensington, Md., will officiate.

title: Red Smith
description: It started during the week of Royal Ascot when Vincent O'Brien saddled eight horses and saw seven of them win. Not even royalty does that at Royal Ascot, and the Wizard of Tipperary compounded his impudence by taking one major stakes with a colt that had raced only once in his life and another with a horse carrying 10 stone [140 pounds], some. thing no other winner of the event ever did.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Latest news on the $2 bill is that there is still a strong possibility it will be reintroduced as a circulating paper money denomination, but there seems to be little likelihood that it will appear as a special issue to commemorate the Bicentennial.

title: O'HaraChristie Team In Anderson Golf Final
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 19Playing as if he lived on the Winged Foot coursehe almost does18yearold J. P. O'Hara and his partner, Neil Christie, 24, of Larchmont, advanced today to the final of the Anderson Memorial fourball golf tournament with two upset victories.

title: Susan Stevens Wed to T. D. Sullivan 2d
description: Susan Stanley Stevens, deputy director of the Newark Watershed Conservation and Development Corporation, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Dennis Sullivan 2d of Newark, an aide to Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark. The Rev. Roger Sinnott of Portland, Ore., cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral here.

title: Quittmans Have Son
description: A son was born July 1 to Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Quittman of Tarrytown, N. Y. at the Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown. The child has been named Daniel Julian. Mrs. Quittman is the former Linda Trupin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Trupin of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

title: He Prefers Contemplation to Confrontation
description: WASHINGTONIn his first meeting with reporters after becoming Attorney General last February, Edward Hirsch Levi, the former president of the University of Chicago and dean of its law school, said he believed that the Department of Justice should be a thoughtful place.

title: Hackensack Comes Alive as Pace of Redevelopment Quickens
description: HACKENSACKConstruction and redevelopment, ?? by private, state and Federal funds, are mov?? a rapid pace here the ??eat of Bergen County, ?? there is probably no one more enthusiastic about the resurgence than the city's No. 1 citizen, Mayor Michael J. D'Arminio.

title: Vietnamese Rejected For 2d Time in U.S.
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., July 19 (AP)  For the second time since arriving in the United States, a prominent Vietnamese has been turned away from a place to settle his family.

title: NEW WARRANTY PLAN IS PROPOSED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Commission has proposed new rules to make copies of product warranties more available for comparison by shoppers before they purchase items.

title: City Is Planning Computer Study To Test Water Quality in Harbor
description: The city is about to embark on a massive computer study of waterquality problems in the Port of New York.

title: Morris County Rink Reopens to Public
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIPThe William G. Mennen Sports Arena on East Hanover Avenue has been reopened for general sessions, figureskating instruction and the William G. Mennen Hockey School.

title: Ellen De Gennaro Wed to E. B. Freeman
description: Ellen De Gennaro, a research librarial at Newsweek magazine, and Emory Bascom Freeman, a commercial paper buyer with the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs & Co., were married yesterday afternoon.

title: Deborah Burki, V. H. Hanson Jr. Wed in Suburb
description: St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Deborah Christen Burki, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arde Burki of New York, to Viggo Hall Hanson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hanson of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Chinese Attempting to Spur Increases in Iron and Steel
description: PEKING, July 19The Chinese leadership is worried that the iron and steel industry will not fulfill the goals of the fiveyear plan that ends this year.

title: Spy Story Along the Hudson
description: An English Connection in Haverstraw. . . . A Spy Unmasked in Tarrytown . . . . A Public Hanging in Tappan!

title: FANFANI WEIGHS VOTING SETBACK
description: ROME, July 19  Amintore Fanfani, leader of Italy's Christian Democratic party, who is under fire as a result of losses in regional elections last month, opened a meeting of his national council today with a twohour explanation of those losses. He expressed the hope that it would be satisfying.

title: Minority Groups Required In Massachusetts Projects
description: BOSTON, July 19 (AP)A program to require minimum percentages of construction workers from minority groups on all future state building projects has been announced by the administration of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Solzhenitsyn Is Berated by Yugoslavs
description: BELGRADE, July 19In an apparent gesture of sympathy toward Moscow, Yugoslavia's Communist  controlled press has denounced an article by kleksandr Solzhenitsyn as raving.

title: Article 1  No Title
Exploring the Central
description: LEBANON  For antiques dealers in Somerset and Hunterdon Counties, the development of superhighways across Central Jersey has provided both hope and severe frustration.

title: City Sanitation Trucks Vandalized in 2 Boroughs
description: About 40 sanitation trucks were vandalized yesterday in Brooklyn and Manhattan as many of the 1,434 dismissed sanitationmen picketed at various garages and depots calling on others to walk off the jobs.

title: INVESTING
description: A dozen years ago, the foodchain stocks had built up a reputation on Wall Street as defensive issues. They were regarded as conservative and steady havens for investor money.

title: If You Go ...
description: ...on a French waterways vacation, there are several ways of doing it. You may charter a specially built or converted luxury barge for a small private group, starting at about $3,000 a week.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The general run of criticism everywhere is not great, as the general run of almost anything including films, is not great. Yet why should the film critic's name be so widely known, even the name of the critic whose work you've never read?

title: Cindy Munsell Wed To John Erickson
description: Cynthia Joan Munsell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger H. Munsell of Washington Mills, N. Y., and Big Moose Lake, in the Adirondacks, was married yesterday afternoon to John Mark Erickson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Raymond Erickson of Orange, N. J.

title: NEW ENERGY TALKS ARE SEEN IN FALL
description: PARIS, July 19The green light has not been given, but from what diplomats and high government officials have been saying a formal resumption of international discussions on energy appears likely, probably this fall.

title: Last Chapter Written in '61 Murder
description: The final chapter to one of the most sensational New York murder cases of the last decade was written in Supreme Court in Manhattan last week.

title: Numbers Centers Raided
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that agents had smashed a multimillion dollar numbers racket operating from some 42 locations in 10 Los Angeles area communities and seized extensive betting records and paraphernalia and an undisclosed amount of cash in raids.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange last week, after reaching their highest level in fifteen months, finished with a loss of 8.68 points, at 862.41. The high on the Dow Jones industrial average was 881.81, the best since March 26, 1974 when it had closed at 883.68.

title: ECOLOGISTS BUY LAND IN PRAIRIE
description: A 12squaremile section of South Dakota prairieland has been acquired for $1.42million by The Nature Conservancy as a nature bank so future generations can appreciate some of the pioneer heritage of the Midwest.

title: A Great Tarin Robber Is Held for Shoplifting
description: LONDON, July 19 (AP)Ronald Edwards, convicted as one of Britain's great train robbers for a theft of nearly $7million in 1963, was charged today with shoplifting, the police said.

title: Wolff Appointed to Data Panel
description: MINEOLARepresentative Lester L. Wolff, Democrat of Kensington, L.I., has been appointed by Carl Albert, Speaker of the House, as a member of a new fiveman information committee of the House of Representatives.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pied Piper Leads His Flock in a Flatbush CleanUp and Beautification Campaign
description: When Dennis Lyden, an industrial designer, moved to his new apartment in the North Flatbush section of Brooklyn more than a year ago, he started remodeling his apartment. Then, last spring, he began to work on the outside.

title: Helicopters After The Vietnam Era
description: Many experts believed that the helicopter business, after its growth during the Vietnam era, might sink again into relative obscurity.

title: Surefire Hanover Wins Yonkers Trot
description: YONKERS, July 19Stanley Dancer, the millionaire owner, driver, trainer and breeder from New Egypt, N.J., demonstrated again tonight that when it comes to the annual presentation of the prestigious Yonkers Trot he bears close watching.

title: Exhibit in Newark a Tribute to Jersey Artist
description: NEWARKThe current exhibition in the socalled minigallery at the Newark Museum is evidence of the tribute that the museum pays to New Jersey artists. Now on view there are paintings by Robert Anderson of Morris Plains.

title: Madame Catherine
description: A tourist in France learns of Catherine de Medici in the pleasantest possible way. Standing in the gardens of Chenonceaux perhaps after a light lunch and a local bottle of wine from the Loire Valley, one observes the gallery arches over the Cher River and learns from the Michelin guide that Catherine de Medici lost no time, after the accidental death of her husband Henri II; in turning out Diane de Poitiers, the King's and the chateau's mistress, presumably still dressed in her eternal black and white. The tone of the recounting, as I recall it, is lighthearted, a tale of one scorned woman's revenge over another, the better loved. The rest of Catherine's career is more sketchily detailed, but in general she presided as regent and as Queen Mother during the succeednig reigns of her sons Francois II, Charles IX and Henri III, during which France went hell in handbasket.

title: New Hampshire Asks Senate To Return Voting Machine
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 19The New Hampshire Ballot Law Commission has voted to demand that the United States Senate release voting machines belonging to Manchester and Portsmouth. The Senate impounded the machines in February in view of the longstanding dispute over last year's Senate election.

title: U.S. Bars Integration Plan For Schools in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 19 (AP)The Federal Government has notified the Kansas City school district that its latest desegregation program for the fall term is not acceptable and has given it 30 days to come up with another.

title: Retriever Is Given Putnam Top Prize
description: BREWSTER, N. Y., July 19 A Labrador retriever, Ch. Kim Valley Warrenton, owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr., and Mrs. Diane Beckett of Middleburg, Va., scored today in an upset at the Putnam Kennel Club Show on the Brewster school district campus.

title: Park Plan May Ease Townhouse Controversy
description: HACKEITSTOWNA proposal to build a 350acre county park may relieve this Warren County municipality of its most controversial topic of the last year: the development of 165 acres into a vast townhouse project. The land, now owned by a developer, would be purchased with state and Federal recreation grants.

title: The Campaign to Suppress Coonskin
description: Ralph Bakshl, the director of Fritz the Cat and Heavy Traffic, has almost singlehandedly changed the popular conception of what is possible in animated films; he has proved that the cartoon form can encompass controversial, adult, racy subject matter. Although Bakshi is white, he grew up in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, and his first two films showed a strong interest in blacks. In his latest creation, called Coonskin, most of the major characters are black. Mixing live action and animation, and featuring such actors as Scatman Crothers, playwright Charles Gordone, and pop singer Barry White, the film is satiric fable about oppression and revolution in the ghetto.

title: CHESS
description: Not all players who use the CaroKann Defense are conservatively out to draw. True, the main tendency of this setup is to grant White a mild initiative, which Black works to circumscribe for the remainder of the game, but one can add a psychological twist to such basic strategy.

title: India Asks for Pledges To Abide by Censorship
description: NEW DELHI, July 19 (AP) The Indian Government togan today asking foreign correspondents to sign pledges that they would submit, their dispatches to censorship. Officials said that failure to sign the pledges could result in expulsion.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT, in real terms, declined 0.3 per cent in the second quarter. In current dollars it rose 1.2 per cent to $1.433.4billion ... Disposable income in the quarter rose by 63.3billion, annual rate, of which $36billion was accounted for by tax refunds . . . Consumer savings rose to 10.6 per cent of aftertax income in the quarter, a record for any quarter since the end of World War II.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: J. Paul Getty 3d Fined
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 19 (UPI) J. Paul Getty 3d 18yearold grandson of the billionaire oilman, was fined $150 yesterday and placed on two years probation by a municipal court judge after pleading guilty to a charge of leaving the scene of an accident.

title: MAN SLAIN IN CHASE AFTER BRONX THEFT
description: One man died and another was wounded in the stomach during a running gun battle in the Bronx late Friday night that began when two police officers spotted a car speeding away from a gasoline station at Webster Avenue and 168th street.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: From an unsophisticated snapshooter's point of view, taking pictures at the beach is almost certain to bring happy results since the necessary elements are usually presentadequate sunshine, leisure time, friends, family, bright colors, a scene that enchants all the senses, and a feeling that this is something of a special occasion that should be recorded for the future.

title: Parkin Brooklyn Honors Aunt Mary
description: For many years, on Pres ident Street in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, lived a woman named Mary Borden, whom everyone, kin or not, referred to as Aunt Mary. She was the kind of woman who would give you a homecooked meal, a handout and a piece of her mind with equal speed, neighbors recall.

title: SPANISH GALLEON BELIEVED FOUND
description: KEY WEST, Fla., July 19 (UPI)  Ten bronze camion found on the sea bottom are expected to bring about $20,000 each, but their discovery may lead to far Ereater treasuregold and sliver.

title: Business Doesn't Need More Tax Breaks
description: Business and financial leaders have been alleging that there is a serious capital shortage in this country and that unusual tax measures should be adopted to remedy this deficiency. The type of tax changes that they have in mind would reduce the taxes of corporations and highincome recipients. The arguments usually made to support tins position, nowever, are not persuasive. Our capital needs during the next several years can be met without distorting the tax structure.

title: Pension Funds Edge Into Real Estate
description: Last summer, when managers of the nation's pension funds began casting around for some alternative to the vicious bear markets in stocks and bonds, there were only half a dozen insurance companies and banks offering vehicles for investments in real estate.

title: S. H. Haig Fiance Of Jean P. Harris
description: Jean Phutips Harris, former principal violist of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, and Stephen Hawley Haig, who is with the First National Bank of Boston, plan to be married Aug. 2. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David H. Harris of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Hawley. Haig of Summit, N.J.

title: South Africa Planning Homeland Rehabilitation Centers for Blacks Violating Racial Laws
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 19 (Reuters)South Africa plans to establsh rehabilitation institutions in black homelands for those who violate laws governing black employment and migration.

title: Notes: 98 Big Guns For the Bicentennial
description: IN a converted automobile showroom in Brunswick, Md., about 60 miles northwest of Washington, a score of National Park Service employes are turning out 98 iron and bronze cannons. Their intent, however, is peaceableto supply firearms for Revolutionary War sites being spruced up by the Park Service for the Bicentennial. In most cases, the new cannons will replace originals that, in the words of one Park Service official, are being loved to death by visitors.

title: Demand for L.I. Arts Activities Rising
description: With the market for farflung vacations down, the market for local cultural activities and entertainment is up.

title: Civilization
description: Among primates, man alone needs to wear glasses, but only if he has, to some degree, been civilized. Some years ago, a team of anthropologists from Harvard found the great majority of New Guinea natives to be neither nearnor farsighted. And Dr. Francis Young, following his own course in Alaska, discovered the same thing to be true of Eskimo childrenas long as they remained in the wilds. When they moved into town and enrolled in schools, the number who became myopic jumped dramatically. Previously, Dr. Young had shown that chimpanzees, naturally farsighted, turned myopic in captivity.D.D.

title: Daughter to Mrs. Young
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Ryan Young of New York on June 22 in the Harkness Pavilion. The child has been named Amanda Jennings. Mrs. Young is the former Anne Honora Sullivan of Allendale, N. J.

title: The New York Book Fair
description: Over 300 small independent publishers and littlemagazine buffsfrom Portland, Me., to Portland, Ore.took part recently in the second New York Book Fair. The three day event was, as they say, something else again. The scene was Cass Gilbert's Customs House, in itself the surprise for many. This was no small coup: the Beaux Arts beautyat least its spacious rotundahad been dark for some 15 years. The smallpressers displayed their books, poetry chapbooks, graphics, political tracts on two floors, all under the handsome dome (with its early Reginald Marsh frescoes) of the mottled gray Customs.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article last Sunday about companies that are buying back their stock, Arthur M. Borden was incor rectly identified. He is an adjunct associate professor of law at the New York Law School. He presented his views on this issue in the December, 1974, issue of the New York University Law Review.

title: In a Year, President Lopez Could Not Deliver Promised Reforms
description: RIO DE JANEIROColombia's President Alfonso Lpez Michelsen, a liberal law professor, came to power not quite a year ago with a lofty program for broad social and economic reforms within a democratic system.

title: Edwards, on 207, Holds Stroke Lead
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 19 (AP)Danny Edwards birdied his last two holes today for a 69, and took the lead in the $200,000 Pleasant Valley Golf Classic. He posted a 54hole total of 207 in getting to the top of one of the most tightlypacked player jams on the tour in years.

title: MAIL UNIONS SEEK TO AVOID A STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Postal union leaders said today that they would be willing to extend the contract to avoid a mail strike if satisfacory progress was made in negotiations before the deadline of midnight tomorrow.

title: A Church Vanishes, Spoiling a Script
description: I thought I was hallucinating, said Harry Joe Brown Jr. The church my churchhad vanished. It was there a month earlier, when I left for Europe. Now it was gonedemolished!

title: Letters: Travel Agents Brickbats & Bouquets
description: The Letters Column this week is devoted entirely to correspondence addressed to the Travel Section in response to a twopart story on travel agents by Paul Grimes that appeared in the issues of June 29 and July 6.

title: Investigation of Police Chief Causes Wide Dispute in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 19The investigation of the county's. Police Commissioner by the Suffolk District Attorney on charges of corruption misconduct in office and other, more serious crimes, has ignited a dispute that, according to officials, threatens efficient law enforcement here.

title: The Uncrowned Queen of Ireland
description: Here's a plot to conjure with: spirited young Englishwoman called Katharine marries dashing, curlyhaired, horseloving Irishman. When romance sours. Katharine transfers her devotion to the compelling, aloof English hero of Irish politics. They live in blissful sin until the world cruelly interferes and brings them both downthus our heroine destroys the career of one of the greatest leaders in Irish history and wrecks forever the chances of Ireland's becoming free of the yoke of English oppression.

title: Hospital in Bergen Opening New Unit
description: ENGLEWOOD  Emergency care at Englewood Hospital takes on added dimension tomorrow, when the institution's new Emergency Department will be opened.

title: Peruvian Ceramics Shown in Queens
description: Exhibitions such as the current one at the Queens Museum, which is devoted to the ancient art of Peru, dispel the oncewidespread notion that Peruvian ceramics were primitive in nature. Once cavalierly describeti by art historians as simple, stark and unsophisticated, they are appreciated today as esthetically, socially and religiously significant accomplishments of a golden era in art.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Engagements

title: Grain Deals With Russia Are Still Marked by Secrecy
description: WASHINGTONIn wide areas of the Volga region, the southern Urals and northern Kazakhstan, important Soviet graingrowing areas, the corn has been tasseling at waistlevel, the leaves are curled and the stalks are orange near the ground. The wheat stands are uneven and drab in color. These and other signs of a poor harvest mean that, unless they decide to tighten their belts, the Soviets will have to turn to the world market for wheat and corn.

title: From Jungle to Jumble
description: LISBONJust as in France during the fruitless Indochina campaign, the Portuguese Armywhich is to say its officer corpswas conquered by its enemies in a colonial war. But there is one major difference.

title: Rising Costs Strain West German Health Insurance
description: BONN, July 19Udo Halata drove his pregnant wife, Erika, to the Bonn University Hospital the morning of July 8 for her last prenatal checkup.

title: Insurance Agent And Judith Self Plan Marriage
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Baldwin Self of New York and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Judith Bellinger Self, to Charles Malcolm Murphy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy of Old Lyme. Conn.

title: House Panel Said to Weigh Report of a Justice Dept. Deal With Teamsters' Fitzsimmons
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19  A selfdescribed longtime Government informer, Harry Haller, says he has told the House Judiciary Committee that the Justice Department made a secret deal with Frank E. Fitzimmons president of the teamsters union, in which the department agreed to go easy in pressing criminal action against the labor leader's son and another union official.

title: Other Scientific Exchanges With Russia Are Not So Smooth
description: The spectacular cooperation of the Soviet Union and the United States in space creates a spectacular picture, that of intimate scientific and technological collaboration between the two countries. To many American working scientists experienced in dealing with the Soviet scientific establishment, however, the picture of intimacy is misleading. Paradoxically, at the present moment it is much easier, politically and administratively, to arrange for Soviet and American astronauts to meet in space than it is for an American scientist in Ann Arbor or New York to invite a Soviet colleague in Moscow or Leningrad to come to work in his laboratory.

title: Recreation Added To 3R Program
description: JERSEY CITY  Education's traditional three R's have received a new look at the St. Peter's College Reading Center, where recreation has been added to studies in reading, writing and arithmetic.

title: In Bensonhurst, New Sicilians Find Way of Life Unknown to Forebears
description: Sicilian used to be the language of the old people in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, but now, as a new wave of immigrants has settled in the area, it has become the language of the young as well.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Last month the Belgians struck a blow for liberty, of a sort, and young musicians were the beneficiaries. The Queen Elisabeth music competition is one of the most prestigious in the world, and up to this year's joust it was run as competitions anywhere are run. Pianists or violinists pit themselves against each other. Eminent judges soberly listen, pencil at the ready. Prizes are awarded, and some talented youngsters get their names into the papers. Perhaps a major career or two has been launched.

title: Article 4  No Title
Why Boulez Likes the Rugs and the Ruggers Like Boulez
description: A few weeks ago, Pierre Boulez was heard to suggest that the New York Philharmonic ought to play 30 weeks of Rug Concerts and two weeks of subscription concerts, rather than the other way around. Spoken in jest, of course, yet easy enough to sympathize with. There, packed onto cushions all over the floor of what I trust Mr. Avery Fisher will prefer that we remember as old Philharmonic Hall, Boulez has found the audience he sought inNew York: the people who cheer Varse as loudly as they applaud Mozart.

title: ACTION TO ASSURE JOB RIGHTS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The United States Civil Rights Commission, in its report this week urging the formation of a new and comprehensive agency to protect the job rights of minorities, proposed a number of interim moves to improve Federal enforcement of present laws against employment discrimination.

title: Art Thefts a Shore Whodunit
description: LONG BRANCHA confusing controversy involving the Monmouth Medical Center, its Ladies Auxiliary. nearly 100 local artists and the Long Branch Police Department has developed into a whodunit, which, some people say, rivals the mystery reruns being shown on television this summer.

title: POPULATION DROP IN CITY CONTINUES
description: New York City's population is continuing to decline, with a drop of 328,400 residents, or 4.2 per cent, from the 1970 census to mid1974, according to new estimates by the Census Bureau.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Run to Live
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A KEY PERON AIDE LEAVES ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, July, 19 Jos Lpez Rega, the controversial rightwing strongman of the Argentine Government, left the country tonight.

title: Socialists in Lisbon Stage Big AntiCommunist Rally
description: LISBON, July 19The largest series of demonstrations against the Communist party since the start of the Portuguese revolution 15 months ago culminated tonight in a large rally by the Socialist party in the heart of Lisbon.

title: Works of 18 Artists On View in Summit
description: SUMMITJacob Landau, Louise Nevelson and Philip Pearistein are among the 18 artists represented in the Summit Art Center's new exhibition of collographs, monotypes, etchings, lithographs and other graphics.

title: Bicentennial House Opened in Nassau
description: The former Historical Museum at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow has been reopened as the headquarters for the Nassau County American Revolution Bicentennial Advisory Commission.

title: W.F.L. Opens Saturday Night; Familiar Names Dot League
description: Most of the National League's players, the rookies and veterans alike, will have reported and be, hard at work at their training camps by tomorrow. The first of the preseason games, the champion Pittsburgh Steelers against the College AllStars at Chicago is 12 days away. Meanwhile, the World Football League, following its early bird philosophy, is deep into its exhibition campaign, with the regular season set to start next Saturday night. That's when the Charlotte Hornets play the San Antonio Wings in the Texas city.

title: A Centennial Celebration for Plant Research
description: A hundred years ago today, Charles R. Ingersoll, governor of Connecticut, signed a resolution of the General Assembly intended to promote agricultural interests and so authorized establishment of the first agricultural experiment station in America. The station was to be operated for the general benefit and improvement of agriculture and kindred interests of the State.

title: In Cold Print: Copy Rights
description: We'll try to make this as short as possible so we don't have to register as lobbyists, Art Buchwald, the husband of literary agent Ann Buchwald, told a standing room only (because there were no chairs) audience in the Gold Room of the Rayburn House Office Building a few weeks ago.

title: Floods Bring Calls for Controls
description: TRENTONThe torrential rains that flooded dozens of New Jersey communities last week have prompted renewed pressure for swift action on proposed floodcontrol measures for the Passaic and Raritan River watersheds, the main areas hit by the storm.

title: A Private World That They Hope Never Changes
description: REMSENBURG, L.I.A lot of people have driven through Remsenburg and never known it, and a lot of people here would like things to continue that way. Tourists and trippers aren't encouraged in this treelined hamlet, about 72 miles from New York.

title: Medical Center Gets $1,571,748
description: Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, a division of the State University of New York, has received 39 research and training grants ?? $1.371.748.

title: Vacation Travel Rises in U.S., But Many Trips Are Shorter
description: CHICAGO, July 19Despite inflation, record high gasoline prices and the worst unemployment rate since the Great Depression, more Americans are traveling this summer to vacations in the national parks and at the seashores and resorts than last year.

title: Linda Villari Is Bride
description: Linda Susan Villari, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Villari of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday afternoon to Michael R. Breault, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Breault of Schenectady, N. Y. The Rev. George Duffy performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady Help of Christians Roman Catholic Church. The bride is an alumna of Hunter College. Her husband, a Fordham University graduate, is in his third year at the Georgetown University Dental School.

title: Thinking About Crime
description: If crime is one of the most important current issues of public concern (as public opinion polls have regularly shown) and if this volume by Prof. James Wilson is one of the most insightful books on the topics of crime and punishment (which I believe to be the case), then Thinking About Crime should be read by a very large segment of the population.

title: Edward Taws Claghorn Weds Katrina Elizabeth Van Buren
description: Katrina Elizabeth Van Buren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Martin Van Buren of Walton, N.Y., and New York, and Edward Taws Claghorn were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Thomas E. Adams of the faculty of the Hoosac School in Hoosick, N.Y. He was assisted by the Rev. Edward Caldwell. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church in Walton.

title: Mendenhall Is Still Uncertain On Becoming Giants' Leader
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 19A new season has not resolved old agonies for John Mendenhall, the most valuable New York Giant.

title: Museum Is Displaying Fence Art Works
description: The current exhibition in the Brooklyn Museum's Community Gallery is a show that enables community artists of all types, no matter what their stylistic persuasion, their reputation or ethnic background to participate in a public art display.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Delay lawn weed control until September to avoid herbicide damage. . . . Finish pruning evergreens. . . . Continue rose spraying for control of black spot. . . Pinch mums for fuller plants. . . . Keep up regular fruit spray schedule; flies of apple maggots are about laying eggs which will cause wormy apples.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The CooperHewitt Museum of Designa branch of the Smithsonian Institution in the process of rebirth in the Carnegie Mansion is not letting its current state of unreadiness keep it from putting on exhibitions. If the visitors can't come to the museum, the museum will go to the visitors, or even to the exhibitions. And that is exactly what it has done in the case of Immovable Objects, subtitled An Outdoor Exhibition About City Design On View Throughout Lower Manhattan from Battery Park to Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Sandra F. Mueller Bride Of Will Kenniston Dick
description: Sandra Freeman Mueller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Swan Mueller Jr. of Penn Valley, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Will Kenniston Dick, son of Mrs. Frederick S. Moseley Jr. of New York and the late William K. Dick.

title: Cristin Daniel Is Bride Of Scott C. Viebranz
description: St. Peter's Episcopal Church In St. Louis was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Cristin Ann Daniel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Peyton Daniel Jr. of Ladue, Mo., to Scott Colville Viebranz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Viebranz of Lynnfield Mass., formerly of Larchmont, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Kirk.

title: Norway: Summer's Dream Come True
description: IT was several summers ago, one particularly stifling Manhattan afternoon, that I discovered the restorative virtues of the Museum of Natural History. Half an hour's daydreaming before the Hall of the Birds of the World dioramas proved almost as refreshing as a spell at the beach. Oh, those breezy habitats! As the summer wore on, I grew especially fond of the Arctic diorama, where, in a pooling silver light, stuffed waterbirds of 50 species called from their crags against a backdrop of beckoning mountains. Longingly I'd wonder: Do such places still exist, now that the far north is being turned into a vast oil rig?

title: A Soviet Space Expert Predicts Cooperation on Shuttle Missions
description: MOSCOW, July 19 (UPI)The Soviet Union and the United States will make shuttle flights to orbiting stations their next cooperative effort, a Soviet space expert, Viktor Blagov, said today.

title: Welfare Rise Levels Off In Nassau
description: MINEOLA  Secondquarter welfare statistics released last week by the Nassau County Department of Social Services indicate the upward trend during the first quarter of the year has leveled off.

title: LET HER SINK
description: Sometimes when I am sitting on the Punta della Dogana, the best lounging place in Venice, I deliberately conjure an illusion. Halfclosing my eyes, I see the ravishing city before me, shimmering beyond the Basin of St. Mark's, suddenly restored to imperial grandeur. Then the great banners. floating indolently on their flagstaffs in the piazza across the water, fly not simply for display, but as a boast and a warning to the nations, and the mighty campanile itself seems to look out across the waters as a watchtower of dominiona quarter and a halfquarter of the Roman Empire, as the old Venetians liked to say.

title: Venezuela, for One, Wants Foreigners to Stay On
description: BUENOS AIRESSometime later this year, Vene zuela will nationalize its multibillion dollar industry, now largely in the hands of the foreign companies, Shell, Exxon and Gulf.

title: Sugihara 6Stroke Victor
description: ONO, Japan, July 19 (AP) Teruo Sugihara, a Japanese pro, won the Kansai open golf tournament today by posting rounds of 71 and 69 for a fourround total of 279, nine under par. He finished six strokes ahead of Yoshitaka Yamamoto, another Japanese pro, who finished with 67 and 71.

title: A Nuclear PeaceProfit Motive
description: WASHINGTON  It's not every day that the United Seates can strike a blow for world peace and consolidate a commercial advantage at the same time. But President Ford is trying, at least, with his recent moves on nuclear energy.

title: The Forest Killers
description: The battle between the developers and the preservers, the industrialists and the naturefreaks, the exploiters and the conservationists, the growthmaniacs and the zerogrowth zealots, the Greedheads and the Green Guerrillas goes on and on. Arrayed on one side are the wellorganized forces of Big Industry and Big Government, armed with power, authority and glaciers of money. (And these men get very emotional about money; Mobil Oil spends more in one simple advertising campaign than the Sierra Club, the Friends of the Earth, the Wilderness Society can muster up in their combined annual budgets.) Against them are disarrayed the citizen conservation clubs, angry journalists and lonesome poets hurling books, some concerned and isolated politicians, a few subversive bureaucrats and bitter forest rangers hiding in the lower ranks. These people get very emotional about Nature, that. vast abstraction out there, where, as somebody has said, we throw our beer cans on Sunday afternoons. Warm bodies, bleeding hearts and torrents of furious wordsrubbertipped arrowsbouncing off the armored flanks of the everadvancing Megamachine. To any impartial spectator from afar it must appear, this absurd war, like the most lopsided, foregone and hopeless struggle since those ancient times when the Pentagon descended, in all its majestic wrath, upon the barefoot rice farmers of Vietnam.

title: Latter Day Tories Suggest U.S. and England Reunite
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 19When readers of The Pennsylvania Gazette, the University of Pennsylvania's monthly magazine for alumni, turned to the back cover of the latest issue, they got quite a surprise.

title: Courts Here Are Ordered to Trim Staffs
description: Civil Court judges have been told to dismiss their law secretaries, and Supreme Court justices In the city were instructed to dismiss their confidential assistants.

title: Jane Schwarzschild Is Friancee Of Virginius R. Shackelford 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gustavus Morris Schwarzschild Jr. of Staunton, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Lee Schwarzschild, to Virginius Randolph Shackelford 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shackelford Jr. of Orange, Va.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Shortage of Canning Lids Proves Costly
description: CULPEPER, Va., July 18There have been no canning lids, at any price, for months in the stores here and in thousands of other small towns across the country's farm and garden belt. So when Hazel Black's Aunt Bertha mailed her five boxes of lids from Missouri last month, it made Mrs. Black the talk of this town. She could can her tomatoes.

title: Many Thefts Cited At Cali Swim Meet
description: CALI, Colombia, July 19 (UPI)Although the Columbian police say they tried to sweep all the known vagrants and pickpockets off the streets before the world swimming championships began today, several European coaches and swimmers complain they have been robbed of watches and other valuables.

title: Alaina Reed, Bold And Earthy, Sings At Reno Sweeney
description: Alaina Reed, a 29yearold veteran of Hair casts in Chicago and New York, is also a nightclub singer. In fact, she opened one of the most successful of the current Manhattan boites, Reno Sweeney, in December of 1972.

title: NEW AMTRAK CARS ON DISPLAY HERE
description: Amtrak is getting 38,000 plush, reclinable seats in 492 new Metrolinerlike coaches for its Eastern fleet of trains, and three of the new coaches will be at Pennsylvania Station on Track 6 until Tuesday for public inspection.

title: Constance Trenholm Married To Willard J. Anderson on L.I.
description: Constance Lee Trenholm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Trenholm of Larchmont, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Willard James Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rand Anderson of Long Lake, Minn. The Rev. George Busier performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Mrs. Richard B. Bevier of Westhampton Beach, L. I., the bride's grandmother.

title: 39th Avenue Extension Is Meeting Resistance in Douglaston
description: On some maps, 39th Avenue in Douglaston. Queens is a short road running from Bay Shore Boulevard to 233d Street, a distance of about six blocks. In reality, one of these blocks is missing.

title: Ann Hunsbedt Bride of B.A. Becken Jr.
description: Ann Hoghton Hunsbedt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Norman Hunsbedt of Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Bradford A. Becken Jr. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Side Okas Is Bride Of Dr. Heino Ainso
description: Sirje Okas, a biochemist and daughter of Dr. and Mrs. August Okas of Woodside, Queens, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Heino Ainso, an assistant professor at the Clarkson College of Technology in Potsdam, N.Y. The Very Rev. Alexander Hinno performed the ceremony in the Grace and St. Paul's Lutheran Church, of which he is dean.

title: Sadat Seen Cool To Soviet Treaty
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19Two of Lebanon's leading newspapers, An Nahar and Al Hayat, said today that President Anwar elSadat was considering abrogating Egypt's treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet Union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: W. Germans Top U.S. in Track
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 19 (AP)  Ethiopia's Miruts Yifter and Rick Wohlhuter of the United States established themselves as strong Olympic contenders today as the United StatesPan AfricanWest German meet ended at Duke University.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Ten years ago this week, then Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller announced that an atomicpowered desalinization plant would be constructed on a 45acre site on the north fork of Long Island near Riverhead.

title: U.S. Nine to Play South Korea Stars
description: SEOUL, July 19 (AP)A United States college allstar baseball team will visit Seoul next Friday through July 31 for a fourgame exhibition series against a South Korean allstar squad at Seoul Municipal Stadium.

title: A Showpiece Turkish Town on the Aegean Collects Tourists and Problems
description: BODRUM, Turkey  The travel brochures say about Bodrum: The inhabitants of the town are mostly fishermen and they are hospitable and gay, with a nonchalance that touches on the bohemian. Their simple life has a seductive charm.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Weekend Dance Retrospectives At Cubiculo End Inconclusively
description: The Cubiculo ended its retrospective series this weekend wipi a half dozen pieces by as many choreographers, all of whom started with excellent ideas that few carried to completion. The spectator was left with a feeling more of creative search than successful solution.

title: Beyond SoyuzApollo
description: Back in the 1950's, the Iaunching of the first Soviet Sputniks delivered an unsettling blow to American national selfesteem.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The American and Soviet astronauts yesterday ended their twoday linkup in space at 11 A.M., Eastern daylight time. The Apollo and Soyuz spaceships then flew in formation for a little more than three hours in two revolutions of the earth to conduct two joint experiments involving the sun and earth. When the joint flight had been completed Apollo pulled away from Soyuz for good, dropping into a lower orbit about 138 miles above the earth. The Soviet astronauts are scheduled to return to earth tomorrow, near Karaganda in Kazakhstan, at 6:51 A.M., Eastern daylight time. The Apollo astronauts will stay in orbit until Thursday. They will land in the Pacific Ocean, west of Hawaii. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, ROCK HAS IRONIES
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 19 (Reuters)One of the ironies of South Africa's racially divided society is that whites are not able to attend live performances of an entirely new subculture of black African music.

title: Israel: The Bible For a Baedeker
description: ALMOST 70 years ago my grandfather Abraham Rogowsky, fled his home in Russia and made his way to Palestine, fired by dreams of Zionism and fear of the Czar's army. A few years later he emigrated to the United States bringing tales of frontier life among the Arabs that he later told his grandchildren on long summer nights. My wife, Cokie, had learned in her convent days about the Crusaders' battles against the Infidels, and had yearned to help recapture the Holy Land for Christendom. (Her zeal had been only slightly tempered by her father, who once toured the area and later remarked, I've seen it, and I don't want it back.)

title: College Schedules Basketball Clinic
description: TOMS RIVERA clinic designed to improve individual basketball skills will be offered at Ocean County, College from Aug. 11 to Aug. 1$. The, program is being conducted in cooperation with the college's Department of Health and Physical Education and its Office of Community Education.

title: BICENTENNIAL BACKS WOMEN, MINORITIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The American Revolution Bicentennial Board reminded states this week that they should give special attention to women and minorities in planning Bicentennial activities with Federal money.

title: Florida Lobstermen Are Angry Over Bahamian Fishing Curbs
description: MIAMI. July 19  United States officials are trying to prevent a confrontation between irate Florida fishermen and Bahamian authorities over the. Nassau Government's restriction of lobster fishing in Bahamian and international waters.

title: APPROVAL OF FORD UP ONE POINT IN POLL
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Public approval of the way President Ford is handling his job increased slightly in June, according to a Gallup Poll survey released today.

title: TV VIEW
description: For unspecified sins, I was sent to the West Coast. What, you may ask, is going on on the West Coast? I'm glad you did, because on the Fourth of July in San Francisco there was something called a Media Burn. It was organized by the Ant Farm, a local collective of conceptual artists. They piled 44 old television sets on top or each other in the parking lot of the Cow Palace, soaked them with kerosene and applied a torch. An actor pretending to be John F. Kennedy delivered a speech. Then someone climbed behind the wheel of a rebuilt 1959 Biarritz Cadillac, revved up and rammed the car through the wall of smoldering TV sets. Bang. According to programs distributed before the event, everybody was supposed to experience a cathartic explosion and be free at last from the addiction to television.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: STRATFORD, CONN Shakespeare festivals play it safe; by their lights, they have to. Hundreds of picnickers, thousands of tourists, tens of thousands of schoolchildren are, after all, purchasing a commodity from them, and expect satisfaction. There are refreshments and postcards to be sold. Festival program requirements are, therefore, fairly strict: If not Shakespeare, the play must be, at least, certified by the high school textbooks as a modern masterpiece; the principal actors should each have a large following, preferably acquired on some television series, along with respectable classical credentials; the directors, if not prominent, should at least be British; the productions may make use of any current trends in stage art, but (festival audiences and festival marketers are very strict about this) may not constitute a genuine reinvestigation of the work. In effect, these festivals are made to celebrate whatever common assumptions the audience already holds about Shakespeare and the masterpieces of world drama; any new ideas or revelations would be decidedly out of place.

title: Dr. Claire Marsh Will Be Married
description: Dr. Claire Coverdale Marsh, a fellow in child psychiatry at the Eastern Pennsylvania Psychiatric Institute in Philadelphia, and Stephen Noah Freed, a lawyer there with the Veterans Administration, plan to be married in Philadelphia on Sept. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pauline Hotchkiss, Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Hotchkiss of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pauline Webster Hotchkiss, to Perry S. Boynton 3d of New York and Denver. He is the son of Mrs. Boynton Jr., of New York and tae late Dr. Boynton, a New York physician.

title: Little Ferry Ponders Sports Complex Traffic
description: LITTLE FERRY  Like many other communities that border on the Hackensack Meadowlands, this Bergen County borough is concerned that it might be affected adversely by the vast Sports Complex that is rising in nearby East Rutherford. As Marion Urso, who has lived here for 15 years, put it the other day:

title: Design: American patchwork
description: America has produced very few indigenous art forms in her young life  in fact, only two by my count: the blues and the patchwork quilt. The patchwork quilt is the blues of the American woman, a craft born of harsh necessity that became both the symptom of and the cure for what life demanded of her.

title: Anne Harvey Sets Nuptials
description: Anne Bowdoin Harvey, a teacher at the LowHeywood School in Stamford, Conn., plans to be marriedin October to Gregory Trowbridge Grote, a Latin teacher at the King School in Stamford and head of its Middle School.

title: POPULATION DROP IN CITY CONTINUES
description: New York City's population is continuing to decline, with a drop of 328,400 residents, or 4.2 per cent, from the 1970 census to mid1974, according to new estimates by the Census Bureau.
