description: ASPARAGUS FERN (July 6)

title: To the Blare of a Brass Band, Citizens of Ames, Iowa, Celebrate a New Solid Waste Recycling Plant
description: AMES, Iowa, July 16The Ames municipal band, which zips out marches with the verve of its national military counterparts, blared today from an unusual acoustical background: a concrete alcove of the city's new $5.7million solid waste recovery plant.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: TodayCentury, Old Field Clnb, Stony Brook, LI. Open; preliminary, amateurowner and junior jumpers; green, amateurowner, nonthoroughbred and young working hunters; adult horsemanship. 9 A.M.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Alexandr Solzhenitsyn has been in the United States in recent weeks cautioningunder A.F.L.C.I.O. sponsorshipagainst the dangers of being deceived by detente. Edward W. Cook has been Moscow.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Glenn Miller remains a tangible presence on the American music scene, 31 years after his dramatic disappearance on a flight from England to France. The music of his band and its instrumental style continue to beguile an international audience and to convert the uninitiated, perhaps by recalling a time when life seemed simpler and more rewarding.

title: Expos' TwoRun Eighth Tops Reds, 42; Orioles Beat A's Twice
description: MONTREAL, July 19 (AP) Nate Colbert singled home two runs in the eighth inning, today to lead the Montreal Expos to a 42 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: French Fishing Blockade
description: DEAUVILLE, France, July 19 (AP)Fishermen, angered a pollution of the Seine estuary today blockaded Deauville an Trouville harbors with their boats, trapping hundreds ?? sailboats and other pleasure craft. The fishing boats carried banners saying: The ocean is being turned into a garbage can.

title: L.I. Legislature Panel Gets Green Light
description: MINEOLA  The Nassau County Board of Supervisors lost a lastminute attempt last week to prevent a courtappointed citizens' commission from drawing up a plan for a new form of government.

title: Somalia Denies Report of Base
description: PARIS, July 19 (AP)  A communiqu issued by the Somali Embassy here today said development of the port of Berbera was intended to promote Somalia's economic progress, not to prepare for the establishment of a Soviet military base.

title: Liquor Licenses An Issue Again
description: TRENTON  The controversy involving the granting of liquor licenses in New Jersey has been revived by a State Supreme Court ruling that neighborhood sentiment must be considered before a license Is granted or transferred.

title: M. A. C. Asks City Unions For Voluntary Pay Freeze
description: Executives of the Municipal Assistance Corporation talked, informally yesterday with Labor, officials here to seek a possible voluntary agreement on a wage freeze for City employes, rather chan having it imposed by the State Legislature.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Miss Allen Fiancee of Tsutomu Ishiguri
description: Mr. and Mrs. John N. Allen of Plymouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Priscilla Hope Allen, to Tsutomu Ishiguri of Tokyo. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sakuro Ishiguri of Niigata, Japan.

title: The Nation
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation. has officially admitted what has been openly discussed for a long time, that the bureau itself has for 30 years been committing some of the burglaries that make up the F.B.I.'s annual report on the incidence of serious crime.

title: Son to Mrs. Spiegelman
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Spiegelman of New York on July 14 at Beth Israel Hospital. Dr. Spiegeluran is a dentist. Mrs. Spiegeluran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Siegfried Burg of Queens, is a speech therapist. The child has been named Gregg Howard.

title: GRAIN AGENCY GOT CASH ADVANCES
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 19The agency that is supposed to perform impartial inspection services for the Bunge Corporation grain elevator near here received a number of cash advances from Bunge in the nineteensixties.

title: Mets, Seaver Win, 54; Jones on Trade Block
Doctor Revels in YearRound Fire Island Practice
description: OCEAN BEACHI love it here and the only way you'd get me to leave is to take me off with a straitjacket and handcuffs, says the only yearround doctor on Fire Island.

title: Coast Shows to Set Record for Entries
description: Next weekend will see a record triple in CaliforniaChannel City on Friday, Ventura, Saturday and Santa Barbara, Sunday. They have drawn 11,318 entries, the greatest threeday total in American show history. Had Ventura not been limited to 3,500, the total would have been even higher. However, until Ventura succeeds in obtaining new grounds, the American Kennel Club wisely has restricted its entry.

title: Echoes of Parker In Jackie McLean As He Leads Group
description: Jackie McLean, in the ninetean fifties a promising young jazz alto saxophonist influened by Charlie Parker, has appeared in New York infrequently since. He is now playing here for the first time in seven years, leading a sevenplece group at the Five Spot that includes his son, Rene, also a saxophonist.

title: Imprisoned Basques in Spain Split Over Politics and Tactics
description: BILBAO, Spain, July 19Basque separatists who are believed to number at least 300 and who are being held without trial in four prisons in northern Spain have set up separate communes in the prison cornpounds.

title: President Ford's Economic Policy Machine
description: WASHINGTONKnowing glances undoubtedly were exchanged by members of the White House staff recently when President Ford issued an order enlarging the executive committee of his Economic Policy Board to include Secretary of State Kissinger and two other Cabinet officers.

title: A Special Special School
description: PISCATAWAYUniversal High School is a special kind of school that does not want to be labeled a special school.

title: J. A. Rathschmidt, Nanci Dailey Wed
description: Nanci Clarke Dailey, daughter of Barbara W. Dailey of Princeton, N. J., and the late Gibson Fuller Dailey, and James Alfred Rathschmidt Jr., were married yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rathschmidt of Yorktown Heights, N. Y.

title: One Was to Enhance Mr. Brezhnev's Reputation
description: MOSCOWThe ApolloSoyuz Test Project has had some tangible benefits in the Russian view. The docking in space last week reasserted the Soviet Union's image as a technological equal, in space at least, of the United States. It has also placed a slew feather in the cap of Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, a symbolic dividend of his policy of accommodation with the West that Moscow can exploit.

title: College Receives Data on State Law
description: MONTCLAIRPatrons of Montclair State College's Sprague Library will have additional state law information at their fingertips, thanks to a generous gift from the Class of 1975 and the Student Government Association.

title: G.A.O. STUDY SCORES RESERVE TRAINING
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  Military reservists spend about half their timeand about $1.2billion a yearin lectures about haircuts and other pursuits not related to their military duties, according to Congressional investigators.

title: Bert Breen's Barn
description: At the turn of the century Tom Dolan, age 13, decides to leave school and work in Ackerman and Hook's flour and feed mill. His wages are 25 cents for an 11hour day, with a threemile walk and household chores on either end of it. Tom's father had deserted his family, but his mother's a diligent, selfrespecting woman, who does her best to make up to the children, Tom and his younger twin sisters, for their father's shortcomings.

title: Headliners
description: An attempt to unseat Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn failed last week, but only after some sustained arm twisting by some of baseball's most powerful team owners. The revolt was led by Oakland's owner, Charles O. Finley, who has been feuding with Mr. Kuhn for a long time. Joining Mr. Finley briefly were the owners of the Texas Rangers, the Baltimore Orioles and the New York Yankees, whose principal owner, George Steinbrenner, had been suspended from baseball for two years by Mr. Kuhn after being convicted of making an illegal campaign contribution to former President Nixon's reelection campaign. All four voted no in an informal ballot on extending Mr. Kuhn's contract. But Mr. Kuhn's backers forestalled a formal vote on the matter, and then began pressuring the others to desert Mr. Finley, who is somewhat of a pariah among team owners. By the next day, both the Yankees and the Rangers had withdrawn their no votes. One reason given: Many owners feared the ouster of Mr. Kuhn would establish Mr. Finley as baseball's most powerful owner.

title: SUITS CITE LOCKHEED IN REFUGEE DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has been sued for $2.5billion in connection with the cargo jet crash that killed more than 100 Vietnamese children in April, Lockheed records showed today.

title: 12 U.S. EMPLOYES SEIZED IN ERITREA
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 19 (AP)Two American technicians and four Ethiopians have been kidnapped in Eritrea Province, apparently by the secessionist Eritrean Liberation Front, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Angolan Group Fires on Rivals in Fort
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 19Mortar shells and machinegun fire peppered the vicinity of an old Portuguese fort here today for the third day as one black liberation movement that hopes to lead the country to independence tried to overwhelm soldiers of a rival organization taking refuge in the fort.

title: Confusion Is Surrounding City Layoffs
description: Waves of layoffs, rehirings, promises and threats, modified revenue projections and budget alterations have left the city at a loss to say exactly how many of its employes have been dismissed in the current budget crisis, or how many win be let go in the weeks ahead.

title: Move On to Calm UNESCO Dispute
description: PARISQuiet moves are under way to resolve the dispute between the governing majority in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and Israel, and other steps are being discussed.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Recent demands that State Senator James P. Dugan of Hudson County resign as the Democratic State Chairman clearly called for a response from Governor Byrne. And in a message to all of the state's Democratic county chairmen, Mr. Byrne renewed his support of Senator Dugan, despite the fact that the latter has worked against the administration's programs and policies more often than not.

title: Regulation: A Threat to Prosperity
description: The automobile industry has encountered a number of very serious problems in the put year. Car sales have dropped sharply as a result of the worst recession since World War II, rampant inflation, high unemployment and a serious drop in consumer confidence. However, there are signs that We have hit the bottom or the recession and started on the road to economic recovery. It would appear that the American economic system will again overcome its setbacks, pick itself up and return to the road of progress.

title: What's Doing in the MARITIMES
description: BY THE SEA Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island, three provinces in eastern Canada, known collectively as the Maritimes, are luring more and more frazzled city dwellers from the northeastern United States. Peaceful, largely rural lands with pleasant country roads, a good summertime climate and the sea all around, they form a compact, easytogetaround vacationland, with as much area as New York State and about the same population as Manhattan. According to a friend in Halifax, N. S., the way to see the Maritimes is just to drive down to the end of the road. There you will almost always find the seaand with it, perhaps, some fishermen on the way in or out, a colony of painters, a deserted beach, a delightful lobster bar, an unforgettable sunset. The cities in the Maritime Provinces have little appeal, and can be skipped without pangs. But the open road, with the water usually in view or hidden just behind a clump of trees, offers one reward after another.

title: Man With Vasectomy Sues Sperm Bank on Lost Semen
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP)A man who stored a sample of his semen at a sperm bank and then had a vasectomy has filed a 55million lawsuit against the bank for accidentally destroying the specimen.

description: Bell's Telephone

title: Vietnam Seeking Observers at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 19 (Reuters)North Vietnam and the Provisional Government of South Vietnam, in a policy shift, have decided to send resident observers to the United Nations, it was announced today.

The parents of the child, who has been named Jill Lucille RowlandLowney, were married in 1973, and the mother retained her maiden name. She is a student at Rutgers Law School in Newark. title: Use Seaweed
description: In 1972, when my wife and I moved into our new home in Medford, a farm town in the heart of New Jersey's biggest agricultural county, we had visions of a kitchen garden which would bring happy respite to our food bills and provide us with a satisfying feeling of pioneer virtue.

title: Article 3  No Title
Experimentation on People Without Dehumanization
description: WASHINGTONA virtuous physicist, according to novelist Kurt Vonnegut, is a humanistic physicist. He wouldn't knowingly hurt people. He wouldn't knowingly help policemen or soldiers hurt people. He knows that scientist can be an accessory to murder most foul.

description: Werner Roth has been the backbone of the Cosmos' defense for the last four seasons. He was the team's most valuable player last year; he has represented the United States more than 30 times as a member of the national team; and recently he has been sought by some of the other teams in the North American Soccer League.

description: GENEVA, July 19The 35nation European security conference was putting the final touches this evening on a charter of more than 100 pages, calling for improved EastWest relations, that will be presented for adoption at a summitlevel meeting in Helsinki on July 30.

description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19The sailors who took home trophies after the final day of racing at Larchmont Race Week today knew they earned them. During the five days of competition, they raced in nearly every type of weather: a steady southwesterly breeze, squalls, fog and downpours, no wind, light air building to a fresh breezeand today at last, good, steady wind and sunshine:

title: Upsurge in Digital Watches
description: The digital watches are finally catching on. And one of America's oldest industries; watchmaking, is being drastically shaken up by the inroads of the brand new semiconductor technology involved.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Elite police units, trained for special dangerous missions, have grown increasingly popular in large and small jurisdictions throughout the country. According to police experts interviewed by New York Times correspondent Jon Nordheimer, the creation of such forces, especially in small and mediumsized communities, is often a result not of need but of faddishness and a paramilitary mentality.

title: SOVIET REPORTS SOLE GOODS LAG
description: MOSCOW, July 19The Soviet Union reported today a general economic improvement for the first six months of the year, but disclosed that the production of some consumer goods was lagging.

title: Fittipaldi Captures British Grand Prix
description: SILVERSTONE, England, July 19Several drivers said they thought they were afloat on rafts, others called the circuit here an ice rink. But Emerson Fittipaldi weaved around the wrecks today and won the British Grand Prix, which English weather ended 11 laps earlier than scheduled with an injury list of six. The injuries to the drivers were minor cuts or sprains. A track marshal was hit by a car and had his shoulder and ankle fractured.

title: Thomas Mann at 100
description: If Thomas Mann were alive today he would be 100 years old. That is very old indeed and yet it is not at all impossible to imagine Mann reaching the age of 100, celebrating the year in the rather stiff, worldwide. panegyrical manner of the Supreme Instance great and longlived. He combined the purest gifts with the earthbound consent, of a distinguished old dray horse, to pull heavy loads. Mann lived to be 80and the irony was noted that these were a considerable sequence of years for an artist who connected inspiration with disease and early death.

title: Point of View
description: Suburban sprawl has been eating up our available farm land at an alarming pace while we have allowed inner city areas to deteriorate and have left abandoned thousands of acres of land that could be reutilized. This lack of planning has led this country into a serious economic development crisis.

title: Talks Set Tuesday On Graduate Study
description: MONTCLAIRHow About Graduate School? is the name of a special free program for those persons who have been out of college for a period of time and are seeking information and advice about getting back in.

title: Is the Broadway Musical Changing Its Tune?
description: How unfortunate it would be if all those theatergoers jostling for tickets to A Chorus Line were convinced they were going to see a new kind of musical. That phrase has been associated with this Michael Bennett production from the very start, swelling like a crescendo as the show took shape. First it was a wispy rumor drifting uptown from the Public Theater, where Joseph Papp had provided Bennett, workshop space and cash and lots of rehearsal time. It mounted in volume after preViews began. By now it's so brassily loud it could acCompany Line like a Sousa March when the show highkicks its way in triumph up old Broadway to settle into the Shubert on Friday for a long run. But a new kind of musidar? A new kind?

title: R.S. O'Hara Jr. Weds Miss Durkin

title: Letters
description: Judge Irving R. Kaufman's defense of the First Amendment guarantee of freedom of speech (A free speech for the class of '75, June 8) contains a disturbing error of fact. The First Amendment guarantees that Congress shall make no law abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press. Nowhere does the Constitution guarantee or insure the reaction of the audience to the speaker. Would it not have been preferable for Judge Kaufman to show the strength of his convictions regarding the First Amendment by exercising it? Judge Kaufman piously withdrew from addressing the commencement class at Pomona College on the grounds that he did not wish to disrupt one of the most significant and joyous events in a young person's life. If he had had the courage to speak, despite the audience's possible reaction, and despite the fact that he is a controversial figure, he might, perhaps, have begun to open the dialogue he claims is pass. Judge Kaufman, then, has not in any way been denied his constitutional right to speak; he simply withdrew in a cowardly manner, and covered his withdrawal with a limp platitude.

title: The New York Times Book Review Paperbacks
description: On the way. Coffee table books and 1976 calendars  the words have a jinglebells sound, but in these dog days they're being sung by many paperback editors. The words apply to some of the most ambitious publishing projects scheduled for the next three months.

title: BRIDGE

The users of conventions are of course required to respond to proper questions, but their rights and duties in this respect are not well understood.

description: A 19yearold Brooklyn rabbinical student who was spending the summer at an Orthodox Jewish study and prayer camp in Greenfield Park, N.Y., was shot from a car parked in the woods late Saturday night and died yesterday in Monticello General Hospital.

title: BEAME AND M.A.C AGREE ON 3 MOVES TO AVERT A CRISIS
description: Tentative agreement has been reached by the city and the Municipal Assistance Corporation on at least three of the drastic fiscal economies that could avert the city's insolvency  a wage freeze, further layoffs and salary cuts sources within the statecitycorporation negotiations disclosed yesterday.

title: FORD TELLS OF HOPE FOR TALKS ON ARMS
description: President Ford said in an interview published today that success in the current follow up talks with the Soviet Union on limitation of strategic arms could lead to a relatively stabilized defense budget while failure would mean that defense spending will have to be increased significantly.

title: Iris Rakity Married to Mitchell Shapiro
description: Iris Hillary Rakity and Mitchell Leslie Shapiro were married yesterday evening at the West Hempstead (L. I.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Reuben M. Katz. He was assisted by Cantor Harry Altman.

description: One of the finest of man's adornments of the banks of the Hudson River is Lyndhurst, the Gothic Revival mansion owned for 80 years by Jay Gould and his descendants and now maintained by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

description: The Legislature has cut into the $34.1million it appropriated this year to the New York State Council on the Arts by transferring more than $1million to the jurisdiction of other agencies.

title: New Representatives Presence Felt

Solarz made 12 speeches on the House floor, cosponsored 370 bills, made 24 trips to his Flatbush district and an 18day tour of the Middle East, held 11 news conferences, signed 6,255 letters, spoke at 14 graduations, attended 99 district events, visited 23 subway stations, and published two newsletters sent to constituents along with 513,720 separate pieces of mail.

description: Four cancer research centers working under Federal grants have been unable to confirm assertions that the contraband drug laetrile can cure cancer or inhibit malignant growths, according to previously undisclosed findings of animal studies.

title: ANDREW H. HEPBURN, AN EDITOR OF LOOK
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 20 (AP)  Andrew H. Hepburn, former travel editor of Look magazine, died at his home here Friday. He was 76 years old.

title: Smaller Juries Increase; Divided Verdicts Allowed
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The American jury as seen in history books and movies  the jury of 12 men and women who must either reach a unanimous verdict or return no verdict at allis less and less often the jury seen in America's courts.

title: Cambodians Who Have Fled Say Troops Gunned Down Hundreds
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand July 20 (AP)Nearly 300 Cambodians were gunned down last week by Cambodian soldiers during attempts to escape to Thailand from Cambodia, witnesses said over the weekend.

title: New U.S. Court of Appeals Is Urged by A.B.A. Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) An American Bar Association committee urged Congress today to establish a new national court of appeals to reduce the Supreme Court's workload.

description: HUGO, Okla., Suly 19A pair of elephants has been lost here for a week and the people of Choctaw County are becoming a little defensive about it.

description: The city's fiscal crisis has split the municipal labor unions into two camps, a moderate group led by Victor Gotbaum, who has made it a policy to be accommodating, and a militant group led by, Ken McFeeley, who has not.

title: Paper Says Kissinger's Garbage Had Secret Service Documents
description: LANTANA. Fla., July 20 (AP)A recent sample of Secretary of State Kissinger's household garbage contained hundreds of Secret Service documents and a shopping list for three cases of whisky, The National Enquirer says.

title: Personal Finance: Taxes on Houses
description: The Internal Revenue Service, a businesslike organization not noted for taking liberal views toward romance, does give a tax blessing to some houseowning newlywedsand also to some houseowning divorced persons.

title: Chrysler Lightens Load for Long Haul
description: DETROIT, July 20  A. Chrysler Corporation that will stay its present smaller size, that will not try to match its competitors in every market segment and that will try to develop most of its new cars from fewer basic modelsthat's what Eugene A. Cafiero, who will become president of Chrysler Oct. 1, has envisioned in an interview.

title: ISRAEL UNYIELDING ON SINAI BUFFER
description: TEL AVIV, Monday, July 21  The Israeli Government served notice this morning that it would oppose changes in the United Nations peacekeeping force In Sinai to induce Egypt to approve the extension of the life of the force.

title: FRANK RUCKER
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., July 20 (AP)Frank Rucker, a retired University of Missouri School of Journalism professor, died Friday, in a nursing home here. He was 89 years old.

title: Sheryl Paikin Wed To Steven Delinko
description: Sheryl Lana Paikin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Paikin of Nanuet, N.Y., was married yesterday in the garden of her parent's home to Steven Carl Delinko, son of Mrs. David Delinko of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Mr. Delinko. Rabbi David Posner of Temple EmanuEl here performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Karl Schleinzer Dies; An Austrian Party Leader
description: VIENNA, July 20 (Reuters)Dr. Karl Schleinzer, leader of the conservative Austrian People's party, was killed yesterday with his chauffeur in a headon collision near Bruck an der Mur, southwest of here.

title: His 2d Homer, in 8th, Sinks Astros, 109
description: Mauled or mutinous or whatever they're supposed to be, the Mets subdued their miseries long enough yesterday to score five runs in the fifth inning and four in the eighth for an improbable 109 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: A Chief of State Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) A constitutional amendment to create a ceremonial post of Chief of State, apart from the President, was proposed today by Representative Henry S. Reuss. Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: SIEGFRIED S. MEYERS
description: Siegfried S. Meyers, former professor of physics at Madison College and teacher at Stuyvesant High School, who was an inventor of medical electronic and other electronic devices, died Wednesday in Harrisburg, Va., where he lived. He was 66 years old.

title: City's Ethics Board Rejects Plan to Add To Present Powers
description: The public members of the city's Board of Ethics yesterday rejected a series of recommendations by the State Charter Revision Commission that would turn the hoard into a full investigatory body with subpoena powers and the authority to remove public officials.

title: MRS. PERON'S GRIP ON POWER FALTERS
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 20Jose Lpez Rega, the controversial rightwing strongman of the Argentine Government, left the country last night in apparent exile as a result of presidential palace intrigue involving Cabinet ministers and the armed forces.

title: Jerusalem Explosion Kills Two Children
description: JERUSALEM, July 20 (Reuters)  Two children were killed and four children and two women were injured today when a gas heater exploded in an apartment house here.

description: Outgoing

description: The following is an adaptation of a speech given at a PanAmerican dinner in Chicago. The Cubanborn author, formerly chairman of the political science department at Illinois Benedictine College, now heads a Chicago marketresearch and advertising concern.

description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.At first it looked like an Esther Williams movie.

title: Democrats' Slim Savings Reflect the High Cost of FundRaising
description: WASHINGTON, July 20At midpoint in the year before their nominating convention, seven Democratic candidates for the Presidency have raised nearly $10million in contributions, but together they have barely $2million in the bank tu show for their efforts.

title: Quintuplets Healthy
description: DALLAS, July 20 (UPI)The Davis quintuplets have shaken off symptoms of respiratory distress and appear strong and healthy, a spokesman for Parkland Hospital said today. The four girls and a boy were born by Caesarean section Friday to Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Davis of nearby Lewisville.

title: West, at Security Conference, Rejects Soviet Trade Demands
description: GENEVA, July 20The Soviet Union's drive to win nondiscriminatory treatment in its trade with the West has run up against a wall at the European security conference, now in its closing stages here.

title: 3 IN E.P.A. ALLEGE AGE BIAS IN SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Three Federal employes sued the Environmental Protection Agency in Federal District Court last week, charging age discrimination in what is believed to be the first class action of its kind.

title: Presley Treats Fans to His Best
description: Elvis Presley played Madison Square Garden in 1972 for the first and last time. Since then, he has stuck to the suburbs, like most middleoftheroaders. Except that, when he wants to, Mr. Presley can still rock, and hefelt like rocking a refreshing lot of the time Saturday at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I.

title: Cyclists Thrill Paris as Big Race Ends in a Whirl Through City
description: PARIS, July 20  The ChampsElyses has seen some splendid moments, and today was among them, for Paris and all France. It wasn't grandeur but it was fun.

Schweiker, a member of the Senate committee investigating the Central Intelligence Agency, recommended today the reopening of an official investigation into the 1963 assassination of President Kennedy to determine whether it was linked to C.I.A. plans to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State subsidy contracts with four New Jersey rail lines and more than a dozen bus companies expired at midnight, but masstransit service is expected to be running normally today as the State Senate meets in Trenton to consider a package of tax bills designed to finance new subsidies and restore millions of dollars in other state aid programs.

title: Beame Seeks a TightBelt Image
description: Two months ago, May or Beame suggested freezing a 6 per cent salary increase that would be due city workers on July 1. The ideathen regarded as political dynamiteran into predictable opposition from the unions and was dropped within 24 hours. Most ob servers did not deem the Mayor's proposal serious. Last week, however, a groundswell developed in the Board of Estimate and the City Council around the more radical proposal to roll back the nowgranted 6 per cent increase. Mr. Beame said he would press for it if need be. And in addition, he proposed a series of even more draconian measures such as cutting salaries across the board by 10 per cent.

title: Mets' Records
Prospect of a New Role for Amin Stirs Misgivings Among Africans
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 20The prospect that Idi Amin, the controversial President of Uganda, will become chairman of the 42member Organization of African Unity has stirred serious misgivings among members of the organization, whose ministers are meeting this week in Kampala, the Uganda capital.

title: TAX ERRORS SEEN AMONG CONCERNS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 About onethird of all small corporations, that Is, those with assets of $1million or less, were underpaying their Federal income taxes, as of 1969, and 85 per cent of them were getting away with it.

title: Advertising
description: The phrase horsy set brings to mind far more than people who love horses. It conjures up images of welldressed men and women, elegant people with a taste for the good things in life.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GANG'S ALL HERE Mostly Mozart Festival Fans who live near Lincoln Center or can slip away from work during lunchtime can enjoy a free bonus this afternoon before tonight's festivalopening concert at 8 o'clock in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Saudi Arabia Backs Threat By Egypt to Bar U.N. Force
description: CAIRO, July 20King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, ending a fiveday state visit here, today formally endorsed Egypt's threat to block renewal of the mandate of United Nations forces in Sinai unless there was tangible progress toward a settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict. The mandate expires Thursday.

title: Moscow's Need for Grain
description: In 1975, as in 1972, the Soviet Union is making massive purchases of American grain, particularly wheat. The protests that have already been voiced here against these purchases reveal that the bitter consequences of the 1972 deal have not been forgotten. Those earlier Soviet purchases had been made secretly and at ridiculously low prices which were expensively subsidized out of the Federal Treasury, and therefore by the American taxpayer.

title: Saudi Arabia Backs Threat By Egypt to Bar U.N. Force
description: CAIRO, July 20King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, ending a fiveday state visit here, today formally endorsed Egypt's threat to block renewal of the mandate of United Nations forces in Sinai unless there was tangible progress toward a settlement of the ArabIsrael conflict. The mandate expires Thursday.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Sunday, July 20, 43d day. Weather clear for eight races, rainy for ninth; track fast.

title: Gateway to Tomorrow
description: The Gateway National Recreation Area is a dream come trueor almost come true. This extraordinary 39squaremile treasure of natural assetsocean beaches, bayside shorefronts, wildlife preserves and unspoiled features from holly forests to wetlands and grassy dunes is only twenty miles from Times Square and is readily available to twenty million people in a threestate region. In its first season as a national park in 1974, Gateway attracted five million visitors; eight million are expected this year. But the fate of Gateway is on the line right now.

title: Most Support Tuition at City U. In Poll on Ways to Save Funds
description: Most New Yorkers favor imposing tuition at the City University for students who can afford it as a step to help the city ease its fiscal crisis and also approve renegotiating union contracts to reduce overtime and other costs.

title: Phillies Sink Reds As Schmidt Stars
description: Mike Schmidt, the Philadelphia Phillies' redhaired third baseman, sometimes performs like the girl in the nursery rhyme with the curl in the middle of her forehead. When he's good he's very good, and when he's bad he's horrid.

title: Carole Feldman Wed to Myer H. Bisker
description: Carole Feldman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Feldman of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Myer Harris Bisker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bisker of Silver Spring, Md.

description: Films

title: Silk Stockings, 110, Takes Monticello Trot
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 20 The preludes to next Sunday's MonticelloNew York City Offtrack Betting Classic, which is estimated will reach $300,000 in value, were held in the rain this afternoon.

title: Road to Helsinki: Moscow Hung On, Sacrificed Some, Won Most of Its Goals
description: MOSCOW, July 20With the summitlevel conclusion of the European security conference now set for July 30, the Soviet Union is emerging from a diplomatic exercise of its own making, slightly battered by some unexpected turns but having nonetheless obtained what it sought in the first place.

title: News Summary and Index
description: King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, ending fiveday state visit to Egypt, formally endorsed Egypt's threat to block renewal of the mandate of United Nations forces in Sinai unless there was tangible progress toward a settlement of the ArabIsraeli. conflict. The mandate expires Thursday. In a joint communique, Egypt and Saudi Arabia endorsed the appeal by 40 Moslem countries and organizations for the expulsion of Israel from the United Nations. King Khalid also pledged $600million in credits to the Egyptian Central Bank. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: India Orders Expulsion Of 3 Correspondents
description: NEW DELHI, July 20 (AP) The Indian Government ordered the expulsion of three foreign correspondents today after they had refused to sign pledges that they would abide by censorship imposed under the country's state of emergency.

title: 3 Union County Youths Receive Scholarships to Learn to Fly
description: Three recent graduates of Union County high schools Have won scholarships that with allow them to learn to fly at no cost.

title: How and When the Poll Was Conducted Here
description: The New York Times telephone poll of New Yorkers' attitudes on the fiscal crisis was conducted during the evenings of July 14, 15 and 16. A total of 420 persons were interviewed, a random sample that statistical experts say yields 95 per cent confidence that the results are within 5 percentage points of the attitudes of the population as a whole.

title: Sheila Woods Married Here
description: Sheila Levin Woods and Dr. Kenneth J. Kessler of New York were married here last evening. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony in the Rainbow Room.

title: Bowater Will Close Plant As Newsprint Demand Falls
description: CATAWBA, S. C., July 20 (AP)The Bowater Carolina Corporation announced today it would close its Catawba Newsprint Company operation for one week starting July 28 because of a reduced demand for newsprint.

title: Auxiliary Police Fade Under Layoffs
description: Something has happened to the city's 5,400member auxiliary police force lately. It is missing  and under somewhat mysterious circumstances.

title: Court of Appeals Takes Cautiously Liberal Turn
description: Three years ago the State Court of Appeals unanimously upheld the constitutionality of the Sabbath closing laws. Only two of those seven judges are still sitting on the state's highest court, and the average age of the judges has dropped by 10 years.

title: Way Is Opened in Lisbon To Replace the Premier
description: LISBON; July 20President Francisco da Costa Gomes today invited socialistoriented parties to cooperate in a new government, opening the way for the possible replacement of Premier, Maj. Gen. Vasco Concalves.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: POLL FINDS SUPPORT FOR CONGRESS LOW
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The public became increasingly disillusioned with Congress in the last three months, according to the latest Gallup poll, released today.

title: Equal Job Opportunities
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has assessed the Federal programs designed to achieve equal job opportunities for women and minorities and has found them to be floundering and ineffectual. As a result, the Commission has proposed a stiff remedy: the establishment of a single new agency possessing strong enforcement powers to take over the morass of programs now spread through a plethora of Federal agencies.

title: 6 Women Attack Man Identified as a Rapist
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 20 (AP)  Six women described by authorities as vigilantes armed themselves with knives and slashed an accused rapist before he could he arrested, the police said today.

title: New Ron Johnson Is in Giants' Camp
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 20Maybe Ron Johnson is ready for another giant season with the New York Giants.

title: European Security ...
description: The 35nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, now nearing its climax after 32 months of semantic quibbling, should not have happened. Never have so many struggled for so long over so little as the conference's 100page declaration of good intentions in EastWest relations. So little, and yet so much.

title: On Growing an Alpine Strawberry
description: I planted this from seed, is a favorite remark from Richard Langfelder when he takes visitors around his garden. He is one of those stickitinthegroundanditgrows kind of people who knows how to raise everything extremely well.

title: Joyce A. Slochower Wed to Bruce Rodin
description: Joyce Anne Slochower, who has been named an assistant professor at Hunter College, was married here yesterday afternoon to Bruce Rodin, a land developer. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.

title: Lefty Frizzell, Singer, 47, Dies; At Top of 50's Country Chart
description: NASHVILLE, July 20 (UPI)Lefty Frizzell, the.country music singing star, died yesterday at Nashville Memorial Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 47 years old.

title: IRATE INDICATORS SIGNAL ADVANCE
description: The squeeze applied to the money market by the Federal Reserve a month ago continued to work its way through the fabric of interest rates last week. The banks' prime rate or rates, since a twotier system appears to have imposed itself on this indicator of credit conditionsedged up a quarter of a percentage point.

title: 3 Firemen and a Woman Are Hurt in Brooklyn Fire
description: Three firemen and a woman were slightly injured yesterday when a fire raced through threestory frame dwelling in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn and spread to parts of two adjoining buildings, the Fire Department said.

title: Books of The Times
description: Don Gold, who calls Bellevue a documentary of a large metropolitan hospital, spent seven months observing the daily routine at the hospital and has woven what he saw into a composite single week. We begin early Monday morning with Bernard Weinstein, the hospital's executive director, driving to work from New Jersey and leave, him Friday night musing as he crosses the George Washington Bridge on the zonked psychiatric patients and how someone referred to a straitjacket as an ambulatory camisole. Each day the scene shifts from one to another of the medical servicespsychiatry, chest service, obstetrics, gynecology, neurology and so onand we walk through a day with the doctors and nurses on each service, watching them look to their patients, operate, attend lecturesstaying with them yet never getting to know much about their lives outside the hospital.

title: MATTHEW S. FOX
description: Matthew S. Fox, president of the Commodity Exchange from 1964 to 1973 and a governor since 1945, died yesterday at his home, 201 East 19th Street. He was 77 years old.

title: MRS. PERON'S GRIP ON POWER FALTERS

description: Four cancer research centers working under Federal grants have been unable to confirm assertions that the contraband drug laetrile can cure cancer or inhibit malignant growths, according to previously undisclosed findings of animal studies.

title: In Memoriam
description: COOGANMary C. Mimi, dear Your first birthday in Heaven. We do not know what happened and that we will never know but we know our Heavenly Father must have willed it so. Beside your grave we stand each day and try so hard to understand. The tears in our eyes we wing away but the pain in our hearts is here to stay. The depths of sorrow we cannot fell of the loss of one we loved so welf and while you siren a pearetul Sleep your memory we shall always keep. Love always your sisters Jackie and Julie. Massez at St John Vianney, Flushing & St Cathrine of Alexandria, Bklyn.

title: Syria, With Forces Built Up Since '73, Maintains Alert Stance in Golan Area
description: EL QUNEITRA, Syria, July 12  The town was empty, silent and in ruins. Occasionally a United Nations truck, its white paint glaring in the brilliant sun, rumbled through. The wind blew steadily from Mount Hermon.

title: POSTAL CONTRACT AVERTS WALKOUT
description: WASHINGTON, Monday July 21 (AP)The Postal Service and its unions agreed early today on a new labor contract, averting the possibility of a nationwide postal strike, officials said.

title: Columbia Engineering Names Acting Dean
description: Ralph J. Schwarz, an authority on communication and systems theories, yesterday was appointed as acting dean of the Columbia University School of Engineering and Applied Science.

title: Red Smith
description: For several nights before the Irish Sweeps Derby, Jack Mulcahy slept poorly. Not that he was a stranger to excitement. As a schoolboy in County Waterford, he carried messages through the British lines for the Irish Republican Army. At 16 he was arrested by the Black and Tans, who shot his companions. When he got out of prison a year end a half later, he came to the United States, where he prospered. Now he invests in Irish properties and backs his horses in Irish races but refuses to take money from Irish bookmakers. He bets instead with English bookies and looks upon his winnings as reparations money. Getting into racing with Vincent O'Brien as trainer, he started winning right away, but he never had a Derby starter before this year.

title: Spain, Sweden Gain In Davis Cup Play
description: Despite a victory by the Nastase over Manuel Orantes, Spain defeated Rumania, 32, yesterday and gained the European Zone A final in the Davis Cup tennis competition.

title: Students Restore Olmsted's Vision of Central Park
description: In a sense, it's almost an archaeological experience reconstructing Frederick Law Olmsted's Central Park, said Elizabeth Barlow, head of the Central Park task force of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration.

title: Game Called on Account of Pele
description: This is what Pel means to the Cosmos: The St. Louis Stars asked the New York team yesterday to postpone tonight's exhibition game because the Brazilian star was not 100 per cent fit to play.

title: Third Straight Sunday In City Marred by Rain
description: A line of heavy rain squalls moved through the city for the third successive Sunday late yesterday afternoon, causing a familiar pattern of local highway flooding and subway disruptions.

title: India Bars Visit of Delegation Seeking to Meet Detained Leader
description: LONDON, July 20The Indian Government has refused to admit an official delegation or international Socialists seekling to visit Jaya Prakash Narayen, the imprisoned political leader and follower of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

title: State Offers a Guide on Auto Insurance
description: TRENTON  Those New Jersey motorists who would like to comparison shop for their automobile insurance can now obtain from the state's Department of Insurance a consumer guide that shows clearly the wide range and disparity in rates.

title: . . . and Real Dtente
description: It is true, as Secretary Kissinger has just repeated, that there is no alternative to coexistence of East and West in the nuclear era and that dtentereal rather than illusorymust be pursued. But the Helsinki carnival, like the SovietAmerican handclasp in space, could mislead many into believing that peace already has arrived. Very limited forms of arms control and EastWest cooperation are still accompanied by intensified repression within the U.S.S.R., heightened Soviet rivalry with the West in the Middle East, South Asia and the Indian Ocean and little real sign of progress in strategic or conventional arms reduction talks.

title: Dietz Wins Final Trial In Rowing
description: CAMDEN, N.J., July 20Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club won the final heavyweight single sculls trial today on the Cooper River in convincing fashion. The trials were held to determine the United States representatives in the world rowing championships at Nottingham, England, Aug. 21 to 30.

title: Restless Restless Triumphs on Coast
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 20 (AP)  Restless Restless, in his first stakes race, captured the $136,850 Hollywood Juvenile Championship for 2yearolds at Hollywood Park today in a photo finish.

title: Defeating Unemployment Now, Not in 1976
description: WASHINGTONPresident Ford and his economic advisers appear to be so mesmerized by the specter of inflation that they are willing to live indefinitely with high unemployment, stagnant profits, an economy operating far below capacity.

title: Exclusive New Buildings Here Combine Mixed Use Facilities
description: Olympic Tower and the Galleria are among the most expensive residential buildings ever erected in New York, but they take as their model the old flat on top of a store. The two superluxury buildings, both of which are now nearing completion. are the city's first tests of an old idea that has become the latest thing in urban planningmixed use. The theory is that a combination of residential, commercial and office uses in the same building, something which occurred naturally in the smallscale neighborhoods of the 19th and early 20th century, can provide an antidote to the sterility of much recent largescale development.

title: INDIAN STATE VOTE REPORTED PUT OFF
description: NEW DELHI, July 20The Indian Government, in a move that could have national ramifications, has reportedly decided to postpone the election scheduled to be held in the southern state of Kerala in September.

title: The Glorious Revolution
description: We celebrate this week the first anniversary of a great occasion in American history, a transforming moment in our lives. One year ago Peter Rodino rapped his gavel and asked his colleagues to proceed in good will, with honor and decency. The country watched on television as the House Committee on the Judiciary debated the impeachment of a President.

title: New Representatives Presence Felt
description: WASHINGTON, July 20In his first six months in Congress, Stephen J. Solarz made 12 speeches on the House floor, cosponsored 370 bills, made 24 trips to his Flatbush district and an 18day tour of the Middle East, held 11 news conferences, signed 6,255 letters, spoke at 14 graduations, attended 99 district events, visited 23 subway stations, and published two newsletters sent to constituents along with 513,720 separate pieces of mail.

title: Claudia Franey Is Married on L.I.
description: Claudia Franey, a graduate of Mount Holyoke College, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Jensen, a candidate for a doctorate in French literature at Yale University.

title: Repeats On 66276
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 20 (AP)Roger Maltbie, a littleknown long shot, who is becoming better known fast, overtook eight players with a five  under  par 66, and scored a surprise triumph today in the Pleasant Valley golf tournament.

title: Calcutta, Combatting Cheating, Orders Police to Watch Exams
description: CALCUTTA, India, July 19The Calcutta government deployed policemen at more than 100 places where college students took examinations this week, according to a Calcutta University official.

title: Curb on 5th Ave. Parades Is Criticized as Inadequate
description: The Fifth Avenue Association denounced as inadequate a Police Department proposal to limit parades on Fifth Avenue to 16 a year.

title: F.B.I. Embassy BreakIns Put at OneaMonth Rate
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation broke into an average of one foreign embassy a month in recent years. Newsweek magazine reports in its latest issue. In one Arab mission they met Israeli agents already there, saluted and walked away, the magazine adds.

title: Crucial House Vote Near On Arms Sale to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The House of Representatives will vote this week on whether to allow a resumption of military assistance to Turkey, an issue on which the House is narrowly divided. The test of the measure is viewed by supporters and opponents alike as probably the most important vote on foreign policy so far for this Congress

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: CHARLES P. GROSS, GENERAL, 86, DIES
description: Maj. Gen. Charles P. Gross, U.S.A., retired, chairman of the city s Board of Transportation from 1945 to 1947 and chief of the Army Transportation Corps in World War II, died Friday in the Army Hospital at West Point, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived at 2 Idlewild Park Drive, CornwallonHudson, N.Y.

title: Antipollution Cost Called 1% Burden on Oil Profits
description: Although the oil industry will have to lay out as much as $4billion for air and water pollutioncontrol facilities in the 197483 decade, neither gasoline buyers nor corporate shareholders are likely to feel any pinch, according to the latest analysis.

title: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Houston at New York (8:05 P.M.)Roberts (14) vs. Stone (21).

title: Tanner Chicago Winner
description: CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) Topseeded Roscoe Tanner defeated John Alexander of Australia, 61, 67, 76, in the final of the Chicago international tennis tournament today.

title: 3 Drown on Mission to Salvage $100 Million in Sunken Treasure
description: KEY WEST, Fla., July 20 (UPI)A salvage tug trying to recover a $100million treasure from a sunken 17thcentury Spanish galleon capsized and sank today. The skipper, his wife and a salvage diver drowned.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The cabin cruiser I Dream of Jennie burned to the waterline near Riverside on the Delaware River after a fire apparently began in the. engine room of the craft. The police said the 21foot cruiser caught on fire Saturday minutes after leaving the Bristol (Pa.) Yacht Club.

title: Director of Apollo Project
description: HOUSTON, July 20After Soviet and American spacecraft had docked successfully for the first international linkup in space last Thursday, the man who played a key role in bringing the threeyearold project about said at a news briefing:

title: Dr. Carl O. Sauer Dies; Dean of Geographers, 85
description: Dr. Carl Ortwin Sauer, the emeritus professor of geography at the University of California at Berkeley who was regarded as one of the most influential geographers of his generation, died Friday in Berkeley. His age was 85.

title: Raisela, $41, Is Neck Victor Maltbie
description: Raisela of the Harbor View Farm showed complete disregard for the presence of Sarsar yesterday in the $55,850 Hempstead Handicap at Belmont Park and Robert Sangster's Pass a Glance followed suit. Raisela finished first and Pass a Glance second, far ahead of the favorite, in the 1mile race for fillies and mares.

title: Death of Twin Doctors Linked to Despondency
description: The mysterious deaths of the Marcus brothers, gynecologists and identical twins whose bodies were found in their York Avenue apartment on Thursday, may have been the result of suicidal despondency atter each had suffered an emotional breakdown, a doctor close to them said yesterday.

title: O'Hara and Christie Win Anderson Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 20Neither rain nor lightning nor the United States Golf Association rule book could stay the Learn of J. P. O'Hara and Neil Christie today from becoming the youngest winners in the 42yearhistory of the Anderson memorial fourball golf tournament.

title: Oscar H. Levine Is Dead; Government Economist, 61
description: Oscar H. Levine, an economist who held important Government positions and published studies on manpower and graduate education, died Wednesday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 61 years old.

title: CHIARA PISANI
description: Chiara Pisani, correspondent here for the Italian magazine Gente for more than a decade, died Thursday in New York Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived at 2 Bedford Street.

title: Bolts Beat Tomahawks
description: BOSTON, July 20  Ivan Thompson scored four goals and assisted on three to lead the Boston Bolts to a 2312 victory over the firstplace Long Island Tomahawks in a National Lacrosse League game tonight at the Boston Garden. The Bolts took a 74 lead in the first period, including three goals by Thomason.

title: Mideast's Development Plans Growing As U.S. Companies Vie for Contracts
description: More than $300billion is scheduled to be spent on development within the next five years, according to the official plans of the major Middle Eastern oilproducing countriesSaudi Arabia, Iran, Kuwait and Iraq.

title: Foyt Victor, Clinches 6th U.S. Title
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 20 (AP)A. J. Foyt, the 40yearold Texan whose goal this season was to win a record fourth Indianapolis 500, instead clinched his record sixth national driving championship today, his first since 1967.

title: The Difference Between Allies and Interests
description: CAIROAt the foot of the Mount of Beatitudes, facing the sea of Galilee, where Jesus delivered his most famous sermon a couple of millennia ago, a Bedouin Arab family now lives in a black tent. The woman of the tent works, the kids and their goats nibble at whatever they can find, as the head of the nomadic family stares at a Syrian broadcast on an Israeli television set.

title: Most Support Tuition at City U. In Poll on Ways to Save Funds
description: Most New Yorkers favor im posing tuition at the City University for students who can afford it as a step to help the city ease its fiscal crisis and also approve renegotiating union contracts to reduce overtime and other costs.

title: Bridal for Judy Masor, Sheldon Radin on L.I.
description: Judy Masor, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip L. Masor of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to Sheldon Radio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon L. Radin of North Woodmere, L. I.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown refleets prices as which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: WHITE HOUSE ROLE IN U.S. HIRING CITED
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Additional allegations of political hiring in Federal agencies and departments were made public today by two public interest lawyers who said that there were political referral units operating within the Department of Commerce and the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Exclusive New Buildings Here Combine Mixed Use Facilities
description: Olympic Tower and the Galleria are among the most expensive residential buildings ever erected in New York, but they take as their model the old flat on top of a store. The two superluxury buildings, both of which are now nearing completion, are the city's first tests of an old idea that has become the latest thing in urban planningmixed use. The theory is that a combination of residential, commercial and office uses in the same building, something which occurred naturally in the

title: SOYUZ PREPARING TO RETURN TODAY; APOLLO DOES TESTS
description: HOUSTON, July 20As the Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft circled the earth separately today on their sixth day in space, the Apollo astronauts used their ship as a scientific observatory while the crew of Soyuz prepared to land in central Asia tomorrow.

title: ARNOLD S. ZANDER, LABOR CHIEF, DIES
description: Arnold S. Zander, a Wisconsin city planner who helped establish the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, serving as its president until 1964, died Thursday at his home in Green Bay, Wis. He was 74 years old.

title: BEAME AND M.A.C. AGREE ON 3 MOVES TO AVERT A CRISIS
description: Tentative agreement has been reached by the city and the Municipal Assistance Corporation on at least three of the drastic fiscal economies that could avert the city's insolvency  a wage freeze. further layoffs and salary cuts sources within the statecitycorporation negotiations disclosed yesterday.

title: City's Fiscal Ills Create MunicipalUnion Split
description: The city's fiscal crisis has split the municipal labor unions into two camps, a moderate group led by Victor Gotbaum, who has made it a policy to be accommodating and a militant group led by Ken McFeeley, who has not.

title: ExLong Branch Policeman To Begin Defense in Killing
description: FREEHOLD, N. J. July 20A former Long Branch patrolman who shot and killed the 16yearold son of a former City Councilman there will begin his defense tomorrow on a manslaughter charge.

title: Jazz and West Paterson Dig Each Other
description: WEST PATERSONAnios Kaune's faith in jazz is paying off not only for Mr. Kaune, who owns Gulliver's, a local jazz club, but also for the town of West Paterson.

title: SOYUZ PREPARING TO RETURN TODAY; APOLLO DOES TESTS
description: HOUSTON, July 20As the Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft circled the earth separately today on their sixth day in space, the Apollo astronauts used their ship as a scientific observatory while the crew of Soyuz prepared to land in central Asia tomorrow.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Miss Palmer Captures Open
description: NORTHFIELD, N. J., July 20Sandra Palmer, a hardworking 34yearold golf professional from Fort Worth, broke a logjam wide open today to win the 23d United States Women's Open by four strokes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Service in Jersey Unaffected in Subsidy Loss
description: State subsidy contracts with four New Jersey rail lines and more than a dozen bus companies expired at midnight last night, but masstransit service is expected. to be running normally today as the State Senate meets to consider a package of tax bills designed to finance new subsidies and restore millions of dollars in other state aid programs.

title: About New York
description: The urge to wave at passing ships goes very deep. The most enthusiastic wavers are children, possibly because they are tuned in more clearly to the collective unconscious and were recently afloat themselves in the amniotic sac. Like many other activities, the need to wave seems to diminish as the years go by.

title: Foreign Concerns Reduce Spending For Plants in U.S.
description: Foreign companies' investment in manufacturing facilities in the United States, which ran at peak levels in the 197374 period, fell sharply in the first half of this year, according to the Conference Board.

title: TEACHERS TO ASK 20% RAISE IN PACT
description: The head of the New York teachers union said yesterday that his members would ask for a raise in excess of 29 per cent when they begin negotiations Wednesday with the Board of Education for a new oneyear contract.

title: Smaller Juries Increase; Divided Verdicts Allowed
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The American jury as seen in history books and movies  the jury of 12 men and women who must either reach a unanimous verdict or return no verdict at allis less and less often the jury seen in America's courts.

title: Japanese Moving a Mountain to Expand Port of Kobe
description: KOBE, Japan  This port city is literally moving mountains to expand its piers, wharves, warehouses and capacity to handle cargo.

title: Soviet Girl Triumphs in 3Meter Diving
description: CALI, Colombia, July 20 (UPI)Irina Kalinina of the Soviet Union won the first gold medal of the World swimming championships today by defeating a field of seven other finalists in the women's threemeter event in springboard diving.

title: Ceasefire in Angola Collapses in Hours
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 20A new ceasefire in troubled Angola broke down today almost as soon as it was announced and more powerful weapons began to pound troops of one of the country's three black nationalist movements under siege in an old Portuguese fort.

title: Doc Pardee, Bronco Rider, Played in Tom Mix Movies
description: GLENDALE, Ariz., July 20 (AP)  C.W. (Doc) Pardee, a bronco rider, movie actor, rodeo announcer and trainer and breeder of thoroughbred horses, died Thursday at his home here. He was 90 years old.

title: The Dance: Martine van Hamel & Co.
description: Martine van Hamel is a great dancer whom not enough people know about to make herin realistic termsa great dancer. Oddly enough, everyone knows about Miss van Hamel except the great American public. The dancers know, the fans know, but somehow the secret has become safe with them. It could heaved preserve all of us, be the fault of the critics. Perhaps we have not shouted loud enough to the world that Miss van Hamel is fantastic, a unique acrobat of God, a dancer with the wind of genius blowing through her. Let us, by all means, rectify such omissions. Miss van Hamel is one of nature's gifts to dance.

title: World Team Tennis
description: New York 32, Phoenix 22. San Diego 26, Boston 21.

title: Reports in Doubt on End To IranianPan Am Deal
description: Iranian authorities threw into question yesterday reports over the weekend that the Teheran Government had finally turned down its tentative $300million plan for aiding Pan American World Airways. However, consummation of the original deal still appears in doubt.

title: Foreign Horses Score on Coast
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 21 (UPI)Foreignbred horses demonstrated their grassrunning ability today as Barclay Joy from Ireland and Cruiser II from Argentina captured $75,000 divisions of the Sunset Handicap, the closingday feature of the Hollywood Park meeting.

title: Apollo Shifts Its Position To Aid Landing Thursday
description: HOUSTON, July 21After the Soyuz astronauts landed safely today, the three Apollo astronauts continued to orbit the earth, taking pictures, making scientific observations and maneuvering their spaceship into a better position for its return to earth on Thursday.

title: Gold Drops Criminal Charges Against Former Investigator
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn dropped charges of criminally receiving an automobile yesterday against Walter Buchbinder, 52 years old.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Trends in Portugal Worrying Azores
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores (AP)Independence from Portugal is being openly considered in the Azores, but political and military leaders predict that the final break will not come unless there is a virtual Communist takeover in Lisbon.

title: Market Takes 4th Successive Downturn
description: Market Takes 4th Successive Downturn

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Open its eighth summer of outdoor performances in the metropolitan area, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater will stage an EnglishLanguage version of Osvaldo Dragun's trio of satirical plays, If You Promise Not to Learn, tomorrow at 7 P.M. at Riverside Park, Riverside Drive and 103d Street. (The rain date is Thursday at Public School 163, Amsterdam Avenue and 97th Street, at 7:30 P.M.) Jack Landron, Ernesto Gonzalez, Sandra Gallardo and Mila Conway are featured, under the direction of Pablo Cabrera, who also wrote the English adaptation with Ricardo Matamoros. The three short plays use comedy to make a wry comment on a society that has lost its sensitivity to the individual.

title: 20 Cambodians Gone From U.S. Navy Center
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 21 (AP)  Twenty Cambodian naval officers, who received political asylum in the United States when their Government fell this spring, have left the naval training center here to start new lives.

title: ADOLF WOLTMANN
description: Adolf Woltmann of 1364 Lexington Avenue, a psychoanalyst and psychologist, died Friday of a heart attack, while on a safari near DaresSalaam, Tanzania. He was 71 years old.

title: Kissinger Gets Report on Egypt's Response to Israeli Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Secretary of State Kissinger received an initial report today on the Egyptian response to the latest Israeli proposals on a pullback in Sinai. Administration officials predicted privately that the deadlock in the Egyptian  Israeli negotiations for a new agreement would be broken.

title: Teaneck Youth, 17, Told To Stand Trial for Murder
description: HACKENSACK, July 21Lee Morgenstein, a 17yearold Teaneck youth charged with the July 8 murder of the 22yearold daughter of a neighbor was transferred from juvenile detention today and arraigned in Bergen County Superior Court as an adult offender.

title: M.A.C. BONDS DROP BY 10% ON WALL ST. AS TRADING BEGINS
description: Bonds of the Municipal AsDistance Corporation plummeted 10 per cent in price yesterday on their first day of public trading, indicating that the new state agency may have to pay even higher interest rates for future issues.

title: 4 FOOD CONCERNS ACCUSED BY F.T.C
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged four leading food manufacturers yesterday with having illegal interlocking directorates in violation of both F.T.C. rules and the Clayton Antitrust Act.

title: Library Branches Curtail Staff And Hours to Save $2Million
description: A curtailed schedule of hours and services was put into effect yesterday by the branches of the New York Public Library to allow for the absorption of more than $2million in budget cuts.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Money, money, money. Where is it? Who's got it? Not you? Alas, it's still not possible to live without it, but it is possible to save a few dollars and cents here and there.

title: Limiting Executive License
description: Congress is to vote this week on whether to resume arms shipments to Turkey, as the Ford Administration wishes to do, but that is not the major issue. What is really at stake is whether Congress will stand by its determination to act as a check upon the executive branch even in the conduct of foreign affairs.

title: Wood,Field&Stream
description: A 10pound male Atlantic salmon presently residing in the Berkshire National Fish Hatchery in Hartsville, Mass., is a living symbol of a dream shared by many anglers, biologists and conservationists. Their hope is that the once extensive spawning runs of this magnificent food and game fish may some day be restored to the Connecticut River.

title: State of Emergency Is Condemned as Special Session is Opened
description: NEW DELHI, July 21Oppo sition members today condemned the Indian Government's sweeping state of emergency as the Parliament reconvened in a special session to vote on it.

title: State Senate is in Accord On Stopgap Tax Package
description: TRENTON, July 21  The State Senate reached agreement tonight on a package of stopgap taxes designed to restore more than $260million of the $384million in budget cuts made by Governor Byrne to balance the current budget.

title: Police Call Layoffs a Spur to Crime but Other Experts Doubt It
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, in a strident voice, and police officials, in softer tones, have warned that an increase in crime in New York is inevitable now that 3,000 police officers have been dismissed.

title: Workers Protesting Layoffs Occupy Maimonides Offices
description: Hospital employes protesting the layoffs of 75 workers took over the administrative headquarters of the Mental Health Department at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Discontent of Peasants in Honduras Leads to Violence and Death
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras; July 21Three months after seizing power, the Honduran military Government is facing growing unrest in the countryside, where demands for agrarian reform have led to the death of at least 14 persons in the last month.

title: L'Amour en Visites, One of Jarry's Strangest Plays
description: At the Theatre Nouveau in Paris on Nov. 11, 1896, a most singular event took place. It was the first performance of Alfred Jarry's strange avantgarde masterpiece, Ubu Roi.
