description: Following is a summary of ApolloSoyuz mission highlights.

title: U.S.Japan Space Pact
description: TOKYO, July 21 (AP)Japan has signed a $47million contract with the United States under which three Japanese weather and communications satellites will be launched in 1977 and 1978 from Cape Canaveral, Fla., a Japanese agency said today. The National Space Development Agency said that a 771pound meteorological satellite would be carried aloft in June, 1977.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: EXPORT DEMOCRACY (American Export), Casablanca Aug. 1, Tunis Aug. 7, Beirut 16 and Limasol 22; sails from 42nd St., Brooklyn.

title: Two Hotels and Y Left In Backwater of 8th Ave.
description: Empty and outdated, unwanted by their owners, three large buildings on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan are having trouble becoming useful.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium. Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens. 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9. 8 P.M.) (Radio  WNEW, 8 P.M.)

title: Invasion of Island Is Laid to France; She Denies Charge
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 21 (AP)  A spokesman for the Organization of African Unity said today that French troops were invading the Indian Ocean island of Mayotte that the 46nation group recognizes as part of the newly independent Comoro Republic.

title: Fiscal Relief Pitcher
description: It might not be inappropriate given the course of recent events, to characterize Felix George Rohatyn of Lazard Freres & Co. as the Hugh Casey of Wall Street.

title: Alsace, Though French First, is Stressing Special Identity and Seeking More Autonomy
description: STRASBOURG, FranceJeanPaul Obrecht is a book seller who like most of the Frenchmen here in the historic Alsatian capital on the Rhine, has a Gennansounding surname. Listening to him talk it is hard to tell which country he comes front:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the World Disarmament Conference10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Good News for Cities
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.Goods news has become a rare commodity for urban America.

title: 4 FOUND IN. REMAINS, OF A MISSING PLANE
description: Three men and a boy were found dead yesterday in the wreckage of a singleengine ariplane missing since Saturday, on a flight from Caldwell Airport to Pennsylvania.

title: Hospital Bulletin on Hathaway Calls Him Physically Exhausted
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Secretary of the Interior Stanley K. Hathaway will be hospitalized for an indeterminate period for physical exhaustion, according to a medical bulletin today from the Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md.

title: Shriver is Being Rebuffed by Kennedy Hands Waiting for Teddy
description: WASHINGTON. July 21There is trouble in the Kennedy camp and perhaps in the Kennedy family over brotherinlaw Sargent Shriver's incipient Presidential campaign.

title: News ummanr and Index
description: Opposition members of the Indian Parliament; in a special session that was called for a vote on it, condemned the state of emergency declared by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on June 26. They protested the jailing of their colleagues in the opposition, the censorship of the press, and the suspension of civil liberties. But Mrs. Gandhi's Congress party and its supporters have majorities in both houses, and with dozens of the opposition in jail, the Government's control of the proceedings was firm. A vote on the emergency declaration was expected today. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: BIG GRAIN CONCERN INDICTED WITH 13 IN EXPORT THEFTS
description: NEW ORLEANS; July 21A Federal grand jury indicted the Bunge Corporation, one of the world's largest grain companies, and 13 present and former executives and employes today on charges of conspiracy to steal grain by shortweighting shipmerrts and conspiracy to cover up the thefts.

title: END OF CUBA BAN IS EXPECTED SOON
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 21Foreign Minister Gonzalo J. Facio of Costa Rica said today that the Organization of American States would vote to end its 11year embargo against Cuba, possibly as early as this weekend.

title: City Begins a Drive Against Dog Bites
description: The city's Police and Health Departments have begun a concerted enforcement and education campaign to deal with dog bites.

title: 3,600 IN CLEVELAND WALK OFF CITY JOBS
description: CLEVELAND. July 21 (UPI)About 3,600 clerical, technical and bluecollar city employes went on strike early today, threatening city operations.

title: The Regulators
description: When the Interstate Commerce Commission was established in 1887 to protect farmers and small businessmen against rapacious railroads, it was a progressive reform. Later liberal Administrations added other regulatory agencies, with the Federal Trade Commission coming into existence under President Wilson and the Securities and Exchange. Commission, Maritime Commission, Civil Aeronautics Board and others established during the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: COMPUTER MAKING WILLEND ATXEROX
description: The Xerox Corporation, which in 1969 paid $900million to acquire the computer business of Scientific Data Systems, Inc., announced yesterday that it would withdraw in about a year from manufacturing computers.

title: In memoriam
description: In memoriam

title: Market Place
description: About a decade ago, the University of Chicago published the results of a stock market study covering 40 years. The study indicated that stocks had yielded an average 9.3 per cent annual return on a compounded basis between 1926 and 1965.

title: Boggs Goes Into Lead in Title Diving
description: CALI, Colombia, July 21 (AP)Phil Boggs, the defending champion, was the top qualifier today in the men's springboard diving eliminations with a total of 581.34 points at the World aquatic championships.

title: Firestone is Dropping Unit
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 21 (Reuters)The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today Bank Firestone, Ltd., a subsidiary in Switzerland, was planning to discontinue operations this year.

title: Yearling Brings Record $715,000
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Groves of Minneapolis, paid $715,000 tonight, a record, for a full brother to Majestic Prince and Crown Prince at the Keeneland sale of thoroughbred vearlines.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Opposition members of the Indian Parliament, in a special session that was called for a vote on it, condemned the state of emergency declared by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on June 26. They protested the jailing of their colleagues in the opposition, the censorship of the press, and the suspension of civil liberties. But Mrs. Gandhi's Congress party and its supporters have majorities in both houses, and with dozens of the opposition in jail, the Government's control of the proceedings was firm. A vote on the emergency declaration was expected today. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Cairo, Despite Risks, Is Looking to Western Europe for Arms
description: CAIROPolitical and military leaders here have been contemplating a shift in weapons procurement from the Soviet Union to Western Europe despite the risk involved in such a change of policy.

title: Daughter of Onassis Expected to Marry
description: Christina Onassis, the 24yearold daughter of the late Aristotle Onassis and heiress to one of the largest fortunes in the world, will marry Alexander Andreadis, the youngest son of a Greek shipping family that had once been in competition with her father's shipping business, a relative of the Onassisl family said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The City Commiskion on Human Rights initiated formal complaint against Composition Roofers Union Local 8 and Joseph De Vita, its business agent, charging them with subjecting minoritygroup workers to unequal treatment. Mr. De Vita has admitted replacing black and Puerto Rican workers with whites on union jobs as a protest against what he said was Federal failure to observe antidiscrimination rules on nonunion construction at Fort Hamilton.

title: Soyuz Crew Lands Safely After Very Hard Flight
description: MOSCOW, July 21The two Soviet astronauts of Soyuz 19 touched down safely in a billowing cloud of dust on the steppes of Soviet Central Asia today, successfully winding up their rendezvous in space with the American Apollo astronauts.

title: SOVIET BUYS CORN AND BARLEY IN U.S.
description: For the second time in two weeks the Soviet Union has entered the United States grain market for sizable purchases, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterdiy.

title: JAMS AND PERCY ASK HANDGUN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Republican Senators Jacob K. Javits of New York and Charles H. Percy of Illinois introduced a gun control bill today that would ban the domestic manufacture of most handguns and prohibit possesston of them in large urban areas with high crime rates.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 3.3 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose last week to 196.8 from 193.5 a week earlier.

title: HURD TELLS OF AID HE GAVE BERGMAN
description: T. Norman Hurd, the chief of staff to two Governors, assisted in a plan to move retarded children from Willowbrook State School to a nursing home built by Bernard Bergman after he had been told that the home was unsuitable for use as a healthcare facility.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Monday.

title: ALBERT GROSSMAN
description: Albert Grossman, a retired Manhattan lawyer who was a Democratic State Assemblyman in 1926 and 1927, died Friday in Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 85 years old and lived in Cranston, R.I.

title: Torre Hits into 4 Double Plays
description: Dave Kingman hit another home run last night, but was upstaged in the Shea Stadium spotlight by Joe Torre, who broke one record and several rallies by hitting into four double plays while the Houston Astros were mauling the Mets. 62.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: WAR BABIES IMPROVISATIONAL THEATER COMPANY, Battery Park, Noon.

title: BlueRibbon Talent to Council of Economic Advisers
description: With the recent confirmation of two new members of the threemember Council of Economic Advisers, the Administration has deepened considerably its talent pool in policy areas of keen importance to President Ford: energy and capital spending.

title: HotDog Venders Urge City to Halt Summonses
description: Leaders of the Frankfurter Venders Union charged yesterday that big business is putting pressure on the police to harass the city's 13,000 peddlers and that the Beame administration was trying to drive them off the streets by enforcing antiquated laws.

title: Family in LSD Case Gets Ford Apology
description: WASHINGTON, July 21President Ford personally apologized today to the family of Frank R. Olson, who is said to have died after he was given a dose of LSD by Central Intelligence Agency agents in 1953.

title: HURD TELLS OF AID HE GAVE BERGMAN
description: T. Norman Hurd, the chief of staff to two Governors, assisted in a plan to move retarded children from Willowbrook State School to a nursing home built by Bernard Bergman after he had been told that the home was unsuitable for use as a healthcare facility.

title: Solzhenitsyn Says Ford Joins In Eastern Europe's Betrayal
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn accused President Ford today of participating in the betrayal of Eastern Europe by planning to attend the 35nation European summit meeting next week. As a result the exiled Soviet novelist said, he could see no point in meeting with the President.

title: Today's Entries at Delaware
description: Horse listed in order of post positions Letters designate OTB listirg

title: M.A.C. BONDS DROP BY 10% ON WALL ST. AS TRADING BEGINS
description: Bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation plummeted 10 per cent in price yesterday on their first day of public trading yesterday, indicating that the new state agency may have to pay even higher interest rates for future issues.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The media attention to the developing rift between Turkey and the U.S. that has been precipitated by the action of Congress in cutting off aid to Turkey is welcome news. With the vociferous Greek lobby on one side and the general romantic Hellenophillic inclinations of the American public on the other, there has been altogether too little discussion of the consequences of the present official American position toward Turkey, in regard to the best interests of the U.S., NATO, Turkey, and Greece, for that matter.

title: Business Records
description: Petition filled by; JOHN W. DAVIS, 554 W. 114th St., N.Y. Liabilitiles $8,499; assets none.

title: Mrs. Peron's Fatigue Brings Quick End to Labor Discussion
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 21A meeting between Argentine labor leaders and President Isabel Martinez de Pern was cut short today because according to the union chiefs the President was in a state of extreme fatigue and nervousness.

title: Sinai: Toward Peace?
description: As Egypt and Israel move toward their moment of decision on a new interim agreement across the Sinai Peninsula, serious questions are coming from all sides about whether this whole socalled peacemaking exercise has been worth the effort. Is anything of real value being accomplished to bring closer the day when Israel and the Arab states can live in peace?

title: Ismailia, Key City on Canal, Bustling As Ship Traffic Through Suez Rises
description: ISMAILIA, Egypt, July 17Ismailia, the headquarters of the Suez Canal Authority and the United Nations Emergency Force in Sinai, was bustling, thriving and even joyful today, with most of its citizens oblivious to the facts that the mandate for the force is in doubt and that a new EgyptianIsraeli disengagement agreement is hanging in the balance.

title: JOAN LITTLE LOSES A KEY TRIAL POINT
description: RALEIGH, N. C., July21Judge Hamilton H. Hobgood denied today a defense motion to sever a special prosecutor, hired by the family of Clarence Alligood, the slain jailer to aid the district attorney in the Joan Little murder cas, Miss Little a 21yearold black woman, is charged with killing Mr. Alligood in a jail cell in rural Beaufort County in 1974.

title: Canadian Ballerina Symbol of Change
description: As very possibly Rudolf Nureyev's favorite partner of the moment and as a 24yearold Canadian ballerina who has acquired an international reputation within the short span of two years, Karen Kain represents something new in Canada.

title: Big Board Short Interest Off Amex Up
5 Cosmos Put on Waivers As Team Fights Slump
description: The New York Cosmos, in third place in the Northern Division of the North American Soccer League, put five players, including three starters, on waivers yesterday and released another starter outright.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION RISES 3% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended July 19 rebounded to rtne fist time since the week ended June 14, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange generally declined yesterday following a showing of some strength at the opening of trading. Some buyers were discouraged by the move of the First National Bank of Chicago to increase its prime lending rate to 7 per cent, a move made several days ago by the First National City Bank of New York.

title: LOUIS SWIFT
description: Louis Swift, a leading distributor of outoftown newspapers, national magazines and paperback books in the San Francisco Bay area, died Thursday in San Francisco, where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: NEWFIGHTMAPPED ON BIRTH HAZARDS
description: A $20million program seeking to reduce deaths among mothers and babies and to lessen the impact of birth defects and other disabilities that may not show up until childhood or later in life was announced yesterday by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton. N.J.

title: 3 Lead With 72's In Jersey Tourney
description: EDISON, N. J., July 21Sloshing through casual water and often hitting into foggy fairways and high, wet rough, three professional golfers managed to match par 72 over the Plainfield Country Club course today and share the firstround lead in the rainplagued New Jersey open.

title: SENATE TAKING UP VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: WASHINGTON. July 21 (AP) The Senate voted, 63 to 13, tonight to take up a Housepassed bill to extend and broaden the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

title: Blyleven and Twins Defeat Yanks, 30
description: BLOOMINGTON, MM., July 21As the Yankees can attest after tonight's game, Bert Blyleven of the Minnesota Twins has recovered from the sore arm that troubled him last month.

title: RISE STEVENS NAMED MANNES PRESIDENT
description: Rise Stevens has been named president of the Mannes College of Music. Miss Stevens, the former Metropolitan Opera mezzosoprano, succeeds John Goldmark, who died last March. Since that time Hubert Doris, a board member, has been acting president of the school, which was founded in 1916 by David and Clara Damrosch Mannes.

title: Joyce Leads Westchester By a Stroke
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 21Tom Joyce of Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains took a oneshot lead in the 53d Westchester Open golf tournament today with a 34, 3771 at the Stanwich Club.

title: City's Fiscal Troubles Hurt Other Bond Sales
description: New York City's fiscal turmoil in recent months has put a damper on trading in the bonds and notes of other cities around the country.

title: Business Briefs
description: Ashland Oil, Inc., said yesterday that it would reconvene its annual meeting on Aug. 21. The meeting had been adjciurned on Jan. 30 to await completion of a report by a special committee of Ashland's directors on the company's political contributions.

title: Baker's Jet Role in Peril
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 21  The regulars finally made their appearance at the Jets camp today, and the popinga euphemism for headknockingdrowned out the airplanes overhead.

title: Rangers Dismiss Martin
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 21 (AP)Billy Martin, a tempestuous man known as baseball's street fighter, was dismissed as manager of the Texas Rangers today. He was replaced by Frank Lucchesi, the Rangers third base coach and a former manager of the Philadelphia Phillies. He guided the team tonight in a 60 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: DR.C.J. VANRONK, 87, TREATED ATHLETES
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 21 (AP)  Dr. Charles J. Van Ronk, an osteopathic physician known for restoring thousands of professional athletes to health, died Saturday in Norristown Hospital He was 87 years old.

title: Record Flood in Trenton Cuts Northeast Rail Service
description: TRENTON, July 21Record rains and the heaviest floods in 20 years inundated sections of Trenton today and severed Amtrak and Penn Central rail service along the Northeast Corridor, the country's busiest train route. The disruption was expected to last for days.

title: E. STANLEY PRATT
description: E. Stanley Pratt, a retired teacher at the Choate School in Wallingford, Conn., who had President Kennedy among his pupils in public speaking, died Sunday at the New Haven Graduates Club in New Haven, where he lived. He was 80 years old.

title: New Admintstration Plan For Oil Price Rise Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Administration is preparing to send to Congress within a few days a second, modified plan for gradually raising the price of domestic crude oil, according to Administration sources.

title: Solomon Scores 64, 62 Triumph
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)Harold Solomon of nearby Silver Spring, Md., opened his title defense in the $100,000 Washington Star international tennis tou???ment today with a 64, 62 victory over Steve Krulevitz of Baltimore.

title: SOVIET BUYS CORN AND BARLEY IN U.S.
description: For the second time in two weeks the Soviet Union has entered the United States grain market for sizable purchases, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterday.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Soviet Seeks to Purchase Mansion for a Consulate
description: The Soviet Government is negotiating to buy a turnofthe century Italianate mansion at 9 East 91st Street and to open a consulate on the site.

title: Richard R. Hobbins, 63 Law Partner Here, Dies
description: Richard R. Hobbins, counsel to Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolff, sirice he retired as a senior partner of the New York law firm in 1974, died Sunday at his home, 177 Gates Avenue, Montclair, N.J,. He was 63 years old.

title: SCALI REJOINING ABC NEWS STAFF
description: John A. Scali, former chief representative of the United States to the United Nations, will return to ABC News in September as a correspondent based in Washington, according to William Sheehan, president of ABC News.

title: Bridge:
description: Stay level with the opposition in the first half and race away in the stretch is a sound strategy in many competitive activities, and that was the plan adopted successfully by the winners of the Fun City regional knockout team championship at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday night.

title: Pornography Dealer's Tax Trial Told of Payoffs as Deductions
description: A jury was told yesterday that Martin J. Hodas, a major pornography operator in he Times Square area, had made large payoffs to protect his business from violence, apparently involving organized crime.

title: MARIAN BURGESS
description: Marian Bertha Templeton Burgess, a proofreader for The New York Times from 1930 to her retirement in 1969, died yesterday in the St. Elizabeth's division of St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. She was 89 years old and lived at 140 Seaman Avenue.

title: INDIAN CENSORSHIP UPSETS U.S.PRESS
description: The American press reacted with distaste and concern yesterday to India's press censorship guidelines for foreign reporters. But some news organization, indicated that they would sign a pledge to abide by the guidelines.

title: Text of Indian Censorship Guidelines for the Press
description: NEW DELHI, July 21Following is the official Englist text of Censorship Guidelines for the Press distributed to foreign correspondents today by the Press Information Bureau of India: [1]

title: Harold Lloyd Estate Going to Auctioneer.
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 21Next Sunday, in an elegant formal garden rimmed with olive trees and colorful blossoms, an auctioneer will point to someone, shout Sold! and thus one of the few remaining symbols of Hollywood's golden years will pass into the hands of the highest bidder.

title: Crime Rate in U.S. Increased by 18% In First 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  New Federal Bureau of Investigation statistics show that the nation's crime rate rose 18 per cent during the first three months of the year, compared with the similar period in 1974. Attorney General Edward H. Levi called the increase one of the terrifying facts of life.

title: L. F. Powell, 93. of Oxford; Librarian. Johnson Expert
description: L. F. Powell, librarian of the Taylor Institution at Oxford University from 1921 to 1949 and editor of the definitive ediltion of Boswell's Life of Johnlson, died Thursday in a nursling home in Banbury, England. He was 93 years old.

title: Lisbon Leaders Discuss Premier's Fate
description: LISBON, Tuesday, July 22Portugal's ruling body, the High Council of the Revolution, met last night to discuss the political fate of the Communistoriented Premier, Maj Gen Vasco Goncalves, whose ouster has been demanded by the Socialist party.

title: ARNO SCHEIDING
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 21Arno Scheiding, an industrial designer and artist, died last night at Norwalk hospital. His age was 65.. He lived at 142 Five Mile River Road, Darien.

title: Chess Browne Heads for World Title One Championship at a Time
description: The champion of the United States and of West Germany this year is one and the same manWalter Browne.

title: Key Testimony Due Today in Kent Trial
description: CLEVELAND, July 21 The civil suit brought by the parents of the four students slain and the nine wounded on May 4, 1970, on the Kent State University campus is nearing a climactic point after 10 weeks of testimony by 57 witnesses that has flied over 7,000 pages of testimony.

title: CORN, SOYBEANS AND WHEAT SOAR
description: Rumors of a pending corn sale to the Soviet Union combined with reports of continued deterioration of Russian crops and talk of dry weather in Iowa's corn areas sent prices sharply higher for corn, wheat and soybeans in commodities trading yesterday.

title: Sanitation Chief Says Tons of Garbage Are Uncollected as Result of Cutbacks
description: The city's Sanitation Commissioner said that about 1,200 tons of garbage was left uncollected on the city's streets yesterday and that he might have to readjust the severe cutbacks in collection service he instituted only last Friday.

title: Need Reform
description: If President Ford and Congress seriously intend to do something about the commissions, they have to recognize that the regulatory agencies must be treated individually. Moreover, there must be a willingnessof which we do not see much evidence in either the Ford Administration or in Congressto experiment boldly.

title: Ohioans Win Snipe Title
description: HENIERSON HARBOR, N. Y. July 21, (AP)Jerry Tompson and Ron Moore of Lodi, Ohio, won the North American Snipe class sailing championship yesterday. They tallied 29 points in seven races over four days. Don Hite and Don Hite Jr. of Detroit were second with 35 points.

title: Big Chicago Bank Joins Citibank in Move to 7% Prime Rate
description: The First National Bank of Chicago yesterday joined the First National City Bank at a 7 per cent level in its corporate base lending rate. Several other commercial banks, including the Bankers Trust Company, moved their prime lending rate up to the nowprevalent 7 per cent level.

title: 12 City Congressmen Ask U.S. To Pay Its Parking Fines Here
description: Twelve of 17 members of the city's Congressional delegation have called on the General Services Administration in Washington to approve the payment of parking fines incurred by Federal vehicles in New York City.

title: New Administration Plan. For Oil Price Rise Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Administration is preparing to send to Congress Within a few days a second, modified plan for gradually raising the price of domestic crude oil, according to Administration sources.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Switch From Grass to Dirt Cuts Feature to 4 Horses
description: A switch from the grass to the dirt track at Belmont Park yesterday resulted in only four horses competing in the main event on the card.

title: 2 SLAIN IN HOLDUP AT SUPERMARKET
description: The manager and the assistant manager of a Bronx supermarket were shot and killed at 9:15 last night in what the police described as a coldblooded execution by two holdup men who meticulously observed traffic regulations during a leisurely getaway by car.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: DPAtlanta 2, Montreal 2. LOBAtlanta 3, Montreal 5. 2BCorrell 2. HRE. Willlems (8). SCarter. SFFoll.

title: 2 HUNTS INDICTED WITH 5 IN DALLAS
description: DALLAS, July 21Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt, sons of the late oil billionaire H. L. Hunt, the Houston lawyer Percy Foreman and tour other men were indicted by a Federal grand jury tonight on charges of obstructing justice and impeding an investigation into a wiretape case involving the Hunts.

title: Giants Look Better Already
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 21  Clyde Powers moved from his strong safety spot toward the line of scrimmage and shouted Backer, to his defensive teammates.

title: Deprived Youngsters at Camp Blaze Trail Away From Trouble
description: PORT JERVIS, N.Y.Danny is 13 years old, has a cherubic face framed by long brown hair, and speaks his native Brooklynese. He is also, in the jargon of his social worker, a neglected and unwanted child, the kind of boy who may wind up in jailsomeday.

title: 30 Newark Strikers Seized In a SitIn at Blue Cross
description: NEWARK, July 21 (UPI)Policemen armed with nightsticks broke up a sitin by striking employes of New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shiel here today and arrested 30 persons.

title: Supercrisis
description: The state's Municipal Assistance CorporationBig Machas opened a critical dialogue with municipal labor leaders that could determine the fate of the corporation, and this stricken city.

title: Navy Missile Tests Hailed
description: ST. LOUIS, July 21 (UPI)The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced today that its Navy antiship harpoon missile had completed all but two of its 35 test launchings with an accuracy average of nearly 90 per cent.

title: Music: Mozart Festival
description: Summer comes officially on June 21, but there are those who refuse to believe that summer has really come to town until the start of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall. That makes it official. Last night the series, which started in 1966, opened its 1975 season to a soldout house and an adoring audience.

title: BRITISH AIDE RESIGNS OVER INFLATION PLAN
description: LONDON, Tuesday, July 22 A junior minister in the Labor party Government resigned last night as a protest against measures now being prepared to combat Britain's chronic inflation problems. The strict limit on pay increases that the Government envisages and the planned reductions in public expenditure will fall heavily on the working class, he said.

title: Panel says school Economies Could Save City $100Million
description: Greater teacher productivity and other economy measures, such as a reduction in free bus transportation for pupils, could save the city school system more than $100million a year, according to a group of education and business experts.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal District Court judge announced in Camden that he wanted six questions answered before he decided whether tolls over the Delaware River between New Jersey and the Philadelphia area should be trimmed from 65 cents to 55 cents. The judge, Stanley S. Brotman, posed the questions on costs and effects of service cuts to the Delaware River Port Authority, operator of the six bridges. The Federal Government has ordered the tolls cut, and Judge Brotman is deciding whether the Port Authority can refuse to obey the order, which came from the United States Transportation Department.

title: Decline is at 24.3%
Officials Uncertain What Will Happen if City Defaults
description: What will happen three weeks from Thursday when, if the Municipal Assistance Corporation fails to sell its second billion dollars in bonds, New York City runs short of cash to pay its daily bills?

title: Notes on People
description: Frances G. Knight, who has been chief of the United States Passport Office for sc. long that she has been compared to the late J. Edgar Hoover in survivability in government service, will be kept in her job, though she reaches the mandatory retirement age of 70 today. Her extension was granted by the Civil Service Commission and by her boss, Secretary of State Kissinger, after the commission decided that keeping her would be in the best interests of the United States. Mr. Kissinger's office sent her a framed document granting her the extension, for one year, last Friday.

title: Many Refugees Are Reluctant to Leave the Security of 4 Camps and Be Resettled
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 21The effort to resettle more than 130,000 Vietnamese and Cambodians has run into a new problema growing reluctance of many refugees to leave the relative familiarity and security of the four military bases in this country in which they are being housed.

title: Festival Shirts Mostly Mozart, With a Haydn Go Seek Button
description: Pinchas Zukerman was wearing a Tshirt. Not only was he wearing a Tshirt, he was wearing it backward, allowing the image of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart to stare intensely at the noontime audience while Mr. Zukerman, a violinist, conducted.

title: Postal Unions Get 3Year Pact: $1,500 and LivingCost Clause
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Postal workers won a threeyear contract.that will provide scheduled raises  totaling $1,500 over three years continued costofliving increases and a guarantee against layoffs, postal sources said.

title: Mrs. Corliss Lamont, Author, Economist and Educator, Dead
description: Helen Lamb Lamont, an economist, author and educator and the wife of Dr. Corliss Lamont, author and former Columbia University lecturer, died yesterday of cancer in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 69 years old and had homes here, in Ossining, N.Y., and in Maine.

title: Open Interest
description: In contract (Friday)

title: Senate Moves on Mathews
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee unanimously recommended today that Mr. David Mathews, the 39yearold president of the University of Alabama, be confirmed as the next Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Wellfare. If confirmed by the full Senate, he would succeed Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: BURLINGTON OMITS QUARTERLY DIVIDEND
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., which last Friday announced a $10.4million net loss for the second quarter, said yesterday directors had voted to omit the quarterly dividend on Sept. 2??? and that its top executives were taking salary reductions of between 5 and 10 per cent.

title: BISHOP BLANKINGSHIP
description: RICHMOND, July 21 (AP)The Right Rev. Alexander Hugo Blankingship, Episcopal Bishop of Cuba from 1939 until his retirement in 1961, died today at a hospital here.

title: Catholic Women and the Klan
description: By now the women's liberation movement has been both deified and denounced, usually excessively and always shrilly. In the home, women are accused of wanting to wear the pants; in the churches, of wanting to wear albs; and now it seems, some want to wear sheets.

title: 17 Injured as Explosion Rocks Loading Area at United Parcel
description: An explosion shook the loading area of a United Parcel Service building last night, injuring 17 employes, one seriously when he was thrown 30 feet by the blast, losing his right eye.

title: Gold Bricks Used to Build Up a Race
description: Shortly before noon yesterday, a Brinks armored truck drove into Shubert Alley between West 44th and 45th Streets. Out stepped three guards with 38caliber pistols, carrying a heavy wooden case, which they brought into Ma Bell's Restaurant.

title: Impasse on Oil
description: The politicallymotivated impasse between congress and President Ford on control of domestic petroleum prices is threatening to leave the country and the consumer in an intolerable situation.

title: State Jobless Rate in June Stayed Unchanged at 13%
description: TRENTON, July 21 (AP)The unemployment rate in New Jersey remained at 13 per cent in June, unchanged from the previous month.

title: Daughter of Onassis Expected to Marry
description: Christina Onassis, the 24yearold daughter of the late Aristotle Onassis and heiress to one of the largest fortunes in the world, will marry Alexander Andreadis, the youngest son of a Greek shipping family that had once been in competition with her father's shipping business, a relative of the Onassis family said yesterday.

title: Weinberger, Leaving the Government, Deplores Escalating Costs of Welfare
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21Caspar W. Weinberger will leave government Aug. 10, somewhat melancholy about where the nation's commitment to social welfare will lead, but with enough anecdotes about Ronald Reagan, Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford to dine out on for the rest of his life.

title: Harold Lloyd Estate Going on the Block
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 21Next Sunday, in an elegant formal garden rimmed with olive trees and colorful blossoms, an auctioneer will point to someone, shout Sold! and thus one of the few remaining symbols of Hollywood's golden years will pass into the hands of the highest bidder.

title: TIMES COMPANY HAS PROFIT DROP
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported that consolidated net income for the second quarter was $4.6million, or 42 cents a share, down 32.5 per cent from the $6.8million, 160 cents a share, earned in the second quarter of 1974.

title: Discovery of Body Buried in 167 B.C. Reported by China
description: HONG KONG, July 21Chinese archeologists have discovered the wellpreserved body of a man believed to have been buried in 167 B.C. along with large quantities of lacquerware, miniature wooden figures, food and writing utensils.

title: Floating of Dollar Defended by Simon
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon presented to Congress today a strong defense of a floating exchange rate for the dollar and said the United States would never accept a new international obligation to return to a fixed exchange value against other currencies.

title: Film: Holmes Nostalgia:'Hound' on Bill With First-Rate Keaton
description: The first bit in a program of Sherlock Holmes nostalgia at the D. W. Griffith Theater is an old filmed interview with Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Stout, mustached and affable, the 68-year-old author made it clear what some people had always suspected: it was Watson who invented Holmes. In any case, Sir Arthur was mainly interested in talking about psychic research.People wanted to know what happened to the generation of young Englishmen who died in World War II, he said. "Are they dissipated into nothing," he inquired, patting his dog, "or are they still the grand fellows we used to know?"It wasn't Sir Arthur's ghosts that made a success of haunting: it was his stories. "Sherlock Holmes" is on Broadway, tourists still go on forlorn searches up Baker Street, Gene Wilder is filming Holmes's younger brother in London and Lord Olivier will tackle Moriarty this fall.The centerpiece of the Holmes's film program is the 1939 Darryl F. Zanuck production of "The Hound of the Baskervilles." It isn't a great picture. It isn't even a great mediocre picture, but it is a good mediocre picture, and perhaps they made better mediocre pictures in those days than they do now.Dartmoor, the funereal setting for "The Hound," may be partly painted backdrop but they roll in enough studio fog to do "Wuthering Heights twice. Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce play Holmes and Watson with comic exaggeration. It is a serious kind of comic exaggeration. It lets you watch it. It doesn't spoof itself: it doesn't wink at you and tell you that it's really just as sophisticated as you are and knows it is making a fool of itself down there on the screen.The hound is just a large ugly dog, but it manages to be quite as frightening as the mechanical floor waxer in a white shark suit that plays the lead in "Jaws," and a lot less gory.And then there are the phrases. "Mr. Holmes, you're the only man in all England who can help me." "I'm in mortal fear Sir Henry's life will be snuffed out." "They were the footprints of a gigantic Hound." "Watson, keep your eye on that hansom." "That's what I hate about his moor, there's always something strange." And, of course: "Oh Watson, the needle."It's like the tunessingable with a life of their ownthat pop out of Gilbert and Sullivan.Some of the audiences leaves after "The Hound," and the usher urges them back to their seats. He's right: the last picture in the program is a 45-minute Buster Keaton classic."Sherlock Junior" is not really a Sherlock Holmes picture. It is about a movie projectionist (Keaton) who wants to be a detective, courts a girl, is thrown out after a rival steals her father's watch and lays the blame on him, falls asleep while projecting a picture and dreams himself into the picture. There he becomes Sherlock Holmes, frustrates the scoundrels and wins the girl.If it's not quite the masterpiece that "The General" or "The Navigator" is, it is still first-rate Keaton. That is, it is both disciplined and wild. The major part of the picture, where in his dream he literally walks down the aisle, climbs into the screen and joins the plot as Holmes, is full of marvelous chases, escapes and battles with exploding billiard balls.But the quieter bits are even better. For example, he sweeps out the theater and finds in the debris two or three dollar bills that will allow him to buy candy for his girl. The customers return one by one to claim them. One is an old woman who comes up weeping. With agony he yields up the dollar bill to her. She takes it and yields her handkerchief to him.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9;00 A.M: TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (701) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95100; NASSAU CO. (561) 740500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3407767.

title: Books of The Times
description: An anecdote  according to Prof. James Sutherland of University College, London is what the Oxford English Dictionary says it is: the narrative of a detached incident, or of a single event, told as being in itself interesting or striking. A literary.

title: Controls Over Foreign Newsmen Tightened 3 Are Expelled
description: NEW DELHI, July 21 The Government adopted a tougher position today on news dispatches filed by the several dozen foreign correspondents who are here to cover the country's continuing political crisis.

title: BOB DYLAN MAKES OTHER END SCENE
description: The names posted outside the Other End in Greenwich Village last week were certainly not ones that would excite the general listening public. How many people, after all, are familiar with the music of Rusty Weir, Jake and the Family Jewels and Bobby Neuwirth?

title: Librarian of Congress
description: President Ford has selected the American historian Daniel J. Boorstin to be Librarian of Congress. As scholar, writer and director of the Smithsonian Museum of History and Technology, Dr. Boorstin would bring to the post the kind of distinction and cultural enthusiasm that graced it most notably under Archibald MacLeish.

title: Pennsylvania States Offices Operating After Walkout
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 21 (AP)For the first time in almost three weeks, all state offices in Pennsylvania were operating on a normal schedule today.

title: BIG GRAIN CONCERN INDICTED WITH 13 IN EXPORT THEFTS
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 21A Federal grand jury indicted the Bunge Corporation, one of the world's largest grain companies, and 13 present and former executives and employes today on charges of conspiracy to steal grain by shortweighting shipments and conspiracy to cover up the thefts.

title: Geologists Warn. Research Lag Impedes U.S. Resources Plans
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Geologists from industry and from the academic community warned at a meeting today that rational use of the nation's dwindling resources was imperifed by inadequate knowledge of what remains as well as of ore formation and of heat resources within the earth.

title: Half is Up 30.37%
description: The Kraftco Corporation, the world's largest processor of dairy and packaged food products, reported yesterday a sharp recovery in profits with the second quarter up by 208.5 per cent and the half up by 30.3 per cent from a year ago.

title: Advertising
description: For a number of years businessmen  including ad agency executives  have been urging groups of their fellows to do something to educate the masses to the benefits of the freeenterprise system.

title: Belgium Mourns Merckx Defeat
description: BRUSSELS, July 21The defeat of Eddy Merckx yesterday in the Tour de France, the world's most prestigious bicycling race, has plunged this country into a state of national mourning.

title: ELIZABETH SUTLIFFE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 21  Elizabeth M. Sutliffe, who with her husband, John, operated the Greenwich real estate firm of Sutliffe Associates, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. She lived at 361 North Maple Avenue.

title: Family in LSD Case Gets Ford Apology
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 President Ford personally apologized today to the family of Frank R. Olson, who is said to have died after he was given a dose of LSD by Central Intelligence Agency agents in 1953.

title: Stock Exchange Suspends Thading in Penn Fruit Co,
description: The New York Stock Exchange suspended trading yesterday in the Penn Fruit Company, effective at the close of trading on Friday. The exchange also said it would ask that the company's common stock be taken off the Big Board.

title: ROSE CANTOR SEGAL
description: Rose Cantor Segal, who served on the boards of the Home for the Jewish Aged in Philadelphia and the Philadelphia Geriatric Center, died yesterday in Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 88 years old and lived at Rittenhouse Plaza. Mrs. Segal was the widow of Samuel I. Segal, a manufacturer and distributor of furniture and bedding.

title: Stage: Rip Van Winkle
description: Several seasons ago the Joseph Jefferson Theater Company, an admirable Off Off Broadway theater (founded by Cathy Roskam), situated in the Little Church Around the Corner, rediscovered Rip Van Winkle. This is the Dion Boucicault 1864 adaptation of the Washington Irving Sketch Book tale, as made popular on stage by Joseph Jefferson, the actor, in the late 19th century.

title: Trends in Portugal Worrying Azores
description: PONTA DELGADA, Azores (AP)Independence from Portugal is being openly considered in the Azores, but political and military leaders predict that the final break will not come unless there is a virtual Communist takeover in Lisbon.

title: Westbury Opens Minus The Double
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 21In perfect weather conditions that George Morton Levy, its 85yearold president said he had put in a special order for, Roosevelt Raceway opened its 72night summer meeting tonight.

title: Du Pont Profit Plunges 81.9%
description: The nation's largest chemical company, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., reooported yesterday a drop of 81.9 per cent in second  quarter earnings. Sales were down only marginally from a year ago.

title: Aluminum Supplies Tied to Price Rises
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Unless the aluminum industry is allowed to raise prices and improve profits, the nation faces a severe shortage of aluminum in years ahead, the president of Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation told the Ford Administration today.

title: Robin Wins TransAtlantic Race
description: PORTSMOUTH, England, July 21 (UPI)Robin, the new robinegg blue sloop from Marblehead, Mass., won the transAtlantic race from Newport, R.I., today by beating Kialoa, which had been first to finish, by 65 minutes on corrected time.

title: State of Emergency Is Condemned as Special Session is Opened
description: NEW DELHI, July 21Opposition members today condemned the Indian Government's sweeping state of emergency as the Parliament reconvened in a special session to vote on it.

title: Reds Show Off Power, Rout Phils, 104
description: The Big Red Machine, otherwise known as the Cincinnati Reds, once again demonstrated its power last night in a rout of the Phillies, 104, in Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium.

title: U.N. Agrees to Ask Egyptians to Renew Sinai Peace Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21The Security Council voted 13 to 0 tonight, with two members not participating, to appeal to Egypt to reconsider and consent to extension of the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sinai.

title: CANADA BIDS U.N. POSTPONE PARLEY
description: OTTAWA, July 21Canada has asked the United Nations to postpone an international conference on crime and penology that had been scheduled to open in Toronto in September. The request followed long and bitter controversy here over the possible presence of an observer delegation from the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Soviet Oil'Output a Record
description: MOSCOW, July 21 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union's central statistical agency said today oil production in the first half of 1975 set a record of 240 million tons. In 1974 the Soviet Union overtook the United States to become the world's major oil producer with an output of 459 million tons  nine million more than the United States and the officially proclaimed target this year is 489.4 million tons.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Egyptian March, Strauss; Viola Concerto in C, Vanhal; Symphony No. 3, Schubert.

title: Senators Seek to Cut Jordan Arms Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Administration was under Congressional pressure today to compromise on a proposed $350million sale of airdefense weapons to Jordan by scaling down the size of the transaction.

title: 0.E.C.D. Says Recovery May Be Weak
description: PARIS, July 21A top Western economic body warned today that the recovery now under way in the nonCommunist industrial nations may prove to be too weak to be selfsustaining.

title: Controls Over Foreign Newsmen Tightened 3 Are Expelled
description: NEW DELHI, July 21  The Government adopted a tougher position today on news dispatches filed by the several dozen foreign correspondents who are here to cover the country's continuing political crisis.

title: Northwest Energy Offers $25 a Share For Apco Oil Stock
description: The Northwest Energy Company of Salt Lake City raised yesterday its bid for the Apco Oil Corporation to $25 a share for up to 1.5 million shares. It also amended its offer in some other respects. Northwest EnerMerger gy's bid tops the News $23.50 bid made last week by Alaska Interstate Company of Houston. The Alaska Interstate bid topped Northwest Energy's original bid of $20 a share.

title: Soyuz Crew Lands Safely After Very Hard Flight
description: MOSCOW, July 21The two Soviet astronauts of Soyuz 19 touched down safely in a billowing cloud of dust on the steppes of Soviet Central Asia today, successfully winding up their rendezvous in space with the American Apollo astronauts.

title: Israel Awaits Response
description: JERUSALEM, July 21The Israeli Government is hopeful that its latest proposals for a new interim agreement with Egypt will elicit a generally positive response from Egypt this week, opening the way for another diplomatic shuttle by Secretary of State Kissinger some time in August.

title: FORD'S EUROPE TRIP TO START SATURDAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The White House announced today that President Ford would leave Saturday on a 10day trip to Europe that will include four days in Helsinki, Finland, for the closing session of the European security conference.

title: 10 Men on a Horse at Monticello
description: The owners of Golden Fulla Farms were surrounded by harnessracing people with farms that are farms.

title: Steingues Inquiry Seeks To Get Bank Law Changes
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut is seeking changes in banking laws by opening an inquiry into the banks current practices regarding controversial city and state bond sales.

title: Many Find That Mail is Just a Nuisance
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 Sarah Boling was rather looking forward to a nationwide mail strike today and she was disappointed to see her mailbox fill up anyway after the unions reached an agreement with the United Statec Postal Service.

title: 1959 F.B.I. Search of Room Of a Newsman is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation entered the Washington hotel room of a reporter in 1959 to search his belongings for clues to his news sources and for evidence of impropriety in his personal life, acording to a wellplaced source with direct knowledge of the operation.

title: Osteopaths Fill Post
description: CHICAGO, July 22 (AP)Dr. George J. Luibel of Fort Worth, Tex., was named presidentelect today of the American Osteopathic Association, Dr. Earl A. Gabriel of Allentown, Pa., was installed as president, succeeding Dr. Paul E. Wilson of Ocala, Fla. Dr. Dale Dodson of Northfield, Minn., was named first vice president, Dr. D. S. Strickland of Tucker, Ga., second vice president, and Dr. Eugene Sikorski of Pontiac, Mich., third vice president.

title: Kiefer Leads Jersey Open by a Stroke
description: EDISON, N. J., July 22Jack Kiefer decided two weeks ago that he would attack the 7,000  yard Plainfield Country Club course during the New Jersey open golf championship. And today the commitment seemed to be paying off as the Emerson Country cam pro moved into a onestroke lead at the halfway mark of the 72hole tourney with his second straight 72 for a 144 total.

title: Yesterday's Results at Delaware
description: FIRSTS4,000, cl., 3Y0 and up, 6f.

title: CLOSE MANDEL AIDE CITED ON 51 COUNTS
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 22A former campaign manager of Gov. Marvin Mandel who heads the state's SIbillion school construction program was indicted today on 51 counts of forgery and embezzlement of state funds.

title: Healthier Than Life Itself
description: 100% natural. No artificial anything. None of today's additives. No mystery ingredients.

title: Slade Rock Group, At Schaefer Fete, Proves Puzzling
description: Slade, the hardrocking British quartet, was supposed to be the new sensation just a few years ago. But British chartbusters have had trouble with the vast American market in the nineteenseventies, and the group hasn't performed in this country for two years. Monday night it was back, at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park, and the impression once again was puzzling.

title: Local Labor Party Clash Highlights Tssue of VVhc Runs British Politics
description: LONDON, July 22Tomorrow night 57 men and women will gather in a shabby hall in the East London constituency of Newham NorthEast to decide the fate of one of Prime Minister Ha'old Wilson's senior ministers.

title: Ford to Visit Portland
description: PORTLAND, Me., July 22 (UPI)President Ford will visit Portland on Aug. 30 and also may stop in Augusta, the Republican party state chairman, John R. Linnell, announced today. Mr. Linnell said the President would take part in a fundraising luncheon in Portland and might make an appearance at the A.F.L.C.I.O. Field Day in Augusta.

title: NURSING HOME SHUT BY A STATE AGENCY
description: ALBANY, July 22 (AP)The State Health Department said today that it had suspended the license of the Canajoharie Nursing Home in Montgomery County and ordered the immediate removal of all patients.

title: FORD IS REBUFFED BY HOUSE OIL VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 The House of Representatives, by a vote of 262 to 167, rejected today President Ford's proposal to allow the average price of oil produced in the United States to rise by more than 60 per cent over the next 30 months.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
description: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: Army is Said to Be Using Military Personnel in Current Tests of 2 Drugs That Can Cause Hallucinations
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Army is currently testing on military personnel at the Edgewood Arsenal in Maryland two drugs that can cause hallucinations, Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk, said today.

title: Imbalance on Arms
description: As United States policy aims at reduction of tensions in the Sinai, another Ford Administration decision could actually intensify the military pressures on Israel from her northern and western frontiers. This is the plan, now under strong challenge in Congress, to sell $350million worth of sophisticated antiaircraft technology Jordan.

title: People in Sports
description: The successor to Bill Martin as manager of the Texas Rangers slipped unobtrusively into the new role. It all happened so fast, said Frank Lucchesi, who managed the Philadelphia Phillies for 2 years and was serving as the Rangers thirdbase coach when Martin was dismissed.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Entertainment Events Today

title: CITY AND UNIONS UNABLE TO AGREE ON FISCAL REMEDY
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Beame, officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the leaders of the city labor unions met throughout yesterday but, with barely two weeks remaining before the next scheduled Municipal Assistance Corporation bond sale, there appeared no solution for the City's crisis that all parties could support.

title: Citizenship is Voted For Robert E. Lee
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Robert E. Lee won his final skirmish of the Civil War today as Congress agreed to restore his citizenship.

title: People and Business
description: President Ford announced yesterday the nomination of Edwin Yeo (pronounced Yoh) a Pittsburgh hank economist, to be Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs.

title: Italy's Dominant Party Deposes Its Leader in Wake of Setbacks
description: ROME, July 22Amintore Fanfani, the leader of Italy's governing Christian Democratic party, was voted out of office tonight by his party's National Council.

title: METHADONE CENTER FACES LICENSE LOSS
description: Dr. Seymour Joseph, deputy commissioner in the State Office of Drug Abuse Services, reported yesterday that his agency had moved to revoke the license of a private methadone treatment center in downtown Manhattan for failing to comply with state regulations.

title: JOSEPH G. M'GANN
description: Joseph G. McGann, controller of Rodermond Industries, Inc.Gallagher Brothers Sand and Gravel, Jersey City, died Friday at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L. I. He lived in West Hempstead, L. I.

title: Opening Political Travels, Rockefeller Says Republicans Can Ill Afford Fight Over Ticket
description: CINCINNATI, July 22Vice President Rockefeller, opening an extensive new schedule of political travels, told reporters today that the Republican party could ill afford a fight over its 1976 ticket.

title: LOBBYING INTENSE ON AID TO TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 GreekAmericans and their allies engaged in intensive lobby ing on Capitol Hill today to prevent the Ford Administration from resuming arms shipments to Turkey.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesda;.

title: Colt by Graustark Is Sold for $410,000
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 22 (AP)T. M. Evans, the buyer for Buckland Farm of Gainesville, Va., paid $410,000 tonight at the annual Keeneland yearling sales for a chestnut colt by Graustark out of Eastern Princessa daughter of Nasrullah.

title: Wilson Plan to Curb Pay Rises Endorsed in House of Commons
description: LONDON, July 22Prime Minister Harold Wilson's plan to combat inflation by limiting pay increases to a maximum of $13.20 a week was endorsed tonight by the House of Commons.

title: William A. Lyon is Dead at 72; ExState Banks Superintendent
description: William A. Lyon, State Banking Superintendent from 1950 to 1954 and chairman of the Dry Dock Savings Bank from 1966 until his retirement in 1970, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N.Y., of complications following a heart attack May 8. He was 72 years old and lived at 58 Hemlock Drive, North Tarrytown.

title: Strike in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, July 22 (UPI)A strike by 3,600 technical, clerical and bluecollar city employes was in its second day with no new negotiations ???

title: GanCarrying Legislator Shot in Dispute at Home
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 22 State Representative Ray Burgess, who three months ago bowed to pressure from colleagues to stop bringing a pistol onto the floor of the State Legislature, was critically wounded early today by a pistol shot in the head after a domestic dispute at his home near Anniston. He was taken to Birmingham for surgery and doctors described his condition as guarded.

title: 10 JAILED BY SPAIN IN 1972 LABOR RIOTS
description: MADRID, July 22A political court sentenced 10 persons to imprisonment for up to seven years today for taking part in labor riots three years ago.

title: Pele Drills; Found Fit For Action
description: The New York Cosmos yesterday hact more than one good reason to cheer about tonight's North American Soccer League game against the San Jose Earthquakes at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: Bid to Oust U2 Fails
description: LONDON, July 22 (Reuters)The British Government today rejected a call from a leftwing Labor Member of Parliament to suspend facilities in Britian for American U2 aircraft. The Government denied suggsetions that the planes were engaged in spying activities.

title: ARMY ANNOUNCES PRODUCTION SLASH
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Army announced today a sharp cutback in ammunition production and said that more than 12,000 civilian workers would eventually be laid off as a result.

title: SAUDIS REASSURE PARIS ON OIL PRICE
description: PARIS, July 22  Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia told President Valery Giscard d'Estaing today that the oil producers did not plan to raise prices again later this year if currency rates in the West were stabilized, according to a senior French official.

title: Federal Law Agency Struck By Bombs in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (UPI)Two powerful bombs apparently set by an underground terrorist group, shattered offices of a Federal law enforcement agency on the 34th floor of a downtown skyscraper last night, causing more than $250,000 damage.

title: Tackson TV Unit May Be 25% Black
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Television Channel 3 in Jackson, Miss., whose previous operator lost its license on the ?round of racial discrimination, may be taken over by a new corporation with about 25 per cent black ownership.

title: SOYUZ CREW EAGER FOR ANOTHER FLIGHT
description: MOSCOW, July 22 (UPI)The Soyuz 19 crew, Col. Aleksei A. Leonov and Valery N. Kubasov, elated after their flawless plunge back to earth after linking up in orbit with Apollo, say they're eager to do it over again.

title: ADM. W. R. CARTER EXPERT ON SUPPLY
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., July 22 (AP)Rear Adm. Worrall Reed Carter died yesterday in the Portsmouth Naval Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: C.I.A. Kept Data Secret On Possible Agent Crimes
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Central Intelligence Agency withheld from the Justice Department on at least nine occasions over the last 20 years information about possible criminal violations committed by C.I.A. employes, according tc agency documents made public today.

title: Klein Seeks Bonds For Sewer Project In. Suffolk County
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 22Citing sharply rising costs, John* V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, announced today that the county would haveio issue bonds to raise additional money for the controversial $641million Southwest Sewer District, the largest publicworks project on Long Island.

title: Guerrilla Group in Argentina Calls for Mrs. Peron's Ouster
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 22 The political arm of the largest deftwing Peronist guerrilla group called today for the resignation of President Isabel Martinez de Peron and new elections in Argentina.

title: Heavy Rain Slows Essential Services rn Nigerian Capital
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 22linusually heavy rains have disrupted essential services in this: coastal city.

title: $12,000 QUARTER NET AT EASTERN AIRLINES
description: A $2.5million profit for June enabled Eastern Airlines to report yesterday a $12,000 profit for the second quarter and Ec net income of $153,000 for the first half this year. In the second quarter last year Eastern had a profit of $12.2million; its first half net in 1974 was $10.6million.

title: ModernDay Paul Bunyans Commute to Their Forests
description: NOYO, CalifPaul Runyan is dead.

title: Bid for Vice Presidency
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 22 (AP)Mayor Charles B. Wheeler Jr. of Kansas City says he is a candidate for the Democratic VicePresidential nomination. Mayors are the coming thing, IMr. Wheeler said last night after making the announcement on an educational television station here. As far as I can Jell I am the only Missourian running for the Vice Presidency.

title: U.S. Girl Is Victor In Swim
description: CALI, Colombia, July 22 (UPI)Kathy Heddy of the Central Jersey Athletic Club upset the worldrecord holder, Ulrike Tauber of East Germany, in the final tonight and won the gold medal in the women's 200meter individual medley at the world aquatic championships.

title: HUSSEIN'S RATING WITH ARABS SOARS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 21 King Hussein of Jordan, long the odd man out in the Arab world, has lately struck a comfortable, advantageous balance with Egypt and Syria as the process of Middle Eastern peace negotiations unfolds.

title: Bridge:
description: Italy seems bent on demonstrating that it can leave most of its best players at home and still carry off the European Bridge Championship title.

title: KENT TRIAL HEARS GUARD'S EXCHIEF
description: CLEVELAND, July 22The former top officer of the Ohio National Guard and his immeIdiate assistant testified today Mat the trial in the civil suit brought by the victims of the shootings at Kent State University on May 4, 1970.

description: (OTB Payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Red Smith
description: There were salmon in Butler's Pool, John Sullivan said, but if you had been here three years ago it would fairly break your heart to see it now. Three years ago, John said, you could walk across the river on fish, but that was before the Government relaxed the restrictions on netting around Castlecove over beyond Hog's Head. The worst of it was, this was the nest year TOr salmon in long while. By the last count he had heard, 32,000 fish had been killed in Galway, 7,000 in one night, and it was certain the catch down here in County Sports Kerry would pass 75,000. And all of them taken before they could get into the of rivers to spawn. John Sullivan is Jack MulThe Times cahy's ghillie, and as he talked he rigged flyrods for a couple of guests in Mulcahy's Waterville Lake Hotel. You've got to get us invited that place where they keep salmon tethered to stakes, one of them had told Fred Corcoran before leaving the United States. Jack Mulcahy's? Fred had said. Golf promoter nonpareil, Corcoran has threeputted in 47 countries. Naturally, he is a friend of Mulcahy, the IrishAmerican who made his stack in New York and now invested in Irish properties. Consider it done, Fred said, and it was.

title: Olsons Reveal That Ford Told C.I.A. to Yield Data
description: President Ford has instructed the Central Intelligence Agency to make available to the family of Frank R. Olson all relevant materials and documents concerning his death and the agency's LSD drug experiment in which he participated shortly before his death, family members said yesterday.

title: Too Much Energy, Too Soon
description: BERKELEY, Calif. The United States is threatened far More by the hazards of too much energy, too soon, than by the hazards of too little, too late.

title: U.S. Says Coors Owes $5.1Million in Taxes
description: DENVER, July 22 (UPI)The United States court of appeals for the 10th circuit said today the Adolph Coors Company owes the Government $5.1million in back taxes for understating income in 1965 and 1966.

title: Copper Prices Cited
description: The Anaconda Company lost $13.7million in the second quarter in contrast to net income of $51.7million, of $2.34 a share, after a $16.9million tax credit a year earlier, the copper producer reported yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Mayor Beame leading a meeting in his City Hall office.

title: The Other Monsieur Giscard
description: PARISThe President of France, generally known by his countrymen as Giscard, would be surprised td know his capital is also inhabited by another ambitious political leader who for most of the 21 years he has been a Parisian carried false identity papers with the alias Giscard.

title: Power Failure Interrupts IND Service for 2 Hours
description: A power failure interrupted service on the IND subway in. Manhattan and the Bronx for two hours last night. A Transit Authority spokesman said that police and firemen removed hundreds of riders from four stalled trains. There was no report of injuries.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium. Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street. Flushing Meadow, Queens, 6:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8:05 P.M. (RadioWNEW, 8 P.M.)

title: BRITISH STEEL SEES BIG LOSS FOR YEAR
description: LONDON, July 22The huge, Government  owned British Steel Corporation, the leading steel producer in Europe, is losing money at a rate of $572million a year, the company disclosed today.

title: Never Again? Well, Hardly Ever
description: The guest strikes back

title: How to Cook Corn on Cob
description: Add enough water to a kettle to cover the shucked corn. Do not add salt but bring the water to the boil. Add the corn and cover. When the water returns to the boil, remove the kettle from the heat. Let the corn stand in the water five to 10 minutes and serve immediately without further cooking.

title: Record Lottery Income
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 22 (AP) The New Hampshire Sweepstakes Commission says it has earned a record $4.2million in lottery income for state public school districts in the fiscal year 1975. The figure represents an 88 per cent increase from the distribution of $2.23million in the fiscal year 1974.

title: Gregory of Giants Has Leaner and Hungrier Look
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., July 22Jack Gregory labored through the final few steps of a 300yard interval training drill today that is designed to increase the endurance of New York Giant football players.

title: Christina Onassis is Unexpectedly Wed To a G reek Banking and Shipping Scion
description: GLYPHADA, Greece, July 22Christina Onassis married, Alexandros Andreadis tonight in a tiny chapel overlooking this seaside suburb of Athens, uniting two of Greece's great fortunes.

title: Ozawa Quits as Director Of the San Franciscans
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP)Seiji Ozawa announced his resignation Sunday as music director of the San Francisco Symphony after the 197576 season. But he said he would accept the new post of musical adviser for the 197677 season and spend 10 weeks here as euest conductor.

title: FRENCH DRIVE ON TO REDUCE WASTE
description: PARIS, July 22The French Government declared war on waste today with a program that could force profound changes in the consumer goods industry.

title: J. M. Bernstein Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for Joseph M. Bernstein, the translator and editor, will be held Friday at 1:30 P.M. at the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street. Mr. Bernstein, who was 56 years old, died July 11.

title: White House Says Pad Won't Settle Borders in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The White House maintained today that the European security agree ment to be signed next week by President Ford and 34 other heads of state in no way legally settles borders in Eastern Europe.

title: Street Sweepers Get Raise
description: SAN FRANCISCO July 22 (UPI)This city's celebrated $17,000ayear street sweepers soon will be $19,000ayear.

title: News Summary and Index
description: India's upper house of Parliament gave its expected overwhelming approval to Prime Minister Gandhi's sweeping emergency powers, and the main opposition parties then walked out in a boycott of the session, called to ratify the state of emergency. An opposition member said the session could not function as a free and democratic Parliament. He cited the suspension of rules under which members could queation Cabinet ministers, and the Government's decision to apply to speeches in Parliament the ban on publishing statements by the opposition. The ban applies also to foreign publications but a number of correspondents reported them anyway. Two British journalists and one American left under an expulsion order early yesterday. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: FloodedOut Trentonians Return Home
description: TRENTON, July 22Hundreds of local residents returned to their homes and rail service through the Northeast Corridor was restored today following a flash flood here yesterday that disrupted rail and bus traffic and forced people to flee to drier areas.

title: SELLOFFS ON AMEX SEND PRICES DOWN
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped sharply yesterday under the impact of selling by investors concerned in k recent days over the increase in the prime lending rate by some leading banks and by the sharp increase announced yesterday in the consumer price index.

title: Cut in Planned Sale Of Arms to Jordan Arranged in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July. 22The State Department and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tentatively agreed today to scale down the proposed sale of air defenses system to Jordan.

title: SOVIET AND COOK IN 2D MEAT DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) A major American grain trading company, Cook Industries, Inc., has sold an additional 36.7 bushels of wheat to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Federal Reserve Board reaffirmed today its 1969 policy statement asking member banks not to solicit or accent deposits at their foreign branches from residents of the United States.

title: Soviet Buys Wheat
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 36.7 million bushels of wheat from Cook Industries, Inc., bringing its total purchases of American grain this year to 381.7 million bushelsjust under the 389 million bushels forecast by the Department of Agriculture as the maximum it might buy. Page 55.

title: ALCOA INSISTENT ON RAISING PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The aluminum industry may push through two price increases this year, despite Government warnings that they could fuel inflation, the chairman of the Aluminum Company of America said today.

title: Yankees Win, 116
description: CHICAGO, July 22  The Yankees, spraying singles and doubles to all parts of the spacious outfield at 65yearold Sox Stadium overwhelmed Chicago 116, tonight.

title: SENATE REJECTS BID BY SOUTH ON VOTING
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Senate today defeated a move by Southern Senators that would have expanded coverage of the Voting Rights Act, passed in 1965, to all parts of the country.

title: URSULA B. AINSWORTH
description: Ursula B. Ainsworth, staff assistant to the regional commissioner of the Customs Service, Idled yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital.

title: Meeting of Amax Backs a Sale of Shares
description: Despite picketing by a handful of members of the United Mine Workers of America and the pleas of union lawyers, stockholders of Amax, Inc., overwhelmingly approved yesterday the purchase of a 19.9 per cent interest in their company by the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: Widow, 77, Is Found Strangled In Ransacked Brooklyn Home
description: A 77yearold widow living in a quiet, residential Brooklyn neighborhood, was found strangled yesterday morning in her fiveroom, firstfloor apartment, which had been ransacked.

title: Tomahawks Take First
description: UNIONDAL, L.I., July 22The Long Island Tomahawks, with four goals by Jimmy Johnston, scored a 2211 victory over the Quebec Caribous in the National Lacrosse League tonight before 3,482 fans at Nassau Colikum. The victory moved the Tomahawks into first place in, the Northern Division.

title: ROBERT SEITEL
description: Robert Seitel, founder and former president of the Air Freight Forwarders Association of New York, died Sunday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He was 54 years old, and lived on Jones Road, Englewood.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The New York Times/Paul MUMS

title: MRS. GANDHI WINS PARLIAMENT VOTE
description: NEW DELHI, July 22The upper house of Parliament voted its overwhelming approval as expected today of Prime Minister Gandhi's sweeping emergency powers, and the main opposition parties walked out in a boycott of the session. The session was called to ratify the state of emergency.

title: 2NETWORKSAGREE TO INDIA'S RULES
description: The news divisions of ABC and NBC said yesterday that they would comply, under protest, with the news coverage guidelines imposed by the Government of India, but CBS News has decided to risk expulsion from that country by taking a firm stand against signing an agreement to honor the restrictions.

title: IRVING C. JENNINGS
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 22Irving C. Jennings, board chairman and former president of the Nash Engineering Company, maker of pumps for airconditioning equipment, died last night at Norwalk Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at Wilson Point.

title: House Backs 1012% Rise In Disabled Veterans Ail
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The House passed by voice vote today a bill providing increases of 10 to 12 per cent for two million veterans disabled in military servicemore than double what the Ford Administration asked.

title: Christina Onassis Is Unexpectedly Wed Toa Greek Banking and Shipping Scion
description: GLYPHADA, Greece, July 22Christina Onassis married Alexandros Andreadis tonight in a tiny chapel overlooking this seaside suburb of Athens, uniting two of Greece's great fortunes.
