description: Following is a summary of ApolloSoyuz mission highlights:

title: SANTA FE INDUSTRIES POSTS 24% NET DROP
description: John S. Reed, chairman of Santa Fe Industries, Inc., the holding company that owns the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway, reported yesterday a 24 per cent drop in the consolidated company's secondquarter net. The decline reflected almost entirely a 76 per cent drop in pretax earnings of the railway to $4.7million from $18.5million a year earlier.

title: Advertising
description: The events that have shaken the worldboth political and economichave also altered the behavior of consumers in some strange ways.

title: Orioles Hand Ryan 8th Loss in a Row
description: What began as a brilliant pitching season for California's Nolan Ryan has turned into a disaster. The Angel righthander pitched his fourth career nohit game against Baltimore in Anaheim on June 1, tying Sandy Koufax for the record.

title: Westchester Playoff Won By Gentile
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 22Sudden death provided a second wind today to struggling John Gentile. The 28yearold teaching pro from Round Hill turned back Bob Bruno of Pelham Manor on the second extra hole and won the $7,500 Westchester opert golf championship at the Stanwich Club.

title: Hoarding Cited as Shortage Of Canning Lids Spreads
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The shortage of lids for home canning has become critical in some areas and is getting worse, the White House consumer adviser, Virginia H. Knottier told Congress today.

title: Market Place
description: Until recently, the Xerox Corporation had been regarded in Wall Street as a storybook company. Emerging out of a moribund corporation some years back. Xerox became a sensation as the producer of a patented dry process facsimile maker. The copying method became so popular and was so superior to the photographic methods of its day that the term Xerox because synonymous with office copying.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Notre Dame, Schmidt; Harp Concerto, Boieldieu; Suite Pastorale, Chabrier.

title: Bowery Is Home to Young Bands
description: Given the popularity of rock music it might seem strange that there are so few public places for aspiring young bands to play. Every third door in Greenwich Village seems to offer an earnestly strumming folkie, but rock poses problems or image and amplitude that seem to daunt all but the most intrepid of clubowners.

title: ROCKEFELLER BACKS FORD ENERGY PLAN
description: CINCINNATI July 22Vice President Rockefeller sought today to assure Middle Western Governors that President Ford was easing the energy crisis and stimulating economic recovery by insisting on removing price controls on domestic oil and natural gas.

title: A FREED WRITER DEFYING MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, July 22Andrei Amalrik, the dissident writer who spent the last five years in prison and internal exile, resumed his public criticism of Soviet authorities today.

title: E. MILO GREENE
description: E. Milo Greene, board chairman of Heinz International, a division of Shearson Hayden Stone, a brokerage concern, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 993 Park Avenue.

title: Dividend Unchanged
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, the nation's largest investorowned electric utility, reported yesterday a 9.8 per cent increase in second  quarter earnings, compared with a year ago. Despite the continued improvement in the company's financial position, the quarterly dividend payment was held at the reduced level of 30 cents a share.

title: PROF. GEORGE W. BACON
description: George W. Bacon, a retired Fordham University law professor, died yesterday at Hartwyck West Nursing and Convalescent Home, Cedar Grove, N. J. He was 83 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court in Trenton has ruled that people who believe they were injured by doctors treatment have two years from when they discover the injuries file malpractice suits. In interpreting a 1973 State Supreme Court decision, the Appellate Devision of Superior Court said it was ruling flatly that the twoyear statute limitations would count only from the time the patients discovered the harm, not from the time of treatment. The court rule that Michael and Cannel Moran of Rutherford had sued in time for injuries the wife said she had suffered when two Woodbridge physicians allegedly treated her colitis improperly. The suit contends malpractice caused her to have part of her large intestine removed.

title: Museum Hall Entrance Designated a Landmark
description: Memorial Hall, the Romanstyle entrance chamber to the American Museum of Natural History from Central Park West, was desigated an interior landmark yesterday at a meeting of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Since food prices began rising dramatically at the beginning of the nineteenseventies, the question of who is responsible has been nagging at consumers. A recent report by the economic staff of the Federal Trade Commission, which is investigating competition among supermarket chains, offers some new insight into this question, although no definitive.

title: Hunt Sons Charge C J.A. Used Agents To Embezzle Funds
description: DALLAS, July 22 (UPI)Two sons of H. L. Hunt, the late billionaire contending they were discriminated against because of their conservative views, charged today that the Central Intelligence Agency infiltrated the family oil empire and used secret agents to help embezzle more than $50million from them.

title: Rockefeller Friend Tells Of Trying to Aid Bergman
description: Samuel Hausman, a friend of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, for whom he raised campaign funds, Interceded on behalf of a Bernard Bergman nursing home with two state departments and the offices of both Mr. Rockefeller and Gov. Malcolm Wilson, according to Mr. Hausman's testimony yesterday before the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes.

title: Sadat Postpones Decision on Ending U.N. Peace Force
description: CAIRO, July 22  President Anwar elSadat declared tonight that Egypt still did not have sufficient ground to agree to the renewal of the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sinai. The mandate expires Thursday.

title: WINE TALK
description: NAPA, Calif.Hidden in the hills due west of this bustling wine city is Mont LaSalle, a novitiate or training school for young men becoming Christian Brothers, and one of the teaching order's three wineries in the Napa Valley.

title: Notes on People
description: F. David Mathews, president of the University of Alabama, was confirmed yesterday in a voice vote by the Senate as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. The 39yearold Dr. Mathews succeeds Caspar W. Weinberger, who is resigning for personal reasons. Dr. Mathews who has described his new post as hard and often thankless, was the youngest person to head a major university when he was named president of the 13,000student University of Alabama in 1969.

title: Food Price Rise is No Surprise
description: The sharp price advances in food reported in the Consumer Price Index yesterday (Details on Page 1) came as no surprise to supermarket shoppers here or in other cities.

title: Queens Skydiver Leaps Safely From Roof of the Trade Center
description: Almost a year after Philippe Petit stunned New York by walking between the towers of the World Trade Center on a tightrope, a Queens skydiver got into the act yesterday by parachuting from the roof of one building and fluttering safely to the ground 1,350 feet below.

title: Fungicide Foe Reinstated, Praised
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 22A 22yearold Hempstead Town employe who was charged with insubordination and suspended without pay for refusing to use an illegal fungicide spray was reinstated today and, to his surprise, commended for his action.

title: 30 ACCUSED IN SUIT OF OPENING MAILS
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 22 (AP)Thirty present and former officials of the Central Intelligence Agency and other Government agencies were accused in a class action suit today of illegally opening the mail of Americans.

title: Approval of Business Levy Viewed as Easing Crisis Over Jersey Budget
description: TRENTON, July 22Governor Byrne signed the key bill in a fivebill package of stopgap taxes today, apparently signaling the winding down of a budget crisis that began when he cut $384million from the current state budget in order to balance it.

title: Strength and Stability
description: The efforts of Arab moderates in recent years to convince a skeptical world that they had finally accepted the necessity of peaceful coexistence with Israel have been given a setback in recent days as the current phase of atmbysten neantiations has approached a climax.

title: Deaths
description: ACAMPORAMarla. On July 22. 1775. Beloved wife of the late Alexander Dear morner of P.amel, Col. Tullius. Caroline, Anna and the late Louisa. Also soreivea by eight grandchilcren. Reposing Waite B. Cooke Funeral Home, I W. 190 Se. Bx. Funeral Mass Frarcis Schervier Home, Thursday, le A.M. Interment St. Raymona'e Cemetery.

title: Forecasters Consistent
description: The economic civil servants who work for international organizations are not famous for their candor, their willingness to take on the representatives of the nations that constitute their membership, nor the forthrightness of their policy conclusions. Economists who cannot live within such inhibitions usually walk or are pushed off to other jobs.

title: BEAME TO TESTIFY ON NURSING HOME
description: In a surprise development Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would testify before the Moreland Act Commission today about a meeting with Bernard Bergman, the nursing home operator, at City Hall last year.

title: U.S. SUMS UP CASE AGAINST GURNEY
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 22Contending that former Senator Edward J. Gurney knew all along what was going on, a Federal prosecutor argued before a trial jury today that Mr. Gurney was part of an illegal conspiracy to raise seIrret camnaien funds.

title: Senate Unit is Given Gun Bill, But it Wins No Early Sponsor
description: WASHINGTON, Julv 22Attorney General Edward H. Levi brought the Ford Administration's guncontrol bill before a Senate subcommittee today, but at the end of the day there was still no immediate sponsor to introduce it.

title: Mariana Commonwealth Is Supported by House
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)The House of Representatives voted yesterday to create a selfgoverning commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands under the United States flag. A voice vote sent the measure to the Senate, which is expected to nass it.

title: On China's Economy, Outpouring of Cheer
description: HONG KONG, July 22 The statistics announcing China's industrial and agricultural performance for the first six months of the year have beeun to nour out and like the mighty Yeilow River, they seem to have an irresistible force: Oil production is up 24 per cent, Peking, Tientsin and Shanghai, major industrial cities, have topped their halfyear quotas, and provinces all across the North China plain have harvested a record summer wheat crop.

title: Stage: Twelfth Night
description: The stage at Playwright's Horizons is almost setless. Costumes are casual, as if plucked off the rack or out of the actors closets. There is a healthy air of informality and spontaneity about the Lion Theater Company's production of Twelfth Night.

title: Books of The Times
description: We seem to be in the midst of a boomlet in literary Victorinna. Perhaps people have a nostalgic need for the age's chesty optimism, its selfassurance grounded in an immutable moral code; and, to balance the pompousness and add spice to the dish, its oncehidden scandalous sideits nefarious criminals and underground pornographers.

title: Eddie Brannick, 82, Dies; Served Giants 65 Years
description: Eddie Brannick, who started in 1905 as an office boy for the New York Giants baseball team and rose to traveling secretary and a chief aide of Horace C. Stoneham, the Giants owner, died Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: 7 Priests From Haiti Bridge A Cultural Gap in Brooklyn
description: Two Haitian men sat in the living room of a Crown Heights apartment, pouring out their problems in Creole to a Haitian priest and dreaming of a new start in life.

title: Citizenship is Voted For Robert E. Lee
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Robert E. Lee won his final skirmish of the Civil War today as Congress agreed to restore his citizenship.

title: World Team Tennis
description: Boston 27, San Diegn 21.

title: CONSUMER PRICES SHOW BIGGEST RISE FOR A MONTII IN 75
description: WASHINGTON,Jnly 22  The nation's progress toward a lower rate of inflation was reversed in June, at least temporarily, the Labor Department tenorteri today.

title: POLICE ON BEATS AT ALBUQUERQUE
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 22 (AP)City policemen voted to enda 10day strike and returned to their beats today.

title: Golf Results
description: WESTCHESTER FATHERSON

title: ARSON PLAN LAID TO CHIROPRACTORS
description: Two chiropractors were arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court in the Bronx on charges of conspiring to set fire to one of three medical centers they operated in the borough.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Dallas Quintuplets Gain
description: DALLAS, July 22 (UPI)Three of the quintuplets born last week to Mrs. Debbie Davis were ready today to leave Parkland Hospital's intensivecare nursery for its premature nursery, an indication of their strength and of doctors optimism for their survival.

title: NATURAL GAS CRISIS SAID TO BE IMMINENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) A shortage of natural gas next winter could endanger the nation's economic health and security and reach the proportions of a national emergency a House committee report says.

title: Israel Describes Incident Across Lebanese Border
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, July 23 (Reuters)Israeli Army headquarters announced today that Its forces had exchanged fire across the Lebanese border early today with Arab forces.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN GRAIN FUTURES
description: Strong opening prices marked wheat, corn and soybean futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, before the three moved off in separate directions.

title: National Day of Prayer
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) President Ford has proclaimed Thursday a national day of prayer in keeping with a tradition begun 200 years ago. Mr. Ford issued the proclamation yesterday and received a historical collection of national day of prayer proclamation issued by Congress or Presidents, including the first, dated: June 12, 1775. A delegation of, religious leaders of a variety of demnominations presented the memorabilia to Mr. Ford in a ceremony at the Oval Orfire.

title: Music by Schuman
description: WASHINGTONPresident Ford sets out Saturday for Helsinki and the summit extravaganza that is to mark the conclusion of the Conference on European Security and Cooperation. A contrast can be drawn between this empty charade and the extraordinary initiative of the French postwar Foreign Minister Robert Schuman 25 years ago that started the process of European unification.

title: CONSUMER PRICES SHOW BIGGEST RISE FOR A MONTH IN 75
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The nation's progress toward a lower rate of inflation was reversed in June, at least temporarily, the Labor Department retorted today.

title: Hathaway Suffers From Depression
description: WASHING1 ON, July 22Secretary of the Interior Stanley K. Hathaway said in a hospital. statement today that he was suffering from moderate depresion brought on by overwork.

title: Tampering With the Grand Jury Laid to DiGiglio Defense Aide
description: NEWARK, July 22 (UPI)A member of the defense team for John DiGilio, a reputed mobster, and three associates allegedly attempted to tamper with the grand jury today, United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein charged.

title: Saigon Aide Reports Sabotage Against Communist Government
description: PARIS, July 22The Foreign Minister of the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam says that there have been certain acts of sabotage since the Communist takeover and that those responsible will be severely punished.

title: Living in New York: The Mistress of a Lively Salon
description: A good salon is a rare thing, but on a good evening in a good salon you can hear conversations on six or seven topics by people from six or seven different places. It is the essence of a salon.

title: CUSTOMER RECORDS EXAMINED BY A.T
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been quietly examing for three years the longdistance telephone records of embassies and corporations to try to identify those likely to sign up as customers of new competing communications companies.

description: Sandy Hook WIlists Shinnecock Fire Island Montauk New Rockaway Inlet Point Canal Inlet Point London

title: Belmont Entries
description: Horses listed in order or post Position.

title: 2 Russian Astronauts Congratulated by Ford
description: MOSCOW, July 22 (UPI) The Tass press agency released today the text of a cable from President Ford in which he said the ApolloSoyuz flight was but the first step in United StatesSoviet cooperation in manned soave activities.

title: PROGANDEll VOTE BRINGS A WALKOUT
description: NEW DELHI, July 22The upper house of Parliament voted its overwhelming approval as expected today of Prime Minister Gandhi's sweeping emergency powers, and the main opposition parties walked out in a boycott of the session.

title: Rrannick Dead at 82
description: Eddie Brannick, who rose from office boy to traveling secretary of the Giants baseball team, died Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla., at the age of 82. Obituary on Page 38.

title: $1.75Billion Deal Sets Mark for a Private Placement Interest is at 10%
description: Insurance companies and other institutional lenders have committed themselves in principle to buy $1.75billion in notes to finance the transAlaska pipeline. Details were announced yesterday for the transaction that would mark the largest private placement in Wall Street annals. Tha notes, all bearing a rate of 10 per cent, fall due in 1993 and 1998.

title: Closed Computer School to Give Students $750,000 in Refunds
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) Lear Siegler, Inc., has agreed to refund nearly $750,000 to its former computer school students who were allegedly duped by false job promises, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Exxons Earnings Tumble 34.3% Asinventory Profits Abroad Fade
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest industrial company, reported yesterday a 34.3 per cent drop in its secondquarter earnings from the record level of a year ago.

title: FORD IS REBUFFED BY HOUSE OIL VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 The House of Representatives, by a vote of 262 to 167, rejected today President Ford's, proposal to allow the average price of oil produced in the United States to rise by more than 60 per cent over the next 30 months.

title: Payola Threatens Recording Profits
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 22Like thousands of other American young people, Daryl Dragon and Toni Tennille dreamed of breaking into the music business with their own act. Spending $250, they made 500 copies of the record they had taped, sent copies to a few disk jockeys here, and then got into their camper truck and visited 130 radio stations in 22 states to promote it.

title: Living in New York: The Mistress of a Lively Salon
description: A good salon is a rare thing, but on a good evening in a good salon you can hear conversations on six or seven topics by people from six or seven different places. It is the essence of a salon.

title: ExPoliceman Acquitted Of Slaying at StakeOut
description: FREEHOLD, July 22John F. Adams, the former Long Branch patrolman who shot and killed a 16yearold youth fleeing a police stakeout, was acquitted today of a manslaughter charge.

title: Stocks Off for 5th Day; Dow Index Drops 7.98
description: Prices declined yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange for the fifth consecutive day as investors turned wary over renewed evidence of inflation and a rise in shortterm interest rates.

title: Time for the Golden Glories of Cornon the Cob and Off
description: New corn, fresh from the kettle, is one of those foods which, like the first radish in spring or a woodland raspberry, are utterly irresistible.

description: FIRST OAKLAND (A.) GAME DETROIT (A)

title: Trade Benefit for Rumania Asked in View of Visa Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 The chairman of a major Jewish organization urged Congressional approval today of a trade agreement making Rumania eligible for nondiscriminatory tariff status because of a positive trend in recent weeks in Rumanian approvals of exit visas for Jews.

title: Burlington Industries Earnings Decline 60% in Quarter
description: Burlington Industries. Inc., the nation's largest textile producer, reported yesterday a 60 per cent decline in earnings for the quarter ended June 28.

title: Fishing Zone Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) A House subcommittee has approved a bill to extend United States fishing jurisdiction to 200 miles off the coast. The legislation, first proposed more than two years ago to deal with foreign fishermen off the United States coasts, would extend the nation's fishing zone from its current 12 miles heginninc July 1, 1976.

title: KEY TAX MEASURE SIGNED BY BYRNE
description: TRENTON, July 22Governor Byrne signed the key bill in a fivebill package of stopgap taxes today, apparently signaling the winding down of a budget crisis that began when he cut $384million from the current state budget in order to balance it. they'll manage on good faith, Mr. Sagner said.

title: Little Likelihood Seen For U.S. Aid to the City
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Ford Administration officials and Congressional leaders said today that there was little likelihood that the Federal Government would act to stave off New York City's worsening fiscal crisis.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
PFIZER'S EARNINGS UP 13% IN QUARTER
description: Secondquarter earnings of Pfizer, Inc., increased 13 per 1cent to a record $33million, or 47 cents a share, from the yearearlier $29.2million, or 41 cents a share, the diversified pharmaceutical company reported yesterday. Worldwide sales rose 5 per cent to $393.2million from $372.8million.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A special state grand jury is investigating allegations that members of the Police Department's autotheft squad sold confidential police information and protection from the law to some largescale cartheft rings.

title: C. L Leonard, Newsman, Dies; Jailed in 48 Over Article Source,
description: Charles L. Leonard, who while a newsman in Newburgh, N. Y., spent five days in jail in 1948 for refusing to tell where he had obtained illicit numbers game tickets, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, in Chicago. He was 55 years old.

title: Mets Koosman Defeats Reds On 6Hitter, 31
description: The New York Mets had less trouble with the Cincinnati Reds last night than they had with Cleon Jones as Jerry Koosman pitched them to a 31 victory over the team with the best record in baseball.

title: Governing By Veto
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Lacking any energy policy of its own, the Ford Administration has effectively diverted attention from its failure by attacking Congress for its alleged inability to devise a program. Rarely has this political ploy worked so well. Thus, the House of Representatives has received much more criticism in recent weeks for its failure to approve a gasoline tax proposed by one of its committees than the White House has received for its failure to propose anything at all.

title: and Turkish Embargo
description: The House is expected to vote today or tomorrow on a compromise proposal for a partial lifting of the Congressional embargo on arms shipments to Turkey. The embargo, in effect since February, had previously been twice suspended by Congress for several months to advance a settlement of the dangerous quarrel between Greece and Turkeybut without success.

title: OPEC INVESTMENT IN U.S. IS REDUCED
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The United States received only about $2.3billion in investments trom major oilexporting countries in the first half of this year and its share of their global investments was reduced, a high Treasury Department official disclosed today.

title: Sadat Postpones Decision on Ending U.N. Peace Force
description: CAIRO, July 22  President Anwar elSadat declared tonight that Egypt still did not have sufficient ground to agree to the renewal of the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Sinai. The mandate expires Thursday.

title: Taxi Commission Called Hamstrung by Patronage
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission, created more than four years ago to improve service here, has amassed a record of patronage appointments and political favors that industry leaders say have crippled efforts to solve a growing taxi crisis.

title: 11TH JUROR SEATED IN JOAN LITTLE CASE
description: RALEIGH, N. C., July 22After seating an 11th juror in the first halfhour today, attorneys at the Joan Little murder trial spent the rest of the day in a search for a 12th juror. More than 20 prospective jurors were questioned with no success.

title: Rail Clerks Ratify Contract Raising Pay to $16,582
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)  The Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks has ratified a contract that union leaders said would result in average annual pay of $16,582.99 by the end of the threeyear pact.

title: Rockefeller Friend Tells Of Trying to Aid Bergman
description: Samuel Hausman, a friend of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, for whom he raised campaign funds, Interceded on behalf of a Bernard Bergman nursing home with two state departments and the offices of both Mr. Rockefeller and Gov. Malcolm Wilson, according to Mr. Hausman's testimony yesterday before the Moreland Act Conimisaion on Nursing Homes.

title: Olsons Reveal That Ford Told C.I.A. to Yield Data
description: President Ford has instructed the Central Intelligence Agency to make available to the family of Frank R. Olson all relevant materials and documents cone cerning his death and  the agency's LSD drug experiment in which he participated shortly before his death, family members said yesterday.

title: About Education
description: After decades of expansion into more than 70 per cent of the nation's school systems, kindergarten is one of the few areas of education that has many champions and almost no opponents.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Harness Tracks of America, the association of 50 North America's largest harness race tracks, accepted the resignation yesterday of its president and board chairman and then appointed a new nineman executive committee. Ernest B. Morris of Saratoga (N.Y.) Harness Racing resigned from the presidency and Donald D. MacFarlane, a founder of the organization who had served as president for terms, resigned as chairman. MacFarlane was succeeded by Herman R. Grannis, general manager of Batavia (N.Y.) Downs. A new president was not named.

title: 3 CABINET AIDES RESIGN IN LISBON
description: LISBON, July 22 (Reuters) Three Portuguese ministers have handed in their resignations and declined to join the Cabinet now being formed, a spokesman for the Premier, Maj.. Gen. Vasco Gongalves, said today.

title: Week's Market Basket
description: Food for a family of four rose 0.3 per cent last week, and the 38item market basket of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs cost $67.31, 20 cents more than it did in the previous week, the department reported yesterday.

title: Purchaser a Problem as Xerox Abandons Computers
description: When the Xerox Corporation said it would abandon the manufacture of comnuters late Monday afternoon, industry specialists immediately began speculating about a possible purchaser of the large operation.

title: MRS. WILLIAM MANICE
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 22Harriet Ferry Manice, owner of Edgehill, one of Newport's largest estates, died at the local hospital yesterday.

title: Fund Cuts Stir Furor at City's Museums
description: Reports that the New York State Council on the Arts will make major cuts in its grants to museum and other primary institutions funded by its visualarts program are causing a furor among trustees and directors here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was surprised to read your June 29 editorial Planting the Flag and your statement that the U.S. was about to annex the Northern Marianas without as yet even a semblance of serious Congressional consideration.

title: The Charter Reform
description: While city officials and most citizens are preoccupied with daytoday efforts to avert disaster in the deepening fiscal crisis, twelve New Yorkers are feverishly winding up a twoyear effort that could help to reduce the danger of similar crises in the future. They are members of the State Charter Revision Commission, which is scheduled to formulate its final recommendations by Aug. 6 for presentation to city voters in a referendum in November.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 22(UPI)The movie producer Joseph E. Levine has withdrawn his offer to give to the state the Christina Olson house in Cushing, made famous in paintings by Andrew Wyeth.

title: Specific Cause Not Found For Illness at Crater Lake
description: Crater Lake National Park in Oregon has been closed for nearly two weeks because more than 1,000 visitors, and residents suffered from an intestinal illness that was traced to acute sewage contamination of the drinking water.

title: Lefkowitz Asks Veto of Bill Easing Grand Jury Rules
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has drafted a memorandum to Governor Carey strongly urging a veto of a controversial bill that would permit a witness who waives immunity to bring an attorney into the grand jury room.

title: B. P. Lowers Estimate Of Crude Oil Reserves
description: LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., said today it estimated its share of the proved reserves of crude oil in the Ninian Field of the North Sea at about 140 million barrels.

title: ADM. C. A. POWNALL, A GOVERNOR OF GUAM
description: SAN DIEGO, July 22 (AP)Vice Adm. Charles A. Pownall, a veteran of both World Wars and a former Governor of Guam, died Saturday. He was 87 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The newlyweds have a good deal in common, not least that their fathers both maintained good relations with the military junta that ruled Greece until a year ago and were interested in building a major oil refinery on the same land. Mr. Onassis won the original contract; When he pulled out of the Mr. Andreadis took it over.

title: Jets Try to Catch Speedy Back
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.T., July 22 In recent years the New York Jeti running game has received as much adulation as, say, the runnerup in the Miss America Pageant.

title: Zarb is Praised as Man in Middle on Oil Price Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, July 22As President Ford and the Democratic Congress head for a showdown on oil price controls, the man in the middle, depicted today by a Democratic Congressman as a man willing to go the extra mile to reconcile differences, is Frank G. Zarb, the Federal energy administrator.

title: CITYAREA PRICES UP 0.5% IN JUNE
description: Consumer prices, measured on a basis that eliminates seasonal influences, rose 0.5 per cent in June in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: About New York
description: Those machines that the big commercial banks are busily installing so that depositors can get money to indulge their whims at high interest after banking hours are turning out to be like almost everything else, a mixed blessing.

title: Saudi Arabia. Seeks American Bids For $15Billion Electrification Plan
description: Saudi Arabia is actively seeking American bidders for her $15billion electrification and desalination program.

title: CITY AND UNIONS UNABLE TO AGREE ON FISCAL REMEDY
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Beame, officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the leaders of the city labor unions met throughout yesterday but, with barely two weeks remaining before the next scheduled Municipal Assistance Corporation bond sale, there appeared no solution for the city's crisis that all parties could support.

title: Astronauts Maneuver Apollo for Tests in Orbit
description: HOUSTON, July 22  The Apollo astronauts, on their eighth day in orbit, continued to maneuver their spacecraft Tor astronomical observations and views of earth, while performing experiments in their space cabin.

title: U.S. Five Scores In Wheelchair Play
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 22 (UPI)The United States wheelchair basketball team scored a 6148 victory over the Netherlands tonight for its second straight triumph in the World Olympics for the disabled. The Netherlands led at halftime, 2926.

title: News Summary and Index
description: India's upper house of Parliament gave its expected overwhelming approval to Prime Minister Gandhi's sweeping emergency powers, and the main opposition parties then walked out in a boycott of the session, called to ratify the state of emergency. An opposition member said the session could not function as a free and democratic Parliament. He cited the suspension of rules under which members could question Cabinet ministers, and the Government's decision to apply to speeches in Parliament the ban on publishing statements by the opposition. The ban applies also to foreign publications but a number of correspondents reported them anyway. Two British journalists and one American left under an expulsion order early yesterday. [Page I, Column 5.]

title: Solomon S. Lieberman, 57, School Psychologist, Dies
description: Solomon S. Lieberman, a psychologist with the Plainedge, L.I., public schools and a consultant to various govern'mental and other agencies, died of cancer Sunday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived at 6766 Springfield Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, and in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: About New York
description: Those machines that the big commercial banks are busily installing so that depositors can get money to indulge their whims at high interest after banking hours are turning out to be like almost everything else, a mixed blessing.

title: YellowBellied Toads Have Builders Jumping
description: HILDESHEIM, West Germany, July 22 (Reuters)Two dozen rare yellowbellied toads have halted construction of five houses on a new suburban development here, the town council said today.

title: Panel to Explore What Happens if City Defaults
description: On the theory that the Federal bankruptcy laws simply would not have any practical application to New York Citya theory that appears to be shared by most lawyerpoliticiansCity Council President Paul O'Dwyer has set up a unit to study what steps should be taken if the city ran short of money to pay its bills on time.

title: New Orders for Durable Goods Up in June, Third Month in Row
description: WASHINGTON, July 22New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods rose moderately in June, marking the third consecutive monthly increase the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Ashe, Smith Triumph in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)Arthur Ashe, returning to competition for the first time since winning at Wimbledon 17 days ago, needed only 48 minutes to defeat Haroon Rahim of Pakistan, 60, 62, in the $100,000 Washington Star international claycourt tennis tournament, tonight before a sellout crowd of 5,500.

title: K. KRIEGER, TAUGHT CHEMISTRY AT PENN
description: Knut A. Krieger, assistant chairman of the University of Pennsylvania chemistry department since 1969, died Saturday at Worton Creek Marina in Maryland. He was 64 years old and lived in West Philadelphia, Pa.

title: Prisoner at Rahway Escapes By Leaving Dummy Behind
description: RAHWAY, July 22 (UPI)A Rahway State Prison inmate had a brief moment of freedom Tuesday after he used a dummy made of dungarees, sheets and, socks to conceal his escape.

title: Hathaway Suffers From Depression
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Secretary of the Interior Stanley K. Hathaway said in a hospital statement today that he was suffering from moderate depression brought on by overwork.

title: Ballet: Baryshnikov Performs 2 Contrasting Roles
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov returned to New York on Monday night in two completely contrasting roles. The famous Russian dancer was appearing at the New York State Theater with, of course, his recently adopted home company, American Ballet Theater. For this first appearanee of the season he elected to be seen in the romantically classical Corsaire pas de deux, partnering Gelsey Kirkland, and in Roland Petit's existentialist memoir of the nineteen  forties, Le Jeune Homme et la Mort, in which he was matched by Bonnie Mathis.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Not too long ago there was an auction of the contents of the closed New Marlboro Cafeteria at 1359 Broadway, and catercorner from it the former Lodge Coffee Shoppe had a forrent sign In the window.

title: An Heiress and Now a Bride
description: Christina Onassis is a young woman of many facets, alternately serious and impetuous, shy and blunt, friendly and forbidding, and vlunerable with a steely resolve.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Amin Says He'd Like A Renewal of Ties, To U.S. and Britain
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 22 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda said today that he wanted to restore good relations with the United States and Britain and would welcome reopening of the United States Embassy in Kampala, which was closed two years ago in a dispute over Marine guards.

title: Hopman Spreading His Word to Florida
description: Harry Hopman is on the move again, continuing his quest for another Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall or John Newcombe.

title: School District, Seeking No Fail, to Enroll Babies
description: CLAYTON, Mo., July 22In an effort to achieve a nofail education for all its pupils, this St. Louis suburban school district will soon be searching for babies to enroll in public school.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FILM FEAST Those yearning to see Dinner at 8 (1933) and The Women (1939) without television commercials have their chance today through Saturday in the festival of golden years hits from MetroGoldwynMayer at the Regency Theater (7243700), Broadway and 67th Street. The two adapted plays make a rounded, adult entertainment package. To many critics and moviegoers, Haywood improved the Broadway originals by the team of George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber, and by Clare Boothe Luce. Indeed, there was a substantial theory some years hack that a shortlived Broadway revival of Dinner at 8 was done in by a TV showing of the movie. How could anybody compete, the question went, with an array such as Marie Dressler, John and Lionel Barrvmore, Jean Harlow, Wallace Beery, Billie Burke, Lee Tracy and Madge Evans? The same question came hack two seasons ago with a reshowing of Hollywood's The Women, as the stage revival foundered. How do you match a sorority like Norma Shearer, Joan Crawford, Rosalind Russell, Mary Boland, Joan Fontaine, Paullette Goddard and Marjorie Main?

title: C.A.B. OFFERS PLAN EASING FARE CURBS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board made public yesterday a special staff study recommending Congressional action that would, within three to five years, eliminate controls on domestic air fares and on entry into and exit from domestic airline routes.

title: Sanitation Chief Says Picketing Is Slowing Up Collections Here
description: The city's Sanitation Commissioner, Robert T, Groh, said yesterday that his department was not cleaning up the garbage as fast as he thought it would under the sharp manTower cutbacks because of conrtinuing sporadic picketing by laidoff workers and difficulties in adjusting to new schedules.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: NOVOGUDOK (Batt Atiantitiz), Leningrad Aug. 9; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

title: City U. Will Raise Fees in September; 5,000 Late Applicants Face Rejection
description: The City University will have to raise fees for undergraduate and graduate students and begin strict enforcement of the deadline for undergraduate admissions this fall under an austerity plan put forth by its board yesterday.

title: Student Testing Service Is Named in Trust Suit
description: The Educational Testing Service, Inc., and its associate, the College Entrance Examination Board, were charged yesterday with monopolizing the sale of student lists to colleges, universities and other organizations in violation of Federal antitrust laws. The lists are used by educational organizations to recruit students.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRACKETTCora S. July 23, 19???9. Those who have never lost a male, will tell ??? that time heals. Those who have, know that time mar heal the flesh but only soothes the mind or soul. Reg.

title: Taxi Commission Called Hamstrung by Patronage
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission, created more than four years ago to improve service here, has amassed a record of patronage appointments and political favors that industry leaders say have crippled efforts to solve a growing taxi crisis.

title: Ah! Those Weekend Guests: It's Fun When They Arrive, Sublime When They Depart
description: They arrive on Friday, the darlings, bearing gifts of cheese and wine and the latest gossip from town. You're delighted to see them. Of course, you wish they hadn't brought the dog, or that they'd warned you that their youngest may be coming down with something. Come Sunday night, you're even more pleased to wave them goodby, and as you pile mounds of towels into the washer, you find yourself muttering never again.

title: Sales Run Slower
description: The Kennecott Copper Gorporation yesterday reported heavy declines of 65 per cent or more in net income for the second quarter and first half. Sales in both periods fell more than 17 per cent.

title: Ballet: Sleeping Beauty
description: No one understands better than Rudolf Nureyev the mystic, fairytale quality of the great ballet classics. Not only does his acting and dancing have a bold, emblematic flamboyancehe is every inch the Princebut also his productions of such ballets as The Sleeping Beauty have a grand simplicity and coherence that enables their legends to leap to life.

title: Beame Tells of Plea Made by Bergman At City Hall Talk
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome entrepreneur, had met with him at City Hall last August to discuss the problem of a vacant nursing home on Staten Island.

title: How Cuts Affect the City's Precincts
description: The commander of the 78th Police Precinct station in Brooklyn has taken 14 plainclothes policemen who used to make a third of the felony arrests in the area and put them back into uniform to bolster his depleted patrol force.

title: PAN AM REPORTS A LOSS FOR JUNE
description: Continued From Page 35

title: Notes on People
description: In a ceremony in the Old Supreme Court Chamber in the United States Capitol, the American Institute for Public Service honored four persons yesterday for the highest ideals and achievements in the field of public service in the United States.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: ALBANY, July 23At the end of this year, 87 solarheated houses will have been added to the country's housing stock, or about as many as were built in the previous 16 years.

title: U.S. Delaying Removal of Warheads
description: WASHINGTON, July 23At the suggestion of the State Department the Defense Department has delayed plans to remove obsolete nuclear warheads from Italy and Greece.

title: Own Gun Wounds Law Aide
description: DANVERS, Mass., July 23 (AP)A State Registry of Motor. Vehicles officer, George Dobson of Danvers, was shot in the abdomen yesterday with his own gun after he stopped three motorcyclists, the police reported. Mr. Dobson said that while holding the weapon, one of the motorcyclists hit his arm with a chain, causing the gun to fire. Mr. Dobson was reeased after treatement at a hospital. The motorcyclists escaped.

title: Open Interest
description: Tues

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: FOUR ONEACT COMEDIES, by Lo??? De Rueda and Miguel Cervantes; and not drama by Rene Marques. Spanish Theater Repertory Company. At the Federation de Inauilinos de Williamsburg, 101 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, 7:30.

title: MRS. NORMAN READER
description: Jeanne Gelin Reader, the wife of Norman Reader, who retired recently as public information director of Air France for North America and the Caribbean, died yesterday after surgery at the Southampton Hospital. She was in her 60's and lived on Hand Lane, Amagansett, L.I.

title: Jersey Senate Tax Plan Leaves $20Million Gap
description: TRENTON, July 23  The State Assembly will have to find $20million more when it meets Friday to act on a package of tax hills passed by the State Senate to finance a $267million restoration of budget cuts.

title: EGYPTIANS AGREE TO NEW MANDATE FOR U.N.'S FORCE
description: CAIRO, July 23  In a lastminute response to an appeal from the United Nations Security Council, Egypt decided today to permit renewal of the mandate of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Sinai for three months. The mandate exnires tomorrow.

title: Bankers View M.A.C. Bonds as Sound Investments
description: A public misconception over the security that stands behind the bonds of the Muncipal Assistance Corporation for New York City was in part responsible for the sharp decline experienced by the bonds since they began trading, in the open market Monday.

title: COAL SUPPLY IS SET FOR ARIZONA PLANT
description: The PeabodyThermal Energy Company and a subsidiary of Santa Fe Industries, Inc., said yesterday they had signed a memorandum of intent to sell 86 million tons of coal over 35year period to the Salt River. Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District. The district is a political subdivision of Arizona.

title: SENATE MODIFIES VOTING ACT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Senate voted tonight for an amendment that would extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for seven years, instead of the 10year extension previously approved by the House of Representatives.

title: Jets Are Teaching New Tricks to Barzilattskas
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI, July 23 The ughs, sounding like pleas for help, coming from the Jets field today belonged to the offensive linemen who were victimized by the sheer power of Carl Barzilauskas.

title: Remarks Delay U.S. Action
description: WASHINGTON. July 23The statement by King Hussein today opposing anything less than the $350million airdefense system originally promised to him by the United States postponed a proposed compromise between Ole Anministration and Congress on the sale.

title: 70 Nixon Order to C.I.A. To Balk Allende Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 President Richard M. Nixon authorized the Central Intelligence Agency to make a lastditch, allout effort in September, 1970, to keep Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming President of Chile, authoritative Government sources said today.

title: Hussein Warns U.S. Not to Curb Arms
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 23 (AP)  King Hussein warned the United States Congress today not to attempt to scale down sales of airdefense arms to Jordan, saying: Otherwise we shall not hesitate to seek the weapons we need from other sources.

title: CHRISTOS BITAS
description: Christos C. Bitas, president of Orion & Global Chartering Company, Inc., a steamship concern, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 52 years old and lived in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: Ford vs. Solzhenitsyn: II
description: The White House has responded rather curiously to the charge by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn that President Ford is betraying Eastern Europe by participating in next week's Helsinki summit and signing the socalled European security agreement there. The White House defense is that the document in question in no way legally settles borders in Eastern Europe. But neither Mr. Solzhenitsyn nor anyone else says that it has.

title: ISRAELI MAKES PLEA FOR SUPPORT IN U.N.
description: TEL AVIV, July 23An Israeli leader appealed today to what he described as the enlightened members of the United Nations to try to head off any move to suspend Israel from the coming General Assembly session.

title: Ashe is Extended in Victory Over Crealy
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters)Guillermo Vilas, Arthur Ashe, Ilie Nastase and Roscoe Tanner advanced today in the $100,000 Washington Star International claycourt tennis tournament.

title: Captured Lion Dies
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 23 (AP) A young mountain lion that was captured inside the city limits died today as Arizona Game and Fish Department workers tried to set it free in the mountains east of here.

title: Yankee Records
Dock Workers Vote to Refuse To Load Grain Going to Soviet;
description: MIAMI, July 23 (AP)Representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association voted today to refuse to load American and Canadian grain on ships destined for the Soviet Union. They indicated that the ban would be lifted if the interests of the American public are adequately protected.

title: Rabin Says Direct Talks Are Needed for Accord
description: JERUSALEM, July 23Preinier Yitzhak Rabin said tonight that a new interim agreement with Egypt could not be concluded without facetoface negotiations between Israeli and Egyptian delegations on the final details of an accord.

title: Advertising
description: Representatives of 15 major magazines showed up at Doyle Dane Bernbach yesterday morning to hear a pitch for free space from the United Fund of Greater New York.

title: London Issue: 30,000 Squatters
description: LONDON. July 23Marjorie McFarlane is frightened. Alistair Black, the Under Sheriff of London, is vexed. The young people at 19 Elgin Avenue are adrift and resentful.

title: SAIGONESE ENTICED TO RETURN TO LAND
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam June 23 (UPI)Nguyen Duo Lang, a soldier of the form South Vietnamese Government clutched a child as he heave his 90 pounds of rice aboard the bus leaving Saigon.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: With Help Near, Woman Dies in Fall
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Canada Shut's Ports To Soviet Trawlers
description: OTTAWA, July 23Canada announced today that she would close her Atlantic ports to the Soviet fishing fleet Monday. She charged that Soviet fishermen had exceeded internationally agreed limits on catches in waters off eastern Canada.

title: The Snapping Turtle
description: We saw the snapping turtle at the beginning of summer. It would appear toward evening, its head sticking out of the water just below the house a menacing sight, after all we had heard about snapping turtles. They ate baby ducks and were a general menace to wildlife; they could shoot their head out and snap a man's toe in their powerful jaws.

title: Mayer Paces Sets Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., July 23 The New York Sets defeater the Cleveland Nets, 2521, in World Team Tennis at the Nassau Coliseum tonight before 3,167 fans. Sandy Mayer scored a 64 victory over Marty Riessen in the turning point of the match.

title: Refunding is Stage in Borrowing Goal of $40Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Treasury announced today threepart financing operation for next week, including sale of $800million of longterm bonds, as part of its plans to borrow nearly $40billion in the market in the last half of this year.

title: Reform Democrats Want Voters To Pick Entire State Delegation
description: The reform faction of the Democratic party, charging that there was a regular party plot for theft of New York delegates to the Presidential nominating convention, gave formal notice yesterday of a challenge to the selection rules.

title: Peoples Gas Aids Chevron With Offshore Exploration
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (Reuters)  The Peoples Gas Company said today that its subsidiary, the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, had agreed to advance $250million to the Chevron Oil Company's California Company division for gas development on 38 tracts offshore of Texas and Louisiana.

title: DR. GEORGE K. BRAZILL
description: Dr. George K. Brazill, a retired dentist, died Tuesday at the Sarah R. Neuman Nursing Home, Mamatoneck, N. Y, He was 80 years old.

title: A.P. Bureau Chief in Peru Is Ordered Out of Country
description: LIMA, Peru, July 23 (AP)The Peruvian Government last night expelled Edith M. Lederer, Associated Press bureau chief here.

title: Books of The Times
description: One would prefer not to collapse into oldfogeyism. But the temptation to do so became too much to bear the other evening when, during a cloudburst over Shea Stadium, a New York Yankee radio broadcaster and the baseball club's promotion director began to hold forth on what a summer it had been at Shea Stadium. Why, with the season not yet three months old, there had already been a batday, a shirtday, and a battingglove day (or something or other), and even now they were preparing a surprise (something to wear, the promotion director hinted lightly), which was to be just about the greatest thing ever in baseball, words to that effect.

title: T.W.A. Says it is Unable To Pay Preferred Dividend
description: Trans World Airlines, whith reported an $86.8million net j loss for the first half this year, announced yesterday its directors could not under terms of the company's senior note agreements pay the thirdquatter dividend of 50 cents on the Series A $2 cumulative convertible preferred stock. It was the third consecutive quarter in which the preferred stock dividend has not been ordered. Unpaid dividends on the stock are cumulative.

title: Television
DR. E. C. REIFENSTEIN JR.
description: Dr. Edward C. Reifenstein Jr., who was associate medical director of the E. R. Squibb & Sons Institute for Medical Research in Princton, N.J., at his retirement in 1973, died yesterday at Chilton Hospital, Pompton Plains, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Kinnelon, N.J.

title: Con Edison Employe Held On Bribe Charge on Bills
description: A Consolidated Edison employe was arrested yesterday on charges that he accepted a payoff from the owner of three West Side brownstones in order to make a pending bill disappear.

title: Diversion of More Delaware Water is Called Unsafe
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23A representative of the League of Women Voters Delaware River Basin Interleague Council said at a public hearing here today that the controversial I Tocks Island dam should not be built because the basin cannot safely divert more water Ito North Jersey and New York City than it already does.

title: Wood,Field&Stream
description: Those who delight in taking broadbill swordfish on rod and reel never have had an easy time of it, for Xiphias gladius always has been a difficult mark.

title: Robert J. Schmertz Dies at 48; An Owner of the Boston Celtics
description: Robert J. Schmertz, an owner of the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association, died last evening in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 48 years old and lived at 820 Fifth Avenue and in Lakewood. N.J.

title: 2 Injured by Bombs Thrown at Ships in Okinawa
description: NAHA, Okinawa, July 23 (UPI)Two ??? in a motorboat threw firebombs at Chilean Navy sailing vessel and three other craft today in 30minute attack on ships visiting the Expo 75 fair here, the police said.

title: U.S. Limits Visits
description: BOSTON, July 23 (AP)  A Coast Guard spokesman here said that Soviet ships were limited to four visits a month at each of four United States east coasts ports  Boston, New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore. Spokesmen at those ports said Soviet fishing vessels rarely stopped there.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Soliloquy
description: LONDONEnvision the farsightedness and courage of the government of. New York City applied to a whole nation: That's the Government of Great Britain.

title: U.S. REBUFFS DALLAS ON 1971 SCHOOL PLAN
description: DALLAS, July 23The United St ates Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled on a fouryearold appeal in New ed States Court of Appeals court plan for desegregation of Dallas schools was inadequate and said that the dual school structure of the Dallas Independent School District must be dismantled by January.desegregation plan of 1971 for the school district that was drawn up in July, 1971, by Judge William M. Taylor Jr. of the Federal district court.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Foreign Minister Ismail Pahmy announced that Egypt would allow a renewal for three months of the expiring mandate of United Nations forces in Sinai. The decision was made at a National Defense Council meeting under the chairmanship of President Anwar elSadat. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Miss McLean Scores
description: PAXTON, Mass., July 23 (AP)  Unseeded Mary McLean of Fort Worth, Texas, toppled Robin Tenney of Miami, 36, 63, 76, in the second round of the $10,000 Ms. America. Tennis competition today.

title: U.N. Council to Act Today
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23The Security Council, assured of Egypt's consent, will meet tomorrow to extend for three months the mandate of the United Nations force in Sinai, which expires at midnight. The Council will meet at 11 A.M.

title: Joint Flight Assessed
description: HOUSTON, July 23The ApolloSoyuz space mission was, in many respects, like summit conference of world political leaders.

title: Mine Union Election in West Invalidated by U.S. Judge
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 23 (AP)A judge has ruled that Federal laws were violated by District 22 of the United Mine Workers of America in a 1973 election for an international hoard member post and the election is invalid.

title: Unorthodox Leader for the Army
description: WASHINGTON, July 23As a young Arrtkv officer 20 years ago, Martin Richard Hoffmann decided the paratroopers were too conservative in their jumping techniques and should take up sky dming to demonstrate their courage. He prevailed upon the generals to change the restrictive regulations, and became one of the first Army officers to qualify as a sky diver. Mr. Hoffmann, now general counsel of the Defense Department, prepared to take another jump this week, this time upto the highest level of the Army. Yesterday President Ford nominated the 43year old lawyer to be Secretary of the Army, succeeding Howard H. Callaway, who has become the President's campaign manager.

description: Article 2  No Title

description: Following is a summary of ApolloSoyuzmissionhighlights:

title: House Rejects a Proposal to Raise and Another to Lower the Price of Domestic Crude
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The House of Representatives rejected today two contrasting proposals on oil prices, one of which would have permitted the price to rise significantly and the other of which would have reduced the average price of domestic crude oil slightly.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: PAN AM REPORTS A LOSS FOR JUNE

title: TIMES MAN URGED BY INDIA TO LEAVE
description: NEW DELHI, July 23The Government asked the resident correspondent of The New York Times tonight to leave India voluntarily, and it warned that if he refused he would probably be deported.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An autopsy reports on Betty Jean Belt, 16 years old, of New Brunswick, whose body was found in a drainage ditch on Monday, indicates she died of a skull fracture.

title: Tanana Makes Up For Ryan's Lapse
description: At the start of the season the No. 1 man on the California Angels pitching staff was Nolan Ryan. But that spot has been taken over by Frank Tanana, especially after his 10 victory over the Orioles in Baltimore last night.

title: GOVERNORS SCORE. GAS PRICE CURBS
description: CINCINNATI, July 23Midwestern Governors of both parties called today for the removal of price controls from newly developed natural gas.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A recent Times editorial referring to my income while a member of Congress for fourteen years calls for a correction of some factual inaccuracies and misleading impressions.

title: Mets Beat Reds, 52; Kranepool Bats In 3
description: While they continued to mull over the Cleon Jones matter in private, the New York Mets continued to maul the Cincinnati Reds in public last night, when Jon Matlack pitched them to their second straight victory over the team with the fanciest performance chart in baseball.

title: Mozart Festival Captures Mood Of Salon Music
description: The days, before airconditioned halls, when the words summer concert meant the musical equivalent of pink lemonade, have long since gone. The current Mostly Mozart Festival offers a fairly solid repertory, not greatly different from winter fare, and might well go further in that direction without alienating its patrons.

title: World Team Tennis
Israeli Troops Enter Lebanon, Take 7 Arabs for Questioning
description: TEL AVIV, July 23 (AP) An Israeli force crossed into southern. Lebanon before dawn today in a search for guerrillas, and the Israeli command said seven Ara cs were captured in a frontier village and brought back for questioning.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium. Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street. Flushing Meadow. Queens, 2 P.M. (RadioWRVR, 2 P.M.)

title: EDITH NICHOLS
description: Edith Docekal Nichols, wife of Wade H. Nichols, a vice president of the Hearst Magazines division, died Tuesday at her home in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 59 years old.

title: City Aides Can't Pinpoint Number of Employes Cut
description: City officials aclmowledged yesterday that they did not know how many municipal employes had been cut from the payroll as a result of the fiscal crisis, and they refused to say when a firm layoff figure would be forthcoming.

title: Peking, on the Women's Parley
description: The Peking Review, an Englishlanguage periodical published in China, in a recent issue commented on the United Nationssponsored International Women's Year World Conference, in Mexico City, which concluded July 2. The article, Struggle Against Hegemony. spoke of a complicated struggle around problems concerning the road to women's emancipation, and then went on to say, in part:

title: JOAN LITTLE TRIAL GETS 12TH JUROR
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 23The rregardless Cafe, a local vegetarian restaurant and countercultural meeting place, expects to be shorthanded for some time. One of its owners, Jule Hudson, 23 years old, and one of its waitresses, Cornelia Howell, 21, will be among the jury members hearing the Joan Little murder case.

title: The Flow of City's Cash
description: The cash in the city's treasjury has sunk to precariously low levels over the last few days as the Municipal Assistance Corporation has begun exercising its real power over the citythe power of the purse.

title: U.S. FINDS THREAT TO ALLIGATOR EASED
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The Federal Government has decided that the American alligator no longer faces extinction and plans to take the reptile off its endangered species list in most of the South.

title: An Earthquake in Burma Ravages Ancient Shrines
description: PAGAN, Burma, July 17An earthquake this month irreparably damaged many of the great temples of Pagan, an artistic landmark of Asia and the center of the Burmese national culture.

title: Newsweek Refuses
description: Newsweek has refused to comply with India's selfcensorship rules for foreign reporters.

title: Kissinger Conveys Response
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Secretary of State Kissinger conveyed to Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel today the Egyptian response to the latest Israeli proposals for breaking the deadlock in the zegotiations on a new EgyptianIsraeli agreement in Sinai.

title: I.R.S. Reconsidering Tax Status Of Fund for Vietnamese Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Internal Revenue Service has withdrawn for reconsideration a ruling it made last month denying taxdeductible status to contributions made to the Bach Mai Emergency Hospital Fund, Inc.

title: Apollo Returns Today
description: The Apollo spacecraft is scheduled to splash down in the Pacific Ocean today at 5:18 P.M., Eastern daylight time, some 320 miles west of Pearl Harbor. Page 58.

title: Westchester Inquiry Clears Sheriff's Unit Of Any Wrongdoing
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 23After three months of investigating allegations of misconduct in the Westchester County Sheriff's Department, a county grand jury announced today that no evidence of wrongdoing had been established.

title: Pele Scores Tying Goal In Cosmos 21 Triumph
description: Thanks to Pele and their goalie, Kurt Kuykendall, the New York Cosmos defeated the San Jose Earthquakes, 21, at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island last night.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP) Monty rates for Wednesday.

title: Help From the Feds?
description: If it is to fulfill its mission of helping the city, Big Mac itself needs help. Primarily that help must come from the city, through fast action to implement the economies and reforms which are still largely in the talking stage. But an additional boost may be essential to overcome the psychological block that has developed against any securities connected with this beleaguered metropolis. That is something the Federal Government alone can provide under a plan that has been pressed by Felix G. Rohatyn of the Big Mac triumvirate, among others, for a Federal guarantee of municipal bonds.

title: Blue Cross Payments Assailed By Both Hospitals and Clients
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York, which pays hospitals in the metropolitan area almost $1billion a year, was charged at a State Health Department hearing yesterday with wasting subscribers money by being too generous with hospitals and with endangering quality health care by not being generous enough.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DURABLE BAIT Agatha Christie aficionados and new fans won over by, Murder on the Orient Express (her biggest screen hit since the 1957 Witness for the Prosecution') can see her most successful stage whodunit in an Off Broadway production. This is the current revival of The Mousetrap, playing for two more weekends, Thursday through Sunday at 8 P.M., with a Sunday matinee at 3, at the National Arts Theater (7309264) 25 East Fourth Street (between the Bowery and Lafayette Street).

title: FASHION TALK
description: To look at his work now, you'd never guess that Tarquin Ebker once did pretty good imitations of the stiff, straight Courreges look. The world turns and today his clothes are supple, soft and fluid. Working out of a basement in the Park Avenue building in which he lives, he happens to he turning out some of the more inventive and, yes, avantgrade clothes anywhere.

title: SUCREST AND CPC RAISE SUGAR PRICE
description: Two East Coast sugar refiners  the Sucrest Corporation and the Corn Products unit of CPC International, Inc.  announced yesterday that they would increase prices by 55 cents per 100 pounds, effective today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the World Disarmament Conference10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

title: No Amer Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: AMEX PRICES OFF FOR 5TH SESSION
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell for the fifth consecutive session yesterday, bringing the market index to 92.41, off 1:54. Volume rose to 2.55million shares from 2.47 million.

title: After 5 Months, the Crisis Mood at U.D. a Gives Way to a Steady Salvage Operation
description: The Urban Development. Corporation today will receive a $140million loan from an obscure state insurance fund, half the money the once solvent agency needs to finish its building program and one of the crucial pieces in the complex rescue effort that followed the corporation's default five months ago.

title: Personal Finance: Late Tax Returns
description: When the Internal Revenue Service uncovers a taxpayer who has neglected to file a tax return, it takes a very negative attitude.

title: Barnard Appoints Leroy C. Breunig Interim President
description: Barnard College yesterday named Dr. Leroy C. Breunig, the college's dean of faculty for five years, as its interim president.

title: EGYPTIANS AGREE TO NEW MANDATE FOR U.N.'S FORCE
description: CAIRO, July 23  In a lastminute response to an appeal from the United Nations Security Council, Egypt decided today to permit renewal of the mandate of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Sinai for three months. The mandate expires tomorrow.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Prices of wheat, corn and soybeans drifted downward on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The selling pressure came because the Soviet buying had been formally announced and traders accepted the statements by both Cook Industries, one of the exporters involved, and the Department of Agriculture that Soviet buying was over, at least, for the present.

title: Chess:
description: Mikhail Botvinnik, world champion off and on from 1948 to 1963, advised that it was a mistake to try to cevelop an openings repertoire that would be allinclusive. A few choice openings, certainly not more than three or four, should be studied in depth for each event, but, he thought, to go for greater comprehensiveness would be to invite shallow thinking.

title: Ample Gasoline Seen
description: The likelihood of a summer gasoline shortage in the nation has all but disappeared due to further gains in the output and supply of the fuel, according to weekly industry figures. Page 35.

title: Further Output. Upturn Raises U.S. Stocks
description: The chances of a gasoline shortage in the nation this summer have all but evaporated because of further gains in the production and supplies of the Motor fuel in the week ended last Friday, according to weekly industry figures.

title: Brooklyn Residents Karl Garbage Into Streets
description: Residents of the Crown Heights and Bedford Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn tossed garbage into the streets in several areas last night in protest at what they said was a lag in collections by sanitationmen.

title: Malevolent Clown
description: The annual summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity, scheduled to meet in Kampala next week, will honor itself in the eyes of the world if it abandons one of its not yet deeply entrenched customs. That tradition is to make the head of the host country automatically chairman of the organization for the ensuing year. Unless that rule is suspended this time, the O.A.U. will be headed by President Idi Amin of Uganda, a man whose savagely eccentric behavior can only damage the prestige of a major international agency.

title: After 5 Months the Crisis Mood at U.D. C. Gives Way to a Steady Salvage Operation
description: The Urban Development Corporation today will receive a $140million loan from an obscure state insurance fund, half the money the onceinsolvent agency needs to finish its building program and one of the crucial pieces in the complex rescue effort that followed the corporation's default five months ago.

title: City Bids Other Cities Hire LaidOff Firemen
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said las:. night that he was sending out letters to about 90 fire commissioners in other cities asking them to consider hiring some of the 908 firemen recently laid off here in austerity cuts.

title: Hathaway Offered His Resignation on Entering Hospital, but Ford Rejected It
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The White House confirmed today that the resignation of Secretary of the Interior Stanley K. Hathaway was tendered toand rejected by  President Ford on July 15, the day that Mr. Hathaway voluntarily entered the Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., for rest and psychiatric treatment.

title: Bold Forbes Sets Record In U.S. Bow
description: E. Rodriguez Tirol's Bold Forbes arrived in New York 10 days ago with mighty credentials. In his five career startsat El Comandante in Puerto Ricohe had scored easy triumphs, none by fewer than five lengths. Yesterday, the 2yearold colt made his first appearance in the United States. He was sent to the post by a crowd of 23,772 as the $5.40for$2 second choice in the 83d running of the Tremont at Belmont Park. The sixfurlong fixture, worth $26,950marked the first time the youngster was competing for a sizable purse.

title: Grant is Upset
description: ROSLYN, L.I., July 23 Mike Fishbach upset Mike Grant, the firstseeded player, 60, 63, in the quarterfinals of the Nassau invitation tennis tournament today at the. Engineers Country Club. It was a battle betweeri two of the area's most promising young players.

title: APOLLO PREPARES FOR RETURN TODAY
description: HOUSTON, July 23  The crew of Apollo made preparations in earth orbit today for a splashdown in the Pacific Ocean west of Hawaii at 5:18 P.M. Eastern daylight time, tomorrow as a finale to their historic joint space mission with the Soviet Soyuz.

title: State's Gas Supply Said to Be Adequate If Winter is Normal
description: NEWARK, July 23 (UPI)There will be enough natural gas in New Jersey this winter if temperatures are normal, but customers in the southern part of the state will have to pay higher prices, power company executives said today.

title: Production and Oil Use Balanced Precariously
description: As the world economic slump begins to abate, production and consumption in the world oil trade are for the moment precariously, balanced. But there are forces present on both the supply and demand sides that could upset the preserrt equilibrium.
