title: KENT TRIAL HEARS EXGUARD LEADER
description: CLEVELAND, July 23 Robert Canterbury, a retired brigadier general of the Ohio National Guard who was the highest ranking officer on the Kent State University campus on May 4, 1970, testified today that he had had no direct responsibility for the weapons used and whether they were loaded or for the tactics of the troops and the methods of dispersing students protesting against the United States invasion of Cambodia.

title: Commons Votes Itself A A 28% Pay Increase
description: LONDON, July 23 (AP)Members of the House of Commons voted early today to raise their salaries immediately by nearly 28 per cent, and accepted a recommendation that they eventually rise by 144 per cent.

title: Frost in Brazil Said to Ruin Half Of Coffee Crop and Peril Herds
description: RIO DE JANEIRO. July 23 (UPI)Frost in Southern Brazil has ruined an estimated 50 per cent of next year's coffee harvest and is threatening six million head of cattle, Parana state officials reported today.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: News Summary and Index
description: Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy announced that Egypt would allow a renewal for three months of the expiring mandate of United Nations forces in Sinai. The decision was made at a National Defense Council meeting under the chairmanship of President Anwar elSadat. [Page 1, Column 8.)

title: CITY DRUG AGENCY UNDER U.S. REVIEW
description: Federal auditors have begun a confidential review of how the city's Addiction Services Agency allocated Government funds here last year following complaints that as much as $500,000 had been improperly withheld from private drug rehabilitation programs.

title: Revision is Urged in Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON July 23The General Accounting Office recommended today revising the nation's $30.2billion Federal revenue  sharing program to provide for strict enforcement of antidiscrimination laws and, to require local governments to involve their citizens in determining how the funds are to be spent.

title: Country Wedding in France A Ritual That Never Changes
description: MONTPELLIER, FranceGen. Antoine (Tony) de Reals changed swiftly from his dress uniform and gold embroidered kepi (for the wedding of an officer's daughter), into a sober, dark suit and said gaily, In July, everybody in France gets married.

title: Rate of Crime Believed Lower In Albuquerque's Police Strike
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 23 During the 10day police strike that ended here Monday, striking policemen daily predicted a crime wave.

title: WrightJanotka Win
description: POUND RIDGE, N.Y., July 23  Eleanor Wright and Marlene Janotta won the Westchester women's doubles title yesterday with a 26, 61, 75 victory over Jane Weed and Louise Cilia in the final.

title: Johannesburg, Miss. (circa 1954)
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.The paradox was shattering. I had traveled 9,000 miles from home and yet I was not a stranger and the land was not strange. It was as if the jet plane that Congressman Andrew Young and stepped down from on a November day in 1974 was a Jules Verne time capsule returning us to the Mississippi of two decades earlier.

title: Beame Tells of Plea Made'by Bergman At City Hall Talk
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome entrepreneur, had met with him at City Hall last August to discuss the problem of a vacant nursing home on Staten Island.

title: Scott in Semifinals
description: Gene Scott of New York beat Tony Fusco of Ridgewood, N.J., 61, 63, and reached the semifinals of the Summer. Jamboree 35er tennis toarnament at the West Sid Tennis Club last night.

title: American Opera at Washington Sq.
description: The annual series or summer concerts in Washington Square Park is observing America's forthcoming Bicentennial, and it began with a singularly appropriate program on Tuesday night. The After Dinner Opera Company had been invited to present its special recraetion of early American opera excerpts. It is just possible that, blurring chronology a hit, a comparable program might have been enjoyed qutdoors by New Yorkers 200 years ago, say at a place like Columbia Gardens in the Battery.

title: Screen: 'The Apple Dumpling Gang':Animated People Seen in July's 4th Disney Wild West, 3 Orphans Served Up Cheerfully
description: Walt Disney started by making movies in which animated drawings played the parts of people or animals who stood for people. Later he turned to making movies in which people or animals play the parts of animated drawings.They bound, they double-take, they simper when moved and quack when angry. Their disasterscrashes, plunges through space, explosionsare weightless."The Apple Dumpling Gang," the fourth Disney production to open here this month, is a fair example. It is about a Wild West cardsharp named Donavan who agrees to take delivery of some valuables for a friend, only to find that the valuables are three orphan children.The three children are hellions, of course, and darling to boot. The gambler doesn't boot them, this being Disney Productions: he takes them in with the tough-talking but golden-hearted assistance of a woman stagecoach driver. Adventures occur, including the children's discovery of a giant gold nugget and the efforts of two wildly incompetent bandits to take it away from them.Donavan, played by Bill Bixby, models his sputtering but doomed resistance to the tide of Disneyish good feeling on Donald Duck. The bandits, Don Knotts and Tim Conway, are clearly Disney skunks. The children are chipmunks except for the youngest, played by Celia Bradley. She is a little blond girl who creeps into Donavan's lap and says such things as "I love you, Mr. Donavan." She is probably Dumbo.It is as cheerful and indistinguishable as rice pudding. It even has the two-and-a-half raisins that a quality-control office somewhere inside Disney Productions seems to allow its pictures. One, for example, when a bandit tries to rope the gambler and gets tangled up in his own noose. "Maybe we can head him off at the pass," he suggests without any conviction. "Mmmhmm," his partner answers after a long silence.It will keep the children away from poison ivy, and it will probably amuse them, though at a preview most of the laughing was done by a father whose two daughters sat in amiable silence. It won't hurt them, anyway, though after four Disney pictures in one month it may be necessary to hit them a bit if they show signs of crawling into your lap.

title: Back to Washington.
description: The threeman executive committee of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation (Big Mac) is scheduled to visit Washington tomorrow to report to top Federal officials on efforts to overcome New York City's acute fiscal crisis. Although the Big Mac executives have denied that they also will be seeking Federal action to help Big Mac surmount its own critical funding problem, the case for such action is persuasive and urgent.

title: Median Income Down 4% in 74, Totatof Poor Rises, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON. July 23, (AP) Another 1.3 million Americans were added to the nation's list of poor last year, raising the total of poor Americans to 24.3 million, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Is 8 Shots Ahead
description: DEAL, N.J., July 23Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks carded a par 74 today and took a commanding eightstroke lead in the 40th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54hole championship. Play was at the Hollywood Golf Club today.

title: 2.9% Fall in Profit Is Kodak's 2d Drop
description: The Eastman Kodak Cornpany, the world's largest photo graphic equipment manufacturer, reported yesterday a 2.9 per cent drop in Junequarter earnings, making the second time in its history that profits declined from the year before. Net income fell 17 per cent in the initial quarter this year.

title: 'Beyond the Door' . . . Exorcism
description: "Beyond the Door," which opened yesterday at the National and Trans-Lux East, reminds us once again that, in some movies, at least, the devil's work is never done. This case, involving a young, pretty San Francisco matron possessed by a demon during a decidedly weird pregnancy, serves only to conjure up a pallid successor to the likes of "Rosemary's Baby" and "The Exorcist," as well as last year's equally imitative "Abby."As the work of Oliver Hellman who, the distributors report, is making his theatrical feature-film directorial debut with "Beyond the Door," it is more puzzling than shocking.Gynecologists might note that Juliet Mills's gestation is the speediest on record. Not only is her term alarmingly abbreviated but it's also accompanied by other startling changes. There are ominous sounds and a few furies around to slam doors, open drawers and, above all, to change her into a howling hag with basso voice shouting some raunchy dialogue and with wretching enough to scare the daylights out of her two kids and her terrified, record-producer husband.For reasons understood only by qualified necromancers, it seems that Richard Johnson, who once was her boy friend and appears to have been killed in an auto accident, had made a pact with evil forces.Under the circumstances, the bearded Mr. Johnson; Miss Mills, who is levitated during one of her manufactured seizures and David Colin Jr., as her agitated husband, cannot be faulted for merely acting distraught.

title: DR. GORDON TOMKINS, A HORMONE EXPERT
description: Dr. Gordon M. Tomkins, University of California biochemist who pioneered research on hormone activity, died here Tuesday at the age of 49.

title: Limited Growth is Voted for S.I. Area
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday approved designating Staten Island's South Richmond area as a special zoning district in an effort to insure that future development of the area does not outpace construction of necessary sewers, educational, transportation and health facilities.

title: COURT SANCTIONS STUDENT POLICIES
description: TRENTON, July 23 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the Blue Cross and Blue Shield hospital and medical insurance plans in New Jersey may provide accident insurance for schoolchildren.

title: N.J. Open Captured By Kiefer
description: EDISON, N. J., July 23Jack Kiefer didn't realize he shad won the New Jersey open golf championship when he dropped his final putt for a bogey 5 on the 72d hole today at the Plainfield Country Club.

description: Three more of the nation's leading oil companies yesterday reported sharply lower earnings for the three months ended June 30.

title: G.I.'s in Test Not Aware That They Received LSD
description: WASHINGTON, July 23A senior United. States Army medical researcher said today that none of the nearly 600 soldiers who were given LSD, ins Army experiments were told before or after that they had received the drug,.and he said that followup studies were done on only 10 per cent of the men.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A study that will examine the programs, facilities and services of the city's detention centers with a view toward improving them, was announced yesterday by the city's Department of Correction. The yearlong project, financed by a $250,000 Federal grant, will be conducted by the firm of Curtis and Davis, architects and planners, which has helped design prisons in other states.

title: MUSEUMS HEEDED BY ARTS COUNCIL

The $2million cut, made in the visualarts program, had evoked vociferous expressions of alarm among museum directors, trustees and their supporters.

title: 70 Nixon Order to C.I.A. To Balk Allende Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 President Richard M. Nixon authorized the Central Intelligence Agency to make a lastditch, allout effort in September, 1970, to keep Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming President of Chile, authoritative Government sources said today.

description: Research is the field of Dr. Thomas M. Davies, a physical organic chemist. And it was a different kind of research that led him to, what was at the time, a relatively unknown breed in the United Statesthe bearded collie, a mediumsized shaggy dog.

title: ITALY'S TOP PARTY SEEKING A LEADER
description: ROME, July 23As an era that Italians call the afterFanfani began today, the governing Christian Democrats put off until tomorrow the start of the process of naming a successor to their ousted party leader.

description: WASHINGTON. July 23 Jordan has agreed not to ask American companies that export to Jordan whether they have Jews on their boards of directors, the United States Commerce Department said today.

description: NEW DELHI, July 23Parliament today completed its ratification of the current state of emergency, under which the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has assumed sweeping powers and arrested thousands of its political opponents.

description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Supreme Court has a new historical society, in time for the Bicentennial, and late this morning, to publicize it, the Court's chief antiques buff joined with the society's president to give reporters coffee and a tour of the objects already on hand.

description: BILDNERPatricia Elman in memory of my beloved sister on her 53rd birthday. So dearly remembered, so very sadly missed.

description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23Af ter avoiding it for years, this old city seems finally to have come face to face with the issue of busing, a question that has brought tension and even violence to Boston and other American communities.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 23 (AP)Four persons were injured yesterday in a flash fire on the 19th floor of a student residential hall at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI)  An 18yearold man climbed on the statue of Abraham Lincoln at the Lincoln Memorial, began singing songs and shouted at the police for nearly an rhour yesterday before he was coaxed down. The man, who was taken to a mental bosWise, was identified as Robert Wise, of Falls Church, Va. The police did not file charges.

description: FORT MONROE, Va.The young Army skin diver climbed out of the murky waters of the moat, cradling a cardboard box as carefully as though it were filled with live ammunition.

description: MIAMI BEACHElisha Obed, 155 pounds, Nassau, the Bahamas, knocked out Gene Wells, 160, Mobile, Ala., 5 rounds.

description: CALI, Colombia, July 23 (AP)  An American foursome set the first world record of the aquatic championships tonight, winning the men's 400meter freestyle relay in a time of 3 minutes 24.85 seconds.

Brezhnev, at the 35nation European security conference in Helsinki at month's end.

title: 3Man Collective Said to Be Taking Power in Portugal
description: LISBON, July 23 (Ap)A high Government official said today that three top military men are preparing to take full power in Portugal, now governed by a Revolutionary Council of 30 military officers.

description: A column that recently appeared in the pages of this newspaper as a paid advertisement deserves attention both for the importance of the subject and the prestige of its author, Bayard Bustin. Unfortunately, it deserves rather less admiration.

title: Eddie Mahan, 83, Harvard Back And 3 Times AllAmerica, Dies
description: NATICK, Mass., July 23 (AP)Edward W. Mahan, threetime AllAmerica football player who was considered the greatest back in Harvard's history, died yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Local Party Votes to Drop Wilson Aide

title: A Faster Recovery for the Economy Urged by Okun
description: WASHINGTON, July 23Arthur M. Okun, the economist, told Congress today that a much faster economic recovery than the Administration wants would be desirable. He said a faster recovery would present little danger of increased inflation and that it probably cannot be achieved if the Federal Reserve System adheres to its present objectives for monetary policy.

title: Columbia Names Coach
description: Mike Baskauskas former Yale star, was named yesterday assistant basketball coach at Columbia.

description: CANTON, Ill., Juy 23 (AP)A tornado smashed through downtown Camon tonight. The Illinois State Police said that four persons were killed and at least 37 others injured.

description: CHICAGO, July 23The concrete path in the damp passageway between the visitors clubhotise and the visitors dugout in ancient White Sox Park is worn thin from the spike marks of generations of ballplayers.

description: OTTAWA, July 23  Canada announced today that she would close her Atlantic ports to the Soviet fishing fleet Monday. She charged that Soviet fishermen had exceeded internationally agreed limits on catches in waters off eastern Canada.

title: Barnard Appoints Leroy C. Breunig Interim President
description: Barnard College yesterday named Dr. Leroy C. Breunig, the college's dean of faculty for five years, as its interim president.

title: Bridge Unknown Young Foursome Outdoes the Top Players
description: Nev York team events invariably attract a substantial nucleus of highranked players and are probably harder to win than any comparable contests in the United States. The luck factor, which plays an important role in pairs championships is considerably diminished.

title: SENATE MODIFIES VOTING ACT PLAN

title: AIDE OF LOPEZ REGA FORCED FROM OFFICE
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 23 (Reuters)Argentine legislators tonight purged from office close associate of the ousted Government strongman, Jose Lopez Rega, forcing the resignation of Raid Lastiri as Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies.

title: G.I.S in Test Not Awaie That They Received LSD

title: SALES IN MIDJULY OF AUTOS IS UP 470
description: DETROIT, July 23 (AP) The pace of new car sales in midJuly hit the highest lavel for a midmonth period since June, 1974, toppin' last year's depressed totals by 4 per cent, domestic automakers reported today.

description: Pressed to pay a municipal debt, New York auctioned off some of the City Hall furniture. The Mayor was the high bidder.

title: M. CURTIS YOUNG, LED AIRLINES IN JERSEY
description: MARGATE, N. J., July 23M. Curtis Young, president of South Jersey Airways and Allegheny Commuter Airline, died yesterday of a heart attack while playing golf. He was 54 years old and lived here.

title: M.A.C. Bonds Rise a Bit in First Ralik
description: Bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation gained to 3 points yesterday in their first rally since the start of public trading on Wall Street. This means that the bonds gained $20 to $30 per $1.000 face value. On Monday, the 10year and 15year maturities of the state agency created to rescue New York City from default plunged 10 points, or $100 per $1.000 face value, in their initial debut. thereby shocking the investment community and dismaying buyers of the $1billion issue on June 30.

title: Caribous Top Tomahawks
description: QUEBEC CITY, July 23The Quebec Caribous scored a 1714 victory over the firstplace Long Island Tomahawks in a National Lacrosse League game here tonight. The two teams, penalized a total of 148 minutes last night at Nassau Coliseum, were, assessed 75 minutes tonight. There were nine fights.

title: FASHION TALK
description: To look at his work now, you'd never guess that Tarquin Ebker once did pretty good imitations of the stiff, straight Courreges look. The world turns and today his clothes are supple, soft and fluid. Working out of a basement in the Park Avenue building in which he lives, he happens to he turning out some of the more inventive and, yes, avantgrade clothes anywhere.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS IN ANGOLAN PLEA
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 23  Angola's feuding guerrilla movements were urged last night to send their military commanders to Kampala next Monday to attempt to work out A lasting peace with the help of African leaders here for the 12th leaders meeting of the Organization of African Unity.

title: Possible Conspiracy in Dr. King Killing Investigated
description: ATLANTA, July 23The Atlinta Public Safety Commissioner, A. Reginald Eaves, said today that four city police detectives were continuing their investigation into allegations that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was the victim of a conspiracy rather than of the lone assassin James Earl Ray. Mr. Eaves said he expected a full report by Friday or Monday. At that time, he said, determination would be maae as to whether information developed from a written statement by a convicted drugseller was sufficient to warrant further inquiry for possible indictments, The commissioner said he was not sure at this time whether the Atlanta authorities would attempt to move on their own, if warranted or if they would request Federal action.

title: Reggie Jones Victor in Dash
description: CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) In the absence of Ivory Crockett and Houston McTear, Reggie Jones took the 100yard dash with a time of 9.5 seconds in the United StatesPan Africa track meet today at BaldwinWallace College.

title: SENATE DELAYS VOTE ON NEW HAMPSHIRE

The financially pressed company was able to report a net profit of $4million for the second quarter, or 10 cents a share, but only because of favorable adjustment that increased ticket revenue for the period by $28.3million.

title: W.W.'Is Pleasant Summer Surprise
description: Even if you don't think you're ready for another variation on the one about the traveling con artist and the orphan who melts his slush-cold heart, you may find John G. Avildsen's "W.W. and the Dixie Dancekings" an unexpectedly pleasant surprise. It's a skylarking sort of movie, full of the good humor and nave optimism with which you start out on an all-day picnic on the hottest day of the year."W.W. and the Dixie Dancekings," directed by the man who made the schizophrenic "Joe" and the sentimental "Save the Tiger," is a small-scale, ebullient period (1957) comedy, set in and around Nashville and its country music business, though it has less in common with Robert Altman's epic "Nashville" than with Peter Bogdanovich's folksy "Paper Moon." It opened yesterday at Loews State 2, Loews Tower East and other theaters.The film, based on an original screenplay by Thomas Rickman, is about a debonaire, somewhat eccentric holdup man named W.W. (Burt Reynolds), about his 1955 black-and-gold Oldsmobile hardtop, one of Oldsmobile's golden anniversary specials, and about the Dixie Dancekings, a third-rate, five-piece, country band he adopts and, through one awkward ploy and another, guides to Grand Ole Opry stardom.A certain part of this lunge to stardom is financed by W.W. through a series of holdups of S.O.S. gasoline stations, part of the S.O.S. empire owned by a nutty Nashville fundamentalist named Elton Bird (Sherman Lloyd), who looks upon the robberies as the work of the devil. To stem this wave of sin, Elton calls in an old associate, an equally nutty fundamentalist who goes by the name of Deacon (Art Carney).One of the charms of the movie is the casual way it seems to discover its story while it wanders from one minor crisis to the next. Mr. Avildsen's manner here is soft sell. It's a tall story, unhurriedly told, which allows the actors, particularly Mr. Reynolds and Mr. Carney, to work some very funny variations on rather conventional roles.The overpublicized Reynolds machismo is apparent all right, but in this film it fails from time to time, as when he attempts to rob "the Southland's first drive-in bank" and succeeds only in wrecking the physical structure.The film's supporting roles are very well cast, largely, it seems, by Nashville country music personalities who are unknown to me. These include Conny Van Dyke, who plays Dixie of the Dixie Dancekings, a steely sort of virgin with a heart of gold, and Jerry Reed, who plays one of the Dancekings. Ned Beatty, who appears as Country Bull Jenkins, a country music star, is the only member of the cast who is also in "Nashville" (as the fast-talking lawyer).Mr. Carney isn't around a lot of the time, but he is very funny when he is, especially in a radio broadcast in which he exhorts the audience to be on the lookout for the devilthe true devil, not a metaphoric onedriving that old black-and-gold 1955 Olds. He reminds his listeners that while the devil can change his shape, Oldsmobiles can't.

title: The Road Secretary's Last Trip
description: Eddie Brannick, a kid from Hell's Kitchen who left New York temporarily, when the baseball Giants went West in 1958, left permanently this week. A crowd gathered in St. Ignatius Loyola Church at Park Avenue and Roth Street to see him off. It wasn't a big crowd, but the right people were thereold friends like Jim Farley and Horace Stoneham, who was also Eddie's boss; old players like Monte Irvin and Tom Ferrick; Bowie Kuhn and Joe Reichler and Lee MacPhail and Bob Fishel and Bob Holbrook of the baseball hierarchy, Sports and newspaper guys, active and retired, who can remember a place called the Polo of Grounds and people named John McGraw The Vanes and Bill Terry and Mel Ott. This was Wednesday, the day after Eddie's 83d birthday and five days after his death in West Palm Beach, Fla. Twenty years ago no church in New York could have held the crowd at Eddie Brannick's funeral, but it has been 17 years since he was the tireless, buoyant manabouttown who knew everyone; 10 years have passed since he ceased to be a manaboutbaseball as traveling secretary of the Giants, and for the last five years he and his Kathleen lived in Florida so quietly that it wasn't until the morning of the funeral that news of his death reached the obituary page. Many old friends packed it in before Eddie did and many others didn't get word in time for the funeral.

title: Shanker's Fear Tactics
description: Albert Shanker has now stooped to aping the fear city scare tactics of the police union. In predicting that the austerity budget will leave classrooms too crowded for learning and the schools abandoned to violence, the president of the United Federation of Teachers is trying to persuade parents that their children can be saved from chaos only by surrender to his union's excessive demands.

title: End of Apollo Opens Way for the Shuttle

But this Sunday evening at 10:30, WNBCTV is offering a short play, Lonely Lives, and the author, Hector Rodriguez, is indeed a 15yearold who freely and cheerfully admits to being functionally illiterate. Once again, the medium is overwhelmed by reality.

description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Senate Finance Committee voted tentatively today to impose a special tax ranging from $100 to $800, starting in 1978, on automobiles that get less than 17 miles per gallon. The $800 tax would apply to cars gettiing less than 13 miles per gallon.
