description: RANGOON, Burma, July 21In her 28th year of independence and 14th of military rule, Burma is stagnating in pervasive poverty. Intellectuals, including many in government, and the foreign community consider Burma a developing country in name only.

title: Tribe in Minnesota Builds A Big Hotel in Wilderness
description: GRAND PORTAGE, Minn.A Chippewa brave in this unspoiled wilderness region near Canada attached a hotel key to a flaming arrow, raised his bow and sent the missile arcing out over Lake Superior.

title: N.Y. Phone Earnings Fell By 10.9% in the 2d Quarte?
description: A 10.9 per cent drop in 1975 secondquarter earnings was reported yesterday by the New York Telephone Company, one of the biggest money makers in the Bell Telephone System.

title: The Gun Debate
description: Although they fall short of nationwide licensing and registration requirements, the Administration's new gun proposals constitute a fair start toward necessary controls. They contain handgun limitations which are similar to a bill passed by the Senate in 1972, but defeated ht the House largely as a result of the Administration's own efforts.

title: DUNLOP SEES NEED FOR NEW TAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (Reuters)Labor Secretary John T. Dunlop said today he was sympathetic to another tax cut this year to further stimulate the economy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 25, 1975 Committee on the World Disarmament Conference10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The House of Representatives rejected by a close vote of 223 to 206 a major effort by the Administration to partly lift the sixmonthold arms embargo against Turkey. The vote followed a day of often bitter debate and weeks of intensive lobbying by proGreek forces. It was regarded as a significant personal setback for Mr. Ford, who gained 103 votes from Democratic and Republican members of the House, but failed to carry 184 Democrats and 39 members of his own party. [Page 1, Columns 12]

title: The Hew Yolk Times/Don Hogan Charles
description: The Hew Yolk Times/Don Hogan Charles

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Despite the tumult, I wonder if New York City's financial mess isn't fairly simple to handle. The problem is maturing debt which cannot be refunded in a market empty of buyers. The solution is not to refund bonds but to extend them.

title: Women Designers: Force to Reckon With
description: Designing clothes is a natural occupation for women, right?

title: India's Parliament Places Crisis Rule Above Courts
description: NEW DELHI, July 24The Indian Parliament, moving along swiftly now that the opposition members have walked out, barred the courts today from upsetting states of emergency like the current one, which gives Prime Minister Indiral Gandhi sweeping powers.

title: Booz. Allen May Buy Stock
description: A plan to acquire all or part of its shares is under consideration by Booz, Allen & Hamilton, Inc., the management consulting firm said yesterday. It said the price would bet about $7 in cash or company obligations.

title: Theodore Hanff, an Owner Of 2 Delaware River Spans
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) Theodore R. Hanff, a principal figure in the controversial 1948 sale of the TaconyPalmyra and BurlingtonBristol bridges over the Delaware River, died Tuesday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Ralph H. Matthiessen Dies; Founder of General Time
description: Ralph H. Matthiessen, a founder and former president of the General Time Corporation, died Wednesday at his home in Hume, Va., at the age of 85. He formerly lived at IrvingtononHudson, N.Y.

title: A Biographer's Notes
description: Many of the papers Boswell gathered at his home, Auchinleck, remain to be processed and published by Yale's Boswell Factory. Here are excerpts from future output.

title: R. DUFFY LEWIS, 66 EXKLEIN'S OFFICER
description: R. Duffy Lewis, former president of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., and the McCrory International Corporation, died Wednesday of a heart attack in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 66 years old and lived at 1050 Fifth Avenue.

title: Voting Act Advances
description: The Senate, 77 to 12, passed a bill extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for seven years and broadening it to include Spanishspeaking citizens. The measure now goes to the House, which passed a 10year extension last month. Page 28.

title: Voting Act Advances
description: The Senate, 77 to 12, passed a hill extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for seven years and broadening it to include Spanishspeaking citizens. The measure now goes to the House, which passed a 10year extension last month. Page 28.

title: World Team Tennis
description: Roston 20, Cleveland 26. Hawali vs Los Angeles

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Burns Denies Aim is to Lift Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Recent actions by the Federal Reserve that helped increase shortterm interest rates had very little significance, Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today.

title: Inflation Again?
description: With the first signs of economic recovery, is inflation also accelerating once more? The eighttenths of one per cent increase in the consumer price index in June9.6 per cent at an annual rate, seasonally adjustedwas disturbing, as were recent price increases by the auto, steel and aluminum industries, which are still operating far below capacity.

title: Advertising
description: There are some folks down in Dallas who just may know the secret of why the Philadelphia Phillies are having their best season in years. It may just be the gold pretzel.

title: BRITAIN WILL FREE ULSTER INTERNEES
description: LONDON, July 24The British Government announced plans today to end the controversial policy of interning suspected terrorists without trial in Northern Ireland and to release all internees by Christmas.

title: Gurney's Lawyer Says Senator Was Conned by a Former Aide
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 24  A lawyer for former Senator Edward J. Gurney told a trial jury today that Larry E. Williams, a fund raiser from Orlando, simply conned Senator Gurney, just like he conned everybody else.

title: City Agencies Said to Fail To Report Staff Changes
description: Many city agencies are failing to report layoffs and other personnel changes in The City Record, as required by law, two City Councilmen charged yesterday as the Beame administration deferred at least until today a definitive count of municipal workers dropped frorr the payroll in the budget crisis.

title: CORRECTION
description: Due to an editing error, an article in The New York Times July 10 stated incorrectly that Medicare was health insurance program for the indigent elderly. Anyone covered by Social Security is eligible for the program.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP) Money rates for Thursday.

title: BEAMS AND M.A.C. ASK AQUICK RISE IN TRANSIT FARES
description: Mayor Beame and the Municipal Assistance Corporation asked the Transit Authority yesterday to increase the 35cent fare on subways and bus lines by an unspecified amount as part of a program to restore the city's fiscal credibility.

title: About the Giants
description: Welcome back, Spider Lockhart, someone shouted from the sidelines yesterday. On the first play of the veterans first scrimmage, Lockhart attempted to stop the 240pound Larry Watkins on a draw play. The 172pound Lockhart was out for the rest of the drill. Leonard Dunlap, acquired from San Diego on Tuesday, reported to camp. John King, a running back, left camp as he was cut. King, from the University of Minnesota, also failed a Pittsburgh Steelers test last season. The Giants will stage a major scrimmage tomorrow at Westchester Community College. Proceeds will go to Pop Warner football. Admission for the 3:30 P.M. start is $2 and $1.

title: Business Loans at Banks In City Slumped for Week
description: Business loans at leading New York City banks, a key indicator of national economic, activity, declined sharply in the week ended Wednesday, according to a report yesterday from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: School Critics Press Drive for Old Values
description: The dispute between parents and educators over what public schools should teach and what texts should be used has spread from West Virginia's Kanawha County where it exploded in shots and arson last year, to dozens of other communities across the country.

title: TEXACO EARNINGS PLUNGE BY 52.2%
description: The steep decline in secondquarter earnings for the major American oil companies continued to be reported yesterday, as Texaco, Inc., second largest after the Exxon Corporation, announced a decrease of 52.2 per cent, from the corresponding period last year.

title: Earnings Down at Inco And McDonnell Douglas
description: Earnings Down at Inco And McDonnell Douglas

title: A Correction
description: In the recipe for curried corn and cheese souffle published Wednesday, Step 5 was incomplete. It should also have said, at the end of the step, to add the cheddar cheese and fold in the corn.

title: MRS. WILLIAM MASLAND
description: Anne Comfort Masland, a former teacher at the Greenvale, L.I., School and clerk of the Manhassett L.L, Meeting of Friends, died Wednesday at her home in Manhasset She was 64 years old.

title: Moreland Panel to Invite Rockefeller
description: The Moreland Act Commission investigating nursing homes voted unanimously yesterday to invite Vice President Rockefeller to testify concerning his staff's activities on behalf of Bernard Bergman, the nursing  home entrepreneur, when Mr. Rockefeller was Governor.

title: Forewarning On Birth Control
description: LYNDONVILLE, Vt.  The Pill and the intrauterine device pose ethical problems that are unique, unprecedented.

title: Books of The Times
description: Psychohistory remains a somewhat con troversial discipline (some might not even call it a discipline). The pioneer in the technique of applying psychoanalysis to historical figures was, as in most things psychiatric, Sigmund Freud, in his study of Leonardo da Vinci. Erik H. Erikson's biographies of Martin Luther and Gandhi were generally acclaimed and represented the successful application of Mr. Erikson's own seminal ideas on the identity crisis.

title: Carey Tells Union Aides Problem is Washington
description: SYRACUSE, July 24 Haunted by New York City but determined to show something more than a crisis aura to his administration, Governor Carey came to this fiscally pacific city today to talk to construction union leaders and medical administrators.

title: President, Now Confident, Shuns Isolation
description: WASHINGTON, July 23A year ago, he was living in a modest suburban home, rising early to fix his own breakfast, starting his day by reading the sports pages.

title: 6 FAITHS PRESENT AT CHURCH CENTER
description: Leaders of six of the world's major religious bodies marked this country's National Day of Prayer yesterday at a ceremony attended by 100 people in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations, at First Avenue and 44th Street.

title: Ford Sums Up First Year In 'Different' White House,
description: WASHINGTON, July 24President Ford, affirming that he ndGov. George C. Wallace of Alabama share a good, many similarities on domestic issues, is nearing the end of his first year in the White House with apparent confidence in the conservative course he has set.

title: U.S. Mining Concern Expropriated in Chile
description: LIMA, Peru, July 25(AP) The Peruvian military Government tonight announced the expropriation o the United Statesowned Marcona Mining Company, a subsidiary of the Utah Company.

title: Flood Victims Are Entitled To Fast U.S. Tax Relief
description: NEWARK, July 24 (AP)Flood victims in the 12 New Jersey counties declared disaster areas can get immediate Federal tax benefits, the Internal Revenue Service announced today.

title: Jets' Rookie Runs Backwards For the Chance to Play in Pros
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 24It has been an agonizing first week for rookies at the Jets camp, where many of the newcomers know they are merely cannon fodder, bodies to be employed so the regulars can get into share.

title: Nominee for Housing Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 23(AP) President Ford announced today plans to nominate Charles J. Orlebeke, dean of the College of Urban Sciences at the University of Illinois, to be Assistant Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Nadia Potts Superb Sleeping Beauty
description: One of the unexpected aspects of the National Ballet of Canada's seasons here since 1973 was not that Rudolf Nureyev partnered four different dancers in the ballerina role of Aurora in The Sleeping Beauty but that the company could produce four young women to dancethis grueling role.

title: Racing Proposak Always on Sunday
description: Citing encouraging results, the New York Racing Association said yesterday it hoped to continue its experimeirt of Sunday racing for the rest of the year and into the winter months of 1976. Sunday racing has brought a lot of new fans to the track, said Jack Dreyfus, chairman of the N.Y.R.A. On a weekly basis, attendance shows an increase.

title: People and Business
description: Business leaders who are supposed to have some extra clues on where the economy is heading added a little more to the confusion about recovery yesterday.

title: HewlettPackard Payout Up
description: The HewlettPackard Company yesterday increased its semiannual dividend to 13 cents a share from 10 cents. payable Oct. 15 to shareholders of record Sept. 24.

title: Stock Average Up 3.60 For First Gain in 7 Days
description: Declines ran well ahead of advances again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed with its first gain in seven trading days.

title: Colby, in 1974, Reported Possible Perjury by Helms
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Central Intelligence Agency informed the Justice Department last year that Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, might have committed perjury in testimony before a Senate committee, according to inInformed Government officials.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Michel Legrand, the composerconductor known for his work in many films including the awardwinning French musical The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, directed by Jacques Demy, will make his movie directorial debut with Blind Love. The feature will be produced by the Condor Group, Inc., a newly formed company headed by Mr. Legrand, Nat Shapiro and Norman Schwartz, which acquired rights to the novel of that title by Patrick Cauvin published this spring by Houghton Mifflin. According to Mr. Schwartz, negotiations are currently under way for a screenwriter to adapt the book, which deals with the romance between a blind girl and a divorced, middleaged schoolteacher. Mr. Schwartz added that the English  language feature; which probably will include music by Legrand, hopefully will go into production this spring in the south of France.

title: JOAN BAEZ SINGS AT ASBURY PARK
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 23 Joan Baez's concert at the Nassau Coliseum Saturday night Is being billed as her only New York appearance. But this New Jersey spa isn't much. farther away from New York, and the 3,000seat capacity and Victorian boardwalk ambiance of its Convention Hall is a lot pleasanter than that of the gigantic Coliseum. Miss Baez referred to the hall at one joint during her concert here tonight as a real barn. But that seems more of a comment on her own sound system than on the hall; out front, some feedback aside, the acoustics were far clearer and cleaner than they could ever be in a basketball arena like the Coliseum.

title: state Lottery is the Prize in TV's Richest Game Show
description: In a shower of balloons, amid shrieks muffled by spirited band music, and before an audience of millions of television viewers; Jacqueline Rosenzweig, a 34yearold resident of Jamaica, Queens, who came to this country from Poland 14 years ago, became a millionaire last night as the grand prize winner of the New York State Million Dollar Lottery.

title: PROTEST TIES UP BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: About 4,000 doctors, nurses, other hospital workers, hospital community board members and patients blocked all lanes of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday for about 40 minutes during the noon slack traffic period to protest cuts in the municipal hospitals budgets.

title: Moody's Said to Plan Removal Of Favorable City Note Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service, the nation's leading rating service for municipal notes, is planning to remove its favorable rating of $3.9billion in New York City notes, perhaps as early as today, according to sources in the financial community.

title: A 3d Recall of Meat Is Announced After 11 Poisoning cases
description: A third recall of cooked beef rounds produced by the Cardinal Foods Corporation of Brooklyn has been announced by the United States Department of Agriculture following the outbreak of 11 cases of salmonella food poisoning traced to meat consumed in Edison, N.J.

title: ISRAELIS SEE GAIN ON A SINAI ACCORD
description: JERUSALEM, July 24Egypt's latest proposals of terms for a new Sinai accord were described by high Israeli officials today as serious and well considered. But important differences remain to be overcome on several issues, they added.

title: Turkish Aide Says Curbs On Bases Are Unavoidable
description: ANKARA, July 22Turkey's. Deputy Premier has declared that restrictions on the United States use of bases here might be unavoidable if the embargo on arms sales to Turkey continues.

title: Ford Names U.S. Delegates To United Nations Session
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) President Ford made a series of nominations today for the coming United Nations session.

title: New Books
description: Bogart & Bacall: A Love Story, by Joe Hyams (McKay, $9.95). Famous Books: Great Writings in the History of Civilization, by Robert B. Downs (Littlefield, Adams Paperback, Totowa, N. J., $2.95).

title: Willard Cummings,Artist,Dies; Founded the Skowhegan School
description: Willard W. Cummings, a portrait artist who was cofounder and president of the Skowhegan (Me.) School of Painting and Sculpture, died Wednesday evening in a Skowhegan hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Psychohistory remains a somewhat controversial discipline (some might not even call it a discipline). The pioneer in the technique of applying psychoanalysis to historical figures was, as in most things psychiatric, Sigmund Freud, in his study of Leonardo da Vinci. Erik H. Erikson's biographies of Martin Luther and Gandhi were generally acclaimed and represented the successful application of Mr. Erikson's own seminal ideas on the identity crisis. James David Barber has studied Presidential character with the clear intent of mattang psychohistory a predictive technique, and Bruce Mazlish, professor of history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and one of the most active academic pamphleteers of the method, did a 1972 study of Richard M. Nixon (In Search of Nixon) that holds up remarkably well.

title: Ford Disavows U.S. Report on Aged
description: WASHINGTON, July 24President Ford disavowed today a report by a Presidential council that charged his Administration with apparent lack of consideration for the economic plight of the elderly.

title: In Aemoriam
description: SILVERBERGSima Your birthday. Always in our hearts. THE FAMILY

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold Prices T???day London: Morning fixing $164.50, up $0.25; afternoon fixing $164.85, up 50.60.

title: BRITAIN WILL FREE ULSTER INTERNEES
description: LONDON, July 24The British Government announced plans today to end the controversial policy of interning suspected terrorists without trial in Northern Ireland and to release all internees by Christmas.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: LEVI TO ASK RUTH TO STAY IN OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that he would ask the Watergate special prosecutor to keep his office in operation until the appeals from several of its cases were settled.

title: DAILY NEWS UPHELD ON L.I. DISTRIBUTION
description: A Federal appeals court has given its approval to the way The Daily News distributes newspapers to homes on Long Island.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: LANDOVER. Md.Emile GrifPith, New York, 157 pounds, outpointed Leo Saenz, 156, Potomac, Md., 10 rounds.

title: MORELAND PANEL SEEKS ROCKEFELLER
description: The Moreland Act Commission investigating nursing homes voted unanimously yesterday to invite Vice President Rockefeller to testify concerning his staff's activities on behalf of Bernard Bergman, the nursing  home entrepreneur, when Mr. Rockefeller was Governor.

title: Pepsico Raises Dividend
description: Pepsico, Inc., announced yesterday an increase in its quarterly dividend to 40 cents, a share from 35 cents. The dividend is payable Sept. 30 to shareholders of record Sept. 9. The company attributed the increase to improved earnings and a better cash flow.

title: Summertime: Fishing is Dandy
description: From Barnegat to the popular haunts off Rhode Island, such species as bluefish, weaks, fluke and porgies were being taken in number. There even were giant tuna being found between Montauk and Block Island.

title: Reagan Backers Register
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) A committee officially promoting Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California, for President registered with the Federal Election Commission today. The committee was authorized by Mr. Reagan although he said in a letter that he had not made up his mind on becoming a Presidential candidate.

title: Market Place
description: Now, that Bond Industries, Inc., is offering to purchase all its outstanding shares at $6 each, many Wall Streeters are wondering whether the New York Stock Exchange acted in the best interest of investors when it delisted the company's shares.

title: McKeon Ousted by Royals
description: KANSAS CITY; July 24 (AP)Jack McKeon was dismissed as manager of the Kansas City Royals today and was replaced by Whitey Herzog, who had been a coach with the California Angels.

title: Russians Tell of Flight's Difficulties
description: MOSCOW, Friday, July 25The Soyuz 19 astronauts salt yesterday that they had experi enced tension and slight diffi culties on their joint space mission with the American Apollo.

title: Miss Ender Betters Record in Butterfly
U.S. REQUESTS DATA ON ARMS BUDGETS
description: GENEVA, July 24 The United States proposed today that the 30nation disarmament conference here study how the military expenditures reported by various nations could be expressed in comparable terms.

title: BEAME AND M.A.C. ASK A QUICK RISE IN TRANSIT FARES
description: Mayor Beame and the Municipal Assistance Corporation asked the Transit Authority yesterday to increase the 35cent fare on subways and bus lines by an unspecified amount as part of a program to restore the city's fiscal credibility.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: News Summary and Index
description: The House of Representatives rejected by a close vote of 223 to 206 a major effort by the Administration to partly lift the sixmonthold arms embargo against Turkey, The vote followed a day of often bitter debate and weeks of intensive lobbying by proGreek forces. It was regarded as a significant personal setback for Mr. Ford, who gained 103 votes from Democratic and Republican members of the House, but failed to carry 184 Democrats and 39 members of his own party; [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: The small restaurant that sets out to create an original personality for itself runs the danger of falling into eccentricity or preciousness, but here are a couple that have made the grade, and a newcomerabout a month oldthat still shows symptoms of birth trauma but is full of promise.

title: RollCall in the House on Bill to Renew Arms Sales to Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, JULY 24 (AP)  Following is the tally today by which the House of Representatives voted 223 to 206 to defeat a bill that would have permitted a partial resumption of arms sales to Turkey. Those voting no were against lifting the ban on sales.

title: DRUGGISTS PROTEST MEDICAID CHANGES
description: TRENTON, July 24 (AP)Four of every five phrarmacies in New Jersey are threatening to refuse to fill prescriptions in a protest over reductions in Medicaid payments, the State Pharmaceutical Association said today.

title: APCO SUIT ACCUSES CHEMICAL AND KUHN
description: The complaint in a suit filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by the Apco Oil Corporation against the Alaska Interstate Company of Houston has charged the Chemical Bank and Kuhn, Loeb & Co. with violations of the Federal Securities Act for financing Alaska Interstate in its tender offer for shares of Apco Oil.

title: Yankee Records
As Britain Tackles Inflation, Jobless Soar
description: LONDON, July 24While the British Government has wrestled to purge the country of rampant inflation, new troubles have developedthe worst recession since the nineteenthirties.

title: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: Business Records BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Chaos in Argentina
description: There are strong intimations of approaching chaosboth political and economicin Argentina. The nation's President, Isabel Martinez de Perlin, has been virtually deprived of all power in the last few weeks; the question now seems only when, not whether, she will finally be deprived of her title and position.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Merely to stroll around the South Street Seaport area with its picturesque old shops and dwellings, where you can also step aboard vintage ships anchored nearby, is one of the cooling weekend treats in town. And, there's entertainment in the evening. Thursdays through Saturdays at R:30 P.M. and Sundays at 7:30 P.M., through Aug. 31, the TheateronthePier (No. 17 at Fulton Street) is reviving the company's Spoon River Anthology from several summers back, an adaptation of Edgar Lee Masters's freeverse classic of smalltown life. Once again, four players and a folk singer will be creating a gallery of village inhabitants. The New York Times review of the original production said it was strong, vivid and Unpretty, rendered even more effective by the dockside setting. Tickets are $2.50. Reservations: 7669044.

title: Passport Chief, 70, May Just Go on and On
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Frances G. Knight is probably not immortal. It just seems that way. But there are very few people in Washington who would be prepared to state absolutely that the 70yearold head of the Passport Office won't go on for ever and ever.

title: LEVI MAY BLOCK CAREY OIL PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24Attorney General Edward H. Levi indicated today that he was not inclined to honor Governor Carey's request to make public all documents in a Justice Department investigation of Mr. Carey's alleged intervention, while in Congress, to obtain Federal licenses to export oil.

title: India, to Raise Exports, Tries to Sell Arabs Tea
description: CALCUTTA, India, July 20The Indian Government, hoping to win support by improving the economy, is trying to increase tea exports to the oilpioducing nations of the Arabian peninsula.

title: TAXPAYERS GET VETO ON RAISES
description: HACKENSACK, July 24 (AP) Judge George B. Gelman ruled in. State Superior Court here today that contracts between municipalities and their employes could be subject to public referendums.

title: Dorothy Day, 77, Is Dead; Actress, Writer and Critic
description: Dorothy Day, a former actress and writer, died yesterday at her home, 300 East 74th Street. She was 77 years old.

title: Jones to Stay a Met?
description: The Mets confirmed last night that they had suspended Clean Jones earlier this week because of his refusal to play last Friday, but said the Players Association had filed a countercharge. Consequently, they were trying to settle the impasse on a personal level between the 32yearold outfielder and Manager Yogi Berra.

title: Ashe Beats Amritraj in Tiebreaker
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)Arthur Ashe the Wimbledon champion, narrowly escaped defeat today in the $100,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament. He was forced into a thirdset tiebreaker against Vijay Amritraj of India, whom he finally defeated, 36, 63, 76. Ashe, seeded second, was ahead, 31, in the third set when a heavy rain storm caused a recess in play for more than an hour.

title: Possible Perjury by Helms Cited in 74 C.I.A. Report
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Central Intelligence Agency informed the Justice Department last year that Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, might have committed perjury in testimony before a Senate committee, according to informed Government officials.

title: City Hall Accused by Weisl of Breaking Promise of 700 Summer Jobs for Poor
description: Edwin L. Weisl Jr., the Administrator of Parks. Recreation and Cultural Affairs, said vesterday that City Hall had failed in its promise to fill the 700 summertime jobs it controlled in the Parks Department with members of minority groups and the poor.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: New Haven Clerk is Sentenced For Not Testifying in Fraud Case
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 24 Peter Lynch, the New Haven Town Clerk, was sentenced to an indefinite jail term today for refusing to testify before al special grand jury looking into this city's twoyearold votefraud scandal.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP)Net redemptions of mutual funds rose to $107.4million in June, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: New Hampshire Senator
description: In this Bicentennial commemoration period, we are often reminded that the United States was founded in part on the slogan, No taxation without representation. These days the citizens of New Hampshire have a right to complain that they are being governedand taxedby Washington while denied their full representation. They have only one member of the Senate while every other state has two.

title: School Critics Press Drive for Old Values
description: The dispute between parents and educators over what public schools should teach and what texts should be used has spread from West Virginia's Kanawha County, where it exploded in shots and arson last year, to dozens of other communities across the country.

title: CORRECTION
description: Due to an editing error, an article in The New York Times July 10 stated incorrectly that Medicare was a health insurance program for the indigent elderly. Anyone covered by Social Security is eligible for the program.

title: Jury Selection Starts in Priest's Death
description: SALEM, July 24Jury selection began today in the murder trial of David N. Gary, who is charged with murdering a priest and wounding a teacher last winter in a Penns Grove grammar school.

title: Plane Pool Reduced
Presidential Aide Critical
description: WASHINGTON, July 24(AP) A member of President Ford's political advisory group today criticized statements aimed at Vice President Rockefeller by Mr. Callaway.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: You can bounce quarters off the beds. No gum wrapper mars the sweep of the floor. Every cubbyhole is a model of neatness and organization worthy of the pages of a home furnishings magazine. Even the washrooms and communal shower stalls are immaculate. Inspection time at an army barracks? No, it's visiting day at summer camp.

title: Nicolas Rossolimo, 65, Is Dead; Grandmaster Ran Chess Studio
description: Nicolas Rossolimo, one of the country's 12 grandmasters of chess, and for more than 20 years the proprietor of a chess studio in Greenwich Village, died at St. Vincent's Hospital early yesterday, apparently of injuries suffered in a fall last Monday. He was 65 years old and lived at 144 East Seventh Street.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLIMB PRICE LIMIT
description: Additional Soviet grain purchases in Canada influenced a strong rise in futures prices on the Chicago. Board of Trade yesterday. But strength was particularly visible in soybeans, the commodity that the Russians have apparently not yet bought.

title: Ford Sums Up First Year In Differenet White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 24President Ford, affirming that he and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama share a good many similarities on domestic issues, is nearing the end of his first year in the White House with apparent confidence in the conservative course he has set.

title: The New Haven Leaves at 5:30 for Bastogne, Salerno, Anzio and Tobruk
description: July 3: Charlie has promised I can start my Basic Training next week: Wait till the fatter guys have fled to Vermont and Nantucket for the summer, Charlie said. When the 7:41 is less crowded thetes less danger some broadhipped commuter will squeeze himself between us to clainipossession of the middle seat.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt. Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P M.

title: Mary E. McKeveny Wed to Jay Nathan
description: Mary Elizabeth McKeveny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gerard McKeveny of Woodmere, L. I., and Sunset Beach, N. C., was marriedyesterday evening to Jay J. Nathan, son of Hyman Henry Nathan of New York and the late Eleanor Burnstine Nathan.

title: For a Positive U.S. Policy Toward Italy's Reds
description: BELLAGIO, ItalyItaly, a country considered for a long time to be the sick man of Europe, has emerged since the local, regional and provincial elections in June as an interesting, Squieting but maybe promising experiment.

title: Retail Sales Up in Week.
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Department of Commerce said today that total retail store figures for the week ending July 19 were an estimated $11.52billion, up 7 per cent from last years $10.56billion. Department store sales for the week ending July 19 were an estimated $1.06billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $973million.

title: Senators Vote to Extend Voting Rights Act 7 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Senate approved a bill extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for seven years and broadening the protection to include Spanishspeaking citizens and Dther language minorities.

title: Ruhs Takes Medal by Shot in Met. Golf
description: EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 24  Jack Ruhs, a lefthanded golfer who manufactures clubs for anyone righthanded or lefthanded, won today the medalplay portion of the Metropolitan Golf Association's 73d amateur tournament. His score was a fouroverpar 146 at Wheatley Hills Golf Club and his margin was one shot.

title: Bridge:
description: Italy, though not at full strength, is virtually certain to win the European bridge championship that ends tomorrow in Brighton, England.

title: SINGER CO. MOVES BACK INTO BLACK
Ballet: Rustic 'Coppelia by Canadians
description: The National Ballet of Canada is a company that lacks a great choreographer indeed in terms of residency nowadays it lacks even a bad choreographer. There is not a major Canadian choreographer, despite the efforts to find one by ell three of the Canadian classical companies Canada should take heartthere are tew cnoreographers anywhere. Meanwhile, still waiting the National Ballet has assumed the very reasonable policy of concentrating on certain revivals and sumptuously mounted productions of the old classics. It is far from being a foolish policyfor conskier the alternative.

title: The Human Touch of Emlen Tunnell
description: Almost hauntingly now, Einlen Tunnell once spoke of his reluctance to retire as a safetyman.

title: Army is Pushing Toward Luanda
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 25An armed column of angry black nationalists fought their way close to Luanda today in an effort to redress their defeat in the capital earlier this month by a rival political organization.

title: The Curse. Of Gray Shingles
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.On Nantucket, at least 99 out of every 100 buildings are gray; almost every summer cottage, the hospital, the high school, the statepolice station, the two supermarkets, the newspaper office, the steamboat dockyou name it and it's gray.

title: Dog Show Results
description: TERRIER (Michael Gately, judge)1, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Underhill's kerry blue terrier, Ch. Marberiane's Medicine Mann; 2, Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell, Jr.'s, lakeland terrier, Ch. Baron's Carbon Copy; 3, Mrs. Milton Fox's Australian terrier, Ch. Tlnee Town Talkbac Rorn; 4, Kae Smith and Ellyn Gabriel's Cairn terrier, Gingerbred's Rock Candy.

title: C.F.L. Punt Rule Has a Dissenter
description: TORONTO, July 5 (AP)The Canadian Football League, in an effort to make the game more exciting for fans, has changed its rules this year to allow blocking on punt return's. But Russ Jackson predicts the fans may be disappointed.

title: Canada Sets Guidelines for Arctic Oil
description: OTTAWA, July 25The Govenrment issued strict new guidelines today for an enhanced Canadian participation in the extensive development of Arctic oil and natural gas in the federally administered Yukon and Northwest Territories.

title: Concert: Summer Balm
description: To one who has been long in city pentin New York in July, to be specifica concert such as the one that the Mostly Mozart Festival offered Thursday night can come as an analgesic balm. Who could worry over the threat of the $1 subway ride or the $5 gallon of gasoline, for instance, while Paula Robison was blessing the air of Avery Fisher Hall in Mozart's Quartet for Flute and Strings in A (K.298), while Rudolf Firkusny was leading the way through Mozart's Quartet in E flat for piano and strings (K.493) or while the Tokyo String Quartet was probing Beethoven's String minor (Op. 95).

title: Rabin Says Terms Of Egypt on Sinai Are Not Acceptable
description: TEL AVIV, July 25Premkr Yitzhak Rabin said in a television interview tonight that Egypt's proposals for a new disengagement agreement in Sinai were still substantially not acceptable.

title: In Honduras the Land Issue is Creating a Dangerous Class Feud
description: JUTICALPA, Honduras, July 23Schools and bars have reopened, the dusktodawn curfew has been lifted and soldiers standing in full battle dress on street corners once again seem more interested in passing women than in possible guerrillas.

title: Webster Pulls the Strings at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 25 An unusual way to win a harness race developed tonight when a pair of pulled earplugs helped Hero Almahurst, owned by Kurt Bertmark of Sweden, capture the $101,550 Realization Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: SOVIET JEWS CITE CENSORSHIP CASE
description: MOSCOW, July 25  A grout of Soviet Jews asserted today that Soviet authorities were trying to suppress a nonpolitical Jewish publication here and in other cities.

title: Citizen Lee
description: Few Americans will be terribly excited by the restoration of citizenship to the late Gen. Robert E. Lee, C.S.A., even in his own home town of Lexington, Va., as a story in today's Times makes clear. Their subdued reaction no historical judgment on the beloved Confederate commander but rather on those easy symbolic gestures that from time to time delight the sentimental and assure politician a footnote in history as the dispenser of belated justice.

title: Charles H. Brown is Dead; Reporter and Editor was 61
description: Charles H. Brown, vice president and public relations director of the International Executives Service Corps here, died of cancer yesterday at his, home, 91 Pine Road, Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Adm. Thomas Klakring Dead; Sub Hero Sank 8 Japanese Ships
description: Rear Adm. Thomas B. Klakring, U.S.N. retired, one of the early submarine heroes of the Pacific battles off Japan in World War II and a former vice president of the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat Division, died Thursday at Balboa Naval Hospital in San Diego. He was 70 years old.

title: Javits and Buckley Fight Giving Aged Means Tests
description: WASHINGTON, July 24New York Senators, Jacob K. Javits and James L. Buckley, have often differed, but they are united in an effort to save thousands of people from having to take means tests in order to use services at federally financed centers for the elderly.

title: Fanfani: A BurntOut Case
description: ROMEThe Christian Democratic party has dominated Italian Governments for almost thirty years but during that period it produced only one great man, Alcide de Gasperi, and no identifiable ideology except for antiCommunism. Indeed, it used to be said that there were just two parties in this country, the antiCommunists and the Communists.

title: FURKEY IS HALTING MOST OPERATIONS AT BASES OF ES,
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 25.The Turkish Government announced tonight that it would halt virtually all activities at American military installations in Turkey starting tomorrow.

title: Computer and Spirit: The Chasm
description: The following is adapted from a speech by Farah Pah(evi, Empress of Iran, at a meeting of the hoard of trustees of the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies, in Colorado.

title: Cost of Electricity Rose 30% in 1974, E.P.A. Study Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) The price Americans paid for electricity jumped 30 per cent last year, primarily because of higher fuel costs, according to a report from the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Stands Over CityUnion Talks
description: City union leaders are reported to have asked Mayor Beame this week whether, he would guarantee no further layoffs if they gave up the 6 per cent wage increase they are due. He is reported to nave answered: I don't know. I have to do what they tell me.

title: Ford Appeal's for Reversal Of House Vote on Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 25President Ford said today that it was essential for the House of Representatives reverse itself and lift the arms embargo against Turkey that it reaffirmed yesterday.

title: Lee's Town Calm On His citizenship
description: LEXINGTON, Va., July 25 It isn't difficult to see why General Robert E. Lee, having just fought a war and lost it, would have moved to this quiet little town, assumed the presidency of a small college, and stayed for the rest of his life.

title: John S. Samuels 3d to Head City Center
description: John S. Samuels 3d, a lawyer and businessman virtually unknown in the city's cultural life, has been elected chairman of, the board of governors of the City Center of Music and Drama. His election, along with that of Martin J. Oppenheimer, also a lawyer, as vice chairman, is a key step in the radical reorganization of the City Center that has been going on for several months.

title: No Large Impact Is Seen on Prices in the Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Economists who had worried that a steep rise in oil prices could abort the recovery from the recession expressed considerable belief today over the new price decontrol plan presented to Congress by President Ford.

title: Rapid Garbage Pileup is Laid to Layoffs Confusion and Slow owns
description: City sanitation officials said yesterday that garbage was piling up on the streets at a faster rate than expected, not only because of layoffs in the department, but also because of confusion stemming from problems in redistributing the remaining work force properly, deliberate slowdowns by some men on the street, and low. morale.

title: Hathaway Resigns as Secretary for Reasons of Health, and President Accepts
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Secretary of the Interior, Stanley K. Hathaway, although encouraged last week by President Ford to stay on while recovering from moderate depression and physical exhaustion, submitted his resignation again today, and it was accepted by Mr. Ford with deepest regrets.

title: Hearings End on Massena Power Project
description: ALBANY, July 25More than a year after the residents of Massena voted to take over the electric power company in their town, the State Public Service Commission completed public hearings this week to determine how much it will cost.

title: Demand Adequate Security Against Muggers in Area
description: About 200 New York Times pressmen seeking adequatel protection against muggers and other undesirables in the vicinity of the Times plant at 229 West 43d Street staged a twohour protest last night, causing a delay in the production of the first edition of the newspaper.

title: Blackout Deepens Gloom at City Hall
description: Shrouded already in foggy fiscal gloom, New York's embattled City Hall blew a fuse yesterday and lost its cool as well as its lights.

title: Memo Filed With S.E.C. on Deal for Apco
description: John G. McMillian, chairman of the Northwest Energy Company of Salt Lake City, said yesterday that the company had filed a memorandum with the Securities and Exchange Commission criticizing the financing arrangement of the Alaska Interstate Company to gain control of the Apco Oil Corporation.

title: Samuelson Proposes More Tax Cuts, U.S. Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) Paul A. Samuelson, the economist, said today that the new tax cuts or higher Federal spending or both are needed to thea vigorous recovery from the recession.

title: WOMAN IS UPHELD ON STERILIZATION
description: BARNWELL, S. C., July 25 (UPI)A Federal court jury of five women and one man ruled today that Dr. Clovis Pierce had violated the civil rights of a young black woman when he demanded she be sterilized.

title: Dance: La Bayadere
description: When Marius Petipa choreographed La Bayadere in 1877 in Russia, the ballet's romantic theme and revengetragedy plot gave it a dramatic element that has not been able to travel across time or oceans.

title: Soybean Futures Up Amid Reports Of Soviet Demand
description: Soybean prices again moved up the 20cent limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, gaining their impetus from recurring reports that the Soviet Union was interested in buying soybeans and soybean meal. Both are a rich source of protein. Soybeans are often crushed for oil used in foods, and soybean meal is used to feed animals.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SITE AND SOUND Free classical music concerts by small ensembles in locales denoting American history are the theme of the Sunday programs being presented by the Bronx County Historical Society in such settings as the uptown Van Cortlandt Mansion, the Museum of Bronx History and Poe Cottage. Tomorrow's twohour session by the Bronx Opera Chamber Players, a trio, is at 2 P.M. and includes music by Morley, Telemann, Haydn, Vivaldi, Handel and Mozart.

title: Conservative Cleric Expelled by Kenya After Stating Views
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 25 (Reuters)  Kenya today deported Dr. Carl McIntire, president of the International Council of Christian Churches, which is holding its world congress here.

title: A REPUTED LEADER OF I.R.A. CONVICTED
description: DUBLIN, July 25  David O'Connell, generally regarded las one of the leaders of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army and its chief political strategist, was convicted here today of membership in the organization and sent to orison for a year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Few members of the faculties of the City University of New York would question the principle of the Open Admissions program. In opening the doors of the city colleges to those who prior to 1970 would have been restricted to a secondaryschool education, New York has provided the children of the economically most deprived segments of the community with an opportunity for intellectual growth and professional advancement that must surely benefit the community as a whole as well as the individual.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: PHILADELPHIA  Tyrone Everett, Philadelphia, stopped Huy??? Chi Kim, Korea, 6 rounds, ???

title: Maine Coast Towns Fighting Tax
description: CASTINE, Me., July 25This will be our Bicentennial project, Oskar H. Pedersen the town manager, said with a grin as he waited for the lawyers to arrive.

title: U.S. Handgun. Registration, Gains Support of Beanie
description: Calling for arms limitation talks within this country, Mayor Beame came out yesterday in support of Federal legislation to require registration of all handguns.

title: SIBYL TERMAN
description: STANFORD, Calif., July 25 (UPI) Sibyl Terman, a teacher and writer of books on children's reading problems, died here Wednesday. She was 73 years old.

title: Joint Chiefs Support Jordan Arms Cut
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at a hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Chiefs of Staff had unanimously recommended the sale to Jordan of only six batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles, not the 14 batteries proposed by the Ford Administration.

title: CHESTER A. BARCLAY
description: Chester A. Barclay, MUSE and former personnel manager of the American Ballet Theater and New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, died Monday in the Veterans Hospital in East Orange, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived in Port Murray, N.J.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 25 (UPI)The United States defeated Argentina, 6848, today to reach the basketball final in the Wheelchair Olympics. Don Vandello of Chicago scored 25 points and David Kiley of Huntington Beach, Calif., scored 17.

title: Senate Spy Unit Debates Calling Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence debated today in closed session whether to seek testimony from former president Richard M. Nixon on Cen tral Intelligence Agency operations in Chile, Senate sources said.

title: Motorist Who Has a Flat Is Killed Fleeing Mugger
description: A Queens motorist who was stopped on the Van Wyck Expressway early yesterday to repair a flat tire was killed by a hitandrun driver as he crossed the highway to escape a mugger who had assaulted him.

title: Geological Fault Causes Con Edison To Diop APlant
description: An upstate utility that had planned to build a nuclear Power plant at Somerset, N.Y., disiclosed yesterday that it was changing its plans and switching to a coal fired generating plant because a geologic fault had been lound 40 miles away.

title: Watergate Prosecutor Opposes Publication of Nixon Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) Henry S. Ruth, the special Watergate prosecutor, said today that he would not seek to make public former President Richard M. Nixon's testimony last month to two grand jurors, and that he doubted if such information could ever be made public.

title: Two Inches of Rain Here In 6 Hours Causes Floods
description: Thunderstorms swept into the metropolitan area early yesterday morning and by dawn had dumped two inches of rain on the city, disrupting subway operations, flooding roadways and cutting off telephone service to 900 subscribers on the Lower East Side.

title: MISS LITTLE DENIED COCOUNSEL STATUS
description: RALEIGH, July 25  The judge at the Joan Little murder trial denied today a motion by defense attorneys to permit Miss Little, a 21yearold black woman, to act as cocounsel in her own defense.

title: Books of The Times
description: Eightyfive years ago no newspaper reader would have had any difficulty identifying Katharine O'Shea or Charles Stewart Parnell, the Irish Nationalist leader who jolted her into notoriety when he was named corespondent in her husband's suit for divorce. The scandal shook English and Irish politics and reverberated strongly among IrishAmericans, for the revelation of Parnell's 10year relationship with Mrs. O'Shea effectively shattered his leadership of the Home Rule movement and the cause of Irish unity. Now the scandal is a remote memory, interred as a longpast chapter in the turbulent history of Ireland. Its revival by Joyce Marlow is a brilliant tour de force that is a biography of Mrs. O'Shea, a recital of the scandal and a superb portrait of uppermiddleclass NA in Victorian England.

title: Political Health Care
description: The laws of New York State governing nursing homes were victims of a bipartisan gang rape, Dr. Andrew Fleck, the state's former First Deputy Commissioner Health, told the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes. What he meant has become clear the last few days as a parade of present and former high state and city officials have been interrogated by the commission about their extraordinary solicitude for the Bernard Bergman nursing home interests.

title: Foreign Purchases Of U.S. Stocks Up
description: Foreign buying of American stock is on the upswing, the New York Stock Exchange has reported.

title: Sweden With Spain In Cup Play
description: The European Davis Cup one finals opened yesterday with Bjom Borg carrying the burden for Sweden in Zone A and Jan Kodes the key man for Czechoslovakia in Zone B.

title: LESTER JOHNSON, EXCONGRESSMAN
description: AUGUSTA, Wis., July 25 (AP)  Lester R. Johnson, farmer and country lawyer who shook the nation's Republicans with an upset victory in a 1953 Congressional race, died last night, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

title: Mother Sentenced For Bombing Role In West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 25A 28yearold mother of two preschoolaged children and a 29yearold male accomplice were sentenced by a federal judge here today to prison terms for their, roles last fall in a bombing conspiracy that temmed from protests over school textbooks used in Kanawha County.

title: Hathaway Resigns
description: Interior Secretary Standby K. Hathaway, in the hospital for moderate depression and physical exhaustion, submitted his resignation to President Ford a second time, and it was accepted. Page 10.

title: Capital Gains Levy Is Voted in Jersey And Sent to Byrne
description: TRENTON, July 25The State Assembly, after two false starts, gave final legislative approval this evening to a capital gains tax designed to provide $65million to help restore programs cut from the current state budget for reasons of economy.

title: Student Held in Zaire Since May is Freed
description: STANFORD, Calif., July 25 (AP)Stephen Smith, a Stanford University research assistant held captive by, rebels in eastern Zaire since May 19, has been released unharmed, university officials reported tonight.

title: Jacobson is Injured.
description: Larry Jacobson, a defensive tackle, suffered a fractured left ankle in scrimmage yesterday afternoon and may be lost to the Giants for the entire National Football League season.

title: About the Yankees.
description: Ron Blomberg said he had visited the doctor about his ailing right shoulder and was told not to swing a bat for three weeks. It's conceivable that the designated hitter will do no more hitting this season  Pat Dobson developed some stiffnesses in his right arm after his last start, but he threw before last night's game and said he could pitch today. That gave some relief to Manager Bill Virdon. He has to start Tippy Martinez, his lateinning reliever, in tomorrow's doubleheader because the rainout in Chicago last Wednesday delayed George Medich's start for a day  Catfish Hunter will pitch the other game, while Rogelio Moret and Bill Lee will go for Boston  Yankees had advance sale of about 112,000 for the Red Sox series, including 47,000 for tomorrow.

title: PATTI WICKS'S JAZZ HAS A WIDE CONCEPT
description: In the five years that Patti Wicks has been in New York pursuing a jazz career as a pianist and occasional singer, she has, through necessity, played more cocktail lounges and restaurants than jazz rooms. As a result, when she is in a jazz roomas she is currently Thursdays through Sundays at West Boondock, 10th Avenue at 17th Street  she brings a broader concept of performance to her work than most pianists who concentrate solely on jazz.

title: FORD SEEKS FUNDS FOR FOOD STAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) President Ford asked Congress today to appropriate an, additional $3billion to cover food stamp costs that have nearly doubled in the last six months under the strain of rising unemployment.

title: India Arrests One of. Her Most Important Journalists
description: NEW DELHI, July 25 The Indian Government, continuing its crackdown on dissidents, today arrested one of the country's most prominent journalists.

title: LICENSES SUSPENDED AT GRAIN ELEVATORS
description: DALLAS, July 25 (UPI)The Agriculture Department announced the suspensions today of the Federal warehouse licenses of the Bunge Corporadon grain elevators in Destrehan, La., end Galveston, Tex., effective at the close of business tomorrow.

title: Children's Summer Days Are Filled With Music
description: Are there actually bright, healthy, active children from 8 to 12 years old who, instead of using the long summer days for tennis, baseball, swimming and other sports, would rather be indoors studying something?

title: Rapid Garbage Pileup is Laid to Layoffs, Confusion and Slowdowns
description: City sanitation officials said yesterday that garbage was piling up on the streets at a faster rate than expected, not only because of layoffs in the department, but also because of confusion stemming from problems in redistributing the remaining work force properly, deliberate slowdowns by some men on the street, and low morale.

title: Olympic Preview Has 278 Long Jump,
description: MONTREAL, July 25The Olympic spirit is alive even one year early and engulfed in high winds.

title: Brewer, Nicklaus Tie at 136
description: MONTREAL, July 25 (AP) Gay Brewer made two sand shots for birdies, scored aneagle, rallied from three strokes off the pace with a 68 and tied Jack Nicklaus for a onestroke lead today after the second round of the $200,000 Canadian open golf tournament.

title: Bonn Opposition Bids Schmidt Refuse to Sign Helsinki Accord
description: BONN, July 25The opposition Christian Democratic Union demanded during a special session of the West German Parliament today that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt refuse to sign the closing declaration of the European security conference next week.

title: Ford Sees 35Nation Charter as a Gauge on Rights in East Europe
description: WASHINGTON, July 25President Ford declared today that the European security agreement he will sign next week in Helsinki will provide a yardstick to gauge advances in human rights for subjects of Communist rule in Eastern Europe.

title: A Compromise Plan on Oil Sent to Congress by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, July 25President Ford sent to Congress today a new plan for a gradual rise in oil prices that included some concessions intended to make it acceptable to the Democratic Congress.

title: Black and White Incomes: The Gap
description: There were many surprises in the Census Bureau's annual survey of the income inequalities of race, released this week.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Assadated Press

title: Leftists in Argentina Begin Attacks on Policel Stations
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 25 (AP) Leftist guerrillas using a bazooka, firebombs and machine guns began attacks tonight around Buenos Aires. Seven police stations were raided and at least three officers were wounded, the police said.

title: State Orders 3 Nursing Homes in City To Close by Thursday for Deficiencies
description: Three nursing homes in New York City, two owned by Eugene Hollander, who was recently indicted by state and Federal grand juries on charges of stealing more than $1.2million in Medicaid and Medicare funds, have been ordered to close by Thursday, State Health Commissioner Robert P. Whalen announced yesterday.

title: Cosmos Acquire Ord
description: The New York cosmos have purchased Tommy Ord from the Rochester Lancers for a substantial cash sum. Ord, the Lancers leading scorer, will play against his former teammates Wednesday night when th Cosmos meet Rochester in a North American Soccer League game her.

title: STATE PANEL SPLITS ON TOCKS I. PROJECT
description: TRENTON, July 25 (AP)A citizen's advisory committee appointed by Governor Byrne to advise him on the Tocks Island Dam proposal split down the middle today off what he should recommend.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERIKANIS (Costa), Left Bermuda July 24; due A A.M. at W. 55th St. DORIC (Nom), Left Bermuda, July 24; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th St.

title: A FARE INCREASE TO 45 OR 50c SEEN; FERRY RISE VOTED
description: Bus and subway fares will increase to 45 or 50 cents now and perhaps rise again next year, deficit projections released by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority indicated last night.

title: F.D.A. SEEKS APPEAL OVER PREGNANCY KIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration asked the Justice Department today to appeal a Federal court decision involving a doityourself pregnancy test kit. It said the decision could hobble its regulation of diagnostic medical devices.

title: Beverly Voted Head of Lacrosse Group
description: James E. Beverly of Annapolis, Md. long affiliated with the Maryland Lacrosse Club, has been elected president of the United States Club Lacrosse Association. He succeeds Joseph B. Harlan of Baltimore.

title: HOLGER C. ACKERLIND
description: Holger C. Ackerlind, president of Ackerlind Steel Company, Inc., died yesterday of cancer at his home here. He was 57 year old.

title: He's Carrying a Purse and He's Proud of
description: The first thing I'd better get straight is that I got my prose as a Christmas present from my wife. I wouldn't want those who care about such things to get the wrong idea about my deployment of what until fairly recently has been virtually a homosexual identification badge.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices moved lower yesterday on reduced trading on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market. It marked the seventh consecutive decline and reflected continuing uncertainties surrounding interest rates and inflationary prospects.

title: Six Youths Seized In Three Slayings And Thefts on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UPI) Barbara Colby, 36yearold daughterinlaw of Ethel Merman, the singer, was shot to death with a man last night in the parking lot of a dramatic school in the Palms district of West Los Angeles, the police disclosed today.

title: Ford Appeals for Reversall Of House Vote on Turkey;
description: WASHINGTON, July 25President Ford said today that it was essential for the House of Representatives reverse itself and lift the arms embargo against Turkey that it reaffirmed yesterday.

title: Museum Show Here Focuses on Revolutionary Days
description: A New Yorker picking up a leaflet on July 9, 1776, might have been delighted  or shockedthat he had become an American.

title: WOMAN, 80, IS SLAIN IN BRONX APARTMENT
description: While her elderly roommate was shopping, an 80yearold woman was stabbed to death in their sixthfloor apartment in the Bronx Thursday, the police renorted.

title: Now, the Lighter News From Israel
description: JERUSALEM, July 25The case of the disappearing cablegram, the furor over Abba Eban's bill at the Hotel Pierre, the personal pique of the prima donna labor boss at Ash dod port  these are topics absorbing Israelis this summer.

title: Business Records
description: INCR ES LINE AGENCY. INC., 277 Park Ave., N.Y. Signed by Sven Hansen, president. A list or creditors represent claims against alleged bankrupt.

title: ITALY'S MAIN PARTY ELECTS NEW LEADER
description: ROME, July 26 (Reuter) Italy's governing Christian Democratic party today elected a compromise candidate, Benigno Zaccagnini, as its new leader.

title: Britton, Dalrymple Gain Golf Final
description: EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 25Bill Britton, a 19yearold golfer from Staten island, became today the first ???? links player to reach the final of a Metropolitan Golf Association amateur Champion in the 73d annual tournament at Wheatley Hills Golf Club.

title: Depression Called One of Most Treatable Disorders
description: Most authorities on mental, depression agree that there is seldom any medical reason why an episode of the malady should disqualify from publici office a person other than one with his finger on the button.

title: Next Steps in Space
description: The safe return of the Apollo crew completes the historic ApolloSoyuz manned space mission. That mission fulfilled its objectives, which were primarily political rather than technical and scientific, demonstrating that the United States and Soviet Union can cooperate harmoniously and successfully toward a common objective despite differences of ideology, language and technical orientation. Only the absence of political will would prevent future joint ventures for mutual advantage, which could be expanded to represent all of the earth's population.

title: Geological Fault Causes Con Edison To Drop APlant
description: An upstate utility that had planned to build a nuclear power plant at Somerset, N.Y., disclosed yesterday that it was changing, its plans and switching to a coalfired generating olant because a geologic fault had been found 40 miles away.

title: American Released in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July. 25 Pathet Lao have released an American tourist after holding him 14 days without charges. la United States Embassy spokesman said today. The Embassy said the man, whose name was not given, was detained July 11 after he went to a police station to complain about a taxi driver overcharging him by 33 cents.

title: Court is Told Professor Smuggled Drugs Into U.S
description: An agricultural  journalism professor at the University of Wisconsin went on trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that he had conspired to import and sell cocaine here that he had picked up while working in Chile on projects sponsored by the university and the Ford Foundation.

title: Aid Group Says U.S. Curbs Export of Items to Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The, American Friends Service Coinmittee disclosed today that it had been denied a license to ship agricultural and fishing equipment to North or South Vietnam and charged that the action represented a change of policy on the part of the Government.

title: Temple, Penn State Shift Their Game
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) The Penn StateTemple football game, originally scheduled for Nov. 15 at State College, Pa., has been rescheduled for Sept. 6 at Franklin Field here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Turkish Government announced yesterday that it would halt virtually all activities at American military installations in Turkey starting today. The fictionwas taken in retaliation for the refusal Thursday by the United States House of Representatives to approve the respmption of arms shipments to Turkey. Ankara said existing joint defense agreements had lost their legal validity. The air base at Incirlik in southern Turkey was excepted from the order, but Ankara specified that it would allow only defense activities there on behalf of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Ford Considering Visit To Auschwitz Camp
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  The White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today that President Ford was considering a visit to the Auschwitz concentration and death camp operated my Nazi Germany in occupied Poland during World War II.

title: CONFEREES BACK ARMS FUND RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 House and Senate conferees agreed today on a military procurement bill that authorizes preliminary funding for production of a B1 strategic bomber costing $84million a plane and construction of a $1.2billion nuclearpowered cruiser for the Navy.

title: Common Market Reaches Accord With Arab League
description: ROME, July 25 (UPI)The European Common Market and the Arab League said today that they had agreed to explore prospects for cooperation, In industry, farming, finance, trade and technology.

title: SECURITY CHECKS ENDING IN CAMPS
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 25With security checks completed on all but a handful of the Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees who have arrived at four military bases in this country, only 57 are being held up for further investigation, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today.

title: A Compromise Plan on Oil, Sent to Congress by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, July 25President Ford sent to Congress today a new plan for a gradual rise in oil prices that included some concessions intended to make it acceptable the Democratic Congress.

title: Concorde Jetliner Clears Big Barrier to U.S. Flights
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (Reuters)The AngloFrench supersonic jetliner Concorde today cleared another major obstacle standing in the way of flights to the United States.

title: PRESSMEN DELAY EDITION OF TIMES
description: About 200 New York Times pressmen seeking adequate protection against muggers and other undesirables in the vicinity of The Times plant at 229 West 43d Street staged a twohour protest last night, causing a delay in the productide of the first edition of the newspaper.

title: CORRECTED VOTES ON ARMS TO TURKEY
description: The list showing the House of Representatives vote on arms sales to Turkey printed in The New York Times yesterday contained a number of errors in early editions. Following is a tally of the votes of those Representatives who were listed incorrectly. Those voting no were against lifting the ban on sales.

title: Welcome is Canceled
description: HONOLULU, July 25  An elaborate public ceremony at the Pearl Harbor Naval Base that would have given the Apollo astronauts a typical Hawaiian welcome was canceled today after they were admitted to Triplet Army Medical Center.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Abductors Free Sardinian
description: NUORO, Sardinia, July 25 (Reuters)Sardinian industrialist, Italo Maffei, was released by kidnappers today after spending nearly two months in captivity, the police said. It was not known how much the Maffei family paid in ransom.

title: Douglas P. Sinsel Weds Pamela Gibson
description: Pamela Gibson, a television studio audio engineer with the National Broadcasting Company, was married yesterday afternoon to Douglas Putnam Sinsel, a producer with the NBC News Today program. The Rev. Dr. Stanert Dransfield performed the ceremony in the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L. I.

title: Music: Newport Rarities
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 25The seventh annual Newport Music Festival may be under new management, but the musicians remain very much the same as in previous years, and the programs are still the most unusual to be found at any American music festival.

title: Process Purifies Contaminated Blood
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Two chemical engineers at the Tufts Medical School in Boston believe they have eliminated the danger of serum hepatitis, a disease causing inflamma tion of the liver. The hepatitis is often contracted from blood transadministered for various medical reasons. Prof. Stanley E. Charm and Bing Lou Wong, an instructor, were granted patent 3,896,218 this week, assigning it to a foundation that will license industry.

title: ARTHUR MILLS
description: UTICA, N.Y., July 25 (UPI)Arthur Mills, a coach for the 1945 world champion Detroit Tigers in baseball team, died here Wednesday. He was 72 years old.

title: Power Plant's Effect on Sea Life Tested
description: BRIGANTINEWhat happens to aquatic life when you draw three billion gallons of sea water a day into a billiondolar offshore nuclear power plant and expel it hark 17 degrees warmer?

title: Du Pont Announces Increases In Prices of Dacron and Orlon
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., said yesterday that it was raising pric6's for dacron polyester staple and orlon acrylic fiber, effective immediately. The giant chemical company said that the price of dacron would be raised by 5 cents a pound to 50 cents and orlon by varying amounts up to 10 cents a pound.

title: Impasse in Jones Case
description: CHICAGO, July 25  The Mets failed to resolve the Cleon Jones situation today, but they have two options. Jones is under suspension by the club for a series of incidents, the latest involving a refusal last week to take the field when ordered to by Manager Yogi Berra.

title: Coach Out of Hospital
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 25 (UPI)Jack Wallace, the Drake University football coach, was released from the University Hospital in Iowa City today. Wallace, 49 years old, underwent surgery eight days ago to repair three bypass arteries around the heart.

title: Harold Cutbill, 77, Runner Known as Flying Parson
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 25Harold Cutbill, the runner known as the Flying Parson because he had also been a minister, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: GOLD
description: Sewed World gold prices Friday. London: Morning fixing 5165.00, up $0.15; afternoon fixing $166.25,. up $1.60.

title: City on Trial
description: This ominous warning was sounded the other day a letter to the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation from the underwriters who must market M.A.C. Ps next bond offering if New York City is to be saved from imminent fiscal collapse.

title: Home Health Care
description: Strange and horrible things are apt to happen in the dark of night in Albany even when it isn't Halloween. As the last session of the Legislature was ending with efforts to control the buccaneers in the nursing home industry, somebody slipped through a bill that would enable them to enter the closely related home health field.

title: DEMOCRATS OPEN TV RUSH TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Democratic party will go on network television for 22 consecutive hours this weekend in its most ambitious attempt to promote massive fundraising and political propaganda within a popular entertainment format.

title: Talks on SouthWest Africa Will Begin in September
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, July 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  Constitutional talks on the political future of SouthWest Africa, also known as Namibia, will open here on Sept. 1 between tribal leaders and the South African Government, it was announced here today.

title: TV LOTTERY SHOW GETS POOR RATING
description: The telecast Thursday night of the final phase of the state milliondollar lottery on WABCTV drew disappointing ratings in the metropolitan area, reachlog only 19 per cent of the homes tuned to television from 730 to 8 P.M.

description: Photos made in Cambodia shortly after the Khmer Rouge takeover have been published

title: BEAME CENSURES HIS COMMISSIONERS
description: Describing himself as damned, angry and upset, Mayor Beame yesterday Charged his administrators and commissioners with providing him with faulty figures on personnel layoffs and allowing city employes to leave work even earlier than 4 P.M.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration arrested three men on a street in Point Lookout, L.1., Thursday night, seizing $150,000 in cash, 10 kilograms of heroin, reportedly worth $5million on the street, and three automobiles, one of which allegedly contained $16,000. The three men, accused of trying to sell the heroin, were identified as Charles A. DiPalermo, 50 years old, of 10 Eyck Avenue, Greewood Lake, N.Y., and Joseph A. Salvato, 29, of 1705 Shore Parkway, Brooklyn. The third person seized is Robert LeBoy of Paris.

title: Portuguese Give Three Key Generals Full Political and Military Authority
description: LISBON, July 25  Portugal's governing Armed Forces Movement entrusted political and military power tonight to its three leading figures, all generals  President Francisco da Costa Gomes, Premier Vasco Gonalves and Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, the head of internal security forces.

title: Antiques: Top Collection M ay Lead to Bottle Auction of Century
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.Fortysix years ago next month Charles B. Gardner purchased his first period bottle, an early 19thcentury, cornucopiashaped flask made in Coventry. Conn.

title: Market Place
