title: Byrne Urges Fast Start On Exploratory Drilling
description: OCEAN CITY, July 25Governor Byrne called today for a swift start on exploratory drilling for oil and gas off, the Atlantic Coast.

title: Apco Flight: Key to Northwest Energy
description: A fight among board members of the Northwest Energy Company, a major natural gas pipeline enterprise in the Pacific Northwest and Rocky Mountain region, for control of the company's activities has spilled into public view. It has become a classic takeover battle involving a bidding war, lawsuits and big financial names in New York.

title: BERME CENSURES HIS COMMISSIONERS
description: Describing himself as damned angry and upset, Mayor Beame yesterday charged his administrators and commissioners with providing him with faulty figures on personnel layoffs and allowing city employees to leave work even earlier than 4 P.M.

title: Silver Bullet Streaks Into Giants Camp
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 25  Andy Selfridge drove The Silver Bullet toward the practice field at Pace University today before he was stopped by an attendant wearing a white New York Giant tshirt.

title: Bears Aide Hired As Seattle's Scout
description: SEATTLE (AP)  Ralph Goldston, a 44yearold offensive backfield coach with the Chicago Bears, has been named staff scout for the Seahawks, Seattle's National Football League team that will begin play in 1976.

title: Now, the Lighter News From Israel
description: JERUSALEM, July 25The case of the disappearing cablegram, the furor over Abba Eban's bill at the Hotel Pierre, the personal pique of the prima donna labor boss at Ash dod port  these are topics absorbing Israelis this summer.

title: J. Kutsher is Dead at 62; Catskills Club PartOwner
description: Joseph Kutsher, executive director and partowner of the Kutsher Country Club in Monticello, N.Y., died at the club yesterday after having suffered a heart attack the night before. He was 62 years old.

title: U.S. Prods Local Gas Stations To Post Ceiling Prices of Fuel
description: On orders from Washington, the Federal Energy Administration in the New YorkNew Jersey region has embarked on a campaign to get local service stations to post the ceiling prices of gasoline.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, July 25 (Reuters)The Bank of England today increased its minimum lending rate by one percentage point in a move that it hopes will help to protect the external position of the pound.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Index of Commodity Prices Fell to 196.5 in the Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 196.5 from 196.8 last week.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Turkish Government announced yesterday that it would halt virtually all activities at American military installations in Turkey starting today. The action was taken in retaliation for the refusal Thursday by the United States House of Representatives to approve the resumption of arms shipments to Turkey. Ankara said existing joint defense agreements had lost their legal validity. The air base at Incirlik in southern Turkey was excepted from the order, but Ankara specified that it would allow only defense activities there on behalf of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. [Page 1, Column 8.1

title: Divided. Stakes Tops Belmont's Closing Card
description: The downstate thoroughbred racing program will be interrupted after today's program at Belmont Park, and the action will shift to Saratoga on Monday. Featuring today taro is the Lexington Handicap, a turf event that has attracted so many candidates that it will be run in two divisions.

title: Merchant Says U.S. Guns Never Arrived in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25A Lebanese arms merchant said today that a controversial consignment of American  made handguns originally approved by the State Department for retail sale in troubled Lebanon had not been delivered here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In early editions of The New York Times yesterday, because of typographical errors some Representatives votes in the House rollcall on arms sales to Turkey were listed incorrectly. A corrective article appears on Page 7.

title: Waldheim, in Cairo, Says Sadat is Impatient on Talks With Israel
description: CAIRO. July 25  Secretary General Waldheim said tonight that he was convinced President Anwar elSadat was in favor of a negotiated settlement with Israel and genuinely impatient over the slow pace of negotiations.

title: Media General and Knight Sign Newsprint Study Pact
description: RICHMOND July 25 (UPI)Media General, Inc., and KnightRidder Newspapers, Inc., said today they had signed an agreement for studying the feasibility of a joint project to construct a newsprint mill in the Southeast.

title: TURKEY IS HALTING MOST OPERATIONS AT BASES OF U.S.
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 25The Turkish Government announced tonight that it would halt virtually all activities at American military installations in Turkey starting tomorrow.

title: School Principals Win Tenure in Bill Signed by Carey
description: ALBANY, July 25School principals, assistant principals and other middle level administrators will be granted tenure after a threeyear probationary period, under a bill signed today by Governor Carey.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. James Lawson, president of Fisk University in Nashville, resigned yesterday, citing ill health as the reason. Dr. Lawson who has been on sick leave since April, became president in 1967.

title: Astronauts Suffer Effects of Fumes; Placed in Hospital
description: HOUSTON, July 25  The Apbllo astronauts entered Tripler Army Hospital in Hdnolulu today for observation and treatment of respiratory irritations suffered when their spacecraft filled with a yellowish noxious gas during their return to earth yesterday.

title: Swiss Team Championship Opens Weekend Play Today
description: Team enthusiasts in New York City face their second weekend of serious tournament play this weekend. If they failed to win any titles in the Fun City Regional last weekend, they can try again in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss Team Championship.

title: Mr. Hathaway Resigns
description: The failure of health which has led to the resignation of Secretary of Interior Stanley K. Hathaway is highly regrettable, and we wish him a speedy recovery. While this newspaper strongly opposed his appointment because of his poor environmental record as Governor of Wyoming, one aspect of his leaving a post he had occupied hardly more than a month entitles him to the respect those who fought his nomination.

title: U.S. Team Disqualified in Relay After Breaking a World Record,:
description: CALI, Colombia, July 25 (AP)Bruce Furniss started the final leg of a race premateurely tonight and disqualified the American team after a worldrecording seting performance in the 800meter freestyle relay in the world aquatics championship.

description: Fireball Class (even numbered divin)1, Gerald Coleman, Larchmont; 2, Tucker Edumundson, Noroton; 3, Ellen Coneys, Port Washington; 4, Kitty Csenee, Larchmont; 5, Paul Dickey, Indian Harbor; 6, Mark Werner.

title: Bill to Assist Flood Victims Passed by AssemblySenate Approval Seen,
description: TRENTON, July 25The Assembly this evening unanimously passed on an emergency basis a bill that would provide $500,000 in additional state and Federal assistance to victims of New Jersey's disastrous floods.

title: Making Time Sympathetic
description: Watchmaking reached its zenith in the half century that AbrahamLouis Breguet, the Swiss horological genius, catered to European aristocracy from, for the most part, his Paris workshop. In Breguet's hands, the chubby, rarely reliable pocket watch evolved from a toy to a refined tool so admirable in design and mechanical sophistication that further horological advances would not occur until more than 80 Nears after his death at 76 in 1823.

title: Simon Tells M.A.C. Aides U.S. Aid to City is Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Treasury Secretary William E Simon told officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation today that the Federal Government was not likely tc ease New York City's fiscal crisis, even if the city put an austerity program into effect of defaulted on its bonds.

title: Shipments Show Drop For Canada Newsprint
description: MONTREAL, July 25 (AP) Canadian newsprint shipments in June totaled 786,741 tons, down 2.4 per cent from May, but up 1.5 per cent from June 1974, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association said today.

title: Massena Power Talks
description: The New York State Public Service Commission completed hearings this week to determine how much it will cost for the residents of Massena to take over the electric power company in their own on Page 33.

title: Conferees Agree on Arms Bill; New Plane and Cruiser Backed
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 House and Senate conferees agreed today on a military procurement bill that authorizes preliminary funding for production of a B1 strategic bomber costing $84million a plane and construction of a $1.2billion nuclearpowered cruiser for the Navy.

title: Ford Vetoes School Bill as Inflationary
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 President Ford vetoed today $7.9billion aidtoeducation bill saying it would add too much to the Federal budget and was therefore inflationary.

title: People and Business
description: George W. McKinney, senior vice president and chief economist of the Irving Trust Company, urggd yesterday a reduction in the reserve deposits member banks must maintain with the Federal Reserve System.

title: Talk Between Astronauts and Ground
description: HOUSTON. July 25 (AP) Following is a partial transcript of the conversation relating to the gas seepage problem aboard Apollo as the space ship splashed down in flip Pacific Ocean yesterday.

title: ALASKA DOCTORS WORK UNINSURED
description: Many doctors in Alaska, confronted by soaring rates for malpractice insurance, have begun to practice medicine without the liability insurance that doctors elsewhere consider indispensable for their personal economic security. Of Alaska's 315 licensed doctors, at least 63, or 20 pei cent, have no malpractice insur ance, according to Dr. Gary Hedges, president of the Alaska State Medical Association.

title: Art: Whitney Unpacks Abstracts
description: The big fourthfloor gallery space of the Whitney Museum, originally designed by Marcel Breuer to accommodate the kind of large, muralsize paintings and immense constructed sculpture that became commonplace in American art from the late nineteenfifties onward, has tended to be more of a problem than a solution for the museum's installation staff. The walls rise to a height of 11 feet 9 inches; the busy ceiling fixtures obtrude unmercifully on the display of every object, no matter how great its size; and the absurd single window on the north wall, looking like the vaguely as kew afterthought it was, lends a slightly comic affect to every exhibition, no matter how solemn its intention.

title: A FARE INCREASE TO 45 OR 50c SEEN; FERRY RISE VOTED
description: Bus and subway fares will increase to 45 or 50 cents now and perhaps rise again next year, deficit projections released by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority indicated last night.

title: Fate of Ford Oil Proposal In Congress is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Congress is deeply split over President Ford's new oilpricing proposal, and it was not clear today whether the plan would be rejected next week.

title: Hone Dim for Arms Sales to Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24American hopes of selling arms to Yugoslavia and thereby establishing valuable political contacts with military leaders here have apparently been stalemated.

description: HOUSTON, July 25  The Apollo astronauts entered Tripler Army Hospital in Honolulu today for observation and treatment of respiratory irritations suffered when their spacecraft filled with a yellowish noxious gas during their return to earth yesterday.

title: 2to1 Turndown of Minorities For Mortgage Loans is Found
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A survey of six metropolitan areas by the Controller of the Currency shows that minoritygroup applicants for mortgage loans are rejected almost twice as often as white applicants in the same financial brackets.

description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates tel Friday.

title: Mets Defeat Cubs, 63; Kingman Clouts 20th
description: CHICAGO, July 25The New York Mets, who may or may not be as good as when they last played here at the end of April, won, 63, today from the Chicago Cubs, who definitely aren't as good as they were at the end of April.

title: SENATOR DEFENDS PANEL'S EXPENSES
description: TRENTON, July 25, (AP)Senator Joseph Merlino, state chairman of the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee, said today that a bill of nearly $25,000 that his committee ran up for consultants fees, hotel bills, lunches, dinner and other expenditures, was not excessive.

title: Jets Still Looking For Talented Legs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. July 25'There's 60,000 people watching you, You can't choke! shouted Coach Charley Winner to his kickers today.

title: African Group Studies Action on Israel
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 25 Foreign ministers meeting here to prepare the agenda for the Organization of African Unity conference next week today named a committee to prepare a resolution seeking the ouster of Israel from the United Nadons.

title: WAGE CONTRACTS TOPPING 74 GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25Despite the recession and high unemployment, wage settlements won by unions in the first half of this year averaged a little higher than last year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: NEW PLAN ON OIL OFFERED BY FORD
description: A view believed to be held by some members of Congress on the oil issue was voiced by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, an energy subcommittee chairman. He said that he could not support a move toward higher oil prices until Congress, or at least the House, committed itself to adoption of a windfall profits tax coupled with income tax rebates to individuals. sumption and encourage production.

title: Dow Down 6.96 to 833.31 On interestRate Worry
description: Unable to shake off concern over the nearterm course of interest rates, the stock market moved lower again yesterday in moderate trading.

description: TEL AVIV, July 25Premier Yitzhak Rabin said in a tele vision interview tonight that Egypt's proposals for a new disengagement agreement in Sinai were still substantially not acceptable.

description: BANGKO,K Thailand, July 25 (UPI)Thai officials said bodia's bid to establish diplomatic and trade relationsfirst attempt by Phnom Penh's new Government to open the world.

title: Release of Rice by U.S. Hurting Thailand Trade
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  The release of large quantities of; American rice, much of it originally destined for aid programs in Cambodia and Vietnam, onto the commercial market in recent weeks has caused a sharp drop in prices and severe economic problems for Thailand, one of the world's major rice exporters.

title: Wolf That Bit Girl to Get Rabies Test
description: The owner of a timber wolf that bit a oneyearold girl has called the State Department of Health from Chicago and promised to have the pet observed by a veterinarian for rabies. A 66yearold man was being held without bail in the Camden County jail on a homicide charge after allegedly shooting a neighbor whose baseball had rolled into his yard Thursday night. According to Camden County Prosecutor Thomas J. Shusted, the neighbor, Bruce Auletto, 28, and two youths were playing catch when the ball rolled into the yard of the suspect, Egon Leggiadrini. His wife returned the ball to Mr. Auletto, Mr. Shusted said, but an argument developed, and Mr. Leggiadrini got his 22caliber rifle and fired the shot at Mr. Auletto.

title: Ozark Was a Dodger
description: The Philadelphia Phillie manager, Danny Ozark, was signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1941, never played with them in a league game but was a Los Angeles Dodger coach seven years.

title: Hathaway Resigns
description: Interior Secretary Stanley K. Hathaway, in the hospital for moderate depression and physical exhaustion, submitted his resignation to President Ford a second time, and it was accepted. Page 10.

title: MORE BANKS RAISE PRIME TO 71/2%
description: Most of the nation's leading banks announced quarterpoint increases in their prime lending rates yesterday, establishing 7', per cent as the basic interest charge on loans to the biggest and most creditworthy business borrowers.

title: Lure of Fresh Vegetables at a Country Stand
description: HUDSON, N.Y.The first sweet corn of the year has just reached the farm stands of the Hudson Valley, where sweet cherries, green beans, and yellow and green squash already are on sale, with vineripened and lushly red tomatoes not far behind.

title: Yankees Down Red Sox by 86
description: The people in the Yankee front office tried to stir up their team with psychology, but the people in the Yankee uniforms unveiled their own secret weapon last night and defeated the Boston Red ox, 86.

title: CAPITAL GAINS TAX IS VOTED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, July 25  The State Assembly, after two false starts, gave final legislative approval this evening to a capital gains tax designed to provide $65million to help restore programs cut from the current state budget for reasons of economy.

title: New Detention Center at Foley Sq. Is Hailed as Advance in Jail Design
description: The Tombs, the Women's House of Detention and the West Street Federal jail never gave New York City much of reputation for advanced prison design. In fact, all three were considered seriously regressive by prison experts, and two of the three have been closed with their replacements An rated little better.

title: Korea Apparently Coming Out of Oil Shock
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean economy, which was badly battered by the oil crisis, seems to have picked itself up off the flor and begun a slow recovery.

title: AFRICAN ORYX HELD GOOD MEAT SOURCE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 26 (ReutersThe largehorned antelope called the oryx has big advantages over cattle in such drought areas as subSaharan Africa, according to the results of a fouryear test in an and area of eastern Kenya.

title: TEACHERS EXPECT TOUGH BARGAINING
description: The city's 60,000 schoolteachers, looking toward the expiration of their contract on Sept. 9, will find themselves in the unenviable position tomorrow of opening bargaining talks amid the City's financial crisis.

title: Sports and the Masculine Obsession
description: It has been my experience that American men who grew up actively participating in competitive athletics intuitively understand the role sports played in forging their manhood. Sport is our civilized society's most prominent masculinity rite. At least that's the way it was when I grew up as a teenager during the late 1950's in Scranton, Pa.a town about 15 miles from the South Caanan Farmhouse Hideout, for those of you who read more than the sports pages.

title: Bumping VW Out of First Place
description: LOS ANGELESWhile Detroit is still scanning the horizon for signals of an upturn in business, automakers in Tokyo and Takaoka, Japan  and their representatives in this countryare fretting over another kind of problem: they've started to run short of cars.

title: NEW RULES EXEMPT DREDGING ON FARMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Army Corps of Engineers published interim regulations governing dredge and fill operations in the nation's waters yesterday and specifically exempted normal farming, ranching and forestry operations.

title: Stray Dogs Peril Jersey City Area
description: JERSEY CITY  Seven thousand stray dogs, most of them of the larger breeds and considered dangerous, are roaming the streets here in the state's second most densely populated city, according to estimates by public health officials.

title: Arthur Kuper Jr. Weds Nancy Finn
description: Nancy Ruth Finn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Finn of Upper Montclair, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur William Kuper Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kuper of Bay Village, Ohio. The Rev. Edwin C. Bockstiegel performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church of Upper Montclair.

title: A Rare Show in Jersey
description: Owners of American saddlebred horses always have maintained the breed was one of the more versatile in the world.

title: Sunshine, at Last, for Wall St.
description: Stockbrokers can hardly believe it. It's almost like having a private money machineif you're with the right firm.

title: Druggists Concerned By Cutbacks In Medicaid
description: PATERSON  Pharmacists have informed state officials that cutbacks in Medicaid payments scheduled for Friday could lead to reductions in prescription services.

title: CHARLES NEWHILL
description: ORADELL, N.J., July 26Charles Newhill, for 42 years the chauffeur of the actress Katharine Hepburn, died at his home here today. He was 82 years old.

title: American League
description: Boston 4, New York 2. Baltimore 4, Milwaukee 0. Chicago 5, Oakland 2.

title: Miss Mann Leads by 5 With 66134
description: HORSHAM, Pa., July 26 (UPI)Carol Mann, a former United States open champion, tied the course record with a sevenunderpar 66 today and led by five strokes after two rounds in the George Washington. Ladies Golf Classic at Hidden Springs Country Club.

title: Spotswood Suffering Growing Pains
description: SPOTSWOODAlong with the rest of Middlesex County, this borough has grown tremendously in the last decade. Before World War II, there were fewer than 1,000 people here, now the population stands at 8,500 and the town, as a result, is suffering from growing pains.

title: Solomon Beats Ashe
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)Harold Solomon dealt Arthur Ashe his first defeat since his Wimbledon singles championship by winning, 64, 75, today and gained the semifinals of the Washington Star tennis tournament.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford flew to Bonn yesterday on the first leg of a 10day journey of diplomatic gestures across Europe, accompanied by his wife and Secretary of State Kissinger. He will participate in the summitlevel confirmation by 35 countries of a charter on European security in Helsinki, Finland, late this week, the primary purpose of the trip, and will visit the capitals of Poland, Rumania and Yugoslavia. A senior White House official said the real, if unpublicized purpose, of the visits to the three East European capitals, was to encourage Poland, Rumania and Yugoslavia to continue pursuit of political lines relatively independent of Moscow. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: Births
description: Altchek

title: FILM VIEW
description: The recession and tight money may have delayed the start of the New York Cinmathque, but that delay has become purely academic this summer. The entire city is currently a cinmathque. Every summer there have been revival programs but I can't remember a recent summer in which there appeared to be such a number of them offering such a variety of programs. Could it possibly be an optical illusion? Because there have been so few openings of new films in the last several weeks, the revivals and reissues are the films that occupy our principal attentionwhich is all to the good.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor.

title: The Ghost Belonged to Me
description: By Richard Peck. 183 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $5.95. (Ages 12 to 15)

title: The Sad Case of Cleon Jones
description: When the New York Mets were a toddling team trying to learn a difficult game, their earnest ineptitude and ludicrous pratfalls warmed a million cockles. There was something endearing about their inadequacy because it was unstudied. They weren't trying to be funny. Can't anybody here play this game? their first baby sitter, Casey Stengel wailed. Sure we can, Case, they would say. Just watch us. Nowoops, sorry. The years went by and the lovable urchins grew up or were replaced by professionals. The team won a couple of pennants and a world championship. Now the only player left who was with them in their infancy is Ed Kranepool, and there is nothing comical about a .350 batting average. The goldenhearted clowns of yesterday belong to yesterday. Today's Mets are pros who are not supposed to fall on their faces, right?

title: The World
description: Attempts to reach a new ceasefire agreement between Israel and Egypt continue, old obstacles surmounted only to be replaced by new ones. The result is that optimism over a swift new accord in Sinai has faded; Israeli Premier Yitzhak Rabin, for one, suggested agreement might not come before September.

title: College Golfers: Amateurs or Pros?
description: A gifted young player, who had recently terminated a fouryear connection at a warmweather golf factory, signed his scorecard after the fourth round of a United States Amateur championship and was passing the time of day with a U.S.G.A. official. The player's future was the topic of conversation.

title: Junking Junk Mail
description: Until recently, if credit card holders wished not to receive merchandise offerings from either the card issuer' or a third party who had rented the issuer's mailing list, a phone call or letter expressing such desire would do the job. Few people, however, took any initiative.

title: Robert Meyzen Marries Susan J. Krach
description: Susan Joanne Krach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell P. Krach of Longmeadow and Monson, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Oliver Meyzen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Meyzen of New York and Georgetown, Conn.

title: Article 1  No Title
Serling Estate Is Probated
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26 (UPI) Rod Serling, originator of the Twilight Zone and Night Gallery series, left most of his estate, worth more than $100,000, to his widow. His will was submitted for probate last week, leaving a home in the Pacific Palisades area of Los Angeles, and other property to his widow, Karolyn, including future royalties on his works, estimated to earn more than $10,000 a year.

title: ULSTER POLICEMAN IS KILLED IN AMBUSH
description: BELFAST, Notrhern Ireland, July 26A policeman was killed and anothe seriously injured in a daylight ambush near Londonderry today that apparently breached the sixmonth ceasefire by the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

title: Mets' Games This Week
description: TodayAt Chicago (2).

title: A Superb Toy Made For Air Superiority
description: PARISThe General Dynamics F16 was designed as a lightweight; relatively unsophisticated airplane that would win dogfights and insure air superiority.

title: LeninismItalian Style
description: ROMEThe only free election won by a Communist party was, so far as I know, that of the Vladivostok City Council in 1917 but this record. may soon be broken on a far more significant scale, in NATO Italy. Only a two point percentage spread now separates the Communists here from the largest if waningparty, the Christian Democrats.

title: Where the Leends of Breucklen Come Alive
description: Gertrude Ryder Bennett gaily slaps her knees and sings the tune of the Dutch nursery rhyme which, more than three centuries ago, was part of her great  greatgrandmother's nursery repertoire in the original settlement of Breucklen.

title: Jobs for Minorities Called a Top Issue
description: ATLANTA, July 26As the 65th annual convention of the National Urban League prepares to open here tomorrow, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the organization's executive director, voiced concern that the upturn in the economy is not good news to blacks and other minorities.

title: House Votes Bill to Permit Construction Site Picketing
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The House voted yesterday to permit strikers to picket construction sites, a major goal of organized labor for a quarter of a century. The measure was approved 230 to 178 and sent to the Senate where a similar bill has been approved by a Labor subcommittee.

title: Malpractice Rates Drive Up Doctor Fees
description: Soaring malpractice insurance rates for doctors and hospitals have sharply driven up, costs of medical diagnosis and treatment for patients and, in the view of many health officials, are threatening the quality of health care given Americans.

title: Actual City Layoffs In Economy Drive Now Put at 13,966
description: Fewer than 14,000 of the more than 300,000 municipal employes are believed to have been removed from the payroll in the economy drive that began nearly two months ago, when Mayor Beame said in his crisis budget messagebased on receiving no additional state aid or taxing powerthat 67,000 city jobs would have to be abolished.

title: Article 7  No Title
Middle Class Joins RentStrike Surge
description: Juana Torres lives on Barretto Street in the Hunts Point, section of the South Bronx, an area whose crumbling apartment buildings and vast social problems have come to symbolize urban decay. Helen Weingarten lives on 86th Street near Park Avenue on the Upper East Side, one of the city's most desirable neighborhoods.

title: Royal Glint First in ??.N. Handicap
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 26 In an impressive frontgoing effort made in aceordance with prerace strategy, Dan Lasater's Royal Glint had no difficulty in topping a ninehorse field in the prestigious $100,000 United Nations Handicap before 13,514 spectators this afternoon.

title: Food
description: Numerous changes in the eating and drinking habits of Americans occurred shortly after World War II, notably cocktails on the rocks and cold savory soups. Prior to the war, a martini or manhattan on the rocks would have seemed downright peculiar. When the late chef Louis Diat created vichyssoise (it was purely and simply the traditional potage parisienne of his childhood, chilled and with cream added), it was in a sense revolutionary. Since that period, cold soups have become very much a popular staple for summer. Here are a few of them to serve cold or hot. And cold garlic soup isn't as far out as it may seem. They've been serving garlic soup in France for generations.

title: Britton Captures Met. Golf
description: EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 26Bill Britton proved today that a public links golfer could beat a lowhandicap player from a private club.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: Apologies to Jerry Stein, a Brooklyn reader who supplied the correct answer for a zucchini question published on July 13. We made an error in printing his answer and Russell Clark, a New Jersey reader, caught our mistake. To set the record straight, a question was raised why zucchini squash blossoms were dropping from vigorous plants growing in fertile soil in a sunny location. The reason is that the male blossoms (not the female) often form first and drop off. Eventually, female blossoms will develop with sufficient male flowers flowers forming to pollinate them. This same pattern can be observed with watermelons, cucumbers and pumpkins.

title: The Fight
description: The career of Muhammad Ali once looked like a sequence of magical, unrepeatable events. It was as if the fighters he defeated simply disappeared from the earth, and when he himself was beaten by Joe Frazier and then by Ken Norton it seemed impossible that he would ever come back. Yet here he is, heavyweight champion of the world, having straightened out the score with Frazier and Norton, having beaten George Foreman and held off a series of new contenders, including Joe Bugner a few weeks ago in Kuala Lumpur; here he is, promising to fight Frazier again in Manila in October, and after that to fight Norton and Foreman again. The unrepeatable has turned into a minuet, dancing bears revolving in the limelight to the rustle of millions of dollars. Still, losing some of his magic, Ali gains in stature. becomes a champion rather than a star, and one sees why he keeps calling off his proposed retirement. Being champion means proving you are the champion whenever proof seems required.

title: The Ballet
description: Cast changes in Erik Bruhn's production of Copplia for the National Ballet of Canada brought in Vanessa Harwod as Swanilda, and Constantin Patsalas as Coppelius Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Rudolf Nureyey repeated his performance as Franz.

title: Endpaper
description: The art of the chopstick is long to learn. No less a figure than James Restona man who endured acupuncture without an anticipatory quiverconfessed in this newspaper to his anxieties over managing those wily utensils. Meanwhile, as part the general craze in this country for Chinese food, thousands of ordinary Americans have tried their hand at lifting a steamed dumpling from plate to mouth with two 10inch wooden wands.

title: O.A.S. SETS MEETING ON CUBA SANCTIONS
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 26  Twentyone North and South, American nations completed amendment of their hemisphere security treaty here today after having decided last night to vote on lifting the embargo against Cuba by the Organization of American States.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in this section last Sunday said that the entire Senate will be up for reelection in November, as will many Assemblymen. The entire 80member Assembly is up for reelection in November. Senators do not run again until 1977.

title: Rev. Thomas Miller Is Fiance Of Barbara Land Cleveland
description: Barbara Land Cleveland, director of hospital auxiliary services for the Hospital Association of New York State in Albany, will be married Sept. 20 to the Rev. Thomas Edwin Stephenson Miller, assistant minister of the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Albany, where the wedding will take place.

title: No Home in Africa
description: I have no cultural roots in Africa; nor do I want any. I have discovered that Egypt is not black Africa. The skin isn't black enough and the hair isn't kinky enough. An Egyptian merchant put his light brown arm next to my black arm and said, My skin isn't black but I'm African, too. Sincerity was not in his voice.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayElm City K.C. allbreed and obedience, Bethany Airport, Route 63, Bethany. Conn.; 1,098 dogs: 9 A.M.

title: Bases Closing on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 28 (AP)The leadership of the TurkishCyprioteheld part of Cyprus announced today that it was closing two American installations in its part of the wardivided island.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayNew Jersey American Saddlebred Pleasure Horse Association, Johnson Park, River Road, New Brunswick, N.J. 8:30 A.M.

title: FREE LEGAL ADVICE IS GIVEN IN HARLEM
description: Free legal advice. That sounds like a contradiction for a profession schooled in Abraham Lincoln's adage that time and advice are a lawyer's stock in trade.

title: Readers Argue the Other Side on Options
description: The following are comments about an article on options by Simeon H. F. Goldstein, executive director of a private foundation, in which he said the game is stacked against options writers.

title: 4 Attend Andrea Christine Flagg At Bridal to Robb Roy Thomson
description: The Cotton Mountain Church in North Wolfeboro, N.H., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Andrea Christine Flagg to Robb Roy Thomson. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Lewis W. Flagg Jr. of Epping. N.J., performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Orova to Coach Columbia Crew
description: Stephen Orova, a Hungarian who is fluent in four languages and fluid in a shell, was appointed yesterday as head crew coach at Columbia University, succeeding John Abele.

title: SYRIA IMPATIENT AT PACE OF TALKS
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, July 24As Egypt maneuvers on the Sinai negotiating front, Syria is waiting, with a mixture of impatience and suspicion, for her own turn in the unfinished business of Middle Eastern peace talks.

title: A Year After, Members of Impeachment Panel Reflect
description: WASHINGTON, July 26One morning this week 35 spectators listened in Room 2141 of the Rayburn House Office Building as members of the House Judiciary Committee debated the intricacies of the antitrust laws.

title: He Grew Up With L.I. Parks
description: BABYLONJohn G. Sheridan, the new general manager of the Long Island State Park Commission, is a man with what his friends in Patchogue describe as a pretty good feeling for what people want.

title: SENATE VOTE BACKS RUMANIA TRADE TIE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Senate approved yesterday a resolution that would extend mostfavorednation trade status to Rumania and make her the first Communist country to be granted nondiscriminatory tariff treatment since Congress tied tariff favors to free emigration policies.

title: A Potpourri of Free Summer Concerts
description: Pick any day of the week in the Garden State this summer and you will find a potpourri of concertslive, outdoors and free. It may be the majestic sounds of a full symphony orchestra or the hometown charm of a brass band. There is chamber music in a national park, pop music in shopping malls, and jazz and rock in a museum at noontime. To attend, you don't have to live in the communities where the concerts are held, and you may want to bring a chair of some kind or a blanket for comfort.

title: Statement By President
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) In his departure statement today before leaving from Andrews Air Force Base for Europe. President Ford omitted a reference to the three Baltic states that had been included in his advance text. The White House said, however, that it stood by the original statement.

title: Cause of 2 Physicians' Deaths Here Still Unknown
description: Ten days have elapsed since Drs. Stewart and Cyril Marcus were found dead in their Upper East Side apartment, but the Medical Examiner's office has still not been able to determine the cause of their deaths.

title: Not a Treaty, but a Declaration of Intentions in Europe
description: PARISThirty years after the end of World War II, it remains politically impossible for the former belligerents to sign a peace treaty. Half of Germany is an ally of the western part of the wartime alliance; the other half is an ally of the eastern part, the Soviet Union, and of countries that were wartime allies of Nazi Germany: Rumania, Hungary, Bulgaria.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: BLOCKElizabeth Most devoted, beautiful Mother. Until life departs, always lovingly In our thoughts and heart.

title: John Riordan Weds Barbara Munder
description: Barbara Ann Murkier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Munder of Fort Salonga, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to John James Riordan, son of Mrs. Thomas Riordan of Fermoy, County Cork, Ireland, and the late Mr. Riordan.

title: TV VIEW
description: Cry for the soap opera. Struggle as it may, it still finds respect elusive. Every so often, an executive producer decides to prove to the critics that the maligned form is bursting with firstrate talents. The critics are invited to studio performance sessions. The reviews are written. The verdicts still range from patronizing to devastating. Directors and actors return to muttering darkly about things like insensitivity.

title: Jones Ties 100Meter Mark at 9.9
description: BOSTON, July 26 (AP)Reggie Jones, a 21yearold sprinter from Saginaw, Mich., equalled the world record for the 100meter dash with a 9.9second clocking in a track meet today at Boston University Field.

title: Ruling Expected in August In C.A.B. Suit on United Air
description: CHICAGO, July 26 (UPI)A ruling is expected in August in a suit against United Airlines that seeks access to financial records dealing with the airline's campaign contributions to former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Musician Is Critically Hurt After Leap From Bridge
description: A 23year old musician yesterday jumped from the Throgs. Neck Bridge into the East Rivet off the Queens shore and suffered critical injuries in the 130foot fall, the police said.

title: Unemployment Figures Are Out of the 30's
description: In the auto industry, more than in any other business, and in Detroit, more than in any other city, the recession of 1975 has looked like the Great Depression of the 1930's. A quarter of a million auto workers were unemployed in February of this year. One in three of the production workers employed by the large auto corporations in the fall of 1973 was out of work. Half of all Chrysler workers were unemployed. The unemployment rate was higher in Michigan this year than in any other large state, and higher in Detroit than in any other large metropolitan area. This winter, as in the winter of 1931, busloads of people left Detroit to look for work in southern towns.

title: A Large Slice of Americana, Served Up in Cooperstown
description: COOPERSTOWN is a pleasant village in central New York, 70 miles west of Albany. It is also the place where in 1839 a youth named Abner Doubleday supposedly scratched a crude diamond in the dirt with a stick, drew up some rules and turned a formless, disorganized game called town ball into our national pastime. Doubleday went on to fire the first gun for the Union side in the Civil War as a captain at Fort Sumter, and eventually became a major general, but today he is remembered for one thing onlybaseball. And Cooperstown, by and large, is thought of only as the Home of Baseball, the site of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum. Which is a pity, for it is much more than that.

title: British Novels Flow From a Palisades Studio
description: NORTH BERGENFrom the time American soldiers gave me chewing gum as a child during World War II, I had wanted to come to America to seek fame, fortune and romance, and I had always wanted to write, Susan Howatch recalled the other day.

title: Nan Peletz Is Fiancee Of William Hearst 3d
description: Shirley Gates Peletz of San Francisco has announced the engagement of her daughter, Nan Peletz, to William Randolph Hearst 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hearst Jr. of New York. The couple plan to marry next month.

title: Carlton Mews: From a Barn to an Elegant Home
description: PLAINFIELD  A 1924 issue of Charm magazine included an article, Where Once There Was a Barn, that described Carlton Mews, a barn that had been turned into a carriage house and, finally, a residence. Now a halfcentury later and currently the home of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Rose, it is the dwelling most often included on tours of homes in Plainfield.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Frank Lucchesi, new manager of the Texas Rangers, talking about his 13 years in the minor leagues as a player: I've played in more towns than Gone With the Wind.

title: FORD TO SEEK OUT TURKEY'S PREMIER
description: BONN, July 26President Ford will attempt to meet with Premier Suleyman Demirel of Turkey at the European security conference next week in Helsinki, reporters were told today.

title: Their Crises Have Just Begun
description: The municipal unions, which have grown tremendously in the last decade in size and importance, are now fighting to hold on to the substantial contract gains they have wrung from a strikewary city.

title: Turkish Arms
description: The narrow House vote against lifting the Congressional embargo on arms shipments to Turkey reflected the strong feeling that the prohibition against the use of American arms for nondefense purposes had been violated by Turkey in her invasion of Cyprus a year agoas indeed it had. This principle is incorporated in all American arms sales agreements: and it is imperative that it be sustained.

title: Reagan Support in South Wanes as Ford's National Strength Grows; Rockefeller Is Expected to Get Bid
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Ronald Reagan's Presidential challenge is wilting fast this summer where it was expected to blossom brightestamong the closely allied, mostly conservative chairmen of the Republican party in 13 Southern states.

title: Lisbon's New Triumvirate Faces Strong Opposition
description: LISBON, July 26Portugal's new military triumvirate today faced strong opposition from within the armed forces and the main political parties and the prospect of growing unrest.

title: BubbleGum Cards Help to Pay Tuition
description: A Brooklyn girl trying to help pay her way through college has gone into the business of selling baseball player bubblegum cards.

title: New ChildFood Controls
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Agriculture Department has put into effect new regulations aimed at streamlining state supervision and bookkeeping involved in Federal child nutrition programs, including school lunches.

title: Christina Gignoux Wed to a Professor
description: Christina Alsop Gignoux, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Alsop of Stockbridge, Mass., was married there yesterday afternoon to William Beautyman, son of. Dr. and Mrs. William Beautyman of Pittsfield, Mass., and Winter Harbor, Me. The Rev. Theodore H. Evans performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Gignoux home.

title: Proposed Postal Rates Termed Peril to Publications
description: One of the ?? economic problems ??ing American newspapers and magazines is recent propo??als to restructure the cost of sending mail, most publishers believe.

title: In This Century, Other Nations Act More Responsibly Toward Them
description: LONDONThe crisis in Angola, the last of Portugal's provinces in Africa, is adding tens of thousands of political refugees to the many millions already scattered across the contemporary world. Since Portugal's domestic revolution last year, when Angola was promised independence, the white population there has been reduced by an estimated 100,000 persons, leaving 400,000 more filled with misgivings or panic. Thousands more are scrambling out every week. Back in Portugal, they will join 50,000 other whites who have already fled Portugal's other big African colony, Mozambique, which became independent last month.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Tire Company Restricted
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission has accepted a consent order prohibiting the Bridgestone Tire Company of America, Inc., from making unsubstantiated claims about its radial tires.

title: Shell Oil Fined $5,000
description: BOSTON, July 26 (AP)The Shell Oil Company has been fined $5,000, the maximum under current Federal law, for, a spill of more than 100,000 gallons of kerosene at its West Boylston storage plant last January.

title: Pamela L. Pry, Harold F. Miller Have Nuptials
description: Pamela Lee Pry, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert H. Pry of Schenectady, N. Y., was married there at noon yesterday to Harold F. Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Miller of Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Saccone performed the ceremony in St. Helen's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Cuellar Pitches 1Hitter
description: MILWAUKEE, July 26 (AP) Baltimore's Mike Cuellar checked Milwaukee on one hitGeorge Scott's single in the seventh inningand the Orioles, aided by five errors, posted a 40 victory over the Brewers today.

title: A WOMAN PRIEST DEFIES BAN ON RITE
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 26  The Rev. Nancy C. H. Wittig, the 29yearold mother of a 2monthold daughter and one of 11 women ordained to the Episcopal priesthood a year ago, defied church law here today by celebrating holy communion at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: MANILA PUSHING FAMILY PLANNING
description: MANILA, July 26Family planning clinics have been set up in outdoor food markets as part of a campaign to reduce the Philippine birth rate, one of the highest in the world.

title: WindSun Power Urged for Denmark
description: Denmark could derive virtually all its energy from wind and sunlight by the year 2050, according to a proposal of a physicist at the Niels Bohr Institute of the University of Copenhagen.

title: Millan Bats In Winner With Fourth Hit
Wings Capture W.F.L. Opener
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 26 (UPI)Bill Sadler plunged for two touchdowns and Johnny Walton scored another as the San Antonio iWngs defeated the Charlotte Hornets, 2710, tonight in the opener of the World Football League's second season.

title: Antonia Brico Film Due in Fair Lawn
description: FAIR LAWN  Antonia, Portrait of a Woman, a documentary film on the orchestral conductor Antonia Brico will have its first public showing in New Jersey, in conjunction with Dr. Brico's Aug. 3 engagement to conduct the New York Philharmonic Orchestra at Lincoln Center.

description: Airlines

title: Dr. Joseph M. Bobbitt, 66, A Behavioral Psychologist
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Dr. Joseph M. Bobbitt, a behavioral psychologist with the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, the National institutes of Health and the National Institute of Mental Health, died Thursday of a stroke and heart attack at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. He was 66 years old.

title: Correction
description: Margery Allingham's name was incorrectly given as Margaret Allingham in the June 29 Criminals at Large column.

title: Harness Driver Killed
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 26 (AP)Forrest Short, an 81yearold harnessracing driver from Circleville, died last night as a result of an accident at Scioto Downs. Short won the first race staged at Scioto Downs, Oct. 9, 1959. In 1960, he was the leading driver at the track.

title: He Makes Movies That Make Money
description: At the moment, Dino de Laurentiis, the Italian movie producer who three years old abandoned Rome to take up residence in the United States, is in roughly the equivalent position of a Las Vegas high roller who has been making pass after pass. Since moving his operation to America, in any, event, de Laurentiis has produced five films (The Valachi Papers, The Stone Killer, Serpico, Death Wish and Mandingo) all of which have been highly profitable and two of whichSerpico and Death Wish  have been financial blockbusters.

title: Christine Blakely Sets Fall Bridal
description: The engagement of Christine Blakely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Robert T. Blakely of Greenwich, Conn., to William Russell Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Edgar Bennett, also of Greenwich, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A wedding in the fall is

title: Susan VanderPoel Is Married To Robert James Barrett 3d
description: Susan Hopkins VanderPoel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Farnsworth VanderPoel of Oyster Bay, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert James Barrett 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Barrett Jr of Bangor and Bar Harbor, Me.

title: The North Fork Coming on Strong
description: GREENPORT, L.I.After years in the shadow of the more glamorous South Fork, Long Island's North Fork the shorter of the two capes that jut into the Atlantic at the island's eastern endis finally coming into its own.

description: Mrs. Carl Peter Doelger Jr., of Chatham, Mass., formerly of New York, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lilian Elizabeth Doelger, to Robert Michael Byrne of New York and Chatham.

title: Helms Linked to C.I.A. Memo for Kissinger and Mitchell on Plot in Chile
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Richard Helms, while director of the Central Intelligence Agency, prepared a memorandum in the fall of 1970 informing Henry Kissinger and John N. Mitchell that the agency had supplied machine guns and teargas grenades to men plotting to overthrow the Chilean Government authoritative Government sources said today.

title: WALTER H. SHUTT
description: Walter H. Shutt, who developed means for using salt water more effectively as a cooling agent for marine engines, died Thursday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., at the age of 91.

title: Wright Captures Pinter Golf on 69
description: HAPPAUGE, L. I., July 26 Jimmy Wright of Inwood, a former Metropolitan open champion won the Pinter Tournament of Stars over the 6,836yard Colonie Hill Country Club course today with a 3underpar 69.

title: Life in East Europe Better But Confined
description: BELGRADE Yugoslavia, July 24In the three decades since World War II, the Sovietbuilt political barries that for years separated desitute peoples of Eastern Europe from the outside world have evolved into reasonably comfortable confinement.

title: Sociobiology
description: The New Synthesis. By Edward O. Wilson Illustrated. 697 pp. Cambridge. Mass.: Belknap Press of Harvard University. $20.

title: Election Commission Rules On Paying Campaign Debts
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Political candidates who ran up campaign debts in 1974 or earlier may raise funds to pay them off this year without counting the money against future campaign spending and contribution limits, the Federal Election Commission has ruled.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: . . . A Way Out
description: President Ford has himself given the Congress a possible way out of the morass, if the legislators should miraculously be able to pull themselves together after a month's recess to lake advantage of it. A formal threemonth extension of present controls legislation required for implementation of the President's phased decontrol program; and Mr. Ford himself suggested that this period be used to consolidate oil price policies and put them on a statutory basis.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Liberal Parents, Radical Children

title: C. B. Asmussen Weds Christine Rusin
description: Mary Christine Rusin and Christopher Burke Asmussen of Brooklyn, who in May received master's degrees in student personnel administration from Teachers College of Columbia University, were married yesterday afternoon in Columbia's St. Paul's Chapel.

title: The Left Wing of His Labor Party Is Not Leaving Him Choices
description: LONDON  Alchemist, confidence man, disingenuous conjurer from Yorkshire. These words and more like them have been used to describe British Prime Minister Harold Wilson, whose ability to hold the Labor party together over the years has been cause for both envy and despair among his colleagues.

title: The Nation
description: But Inflation Has Clearly Not Ended

title: Court Trims A Policeman On Bid for Sideburns
description: A Nassau County policeman has lost the latest round in his court fight against a regulation that requires members of the force to wear neatly trimmed hair with short sideburns and no beards.

title: Democrats at the Gate
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 The race for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination is the most crowded field in either party in recent history. Nine then are actively seeking the nomination and another three are under serious consideration by party leaders.

title: Stadium's New Big Bat Proves A Hit in First Appearance Here
description: As a handful of young baseball fans looked on, a 138foot smokestack that is shaped like a baseball bat was set up in the stands behind the home plate side of Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: Illinois Acts to Curb Sales Of Liquor on 11 Big Airlines
description: CHICAGO, July 26 (UPI)The Illinois Liquor Commission has issued citations agains 11 mafor airlines for operating as retailers and wholesalers of liquor.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Georg Jensen, Inc., in an expansion move, has leased the fivestory building at 605 Madison Avenue, between 57th and 58th Streets, adjoining Jensen's main store.

title: Enquirer Editor to Retire
description: CINCINNATI, July 26 (UPI) Brady Black, a journalist for more than 48 years, will retire Sept. 1 as vice president and editor of The Cincinnati Enquirer. William J. Keating, who joined The Enquirer as president in 1973, will become editor.

title: Pentagon Questions Navy Cut in Torpedo Mine Output
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Defense Department is questioning a Navy decision to slow production of a torpedo mine that potentially could help seal off the Soviet submarine fleet from the Atlantic sea lanes.

title: For devotees of Scott Fitzgerald? Edward FitzGerald?
description: James Salter is the author of A Sport and a Pastime. His latest novel, Light Years, is a very classy book. Its characters drink their Margaux and consume their Brie in a large, whitepainted Victorian house on the west bank of the Hudson within sight of the Tappan Zee Bridge. On winter days they return from skating on the frozen river for an earlyafternoon repast of chocolate and pears. The principal bathroom contains sponges, soaps the color of tea, books, watercurled copies of Vogue. The husband, Viri, we are told (irrelevantly, as it turns out), is a Jew, the most elegant Jew, the most romantic, a hint of weariness in his features. ... We follow him as he orders custommade shirts from a wise old Viennese shirtmaker, who says, I have made some very good shirts, I have made some bad shirts, but altogether I have not failed to learn my art completely. Together they decide on a cloth that was painted like feathers, feathers of dark green, black, permanganate, another the color of deerskin, and a third the blue of police.

title: Home Buyers Get A New Enticement
description: Thousands of new housing units throughout the nation that failed to meet the price qualification for 5 per cent Federal tax credit will do so now because of an amendment liberalizing the law.

title: FORD COMMENCES A EUROPEAN TOUR WITH BONN VISIT
description: BONN, July 26President Ford arrived here tonight to begin a journey of diplomatic gestures across Europe.

title: Deborah Travis To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Merwin Travis of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Martin Travis, to Dr. John Kelver Willis 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kelver Willis of Johnson City, Tenn. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: The World
description: Africa's leaders have made another try to end the fighting between Angola's two principal nationalist guerrilla groups. But this peace effort by the foreign ministers of the Organization of African Unity meeting in Kampala, Uganda, does not appear to have any greater chance for success than several previous tries.

title: State Urban Unit Under Fire
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Community Affairs initially described as a visionary approach to solving New Jersey's urban problems, has come under increasing attack in recent years and now is threatened with abolition.

title: SovietBloc Nations Differ Despite Basic Uniformity
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24  Despite the basic uniformity of the Soviet political system throughout Eastern Europe, great differences exist between individual countries.

title: Janet Thayer Bride Of William Phillips
description: Janet Elizabeth Thayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Thayer of London and New York, was married yesterday in London to William Roger Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Phillips 3d Of Hartsdale, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: CHESS
description: Coming up with predictions about the future of a bright young player is by no means easy, for while the spark of talent may be unmistakable and past progress from tournament to tournament reasonably chartable (allowing for some irregularly occurring setbacks), the point at which levelingoff will begin has to involve guessing.

title: Cuban Star to Dance Here Tomorrow
description: Alicia Alonso, the Cuban ballerina who was one of the American Ballet Theater's first stare and has not danced here for 15 years, has arrived in New York to perform at the company's gala performance tomorrow night at the New York State Theater.

title: The Pearsons Give Their Own Dances In Sumptuous Way
description: Sara and Jerry Pearson are two of the most talented and delightfully unpretentious performers in the current dance II world. They maintain a becomling modesty despite their exciting and almost magical fluidity in turning dance phrases. They presented a program of their works at New York University's School of the Arts on Friday evening.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe 1970 census recorded that there were more than 8 million persons of Hispanic heritage in the United States, almost 800,000 American Indians, more than a million AsianAmericans and 50,000 Alaskan natives. None of these groups participated as fully in the political process as the white, Europeanstock majoritya situation that the new Voting Rights Act, now moving toward final passage, seeks to remedy.

title: New York A. C. Leads in Rowing
description: CAMDEN, N.J., July 26The New York A.C., by win ning the day's final event, the intermediate doubles, took the lead today in the 99th national rowing championships on the Cooper River.

title: . . . Into the Future
description: Where the Administration and its critics disagree, however, is in their assessment of what. the Helsinki agreement portends for the future. Mr. Ford says that he sees the agreement as helping to open Eastern Europe for easier travel and better journalistic access; he also sees it as a followup to the accord on the status of West Berlin and a move forward toward possible agreement on the mutual balanced reduction of forces.

title: Prospect Park Gets Free Nature Walks
description: The Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration will sponsor a series of free guided nature walks in Prospect Park in Brooklyn beginning tomorrow.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Give Diabetic a Chance
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Article 6  No Title
Giving And Taking
description: President Ford's new energy proposal has two important things going for it: The concessions that the Administration has made to win the votes of a swing group of Congressional Democrats, and the consequences for the White House, Congress and the economy should the deadlock between them on energy policy persist. Nevertheless the vote will be close, despite resistance from some Democrats who oppose the boost in crude oil prices, perhaps 6 cents higher by 1978.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TOMORROW, JULY 28

title: Program Disputed
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and Jersey City have been involved in a bitter dispute since the city announced that it was dissatisfied with the pickup program for stray dogs.

description: The Police Commissioner believes New York Is less safe. The Fire Commissioner fears greater risk to life. The Sanitation Commissioner sees a dirtier city.

title: Proposal to End Jamaica Ave. El at Queens Blvd. Is Opposed
description: A proposal to terminate service on the antiquated Jamaica Avenue elevated line at the Queens Boulevard station ran into opposition last week when residents of the Von Dohlen area, a small residential enclave, objected at a City Planning Commission hearing.

title: Congressman Denies Getting Philadelphia Contract Bribe
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP)  Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Philadelphia, has denied charges that he received a bribe from a Philadelphiabased engineering concern, but admits the company's chairman made contributions to his campaigns between 1968 and 1972.

title: There's New Popularity For the MiniRoses
description: All kinds of plant surprises can pop up in gardens. And one of the most famous was the appearance of a miniature rose in the Swiss window garden of a Hollander named John de Vink. This happened 38 years ago and started a slow steady revival in the growing of miniroses which today is reaching a new high.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ANY one who confesses to a sense of confusion and uncertainty these days after reading a constant array of conflicting economic reports  as well as the diverse analyses of them from various quarters  should be readily pardoned. There is ample reason for the public's bewilderment about the real state of the economy at the moment and its nearterm prospects.

title: Miss Holmes Wed to Paul Gryska
description: Margaret Swearingen Holmes and Paul vonRyll Gryska, graduates last May of Trinity College in Hartford, were married yesterday afternoon in the Riverside Presbyterian Church in the Bronx by the Rev. David Denison Cockcroft.

title: Fight Night Changed
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 26 (AP)  The world bantamweight boxing title fight between Alfonso Zamora of Panama City, the champion, and Thanomjit Sukhothai of Thailand was rescheduled yesterday for Aug. 30 after Zamora told promoters he had suffered a training injury. The 15round bout originally was set for Aug. 2 at the Forum in Inglewood, but was later moved to the Anaheim Convention Center because promoters could not get a Saturday night date at the Forum.

title: A Reading on the New Stock Tape
description: In its first six weeks of operation, the consolidated stock taperegarded as one of the major steps toward the creation of a national stock markethas made no fundamental change in the nation's securities markets, but it has produced some interesting sideeffects.

title: JERSEY OPENS FIRST OF 5 FLOODAIDSITES
description: Close to 300 applications for relief were processed yesterday as the first of five regional disaster centers opened in Trenton to help New Jersey flood victims get emergency assistance and make fresh starts in homes, farms and businesses ruined by the recent floods.

title: U.S. Choice in Admiral's Cup
description: The Admiral's Cup, the biennial clash in the seas off Southern England among the world's hottest skippers and fastest ocean racing yachts, starts Friday. But for one of the three boats on the American team, the most important race is against time.

title: 10,000 Protest in Gujarat By WILLIAM BORDERS
description: AHMADABAD, India, July 26 Ten thousand people gathered on a soccer field here this evening for a protest rally against the authoritarian new position of Prime Minister Gandhi's Government.

title: Helen Gorton Fiancee of William David
description: Helen Gail Gorton, who is in the executive training program at Tiffany's, and William Stephenson David, associate publisher of Popular Science magazine, plan to be married Sept. 27.

title: JACK DeJOHNETTE AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: The Bottom Line is New York's leading rock club, but it has also made room for a fair amount of jazz. Jack DeJohnette's new quartet, Directions, is opening for Larry Coryell and the Eleventh House there through tonight.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Detective Shell Scott has been around for a long time, and he is as resourceful, indestructible and smartalecky as ever in Richard S. Prather's THE SURE THING (Pocket, $1.25). This paperback original starts with a cute idea. Here is a sheik visiting America, and his harem has been stolen all six women. Scott is engaged to restore good relations between America and the sheikdom. Naturally oil enters the picture, in the form of a man who has worked out a method of dowsing for that interesting fluid. It's all unbelievable, and it's all good, clean fun.

title: Design
description: Even when a farmhouse Is not old enough to qualify as a landmark, it may have other features worth considering. Three years ago, Robert Siegel, of the architectural firm GwathmeySiegel, and his artistwife, Hazel, bought a crude, 50yearold farmhouse on five acres In Bedford, N.Y. The property had fine views and the Siegels planned to raze the house and build anew, but the recession changed their plans and they decided on a kind of exurban renewal.

title: Special Dog Diets Available
description: The major producers of pet foods have developed complete or balanced rations that support the normal dog in good health. But dogs, like people, may have health problem that require specific dietary controls. Now there are special formulated foods available through a veterinarian. These are for overweight animals or those with heart disease, intestinal disturbances, allergies etc. These are ailments in animals often unrecognized by owners.

title: Anna Elizabeth O'Dea Wed to David Morris
description: In St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in Westwood, N. J., yesterday morning, Anna Elizabeth O'Dea of Ridgefield Park, N.J., daughter of Mrs. Arthur J. O'Dea of Westwood, and the late Judge O'Dea of the Bergen County Court, and David Joseph Morris were married. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. James Stanley Morris of Millington, N.J., and the late Mr. Morris.

title: Court to Rule This Week On Sanitationmen Layoffs
description: The State Supreme Court this week is expected to decide Whether the city has the right to lay off membefs of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association or whether its contract with the union guarantees their employment.

title: Plan to Meet With City And Unions Tomorrow
description: The executive committee of the Municipal Assistance Corporation will participate in threeway negotiations among city officials, staff of the corporation and city union representatives when talks aimed at achieving a voluntary wage freeze for city employes resume tomorrow.

title: Patricia Jeanne Hitchens Is Bride
description: Patricia Jeanne Hitchens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Kitchens of Seaford, L. I., and David George Barnhizer, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Dean Barnhizer of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and Venice, Fla., were married yesterday afternoon.

title: Road Deaths Rise in Cuba
description: HAVANA, July 26 (Reuters) Road deaths in Cuba rose 25 per cent in the first four months of this year, according to official figures published here. They showed that 293 people had been killed in road accidents and that 5,064 had been injured.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodaySuburban Sports Car Club funtype rally; start at Acme Super Saver, junction of Bloomfield and Passaic Avenues, Caldwell, N. J. Registration: 1 P.M., first car off at 2.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: After the Democratic convention in Chicago in 1968, a number of large organizations vowed they would never hold another convention there. Many professed to be outraged by the treatment of the young antiwar protesters by the Chicago authorities during the convention.

title: BENJAMIN E. ROBERTS
description: Benjamin E. Roberts, treasurer and sales manager of the Simplex Industrial Corporation of Elmont, L.I., distributors of machine tools, died Thursday in South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Freeport, L.I.

title: Let a thousand paper cranes fly
description: It had been 10 years since I last visited the statue of Sadako Sasaki with the young members of the Folded Crane Club in Hiroshima. Standing there in the Peace Park, dwarfed by the high  rise buildings that reflected Japan's recent prosperity, the statue now looked smaller than I remembered it. I wondered if the memory of Sadako was shrinking too.

title: India Holds 8 Prominent Elders For Threat to Defy Restrictions
description: NEW DELHI, July 26The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today arrested a group of prominent elderly citizens who had threatened to defy her curbs on freedom of the press and speech.

title: The Communists Are Somewhere in the Middle
description: LISBONPortugal's free fall leftward since the April 25, 1974, revolution has produced a cluster Marxist parties: the Socialists on the right of the Marxist spectrum, the Communists somewhere in the middle, and on the far left a dozen small but noisy and sometimes effective groups. In addition, sometimes connected and sometimes separated, there is the Armed Forces Movement.

title: What's Doing on the MAINE COAST
description: OVERVIEWAs the gull flies, the coast of Maine is 230 miles long, but if all the bays, peninsulas, inlets and promontories that twist and turn from Kittery on the southern border to West Quoddy Head in the north were straightened out, the coastline would measure 3,500 miles. From Kittery the coast runs through such popular spots as Ogunquit, with its summer theater and renowned art colony, and Kennebunkport, where the late Kenneth Roberts wrote many of his bestselling novels. Ten miles or so farther north is Old Orchard Beach, which attracts thousands of Canadians. On any summer day one might think Montreal had been transplanted, what with all the FrenchCanadian patois to be heard in the busy streets and along the miles of white sand beach. Up the coast is Cape Elizabeth, adjacent to Portland, and Casco Bay with its 365 islands, one for each day of the year. Boats leave from Portland at regular intervals for many of the islands. Still farther north is Bath, home of the Bath Iron Works, a shipbuilding concern, and Wiscasset, with its beautiful homes built by shipping merchants and sea captains. Boothbay Harbor is nearby with fishing, boating, yachting and boating facilities. The PenobscotAcadia area reaches from Castine on Penobscot Bay to Schoodic Point on the east and is capped by the grandeur of Mount Desert Island, where Bar Harbor is situated. Then comes the Washington County region, which runs to the Canadian border. As for the weather all along the coast, it is generally cool in the summer, the temperature averaging 66 degress.

title: On the Aesthetics Of Birding
description: Though the following focuses on the sport of bird watching the sentiments expressed will be appreciated by gardeners, many of them avid birders.

title: HYMAN SHAPIRO
description: Hyman Shapiro, former business manager of Local 664, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, and former business representative of Local 3, both of New York, died Wednesday in Weslaco, Tex., where he lived. His age was 62.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Of the final two presentations by the Bolshoi Opera, The Dawns Are Quiet Here by Kiril Molchanov is beneath contempt. It is cheap, sentimental cynical Soviet art at its worst. But Prokofiev's War and Peace, set to the Tolstoi novel, is a different matter. There are those who consider it a masterpiece. There are also those who think that it fails to come off. But even those who do not like the opera, and this writer is among that number, have to concede that it is a monumental effort from the pen of a man who was, after all, one of the important composers of the century.

title: Laura Goodman Bride in Boston
description: Laura Denise Goodman and John Halstead Humphrey, both of Ann Arbor, Mich., were married yesterday evening at the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston by Rabbi Ronald M. Weiss.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP)Owners of dogs that bark persistently may he fined up to $250 under a new ordinance passed by the Board of Supervison

description: Nancy Davison Spears, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Spears of Chagrin Falls. Ohio, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Bassett Whitcomb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Whitcomb of Norwell, Mass.

title: A Little Bit of Europe, Made in the U.S.A.
description: WILL the Bard or won't he? Spin in his grave five times a day, that is. I'm wondering because I am sitting inside an outlandish, doublesize reproduction of London's old Globe Theater, watching characters named Romeo, Tybalt, Falstaff and Prospero trample Shakespear in a lurid amalgam of themes that have been pared down to essentially superficial and macabre qualities. The basic struggle between good and evil, graced by the quest for true loge, is lavishly surrounded by thunderbolts, smoky explosions and hideous monsters. At any minute I expect a chorus line to come storming out in Elizabethan regalia cancanning to the theme of Shakespeare is the . . . one peer to have . . . when you're having more than one. But that's not likely. I'm in the Old Country, in Williamsburg, Va., the latest Busch Gardens amusement park, and an entirely different brewery from. . .that other one.

title: A Parish in Hollis Surveys Its Needs
description: Four Roman Catholic seminarians, wearing black suits and carrying briefcases, have been ringing doorbells throughout Hollis, Queens, as part of a 10week census and survey of St. Gerard Majella Church, 18816 91st Avenue.

title: Rebels in Zaire Release American Held 10 Weeks
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 26 (AP)Kenneth Stephen Smith, an American student held captive for 10 weeks in a jungle camp, arrived here today after he had been freed by African guerrillas.

title: Cheesecake Like Lindy's
description: BOGOTAThe cheesecake taste she was after was strictly Lindy's, when Joanne Taylor first chose to go into the baking business nearly 15 years ago. And that, says the founder of the thriving Cheese Cake Pantry, at 129 Queen Anne Road here, is what she's got.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Mulch to conserve soil moisture and keep down weeds: use straw, grass clippings (sparingly), compost, wood chips, etc. . . . Slugs are everywheretrap with shallow pans of beer or place boards on the soil and pick them off in the morning or salt them. . . . Keep after white fly. . . . Keep up with rapid harvest time. . . . Feed roses once more to encourage fall bloom.

title: Many Soviet and U.. Craft Are Examining the Planets
description: In three weeks the United States plans to launch an unmanned space craft, the Viking, scheduled to land on Mars on July 4, 1976, and to conduct an elaborate search for life or its fossilized remains.

description: By Daniel Cohen. Illustrated. 172 pp. New York: Dodd. Mead & Co. $5.50. (Ages 11 to 15)

description: In Memoriam

title: Energy Crisis: It's Real
description: Maybe President Ford's new compromise proposal on oil price decontrol over a 39month period, together with a gradually rising price ceiling, break the deadlock that has developed between him and the Democratic Congress on energy policy. But the first reaction of the Democrats is not promising, since many see the Ford proposal as both inflationary and ineffective.

description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 26Turkish troops started taking control of American military installations today while diplomatic analysts debated the reap meaning of the move and where it might lead.
