description: GENEVA, July 26United Nations officials fighting the illicit drug trade have reported after a week in Turkey that they were well impressed by the handling of the first opium poppy crop there since 1972.

title: The Region
description: Following new and stronger warnings from the banking community, demands for action by his own Board of Estimate and increasingly unsubtle proddings from the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, Mayor Beame has begun to take steps believed necessail to restore faith in New York City's financial credibility.

title: Robert Musil, Where Are You?
description: As we celebrate the centennial of Thomas Mann's birth, Americans should not overlook a contemporary of Mann's, a writer of equal stature who is much less well known. The name of Robert Musil (18801942) writer, philosopher, psychologist, engineer, mathematician, has been surfacing over the last 15 years as one of the century's major writers. As the world catches up with him, his time is arriving; but it is arriving much more rapidly in Europe because his works are available there, in various languages, as a part of the intellectual landscape. In this country, Musil is a name treated with vague respect among the cognoscenti, a base to be touched at literary cocktail parties (although what game the base belongs to is unclear). He shows up more tangibly in such places as Allan Janik's and Stephen Toulmin's book, Wittgenstein's Vienna.

title: Shah Says His Nation Has $4Billion Deficit
description: KUWAIT, July 26 (UPI)Iran, the world's second largest oilexporting country, has a $4billion deficit, the Shah said today.

title: People/Business
description: Whether or not New Jersey's economy is about to take an upswing remains to be seen, but at least one indicator points to an improving situation. For the fifth consecutive month, mortgage loans made by the state's 260 savings and loan associations have increased, going from $150million in April to $183million in May. latest month for which figures are available.

title: Favorite Scores in Rich Sorority
TV's Italian Cops  Trapped in Old Stereotypes
description: ItalianAmericans may, before long, be yearning for the days when they were, depicted in the lively arts as the onedimensional Mafia villains gunned down by Eliot Ness's Untouchables. It is now fashionable in the lively arts to be Italian, and that's a lot worse than being unfashionable. This ethnic revival has removed Italians from a onedimensional stereotype to a twodimensional stereotype, which turns out to be no improvement at all.

title: Black Rock Band, Earthy and Fiery, Plays the Garden
description: Earth, Wind and Fire (what happened to water?) is a nineMan black band that can be called flashy In both the figurative and literal senses of that much overused adjective.

description: LANDOVER, Md., July 28  The Long Island Tomahawks moved 4 points in front of the secondplace Montreal Quebecots in the National Lacrosse League by scoring an 1810 victory over the Maryland Arrows tonight at Capitol Center.

description: The city's Traffic Department has begun installing modernized signals and pedestrian controls at 945 street intersections in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx in the third phase of a program jointly financed by the state and the Federal Government.

description: An appeals court has decided that an undercover agent's safety is more important than a defendant's right to a public trial.

description: In the First Parish Church Unitarian in Framingham, Mass., yesterday afternoon, Hannah Adams Horne, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Horne Jr. of Framingham, and Andrew James Lord 3d were married by the Rev. Harvey Ammerman.

title: Headliners
description: Christina Onassis, heir to the billiondollar Onassis shipping empire, has married Alexandros Andreadis, the son of another Greek Shipowner and banker. The wedding surprised friends and relatives; the couple had only known each other for about a month. The marriage unites shipping interests which at times competed for contracts, but which have, both suffered in recent months because of their former ties with the ousted military regime in Greece.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to price and the quality of comparable establishments Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Prices Outpace Factory Wages
description: TRENTON  The average New Jersey factory worker with three dependents has had a 55 per cent increase in takehome pay since 1967, but a loss in real spendable income.

title: Fifth Ave. Fighting Nightclub Incursions
description: The Fifth Avenue Association is moving in court to combat the spread of nightclubs In elite shopping areas along Fifth and Madison Avenues.

description: WASHINGTON, July 26Senate John V. Tunney made public today a small portion of a White House transcript of a conversation in 1973 in which H. R. Haldeman told President Nixon that the original Watergate prosecutor, Earl J. Silbert, was limiting the Watergate investigation.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Darwin's theory of the survival of the fittest, most modern scientists agree, still elucidates what the 19thcentury natural historian sought to explain. What remains unexplained by 20thcentury biologists is how, or whether, natural selection operates on the most fundamental organic level, in the molecular particulars of animals and plants.

title: Anita Karp Is Engaged to R. S. Chargar

Moore, former Ambassador to Ireland, died Friday in Prospect, St. Vincent, West Indies Associated States where she lived. He age was 70.

description: American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater is giving the kind of performances you want to store up in your memory for a rainy day. On Friday night, we had Bournonville's La Sylphide, with Cynthia Gregory and Ivan Nagy, and It was absolutely beautiful.

But on, Thursday and Friday evenings, at the Shirtsleeves Theater, 321 East 73d Street, Mike Lipskin gave concerts devoted to this delightful art.

He considers it every bit as important as his golf game, with which he has, won 15, major championships and 52 others.

title: Timbers and Sounders Thrive Far From the Fuss Over Pele

That's 3,000 miles from where Pele is playing, but soccer fans in that area don't give a boot where Pete is playing. They just care about their Sounders and Timbers, who are both attracting record crowds to their North American Soccer League games.

title: QUEENS STORE GUARD SHOT IN LEG BY THIEF

title: Tombstones, Manhole Covers and The Ancient Art of Rubbing
description: Some of the people whom one comes across these days kneeling in a church or old castle or in front of an old gravestone or historic milestone marker are not necessarily performing an act of reverence or exhibiting signs of exhaustion: there is a good chance they may simply be making a rubbing.

title: Shell Oil Fined $5,000
description: BOSTON, July 26 (AP)The Shell Oil Company has been fined $5,000, the maximum under current Federal law, for a spill of more than 100,000 gallons of kerosene at its West Boylston storage plant last January.

title: ART VIEW
description: Herrri Matisse, who died in 1954 at the age of 84, was widely recognizedand nowhere more enthusiastically than in the United Statesas one of the greatest artists of his time. Certain reputations, even among the acknowledged great, tend to diminish with the passage of time, yet Matisse's has steadily prospered, and the place accorded his manysided achievement is now, if anything, even higher than it was in his lifetime. It looks, indeed, as if the nineteenseventies are going to be a decade of celebration and rediscovery for this artist whose work, in some very important respects, we are just beginning to understand.

title: Whooping Crane Refuge Is Opposed by U.S. Navy
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 26Conservationists and the United States Interior Department want to use 4,000 acres of Federal land in Texas as an additional refuge for whooping cranes but have run into opposition from the Navy.

title: Soto Scores Decision in Quarry Bout
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. July 26 (AP)Pedro Soto of Puerto Rico scored a 10round split decision over Mike Quarry of Orlando, Fla., after scoring a secondround knokdown in their lightheavyweight bout last night.

title: It May Save Her Economically, and Do Much More Than That
description: LONDONJust as Britain's economic plight neared collapse over the last few weeks, the first of the country's longpromised North Sea oil finally arrived onshore.

title: Top Salary in China Put at $220 a Month
description: TOKYO, July 26 (AP)Deputy Premier Teng Bsiaoping of China receives 400 yuan ($220) a month, the highest pay level in China, the Kyodo News Service reported from Peking.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported decrease in incidents of serious crime in the subways, and a crackdown on 13,000 fare evaders. There were 330 crimes of force and fear in June a decline of 25 per cent from the 438 of June, 1974. Robberies, including muggings, dropped from 305 to 188, and pocketbook theft declined from 107 to 104. But rapes increased from one tothree, and felonious assault went up from 25 to 35.

title: Capra Out For 1975
description: ATLANTA, July 26 (AP)Buzz Capra of the Atlanta Braves, bothered by tendinitis in his right shoulder, will miss the remainder of the 1975 season, the National League club said last night. Capra, the league's earnedrunaverage champion in 1974 with a 2.28 mark and a 168 wonlost record, had not pitched since June 8 and two days later, was placed on the disabled list.

title: City Can Solve Problems On Its Own, Carey Asserts
description: Governor Carey says he feels very strongly that the city does not need special legislative help to deal with the current fiscal crisis.

title: Miss Kaulakis, Tom Potter Jr. Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Francis Kaulakis of Chatham, N. J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Kaulakis to Tom Randolph Potter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Potter of St. Louis.

title: Store Helps Migrant Workers
description: CRANBURY  The people of Cranbury are proud not only of their tree  lined streets, their white Colonial homes and their spotless community, but also of a store that caters to the needs of the area's migrant farmers.

title: Miss McMillan Outjumps 7
description: MONTREAL, July 26If She continues er current rate of improvement, Kathy McMillan may set the world record in the women's long jump before next summer's Olympics.

title: Grundy Victor At Ascot
description: ASCOT, England, July 26Grundy, a lighttan horse who who looks as if he belong in a cowboy film rather than a racetrack, convinced the welldressed crowd at Ascot he was faster than Trigger and Silver today.

title: RURAL VACATIONS A JOY TO CHILDREN
description: Efraim Camacho, 8 years old, threw himself against the bus that was about to leave the George Washington Bus Terminal, carrying children to Pennsylvania, and with shoulders shaking, began to sob.

title: RURAL VACATIONS A JOY TO CHILDREN
description: Efraim Camacho, 8 years old, threw himself against the bus that was about to leave the George Washington Bus Terminal, carrying children to Pennsylvania, and with shoulders, shaking, began to sob.

title: Brewer, Nicklaus Are Tied
description: MONTREAL, July 26There's nothing like a stubborn standoff to keep a golf tournament interesting, and it also helps when a strong competitor threatens from just one stroke behind.

title: The Great American Hum 200 Years of Choral Works
description: My God, the Bicentennial's just around the corner, and nobody's looking! wails choral director Gregg Smith. Though he and his chamber choral ensemble, The Gregg Smith Singers, have been immersing themselves in Bicentennial preliminaries, their efforts are receiving scant response from people who should know better, such as college concert promoters and a certain record company.

title: Cynthia Doggett Bride Of John Munn Ellis 3d
description: Cynthia Manning Doggett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert K. Doggett of Mendham, N. J., and John Munn Ellis 3d were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John C. Belmont Jr. in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N. J.

title: A SalesTax Exemption Stirs Dispute
description: TRENTONEnacting new taxes generally makes the potential taxpayers unhappy, but the State Senate is drawing as much criticism for a tax exemption it voted last week as it is for the $267million package of new taxes it adopted.

title: A Clamp on the Trigger Finger
description: BOSTONAmericans everywhere are subject to a vicious cycle of crime and fear of crime. The selfimposed barricades of multiple locks, guard dogs, and sophisticated burglar alarm systems, the millions spent annually on security measures, are not enough.

title: How a $13,000 Bus Driver Won a Pension of $15,600
description: A $13,000ayear Transit Authority bus driver has retired at age 50 with a $15,600 pension annually for life. He took advantage of the regulation basing pensions on finalyear earnings and was able to pile up $17,000 in extra pay through overtime work in his last year.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: DampRockefeller Bid Is Criticized by Reagan
description: RALEIGH, N. C., July 26 (AP)  Vice President Rockefeller has received shoddy treatment from President Ford's aides, Ronald Reagan said yesterday.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: An exercise in visual perspective at the Cultural Center

title: Symbolic Journey . . .
description: Like most such journeys of heads of state, President Ford's forthcoming trip to Finland to sign the European security agreement and then to three nations of Eastern Europe is a symbolic rather than a substantive mission.

title: New Head for Wilson College
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., July 26 (AP)  Dr. Margaret A. Waggoner, professor of physics at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., is the new president of Wilson College, a women's school here, it was announced yesterday. She succeeds Dr. Lawrence Dennis, acting president of Wilson.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Remember those meticulously tailored coats that stood up themselves like little soldiers? Their labels read Originala. and they were just the thing women would slip into when they weren't wearing their mink or sable.

title: No. Am. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: In power, and down and out
description: Early last May, on the eve of her 56th birthday and four months after her inauguration as Governor of Connecticut, Ella T. Grasso rose early, went to pray at a 6:30 A.M. mass, prayed again at 8 in a Hartford hotel at the Governor's annual prayer breakfast, again at 9 at a memorial mass for John M. Bailey, her political mentor and former state and national Democratic chairman, and finally arrived at the State Capitol at 10.

title: Secret rooms, secret obsessions
description: By Leonie Hargrave. 442 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95.

title: The Art Of Acquiring Museum Gifts
description: The neatlywrapped, unmarked, plain brown paper, package leaned against the streetlevel parapet of the Solomon R, Guggenheim Museum. A museum guard brought it in, and Guggenheim officials unwrapped oitand found a large, framed, unsigned 20thcentury print. They never did find the donor most likely the artistand his gift wound up, rewrapped, in the racks of the Guggenheim's lost and found department. Simply one more example of a gift, meeting refusalas a large percentage of museum gifts do.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Man of Letters Responds
description: Every so often a letter addressed to this column excites the imagination.

title: '76 Revolution Through Artists' Eyes
description: NEWARKA Bicentennial exhibition called Our American Revolution Through the Eyes of Artists is on view at the Newark Public Library.

title: Fashion
description: The police of Miami, one of the places where American civilization flowers, recently arrested three young women after observing them in a socially disruptive activity. The women, while chatting in a public park, had been breastfeeding their infants. The charge was indecent exposure.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JULY 27, 1975

title: Doctors charged a flat $2 for office visits
description: In 1969, Cabell Phillips produced From the Crash to the Blitz: 1929 1939, the first of four planned volumes in The New York Times Chronicle of American Life. Fie called it a journalistic reprise rather than formal social history. I have sought to describe the thirties in the round, he wrote, and to recreate the sense of involvement and propinquity that so many of that generation experienced.

title: City Reports Progress In Cleanup of Garbage
description: The Department of Sanita tion reported measured progress in its effort to collect the city's garbage with 14 per cent fewer men than it had a week ago, as 100 extra sanitationmen worked for the second day in the Frown Heights and Bedford Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn, two of the most severely affected areas of the city.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Hoffman Bride Of Henry W. Doyle 3d
description: Susan Jane Hoffman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Brooks Hoffman of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Henry Watkins Doyle 3d, on of Dr. and Mrs. Doyle Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Bradford Hastings, assisted by the Rev. James R. MacColl 3d, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: And Then There Was One
description: The only convertible surviving when Detroit starts '76 model production will be Cadillac's Eldorado. The other four General Motors divisions are killing their ragtops with the end of the '76 run. American Motors, Chrysler and Ford killed theirs year ago.

title: LEIGH WHIPPER, 98, CHARACTER ACTOR
description: Leigh Whipper Sr., the first black member of the Actors Equity Association, died yesterday in Harlem Hospital. He was 98 years old and lived at 226 West 150th Street.

title: Aznavour's Swiss Bank Account
description: Switzerland's influential banking industry has unleashed its biggest guns to pop a trial balloon over the possible abolition of numbered bank accounts. The balloon was launched by the highest Government officials in what now appears to have been a bit of psychological maneuvering in international diplomacy.

title: STAMPS
description: The United States is joining In the observance o International Women's Year with a new commemorative to highlight this year's concentration on furthering progress and equality for women all over the world.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1BRUCE COLEMAN. INC./DAVID OVERCASH

title: BRIDGE
description: The single brilliant thrust aimed at cutting the opponents' communications was a feature of many of Napoleon's battles. Similar Napoleonic strokes are available at the bridge table.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The arrival of Bicentennial half  dollars earlier this month at banks throughout the country is sure to put coin collecting on the map again: But this time the prominence will be positive, not like the black eye the hobby acquired from some of the coin hoarding and speculation incidents of recent years. Millions of noncollectors will be taking a second 16ok at any halfdollars they receive (to see if they have the Bicentennial design on the reverse side) and will be doing the same with quarters later this summer, and with dollar coins in the fall.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have water under my cellar floor (and have a sump pump in case the water gets too high) and the cellar is always damp even though there is no actual water in the basement: I want to paint the floor and walls of this cellar. What kind of paint I should use as a sealer? T.D.L., Florida, N.Y.

title: Letters
description: Water baddies

title: Camping on the Beach: A Surf Lover's Guide to Long Island
description: OLDTIME outdoorsmen remember what camping on the beach used to be: a small tent, unshaven fishing cronies, the whole party off by themselves somewhere, ostensibly surf casting, but mostly tippling. Today's outdoor family, on the other hand, is likely to be ensconced in a wellappointed camper or motorhomeor if in a tent, almost certainly in a modular, compartmentalized one with privacy curtains, sewnin flooring and other creature comforts. And when the family sets up camp, it's usually in a regulated campground.

title: Senate Money Bill Contains $175,000 for Staff of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Senate passed a $6.34billion appropriation bill today, including funds for office staff for former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: ISRAEL'S FORCES SHOW NEW VIGOR
description: JERUSALEM, July 21Israel's ground, air and naval forces are significantly stronger in numbers, weapons and morale than they were when the Egyptians and Syrians attacked on Oct. 6, 1973.

title: AirConditioners Disturb Facades and Tempers
description: Temperatures are up again, and so is the ire of residents in older, architecturally distinctive apartment buildings, who are encountering resistance to the installation of room airconditioners.

title: The Tax Angle
description: One aspect of advertising the prices of competing exchanges on the consolidated tape, one that particularly worries New York Stock Exchange officials, is transfer taxes.

title: Laotians Decide to Break Relations With South Korea
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 25 (Reuters)Laos has announced that she has decided to break diplomatic relations with South Korea.

title: Jane Luxton Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elvin L. Luxton of Allison Park, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Charlotte Luxton, to Charles Matz Horn. Both are thirdyear students at the Cornell University Law School.

title: Doyle, Burleson Play Key Roles for Boston
description: In his straightforward, unspectacular way, Bill Virdon summed up the Yankees' 42 defeat by the Boston Red Sox yesterday as follows: They made the plays and we missed the play on the sacrifice fly.

title: UFOS Explained
description: One beautiful evening in the spring of 1964, Stanley Kubrick and I, after weeks of brainstorming, finally decided that we'd make a film about space. In a mood of cheerful exhilaration, we walked out onto Stanley's penthouse balcony to admire the view over Manhattan.

title: Like most Hamsun heroes, alone wherever he was
description: Under the Autumn Star and On Muted Strings. By Knut Hamsun. Translated from the Norwegian by Oliver and Gunnvor Stallybrass. 281 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $7.95.

title: Letters: The Looting Of Costa Rican Ruins
description: To the Fditor:

title: Nassau Sets Up a Bicentennial Center
description: EAST MEADOWAt the time of the American Revolution, most people who lived in what is now Nassau County were Loyalists, and if the rest did not support King George III they were at least cool to the hotheads from New England who were determined to win their independence.

title: House Outlook Is Unclear on Plan to Authorize $2Billion for Range of Programs
description: WASHINGTON, July 26President Ford vetoed today a $2billion health bill, and the Senate, acting with unusual speed, overrode the veto by 67 to 15.

title: State Recommends Closing a Racially Imbalanced Underused L.I. High School
description: BRIDGEHAMPTONIn a special report on this East End community's school system, the state's Department of Education has recommended the closing of the high school in the district, which in the last five years has become 80 per cent black and has seen its enrollment drop 42 per cent.

title: Angola Force Reported Pressing On
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 26A Spokesman for one of Angola's three rival black nationalist movements said today that his troops would continue their advance toward this capital city to reoccupy positions lost earlier this month.

title: Paris and Bonn Combine Steps to Stir Economies
description: BONN, July 26France and West Germany will begin synchronized programs at the end lof August to improve their economies, President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany announced after conferring here today.

title: Future Events
description: Well Met by Moonlight Aug. 2That's a slight variation of Oberon's words to Titania as he peevishly greeted his queen in A Midsummer Night's Dream, but it's a better way to describe the spirit of achievement felt by the Saratoga Performing Arts Center as it celebrates its 10th season of performance with the Anniversary Ball at the Hall of Springs. It's actually the 11th annual ball; the first was a springboard to get things going. Because the center opened with George Balanchine's ballet based on Shakespeare's fantasy, Dream will be the ball theme. Immediately after the New York City Ballet's performance, the 450 or so guests will find themselves in a sylvan setting lent by the ballet company. The menu will be less derivative (and more substantive) than the apricocks and dewberries Titania ordered for Bottomthings like chicken Cordon Bleu, mushroomed wild rice, shrimp salad Nigoise and the chef's surprise dessert. Stan Rubin and his orchestra will provide the sportive harmonics. Tickets, $50; $75 for patrons; $25 for juniors (under 35). Mrs. James P. Furlong, Melissa Hayden and Mrs. Kenneth T. Lally are cochairmen.

title: RollCall of 67to15 Overriding Ford Veto
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate voted today to override President Ford's veto of a $2billion health services bill:

title: 5 Air Force Reservists Die In Michigan Plane Crash
description: IMLAY CITY, Mich., July 26 (UPI)  A United States Air Force C130 Hercules transport plane crashed into a field and burned today, killing five of the six reservist crewmen on board, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: Music: Mostly Mozart Festival With a Difference
description: Lincoin Center's Mostly Mozart Festivals have been hospitable to wellknown musicians who wished to explore performing areas relatively unfamiliar to them, and the 1975 series began just a few days ago with Pinchas Zukerman, familiar as a violinist, appearing also as a conductor.

title: Pastoral Art at Princeton
description: PRINCETONThe current exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum is an example of the special kind of visual delight that is available during the lazy summer months.

title: If You Go...
description: ...to the Old Country, the new Busch Gardens in Williamsburg, Va., you will find the amusement park/brewery complex on U.S. 60 about four miles east of Colonial Williamsburg. The area is accessible from the north by way of Interstate 95 and from the east by, way of I64.

title: Miss Strickland Bride of J. B. Given 4th
description: Susan Lawrence Strickland, who graduated last month from Bucknell University, was married yesterday afternoon to James Bartley Given 4th, a Bucknell senior. The Rev. Paul M. Corson performed the ceremony in the Yardley (Pa.) United Methodist Church.

title: The Great Ghost Rescue
description: You may not have noticed, but picturesque ghostly homesteads are fast becoming a thing of the past. Dank dungeons and deserted castles are falling prey to the greed of myopic real estate developers. The latest victim is Craggyford Castle, the ancestral home of Humphrey the Horrible and his family. Modern improvements are making it an unfit place for selfrespecting ghosts to live. So, the family reluctantly decides to move. It's a formidable group: Humphrey, who wants to be horrible, but isn't very good at it; his mother the Hag, who delights in smelling dreadfully; his brother the screaming skull; his sister, Wailing Winifred; his father, a Scottish ghost known as the Gliding Kilt because he lost his legs in an ancient battle; and Aunt Hortensia, a former housekeeper of Henry VIII's who met several of his wives.

title: MOREAU YEOMANS
description: Moreau Yeomans, a lawyer who retired two years ago as vice president of corporate finance of Hornblower & WeeksHemphill Noyes, brokers, died Friday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L. I. He was 66 years old and lived in Greenvale. L. I.

title: SALYUT CREWMEN IN SAFE LANDING
description: MOSCOW, July 26Two Soviet astronauts returned safely to earth from the Salyut 4 orbital station today after setting a Soviet record of 63 days in space. They left unbroken the 84day record set by American Skylab astronauts early last year.

title: BURMA GRADUATES IN A GLOOMY MOOD
description: RANGOON, July 21It can't stay like this, said the young man driving a gypsy taxi. For us there is no future.

title: Allison Knows It's Hard To Cut Pocono Corners
description: At age 37, when many racecar drivers are thinking about cutting back, Bobby Allison is branching out. He has driven in a variety of races this season, but next Sunday at Pocono International Raceway, he will be back home in a 4,000pound stock car, battling Richard, David, Cale and the rest of the good ol' boys.

title: RATES INCREASED ON POSTAL BOXES
description: More than 40,000 New Yorkers who get their mail through post office boxes are digging deeper into their pockets this month to pay for the service. Effective July 1, rental rates on all types of box service went up, in some cases as much as three times the previous rates.

title: Ideas&Trends
description: A former college president, asked recently to give new presidents advice on how to survive in their posts, declined. He said he could not think of any advice to give.

title: Deborah Wood Dunn Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ervin Stanley Dunn 2d of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Wood Dunn, to Cameron Warner Clark, on of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Clark Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and Ocean Reef, Fla.

title: Notes: Cuban Resort Readied by Club Med
description: THE Club Mediterranee, which has 68 vacation centers around the world, has added a new onein Cuba. It's for Canadian and European tourists, but Club Med is planning a second Cuban complex, this one for Americans, even as the finishing touches are being put to the first. Scheduled to open Nov. 1 is the Club Mediterranee Bacuranao, which is 17 miles east of Havana.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26 (AP)The attorney for Cullen Bryant said today he would go to court if necessary to stop the National Football League commissioner, Pete Rozelle, from ordering the running back sent from Los Angeles to the Detroit Lions. In a Rozelle Rule move yesterday, Bryant was ordered to Detroit as compensation for Ron Jessie, the wide receiver who had played out his option with the Lions and signed with the Rams as a free agent last month.

title: Casey and Dodgers: The Funny Losers
description: Seventeen years after Charlie Ebbets had traded him to the Pittsburgh Pirates, Mr. Charles Dillon Stengel became the manager of the Dodgers. In those years Casey had been a great many places, including England, where he hit a borne run before King George V. From the Pirates, he had gone to the Phillies and afterward to the Giants, where John McGraw platooned him in center field against the opposition's righthanded pitching.

title: Morass of Oil...
description: If anyone deliberately set out to write the most confusing scenario possible on how this Congress should deal with the energy question, remarked Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois the other day, they could not improve one whit on the scenario that seems to be unfolding before us.

title: Nureyev, Leave Canadian Ballet Alone
description: TORONTO The bodies surrounding Rudolf Nureyev as he dances at the Metropolitan Opera House these evenings belong to the National Ballet of Canada. Nureyev has been indulging himself in things Canadian for the past couple of years, dancing with the National for several Toronto and Ottawa seasons, developing a spectacular production of The Sleeping Beauty, and helping out with the ticket sales at London galas and summer seasons in New York.

title: Just a Hint of Liberalism on The Moscow Stage
description: Reporting on a week of theatergoing in Moscow, I am probably safest in just giving the facts and keeping trendspotting to a minimum, mainly because recent developments look so heartening. Can some sort of cultural liberalism actually be setting in? A brilliant director who, a few years ago, lost his theater and entered the official doghouse for monkeying with the classics has continued to monkey with the classics his increased his large popular following. and has even been winning signs of official approbation. The prospects for international exchange have been improved by the presence in Moscow of an English director who is, so far as anyone can recall, the first Englishman to direct there since Gordon Craig staged a MossowHamlet in 1912.

title: 15 Riders Called By Jury
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 26 The New Jersey State Grand Jury will hear testimony at Trenton on Aug. 14 on the alleged fixing of the ninthrace trifecta at Atlantic City Race Course on July 14.

title: A key figure in modern art, born five centuries ago
description: Edited by Walter L. Strauss. Six Volumes; 3,084 pp. Illustrated. New York: Abaris Books. $360 per set.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: In a season commemorating the centenary of its theater in StratforduponAvon, Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company is offering a panoply of HenrysHenry IV, Part I, Henry IV, Part II and Henry V, with The Merry Wives of Windsor scheduled to join the repertory in August. The first three are presented as if they were one play, with one director, Terry Hands, one designer and the same actors playing the revolving cast of characters. The linchpin of the season, and the major event of the summer at Stratford, is the company's rousingly direct production of Henry V, in which Alan Howard gives a titanic kingsize portrayal in the title role. The performance is convincing evidence that Howard known to American audiences largely for his double role as Oberon and Theseus in Peter Brook's A Midsummer Night's Dreambelongs in the highest rank of young English stage actors.

title: Technology and the Straw
description: The small milk container sold in vending machines and distributed in school systems amounted last year to a 10billion  unit, $135  million business in this country. But it's always been, among other things, hard to open.

title: DOOMSDAY II
description: Nearly four years after Japan's sneak attack on Pearl Harbor, American planes, without warning, dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, wreaking havoc on a scale unprecedented in the history of warfare. The first bomb, code named Little Boy, killed an estimated 70,000 Japanese in Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945, and injured at least as many more. Just three days later, on Aug. 9 a second bomb, Fat Man, killed about 40,000 in Nagasaki and wounded 60,000 others.

title: Many Horses Dying in Shipment
description: Hundreds of horses and ponies bought at auction in the United States and shipped abroad for slaughter as table meat are dying on the way of disease and injury because of conditions in the holds and on the rolling decks of transport ships, according to officials of humane organizations in the United States.

title: Signals from the butterfly
description: In the United States today, 109 kinds of animals and birds are under Federal protection as endangered species. By Congressional definition, species are endangered when they are on the verge of extinction; if they are likely to become endangered in the foreseeable future, the word for them is threatened. Now, the Department of Interior's Office of Endangered Species has called on the scientific community to help it determine whether insectsin this case, some 40 species of butterfliesshould be added to a list of creatures that includes the grizzly, alligator, peregrine falcon, whooping crane and many less publicized birds and animalsKirtland's warbler, the saltmarsh harvest mouse, the Houston toad.

title: Warner's Multimillion Bet on Soccer
description: Warner Communications, Inc., the conglomerate that thrived on The Exorcist and the Rolling Stones, is now trying to tap the sports world potential with soccer demigod Pel and the New York Cosmos.

title: Jane Rabbino Wed To Craig F. Novak
description: Jane Brandt Rabbino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Rabbino of Asheville, N. C., was married there yesterday morning to Craig Francis Novak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Novak of Huntington, L. I. The Rev. Leo Gariazzo performed the ceremony in St. Eugene's Roman Catholic Church.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The drums are talking, the deeper one in short phrases, the higher one in semiimprovised crossrhythms. The melody instrument, a homemade cane flute, plays a hypnotic onemeasure figure over and over, with minimal variations in the relative hoarseness of its reedy tone. Shouts are distantly audible, as are the occasional ululRtions of several women. A sudden signal passes from the flute to the drums and a unison rhythmic tattoo ends the piece. Another musician begins alternately whooping with his voice and blowing into a set of tuned pipes, creating a captivating, continuous pattern.

title: Roof Paint for Cooling
description: A home maintenance product that has been on the Market for many yearsbut one that comparatively few homeowners are familiar withcan greatly extend the life of many home roofs while at the same time considerably reducing the cost of air conditiioning and making the house more comfortable during hot weather. This product is a type of roof coating which is variously called asphaltaluminum, or Just simply aluminum, roof paint.

title: Those Red Sox Rookies
description: Through their history, the Boston Red Sox seldom have won pennants but they've always had hitters. Ted Williams dominates their archives, along with Jimmy Foxx and Tris Speaker and the contemporary, Carl Yastrzemski, their first baseman. They even had a hitter named Babe Ruth but they preferred to employ him as a pitcher. But this sea son, they have introduced two rookie outfielders with the look of winners as well as hitters  Fred Lynn and Jim Rice. One is from Southern California, the other from South Carolina; one is white, one is black; one swings lefthanded, the other righthanded. Perhaps their only common denominator is that each quietly believes he is a hitter.

title: CORRECTION
description: John H. Harper, a special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury, was incorrectly identified in last Sunday's Business and Finance Section as Robert E. Harper.

title: Article 3  No Title
Hearings Due Tomorrow on Changing State Aviation Rules
description: TRENTONA Federal District Court judge will begin hearings here tomorrow on a move by the United States Attorney in New Jersey to strike down part of New Jersey's state aviation regulations.

title: AllStars to Play Steelers Friday Night
description: Remember the College AllStar Game? It's The one that starts the exhibition games each summer, matching the last Super Bowl winner against the supposedly best young players coming out of the college ranks. The pros always win, or almost always. The game was not played last year because of the player strike in the National Football League, but it will be played this year, on Friday night at Chicago with the Pittsburgh Steelers the visiting team. The contest, if that is what one can call it, will be televised over Channel 7 in New York starting at 9:30 and ending sometime early Saturday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TOMORROW, JULY 28

title: Belle M. Giles Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford Robbins of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Robbins' daughter, Belle Mansfield Giles, to Kevin Victor Benfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Victor Benfield of West Bay, Dorset, England.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TodayBoston at Shea Stadium, 2, 1 P.M.

title: The F16 And How It Won Europe
description: PARISJust over a month ago, the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis completed the sale to the Air Forces of Belgium, the Netherlands, Norway and Denmark of $2billion worth of fighter planes, winning what has been dubbed the arms contract of the century.

title: A Plan for Recycling Schools
description: EAST MEADOWA prominent architect here advanced a plan last week to convert schools and their grounds abandoned by underutilization into muchneeded apartment units.

title: Labyrinthian Way
description: Why children and adults in the United States should develop a sudden hankering for mazes is a mystery. Increasing leisure naturally demands new time wasters, but that can't be the whole story. Is it because millions feel trapped in various kinds of labyrinthsreligious, moral, economic, politicaland finding a way out of a paper maze somehow helps relieve anxiety? That might apply to adults, but hardly to children. Perhaps it is just a case of publishers discovering aninterest that children have had all along.

title: Gertrude's Child
description: By Richard Hughes. Illustrated by Nicole Claveloux. Unpaged. New York: Harlin Quist. Distributed by Dial/Delacorte. $4.95. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: Two Scholarships Are Offered by College
description: TOMS RIVERThe Ocean County College Foundation has announced two memorial scholarships for the coming academic yearone to aid a student at the college and the other for a June, 1975, graduate of the college.

title: Detroit Talks to Go On
description: DETROIT, July 26 (UPI)Federal and state mediators persuaded The Newspaper Guild today to resume talks Monday and urged it to set no new strike deadline immediately against the Detroit News, an evening newspaper. Bargainers for the newspaper and union, which represents 300 editorial employes, met for two hours today after postponing a strike deadline set for 12:01 A.M.

title: Katherine Johnson Married To William Hafner on L.I.
description: Katherine Ann Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kirt E. W. Johnson of Manhasset, L. I., was married there yesterday afternoon to William August Hafner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Hafner of Manhasset and Delray Beach. Fla.

title: Guest Observer
description: Remember back when people carried a rabbit's foot, and called avocados alligator pears; when a mile a minute was traveling fast, and crime meant only Frank Costello? Remember squiring Lucy to the soda fountain: this years before anybody could hope to take her to bed? Nevertheless, we knew as we watched her licking vanilla from a longhandled spoon that to provide such fare was a form of possessiondown went the blobby mouthfuls. Already we had some sense that sex itself ;mist be a feast, or if not that, at least a meal. At any age it still is an intimate business to furnish food to a woman, or to be cooked for by her, like lying next to each other for a litte.

title: Paris' Municipal Budget Sound, But City Lacks Independence
description: PARIS, July 26Baron Georges Haussmann, who directed construction of the broad boulevards of Paris more than 100 years ago, called the city the seat from which all public power is exercised in France.

title: Thieu Reported Planning Trip to Britain for Asylum
description: HONG KONG, July 26Former President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam is scheduled to leave Taiwan, where he has been staying, and fly to England next week, authoritative sources said today.

title: Cardinal Cody Is Assailed for Closing 4 Schools in Chicago Ghetto
description: CHICAGO, July 26A unilateral decision by John Cardinal Cody to close four parochial schools in a black ghetto has touched off a controversy among Roman Catholic laymen and brought to public attention a longsimmering dispute between the Cardinal and a group of Chicago priests who regard him as inept, aloof and autocratic.

title: Bond Jargon as Easy as AAA
description: You, too, can talk like a municipal bond salesman.

title: Oldest 2Hump Camel Dies
description: KYOTO, Japan, July 26 (AP) A twohumped camel, said to be the oldest of its kind in the world, died here this week at the age of 30, Kyoto Zoo officials reported. They said the previous longevity record for a twohumped, or Bactrian, camel was 25 years, in a Swiss zoo.

title: DECLINE IS SEEN IN NASSAU SCHOOLS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 26Nassau County's school enrollment will decline 48 per cent by 1985, according to a report by the Nassau County Planning Commission. And while publicschool enrollment is in steady decline, the report said, the cost of educating each pupil has increased 43 per cent in the last five years.

title: A Newark Campus for White Ethnics
description: NEWARK  A neighborhood campus primarily for white ethnics living in this predominantly black city and neighboring white, middleincome suburbs will open here in September In a centuryold mansion, for freshman students of Essex County College.

title: Queens Bus Ridership Bottoms Out After Long Skid
description: Over a matter of nickels and dimes, 13 of every 100 passengers deserted Transit Authority buses in Queens during the last decade.

title: S. G. Wald to Wed Stephanie Brilliant
description: Prof. and Mrs. Richard Brilliant of Scarsdale, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Hannah Brilliant, to Stephen George Wald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Wald of Philadelphia.

title: Football Hall Will Induct Four Players
description: CANTON. Ohio, July 26 (AP)Dante Lavelli, Lenny Moore, George Connor and Roosevelt Brown, all with ragstoriches stories, reach football immortality Saturday.

title: Nuptials for Patricia Barrow, Teacher
description: Patricia Ellen Barrow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Barrow Jr. of Rockville Centre, L. I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Edwin A. Molloy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Molloy Jr., of Merrick, L. I.

title: U.S. Failing to Get Its Due in Oil Royalties
description: WASHINGTONThe United States Government is not getting full value from onshore gas and oil leases on Federal lands, according to a review of the royalty accounting system by the Interior Department's Office of Audit and Investigation.

title: GOULD H. THOMAS
description: Gould Hunter Thomas, a retired oil executive, died of cancer Friday night at his home in Brookfield, Conn. He was 62 years old.

title: Women Weighing Graduate Studies
description: UPPER MONTCLAIRMore than 60 women turned out at the Montclair State College Women's Center last week to explore the possibilities of graduate school after what, for most of them, had been an academic hiatus of many years.

title: Anniversaries
description: Gerard

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Stockings Leads Field Of 10 Pacers
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y. July 26Silk Stockings, the fastgaited 3yearold filly who has been undefeated in her last eight races, was still considered the horse to beat at Monticello Raceway tomorrow afternoon as she and nine rivals concluded their training for the largest purse in the 169year recorded history of the sport on this continent.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Salyut Crew Lands
description: Two Soviet astronauts returned safely to earth yesterday after spending 63 days aboard the Salyut 4 space station. Their stay was the longest for Soviet astronauts in space. Page 30.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed lower last week as the market failed to support a rally attempt on Thursday.

title: Virginia Naber Is Bride
description: Virginia Joanne Naher and David C. Langlas were married yesterday afternoon in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood, N. J., by Msgr. James S. Kelley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Naber Jr., of Franklin Lakes. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Langlas of Waterloo, Iowa, where his father, a retired industrialist, is a business consultant. Mr. Naher is treasurer of Airco, Inc., in Montvale, N. J.

title: Miss Turney Bride of C. M. Matheson
description: Charmian Wallace Turney, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. M. Frank Turney of Knoxville, Tenn., was married yesterday afternoon to Charles MacLean Matheson. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Matheson of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Linda Werner Wed to H. J. Earl 2d
description: Linda Jean Werner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Werner of Hastings, Neb., was married there yesterday afternoon to Harley J. Earl 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Earl of Colorado Springs, Colo., and New York.

title: UNESCO May Check Burma Temple Damage
description: PARIS, July 26 (UPIThe United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has offered to send a restoration expert to Burma to assess the damage to Buddhist temples resulting from an earthquake earlier this month, a UNESCO spokesman said yesterday.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Autumn has come a little early this yearat least it has for American Ballet Theater. For its annual Lincoln Center summer seasona sixweek stint which still has two weeks to runthe company presented two world premieres at the New York State Theater.

title: Miss Lopez Accepts A Golf Scholarship
description: Nancy Lopez, the 18yearold amateur golfer who tied for second place behind Sandra Palmer last week in the United States women's open championship, isn't going to let the Women glamour of playing on the wornen's professional Sports tour or the attractiveness of the money turn her away from Tulsa University this fall.

title: GLENN JORDAN
description: Glenn Jordan, executive director of the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera, since 1970 died Tuesday in Los Angeles at the age of 56.

title: How boomtown greed is changing Alaska
description: FAIRBANKS, AlaskaIt's like a war, except that there are no guns and no particular enemy. The construction of the Alaska pipeline, now in the midst of a summer offensive of bulldozers and welding torches, will cost at least $6billion, will take another two years or more to complete and will finally mean a steady flow of oil each day from the edge of the Arctic Ocean south to the icefree port of Valdez. The project will also kill hundreds of men, turn many women into whores and shatter the quiet lifestyle of the communities along its 798mile route.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: KAY LIVINGSTONE
description: TORONTO, July 26 (AP)Kay Livingstone, an actress and broadcaster who founded the Canadian Women's Negro Association 25 years ago, died yesterday. She was 55 years old.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Herbert Gruenewald has set a goal of $1billion in annual sales for the Mobay Chemical Corporation by the end of this decademore than double its sales last year.

title: Mets Release Jones
description: CHICAGO, July 26The Cleon Jones saga ended todayat least as far as the New York Mets were concernedwhen the club gave Jones his unconditional release.

title: New Corporate Bonds
Salty Goose Takes Queen's Cup Sailing
description: PADANARAM, Mass., July 27Salty Goose, a 52foot sloop from Rye, N. Y., today won the Queen's Cup, one of the mostsought prizes in the trophy locker of the New York Yacht Club.

title: Listing of Grizzly Bear As Endangered Asked
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)The Fish and Wildlife Service said today that it wanted to classify the grizzly bear as a threatened species.

title: Sharon Martin Bride Of Mark Elson on L.I.
description: Sharon Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Martin of North Miami, Fla., was married at noon yesterday to Mark Elson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Elson of Hewlett, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Center, of which the bridegroom's father is president.

title: Polo Results
description: AT BETHPAGE, L.I.

title: How the Layoffs Have Affected Some City Workers
description: Their names mean nothing to the average New Yorker, and little more to City Hall. But until recently, they were a part of the city's backbone work forcea policeman, a fireman, a laborer, a librarian, a cafeteria worker and two school aides.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Unaccompanied Children Pose a Refugee Problem
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 27Officials dealing with the resettlement of 130,000 Vietnamese and Cambodians have discovered in refugee camps more than 300 children who arrived in this country unaccompanied by their parents.

title: Giscard, in Interview, Stresses His Belief in Liberal Reform
description: PARIS. July 27 President Valry Giscard d'Estaing is convinced that conservative democracy is condemned and that most people almost everywhere in the world aspire to liberal reform.

title: Baseball Box Scores and Standings
STATE HEARING DUE ON SOCIAL SERVICES
description: The State Department of Social Services has set a public hearing for Thursday at 2 World Trade Center on the state's proposed plan for social services under the new Title XX amendments to the Social Security Act.

title: FORD AND SCHMIDT URGE COOPERATION IN ECONOMIC PLANS
description: BONN, July 27President Ford and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany agreed here today that it was vitally important that the United States intensify efforts to coordinate economic policy with Western Europe.

title: Weiskopf Defeats Nicklaus With a Birdie on Extra Hole
description: MONTREAL, July 27In one of the tightest finishes of this year's professional golf tour, Tom Weiskopf twice overtook Jack. Nicklaus to day, then beat his old college friend in a suddendeath playoff to win the Canadian open.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Super Yalta
description: A good public relations man would advise Henry Kissinger to let the current press criticism of the forthcoming Helsinki supersummit run its course.

title: BEEF MPH UP, PRICE DIP AWAITED
description: CHICAGO, July 27There are more cattle on the country's ranches and farms today than ever before, offering a betterthaneven chance that consumers will be paying less for beef this fall.

title: Top Paris Ballerina at Ballet Theater This Week
description: Among the surprises American Ballet Theater has planned for its gala performance tonight at the New York State Theater is the first major performance here by a member of the Paris Opera Ballet since that company last appeared here in 1948.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Salyut Flyers Honored
description: MOSCOW, July 27 (Reuters) Vitaly I. Sevastyanov and Pyotr I. Klimuk received the Soviet Union's highest award, the Order of Lenin, today after returning to earth yesterday from a 63day mission in space aboard the Salyut 4 orbital station.

title: Carolyn Patton Bride Of Thomas Mancino
description: Carolyn Gale Patton of New York, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Patton of Jackson, Mich., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Edward Mancino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony T. Mancino of Linden, N.J.

title: Pay N Pak Wins
description: KENNEWICK, Wash., July 22 (AP)George Henley piloted Pay N Pak to her second straight victory in the Gold Cup regatta today and took the national point lead n the unlimted hydroplane racing.

title: LOUIS H. HAMEL
description: Louis H. Hamel, founder and former president of the L. H. Hamel Leather Company of Haverhill, Mass., who had been active in Roman Catholic charities, died Saturday in Boston. He was 76 years old and lived in Haverhill and Oyster Harbor, Mass., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Farrell to Expand Australia Service to West Coast
description: Farrell Lines is about to expand its AustraliaNew Zealand service into a twocoast operation.

title: 5 CAMPAIGN CHESTS TOP $100,000 MARK
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Five members of the Senate have already raised more than $100,000 each for their reelection campaigns next year, even though they do not know who heir opponents will be.

title: Women of the Revolution Were Active In Business and on the Field of Battle
description: WASHINGTON, July 27George Washington never asked Betsy Ross to make a flag. Mrs. Ross was a businesswoman who did it on her own, undoubtedly in an attempt to drum up some sales.

title: Doreen Seidler Is Bride of Rabbi Feller
description: Doreen Harriet Seidler, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Ohio State University, was married yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, to Rabbi Chaim Shlomo Feller, codirector of the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation at Ohio State.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: ASTRONAUTS NEAR MEDICAL RELEASE
description: HONOLULU, July 27  The Apollo astronauts will be released from Tripler Army Medical Center within 48 hours, but will stay in Hawaii for about 10 days for rest and medical observation, doctors said tonight.

title: U.S. Eight Wins Crown; Team Title to N. Y. A. C.
description: CAMDEN, N.J., July 27The United States national rowing team won the eightoared title for the second straight year in the 99th national rowing championships today on the Cooper River. Coach Allen Rosenberg's crew fought bow  to  bow with Vesper for the first 1,000 meters and then pulled away at 39 strokes a minute and won by two lengths. The time was 5 minutes, 53.08 seconds.

title: FOREIGNERS FLEE ANGOLAN FIGHTING
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 27 Americans and Europeans fled from battlescarred Luanda today, and witnesses reported that angry Portuguese soldiers had tired on a crowd of blacks, killing at least 20.

title: Many Nations Try to Regulate News Going Abroad
description: India's sudden and dramatic effort to control reporting foreign correspondents there is only one illustration of the ways many governments try to regulate the flow of news abroad.

title: Bridge:
description: Italy, to nobody's surprise, won the European championships, which ended Saturday in Brighton, England, but the glory went to Israel. An Israeli surge on the final day took them into secondposition behind the Italians, and thus qualified them to compete in the 1976 Bermuda Bowl world championship in Monte Carlo.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: PHEBE W. ANDREWS
description: Phebe Warren Andrews, who operated the PbeheWarren residences for women here, died yesterday in Leroy Hospital. She was 66 years old.

title: RUTGERS UNIT PLANS A STUDY ON ASPIRIN
description: The National Heart and Lung Institute has chosen the Rutgers Medical School's Piscataway branch as one of 30 centers across the country to help determine whether daily doses of aspirin can reduce the threat of recurrent heart attacks or strokes.

title: $1.85Billion Rail Financing Is Proposed
description: In return for $1.85billion in Federal funds to get Conrail rolling early next year, the united States Railway Association is proposing that Conrail, the Govenmentsupported successor to the bankrupt Northeastern railroads, issue $1billion of 7 per cent income debentures and $850million of Series A prefererd stock to the Government.

title: National Rowing Summaries
Two Saigon Observers To the U.N. Fly Here
description: The first two officials of South Vietnam's new Communist Government to come to the United States arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday and were welcomed by Communist diplomats, antiwar activists and two former prisoners of war.

title: China Reports Launching Third Satellite Into Orbit
description: TOKYO, July 27 (AP)China announced today the launching of a third satellite in line with what was termed a policy of promoting preparedness against war. The satellite was expected to be orbiting the earth with all of its instruments functioning properly.

title: Psychiatrist Weds Elisabeth Hoffman
description: Elisabeth Hoffman, a doctoral candidate in clinic psychology at George Washington University, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Anthony Reading, associate professor of psychiatry at the Johns Hopkins University. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony at the Jamaica Estates, home of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hoffman, parents of the bride.

title: Newark Nears Completion Of SchoolSystem Reform
description: NEWARK, July 27Walter Wechsler, who last February was given six months to reform the business management of Newark's public schools, will conclude the assignment next Friday, hopeful that his work will represent a turning point in the improvement of an educational system that has been described as a disaster.

title: Curb on Woodcutters Urged
description: BANGOR, Me., July 27 (AP) Maine should pass legislation restricting the hiring of migrant woodcutters from Canada, Wayne Birmingham, the newly elected president of the Maine Woodsman's Association, says.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Heart Transplants on Coast
description: STANFORD, Calif., July 21 (UPI)Two persons have received hearts in transplant operations at Stanford Hospital. Officials said that on Friday a 42yearold California man received the heart of Leslie Hadley, 26 years old, of Eureka, Calif., fatally injured when struck by a falling tree. The same day a 27yearold Indiana woman received a heart from Laurie Bloyd, 14, of Cottonwood, Calif., fatally injured when struck by a car in Anderson, Calif.

title: Peru Naming Press Chiefs
description: LIMA, Peru, July 27 (AP)Peru's military Government announced yesterday it would appoint new directors for seven previously nationalized newspapers to eliminate antigovernment bias. The papers were expropriated a year ago and officials were appointed to reorganize and run them.

title: Lenny Katzberg Remarries Here
description: Elaine C. Katzberg of Bayside, Queens, an executive secretary with the Louisville Bedding Company, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jerome Prince of New York, dean emeritus of the Brooklyn Law School. Justice Edward Thompson of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: A Bud for Nipping
description: Representative Poage of Texas has served notice on the House Agriculture Committee, of which he is chairman, that he intends to attach to the extension of the Pesticide Control Act an amendment that would paralyze that essential law. The provision would require concurrence of the Secretary of Agriculture before the Environmental Protection Agency could cancel registration of a pesticide, reclassify it or, in fact, promulgate any regulation affecting its use.

title: SmallBusiness Leaders Fight To Keep RobinsonPatman Act
description: The possible repeal of the RobinsonPatman Act, one of the country's antitrust laws, has caused a wave of concern in smallbusiness circles. Then fear was heightened recently with a report that President Ford had requested the Justice Department to prepare legislation for either repeal or amendment of the RobinsonPatman Act.

title: Lawyer Weds Nancy S. Voye
description: In the United Congregational Church at Little Compton, R. I., yesterday afternoon, Nancy Susan Voye, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gilbert Voye of Little Compton, became the bride of Mark Lee Weissler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Laurance Weissler of Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: 2 Escaped Elephants Found In Oklahoma Brush Country
description: HUGO, Okla., July 27 (AP)Isa and Lilly, the 1,500pound baby elephants who escaped from a circus lot 16 days ago and then eluded searchers for more than two weeks in rugged brush country near here, were located today, a circus official said.

title: Youth, 17, Accused In Bludgeon Killing Of Foster Mother
description: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, July 27 (UPI)A 17yearold youth was held in the Cape May County Jail today on charges of beating his foster mother to death and attempting to murder his foster father, the police said.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Ron Guidry, a 24yearold lefthanded relief pitcher, arrived from Syracuse during yesterday's first game and made his majorleague debut in the second game, allowing Boston three hits but no runs in two innings. . . . Dave Pagan, a littleused righthanded relief pitcher, was optioned to Syracuse. . .. Thurman Munson did the Red Sox a favor in the opener by trying to bunt Roy White, who had doubled, to third in the sixth. The bunt went right back to Bill Lee and he threw out White at third. I've always had a tough time getting Munson out, Lee said. I'm glad he bunted. . . . Bernie Carbo was out at the plate in the eighth, trying to score on Denny Doyle's double. The relay went from Lou Piniella to Sandy Alomar to Munson.... These games we've played the past two days are good for the fans and good for baseball, remarked Boston's Fred Lynn. But they're not good for the Yankees.

title: Harold Lloyd's Estate Brings a Top Bid of $1.6Million
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 27The Harold Lloyd estate was auctioned off this afternoon, but the fate of the silentfilm comedian's home remains unclear.

title: Miss Mann 4Shot Victor
description: HORSHAM, Pa., July 27 (AP)  Carol Mann, humiliated last week when she missed the cut in the Women's United States Open, won the $40,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at Hidden Spring Golf and Country Club today with a 12under par, 54hole total of 206.

title: Ordinary Objects Take on New Life
description: WASHINGTONHave you ever seen an egg separator that you could call charming? Or a distinctly rococo pastry knife? An elegant carpenter's plane? An imposing rolling pin? A witty pair of crochet hooks? A ruggedly individual wooden bathtub?

title: Peter Tatistcheff Weds Miss Amzallag
description: Florence Linda Amzallag and Peter Alexis Tatistcheff were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Beadleston in IrvingtononHudson, N.Y. Judge Robert S. D. Roy of the Town Court of Greenburg, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: 2 City Nursing Homes Lose Eligibility For Medicaid and Medicare Money
description: Two New York City nursing homes, the Townview in Man hattan and the Astor Gardens in the Bronx, have lost their eligibility for Medicare and Medicaid funds because of overcrowding.

title: Fix Inquiry Is Under Way at 4 Race Tracks
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 27Thoroughbred race tracks in New Jersey and Pennsylvania have been implicated in a trifecta betting conspiracy.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices as which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: BEAME TO UNIONS: TAKE PAY FREEZE OR GET IT BY FIAT
description: Mayor Beame issued a virtual ultimatum to the city's municipal labor unions yesterday, asserting that voluntary acceptance of a wage freeze by midnight tomorrow was much preferable to an imposed one.

title: Democrats' Telethon Is Short of Its Goal
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Despite 21 hours of political hardsell by an allstar cast, the Democratic party appeared tonight to have fallen short of its telethon fundraising goal of over $5million.

title: Hospital Fund Drive Head Named
description: DeWitt Peterkin Jr.. vice chairman of the board of J. P. Morgan & Company and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, was named yesterday as general chairman of the 1975 fundraising campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

title: Gibson of Cards Wins 251st in Rare Relief Stint
description: Quick now when was the last time Bob Gibson pitched and won in relief before yesterday?

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: F16's Job. Prospects Delight Belgians
description: CHARLEROI, BelgiumNew jobs are scarce in this gray mill city of 250,000 in the coalproducing Sambre River Valley. And now, due to the world steel slump, even the 14,000 steel workers' jobs, long the economic life blood of the city, are no longer secure.

title: Exercise Off Taiwan Ends
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 27 (AP) American and Chinese Nationalist naval ships have concluded a weeklong exercise off southern Taiwan, officials said today.

title: Dr. Kind Sr. Ends Ministry
description: ATLANTA, July 27 (UPI)Dr. Martin Luther King Sr. ended his 44year ministry in the small church next to his son's tomb today.

title: Experts Suggest Solar Energy To Replace Foreign Oil and Gas
description: A new industry is being developed in the United States, devoted to harnessing solar energy to meet some of the total demand for energy and to reduce the country's dependence on foreign suppliers of oil and natural gas.

title: Industrial Archeology: A Dig for Eli Whitney
description: WHITNEYVILLE, Conn. Clues to the simple but purposefully obscured beginnings of the Industrial Revolution are starting to emerge this summer as a team of archeologists digs into the grassy and overgrown banks of the Mill River here.

title: The Early Years
description: The American Federation of Teachers and the National Education Association, setting aside their organizational rivalry, have joined in a campaign for dramatic expansion of preschool education.

title: Africans Plan New Challenge to South Africa in U.N.
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 26  African foreign ministers have begun a campaign here to have South Africa's status as an independent sovereign state declared illegal within the world community.

title: Nuptials for Ronnie L. Scharfman
description: Ronnie Leah Scharfman, a Ph.D. candidate in French at Yale University, and Dr. Joseph Kuhn Youngerman, a clinical instructor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, were married yesterday afternoon at the St. Moritz. Rabbi Benjamin Kreitman of Congregation Shaare Torah of Brooklyn performed the ceremony.

title: REIT Deficit Is Disclosed By Continental Mortgage
description: Continental Mortgage Investors, Inc., Boston, has disclosed that it had a substantial loss in its latest fiscal year and was in default on its loans. It also said it was discussing with the New York Stock Exchange whether its stock would be delisted.

title: Nearby Yacht Results
description: AT INDIAN HARBOR Y. C.

title: Monmouth Freeholders in Court Fight
description: FREEHOLD, July 27The Monmouth County Board of Freeholders, controlled by Democrats for the first time in dts history, has gone to court with a political question that may revise the legal system an all of the state's 21 counties.

title: MRS MEIR SAYS AIM OF SUIT ISN'T MONEY
description: JERUSALEM, July 27 Former Premier Golda Meir said through a spokesman today that any financial award she might receive as a result of her suit against Commentary magazine would be donated to a fund for the settlement of Soviet Jews in Israel.

title: Saratoga to Open Today
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. July 27Saratoga opens its 24day summer meeting tomorrow and the feature race is the $35,000added Schuylerville. Tuesday is an off day for thoroughbreds, but harness racing at Saratoga Raceway is scheduled for the first of three Tuesday doubleheaders at 2:15 and 8:15 P.M.

title: Silk Stockings, 12, Captures Record Pace in Record Time
description: MONTICELLO. N.Y., July 27 Silk Stockings, purchased as a yearling for $20,000 in the hope her earnings would help a needy cause, struck it rich today by winning the final dash in the $230.521 MonticelloNew York City Offtrack Betting Classic with surprising ease at Monticello Raceway.

title: It's a Big City Even to Residents
description: Information clerks manning seven kiosks set up in strategic spots in midtown Manhattan two months ago to aid visitors are doing a rushhour business  helping New Yorkers.

title: Carole Steinbock Becomes Bride
description: Carole Steinbock of New York, director of the Center for Social Research in the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, was married yesterday to Robert Goldfeld, associate director of the Vera Institute of Justice. Rabbi Cy Arsa performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Benenson of Mount Vernon, N.Y., friends of the couple.

title: Andretti 15Second Victor In Formula 5000 Event
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 27Mario Andretti led from start to finish to post his second Formula 5000 victory of the season at Road America today before a crowd of 33,400.

title: Destiny Unmanifest
description: With a haste that is both unnecessary and ominous, the Congress is moving toward rubberstamp approval of a farreaching strategic commitment that Americans may come to regret. This is the covenant granting commonwealth statushence United States citizenship and sovereigntyfor the northern Mariana island chain the western Pacific.

title: Average Jersey Income Higher Than New York's
description: The annual income of the average New Jersey resident exceeds that of the average New York State resident and the gap is widening, according to new Federal Census estimates released yesterday.

title: Bruce Vinik Weds Miss Stephens
description: Carroll Uuderwood Stephens and Bruce Neal Vinik, who graduated this year from Duke University, were married yesterday afternoon in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School. The Rev. William Head, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: The vote by Representative Peter A. Peyser on the bill that would have permitted partial resumption of arms sales to Turkey was incorrectly given in The New York Times yesterday. Mr. Peyser voted no.

title: About New York
description: AMAGANSETT, L.I., July 27 Last yearor was it the year before?it was the string. This year, it might be said, it is the ing.

title: BEANIE TO UNIONS: TAKE PAY FREEZE OR GET IT BY FIAT
description: Mayor Beame issued a virtual ultimatum to the city's municipal labor unions yesterday, asserting that voluntary acceptance of a wage, freeze by midnight tomorrow was much preferable to an imposed one.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT NORTH SALEM, N. Y.

title: SOLO DANCES GIVEN BY KATHERINE LIEPE
description: The performances of Katherine Liepe's dances are far and away more interesting than the conceptions behind them. Miss Liepe has a pliant spine, good balance and a nice jump, all of which she displayed in her program of solo dances Saturday evening at the Terra Firma Studio.

title: Dividend Meetings
53,631 Watch Red Sox Sink Yankees, 10, 60
description: When the Yankees dropped far behind in the pennant race yesterday they didn't do it with a thud they crept away silently, as if they did not want anyone to see them depart.

title: Chief of Italy's Governing Party
description: ROME, July 27In electing Benigno Zaccagnini as their leader, the Christian Democrats of Italy have chosen one of the senior members of the governing party, a man who has come to symbolize unity in a faction ridden movement. Shy, unassuming and free of personal ambition, the 63yearold Dr. Zaccagnini (pronounced zaccanYEEnee) is regarded by party members as a moral reserve to be drawn on during the frequent bouts of infighting.

title: THAI SAYS ACCORDS WITH U.S. ARE VOIDED
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 27 (UPI)Premier Kukrit Pritmoj said today that military agreements with the United States were no longer valid and set next March 20 as a deadline for withdrawal of all American forces from Thailand.

title: Music: A Conductor to Take Seriously
description: LENOX, Mass., July 27This is the season here at Tanglewood for conductors who have taken French leave from the Communist orbit. Mstislav Rostropovich is much in evidence at this summer's Berkshire Music Festival, and another runaway, Klaus Tennstedt, conducted a Beethoven program this afternoon. Mr. Tennstedt, who was music director of the Dresden Opera at the age of 34 and one of the busier East German conductors, left for Sweden in 1971 and came to the Boston Symphony Orchestra last season for a twoweek engagement. He finished his twoweek Tanglewood stay with performances of the Beethoven Eighth and Sixth Symphonies that put one on notice that the 49yearold German is a conductor to take seriously. He knows his business.

title: Portugal's Socialists Call For Nondictatorial Rule
description: LISBON, July 27Portugal's Socialist party appealed today for the creation of a government of national salvation backed by a majority of the people to avoid the restoration of dictatorship.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: India's Iron Curtain
description: Backed by a servile Parliament in her seizure of sweeping emergency powers, India's Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has set about in earnest to erase the last vestiges of freedom in independent India.

title: Federal Aid and Tenant Gains Bring A New Era to Stella Wright Homes
description: NEWARKFor the first time since the tenants of the Stella Wright Homes ended their fouryear rent strike a year ago, residents of the seven 13story buildings in the Central Ward here can see the beginnings of a new era in the management of this troubled, lowinMime, public housing complex.

description: Morning

title: Mother and 4 Children Die
description: HARVEY, III., July 27 (AP)A mother and four young children died today when fire and smoke swept their wostory home in this Chicago suburb. The mother was Loretta Pearson, 25 years old. The children were Larry Jr., 6; Leonard, 5; Leandre, 4; and Latricia, 2.

title: CENSUS CITES RISE IN BLACKS' STATUS
description: WASHINGTON July 27 (AP) Blacks have made important gains in education and election to public office in the nineteenseventies, but, like whites, have experienced a substantial loss of income and jobs, a new Census Bureau report showed today.

title: Work on Genetic Manipulation Must Continue, Scientists Insist
description: Continued work on socalled genetic manipulation, and in microbiology generally, is of the utmost importance for progress in medicine and in public health, a committee of leading scientists has advised the director general of the World Health Organization.

title: MICHAEL SOSNOWSKY
description: Dr. Michael Sosnowsky, associate editor of Svoboda, Ukrainian daily newspaper of Jersey City, died Saturday of a heart attack at the Jersey City Medical Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Irvington, N.J.

title: Seattle Mayor Fights City Union Demands
description: SEATTLEHundreds of municipal employes here are in a state of open revolt against the city administration. Seattle, to a large extent, has become a microcosmand, to somei observers, a previewof a bitter new adversary relationship that is developing between public employes and elected officials in cities across the country.

title: First Hurricane of '75 Heads for Nova Scotia
description: MIAMI, July 27 (UPI)The first hurricane of the 1975 season headed into the North Atlantic shipping lanes east of the United States coast tonight and forecasters said it would pose a defnite threat to Nova Scotia on Monday.
