description: NEWARKFor the first time since the tenants of the Stella Wright Homes ended their fouryear rent strike a year ago, residents of the seven 13story buildings in the Central Ward here can see the beginnings of a new era in the management of this troubled, lowincome public housing complex.

title: BOGUS MONEY USE BY C.I.A. ALLEGED
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) A Senate investigating committee is looking into allegations that the Central Intelligerice Agency counterfeited American money during the Vietnam war to finance secret operations.

title: Personal Finance
description: A backyard barbecue is one of the delights of summer. It can also make a pleasant tax deduction, even if it's an occasion at which no business is discussed.

title: Deaths
Noisy Courtyard Mars Ford's Night in Castle
description: BONN, July 27 (AP)President Ford apparently did not get all the sleep he wanted his first night in Europe.

title: Soviet Expected to Push LongTerm Lab in Orbit
description: MOSCOW. July 27Although they have waxed lyrical about the success of the ApolloSoyuz mission, Soviet space officials here are as reluctant as ever to talk about what they plan for an encore.

title: Mets Win In 10th For Split
description: CHICAGO, July 27After submitting to Bill Madlock's two home runs in losing the first game, 42, today, the New York Mets had to go 10 innings to square matters with the Chicago Cubs, winning the second game of the doubleheader, 41.

title: Salute to Music That Crossed the Sea
description: NEWPORT, R.I, July 27Although the current Newport Music Festival is aimed at the American Bicentennial, that does not mean foreign composers are not represented. Last night's program at the Breakers was called American Exports, and the idea was to show the influence of our musicjazz, specifically  on Europeans. Naturally, Darius Milhaud's La Cration du Monde was represented. This 1923 ballet is de rigueur as an example of American jazz influence on French musical thinking. But even more interesting was a curiosity. from Germany, Der LindberghflugLindbergh's Flight, by Kurt Weill, to a text by Bertolt Brecht.

title: France, World's No. 3 Weapon Exporter, Finds Mideast Agents' Fee High
description: PARISA few days after the close of the Paris air show, staged at Le Bourget every two years, the French traditionally invite some very special guests, all with very military bearing, to the village of Satory near Versailles for an armaments sales fair

title: TOOL ORDERS TRAIL YEARAGO LEVEL
description: New orders for machine tools in June were more than 50 per cent lower than the yearearlier level, according to figures released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. However, for the fourth consecutive month they rose over the previous month.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: ??orses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: F.T.C. SEEKS FINES FOR CIGARETTE ADS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission has voted to seek civil penalties against six cigarette companies for alleged violations of an agreement requiring them to advertise the dangers of smoking, an F.T.C. commissioner says.

title: How the Layoffs Have Affected Some City Workers
description: Their names mean nothing to the average New Yorker, and little more to City Hall. But until recently, they were a part of the city's backbone work forcea policeman, a fireman, a laborer, a librarian, a cafeteria worker and two school aides.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS IN 55% PROFIT DROP
description: Texas Instruments Inc., reported yesterday that its secondquarter earnings were down 55 per cent from the 1974 period, while sales declined 18 per cent.

title: Panama Leader Says U.S. Politics Stalls Canal Talks
description: PANAMA, July 24The head of the Panamanian Government said today that he believed that the Ford Administration was stalling negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty because of political pressures in the United States.

title: CORRECTION
description: The vote by Representative Peter A. Peyser on the bill that ??ould have permitted partial resumption of arms sales In Turkey was incorrectly given in The New York Times yesterday. Mr. Peyser voted no.

title: DOUBLE RING A HIT AT SEATTLE OPERA
description: SEATTLE, July 27The first Pacific Northwest Festival with la double cycle of Richard Wagner's Der Ring des Nibelungen, sung in German and English, closed last night here, with a performance of Gtitterdmmerung in English, to enthusiastic audiences and generally favorable critical attention.

title: Davis Cup Results
description: EUROPEAN GROUP A FINAL Sweden 3, Spain 2 (Sweden next plays Chile in interzone final).

title: Ford Picnics With Troops and Fills Up on Cake
description: KIRCHGONS, West Germany, July 27The Commander in Chief dropped in on a picnic of 3,500 American soldiers and their families here this afternoon, and ate so much cake that he said he would have to swim it off.

title: As Races Lag, Baseball Looks Ahead
description: Mike Marshall, the Dodgers' practically imperishable relief pitcher who has independent views on physical training, interviews, working hours and signing autographs, also takes an independent view of baseball as entertainment. I don't know anything about ballet, he says, but I wish people would watch baseball the way ballet fans watch the dancenot to see who wins but to see how well each player performs his part. There are a few who do. Chances are most of us know somebody who hears and enjoys the music of baseball no matter which teams are playing and no matter who wins. Aficionados like that are a small minority in any ballpark, however, just as racing fans who view their sport more as an athletic contest than a game of chance are in the minority. In both cases this is largely because of the way the product is packaged.

title: U.S. Said to Begin Halting Operations At 4 Turkish Bases
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 27 (Reuters)American officials here said today that the United States had begun to suspend operations at four of its Turkish bases yesterday. They were listed as the installations at Golbasi near Ankara, Sinop on the Black Sea coast. Karamursel on the Sea of Marmara and Diyarbakir in the southeast.

title: Today's Entries at Saratoga
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: HENRY BERETTA, 85, WOOD CARVER, DIES
description: Henry Beretta, a wood carver and sculptor for more than 70 years, died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 85 years old, and lived at 431 East 20th Street.

title: Miss Tennant Dances Stately Aurora
description: Veronica Tennant of the National Ballet of Canada has a quiet center to her dancing that goes admirably with her accomplished technique. Her true ballerina manner makes her the least schoolgirlish of the company's principals in the classics.

title: Books of The Times
description: Still questing after that elusive novel for a lazy summer weekend, I thought to put my faith in the public's judgment and read The Moneychangers, Arthur Hailey's latest tour through American commerce and industry, which has been No. 1 on the bestseller lists these last two months or so. After all, just because a novel is first on the bestseller list doesn't necessarily tell you what it is. For every badbad book there, like a Love Story or a Jacqueline Susann, you're just as likely to see a goodbad book like The Godfather or Watership Down. Come to think of it, I can't name a No. 1 bestselling novel of the last few decades that hasn't had something extraordinary to rec ommend it (unless it was William Brinckley's Don't Go Near the Water, which I simply never got around to reading), though the Lord knows simply to be extraordinary is by no means necessarily a virtue. So I waded into The Moneychangers confident at least of being diverted. And I wasn't entirely mistaken. To be sure, it would be easy enough to ridicule Mr. Hailey's skills as a novelist. Early in the story he introduces a character, Juanita Nunez, whom he describes simply as looking Puerto Rican (like Jose Ferrer, does he mean? Or like Roberto Clemente?). This Mrs. Nunez is a teller in a bank, one of whose executive vice presidents finds his memories of his father and the bank's dying president to be strangely intertwined (this is Mr. Hailey's way of establishing that the bank president, Ben Rosselli, is a fatherfigure).

title: DressedUp Vans Are a New Way of Life
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky., July 27Vantasy, Vantastic, Moby Van, Chiquita Vanana and Van on the Run were all here this weekend.

title: Solomon, Vilas in Net Final
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  Topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina outdueled Mexico's Raul Ramirez, 63, 64, and the defending titleholder, Harold Solomon, defeated Cliff Richey, 75, 60, today, to repeat as finalists in the $100,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PAIR OF ACES Larry Adler and Teddy Wilson are back, and their fans undoubtedly consider it about time. Mr. Adler, considered by many the outstanding harmonica virtuoso of his time, begins his first American cabaret engagement in 13 years tonight at 8 in the Rainbow Grill atop Rockefeller Center with a varied solo program of popular and classical music. Thereafter the harmonica virtuoso who has been living in England since the midnineteenfifties. will be appearing twice a night, at 9:15 and 11:30, except Sundays.

title: Varda Katz Is a Bride
description: Congregation Adas Israel Synagogue Center in Passaic, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Varda Roni Katz, daughter of Rabbi Leon Katz, spiritual leader of the congregation, and Mrs. Katz of Clifton, N. J., to Zeev Nistar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Nistar of Rishon LeZion, Israel. The bride's father performed the ceremony. Mr. Nistar's father is an accounting manager for the Histadrut Organization in Israel.

title: Radio
Olympic Games On for Youths in City
description: Thirteen  year  old Leslie Pooser and her brother, Daryle, 12, said they could be spending their summer afternoons hanging out in the streets. looking for something to get into.

title: Advertising
description: Land deals, fraud scheme, land fraud swindle, zoning scandal and builders and ecologists clashthese are some of the phrases that have appeared in headlines on stories having to do with Florida land development. Not exactly the words that build consumer confidence.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JULY 28, 1975

title: People
description: Robert P. Wilson has been elected senior vice presidentmarketing for Schick, Inc.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: When we stated recently that one reader had problems in finding sources for fresh shallotsa highly sophisticated member of the onion family and one of the basics for fine French cookerynumerous readers replied with their own private sources. And one reader, Mary O'Connell of North Brunswick, N. J., wrote to tell us of a mail order source.

title: Argentines Get the News, Though It's Mostly Bad
description: Argentines Get the News, Though It's Mostly Bad

title: Criminal Behavior
description: Crime is of personal concern to most urban Americans, particularly those who live in heavily populated states. It is also an emotional political issue that is often oversimplified by public officials for political purposes.

title: In Which Reasons for the State of Emergency Are Explained and Defended
description: WASHINGTONThe recent events in India, a culmination of a conflict between forces of change and forces of status quo that has been shaping up for a long time, have been misreported and misunderstood in the West partly because the revolutionit is no lessis so immediate that its implications and possible success or failure are not clearly assessed.

title: 2 Killed at Spa
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 27 (UPI)Wim Boshuis, a Dutch driver, and a track marshal died last night in two mishaps at the controversial 24hour Francorchamps road race for sedans, which ended today. Boshuis was killed after his Commodore, apparently malfunctioning, rammed into three other cars on the Ardennes circuit, known as the Spa.

title: Cleveland Municipal Strike Ending With Tentative Pact
description: CLEVELAND, July 27 (UPI) Cleveland municipal workers accepted today a tentative contract agreement to end a sevenday strike against the city.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Representative James Florio, Democrat of Somerdale, opened a disaster damage reporting center in Glassboro to gather information on Gloucester County flood damage for the Federal Government. Mr. Florio said the center would gather data to determine if the county was eligible for Federal aid. Last week, President Ford declared 12 New Jersey counties disaster areas, but omitted Gloucester, which, Mr. Florio said, suffered more damage than some of the counties on the list.

title: Seattle Mayor Fights City Union Demands
description: SEATTLEHundreds of municipal employes here are in a state of open revolt against the city administration. Seattle, to a large extent, has become a microcosmand, to some observers, a previewof a bitter new adversary relationship that is developing between public employes and elected officials in cities across the country.

title: Auto Racer Injured
description: WINCHESTER, Ind., July 27 (AP)George Snider, who finished eighth in this year's Indianapolis 500, was seriously injured today in a United States Auto Club sprint car race at Winchester Speedway. Snider, the top USAC sprint driver going into the race, was unable to avoid a spinning car and flipped over the other racer, over the retaining wall and down a 45foot embankment.

title: CONGRESS BACKING SEEN FOR OIL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Democratic leaders indicated today that some form of President Ford's compromise plan for gradual decontrol of oil prices would probably win Congressional approval this week.

title: Heroin Seized in Diapers
description: BOSTON, July 27 (AP)A man and woman were arrested on drug charges following a raid on a Dorchester apartment yesterday in which heroin was found concealed in an infant's diaperso the police reported. They said the youngster's mother, 23yearold Joyce Anderson, and Jeffrey Sapp, 41, were charged with possession of heroin with intention to distribute.

title: As recessionary woes mount, thousands of marriages have been threatened; many have cracked and some have been shattered.
description: Maureen and Kevin seemed in some ways to be one of those golden couples who are imagined by some Easterners to populate Southern Californiahe a computer salesman with the lanky good looks of a Notre Dame end, she a secretary, petite and easygoing; the two of them, husband and wife in their middle thirties, sharing and indulging a taste for their fancy apartment, beautiful clothes, swinging parties and high living in general.

title: PreOlympic Effort Called Good, Bad
description: MONTREAL, July 27Canada seems ready and willing to meet its commitment for next summer's Olympic Games. But the nation has yet to convince everyone at the moment that she will be able to leave the starting blocks without wobbling.

title: A Chronicle of the Crucial Dates in the City's Financial Crisis
description: For a year the city has been buffeted by financial crises. The successive attempts to deal with massive budget deficits and cash flow problems that threatened insolvency have led to layoffs that often were more apparent than real and were always confusing; to mostly unsuccessful pleas to the Federal and state governments for aid, always hampered by costly political maneuvering, and to repeated and unavailing efforts to shed New York's national image of fiscal profligacy.

title: 45% SAID TO FEAR THEIR AREA IN CITIES
description: In American cities with at least 500,000 population, 45 per cent of the people are afraid to walk in their neighborhoods at night, according to the latest Gallup poll. Seventyseven per cent of the women In those areas fear for their safety on the streets at night, the survey found.

title: Levitt Says Penn Central Falsifies OnTime Record
description: Can a Penn Central commuter train due in Grand Central at 8:50 A.M. approach the terminal at 8:58 and still pull into the station on time within the fiveminute grace period for ontime performance?

title: Ransom of Students Put at $40,000
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 27 (AP)About $40,000 was paid to win the release of two American students and a Dutch woman who were held in a jungle camp in Zaire by African guerrillas, wellinformed sources said yesterday.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Saturday evening's performance of the revival of Death of a Salesman at Broadway's Circle in the Square Theater was canceled because of the illness of George C. Scott, director and star of the Arthur Miller drama, and James Farentino, one of the play's principal actors.

title: FORD AND SCHMIDT URGE COOPERATION IN ECONOMIC PLANS
description: BONN, July 27President Ford and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany agreed here today that it was vitally important that the United States intensify efforts to coordinate economic policy with Western Europe.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
Soviet Grain Buying on '72 Level Is Seen
description: Americans got a clear view of crop conditions in the Soviet Union last Monday when television showed the Russian space capsule landing in a great cloud of dust in what was called a typical wheat field. To watchful commodity men, that indicated a severe drought.

title: 2 Times Correspondents in India Sign Statement on Responsibility in Reports
description: NEW DELHI, July 27The two American correspondents in India of The New York Times, after extensive consultations with Indian officials, today signed a statement acknowledging full responsibility for their reports from here in regard to the Indian Government's rules for censorship.

title: A Rare Walk in the Sun, and for Two Days in a Row
description: All around the city this weekend, New Yorkers who had become accustomed to carrying umbrellas, just in case, did not have to be told how to take advantage of two sunny days in a row.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Film

title: U.N. and Israel: FullScale Ouster Drive May Come in 1976
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27Twentysix years ago, the General Assembly voted to admit Israel as the 59th member of the United Nations, and the six Arab delegations then in the organization walked out of the meeting hall in protest.

title: Know Not, Harm Not
description: LONDON, July 27The late Richard Crossman was a British politician, a generally leftwing member of the Labor party, who differed from almost everyone else in this country's political life in a respect more fundamental than his view of particular issues. He did not care what the makers of established opinion thought about him. He did not play the game of approval. He was prepared to be thought a nuisance, even cad.

title: GUS CAMPISE
description: Gus Campise, a longtime tennis official and tournament player, died Saturday of a heart attack while playing in the national claycourt championships for men 35 years and older at the Shelter Rock Club in Manhasset, L.I. He was 58 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Venezuelan Mines Minister Expects OPEC Price Rise
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 27 (UPI)Mines Minister Valentin Hernandez said yesterday that oil prices would definitely increase as of Oct. 1, but not by the 30 percent predicted by some oil specialists.

title: Celebrities Serve 1,000 At Montauk Benefit Party
description: MONTAUK, L. I., July 27Someone mistook Carl Stokes for a bartender at a party here last night, but the former Mayor of Cleveland didn't mind because he was, in fact, serving as a bartender for the occasion.

title: MRS. EDWARD TYLER
description: Florence Locks Tyler, widow of the Rev. Edward E. Tyler, presiding elder of the Philadelphia Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church and former pastor of the Bridge Street, A.M.E. Church in Brooklyn and the Allen A.M.E. Church in Jamaica, Queens, died Friday in the Parkview Nursing Home in Riverdale, the Bronx. She was 85 years old.

title: In Wheat Belt: Protein Dispute
description: BIG SANDY, Mont. Americans may well sing of amber waves of grain as the nation winds up a historic harvest of 1.7 billion bushels of winter wheat this month.

title: Fair Recalls Hoboken's Past of Busy Days on River
description: HOBOKEN, July 27Hundreds of residents of this milesquare city this weekend rediscovered the winding Hudson River front, with its incredible panorama of Manhattan, at a fair sponsored by the city's federally financed Community Development Agency.

title: Levitt Says Penn Central Falsifies OnTime Record
description: Can a Penn Central commuter train due in Grand Central at 8:50 A.M. approach the terminal at 8:58 and still pull into the station on timewithin the fiveminute grace period for ontime performance?

title: New Mexico Chief Turns Taskmaster
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 25State government in the Land of Enchantment, as New Mexico calls itself, has always been looked upon as something of a casual enterprise.

title: Burns Captures Scandinavian Golf
description: MALMOE, Sweden, July 27 (AP)George Burns 3d, who recently became a pro, beat Graham Marsh of Australia in a suddendeath playoff today to win the $75,000 Scandinavian open golf championship.

title: HARLEM BASKETBALL
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Nerf Rucker Pros 141 Milbank 138. Mr. B's 152, N.J. Junction Lounge 146.

title: UrbanLeague Head Asks U.S. to Grant Total Amnesty to Veterans of Vietnam
description: ATLANTA, July 27Vernon E. Jordan Jr. executive director of the National Urban League and a member of the Presidential clemency board, broke with the Ford Administration today and urged total amnesty for Vietnam veterans.

title: TransMississippi Golf Won by Wilson
description: KANSAS CITY, July 27 (AP)Tim Wilson, after trailing most of the match, shot a par4 on the 34th hole to beat his University of Texas teammate. Warren Aune, bylup today and take the 73d TransMississippi golf tournament.

title: Dance: Bruhn Sylphide
description: 'Tis the season for male dancers; they come out at this time of year like moths at a midsummer bonfire. On Saturday night, while Rudolf Nureyev held court at the Metropolitan Opera House, on the other side of the plaza, with American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Erik Bruhn (to say nothing of Gelsey Kirkland, who is certainly not male but has never been any the worse for that) were dancing in Mr. Bruhn's production of La Sylphide.

title: Strongman's Departure Opens an Odd Interlude in Which Press Is Free and Comics Have a Field Day
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 27The recent departure of Jos Lpez Rega, the former rightwing strongman of the Argentine Government, has opened a strange interlude in which the press, television and other news media are employing more freedom of expression than at anytime before in two years of Peronist rule.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four men, denied entrance to the Cork and Bottle Restaurant, a night club at 130 East 52d Street, because of their dress, opened fire at 1:25 A.M. and were arrested after one of them was shot in the chest by an offduty Federal agent. The wounded young man, George Pena, who escaped in a cab, was arrested when he applied for treatment at New York Hospital. The police said that they recovered a handgun and a sawedoff shotgun. A woman with the four men escaped.

title: H.E.W. Reported to Have Run LSD Tests on 2,500 People
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare administered the drug LSD to about 2,500 prisoners, mental patients and paid volunteers from 1954 to 1968 to determine whether it had any medical value, according to Government sources.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JULY 28, 1975

title: Ohio Mayor and Councilmen Recalled Over Earnings Tax
description: BELLBROOK, Ohio, July 27 (AP)  Voters have recalled their mayor and five of six councilmen in a battle over a village earnings tax.

title: Cairo Prods Moscow on Debt Dispute By Hampering Naval and Air Activities
description: PARIS, July 27For the first time, Egypt has been using leverage on Soviet naval and air activities to win financial concessions from Moscow.

title: RATES SURPRISE WALL STREETERS
description: The stock market has taken a drubbing lately. Economists still debate the speed and strength of the economic upturn. Consumers are edgy. Against this mixture of uncertainty and hope, one thing is clear: Interest rates are moving up in the credit markets. This rising trend in rates, moreover, has caught many Wall Street analysts by surprise, although few of them are taking out advertising space to announe the fact.

title: World Team Tennis
Unaccompanied Children Pose a Refugee Problem
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 27Officials dealing with the resettlement of 130,000 Vietnamese and Cambodians have discovered in refugee camps more than 300 children who arrived in this country unaccompanied by their parents.

title: Howard Bicycle Victor
description: MILWAUKEE, July 27 (AP) John Howard of Houston won his fourth national road bicycle championship today in a 123mile race. His time was 5 hours 5 minutes 27 seconds.

title: U.S. AND BAHAMAS SET LOBSTER TALKS
description: MIAMI, July 27  Negotiations between the United States and the Bahamas over licensing of American vessels to fish lobsters in the Bahamas Banks are expected to begin within two weeks, according to United States officials.

title: Rowdies Storming N.A.S.L.
description: The Tampa Bay Rowdies won their sixth game in a row Saturday to become the first team in the North American Soccer League to clinch at least a tie for a divisional title. Boston, Portland and St. Louis also triumphed and are the strongest candidates for honors in the other three divisions.

title: U.S. Men Victors In Swim
description: CALI, Colombia, July 27 (AP)American men led the way in swimming and women from East Germany and Australia picked up gold medals in freestyle races on the last day of competition in the second world aquatic championships.

title: Pledge Is Given That Canada Won't Cut NaturalGas Flow to U.S. This Winter
description: OTTAWA, July 28The top energy administrators of Canada and the United States gave a joint assurance today that a proposed cutback in the supply of Canadian natural gas to American consumers would not be applied this winter.

title: Trenton Building Owners Win UrbanRenewal Suit
description: TRENTON, July 28 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court to day extended the protections for property owners whose land and facilities fell in the way of urbanrenewal projects.

title: Intestinal Disorders Fell 70 Campers
description: TRENTON, July 28More than 70 campers and counselors from Camp Dark Waters, a Quakeroperated camp in Burlington County, were hospitalized last night because of suspected food poisoning.

title: Greek Church Plans To Break With Vatican
description: ATHENS, July 28 (Reuters) The primate of Greece said today that the Greek Orthodox Church had decided to break all contacts with the Vatican because of a quarrel over an Orthodox sect that recognizes the supremacy of the Pope.

title: A Fatigued Mrs. Ford Cancels Engagements
description: WARSAW, July 28 (UPI) A fatigued Betty Ford cancelled all her social engagements today and retired to guest quarters here.

title: Schlesinger's Problem
description: WASHINGTON, July 28For the first time since becoming Secretary of Defense two years ago, James R. Schlesinger faces some hard choices on the military budget that will test his control over the military establishmeet. For the last two years, Mr. Schlesinger, an academic product of military think tanks, has reigned somewhat like a philosopher king over that establishment. Probably not since Thomas S. Gates in the final days of the Eisenhower Administration has a Secretary of Defense established such a harmonious rapport with the joint chiefs of staff as has Mr. Schlesinger.

title: U.S. Puts Cost of Conrail at $2.5Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 28A Government agency said today its final plan for reorganizing the bankrupt Northeastern railroads would require $2.5billion in Federal funds and be conditioned on Congressional approval of regulatory reform.

title: Susan's Girl First In the Matchmaker
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 28Those who have money make money could well have been the theme of today's closing scene at the seaside track as Fred W. Hooper's slightly favored Susan's Girl sped to an easy victory in the Matchmaker Stakes, the I 3/16mile contest technically valued at $150,000.

title: President of Portugal Delays Helsinki Trip 2 Days
description: LISBON, July 28Portugal's President has put off for 48 hours his departure for the European security conference in Helsinki, Finland, apparently because of the continuing political crisis.

title: Supervisors Set Hearing Date For New Nassau Government
description: MINEOLA, July 28  The Nassau County Board of Supervisors approved Aug. 11 as the date for a public hearing on three plans for a new form of county government, two of which have already been defeated by the voters.

title: Nastase in Close Battle
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky,, July 28 (UPI)Ilie Nastase kept his temper in check today and struggled to a 64, 57, 63 victory over Sweden's Kjell Johansson in the opening round of the $100,000 Louisville tennis tournament. The Rumanian was bothered by an erratic serve.

title: 600 Suggestions Offered For Improving L.I. Sound
description: NORWALK. Conn., July 28The Long Island Sound Regional Study made public its final report here today, making more than 600 recommendations that ranged in scope from the construction of a fishing pier under the Throgs Neck Bridge in the Bronx to the reorganization of petroleum traffic in the Sound to reduce the danger of oil spills.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC REVENUES INCREASE
description: Revenues of the American Electric Power Company, the nation's largest electric utility holding company, rose to $358.4million in the 1975 second quarter, from $296.4million in the same period in 1974, the company reported yesterday.

title: Guinan Calls for Policemen On Daytime Subways, Too
description: Matthew Guinan, international president of the Transport Workers Union, called for putting policemen on subway trains both day and night, starting from about 7 A.M. He said that many people won't ride even in the daytime because they're being molested. At present transit police are assigned to ride trains between 8 P.M. and 4 A.M.

title: Youngstown Also Off
description: The National Steel Corporation reported yesterday a drop of 72.3 per cent in secondquarter earnings, as sales and operating revenues fell by 22.7 per cent.

title: Vilas Downs Solomon in Net Final
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas played Harold Solomon's game and beat the little Marylander, 61, 63, in the final of the $100,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament tonight. Last year Solomon beat the Argentine southpaw in the final.

title: Italy's Trade Deficit Rises
description: ROME, July 28 (Reuters)Italy's foreign trade deficit increased In June to $321million from $211million in May, according to provisional figure released by the Central Statistics Institute here today. But the deficit was still less than half the June, 1974, figure of $937million.

title: Grand Jury Criticizes Exotic Wagering
description: ALBANY, July 28 (UPI)  A Sullivan County grand jury says regulations at harness tracks in the state are inadequate to prevent tampering with exotic forms betting, according to a report released today. The report, released by the state's Organized Crime Task Force on the orders of Judge Benjamin Newberg, said stricter regulations must be imposed if exotic wagering is to continue. The panel also asked for a legislative investigation or a probe by the Governor's office into potential corruption at harness tracks.

title: Article 3  No Title
Weinberger Acts to Cut Cost of Drug Purchases
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, has given final approval to a program designed to save Federal and state governments $60million to $75million a year in drug purchases.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of pest positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Monday.

title: LEFTISTS SUBDUED IN AN INDIAN STATE
description: TRIVANDRUM, India, July 25 Both critics and supporters of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's new authoritarian methods of rule agree that the Government Is in firm control of Kerala, a crowded, highly politicized state of more than 20 million people, at the southernmost tip of the Indian subcontinent.

title: ROBERT RUMPF
description: Robert Rumpf, who retired in 1940 as manager of the Paris branch of the National City Bank, now the First National City Bank, died Sunday at his home in Bantam, Conn. He was 83 years old.

title: Chart of the Matchmaker Stakes
Need for Quick Action Unites M.A.C. Board
description: The ninemember board of directors of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, after an initial split over how much time should be accorded Mayor Beanie to begin reforms and economies, has now united around the concept of immediate and drastic action to salvage the city's fiscal credibility. Although key, members of the board confer frequently with Governor Carey, and the Governor intervened at one critical juncture last weekto name a new chairman, William Ellinghausthe Governor is not calling the shots, board members insist.

title: Kent General Doubted Peril to Guard
description: CLEVELAND, July 28Brig. Gen. Robert H. Canterbury, now retired, who was the topranking officer of the National Guard on the Kent (Ohio) State University campus in 1970, testified today that at the time the guardsmen opened fire a group of students were within one to two seconds of closing in on the troops on the right flank but that he did not consider the guardsmen to be surrounded at that precise moment, that instant.

title: BAR PANEL SCORES A CAMPAIGN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The American Bar Association has been urged by one of its committees to go on record against any legal limits on the amount that can be spent in a campaign by a political candidate or by citizens and independent committees that support him.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Disheartening Response to Money Crisis Leadership Need

title: 14 MORE FOOD PLACES CITED AS VIOLATORS
description: The Health Department has announced the names of 14 more food establishments cited for violations of the city's Health Code. These places had failed to correct violations found by inspectors on the initial inspection when they were inspected for a second time a month later.

title: Notes on People
description: President Ford announced yesterday his choice of Robert O. Aders, a Washington lawyer and former grocerychain executive in the Middle West, to be Under Secretary of Labor. He would succeed Richard Schubert, who resigned.

title: Books of The Times
description: SAM RAYBURN. By Alfred Steinberg. Illustrated, 391 pages. Hawthorn Books. $15.

title: Town Loses a Bid for Aid In a Compensation Case
description: TRENTON, July 28 (AP)The State Supreme Court ruled today that Howell Township could not depend on a special state fund to help pay compensation to the township's former plumbing inspector, who suffered a disabling heart attack in 1968.

title: Advertising
description: Jack Trout, president, and Al Ries, chairman, of Ries Cappiello Colwell have been talking at a great rate in recent years about positioning. The word has become one of the more popular buzz words of the seventies in the advertising business.

title: Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: American League

title: Marriages
description: CROWLEYCHEATHAM

title: Kampala Puts On a Festive Facade for Big Meeting
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 28A young West African delegate to the Foreign Ministers Conference of the Organization of African Unity rushed one recent evening to the International Hotel where he planned a night of dancing.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Phils Top Pirates 8th Time in Row, 52
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who have won the Eastern Division race in the National League four of the last six years, haven't got the 1975 flag clinched yet.

title: LOUIS KIRSCHNER
description: Louis Kirschner, New York disbursing officer for the Philadelphia Disbursing Center of the Treasury Department, died Sunday of a heart attack on vacation in Las Vegas. He was 51 years old and lived at 22030 75th Avenue, Bayside, Queens.

title: People in Sports
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy has a secret, but it has nothing to do with politics. The Massachusetts Democrat was in New York for a news conference yesterday announcing the fourth annual Robert F. Kennedy procelebrity tennis tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, on Aug. 23. When asked who his playing partner would be, the Senator refused to comment.

title: In the Hot Store League
description: President Ford's top two campaign officials were recently described in this space as Howard (Bo) Callaway, a millionaire Georgia segregationist, and David Packard, a millionaire mogul of the militaryindustrial complex. Several readers have taken objection to these forthright words, a fact which puts their author in mind of a classic Lincoln story.

title: Old Masters Grace Soviet Display in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  Man must hammer or anvil be was one of Goethe's more pregnant sayings: and by now it may well have a redoubled meaning for those Soviet negotiators who have found themselves across the table from Dr. Armand Hammer. the man who drove a hard bargain with Lenin himself is not likely to flinch from Lenin's successors. Nor is there any sign in the choice of Master Paintings from the Hermitage and the State Russian Museum, which opens to the public on Wednesday at the National Gallery of Art, that Dr. Hammer's abilities have weakened with age.

title: INDIA CUTS A.P. LINE AND BUREAU PHONE
description: The Associated Press reported from New Delhi yesterday that the Indian Government had cut its news circuit to London and disconnected its bureau telephone because of what India charged were violations of selfcensorship rules in three dispatches by the news agency.

title: Banker Appointed Head Of Y.M.C.A. Fund Drive
description: Edward L. Palmer, chairman of the executive committee of the First National City Bank, was named yesterday to head a $1.25  million fund  raising campaign for the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court in Trenton extended the protections for property owners whose land and facilities fell in the way of urbanrenewal projects. In a 60 ruling, the court said when urbanrenewal plans carried the threat of condemnation of property in a manner that reduced values owners could consider that their land had been taken. The court acted in a suit against the city Trenton by Washington Market Enterprises Inc., an office building that had faced a major falloff in business since the area it is in was designated for urban renewal 12 years ago.

title: TRANSIT RISE SEEN BY JERSEY AGENCY
description: TRENTON, July 28  The state Commuter Operating Agency declared a formal end to New Jersey's masstransit crisis today but forecast acrosstheboard increases in bus and frail fares and service cutbacks during the year ahead.

title: U.S. Acts on Speed Limit
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  Dr. James Gregory, the administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said today that the Transportation Department would soon require every state to certify that it was enforcing the 55milesanhour speed limit. Any state that fails to do so is prohibited from receiving approval for the federally aided highway projects.

title: Pennsy Seeking Funds For Repair Purposes
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 28, (UPI)  The Penn Central railroad asked a Federal Judge today to approve an agreement under which it would receive $56million in Federal funds for equipment repair work for a period ending next March 31.

title: Serving Civil Service
description: In response to demands made under the Freedom of Information Act, both the Commerce Department and the Environmental Protection Agency have in effect admitted that they engaged in the ageold political practice of undercutting the civil service system.

title: 46 Horses Die in Fire Laid to Arson
description: HARRISBURG. Pa., July 28 (AP)Arson caused a fire that destroyed 46 thoroughbred race horses at the Penn National Race Course, 18 miles east of here, a state police official said today.

title: BILLPAYING SERVICE FROM SAVINGS IS SET
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) Banks may offer a billpaying service from customer savings accounts, effective Sept. 2, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Polish Crowds Hail Ford; Military Detente Stressed
description: WARSAW, July 28  Huge crowds of Poles greeted President Ford today as he proclaimed Long live Poland! in their native tongue on a visit reaffirming a United StatesPolish commitment to pursue militarynot merely politicaldtente in Europe.

title: Resistance to Bonds Is Held Ironic
description: There is an irony to the current investor resistance to bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. When the Municipal Assistance Corporation legislation was being drafted two months ago, some legislators complained that the bonds were being made so secure as to be a virtual giveaway to the investment community, which these legislators felt had not been willing enough to help New York City on its own.

title: Reluctant Governor
description: Governor Carey's reluctance to become immersed in New York City's deepening fiscal crisis is understandable, but unrealistic and potentially damaging to the city, the state and the Governor's own political ambitions.

title: Sanitation Layoffs Hurt Both Collections and Morale
description: There are indications that the solutions for the garbage pileup produced by last week's layoff of 1,434 sanitationmen are not working.

title: Dollar and Gold Advance
description: BRUSSELS. July 28 (UPI)Aided by favorable United States trade figures, the dollar reached eightmonth highs today in Frankfurt and Amsterdam and improved against all other European currencies.

title: A Death at Willowbrook Is Studied as Suspicious
description: The body of a 9yearold boy who was a resident at the Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island was exhumed yesterday for an autopsy as a result of allegations that he had been beaten before his death last Tuesday evening.

title: Injured Pincay Absent
description: Handicappers who play Jockeys rather than horses can forget about getting well with Laffit Pincay during the Saratoga meeting. He won't be around, at least not on horseback.

title: Is There Anywhere to Go?
description: PARIS IN 1932, when I had just turned 19 and was finishing my junior year at the University of Pennsylvania, the provost of the college informed my father (among others) that I was a dangerous Communist. True, I had wet my feet in that pond two years before, partly out of a singular distaste for certain uppermiddleclass notions and knaveries and an infinite frightened outrage at the sudden sight of widespread poverty and despair, but at least as much out of fleshy lusts and a naive trust in all the myths about debauchery on that rockbound shore.

title: Canada to Supply Gas
description: A cutback this winter in the supply of Canadian gas to American consumers has been ruled out. The cut is not expected to come before next year. Page 35.

title: CYPRIOTE IS KILLED IN A FIRING INCIDENT
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 28 (UPI)  Turkish troops opened up with automatic weapons fire along the ceasefire line in Nicosia today, killing a Greek Cypriote in the first outbreak of fatal violence on Cyprus in nearly four months, a GreekCypioate Government communiqu said.

title: China Sends Troops To Troubled Plants In Major Coast City
description: HONG KONG, July 28More than 10,000 Chinese troops have been sent into factories in the city of Hangchow to help with production and three key officials there have been replaced because of continued factional strife and labor unrest, broadcasts from the central coastal city indicate.

title: Dow Stock Index Drops By 6.26 as Trading Slows
description: Stocks moved lower in moderate trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, extending last week's pattern, which saw prices erode under pressure of disappointing earnings reports and doubts over whether shortterm interest rates had leveled off.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Like Thomas Nast's cartoon, Who Stole the People's Money?, the municipal labor unions point to the banks and the banks point to the unions as the chief culprits in the city's financial crisis.

title: Turks Assert Some Bases Will Stay Closed for Good
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 28Some American bases in Turkey will remain closed even if Congress ultimately lifts the embargo on arms shipments, according to senior Turkish officials.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION RESUMES DECLINE
description: Steel production for the week ended July 26 returned to its downward trend after a oneweek increase, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: DR. ARTHUR DALY, 77, AIDED BLACK CAUSES
description: Dr. Arthur George Daly, a black physician who was a leader in fighting discrimination in his profession, died Saturday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: TRANSIT RISE SEEN BY JERSEY AGENCY
description: TRENTON, July 28 The State Commuter Operating Agency declared a formal end to New Jersey's masstransit crisis today but forecast across the board increases in bus and rail fares and service cutbacks during the year ahead.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Congress Extends Lowe rim port Tariff To Rumanian Goods
description: WASHINGTON July 28 (AP)  Congress today approved President Ford's plan for ending a discriminatory tariff on imports from Rumania.

title: Philharmonic Opening 11th Parks' Tour
description: The best things in life are free, they've been singing since 1927. Something new was added to that list in 1965, when the New York Philharmonic took to the city's parks for a series of free concerts. Now an established feature of summer life, this season begins tonight in Central Park.

title: Lobster Unlimited
description: BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 28Mouths watering for lobster, we came to Maine. Got any lobster? we asked the man at the pound. He said one thing he sure had was lobster. He picked two lobsters from a tank and held them out. They seemed much too small to make a meal for two people who had their mouths set for a real lobster dinner.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He thought he had done enough. In the offseason Gabe Paul got Catfish Hunter in an auction and Bobby Bonds in a trade.

title: China Sends Troops To Troubled Plants In Major Coast City
description: HONG KONG, July 28More than 10,000 Chinese troops have been sent into factories in the city of Hangchow to help with production and three key officials there have been replaced because of continued factional strife and labor unrest, broadcasts from the central coastal city indicate.

title: Apollo Trouble Traced
description: Failure to throw two switches in the final minutes of the Apollo mission led to poison gas streaming into the craft, space officials said. Page 56.

title: BID TO SELL ARMS TO JORDAN PUT OFF BY WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Ford Administration today suspended plans to sell 14 Hawk antiaircraft missile batteries to Jordan because of overwhelming Congressional opposition to the transaction.

title: City's Crisis Finds Banks At Center of Controversy
description: New York City's major banks, which have been deeply in volved in the events leading up to the city's worsening financial crisis and in subsequent rescue attempts, today find themselves at the center of a controversy over both their activities and their motives.

title: 2 Pittsburgh Papers Print After a OneMonth Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, July 28 (UPI) The city's two newspapers resumed publication today after a onemonth strike by teamsters deliverymen.

title: PAPER RETRACTS VIETNAM REPORT
description: The Los Angeles Times has said it erred in publishing an article reporting that the United States conducted heavy bombing raids in South Vietnam on the day of the American evacuation from Saigon. The report was denied by the White House before publication.

title: ECONOMIC SURVEY CITES BLACK LOSS
description: ATLANTA, July 28In its annual economic survey, the National Urban League reported that blackfamily economic status continued to deteriorate last year.

title: Justice Quashes 2YearOld Indictment, Decrying Secret Infiltration by Police
description: Art Acting Supreme Court justice yesterday denounced a special Police Department intelligence unit for mounting what he said was a broad and penetrating secret infiltration that violated the constitutional liberties of the people of the Lower East Side for over two years.

title: To Open Show, a Discreet Gala
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Last winter, it was the collection of art and artifacts known loosely as that fabulous Chinese show. This summer of dtente, the big event of the cultural season is a group of paintings that, until now, one would have had to make the trip to Leningrad to see.

title: Strength in Flexibility
description: Secretary of the Treasury Simon has firmly and, we believe, rightly rejected the efforts of President Giscard d'Estaing of France to move the world monetary system from floating exchange rates back to fixed currency values. Floating rates have been a tremendously important factor in the past two years in absorbing a series of shocks to the world economy that could have been devastating.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters)Net savings inflows at Federally insured savings and loan associations were $3.1million in June, the Federal Home Loan Bank ward said today.

title: Illegal Laetrile
description: Under present law, every new drug is born guilty until and unless proved innocent; that is, it must be proved to be both efficacious and safe before it may legally be put on sale in interstate commerce. A controversy over the use of laetrile has revived questions about the validity of national drug policy.

title: EXWALL ST. EDITOR ENTERS GUILTY PLEA
description: William Eric Aiken, former editor of Value Line Selection and Opinion, a weekly publication, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of accepting a $15,000 bribe to tout a stock, United Press International reports.

title: Levine Plans Changes at Met Opera
description: James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera's principal conductor and musicdirectorelect, says his goal is to generate an excitement in the opera house that will develop a certain rapport, a certain trust with the audience.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
Committee Begins Inquiry on Charge Of Bias by State Offices on Farm Jobs
description: HAMMONTON, July 28A court  created committee arrived in New Jersey today for a threeday study of whether federally funded State Labor Department employment offices were serving farm workers fairly.

title: Ford's Expected Tax Plans Criticized by Two Experts
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Changes in the tax laws that the Ford Administration is believed to be considering, with the objective of increasing the amount of money available for investment in new business facilities, may have the opposite result, according to two tax experts.

title: Democrats' Telethon Profit May Be Under $1Million
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Democratic National Committee will probably realize a net profit of less than $1million from the 21hour telethon party leaders conducted on Saturday and Sunday.

title: State Modifies Orders For Schools in 2 Cities
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist yesterday issued two modified integration plans for Newburgh and Mount Vernon, neither of them to be fully effective until September, 1976, at the earliest.

title: Trial of Former Junta Opens in Greece
description: ATHENS, July 28Twenty leaders of the Greek military coup of 1967 were put on trial today for high treason and revolt.

title: Retail Jewelry Sales Rebound Sharply
description: After a spring slump, retail jewelry sales have risen sharply this summer, but this category of merchandise remains highly sensitive to the latest economic news, retailers reported here yesterday at a trade show.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times on Saturday on the election of a new chairman of the board of governors of the City Center of Music and Drama contained several errors. A corrective article will be found on Page 19.

title: NEUROSURGEONS ASK INSURANCEFEE CURB
description: TRENTON, July 28 (UPI)Neurosurgeons in New Jersey asked the state Insurance Department today to deny an increase in malpractice premiums for members of their medical specialty.

title: ALABAMA OPENING INQUIRY ON PRISONS
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 28Federal District Judge W. Brevard Hand will open hearings tomorrow in Mobile on whether overcrowding, inadequate care and exposure to physical violence in the Alabama prison system deprive inmates of their constitutional rights.

title: INCREASE SHOWN IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Productivity, or output ?? hour worked, rose modera??ly in the second quarter after four quarters of decline or no improvement, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Poison Gas at End of Flight by Apollo Is Laid to Failure to Throw Switches
description: HONOLULU, July 28 (AP)Failure to throw two switches in the final minutes of their mission set off a sequence that resulted in poison gas streaming into the spacecraft of the three Apollo astronauts, space officials said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JULY 29, 1975

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times on Saturday on the election of a new chairman of the board of governors of the City Center of Music and Drama contained several errors. A corrective article will be found on Page 19.

title: Bergenfield Workers Fight; Ruling Jeopardizing Raises
description: Sergenfield policemen and publicworks employes have opened an appeal against a Superior Court ruling that could result in a referendum on an 8.5 per cent pay increase negotiated with borough officials earlier this year.

title: Francis E. Rivers Dies; Black City Judge Was 82
description: Judge Francis E. Rivers, the first black judge on the City Court, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 82, years old and lived at 170 West End Avenue.

title: Ford Renews Plea
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)President Ford today renewed his plea to the House of Representatives to reconsider its vote last week denying renewed military aid to Turkey.

title: 18NATION GROUPING ON TRADE PROPOSED
description: WASHINGTON. July 28 (AP) The Atlantic Council proposed today the formation of an organization of 18 industrialized nations to help liberalize world trade and offset the barriers to trade increasingly adopted in recent years by developing, nations.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DISTANT DELVING The public is invited to a twoday program of documentary films on Rumania, folk music and lectures on East European liberalism today and tomorrow at the City University Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. The free event is sponsored by the Center for European Studies at the Graduate Center and by the Rumanian Library. It takes place in Room 207 of the center.

title: $18.60 Nijana Scores as Saratoga Opens
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 28The blue bumper stickers around town used the word exciting, and the red French version put it, Saratoga est passionnant.

title: June Trade Surplus Set Record As Recession Cut Imports of Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The nation's foreign trade recorded its biggest surplus on record in June as imports continued to reflect the deep recession in the United States economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Statement by Ford and Gierek Seeks to Spur TroopCut Parley
description: PARIS, July 28After President Ford arrived in Warsaw today on his way to the ceremonial concluding session of the European Security Conference in Helsinki, he and the Polish leader, Edward Gierek, called attention to a conference, little heard of these days.

title: States Across India Begin Endorsing Emergency Laws
description: NEW DELHI, July 28State legislatures across India began meeting today to give support to the sweeping emergency laws enacted over the last month by the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Torture of Dissidents Laid To Uruguay by Amnesty Unit
description: LONDON, July 28 (Reuters)  The Londonbased humanrights organization Amnesty International accused the Uruguayan Government today of systematic arrest and torture of dissidents.

title: EDWARD SMITH, 55, OF BOOK CONCERN
description: Edward W. Smith until recently senior vice president and editorial director of the American nook Company, lied yesterday of cancer at his home, 33 Charles Street. He was 55 years old.

title: HARRY M. WILLIAMS Sr.
description: Harry M. Williams Sr., owner of H. M. Williams Company, Inc., of Baldwin, L. I., automobile dealer, who founded the concern in New York in 1937, died Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N. Y. He also lived in Southampton, L. I.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Pottery from the island of Rhodes is the raison d'etre for Aegean Arts, the shop Theodore Mastromichalis and his American wife, Carol, opened recently at 239 East 53d Street. They also carry such things as embroidered shirts and blouses of cotton or polyester, macrame shoulder bags and handwoven woolen wall hangings and pillows. But the ceramics take pride of place.

title: Hendricks, Free Agent, to Pick Among Giants, 2 Others Today
description: Ted Hendricks, one of pro football's top linebackers, will make a decision today on whether to play for the Oakland Raiders, New York Giants or Atlanta Falcons.

title: Transit Fare Dilemma
description: Mayor Beanie's request for a transit fare increase is the inevitable result of the failure of the city, and the state, to come to grips adequately with the problem of a soaring transit deficit.

title: Debt Market Calm; Note Sale Is Awaited
description: Activity in the markets for fixedinterest securities was at a minimum yesterday as the trade awaited the sale of the $3billion part of the Treasury's $5.8billion refunding issues today. Where prices were changed, they tended to be off a shade. The Treasury debt market was, naturally, marking time as it waited on the auction results of the $3billion of 33month notes, which are expected after the close today. Wednesday, $2billion of sevenyear notes will be auctioned and Thursday's sale of $800million of 25year bonds should complete the latest offering.

title: Ethiopian Soldiers and Rebels Reported to Be Fighting Again
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 28 (UPI)Heavy fighting has reportedly broken out again between Ethiopian Government troops and Eritrean rebels, and Asmara, the provincial capital, is said to be in a virtual state of siege.

title: 3 BOARDS REPLACE CITY CENTER GROUP
description: Parts of two key sentences were transposed in an article in The New York Times on Saturday on the election of John S. Samuels 3d as chairman of the board of governors of the City Center of Music and Drama.

title: Congress Passes 7Year Extension Of Voting Right Act
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The House of Representatives passed today and sent to President Ford a bill extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for seven years and broadening its protection to Spanishspeaking Americans and other language minorities.

title: Prosecution Opens Case In Trial of San Quentin 6
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 28The prosecution opened its case today in the trial of the San Quentin Six, five inmates, and a parolee who are accused of having participated in an escape attempt at San Quentin Prison nearly four years ago that resulted in the death of George Jackson, the black revolutionary writer, three guards, and two inmate trustees. Three other guards were seriously wounded in the incident.

title: CITY COLLEGE ADDING THEATER ARTS UNIT
description: The Board of Higher Education yesterday approved a theater arts department at City College designed to give a foundation to the Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts and consolidate the college's other performingarts programs.

title: Man Admits Guilt in Death Of Jersey Coed at Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 28 (UPI)Saying he was tired of waiting for all the court action to end, John E. Harris. in a surprise move, changed his plea today and told Judge Ormand Gale of the Onondaga County Court that he was guilty of the 1972 murder of Karen Levy, a Syracuse University student from Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Chess
description: The 1975 United States womens championship held July 13 to 27 at the Plankinton House in Milwaukee was the 21st event in the series. Under the auspices of the International Chess Federation, the tournament also doubles as a zonal competition, the first stage of qualification for the women's championship. The top two prize winners go on to the women's interzonal tournament.

title: Hearings in Major Case Affecting British Press Near an End
description: LONDON, July 28  In the hot, musty Law Courts near the Thames, the first serious stage in a case whose outcome could profoundly influence relationships between the press and the Government here is nearing an end.

title: Bridge:
description: The Swiss team championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association, played during the weekend at Temple Israel, 112 West 75th Street, was won by four young experts, two of whom have established national reputations and two of whom are likely to acquire them.

title: European Hornets Make Presence Felt Stingingly Upstate
description: ITHACA, N.Y. A European yellowjacket that thrives in garbage cans has been discovered in large numbers in upstate New York, according to two entomologists at the New York State College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell.

title: PROFITS PLUMMET 49.2% AT GULF OIL
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, the nation's fifth largest oil company and seventh largest industrial corporation, yesterday reported a 49.2 per cent drop in its earnings for the second quarter of 1975.

title: 100 Whites Attack 6 Blacks On Beach in South Boston
description: BOSTON, July 28 (AP) About 100 whites attacked six black traveling salesmen yesterday on Carson Beach in South Boston, injuring one of the men, the police said.

title: SENATE APPROVES INDIAN OCEAN BASE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Senate gave its approval today to construction of a naval base on the island of Diego Garcia that the Defense Department contends is necessary to maintain a military balance in the Indian Ocean.

title: Honduras Eyes Banana Takeover
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, 25In apparent response to the United Brands Company's recent admission that it bribed a high Honduran official last year, a Honduran Government commission has now recommended the partial nationalization of the country's banana industry.

title: WALTER J. COULTER
description: Walter J. Coulter, a press man with The New York Times 47 years until his retirement in 1960, died Sunday in Terrace Heights Hospital, Hollis, Queens. He was 79 years old and lived at 9447 239th Street, Bellerose.

title: ISRAELI SAYS TERMS ON SINAI ARE FINAL
description: TEL AVIV, July 28 (Reuters)  Defense Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel's latest proposals passed to Egypt by way of Washington for an interim agreement in Sinai were final.

title: Money
Nuclear Power Development Encounters Rising Resistance With Curbs Sought in a Number of States
description: Sentiment for restricting nuclear power development or subjecting it to tightened controls has manifested itself in at least a score of states this year.

title: Millan Gets 4 as Club Continues July Slugging
description: ST. LOUIS, July 28The batters were ahead of the pitchers tonight at Busch Stadium. With a twoteam total of 33 hits bouncing all over the AstroTurf, the New York Mets used their 17 more effectively to post an 117 triumph over the Cardinals in the opener of the fourgame series.

title: Iran Increases Dollar Rate
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 28 (Reuters)  The Central Bank raised its official rate of the dollar by 0.48 rials. The new rates for buyers are 67.25 rials per dollar and sellers 67.50 rials. The Central Bank raised the dollar rate by 0.25 rials last week.

title: Focus of Slaying Trial Had Humble Origins
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 28Until she stabbed her white jailer to death with an icepick because of a sexual abuse she says he forced upon her, almost nobody knew her nameincluding, as one not unsympathatic quip in the Wake County Courthouse has it, Joan Little.

title: Suit Is Lost by Sanitationmen; Court Upholds City on Layoffs
description: A State Supreme Court justice upheld yesterday the right of New York City to discharge sanitationmen to cope with its financial crisis.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Facing overwhelming opposition in Congress, the Ford Administration yesterday suspended plans to sell 14 batteries of Hawk antiaircraft missiles to Jordan. Congress has opposed the sale on the ground that the 14 batterieswith six missile launchers to a batterygave Jordan an offensive capacity against Israel and was more than she needed for her air defense. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Market Place
description: The New York State Attorney General's office is pressing an advantage won earlier this year in court against Concord Fabrics, Inc., by warning companies seeking to go private, or eliminate public shareholders, that they like Concordcould be enjoined from doing so.

title: SILVER FUTURES IN MAXIMUM RISE
description: Speculative enthusiasm, partly inspired by soaring grain prices and partly by renewed fears of inflation led to maximum allowable price rises for silver futures on the Commodity Exchange here.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF 8TH STRAIGHT DAY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday for the eighth successive session, with the Amex index declining by 0.80 to 90.34.

title: Old Masters Grace Soviet Display in Capital
description: WASHINGTON. July 28  Man must hammer or anvil be was one of Goethe's more pregnant sayings; and by now it may well have a redoubled meaning for those Soviet negotiators who have found themselves across the table from Dr. Armand Hammer. The man who drove a hard bargain with Lenin himself is not likely to flinch from Lenin's successors. Nor is there any sign in the choice of Master Paintings from the Hermitage and the State Russian Museum, which opens to the public on Wednesday at the National Gallery of Art, that Dr. Hammer's abilities have weakened with age.

title: NBC NEWS SEEKS NIXON INTERVIEW
description: NBC News is actively pursuing an opportunity to purchase a series of interviews with former President Richard M. Nixon that would be based on his written memoirs when they are completed more than a year from now, Richard C. Wald, president of the news division, said yesterday.

title: Tigers Win on SixHitter by Ruhle, 30
description: The Yankees continued to be futile at runmaking last night at Shea Stadium as Vern Ruhle and the Detroit Tigers shut them out, 30, As in each of their previous two shutouts against Boston Red Sox Sunday, the Yankees amassed six hits.

title: Joan Little Jury Is Told Of Finding of Dead Jailer
description: RALEIGH, N. C, July 28Two Washington, N. C., policemen described the discovery of the body of the slain Beaufort County night jailer, Clarence Alligood, last Aug. 27 as testimony began today in the murder trial of Joan Little.

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: U.S. Confirms Compliance
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The State Department said today that the United States had ceased military activity at all of its bases in Turkey in compliance with the Turkish government's demand.

title: Ways to Enjoy Shoreline of the Bronx
Recluta, Class A Yacht, Takes Run to Vineyard
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 28The New York Yacht Club squadron rolled into this pleasant port on Martha's Vineyard today after a fast run from Padanaram over in Buzzards Bay. It was a niece of cake. The wind was right, a steady southwest breeze of 20 knots which moved the 82 racing vessels right along, through Quicks Hole from Buzzards Bay into Vineyard Sound and then east to Cape Pogue and Edgartown where the fleet will stay until Wednesday.

title: Muskie May Grant Request
description: WASHINGTON July 28Senator Edmund S. Muskie, chairman of the Senate Public Works Subcommittee on Environmental Pollution, said today that he would be inclined to grant President Ford's request to reopen hearings on auto emissions, although he found no substantive justification for the request.

title: Commission Sets Aside MedicalExaminer Test
description: The city's Civil Service Commission yesterday set aside a test given this year for Chief Medical Examiner, declaring that some of the candidates had had a competitive advantage.

title: Goodyear Moves Tires From Y.&R'o Campbell
description: After a 31year relationship, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is moving the advertising responsibility for its auto tires out of Young & Rubicam and into CampbellEwald, which became a Goodyear agency last December. The ad budget has been put in the neighborhood of $12million.

title: LEFKOWITZ FINDS CITY HAS POWER TO FREE WAGES
description: The city, through its homerule and police powers, has ample authority to impose a wage freeze, according to a legal opinion drawn up by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office.

title: Vote in Senate Is Blocked On New Hampshire Election
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The dispute over last November's Senate election in New Hampshire boiled up in the Senate again today, but Democratic leaders were able to prevent a vote.

title: Humphrey's Stock as '76 Choice Rises Among Numerous Political Observers
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, who chipped $40,000 off his old Presidential campaign debt with a party at the New York home of Mary Lasker, the philanthropist, last week, looks like the best bet for the 1976 Democratic nomination to an intriguing variety of political professionals.

title: LEFKOWITZ FINDS CITY HAS POWER TO FREEZE WAGES
description: The city, through its homerule and police powers, has ample authority to impose a wage freeze, according to a legal opinion drawn up by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office.

title: Davis Cup Results
description: EUROPEAN ZONE ?? FINAL

title: Wood, Firld & Stream
description: Deeptrolling anglers are doing well with the big rainbow trout of New York States Lake George. The rainbows are running 12 to 20 inches, and an occasional landlocked salmon is also being caught. Going deep for trout with wire or lead core line lacks the excitement and pleasure of surface fishing, but there are times when it is the only technique that will succeed with any consistency.

title: Scientists Say Oxygen Variant Helped Form Earth and Planets
description: From variations in the nature of oxygen found in the earth, moon and a wide range of meteorites, scientists at the University of Chicago have concluded that these objects were not, as long assumed, formed from the same mix of primordial elements.

title: DONALD M. MATTISON
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) Donald M. Mattison, dean emeritus of Indiana University's Herron School of Art, died today at Methodist Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Amin New Head of African Organization
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 28 President Idi Amin of Uganda became chairman of the 46nation Organization of African Unity tonight.

title: Army Halts Chemical Tests on Humans
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Army suspended today its experiments on human subjects with chemical compoundssome of Which can cause hallucinationsin order to determine all the facts connected with the test programs, a spokesman said.

title: Canada to Supply Gas
description: A cutback this winter in the supply of Canadian gas to American consumers has been ruled out. The cut is not expected to come before next year. Page 35.

title: Ouster of Postal Aide For C.I.A. Ties Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)The chairman of a House subcommittee urged the United States Postal Service today to dismiss its chief postal inspector, William J. Cotter, for allegedly helping the Central Intelligence Agency get access to thousands of pieces of mail for perusal.

title: Today's Entries at Monmouth
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listings.

title: QUAKERS WILL DEFY CURB ON VIETNAM AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)  Leaders of the national Quaker organization said today that they would defy the Treasury Department and ship, $325,000 in aid, including fishing nets and hospital repair tools, to North and South Vietnam.

title: Grain Licenses Reinstated
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) Federal warehouse licenses for two Bunge Corporation grain elevators in Louisiana and Texas, ordered suspended last Friday in connection with a grand jury indictment, have been reinstated, Agricultural officials said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
GROUND COFFEES UP BY 20C A POUND
description: The General Foods Corporation raised yesterday the wholesale price of ground coffees by 120 cents a pound, and by cents an ounce its instant and freezedried brands of ooffee. The increases, which are effective immediately, will affect retail prices of Maxwell House, Sanka, Brim, Yuban, MaxPax and Maxim brands. In Lake Success, L.I., Albert Ehlers, Inc., announced a 10cent acrosstheboard increase in its coffee prices.

title: Miss Rich Is College Harness Victor
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 28Virginia Rich, a 22yearold senior in sociology at Rosary Hill College, came from off the pace with Adios Art to defeat three rivals in the first National Collegiate harness driving championship tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Card of Thanks
description: SALIMBENEJoseph D. The officers, members and stall of the Building Concrete Excavating end Common Laborers Union Local No. 731 wish to express their sincerest appreciation to all of the associates and good friends of nor late Business Ma?? Brother Joseph D. Salimbene. SALVATORE DAMIANO, Secy, Treas Local Union No. 731

title: TALKS PROGRESS IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: Negotiators were reported yesterday to have narrowed the differences between building contractors and four unions whose month old strike has impeded completion of many construction projects in the city.

title: Ford Visit Fails to Assure Bonn on Economic Policy
description: BONN, July 28After President Ford's meeting ??ere with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, the West German Government is still worried that conservative economic policies in Washington may kill a worldwide economic recovery before it really gets started, according to a West German official.

title: Soldiers to Be Exchanged
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 28 (Reuters)  About 150 Canadian and 150 Australian soldiers will train in each other's countries for six weeks in September and October i?? the first of what is planned as an annual exchange, the Aus??alian Defense Minister an ??ounced today.

title: Apollo Trouble Traced
description: Failure to throw two switches in the final minutes of the Apollo mission led to poison gas streaming into the craft, space officials said. Page 56.

title: Grace Fertilizer Unit Set
description: W. R. Grace & Co. announced yesterday it would open this fall a $2.5million fertilizer distribution terminal at Greenville, Ohio, to serve dealers in the nearby territory and to customblend fertilizers.

title: Weekend Fight
description: LOS ANGELESDanny Lopez, Arcadia, Calif., 126 pounds, knocked out Rauol Cruz, Mexico, 6 rounds.

title: LAYOFF SUIT LOST BY SANITATIONMEN
description: A State Supreme Count justice upheld yesterday the right of New York City to discharge sanitationmen to cope with its financial crisis.

title: Radio
New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarity, the reputed numbers czar of Hudson County, was ordered yesterday to serve a 2tothreeyear term on an August, 1973, conviction for possession of lottery slips and conspiracy to violate the gambling law. Judge Samuel A. Lamer in Superior Court in Jersey City rejected a plea for leniency.

title: White House Asks Delay of 5 Years On Auto Exhausts
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The White House formally asked Congress today to delay for five years the strict new auto exhaust standards that fare due to go into effect with the 1977 models.

title: OILTAKEOVER BILL GAINS IN VENEZUELA
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 28A bill that would nationalize almost a score of foreign oil companies operating in Venezuela was approved tonight on the second and final discussion by the lower house of the Venezuelan Congress.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Senators Show Little Friction In Their Orderly C.I.A. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The issues are spying, burglary, shootings and even murdersissues guaranteed to be politically inflammatory.

title: Aug. 22 Is Crucial Date In City's Fiscal Crisis
description: Aug. 22 will be a crucial date in the city's budget crisis, with an estimated total of $806.7million coming due that day and the city either paying up or heading into default.

title: Monmouth Awaits Better Days Ahead
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 28 The crowd of 14,919 today at the thoroughbred race track operating closest to New York City was under the figure of 16,403 posted here last year on the day the Saratoga season opened. But Harvey Wardell, secretary and general manager of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, was far from disappointed.

title: Article 1  No Title
Mets' Records
GeorgiaPacific Directors Vote For Taking Over Exchange Oil
description: Directors of the GeorgiaPacific Corporation voted yesterday in Portland, Ore., to proceed with an offer to merge the Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation of New Orleans into GeorgiaPacific. GeorgiaPacific said that a satisfactory report verifying Exchange Oil's reserves of oil and gas had been received.
