The directors proposed, subject to approval of the shareholders of both companies, to exchange one share of GeorgiaPacific common stock for each 3.4 shares of Exchange Oil common outstanding. On the basis o yesterday's closing price of GeorgiaPacific, 40 on the New York Stock Exchange, the value of the transaction is estimated at more than 862.5million.

title: Today's Entries at Saratoga
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: June Unemployment Rose to 11.7% Here, Highest Since '73
description: Unemployment in New York City rose in June over May by nearly 1 percentage point to 11.7 per cent, the highest level since the recession began in 1973.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Television
Turks Assert Some Bases Will Stay Closed for Good
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 28Some American bases in Turkey will remain closed even if Congress ultimately lifts the embargo on arms shipments, according to senior Turkish officials.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Like Thomas Nast's cartoon, Who Stole the People's Money?, the municipal labor unions point to the banks and the banks point to the unions as the chief culprits in the city's financial crisis.

title: It's an Old Bank That 4 Families Now Call Home
description: JERSEY CITYYou can't miss our place, Arthur Goldberg said the other day. Just head west on Exchange Place, make a left at Montgomery and we're the second tank on the left.

title: A FundRaising Group Formed to Aid Byrne
description: TRENTON, July 28 (UPI)A fundraising organization was formed today to promote the political future of Governor Byrne.

title: Stock Payout Planned
description: The American Express Company reported record earnings in the second quarter and first half this year, with gains of 3.3 and 2.9 per cent, respectively.

title: President's Gun Control Bill Introduced by Senator Fong
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii, has introduced the Ford Administration's gun control bill that went without a sponsor for most of last week.

title: Playboy Mansion Set For Closing on Sept. 1
description: CHICAGO, July 28 (Reuters)Hugh Hefner's Playboy boy Mansion on the wealthy Near North Side of Chicago, scene of hundreds of political and showbusiness parties, will be closed on Sept. 1 and out up for sale.

title: Deficit Far Above Target Feared by Simon and Lynn
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Ford Administration, reporting a record peacetime budget deficit in the fiscal year just ended, warned today that Congress was in the process of producing a deficit in the current year well above the President's target of $60billion.

title: Dock Contract Ratified
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (AP)  The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union announced today ratification of a three year contract raising straighttime pay for 12,000 dock workers by $2.15 an hour by 1977. The current hourly rate is $6.22.

title: Jury Weighing Fate of Gurney In Bribery and Conspiracy Case
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 28A jury of six men and six women began deliberation on a verdict today at the trial in United Stares District Court of former Senator Edward J. Gurney and three codefendants.

title: M.T.A. Still Considering Size of Fare Increases
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority still plans to decide this week on the size of proposed subway and bus fare increases and to review the fares of commuter railroads, a spokesman for the agency reiterated last night.

title: Blacks Bar Rhodesia Talks
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, July 28Rhodesian nationalists have vetoed any further talks with Premier Ian D. Smith in Salisbury and will agree to meet him only at a constitutional conference outside Rhodesia the African nationalist leader Bishop Abel Muzorewa, said here today.

title: BID TO SELL ARMS TO JORDAN PUT OFF BY WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The Ford Administration today suspended plans to sell 14 Hawk antiaircraft missile batteries to Jordan because of overwhelming Congressional opposition to the transaction.

title: L.I. INQUIRY OPEN IN WOMAN'S DEATH
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 28The Nassau County District Attorney's Office started to present testimony today before a grand jury investigating the death of Sophie Friedgood, the wife of a physician, who died on Jane 18.

title: 70 Campers Are Felled By Intestinal Disorder
description: TRENTON, July 28More than 70 campers and counselors from Camp Dark Waters, a Quakeroperated camp in Burlington County, were hospitalized last night because of suspected food poisoning.

title: MORE WOMEN DIE OF BREAST CANCER
description: GENEVA, July 28Despite the efforts being made at early detection of breast cancer to extirpate the disease through surgery, statistics show that more women than ever are dying from it, according to a study by the World Health Organization.

title: Syracuse Man Says ExWife Is Worldwide Drug Trafficker
description: A Syracuse businessman testified yesterday that his former wife, an international model, was a worldwide narcotics trafficker with ties to a French financier who gave $2million to Richard M. Nixon's 1968 Presidential campaign.

title: They Came Seeking Inspiration And Discovered It in Dior '75
description: PARIS, July 28The couturiers here carry on as if no one ever told them they were irrelevant. Indeed, you'd never guess it from the hassle for seats and the expectant air of the viewers waiting for revelation.

title: Dreams and Nightmares
description: As if to prove that his Washington sobriquet, Cap the Knife, was well earned, retiring Health, Education and Welfare Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger delivered a stinging indictment of Federal domestic programs in his valedictory delivered to the Commonwealth Club of San Francisco last week. He spoke of his fear that an allpervasive Federal Government is leading the nation toward bankruptcy and egalitarian tyranny. He also indicated that he thinks that far too much of the nation's wealth is being spent to maintain and improve the quality of American life and that too little is apt to be left for the expansion of capital investment required to strengthen the economy and produce opportunity in the way he deems most desirable.

title: City's Crisis Finds Banks At Center of Controversy
description: New York City's major banks, which have been deeply in volved in the events leading pup to the city's worsening financial crisis and in subsequent rescue attempts, today find themselves at the center of a controversy over both their activities and their motives.

title: Polish Crowds Hail Ford; Military Detente Stressed
description: WARSAW, July 28 Huge crowds of Poles greeted President Ford today as he proclaimed Long live Poland! in their native tongue on a visit reaffirming a United StatesPolish commitment to pursue militarynot merely politicaldtente in Europe.

title: Minnesota Coach Moves to A.B.A.
description: Bill Musselman left the University of Minnesota yesterday without an official goodby to become coach of The San Diego team in the American Basketball Association.

title: Offer by Ford to Abolish 60Cent Oil Fee Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Administration officials were reliably reported today to have told members of Congress that President Ford would abolish the fee of 60 cents a barrel that he put on imported fuel oil if Congress let his latest oilpricing plan take effect.

title: People and Business
description: Grain sales to the Soviet Union may be a boon to farmers but a financial headache for dairymen who blame them for raising feed grain prices. This was a main part of widely differing views on effects of the recent large exports expressed yesterday by the head of a dairymen's group, a Department of Agriculture official and a Florida Senator.

title: F.C.C. Hearings Planned On Washington Star Bid
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission decided today to hold formal hearings on a bid by Joe L. Allbritton, publisher oof The Washington Star, to save the moneylosing newspaper by buying its profitable associated radio and television stations.

title: Marathon Oil Arranges $300Million Financing
description: The Marathon Oil Company said yesterday it had arranged a $300million financing plan with a group of 16 banks headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Henry L. Heguy, 59, Dies; Seaboard Airlines Officer
description: Henry L. Heguy, vice president for system operations of Seaboard World Airlines, died Sunday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 59 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Congress Passes 7 Year Extension Of Voting Right Act
description: WASHINGTON, July 28The House of Representatives passed today and sent to President Ford a bill extending the Voting Rights Act of 1985 for seven years and broadening its protection to Spanishspeaking Americans and other language minorities.

title: In Memoriam
description: FROMKESCharles, July 29, 1968. Dear Pop, miss you. Love Steven.

title: MAN SLAYS WIFE; TAKES OWN LIFE
description: A 39yearold Manhattan insurance underwriter early yesterday, stabbed his wife to death, critically stabbed his 5yearold son, threw his 4year old son to his death and then jumped to his own death from the family's sixthfloor Inwood apartment, according to the police.

title: Acrimony of All Kinds Marks the Talks
description: The city labor negotiations this week have been charactized by acrimonious exchanges between the unions and the city and Municipal Assistance Corporation, and among the labor leaders themselves.

title: City's Congressmen Unable to Obtain Help From Washington in Fiscal Crisis
description: Frustration at its inability to win Federal help for its financially pressed city is permeating New York City's big, but politically toothless, delegation in Congress.

title: The Document: Broth From 35 Cooks
description: GENEVA. July 29As the European security conference was in its neardawn final hour last Monday, after a series of long sessions, a weary American delegate shuffled out of the stuffy meeting room, slumped into an easy chair and said, It makes pretty awful reading.

title: Virginia Prison Strike Ends
description: GOOCHLAND, Va., July 29 (AP)  A sitdown strike by about 40 prisoners at the James River Correctional Center protesting the death of an inmate ended peacefully today after corrections officials promised that a committee would look into the matter.

title: Bridge :
description: In the early thirties, black bridge players formed their own national organization, because many clubs and associations were closed to them. Those days are happily long past, but the American Bridge Association continues to flourish alongside the American Contract Bridge League. The two organizations maintain a cordial relationship, and there is considerable overlap in membership.

title: JOAN LITTLE LOSES DEFENSE LAWYER
description: RALEIGH, N.C., July 29The medical examiner of Beaufort County testified in the murder trial of Joan Little today that examination of the body of Clarance Alligood clearly indicated sexual climav just prior [to], or at the time of death.

title: Hendricks To Pick His Club Today
description: The Stork is expected to arrive at one of three National Football League training camps today.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 700,000 common shares of the MidContinent Telephone Corporation, at $12.875 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith and the Ohio Company. The company has said net proceeds would be used to repay outstanding shortterm debt.

title: Open Interest
description: In Contract (Monday)

title: Frederique Petrides Conducts Orchestral Concerts in the Park
description: In all the talk about woman conductors, it is sometimes overlooked that Frederique Petrides has been living and working here since she founded the Orchestrette Classique in 1933. Nowadays her appearances are usually with the West Side Orchestral Concerts, a series of four outdoor programs in Riverside Park at 103d Street. The third of them was givdn on Monday night, performed by a large string ensemble.

title: Suffolk District Attorney And Police Chief in Truce
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 29The Suffolk District Attorney and the county's Police Commissioner today called a truce in their feud stemming from the prosecutor's announcement three weeks ago that he was investigating the Commissioner on charges of corruption, misconduct in office and other, more serious crimes.

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Mrs. Ford, Rested, Continues Trip
description: CRACOW, Poland, July 29 (UPI)  Betty Ford went sightseeing in Poland's cultural capital today, looking rested after a day in which she had canceled most of her engagements.

title: Nassau Police Win 12.3% Raise, Making Them Best Paid in U. S.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 29An arbitration panel today awarded the Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association a 12.3 per cent increase in a wage and fringebenefit package, which makes the police officers here the highest paid in the nation, according to the association's president.

title: 63 Seized by Police
description: DETROIT, July 29According to Police Chief Philip A. Tannian, 63 persons were arrested last night on charges of breaking and entering and malicious destruction of property after the fatal shooting of Obie Wynn, an 18yearold black youth.

title: ThailandCambodia Relations Growing Warmer
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 29  Thailand's relations with Cambodia appear to be warming substantially as her relations with her other Communist neighbors, Vietnam and Laos, are chilling.

title: Music: Fry's Challenge
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 29Apparently William Henry Fry experienced difficulties back in the eighteenfifties when he tried to get performances of his Stabat Mater. Fry, the contentious composercritic, was out to show the world that an American could meet the European romantics not only on their terms but also one better. He undoubtedly threw the challenge right in the direction of Hector Berlioz. Fry's Stabat Mater is scored for, among other things, 8 piccolos, 8 flutes, 8 French horns, 24 saxhorns, 24 kettledrums. 100 violas, 100 cellos and 100 bass violins.

title: Beirut Reports Israeli Raid. Tel Aviv Issues a Denial
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 (AP)The Lebanese Defense Ministry said an Israeli ground force raided a southern village early today and was driven back by artillery.

title: $400Million Menace
description: The Army Corps of Engineers has jumped the gun on the Delaware River Basin Commission, which we trust will now take a final and definitive stand against the proposed Tocks Island Dam. If, however, the commission approves this long and bitterly opposed boondoggle, a high official of the Corps has announced, he will urge immediate constructionthis on his own dubious inference from a milliondollar study authorized by Congress, that the benefits of damming up the beautiful and freeflowing Delaware would outweigh the harm it would do.

title: School Integration Goal Seen as Failing
description: ATLANTA, July 29A Michigan educator told delegates to the 65th convention of the National Urban League today that the goal of integrated education was failing fast under competing social forces.

title: Crewman Is Killed In a 2Train Crash Under East River
description: An empty Penn Central commuter train bound for Pennsylvania Station rammed into the rear of another empty train in an East River tunnel yesterday afternoon, killing one crewman and injuring another.

title: Dividends Announced
Food Cost Reaches New High
description: The cost of the 38item market basket of foods commonly bought by New York City families rose 0.4 per cent last week to a record level of $67.59, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday. The increase amounted to 28 cents on the week.

title: GARBAGE PILEUPS ANGER RESIDENTS
description: As residents of neighborhoods in all five boroughs of the city said yesterday that they believed the garbage buildup was getting worse, the Sanitation Department conceded that sharply reduced collection schedules were still unmet and that street cleaning had been cut in half.

title: Roosevelt Results
Rockefeller Agrees To Testify Aug. 28 On Nursing Homes
description: Vice President Rockefeller will appear Aug. 28 at a public hearing of the Moreland Act Commission investigating nursing homes in New York to answer questions about the use of his office while he was Governor on behalf of Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome entrepreneur.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JULY 30, 1975

title: Nigeria at a Glance
description: Nigeria, one of the world's most important producers oil, is about twice the size of California and, with 79 million people, is black Africa's most populous country.

title: Highlights of the Plans
description: A wage freeze canceling the 6 per cent increase clue city workers on July 1, saving an estimated $259million.

title: ARCO PROFIT OFF 49.6% IN QUARTER
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company reported yesterday profit drops of 49.6 per cent for the second quarter and 38.4 per cent for the half year. The Cities Service Company also reported declines of 49.8 per cent in secondquarter earnings and 55.1 per cent for the initial six months.

title: Hanoi Asks Nonaligned Entry
description: ALGIERS, July 29 (Reuters) North Vietnam has officially applied for admission to the nonaligned countries' grouping, informed sources said here today. In a message to President Houari Boumediene of Algeria, president of the fourth conference of nonaligned countries, North Vietnamese said it wanted to strengthen ties with nonaligned nations.

title: Servicemen Have Been Warned
description: Servicemen Have Been Warned

title: $94Million to Asian Bank
description: MANILA, July 29  Eleven nations, including the United States, have contributed $94million to the Asian Development Bank for longterm loans to agriculture, power and industrial projects in the poorest countries of the region, the bank said today.

title: Weinberger Moves to End Ban On Research Involving Fetuses
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Casper W. Weinberger, Secretary, of Health, Education and Welfare, acted today to lift the 13monthold Congressional moratorium on medical research involving human fetuses, wellplaced sources said.

title: Black Vice President Sought
description: ATLANTA, July 29 (UPI) The Southern Christian Leadership Conference will start a concerted effort to have a black as a vicepresidential candidate [next year, the conference president the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy, said yesterday.

title: Her Dishes: Expert; Her Teachers: Cookbooks
description: Perhaps it is a sign of senility setting in, but we have spent a lot of time recently ruminating on the phenomenal changes on the American food scene in the last 20 years.

title: Layoffs at Harvester Co.
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 29 (UPI)The International Harvester Company has laid off 168 workers here for the rest of this week because of a credit problem with a customer. A company spokesman said that Iran had ordered large trucks but that its letter of credit covering the purchases had not arrived.

title: Today's Entries at Saratoga
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing

title: Canada Sets Reductions On Some Oil Export Taxes
description: OTTAWA, July 28 (AP)The Canadian Government announced today it would reduce export taxes Aug. 1 on certain petroleum products and place its first exoprt tax on processed oils sometime early in the month.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in The New York Times last Saturday stated incorrectly that the Consolidated Edison Company was dropping plans to build a nuclear plant. The utility in question was the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, which had planned a nuclear plant in Somerset.

title: Garden Sues on Reed Pact
description: Madison Square Garden has filed an $863,415plusinterest suit against Lloyds of London for the Knicks' failure to collect the insurance on the knee injury that prematurely ended Willis Reed's playing career last September. The suit was filed in Federal District Court here. Mike Burke, the Knick president said, They refuse to pay and we're suing.

title: What Is Carey's Real Role in the Crisis?
description: Ever the master of repartee, Governor Carey has taken to using one graceful phrase after another to turn aside questions about his involvement with New York City's endless fiscal agony. New York is a creature of the state, but should not become a ward of the state, he said in Albany the, other day, where he was asked for the hundredth time whether there was more the state might do to help the city out of its latest crisis.

title: Stricken Mayoral Aide Is in Stable Condition
description: Thomas F. Roche, assistant to the Mayor, was in stable condition last night at New York University Hospital following his collapse Monday at the Americana Hotel.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: United Press International

title: 7 Military Officers Arrested in Spain; Secrecy Is Imposed
description: MADRID, Wednesday, July 30 (UPI)A military judge ordered the arrest today of a Spanish major and six captains, a military communiqu said.

title: Gloucester Farmers Seeking Designation as Disaster Area
description: MICKLETON, July 29William Doerrmann's 66acre fruit and vegetable farm here has been in the family 121 years. Now it has a forsale sign out front.

title: Willowbrook Boy Beaten Before Dying, Tests Show
description: An autopsy disclosed yesterday that a 9yearold mongo loid child, suffering from a congenital heart defect, had apparently been beaten before he died at Willowbrook Development Center last Tuesday evening, but that the death was from natural causes.

title: Presalted Frieds': It's Commercial, But Is It Beneficial?
description: Two allbeef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions on a sesame seed bun.

title: 2 Injured in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 29 (AP)A man and a woman were treated for minor injuries and released from Boston City Hospital tonight after a clash between blacks and whites in the city's Dorchester section.

title: G.M.'S PROFITS UP 8.8% IN QUARTER
description: DETROIT, July 29The General Motors Corporation reported today an 8.8 per cent increase in secondquarter earnings to $333million from the depressed period a year ago while the Chrysler Corporation reported a loss of $58.7million in contrast to a profit last year.

title: G.M. Dealers Cleared To Sell 1976 Models
description: DETROIT, July 29  The General Motors Corporation, which begins production of some 1976 models next week, said today its dealers would be able to sell them as soon as they were shipped because of shortages of 1975 models. Dealers will not have to wait until the official introduction day, which varies from late September until early, October at G.M.

title: Medicare and Medicaid After Decade: A Mixed Picture of Gains and Excesses
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Ten years ago tomorrow, President Johnson signed into law the amendments to the Social Security program that created Medicare and Medicaid.

title: CONGRESS ENACTS HEALTH MEASURE OVER FORD'S VETO
description: WASHINGTON, July 29President Ford suffered a significant setback today as the House voted 348 to 43 to override his veto of a $2billion health bill.

title: 2 in Baltic Cause Held, Then Freed in Helsinki
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 29  Two American citizens of Baltic descent were detained by the Finnish police at the Helsinki airport today, reportedly because of fear that they had come to protest the Soviet takeover of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. They were identified as Uldis Grava of Leonia, N. J., and Dr. Joseph Valiunas of New York.

title: 7.94% RATE SET IN TREASURY SALE
description: The Treasury's sale of $3billion of 33month notes was easily absorbed by a highly liquid credit market yesterday. The auction produced an average interest rate of 7.94 per cent, a touch nelow dealer expectations, when results were disclosed after the close.

title: WALTER S. BAUMANN
description: Walter S. Baumann, president of Ludwig Baumann & Co., a homefurnishings chain, from 1946 until it was merged into Spear & Co. in 1952, died July 21 in Buffalo Grove, Ill. He was 72 years old.

title: Ford, in Auschwitz, Cites Pursuit of Peace for All
description: BRZEZINKA, Poland, July 29  The Queen Anne's lace fluttered as the helicopter touched down just inside a barbed wire fence. The tall American alighted and walked slowly past the crumbled concrete ruins of the gas chamber. Two United States marines placed a wreath of red and white carnations at the base of a brutalist stone memorial.

title: Excerpts From the Declaration to Be Issued by the European Security Parley
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 29Following are excerpts from the official English version of the declaration to be signed here Friday by the leaders of the 35 nations participating in the European security conference:

title: Alicia Alonso Renews Ballet Theater Ties
description: American Ballet Theater is a company I was  and am  part of, the famed Cuban ballerina and former Ballet Theater star Alicia Alonso told the troupe's assembled dancers yesterday.

title: State Democrats Conduct Public Hearing on Stand
description: TRENTON, July 29  The state Democratic platform committee opened its annual public hearing today and was surwised at what it didn't hear.

title: Boeing Estimates Worker Reduction At 8,000 for Year
description: SEATTLE, July 29 (UPI)The Boeing Company will cut back a total of 8,000 employes this year through layoffs and attrition, according to a Boeing spokesman.

title: Cuba's Proposed Charter: Sobering Thoughts
description: GLENELG, AustraliaNow that the full text of the first draft of the constitution of Premier Fidel Castro's Cuba has become available, North Americans should pause for some sobering thoughts. It can be taken for granted that this draft is not going to be altered much in discussions around the island, which began April 28, or at the First Congress of the Communist party of Cuba, in December. The outcome of the referendum to be held in 1976 is a foregone conclusion.

title: Highlights of the Plans
description: A wage freeze canceling the 6 per cent increase due city workers on July 1, saving an estimated $259million.

title: Hall Victor,116, After Seaver Loses, 53
description: ST. LOUIS, July 29  The New York Mets tried the TomTom method on the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, but it only half worked. With Tom Seaver, their ace, pitching the first game of a twilightnight doubleheader, the Mets lost, 53. With Tom Hall making a rare start, however, they won, 116.

title: Deaths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. ISM ??0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691100; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Filly Winning a Fortune For a Struggling School
description: BEAR, Del., July 29Not long ago, Au Clair, a respected but struggling school for autistic children, was hard pressed, to pay its bills here in this isolated rural village.

title: $282Million Is Committed At Auction by Fannie Mae
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (Reuters)  The Federal National Mortgage Association said today it had issued $282.2million in fourmonth commitments to purchase Governmentbacked and conventionally financed home mortgages as a result of this week's auction.

title: Hoboken Gets U.S. Aid for Rebuilding Tenements
description: HOBOKEN, July 29Housing was high on the agenda here today as the city received a Federal grant for its newly developed tenement rehabilitaion program and the Mount Carmel Guild broke ground for a 12story, 154unit apartment building for the elderly.

title: Gillespie, in Israel, Is Performer and Pilgrim
description: JERUSALEM, July 29With the single spotlight fused on his round, smiling face, Dizzy Gillespie stepped up to the microphone and whispered huskily: This is for my Bahai brethren all over the world from the place where it all began.

title: Equal School Aid No Panacea in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU  Hawaii, the only state financing its schools in a way that almost equalizes expenditures for each student, is finding that equal educational opportunity is no guarantee of equal peformance.

title: ARAFAT ADDRESSES O.A.U. ON PALESTINE
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 29 (UPI)Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, told the Organization of African Unity today that there could be no peace in the Middle Vast without a Palestine.

title: CHIEF OF TRANSPORT ASSAILS RAIL PLANS
description: TRENTON, July 29 (UPI)Alan Sagner, New Jersey's Transportation Commissioner, complained today that a number of important rail lines for freight and passenger service would be eliminated under a proposed Federal plan.

title: SAKHAROV CALLS PARLEY CRITICAL
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, says in a new essay on EastWest relations that it is up to the European security conference to decide whether dtente is to be a comprehensive, profound process of historic significance or a cynical political game.

title: People and Business
description: Charles L. Brown, executive vice president and chief financial officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has given assurances that the recent $110million loan it obtained from the Government of Saudi Arabia will in no way influence the company's hiring and promotion policies.

title: Bentsen Announces Group Of Supporters in Virginia
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr. of Texas announced today the formation of a committee of Virginia supporters that spans the ideological spectrum of that state's Democratic party and includes most of its leaders.

title: Woman, 89, Is Slain In Bronx Apartment
description: An 89yearold woman was found murdered in her Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon, less than a week after an 80yearold woman was found stabbed to death in her apartment in the same Fordham neighborhood.

title: 33Month Notes Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Treasury sold today $3billion of 33month notes at an average rate of 7.94 per cent. The Treasury received tenders for $5.6billion and awarded $900million of noncompetitive tenders at an average mice of 99.768.

title: TRUMAN B. CLAPP
description: Truman B. Clapp, a pioneer in industrial expositions died Monday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: Security Chief Defends Exotic Betting
description: A grand jury conclusion that exotic betting leads to fixed racing at harness tracks was labeled yesterday was another smear without specifics by the head of Harness Tracks Security.

title: Citizen Groups Charge A.M. A. May Owe $21Million in Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Two public interest groups charged today that the American Medical Association might owe the Federal Government as much as $21million in back taxes on the advertising income of its publications and sought a Congressional investigation.

title: The Cult Of Change
description: WASHINGTON, July 29There is widespread disillusionment with Government, big business, labor unions and other major institutions. Politically, this expresses itself in an uneasy mood that resembles conservatism but is more nearly passivity and a withdrawal from world and national concerns to those of family and community.

title: Nixon Tax Aide Denies Guilt
description: LOS ANGELES, July 29 (UPI) Frank DeMarco Jr. pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of preparing a false tax return for former President Richard M. Nixon. Mr. DeMarco's lawyer said that Mr. Nixon may be called as a witness at Mr. DeMarco's trial.

title: Convalescing Astronauts Spend Final Day in Hospital
description: HONOLULU, July 29 (UPI)The Apollo astronauts today spent their last day hospitalized for lung inflammation from breathing poisonous rocket propellant fumes and prepared to move to vacation quarters.

title: CYRUS CLARK
description: Cyrus Clark, president of the Cyrus Clark Company, a textile manufacturer and converter, which he founded in 1925, died Sunday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at his home on East Shore Road, Kings Point, L. I. He was 77 years old.

title: Liner Is Abandoned Here With 77 Members of Crew
description: A luxury liner that carried passengers to ports throughout the Caribbean has been abandoned in New York harbor with 77 crew members, most of them from Italy, aboard.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SAFETY RULES SET FOR LASER DEVICES
description: WASHINGTON. July 29 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration issued the first Federal safety standards today to protect consumers, students and workers against radiation injuries from lasers.

title: Good News From Finns On World War I Debt
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 29President Urho Kekkonen of Finland had bracing financial news for President Ford when they met here this evening.

title: LUANNA BOWLES, 82, EDUCATOR, IS DEAD
description: Luanna J. Bowles, an educator whose programs overcame illiteracy in several countries, died Friday in Friends House, a Quaker retirement center in Sandy Spring, Md. She was 82 years old.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: A Record 150,000 Hear Philharmonic in the Park
description: They started arriving at 10 o'clock in the morning yesterday, just about the time the orchestra began rehearsing. They laid their blankets on the ground to keep their places. By 7:30 in the evening, Sheep Meadow in Central Park was a sea of people who had come to hear the New York Philharmonic's opening program in its 11th season of free concerts in the city's parks.

title: Yankees Win, 42
description: Dick Hawser did not forget how to wave a runner round third base.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Local Golf Results
description: AT HUNTINGTON C. C.

title: SCOTT DANCE USES SITE IMAGINATIVELY
description: A splendid locale and a warmly bemused crowd were invaluable assets to Judith Scott's outdoor dance concert yesterday. Miss Scott wisely chose the naval memorial in Battery Park for her noontime performance of Recharge Battery II by her improvisation group.

title: Senate Votes Grants for Areas With Big Unemployment Rates
description: WASHIWGTON, July 29The Senate, after listening to repeated references to New York City's fiscal crisis, approved today emergency anti recession grants to states and localities with high unemployment.

title: Helsinki Greets Visitors And Guards Them Well
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 Stringent security measures intruded on the easygoing pace of this small capital today, as national leaders arrived from throughout Europe and North America for the summitlevel conclusion of the 35nation European Security Conference.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Six members of an Edison family were hospitalized, including three in critical condition, after a fire swept through their home. The blaze broke out around 6:15 A.M. in the home of John and Catherine Squire and burned out of control for about 30 minutes, according to the police.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Europeans Ponder U. S. Congress
description: PARIS, July 29The renewed power of Congress in American foreign policy has begun to trouble European leaders and officials, as they gradually become aware that decisions can no longer be made at the summit level alone. Recently in Brussels, a senior European diplomat worrying about Turkey's role in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said:

title: Syrian Court Dooms 5
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, July 29state security court today sentenced four Palestinians and Syrian to death after finding them guilty of participating in bombing attacks by the banned Arab Communist Organization against American and other, targets.

title: Namath to Sign 2Year Jet Pact Today
description: Joe Namath will be back home, where he belongs when he signs a twoyear contract today with the Jets.

title: Business Briefs
CONSPIRACY LAID TO SAN QUENTIN 6
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 29Prosecutor Jerry Herman presented today a chronology of events that will form the basis for the state's case against the San Quentin Six. The sixfive inmates and a former inmate who was recently releasedare charged with five murders stemming from an alleged escape attempt by George Jackson, the black revolutionary writer, at San Quentin Prison on Aug. 21, 1971.

title: Crewman Is Killed In a 2Train Crash Under East River
description: An empty Penn Central com muter train bound for Pennsylvania Station rammed into the rear of another empty train in an East River tunnel yesterday afternoon, killing one crewman and injuring another.

title: Gowon Is Calm as He Learns of His Ouster at Parley in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 29  A Nigerian walked swiftly across the floor of the Uganda International Conference Center's meeting hall at about 10:15 this morning and handed a piece of paper to Gen. Yakubu Gowon.

title: Ford Orders Navy to End Training at Culebra Cays
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) President Ford has told the Navy to end all weapons training at the Culebra Cays of Puerto Rico on Sept. 30, Pentagon sources said today.

title: American League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Handicapped Aid Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) The House voted today to authorize more than $1billion over the next two year step up Federal aid for teaching handicapped children.

title: Gowon Ousted in Nigeria; Coup ends NineYear Rule
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 29 Gen. Yakubu Gowon was deposed as chief of state of this most populous African country today in a bloodless coup carried out while he was abroad.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Dr. Ronald S. Berman, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities and Michael Guy, Minister of Culture of France, have signed in Paris a document of understanding that will result in an exchange of exhibitions and museum personnel between the United States and France. It is to begin in the fall of 1977.

title: Sets Win, 2825, Minus Mrs. King
description: INDIANAPOLIS July 29 Despite Billie Jean King's absence because of a 24hour virus, the New York Sets defeataed the Indiana Loves, 2825, tonight in front of the first sellout crowd in the brief history of World Team Tennis. The match drew 7,135 fans at the Indianapolis Convention Center.

title: Nassau Police Win 12.3% Raise, Making Them Best Paid in U.S.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 29 An arbitration panel today awarded the Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association a 12.3 per cent increase in a wage and fringebenefit package, which makes the police officers here the highest paid in the nation, according to the association's president.

title: WASHINGTON STAR PONDERS FUTURE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The proprietors of The Washington Star, whose future was further beclouded by an adverse ruling from the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, met today to search for a means of survival.

title: Leading Indicators Up Sharply in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Government's revised composite index of leading indicators of the economy showed a significant rise in June for the fourth consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today. The index combines various statistics that often lead, or foretell, economic trends.

title: PLAN OF ACTION
description: The city and officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation  even as they were negotiating with the city's labor union leaders  agreed yesterday to a $500million package of budgetary economies that Mayor Beame is expected to announce this morning at City Hall.

title: Highlights of the Declaration
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 29Following are highlights from the declaration to be issued by the 35nation European security conference:

title: A City Reported Taken
description: LUANDA, July 29 (AP)Malange, a provincial capital in central Angola, has been captured by troops of the Chinesebacked National Front for the Liberation of Angola after days of heavy fighting, according to reports reaching Luanda.

title: U.S. HOPES TO LIFT ME LEASING BAN
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 29Western Governors were told today by representatives of the Department of the Interior that the Ford Administration hoped to lift the moratorium on the leasing of federally owned coal deposits in about a year.

title: Listing of Prices for Contracts in Ftures of Commodities
CUBA SANCTIONS, IMPOSED IN 1964, LIFTED BY O.A.S.
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 29The Organization of American States tonight ended political and economic sanctions against Cuba, effectively abolishing the embargo imposed 11 years ago as a penalty for fostering Communist guerrilla activities in the hemisphere.

description: Theater

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: DURKIN NOW ASKS A NEW ELECTION
description: DURHAM, N. H., July 29John A. Durkin, in a reversal, asked the Senate tonight to declare New Hampshire's disputed Senate seat vacant and trigger a runoff election between him and his Republican rival, Louis C. Wyman.

title: Girl, 7, to Feel Impact Of Educational Trims
description: NEPTUNE, July 29 (UPI)The program that has helped teach Stacey Rizas how to feed herself is in jeopardy because of cuts in state aid.

title: No.Amer.Soccer League
SENATE UNIT VOTE ON RIGHTS BILL DUE
description: TRENTON, July 29As a result of developments here today, an Equal Rights Amendment to the New Jersey Cori, stitution appears likely to be submitted to voters on the November ballot.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TOMORROW, JULY 31

title: AMAX TO ACQUIRE COPPER RANGE CO.
description: Amax, Inc., of Greenwich, Conn., a large international mining company, and the Copper Range Company of White Pine, Mich., announced yesterday the signing of a definitive agreement for Amax to acquire Copper Range. Under terms of the agreement, which provide a taxfree transaction, each share of Copper Range common would be exchanged for eighttenths of one share of Amax common. Amax would issue about 1.5 million shares worth about $76.8million to effect the transaction.

title: BRITAIN RULES OUT CUTRATE FLIGHTS
description: LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) The Labor Government today banned proposed cheap Skytrain flights across the North Atlantic and said that it would not allow competition between Britain's airlines on longdistance scheduled services.

title: Postscript to Summit
description: A newspaper of record has an obligation to keep the record straight. At his interview with members of the Washington bureau of The New York Times last week President Ford was asked why he had not sought a bold domestic di plomacy, as he said he would shortly before becoming President. Mr. Ford replied that it depended on how the term bold domestic diplomacy was defined.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, July 29, 1975

title: Hurricane Hits Quebec
description: CAPAUXMEULES, Quebec, July 29 (AP)  Hurricane Blanche caused heavy damage last night as it cut through the Magdalen Islands in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, the police said today.

title: Rhodes Tells Kent Jury of NearWar
description: CLEVELAND, July 29Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio told a Federal jury today that the situation on the Kent State campus five years ago was almost a state of war.

title: Respect for Lifeand Capital Punishment, Too
description: All the young years of my life I was against capital punishment. Passionately, and with all my heart, as I opposed Richard Nixon (the first Richard Nixon), Joseph McCarthy, and the Pentagon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Revies Payments Lag
description: TOKYO, July 29 (Reuters)Japan recorded a revised balance of payments deficit of $282million in June against a deficit of $391million n May and of $1.27billion in June last year, the Finance Ministry said today. The revised deficit of $391million in May the preliminary. $290million reported earlier this month.

title: Plans Unit Backs Apartment Tower At Lincoln Center
description: The City Planning Commission has voted, 5 to 2, to issue a special permit for a 34story, 620apartment tower on Broadway just across from Lincoln Center. The two dissenters voiced alarm at the population density that would result.

title: Ford, at Auschwitz, Cites Pursuit of Peace for All
description: BRZEZINKA, Poland, July 29  The Queen Anne's lace fluttered as the helicopter touched down just inside a barbed wire fence. The tall American alighted and walked slowly past the crumbled concrete ruins of the gas chamber. Two United States marines placed a wreath of red and white carnations at the base of a brutalist stone memorial.

title: About New York
description: The recent column dealing with the urge to wave at passing ships has brought an amplifying letter from Franklin Heller, director, writer and president of the International Confederation of Book Actors, in Stamford, Conn.

title: People in Sports
description: Willie Wood was named head coach of the World Football League's Philadelphia Bell yesterday. Wood, a former allpro defensive back with the Green Bay Packers, is 38 years old and blackthe first black head coach in pro football since Fritz Pollard coached the Hammond Pros of the National Football League from 192325.

title: SENATE APPROVES TOP U.S. PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Senate approved tonight a costofliving pay increase for members of Congress, the Federal judiciary and top Government executives.

title: Senators Hoping to Force New House Vote on Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Several of the Senators who support ending the military embargo against Turkey said today that they were considering trying to force a new vote in the House of Representatives, which only last week rejected efforts to lift the embargo.

title: Two Iranians Are Arrested In Killing of U.S. Officers
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 29 (UPI) Iranian security agents have captured two leftwing terrorists involved in the ambush slaying of two United States Air Force colonels Teheran last May 21, the official press agency reported today.

title: LEVITT FINDS WASTE IN 3 LEGAL AGENCIES
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt has found that state agencies receiving Federal lawenforcement grants had wasted more than half a million dollars in Federal funds and ignored Federal regulations, thus jeopardizing future grants.

title: ECONOMIC STIMULUS PLANNED BY FRANCE
description: PARIS, July 29The French Government, faced with an unemployment rate that has nearly doubled in the last 12 months, said today it would adopt a vigorous program of economic stimulus this fall.

title: Article 1  No Title
SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Corn and soybean Sutures prices rose sharply yesterday amid growing worry about a dry spell in some Midwest growing areas. Rain was forecast for the weekend, but traders worried whether it would be enough to save a large part of the Iowa corn crop.

title: WINE TALK
description: ST. HELENA, Calif.A diligent wine fan with a lot of patience and a full tank of gas can taste quite a few bottles in a day of driving up and down the Napa Valley. From Calistoga in the north to Yountville and Napa in the south, there are dozens of wineries large and small offering their wares to taste and to buy.

title: Music: Mozart's Prague
description: For half the time on Monday night the Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall was mostly mediocre or worse. Peter Maag and the festival orchestra ran through Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 1 in F as if giving it a final rehearsal. Mr. Maag at the harpsichord (historically correct there, anyway) conducted far too many players (No. 1 can be done nicely with 13), far too lifelessly to overcome glaring instrumental slipups by the horn department, and with far too little concern for such baroque details as dotted rhythms. His ideas about interpretation did not extend much beyond putting on the brakes jarringly for Adagio sections, a dramatic touch but in context rather pointless.

title: G.M.'S PROFITS UP 8.8% IN QUARTER
description: DETROIT, July 29The General Motors Corporation reported today an 8.8 per cent increase in secondquarter earnings to $333million from the depressed period a year ago while the Chrysler Corporation reported a loss of $58.7million in contrast to a profit last year.

title: About the Jets ...
description: Bobby Howfield, the reluctant kicker, arrived at camp more than a week late. How was the knee, he was asked. No comment, he replied. Will he play, he was asked. No comment until I talk to the coach, he replied. Coach Charley Winner said he would be fined.... The club is taking a look at Marvin Crenshaw, who made several allAmerica teams while playing offensive tackle at Nebraska. The 6foot6inch, 240pound lineman was the Pittsburgh Steelers' sixthround pick but they released him after failing to come to contract terms.

title: Dow's Polyethylene Prices Up; Monsanto Raises Acrylic Fiber
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it was increasing prices of highandlowdensity polyethylene by 6 to 10 per cent beginning Sept. 1. Polyethylene is used to make plastics, films and resins. The Moncanto Textiles Company increased the price of its Acrilan acrylic fiber from 6 cents to 10 cents a pound and said polyester staple prices would rise 6 cents a pound while polyester filament prices in the 70denier size and polyester feeder yarns for texturing would rise by up to 5 per cent.

title: Arthur Burns Assails Governance of the City
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told a Congressional committee today that New York City has not been properly governed for many, many years now.

title: CUBA SANCTIONS, IMPOSED IN 1964, LIFTED BY O.A.S.
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 29The Organization of American States tonight ended political and economic sanctions against Cuba effectively abolishing the embargo imposed 11 years ago as a penalty for fostering Communist guerrilla activities in the hemisphere.

title: Rumania Floods Costly
description: GENEVA, July 29 (Reuters)Floods that ravaged Rumania earlier this month affected a million people and turned 2.5 million acres of cropland into lakes, a senior United Nations official reported. Thousands were left homeless and 22 per cent of Rumania's grain harvest, including 1.5 million tons of wheat, was destroyed, Panayotis Stanissis, special representative of the United Nations Disaster Relief Coordinator, said.

title: Sauna Delights Ford; He Applies the Birches
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 (UPI)  President Ford, after beating himself with birch branches, pronounced his first Finnish sauna delightful.

title: Conflicts Hurt N.J. Tracks
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29It used to be that New Jersey's State Racing Commission, well aware that competition for the horseplayer's dollar can reach the saturation point, assigned dates to its thoroughbred plants at Monmouth Park, Atlantic City and Garden State that provided no conflicts. Today, however, as Monmouth Park conducted the 53d program of its meeting, it found itself still in competition with Freehold Raceway, the daytime harness horse racing center only 16 miles to the west. The result is that both tracks have been suffering.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: TUMBLE ON AMEX IS 9TH STRAIGHT
description: Prices of stocks on the American Stock Exchange tumbled yesterday in moderate trading, continuing the decline into the ninth session. The Amex index dropped 0.65 to close at 89.69. Volume rose to 2,124,000 from 1,766,000 on Monday.

title: PLAN OF ACTION
description: The city and officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation  even as they were negotiating with the city's labor union leaders  agreed yesterday to a $500million package of budgetary economies that Mayor Beame is expected to announce this morning at City Hall.

title: Army Secretary Defends Cuts for Bases in State
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Norman P. Augustine, the Acting Secretary of the Army, said today that proposals to transfer giant military operations from New Jersey to other states were necessary because of the reduction in size of the Army since the war in Vietnam ended.

title: Notes on People
description: After three years, Clifford Irving has won permission to publish his hoax autobiography of Howard Hughes as fiction. But by now, he insists, he doesn't much care. In a decision made public yesterday, Justice Andrew Tyler of Manhattan Supreme Court ruled that a 1972 injunction obtained by Rosemont Enterprisesa Nevada company that holds the Hughes biographical rightscannot possibly prevent [Mr. Irving] from presenting a fictionalized work concerning the eccentric and reclusive billionaire.

title: DR. HERBERT ELIAS
description: Dr. Herbert Elias, an internist, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 90 years old and lived at 35 West 81st Street.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 (UPI)Yugoslavia, defeated the United States, 8279, in an Intercontinental Cup basketball match today. With 32 seconds to go, the Yugoslays had an 8079 advantage when, Tommy LaGarde of the United States committed a foul. The Yugoslays took the ball out and got their clinching points when Radivoje Zivkovic scored alone. LaGarde led the Americans with 16 points. Bob Parrish scored 14 and Johnny Davis 10.

title: Steeler to Miss Game
description: LATROBE, Pa., July 29 (AP)Lynn Swann, a secondyear wide receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers, will miss the College AllStar Game Friday night because of a pulled hamstring, the club said today.

title: Yesterday's Saratoga Results
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

title: Pittston Earnings Rose 121% in Quarter
description: Profits for the Pittston Company, the nation's largest independent coal producer and a major exporter of coal, continued to rise in the second quarter, the company reported yesterday. Earnings were up 121 per cent above the corresponding period of 1974.

title: 4 POLICE OFFICERS ACCUSED IN DEATH
description: A Manhattan grand jury will soon investigate the circumstances surrounding the death of a 33yearold man, who his wife said, was killed by four police officers.

title: Black Vice President Sought
description: ATLANTA, July 29 (UPI) The Southern Christian Leadership Conference will start a concerted effort to have a black as a vicepresidential candidate next year, the conference president, the Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy, said yesterday.

title: Part of Waikiki Closed
description: HONOLULU, July 29 (AP) Tens of thousands of visitors and residents have been ordered to stay out of waters along a oneandonehalf mile section of Waikiki Beach because of contamination by sewage.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in The New York Times last Saturday stated incorrectly that the Consolidated Edison Company was dropping plans to build a nuclear plant. The utility in question was the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, which had planned a nuclear plant in Somerset.

title: Marked Place
description: Mention the name Big Mac in Wall Street these days and everyone thinks of the new Municipal Assistance Corporation formed to back up New York City. It's almost as if Wall Street's original Big Mac had been forgotten.

title: Lisbon Orders Censorship On Reports From Angola
description: LISBON, July 29Portugal imposed military censorship today on all news coming from Angola, where the situation was described as extremely dangerous.

title: Dr. Roland Friedland, 38, Dies; ExFordham English Professor
description: Dr. Roland Lloyd Friedland, a professor of English and a writer who was the center of a controversy when Fordham University decided not to renew his contract, was found dead Sunday evening at his home, 46 West 65th Street. He was 38 years old.

title: Wary Respect for Power Seems to Permeate India
description: BOMBAY, India, July 26An executive in Madras, T. R. Shrinivas, intoned, Mrs. Gandhi is a lady, and normally in India ladies are respected.

title: Television
Vatican Declines Comment
description: ROME, July 29 (UPI)The Vatican declined immediate comment today on the announcement that the Orthodox Church of Greece was, breaking relations with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Indian Militant Tells of Attack in South Dakota
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., July 29An American Indian Movement leader, Russell E. Means, received a minor head wound late last night in what appeared to have been an attempt, to kill or seriously injure him as he rode in a car on South Dakota's Rosebud Indian Reservation.

title: ZINC ACCORD SIGNED BY GULF & WESTERN
description: Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the signing of a partnership agreement between its New Jersey Zinc division and Union Min. iere, S.A., of Belgium for construction of the first new zinc refinery in this country since 1941.

title: 18 Urban Experts Advise, Castigate and Console the City on Its Problems
description: JOHN KENNETH GALBRAITH, author of Economics and the Public PurposeI think it's fair to say that no problem associated with New York City could not be solved by providing more money. The remarkable thing is not that this city's government costs so much, but that so many people of wealth have left. It's outrageous that the development of the metropolitan community has been organized with escape hatches that allow people to enjoy the proximity of the city while not paying their share of taxes. It's outrageous that a person can avoid income tax by moving to New Jersey or Connecticut. Fiscal funkholes are what the suburbs ate.

title: Alonso Gala Is a Night to Remember
description: Gala performances are ideally like the menu of a great and memorable mealthey require firstclass ingredignts, careful planning and special love. American Ballet Theater has always made something of a specialty of its fundraising galas, and the Monday night gala celebrating the company's 35th anniversarywas no exception. It was a night to cherish.

title: HYMAN KRAFT, 76, PLAYWRIGHT, DIES
description: Hyman S. Kraft, author and playwright, who did the book for Top Banana, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 221 West 82d Street.

title: About New York
description: The recent column dealing with the urge to wave at passing ships has brought an amplifying letter from Franklin Heller, director, writer and president of the International Confederation of Book Actors, in Stamford, Conn.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: A precept of modern marketing technique is to take a common everyday product, describe some unusual but not necessarily important feature, and then promote the product on the basis of that feature. This prevents any unseemly headtohead price war that might be necessary if the product were identical to that of its competitor.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: M.T.A FARE PLAN IS EXPECTED SOON
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority continued yesterday to consider a package of revenue proposals, including increased subway, bus and commuter rail fares and higher tolls at its bridges and tunnels.

title: 11 in Colombia Inquiry Killed
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 29 (AP)Eleven members of a police commission investigating a murder in a remote area of Colombia that is rich in emeralds were killed yesterday by unidentified assailants, the police here reported.

title: U.S. AND STATE GET MEDICAID REPORTS
description: TRENTON, July 29 (UPI)The State Commission of Investigation handed over to Federal and state agencies today cartons of information it had gathered in its investigation of clinical laboratories involved in a probe of alleged fraud in the Medicaid program.

title: E. THEODORA HECHT
description: E. Theodora Hecht, a retired teacher, died Monday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 65 years old and a resident of Brooklyn.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for

title: Portuguese Troika
description: The decision of Portugal's President, Gen. Francisco da Costa Gomes, to postpone his departure for the Helsinki summit meeting this week underlines the gravity of the mounting political crisis in that country. Since the main point of the Helsinki summit is the signature of a declaration that in effect gives universal sanction to the Communist hold in Eastern Europe, the President of the most leftoriented Government in Western Europe would not endanger his visit to the summit for any light reason. Essentially Portugal stands at a fork of the road, in which one direction points toward genuine democracy while the other points toward a leftist military dictatorship.

title: Bridge:
description: In the early thirties, black bridge players formed their own national organization, because many clubs and associations were closed to them. Those days are happily long past, but the American Bridge Association continues to flourish alongside the American Contract Bridge League. The two organizations maintain a cordial relationship, and there is considerable overlap in membership.

title: CONGRESS ENACTS HEALTH MEASURE OVER FORD'S VETO
description: WASHINGTON, July 29President Ford suffered a significant setback today as the House voted 348 to 43 to override his veto of a $2billion heath bill.

title: U.S. Steel Quarter Profit Off by 19.5%
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 19.5 per cent in secondquarter net income as sales and revenues fell by 14.5 per cent.

title: Ziobro's 67 Leads Jersey Golf by 4
description: CHATHAM, N. J., July 29 Billy Ziobro of Tammy Brook shot a courserecord 67 today in the first round he ever played in the New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association championship. His score at the Fairmount Country Club gave him a fourstroke lead in the 54hole event.

title: Gurney Jury Deliberates A 2d Day Without Verdict
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 29 (AP)Former Senator Edward J. Gurney, looking cheerful and relaxed, joked about eluding photographers today before the jury began its second day of deliberations in the influence peddling case against him.

title: Nat Pierce, Fordham Star, Dies; One of 7 Blocks of Granite, 62
description: Nat Pierce, one of the famed Seven Blocks of Granite of Fordham University's football teams in 1936 and 1937, died Monday afternoon while vacationing in Biddleford, Me., his birthplace. Mr. Pierce was 62 years old. He lived in Farmingdale, L.I.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: UP AND AT 'EM The cityoperated Hall of Science Planetarium in Queens has a new sky show, Comets and Meteors, running Through Sept. 6 at Flushing Meadows in Corona Park.

title: WINE TALK
description: ST. HELENA, Calif.A diligent wine fan with a lot of patience and a full tank of gas can taste quite a few bottles in a day of driving up and down the Napa Valley. From Calistoga in the north to Yountville and Napa in the south, there are dozens of wineries large and small offering their wares to taste and to buy.

title: DISMISSAL DENIED IN DOLKART CASE
description: A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday refused to dismiss an indictment against Joel Dolkart, a former partner in two prestigious Wall Streat law firms, who is accused of stealing more than $2.5million in fees paid the firms from 1967 to 1973.

title: Filly Winning a Fortune For a Struggling School
description: BEAR, Del., July 29Not long ago, Au Clair, a respected but struggling school for autistic children, was hard pressed to pay its bills here in this isolated rural village.

title: 25 Seized in U.F.W. Protest
description: Twentyfive chanting members of the United Farm Workera Union were arrested yesterday when they refused to leave a Waldbaum's supermarket at 8235 153rd Avenue in Lindenwood, Queens. According to Sgt. Joseph McNulty of the 106th Precinct, the demonstrators sat in the aisles singing, praying and asking people nol to buy grapes.

title: Detroit Police and Blacks Clash in Area Where Youth's Death Sparked Earlier Violence
description: DETROIT, July 29 (UPI)Policemen and roving bands of blacks clashed again tonight in a West Side neighborhood where the fatal shooting of a teenager by a white bar owner had triggered looting, burning and street clashes 24 hours earlier.

title: ISRAEL PLANS CURB ON U.N. IF EXPELLED
description: JERUSALEM, July 29 (AP)Foreign Minister Yigal Allon said today that he favored suspending United Nations activities affecting Israel if Israel were suspended, expelled or had her credentials rejected at the General Assembly.

title: Charter Panel Assailed on Plan To Limit Role of the Controller
description: The Citizens Budget Commission voiced its disapproval yesterday of a state panel's proposal that the preaudit and pay roll functions of the City Confroller be transferred to mayoral agencies.

title: University of Defense Planned by Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)The Pentagon said today that it would combine two of its most prestigious graduatelevel service schools into a University of National Defense.

title: Ailing Pele Won't Play Tonight
description: Pel will miss tonight's North American Soccer League game here between the New York Cosmos and Rochester Lancers and perhaps the two following games because of a thigh injury.

title: Chanel and Courreges Show the Timelessness of HighFashion Design
description: PARIS, July 28One of the tenacious myths about fashion is that it changes all the time. Not so. Sometimes it hardly changes at all.

title: VaticanGreek Orthodox Amity Gives Way in Dispute Over Sect
description: ?? of The Times, London

title: Advertising
description: Monsieur Henri, Pepsico's little old winemaker, is going to attempt to take advantage of America's reportedly growing fondness for white wine by adding a white to its Yago Sant'Gria brand, already the bestselling imported wine in this country.

title: Layoff Goal Unachieved, Computer Report Shows
description: The city's Office of Management and Budget yesterday released its delayed, computerized check of dismissals of city workers  an exhaustive report that noted that 10,271 fulltime employes and 2,795 parttime employes had been dismissed from city jobs since the economy drive that began two months ago.

title: Nixon Questioned on Alleged C.I.A. Plots
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Senator John G. Tower, vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that he had questioned former President Richard M. Nixon on the Central Intelligence Agency's alleged involvement in assassination plots.

title: Why I Quit
description: Resignations are followed by a listing of personal accomplishments. One item only on my list; for seven years survived.

title: Trabert Is Slated to Be Davis Cup Captain
description: The new Davis Cup captain is to be named today, and it is almost certain that 44yearold Tony Trabert will inherit the post from Dennis Ralston, under whom the United States suffered earlyround defeats the last two years.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the title story of I would Have Saved Them If I Could, Wallace Stevens's phrase, Death is the mother of beauty. is quoted apropos of the disappearance of a Jewish tailor in Brest. A page farther on a letter of Lord Byron's is quoted in which the poet describes the guillotining in Rome of three robbers and then concludes, the second and third (which shows how dreadfully soon things grow indifferent), I am ashamed to say, had no effect on me as a horror, though I would have saved them if I could. An earlier story, Storytellers, Liars, and Bores, concludes with the narrator's dream of meeting Kafka: A ship had gone down. In one of its rooms, where barnacles were biting the walls. I was reading a story aloud. . . . [A woman with a] broken nose appeared, swimming through the palpable light, her mouth a zero. She said, Have you been introduced to Kafka? He's here, you know. I followed her and was introduced. He shook my hand, then wiped his fingers on his tie.

title: Mets' Records
Volleyball Is Spiking Lunch Hours in City
description: The nets are strung by office workers on the vacant sections of the West Side Highway, by Dominicans and Haitians in Riverside Park and by youngsters in many playgrounds in town.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Manhattan grand jury dismissed charges of manslaughter and negligent homicide against 19yearold Julia Vargas in the death of a 2yearold child on June 17. The child, Katie Etheredge, had been walking with her mother, Tinetta Etheredge, when a glass wine jug slipped from Mrs. Vargas's hands and through her seventhfloor window, at Broadway and 104th Street, killing the girl.

title: Fishing Jurisdiction
description: Canada has seen fit to protect the fisheries off its Eastern coast by completely closing its Atlantic ports to the Soviet fishing fleet. Such drastic actionwhich grew out of alleged violation of the limits agreed on for various catches as well as failure to settle claimsis one the United States may avoid if Congress passes legislation now in the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.

title: Bronx Judge Defends Court Demeanor
description: A Bronx judge charged with behaving in a rude and abusive manner admitted under oath yesterday that he occasionally made irrelevant comments in court.

title: Congress Study Questions Navy Selection of the F18
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A study by the Library of Con1 gress has concluded that the Navy failed to follow budgetary procedures laid down by Congress in selecting the F18 as its new low  cost fighter plane.

title: Richey Upset By German In Opener
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 29 (AP)  Harald Elschenbroich upset Cliff Richey, 46, 62, 75, in the first round of the $100,000 Louisville tennis tournament today.

title: PIER L. CHERICI
description: Pier. L. Cherici, an architect, died Monday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived In Syosett, L. I.

title: DOW DROPS 2.97 AFTER EARLY GAIN
description: The stock market rallied briefly yesterday morning fol lowing the Government's report of the fourth consecutive monthly upturn in its index of leading economic indicators, but the rebound failed to take hold and prices once again closed lower on the day.

title: Stockpiles Blunt Paper Strikes in Canada
description: OTTAWA, July 29Strikes have closed a significant segment of the booming Canadian woodpulp and paper industry, the largest exporters of pulp and newsprint in the world.

title: Callaway, on Rockefeller and 1971: A Shift to Silence
description: WASHINGTON, July 29Howard H. Callaway, who has been acting in recent weeks like an antiRockefeller point man in the Ford infantry, said this morning that he has taken a vow of silence on the subject of the Vice President.

title: Pay and Productivity
description: The debate over the municipal pay freeze, an essential shortrun expedient, has diverted attention from a related issue of potentially far greater importance in determining the city's longterm viability. That is the question of productivity in the municipal services.

title: PROFITS PLUNGE AT TWO AIRLINES
description: Northwest Airlines, Inc., and Continental Air Lines, Inc., both reported yesterday sharply lower profits for the second quarter.

title: Asarco Directors Vote To Cat Dividend to 15c
description: The board of directors of Asarco, Inc., voted yesterday to cut the quarterly dividend on common stock to 15 cents a share, payable Aug. 29 to stockholders of record Aug. 8. The company had paid 37.5 cents a share quarterly since May, 1974.

title: Saigon Aide Notes 3 Problems: Economy, Security, Education
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (UPI)Saigon's three biggest problems are the economy, security and education, a senior Government official has told a policy conference, according to a transcript of his remarks made available today.

title: What's Yours Is Negotiable
description: HELSINKI, FinlandI don't know what else the Helsinki summit will be remembered for in history but there is no doubt it serves as a brass monument to patient, careful Soviet diplomacy which, for 21 years, has been seeking an EastWest accord formally acknowledging East Europe's de facto frontiers.

title: Layoff Goal Unachieved, Computer Report Shows
description: The city's Office of Management and Budget yesterday released its delayed, computerized check of dismissals of city workers  an exhaustive report that noted that 10,271 fulltime employes and 2,795 parttime employes had been dismissed from city jobs since the economy drive that began two months ago.

title: A Quiet Englishman and Don King
description: John Conteh, a reformed hod carrier from Liverpool who holds the lightheavyweight championship of some of the world, is a visitor in New York on his way to Scranton, Pa. If that seems an improbable destination, well, he is going there to defend his piece of the title against Willie Taylor of the Bronx on Aug. 16 and on American Broadcasting Company's Wide World of Sports. Sonic readers may be under the impression that the lightheavyweight champion of the world is Bob Foster, but Bob retired a while back. Last October, before Foster's unretirement, Conteh whipped Argentina's Jorge Ahumada in London and was recognized nized as champion by the World Boxing Council. Also during Foster's absence, Victor Galindez beat Len Hutchins for the championship of the World Boxing Association's planet.

title: Healthy Phils Turn Back Pirates Again, 5 to 1
description: Before the 1975 baseball races began, many of the prognosticators selected the Philadelphia Phillies to capture the throne occupied by Pittsburgh in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Tennis Results
description: U.S. CLAY 35ER

title: MILTON H. MEYERS
description: WATERBURY, Conn., July 29 (AP)Milton H. Meyers, a state judge for 21 years, died at Waterbury Hospital last night after suffering a stroke at his home last week. He was 70 years old.

title: Baseball Box Scores and Standings
European Declaration
description: Excerpts from the declaration of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. which will be signed on Friday in Helsinki, Finland, appear on Page 8.

title: S.E.C. MAY OPPOSE BIG BOARD PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, indicated today that the S.E.C. seriously questioned a proopsal that would decrease the influence of the public members of the New York Stock Exchange's board of directors.

title: Senate Votes to Authorize Use of Navy's Reserve Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Senate voted today to authorize production of oil from the naval petroleum reserves in California and Wyoming, chiefly the Elk Hills Reserve near Taft, Calif.

title: About Education
description: Can the City University afford to continue as a freetuition institution and admit any high school graduate who takes the time to file an application?

title: French Urged Surveillance of Model in Drug Case
description: Three months before a Syracuse businessman accused his estranged young wife of using her worldwide modeling assignments to become an international narcotics trafficker, she was cited by the French police for living on the Caribbean island of St. Martin with a convicted smuggler believed to be dealing in narcotics, a State Senate hearing was told yesterday.

title: POUND REACTING MILDLY TO COUP
description: LONDON, July 29  Early reaction in the British financial community to reports of the coup in Nigeria was surprisingly mild in view of the battering the pound has suffered from less dramatic events in recent months.

title: European Declaration
description: Excerpts from the declaration of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which will be signed on Friday in Helsinki, Finland, appear on Page 8.

title: Mayor Praises New Traffic Plan for Garment Center
description: Mayor Beame made a brief escape yesterday from the city's labor and financial woes to inspect the flow of traffic in the garment center.

title: Net Sets Mark at WarnerLambert Co.
description: Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the WarnerLambert Company for the three and six months ended June 30. Profits were up 12 and 11.3 per cent for the respective periods, the company's report disclosed.

title: Radio
Sawhill Learning Bitter Fiscal Lessons as New Head of N.Y.U.
description: John Sawhill stepped from the brigh sunlight on Washington Square South into the cool shadow outside New York University's towering Bobst Library.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: MAYOR POSTPONES FISCAL PLAN A DAY; TALKS CONTINUING
description: Mayor Beame said last night that he had delayed imposing his adtion plan  including a wage freeze  until today after Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employes Union, citing hope for progress in the negotiations, requested the delay.

title: 2 Pesticides Banned
description: The Environmental Protection Agency banned further production and sale of two widely used pesticides, chlordane and heptachlor, because they are suspected of causing cancer. Page 34.

title: American Motor Inns Cites Gain in Holiday Inns Suit
description: American Motor Inns, Inc.. announced yesterday that a settlement reached yesterday in its litigation against Holiday Inns, Inc., will net it about$4.56millions.

title: I.M.M. Seeks Listing Change
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (Reuters) The International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today, it had filed an application with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission seeking permission to list a futures market in 90day Treasury bills. The I.M.M.'s chairman, Leo Melamed, said the 90day bill was chosen over other shortterm, interest bearing instruments because of its uniform quality and liquidity.

title: Xerox Settlement Is Approved by F.T.C
description: An order designed to end the Xerox Corporation's dominance of the officercopier field was given final approval yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Venezuela's Earnings Rise
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 30 (Reuters)Venezuela earned a record total of $5.21billion in the first six months of this year, bringing the country's foreign exchange reserves to $8.64billion at the end of June, the Central Bank reported today. This compares with $4.42billion during the similar period last year. Reserves at the end of June, 1974, totaled $4.55billion.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
