description: The Town of Greenburgh, faced with dissension in its police force as a result of recent investigations into alleged corruption, has decided to replace Police Chief William Halstead, who resigned recently, with a commissioner selected from outside the force's ranks. A spokesman for the Town Board said that Chief Halstead would be replaced, since Greenburgh law requires the job to be filled and from within the ranks, but state officials said the town could also enact a local law establishing a commissioner's post higher than that of the Chief's.

title: Another Particle Believed Discovered
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., July 30Physicists at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center and the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory believe they have discovered a new elementary particle.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its letest report on changes in stock ownership by leading directors, officers and stockholders of its lifted companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make an insider's report available. The Amex report includes the following:

title: Gasoline Scarcity Continues Remote
description: With what is considered to be sufficient supplies in inventory, the possibility of a gasoline shortage continues to be remote, according to weekly statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Professor Cleared Of Drug Conspiracy In U.S. Court Here
description: An argriculturaljournalism professor at the University of Wisconsin was acquitted yesterday of drug charges after 75 minutes of deliberation by a Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn.

title: False Alarms, Up by 36%, Now Exceed Valid Calls
description: Confronted by a 36 per cent increase in false fire alarms this year, Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the manpowerstrapped Fire Department might soon stop responding to voice boxes which have a high percentage of fake calls.

title: Philadelphia Jobless Aid Up
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) Unemployment offices in the Philadelphia area processed 265,000 public aid claims last week, the largest number for any week since the depression of the nineteenthirties, the Bureau of Employment Security said today.

title: Clean Sweep Precedes Beame Visit to Midtown
description: While street cleaning has been slashed more than 50 per cent by the Sanitation Department since the layoff of 14 per cent of its workforce, the southwest corner of 42d street and the Avenue of the Americas was not neglected yesterday.

title: Da Vinci for Mayor
description: The years ahead will see rebirth in this city. Or they will be spent in its final decay. But despair is inconsistent with our future. If we are truly New Yorkers, accepting the challenge is our only courseThe fact is that the hardiness of the city and its people overwhelmingly favors renaissance.

title: Steward at British Show Rules With Tight Leash
description: Next February, Westminster will hold its 100th dog show, making it one of the oldest consecutively run sports events in America. However, the National Dog Show in Birmingham, England, staged its 103d fixture last May, though its shows were not in succession.

title: Detroit Authorities Move To Keep Unrest in Check
description: Philip G. Tannian, the chief of police, has ordered his force of 4,500 to go on two 12how shifts instead of the normal three eighthour shifts. The move will make more men available in an emegency.

title: Personal Finance: Revocable Trusts
description: Jane J. is a recent widow whose husband managed all of their financial affairs before his death. Harry P. owns a small business that demands his constant supervision. Sally L., who just graduated from college, has received a substantial inheritance.

title: New Hampshire Replay
description: It took seven months of battling; but reason finally won out yesterday in the United States Senate. The Senate Democratic majority accepted the fact that it could not force acceptance of the Democratic nominee as the winner in the closelycontested New Hampshire election. Bath Democrats and Republicans in the Senate had been playing political games: but the Senate vote yesterday at last declaring the New Hampshire seat vacant, left the way open for what was the best solution all along, a new election in the Granite State.

title: Drug Charges for Chemist
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) A chemist at Rohm and Haas, a chemical concern faces charges of manufacturing an illegal drug at the company's research laboratories in suburban Springhouse. The Chemist, Napoleon L. Horton, was arraigned yesterday before a United States magistrate, along with four other Philadelphians.

title: Premier Ousted in 1967 Testifies at Greek Trial
description: ATHENS, July 30When a handful of army officers seized power in Greece on April 21, 1967, King Constantine was urged by his Premier to resist the junta by relying on the loyal officers who were in the majority. The King declined for fear of bloodshed and, as a result, Greece was under a military dictatorship for seven years.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: CHRYSLER EXPECTS ITS LOSS TO GROW
description: DETROIT, July 30Top executives of the Chrysler Corporation said today the automobile company would show a greater loss in the third quarter than the $58.7million loss it reported yesterday for the second quarter of 1975. But they said they hoped Chrysler would show a profit again in the fourth Quarter.

title: Seven Persons Are Honored Here As  Outstanding Senior Citizens
description: At this point of difficulty for the Big Apple, you are its chief resource, City Council President Paul O'Dwyer told New York's oustanding senior citizens of the year at a ceremony yesterday honoring four award winners and three runnersup.

title: Man Sets Himself on Fire, Leaps to Death in Ft. Greene
description: A 25yearold Brooklyn man apparently doused himself with kerosene last night, set himself on fire and jumped to his death from the roof of a 14story apartment building, the police reported.

title: Alfa Romeo Plans Layoff
description: MILAN, Italy, July 30(AP) Alfa Romeo, the Italian auto manufacturer, announced today that it would lay off for one week 17,500 workers in its Arose factory, near here, to recluce its stocks of unsold cars. Workers will be laidoff the first week of September, thus adding an extra week to their summer vacation.

title: 35 States Meet in Helsinki To Insure Peace in Europe
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 The largest summit conference in European history opened here today with the avowed aim of assuring permanent peace on a continent that once knew war every generation.

title: Loss for Nigeria
description: In many countries of black Africa a military coup may be regrettable but not catastrophic either for the people directly affected or for other states in the area. But the overthrow of Gen. Yakubu Gowon in Nigeriawith a population more than double that of the next largest African country and impressive reserves of both natural and human resourcesis likely to prove fateful both for Nigerians and for their neighbors.

title: Open Interest
Met to Stay Open Late Thursdays
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will keep its doors open to the public one evening a week, Thursday evening, beginning Aug. 7, thanks to the receipt of matching grants of $140,000 each from the Billy Rose Foundation, Inc., and Mrs. Ruth Lapham Lloyd of Darien, Conn.

title: All Smiles in Jet Camp As Namath Signs, Drills
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 30His voice hoarse, his slouch the same, his presence still overpowering, Joe Namath returned to the Jets today.

title: Times Declares Dividend
SevenYear Notes Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Treasury sold $2billion of sevenyear notes today at an average rate of 8.14 per cent. Tenders received amounted to $3.7billion. Accepted tenders included 20 per cent of the bids at the highest yield.

title: Nigeria's New Head of State
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 30  The 38yearold professional soldier who now heads the Government of black Africa's largest and richest nation faces the difficult task, in a country where tribal and regional affiliations remain a vital and compelling part of everyday and official life, of convincing the Nigerians that they are one people.

title: U. S. Judge Orders Full Desegregation Of Louisville Schools
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 30 (AP)A Federal judge ordered the full desegregation of Louisville area schools today and made public a plan to bus 22,600 pupils.

title: Democratic Hopefuls' Offices Sprout in Capital Area
description: WASHINGTON, July 30A detailed plan to seize control of the executive branch of the Federal Government is being painstakingly assembled in the paneled library and downstairs game room of a modest colonial home in the Virginia suburbs.

title: Africans, Needing Oil, Weigh U.N. Ban on Israel
description: GENEVA, July 30African nations, seeking concessions from Middle East oil producers, are privately discussing how they will use their votes on the issue of expelling Israel from the United Nations at the General Assembly session in New York this fall, according to western diplomats here.

title: U.S. NOTE AUCTION HAS BRISK BIDDING
description: Aggressive bidding once again marked the Treasury's auction of notes yesterday, which dominated the markets for both Government and corporate debt issues. The Treasury's sale of $2billion of seven notes produced an average rate of 8.14 per cent, somewhat lower than the dealers had expected earlier in the week. More than $3.7billion in tenders were received for the notes.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate ?? in effect, the nomination of martin R. Hoffmann as Secretary of the Army yesterday. Because of a procedural technicality however, the nomination must go through another vote today. Mr. Hoffmann has been general counsel to the Defense Department and was formerly counsel to the Atomic Energy Committee.

title: Popularity Perils Chincoteague Isle
description: CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., July 30Much of fife is still governed on this marshy Atlantic isle by the ebb and flow of the tide.

title: JAMES BLISH, 54, WRITER, IS DEAD
description: LONDON, July 30James Blish, the sciencefiction writer, died today in his home at HenleyonThames, Oxfordshire, after a long illness. He was 54 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CARUSO ALFRESCO Aug. 2, 1921, was a sad day for the music world  Enrico Caruso died. In tribute to the Italian tenor a free, 90minute program of Caruso recordings and commentary will be presented tomorrow night at 7 o'clock at Carroll Park in Brooklyn, at Carroll and President Streets (between Court and Smith Streets). The closest subway stop is the IND Carroll Street station, serviced by the F and GG trains. Sponsoring the 90minute concert are the Carroll Gardens Association and the Committee to Improve Carroll Park.

title: GAIN IS REPORTED IN FUSION SEARCH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 30A major experimental advance was reported here today in the search for a way to control thermonuclear fusion so that it could be used as a new source of energy.

title: 5 North Vietnamese Arrive Here as U.N. Observers
description: A fiveman North Vietnamese delegation of observers to the United Nations was greeted by welcomers and protesters when it arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday.

title: Western States and the Role of Federal Government
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 30In 1907, an Oregon Senator fumed against Federal actions in the West: I deny that it is vise public policy that the Government shall engage in business within the limits of a state.

title: Suit Says Pregnancy Bars Jobless Pay
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and the New York Civil Liberties Union filed a classaction Federal suit here yesterday, charging the State Department of Labor with discrimination against pregnant women who were denied unemploymentinsurance benefits on the ground that they were unavailable for employment.

title: Applause Meter Gets a Workout At Saint Laurent
description: PARIS, July 30Next fall, you wear your blouse over your skirt, not tucked into it, hear? Who says so? Yves Saint Laurent, of course. And you know about him. What Yves wants, he generally gets. Oh, other designers had the same idea. Pierre Cardin, for one. Angelo Tarlazzi at Patou for another. But they didn't do it the same way, they didn't show it so many times and, to be honest, they didn't think it out so carefully or do it so well. Then, they didn't have the exposure. There in the front row of Saint Laurent's new salon on the Avenue Marceau were a dozen or so of the most fashionable women in the world, looking beautiful in the stultifying heat and paying rapt attention. They're the women Vogue's Alexander Lieberman called the women of the moment, the ones who count. Each one was dressed differently, he observed.

title: Geysers of Protest for Nebraska Art
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  When John W. Warner, administrator of the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration, visited here last spring he observed that one of the characteristics of the Bicentennial is that it brings communities and diverse factions together.

title: 35 States Meet in Helsinki To Insure Peace in Europe
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 The largest summit conference in European history opened here today with the avowed aim of assuring permanent peace on a continent that once knew war every generation.

title: Assembly Unit Releases Bill on Low Milk Prices
description: TRENTON, July 30The Asembly Agriculture and Environment Committee released a number of bills today, including a consumer measure designed to keep the price of milk as low as possible and another bill that would significantly reduce air quality emission standards for industries in the state state.

title: July's Price Upturn
description: The specter of doubledigit inflation, which seemed to have vanished earlier this year, came hack to haunt the country during the long, languid days of July. No sooner had the bot tom of the deep recession been reached than bad news for consumers once more began to ripple out of Washingtonbad news that to many sounded eerily like the bad news of a few years ago.

title: U.N. Conference Is Moved From Toronto to Geneva
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 (Reuters)  A General Assembly committee decided today to move the site of the fifth United Nations Congress on Crime and the Treatment of Offenders, in which the Palestine Liberation Organization will take part, from Toronto to Geneva.

title: FORD, IN FINLAND, MEETS BREZHNEV ON ARMS ISSUES
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 30President Ford and Leonid Brezhnev, here for the opening of the European security conference, held today what President Ford termed very constructive talks on strategic weapons but reached no specific agreements on means to limit nuclear arms.

title: Wood. Field & Stream: Fishing
description: NAGS HEAD, N. C.When the boats of the Oregon Inlet charter fleets return in late afternoonmany of them having been 40 miles or more offshore in the Gulfstreamhordes of people, mostly tourists, crowd the docks to look at the fish the mates unload.

title: $1 Tolls on Bridges On the East River Are Under Study
description: A proposal to charge $1 a round trip on East River bridges will be on the agenda today as the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority meets to work out measures to increase its transit and commuter rail revenue.

title: Masked Holdup Men Steal Gems From Suite at Hilton Convention
description: Taking advantage of a jewelry convention, three armed men, two of them wearing masks, walked into a suite of the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday morning, handcuffed 10 people, and stole at least $50,000 worth of jewels being displayed by a Boston firm.

title: Perfection Impossible, But Parents Still Seek It
description: There is no such thing as the perfect parent, Dr. Vincent J. Fontana, medical director of the New York Foundling Hospital Center for Parent and Child Development, repeatedly told the audience at a seminar entitled A Life to Share.

title: Contract Award
Brooklyn Boy Scout, 14, Drowns in Lake at Camp
description: A 14yearold Eagle Scout from Brooklyn drowned yesterday in a lake at the Ten Mile River Scout Camps in Narrowsburg, N.Y.

title: DEMOCRATS MIXED ON FED GUIDANCE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Democrats on the House Banking Committee failed to agree lin caucuses yesterday and today on a proposed report aimed at giving guidance to the Federal Reserve Board on monetary policy.

title: U. S. Is Suing a Washington Law Firm For Files as a Representative of Guinea
description: WASHINGTON. July 30The Justice Department brought suit today against Covington & Burling, a prestigious law firm here, to force it to let Government officials inspect records dealing with the firm's representation of the Republic of Guinea.

title: Assembly Majority Agrees On $111 Million Tax Bills
description: TRENTON, July 30The Assembly's Democratic majority agreed today on a package of tax bills designed to raise $111million and complete financing of a $267million restoration of programs cut from the state budget for economy reasons.

title: Ballet: New Coppelia
description: Who is Dr. Coppellus in that very familiar ballet, Copplia? He is, first, the creator of automatawhich is not a place to eat but a collection of mechanical figures. The tendency has been to depict him as a comic eccentric in most productions, and as a Gothic figure in others.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Pele Out, Cosmos Still Win
description: Playing without Pele, the New York Cosmos dominated the Rochester Lancers at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, last night and came away with a 20 victory before 8,217 fans.

title: Man Sets Himself on Fire, Leaps to Death in Ft. Greene
description: A 25yearold Brooklyn man apparently doused himself with kerosene last night, set himself on fire and jumped to his death from the roof of a 14story apartment building, the police reported.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, emerged from their first meeting at the European security conference in Helsinki to call their discussion constructive. They reached no specific agreements on nuclear arms limitation. Mr. Ford also held private meetings with Prime Minister Harold. Wilson of Great Britain and Premier Constantine Caramanlis of Greece. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: KOSNER APPOINTED NEWSWEEK EDITOR
description: Edward Kosner, managing editor of Newsweek, has been named editor of the magazine, effective Sept. 1. He succeeds Osborn Elliott, who has been named editorinchief.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Diamond M Drilling Company said yesterday it planned to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission by midAugust in connection with an offering of 400.000 common shares. Net proceeds from the offering, the company said, would be used to repay outstanding debt.

title: Article 1  No Title
Advertising
description: The Youngs Drug Products Corporation, a leading manufacturer of condoms, has begun a major effort to get that product category accepted for general television advertising. Currently all contraceptive advertising is forbidden by the Television and Radio Codes of the National Association of Broadcasters, a selfregulatory body.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Dave Anderson
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 30Joe Namath had been demanding $500,000 annually on a twoyear contract while the New York Jets were offering $400,000, but the financier in him finally surrendered to the quarterback in him. Go and do the deal, he told his attorney, Jimmy Walsh, over the weekend. Get it done so I can get, in camp.

title: M.A.C. BONDS RISE; REACTION IS MIXED
description: Bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation rose sharply in price yesterday as dealers indicated that many investors had been encouraged by news reports of progress in the city's efforts to untangle its fiscal affairs.

title: Harrell, Cellist, Star of Mostly Mozart
description: In between their orchestral appearances Monday night and last night, Byron Jams and Lynn Harrell made room for a chamber concert Tuesday in the Mostly Mozart series at Avery Fisher Hall. And just as Mr. Harrell had been more favorably received for his Monday efforts than had Mr. Janis, so did Mr. Harrell prove the more convincing artist Tuesday.

title: Sets Triumph, Stay Near First
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., July 30 The New York Sets gained ground in their World Team Tennis struggle for first place in the East by beating the Indiana Loves, 2918, before 2,021 fans in Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Inquiry on Dr. King Death Encli; Conspiracy Not Substantiated
description: ATLANTA, July 30  The city's Public Safety Commissioner, A. Reginald Eaves, said today that a report that his department received concerning a conspiracy to assassinate the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. could not be substantiated during a department inquiry.

title: Farm Is Accused of Hiring Children Under Legal Age
description: BRIDGETON, July 30Court appointed investigators reported finding violations of state and Federal farm labor laws in South Jersey today, including the employment of children under 12 years of age to pick tomatoes.

title: The Turkish Bases: A Turning Point in Ties With U. S.
description: ANKARA, Turkey July 30After Congress had voted to uphold the arms embargo against Turkey, and Ankara responded by suspending activities at American bases, a columnist in the Istanbul newspaper Milliyet wrote:

title: Eastern Airlines to Offer $150 San Juan Round Trip
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) Eastern Air Lines will offer a $150 roundtrip discount fare between New York and San Juan P R.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey's second highest court refused to halt the roundtheclock flight of jet aircraft at Morristown Municipal Airport. The Appellate Division of the Superior Court, rejecting an appeal from residents of three communities who complained about noise from the jets, said the Federal Government alone had the authority to regulate aircraft noise.

title: 2 ARE ARRAIGNED IN AIRPORT THEFT
description: Two men were arraigned in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday in connection with the, theft of a shipment of ancient artifacts en route from Cairo to the home of a professor of archeology in Chicago.

title: House Clears Way for Increases in Pay For Congress, Judges and Executives
description: WASHINGTON, July 30Amid shouts and catcalls and with lastminute switching of votes, the House cleared the way today for a costofliving pay increase for members of Congress, Federal judges and top Government executives.

title: The Dance: After a Gala
description: What do you do after a gala? The bouquets are wilted, and the compliments have evaporated into the thinnest of thin air. So you sit around contemplating, philosophically one trusts, the stale baked meats and the promises of yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Taxing advantage of a jewelry convention, three armed men, two of them wearing masks, walked into a suite at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday morning, handcuffed 10 people, and stole at least $50,000 worth of jewels being displayed by a Boston firm.

title: Sawhill Learning Bitter Fiscal Lessons as New Head of N. Y.
description: John Sawhill stepped from the bright sunlight on Washington Square South into the cool shadow outside New York University's towering Bobst Library.

title: SAFETY AID URGED BY AIRLINE PILOTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Air Line Pilots Association today told a House subcommittee hearing on air safety that there was a major need for installing windshear detectors in airliner cockpits to cut down on approach and landing accidents.

title: Popularity Perils Chincoteague Isle
description: CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., July 30Much of life is still governed on this marshy Atlantic isle by the ebb and flow of the tide.

title: FORD, IN FINLAND, MEETS BREZHNEV ON ARMS ISSUES
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 30President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, here for the opening of the European security conference, held today what Presi dent Ford termed very constructive talks on strategic weapons but reached no specific agreements on means to limit nuclear arms.

title: U.S. READY TO OPEN TALKS ON CUBA TIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The State Department said today it was prepared to open serious discussions with Cuba on the normalization of relations, but urged Congress not to tamper with the United States trade embargo against the island.

title: False Alarms Up by 36%, Now Exceed Valid Calls
description: Confronted by a 36 per cent increase in false fire alarms this year. Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the manpowerstrapped Fire Department might soon stop responding to voice boxes which have a high percentage of take calls.

title: Gurney Jury Still Out
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 30 (AP)After an exchange of notes with the judge, a Federal jury in the influence peddling case against former Senator Edward J. Gurney recessed today, failing to reach a verdict in its third day of deliberations. Contents of the notes were not disclosed, but Federal District Court Judge Ben Krentzman scheduled a meeting with opposing attorneys tomorrow morning.

title: FARM IN JERSEY CITED ON ABUSES
description: BRIDGETON, July 30Court appointed investigators reported finding violations of state and Federal farm labor laws in South Jersey today, including the employment of children under 12 years of age to pick tomatoes.

title: Slain Women's Neighbors Seem Resigned to Violence
description: Residents of a Bronx neighborhood where two elderly women were murdered in the last week seemed resigned yesterday to the violence that has taken over their area.

title: The 35 Represented At Helsinki Gathering
People and Business
description: Attorney General Edward H. Levi says he has hired one of the best antitrust lawyers in the countrynamely meto determine whether the Justice Department should bring suit in the Federal courts against the Arab oilproducing countries for conspiring to fix oil prices.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JULY 31, 1975

title: Behind the Scenes, Active Negotiations
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 30In between solemn public pledges to improve EastWest, relations, the leaders of govern ment assembled here are trading tough language in private on the problems of Europe.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Strengthen Role Of States and U.S. on Off shore Oil Leases
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 After nearly eight hours of debate, much of it heated, the Senate passed a bill late tonight that would radically change the oil and gas leasing procedures on the outer continental shelf. It would enable the Federal Government to get more information on its resources there from private industry and provide funds for coastal states to deal with the effects of development programs.

title: Court Rules Unit of I.T.T. Violated Raychem Patent
description: BOSTON. July 30 (AP)A division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation violated a wire patent of the Raychem Corporation of Menlo Park, Calif., a Federal Judge ruled yesterday.

title: GRAIN SALE IMPACT ASSESSED BY SIMON
description: WASHINGTON, July 30Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today that he did not believe the amount of wheat sold thus far to the Soviet Union would affect domestic grain prices, but he acknowledged that further sales, and unfavorable crops, could have an impact.

title: Model Denies at Inquiry Charges of Drug Traffic
description: Patricia Richardson Martinson, an international model, testified before a State Senate committee yesterday that she had never been involved in drug traffic and that her former husband had made several attempts on her life. She also disputed a previous witness who said that she had offered him $50,000 to murder her former husband.

title: F. LOVELL BIXBY, PENOLOGIST, DIES
description: F. Lovell Bixby, a prominent penologist who in the nineteenthirties formulated and put into operation a classification program for individualized treatment and care of offenders in Ian Federal prisons and reformatories, died Tuesday of cancer at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 74 years old.

title: Westchester Field Is Good, Not Great
description: HARRISON. N. Y., July 30 What kind of golf tournament can you run without the likes of Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Lee Trevino?

title: Triple. Pays $11,295 at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30Victories by lowpriced favorites in the divided Test Stakes and a longshot triple that paid $11,295 for $2 provided an afternoon of parimutuel contrasts today. Hot n Nasty ($4.80) and My Juliet ($4.40) were the solid winners in the 50th running of the Test, a sevenfurlong event for 3yearold fillies. Hot n Nasty, ridden by Jorge Tejeira, took the $32,775 first division by 2 lengths over A Charm and My Juliet, with Jacinto Vasquez up, scored by 2 lengths over Slip Screen in the $32,650 second division. The winning time in each case was 1:22.

title: More Capital Formation
description: The New York Stock Exchange and other business groups are mounting a major effort to convince Congress and the nation that tax cuts and tax breaks for savers and investors are needed to prevent an enormous capital shortage that would cripple the nation's economic growth. The trouble with their argument is that there is no capital shortage now. On the contrary, there is a surfeit of funds looking for investment.

title: NEW ELECTION DUE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30After nearly 100 hours of debate over 30 days and 35 inconclusive rollcall votes, the Senate declared today its inability to settle last November's disputed Senate election in New Hampshire and sent the matter back to the state.

title: Earnings Down 28.6%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday a 28.6 per cent drop in secondquarter net income as total revenues slipped 3.7 per cent. However, both net income and sales for the first half ran ahead of the corresponding 1974 period, thanks to a strong first quarter.

title: Crime Figure Guilty In the Theft of Files From F.B.I. Offices
description: NEWARK, July 30 (UPI)John DiGilio, a reputed Mafia enforcer, and two associates were convicted tonight of conspiracy and stealing Federal Bureau of Investigation files. A third reputed associate was found not guilty.

title: Edited by Lawyers
description: LONDON  American editors and publishers are rightly sensitive to anything that looks like an infringement of their freedom. But before their next speech about the First Amendment, some of them would do well to visit Britain. They might find out how relatively well off they are at home, in terms of freedom.

title: Scouts Gather in Norway
description: LILLEHAMMER, Norway, July 30 (UPI)The 14th international World Scout Jamboree opened today in this resort town in central Norway With 15.000 scouts participating, including 2,500 Americans.

title: Tito's Caper
description: DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia  Delicious capers, pickled in vinegar, enhance the flavor of smoked salmon, make piquant the taste of steak tartare, and add spice to life in general.

title: Daughter of Senator Scott Arrested in Narcotics Raid
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 30 (UPI)  Marian Concannon, daughter of Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate minority leader, was arrested in a narcotics raid today and accused of selling $100 worth of hashish to an undercover agent.

title: Lien Holder Buys Complex Dropped By Ft. Lee Builder
description: HACKENSACK, July 30The C. I. Mortgage Group, holder of a first lien on the uncompleted Colony North highrise apartments in Fort Lee, bought outright control of the complex at a courtordered auction here today with a bid of $20.750,000.

title: Caso to Aid Woman Asking for a Leave To Adopt Children
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 30A Nassau County woman police officer who was denied permission for maternity leave in order to adopt two Korean children because she would not be the natural mother, was told by the County Executive today that he was optimistic that the problem could be resolved in her favor.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW DECLINES
description: Selling by nervous traders dominated markets for wheat, corn and soybeans yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, along with a large amount of selling by farmers through grain elevator companies.

title: Joan Little Jury Is Told Of Slain Jailer's Injuries
description: RALEIGH, N.C. July 30Medical testimony continued to dominate the murder trial of Joan Little today as Dr. Charles F. Gilbert, a state regional pathologist, gave illustrated testimony about the wound that had caused the death of Clarence Alligood, the jailer Miss Little is accused of killing.

title: Agnew Son's Trial Put Off
description: BALTIMORE, July 30 (UPI) The trial of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's son, James R. Agnew, 27 years old, on trespassing charges in an alleged peeping Tom incident was postponed today in local district court.

title: Nessen Says Jack Anderson Conned Ford
description: Ron Nessen, White House press secretary, said he and President Ford had been conned into giving Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, a 30minute television interview with the President without having it made clear in the beginning that Mr. Anderson had no prearranged agreement for the program to be shown or that the interview was being done on spec (speculation).

title: Member of Portugal Junta Talks of Hard Repression
description: LISBON, July 30Portugal's security chief, a member of the threeman junta, warned opponents of the military Government today that they faced repressive measures.

title: Businessman Convicted in Bribery Case
description: A businessman was convicted in a bribery case yesterday by a Federal judge who criticized the prosecution for using a corrupt and evil man as a key undercover informant.

title: AMEX STOCK RISE ENDS 10DAY DROP
description: After 10 consecutive sessions in which American Stock Exchange prices declined, the Amex's index rose 0.27 yesterday to close at 89.96. At the start of the 10day decline the index stood at 96.86.

title: Dow Advances 6.80 in Light Trading
description: Prices closed higher on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in what brokers described as a largely technical upturn.

title: JEFFERSON'S TASTE IS CONCERT THEME
description: The Washington Square Bicentennial Music Festival hit upon an interesting theme for its second concert this summer on Tuesday night: All the works on the program were drawn from the music library of Thomas Jefferson.

title: A War Ends . . .
description: The 11year economic war between Cuba and the rest of the hemisphere has officially ended with neither side entitled to claim victory, vindication or anything other than relief that it's over. After tedious months of parliamentary and political maneuver, the Organization of American States has now voted to abolish the tottering system of political and economic sanctions against Cuba imposed collectively in 1964. The United States trade boycott, dating from three years earlier, remains in forcefor the time being.

title: Market Place
description: Some followers of Texas Instruments are puzzled because shares of this popular glamour stock dropped 912 points last weekdays before the company announced disappointing three  month earnings.

title: The Aussians Are Buying!
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The reappearance of Soviet grain purchasers in American markets is a remarkable testimony to the rapidity of international economic change.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 NURSING HOMES GET CLOSING STAY
description: Eugene Hollander, the nutsinghome operator, obtained stay until Aug. 7 of an order that would have closed, two of his homes today, because of structural and operational deficiencies.

title: Ruth and Jaworski Say They Oppose Plan for Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) Henry S. Ruth Jr., the special Watergate prosecutor, and his predecessor, Leon Jaworski, said today that they opposed establishing a permanent special prosecutor to investigate and try Government crime.

title: Broadcasters Warned On Load Commercials
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission warned broadcasters today that it was their responsibility to soften objectionable loud commercials instead of making annoyed listeners do it.

title: Mets Beaten by Cardinals, 52
description: ST. LOUIS, July 30A funny thing happened tonight at Busch Stadium. A pitcher pitched a complete. game. But it was not so funny to the New York Mets, who lost, 52, the victims of the St. Louis Cardinals and John Curtis, the Cardinals' lefthander.

title: Shell Ship, Without Symbol, Seeks Oil Off Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 30 To keep what one Shell Oil Company executive calls a low profile until we can explain ourselves, the company's offshore oil exploration ship, the Phaedra, glided quietly out to sea here yesterday without the goldandred corporate insignia that usually adorn her twin stacks.

title: In Memoriam
description: ACKIRONJoan One year today. May your slumber be blessed, my darling Joanie.

title: Books of The Times
description: Philip Agee's Inside the Company is not a diary of nearly 10 years with the Central Intelligence Agency, as the subtitle might suggest. As he explains in the foreword, the diary form is a device to organize his material. What Mr. Agee has done is to reconstruct the events he experienced from memory and supplemental research. Thus the book is more history than diary, with large chunks of material on the political, social and economic backgrounds for events he observed as an operations officer in Ecuador, Uruguay and Mexico from 1960 through 1968.

title: U.S. Report on Smoking Seeks A Ban on HighTar Cigarettes
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)  The Ford Administration, submitting the ninth Government report on smoking and health to Congress, has asked for the power to ban hightar and highnicotine cigarettes.

title: A.P. Line Is Restored by India After Being Shut Down 2 Days
description: NEW DELHI, July 30 (AP)The Indian Government today restored The Associated Press teleprinter link with London, ending a 61hour shutdown ordered because of official objections to the news agency's dispatches.

title: The Big Hat Crime in Connecticut
description: The law is the law in Connecticut, apparently even when it comes to the number of creases in a cop's hat.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS NEW NAVY PLANE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30A House subcommittee gave its approval today, by a 7to5 vote, to the Navy's controversial, $6billion program to build the F18 as its new low cost fighter plane.

title: Tourists Flocking to City Despite Its Fiscal Woes
description: Tourists interested in seeing New York City have not been deterred by its fiscal problems.

title: Reds Snap Pitching Streak
description: Sparky Anderson, manager of the Cincinnati Reds, watched his rookie righthander, Pat Darcy, hurl his first complete game in the major leagues last night, ending Cincinnati's major league record streak of 45 incomplete games by the pitching staff.

title: First Fighting Reported South of Angola Capital
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 30 (Reuters)Fighting has erupted in the port of Novo Redondo, 200 miles south of this capital, according to a Portuguese military communiqu.

title: $15Million Fire in Miami
description: MIAMI, July 30 (AP)A fire swept through a cardboard box factory owned by Simkins Industries near Miami Internaing an estimated total of $15million in damage but no tional Airport yesterday, causinjuries.

title: American League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: No Collusion Found On Gasoline Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 30Assistant Attorney General Thomas E. Kauper said today that the Justice Department's antitrust division, which he heads, had so far uncovered no evidence of collusion in connection with the July 4th increase in wholesale gasoline prices.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH FORESEEN BY INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, July 30The Indian Government today published a generally glowing report on the economy, concluding that this poor and troubled country was now poised for a major phase of rapid economic expansion.

title: NASSAU WILL SUE ON POLICE RAISES
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 30Nassau County will ask the State Supreme Court on Friday to set aside the 12.3 per cent salary and fringebenefit increase awarded to the county police and seek a rehearing on the contract dispute, Ralph G. Caso, the County Executive, said today.

title: Three Linked to Nursing Home Are Accused of Medicaid Fraud
description: TRENTON, July 30 (AP)The state obtained today the first indictments of nursinghome operators for Medicaid fraud, charging the owners of a Wayne nursing home and their accountant with conspiring to get Medicaid money to pay for personal expenses.

title: NEW ELECTION DUE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30After nearly 100 hours of debate over 30 days and 35 inconclusive rollcall votes, the Senates declared today its inability to settle last November's disputed Senate election in New Hampshire and sent the matter back to the state.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Maheu Says He Recruited Man For C.I.A. in Castro Poison Plot
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Robert A. Maheu, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and former aide to Howard R. Hughes, said today that he had recruited a Mafia figure for the Central Intelligence Agency in a plot to poison Fidel Castro, Premier of Cuba.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday about the acquisition of the Copper Range Company by Amax, Inc., the net income of Amax last year was incorrectly stated. Amax earned $148.4million on revenues of $1.16billion.

title: An AvantGarde Play and Other Places to Take Children
Carey Starts 2Day Tour Of Western Part of State
description: FREDONIA, N.Y., July 30Governor Carey inspected grapevines and fire engines, had lunch with the elderly, dedicated a hospital building and fielded questions from dairy farmers today at the start of a twoday trip through western New York that had all the trappings of a campaign swing as well as the folksiness of a refreshing day in the country.

title: Business Briefs
description: MexicanKuwaiti Investment Deal Set

title: Ethiopia Is Said to Seal Off Eritrea City After Fighting
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 30 (AP) Ethiopian troops have reportedly sealed off the capital of Eritrea province following an upsurge in fighting with secessionist guerrillas in the area.

title: Mrs. Ford, Feeling Marvelous, Shops in Helsinki
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 (UPI)Betty Ford, declaring I feel marvelous, did some sightseeing and shopping today and briskly hiked no a hill.

title: U.S. WEIGHS RULES ON JOB SENIORITY
description: ATLANTA, July 30The new chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission disclosed today that the Federal agency was considering issuing guidelines in the highly controversial area of job seniority and minority claims of last hired, first fired.

title: East Orange Officer Indicted In Shooting of Honor Student
description: NEWARK July 30 (UPI)A suspended East Orange policeman was indicted today on charges of murdering an 18yearold honors student during an argument two weeks ago.

title: Parkin Oregon Is Reopened; Authorities Call Water Safe
description: CRATER LAKE NATIONAL PARK, Ore., July 30 (UPI)Crater Lake National Park, closed since July 11 because of a contaminated water supply, will reopen Friday, park officials said today; they added that the Crater Lake Lodge and one campground would remain closed because of limited water supplies.

title: Trabert Davis Cup Captain
description: Tony Trabert was named captain of the Davis Cup tennis team yesterday, but Jimmy Connors, who was not present at the announcement here, grabbed the spotlight.

title: Attendant Arrested In Alleged Beating Of Willowbrook Boy
description: An attendant at the Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island, charged with having beaten a 9yearold resident shortly before the boy died July 15, was arrested yesterday.

title: Finnish Police Tighten Security For Visiting Leaders, but Gently
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 30The police here have responded gently but firmly to the first signs of political protest against the summitlevel conclusion of the European security conference that opened today.

title: Chess:
description: Emanuel Lasker, the world champion from 1894 to 1921. exhibited an unusual preference for the classical exchange variation of the Ruv Lopez: 1 PK4, PK4. 2, NKB3. NQB3: 3 BK5, PQR3: 4 BxN. QPxB: 5 PQ4. PxP; 6 QxP, QxQ: 7 NxQ.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Jay Presson Allen, the playwrightscenarist, has sold movie rights to her first novel, Just Tell Me What You Want, to Warner Bros. for $500,000, according to a company spokesman. Mrs. Allen, who wrote the hit plays Forty Carats and The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie, as well as the movie scripts for Jean Brodie, Cabaret, Funny Lady and Mamie, will adapt her novel to the screen.

title: Brezhnev, Feeling Ill, Leaves Dinner Party
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Thursday, July 31 (UPI)  Leonid I. Brezhnev left a dinner party given by President Urho Kekkonen of Finland at the European security conference here last night after complaining that he was not feeling well.

title: . . . by Upward Thrust
description: It would of course be far better if the savings of private individuals and institutions were put to work in new plant and equipment, the provision of new and better housing, the development of energy resources and other purposes essential to the nation's wellbeing, rather than in simply financing growing Government debt, which is primarily a consequence of the deep slump.

title: Meany Urges Unions To Uphold Contracts
description: George Meany said yesterday that the New York municipal unions should not violate their contracts because of the city's fiscal problems

title: M.A.C. BONDS RISE; REACTION IS MIXED
description: Bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation rose sharpily in price yesterday as dealers indicated that many investors had been encouraged by news reports of progress in the city's efforts to untangle its fiscal affairs.

title: Ethiopia Renounces Claim To LongDisputed Territory
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 30 (UPI)Ethiopia renounced today her historical claim to the adjoining French Territory of Afars and Issas.

title: FLOUR PRICE IS UP AT GENERAL MILLS
description: General Mills, Inc., one of the nation's largest food processors, announced in Minneapolis yesterday it is raising the price of flour sold in grocery stores and chains by 1.6 cents a pound beginning tomorrow. If stores follow their usual practice, the increase, rounded out to 2 cents a pound will be passed on to the consumer.

title: Quarter at $1.08 a Share
description: The Standard Oil Company of California, the nation's fourth largest oil company, reported yeterday a 22.6 per cent drop in secondquarter profits from the yearago period.

title: SENATE PANEL SEEKS TESTIMONY BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Senate Select Committee on intelligence invited former President Richard M. Nixon today to testify on Central Intelligence Agency operations in Chile between 1970 and 1974.

title: TURKEYAID MOVE BLOCKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Ford Administration's attempt to bring about a new vote to lift the military arms embargo against Turkey ran into a parliamentary impasse in the Senate tonight.

title: McDonald's Profit Up by 25.4% for the Quarter
CHARM AND SKILL IN ADLER'S MUSIC
description: Larry Adler is still traveling light. He strolls out on the floor of the Rainbow Grill, where he is making his first New York nightclub appearance in nine years, with nothing in his hand but a harmonica (just a single harmonica), and proceeds in a casual and ingratiating fashion to build a program that rambles easily from James P. Johnson to Beethoven, from folk songs to Gershwin to Bach. And he does it with such charm and skill thatconsidering the instrument and the materialthere is no sense of either condescension or pretension.

title: Member of Portugal Junta Talks of Hard Repression
description: LISBON, July 30Portugal's security chief, a member of the threeman junta, Warned opponents of the military Government today that they faced repressive measures.

title: Gowon Says He Supports Nigeria's New Government
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 30 (Reuters)  Gen. Yakubu Gowon, who was deposed as Nigeria's head of state yesterday while attending an African leaders' conference here, announced his full support today for his country's new Government.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The Helsinki summit meeting and the declaration that the 35 world leaders gathered there are to sign Friday haye provoked unusually bitter controversy. Critics see the declaration as a ratification of Soviet conquests in Eastern Europe; the signers consider it a small but significant step toward European stability.

title: MAYOR POSTPONES FISCAL PLAN A DAY; TALKS CONTINUING
description: Mayor Beame said last night that he had delayed imposing his action plan  including a wage freeze  until today after Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employes Union citing hope for progress in the negotiations, requested the delay.

title: B. A. Botkin, Folklore Expert, Is Dead
description: Dr. Benjamin Albert Botkin'one of the country's foremost folklorists, died yesterday at his home in CrotononHudson, N.Y. He was 74 years old.

title: Heritage Early Leader in Mackinac Sail
description: RACINE, Wis., July 30 (AP)Heritage, a sleek 60foot yacht, took the early lead in the annual 333mile race on lake Michigan from Chicago to Mackinac Island. The yacht, owned by Don Wildman of Chicago, was about a mile ahead of a cluster of boats that included Fantod, owned by Norman S. Hewitt of the Belmont Yacht Club, and Holland Carper's Incredible and Tortuga. An entry of 236 boats set sail at 1 o'clock today. There will be eight sectional winners in the event.

title: Yacht Race Taken By Kindred Spirit
description: MARION, Mass., July 30A beautiful race, shouted Bob Barton, coowner of Kindred Spirit, to the race committee aboard Captiva as the little black sloop sailed across the finish line in Buzzards Bay this afternoon.

title: Astronauts Leave Hospital And Fly to Marine Station
description: HONOLULU, July 30  The Apollo astronauts, Thomas Stafford, Donald Slayton and Vance Brand, ended their fiveday hospital stay and were flown by helicopter to Kaneohe Marine Corps Air Station for 10 days of convalescence.

title: E.P.A. Bans 2 Pesticides Suspected of Cancer Link
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency announced today a ban on further production and sale by manufacturers of two pesticides widely used in homes, gardens and farms and suspected of causing cancer.

title: House Bars Ford Proposal For Gradual Oil Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 President Ford suffered a major political defeat tonight when the House, of Representatives killed his plan for a gradual rise in oil prices over 39 months.

title: 292 GARBAGE FIRES SET IN CITY IN DAY
description: The Fire Department reported 292 garbage fires throughout the city in the 24hour period ended midnight Tuesday as the Sanitation Department struggled for the 10th day to keep ahead of the garbage buildup with a reduced work force.

title: Bridge:
...Will Contact Begin?
description: There are genuine issues to be resolved through official relations, but perhaps not in advance of them. Restoration of trade has certain attractions to cigar smokers in the first instance, and is inevitable eventually; but some caution is warranted to prevent hardships from disruptions of alternate trade patterns that were encouraged during the years of Cuba's estrangement.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The New York Times yesterday about the acquisition of the Copper Range Company by Amax, Inc., the net income of Amax last year was incorrectly stated. Amax earned $148.4million on revenues of $1.16billion.

title: TAX BILL SUPPORT GROWS IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, July 30The Assembly's Democratic majority agreed today on a package of tax bills designed to raise $111million and complete financing of a $267million restoration of programs cut from the state budget for economy reasons.

title: Carli Plans to Step Down As Italian Bank Governor
description: ROME, July 30 (UPI)Guido Carli, a frequent critic of Government inefficiency and political interference in the Italian economy, announced his resignation today as governor of the Bank of Italy.

title: House Bars Ford Proposal For Gradual Oil Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 President Ford suffered a major political defeat tonight when the House of Representatives killed his plan for a gradual rise in oil prices over 39 months.

title: Crime Figure Convicted For Theft of F.B.I. Files
description: NEWARK, July 30 (UPI)John DiGilio, a reputed Mafia enforcer, and two associates were convinced tonight of conspiracy and stealing Federal Bureau of Investigation files. A third reputed associate was found not guilty.

title: Trial Set in Marine Death
description: CHICAGO, July 30. (AP)One of three United States Marines charged in connections with the death of a Great Lakes Naval Training Center recruit will be tried by courtmartial next Tuesday. Cpl. William T. Mason, 22 years old, of Somerville, Mass., and the other two Marines who will be tried later are charged with assault and battery and a failure to follow the center's regulations. They are accused of beating the recruit, Steven Stawnychy, 18, of White Bear Lake, Mina., while he was in the brig.

title: Meany Criticizes Ford's Record, Calls Him an Ultraconservative
description: CHICAGO, July 30 (UPI)George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., criticized President Ford's record today, terming the President an ultraconservative who believes keeping big business healthy will ultimately mean some crumbs for those on the bottom of the economic ladder.

title: Union Leaders Display Dual Personalities
description: For observers of the city's labor scene there are two Albert Shankers, two Victor Gotbaunts and two Ken McFeeleys.

title: Harlem Fire Kills Woman, 63; 30 Firemen and Girl, 6, Injured
description: A 63yearold woman was killed and her 6yearold granddaughter critically injured yesterday in a fire of undetermined origin that swept five floors of a sevenstory tenement in Harlem.

title: 2 Pesticides Banned
JUNE ORDERS RISE FOR NEW BUILDING
description: Despite a 9 per cent decline in residential building, contracts for new construction totaled $9.3billion in June for an overall contract increase of 13 per cent over the yearago month, the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Service said yesterday.

title: Maheu Says He Recruited Man For C.I.A. in Castro Poison Plot
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Robert A. Maheu, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and former aide to Howard R. Hughes, said today that he had recruited a Mafia figure for the Central Intelligence Agency in a plot to poison Fidel Castro, Premier of Cuba.

title: Music: Legacy Pieces
description: The American Bicentennial, already upon us to the sound of drums and fifes, has brought with it a great deal of pretty awful music resurrected from Victorian piano benches and libraries of postColonial memorabilia. Since, in this giddily patriotic time, there is a danger that such stuff will pass for our true national heritage in music, the Gregg Smith Singers are applying a welcome corrective in their July Festival, which ends tonight with a program of choral works at St. Stephen's Church on West 69th Street.

title: SalesMinded Finns Giving Ford Dinner On an Icebreaker
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 30President Ford is dining tomorrow night aboard a Finnish icebreaker as the guest of Finland's President, Urho Kekkonen.

title: Hayes Against Fed Help to City
description: Alfred Hayes, the retiring president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday that the nation's central banking system should not become involved in helping troubled municipalities such as New York City.
